reviews.review: Great to visit BEWARE of scams. TIP: if you are going to try the Old Town Ham!.. make sure to clearly state you want a SMALL piece or no more than 200g!.. or you WILL be given about 500g and charged about €15!!.. if they give you large piece insist on small or walk away! TIP: keep wallets and purses safe!TIP: don't eat at the restaurants in the square unless you want bad service, poor quality food and expensive price!.. walk down the side streets just a minute or two and enjoy the many good restaurants TIP: go up the tower to get a great view

Great for people watching and lots of great places to eat.. The square is the busiest part of old town with many great places to sit outside, eat, and people watch. A perfect place to enjoy the sights after several hours of sightseeing.

Bloody history on the square. Old Town Square is very important for history of Czech people. History was going over this square. Let use the google for the keywords: defenestrationexecutionastronomical clockfire town hall

The most beautiful Old town square. Very nice place with plenty of hictorical gothic, renaissance and baroque buildings. The most popular odl town hall with calendar-clock each hour starting a spectacular attraction with running apostles located just over against an arcade with small shops., This will be for each tourist visited this nice place a good experience. Simply saying Old town square must be visited while being in Prague.
love it. love old town square, such a variety of building and architecture, lots of space and the trading stalls are always lovely to walk around

MUST SEE NR- ONE IN PRAGUE. Beside the Prague Castle, this is another "must see number one" !!!Do not expect "too much" from the astronimical clock though, it is worth seeing for sure, but takes one minute and that is it !!!

do NOT miss the Old Town Square. spend a few hours every afternoon in the old town square, sipping a drink with friends and grazing on tapas. after a day or two you will start to recognise the regulars.all the bars and restaurants surrounding the square have outdoor dining and drinking in the warmer months, and the food is excellent, drinks are reasonably priced and service is great!!
Beautiful old square. I love the old church in this square, and definitely look out for the astronomical clock. It does get very busy though, so choose your time to go

Full of tourists but still captivating!. What a charming old square full of amazing old buildings as well as The Astronomical Clock which chimes every hour - listen for the rooster at the end! The clock itself is very beautiful and best seen in the day as it has very little lighting at night. Most walking tours (and there are many!) leave from this square.

Old , nice. I liked this old town square, reminded me of being in Italy. Many vendors selling food, crafts, etc. lots of tourists visiting the area. Go to the opera house and buy a ticket to one of the concerts....you'll enjoy it.

Typical tourist area. Tons of tourists, no where to sit. I swear there's not a single bench anywhere in this city. The square is a large open area with lots of people milling around. The astronomical clock is tucked off to one side. You can pick up a city tour here and there is plenty of shopping and restaurants.

Even the tourists cannot destroy so much beauty. Even the crowd of tourists that every day fills the Old Town Square cannot destroy so much beauty! It's wonderful in the morning and when the sunset changes the colours. Great atmosphere

Like Disneyland in July - but with more people. If you visit Prague, you will obviously go to the Old Town Square. It's historical, it's beautiful, it's stunning, and it's filled with more tourists like you than Times Square at New Year's Eve. Not for people who feel uncomfortable in crowds. When you walk from here to the Charles Bridge, you will know how a Salmon fighting upstream.

Plenty to do! . There is plenty of beautiful things to see and do in the Old town square! The astronomical clock puts on a show every hour. There are stalls and plenty or bars/restaurants/shops to occupy you for a whole day!

Beautiful. See old town review as this was written for the Old Square. The square is the ideal starting point to visit other attractions. It is beautiful bus busy with lots of bars and restaurants and especially so on the hour when the Astronomical clock strikes.Lots of booths selling food and drink as well as horse drawn carriage rides

Beautiful open space. Right in the middle of the Old Town is this great open space with many beautiful buildings surrounding it.I visited early before the crowds and pretty much had it to myself and just a few locals on their way to work.Make sure you check out the Prague Meridian close to the statue in the middle and find out a bit more about it.
Beautiful historic place.. Wander around the streets surrounding the aquare.Climb (easy) the tall clock tower.Learn about the history of the place.Great!

Way too many people. This is basically a meeting place for tours. Very disruptive to any attempt for photos or reflection. Best time to visit is late night or early morning. Many food vendors with local foods and many restaurants available for sit down meals.

1st time in Prague . Definitely worth visiting. I would suggest arriving earlier or later in the evening since the crowds can be overwhelming during summer months. Avoid the restaurants around the square they are super crowded. Instead check out the choices on the side streets.

The clock. I waited for the clock to hit the hour to see this much anticipated movement . What met my eyes were these small wooden saints possibly, doing this jig like blessing everyone , and rotating , peeping out of the small slot that had opened on the wall fifth above the large clock . My disadvantage was my inability to get first hand information from a qualified guide , and so for the amount of waiting one has to do to see the short display , it was a let down .What one should marvel though is the thought and science applied a long time ago to make something work so precisely .It's said the clock doesn't stop .

Kaleidoscope of colours and styles. Old Town square is full of life and full of attractions – starting from the famous Astronomical clock and Asian Museum of the National Gallery and ending with numerous cafes, restaurants and unending shops selling souvenirs, Bohemian glass and Czech garnets (for rip-off price). If you want to buy some of these, better turn away from The Old Town square. But even to walk around it will be great fun and pleasure to your eye. The Old town square in Prague is not be missed, but then it is practically impossible to miss it: even walking individually one sooner or later comes to the Square.
Absolutely Lovely!. Went here on my first night and thought it was lovely. There was lots of little market stalls with food and crafts and a light show as well as the Astronomical Clock. Amazing!
Well worth a visit. This is a must for a visit, take in the sights and the sounds of street music, Plenty of street bars to watch the world go by.

Historic. The Old Town Square is steeped in history and culture and a must see while in Prague. By day the Square is full of tourists and street performers as well as traders selling beer and traditional snacks.By night it is much of the same although I felt it was very dark compared to other town squares I have visited.

Buzzing. I've been to Prague a few times now and Old Town Square is always a great place to go, anytime of day. If you find yourself wandering round of an evening, go down to Old Town Square and enjoy some good local food and drink from local stalls in a good atmosphere.

Don't miss it. The clock, the old buildings, the restaurants, and the people watching are not to be missed. We wet there as an afterthought after trooping around the castle area and we were glad we did.

Breathtaking architecture and so much to take in!. I had to stop in my tracks when I entered the Old Town Square for the first time. So many layers of culture to observe: the architecture of the buildings, the statues and stones, the bustle of the people (both tourists and locals), the street performers and the mass gathering to watch the astronomical clock perform on the hour. Grab a mulled wine or a beer and take it all in!

Beautiful and breahtaking square!. Wow, this will knock your socks off! Everywhere you turn is another stunning cathedral, buildings from the 14th through 18th centuries showing a cavalcade of colorful structures with a history of architectural styles through the centuries. Huge but yet quant and cobblestoned, pedestrian only, with fountains galore and lots of good eateries and a couple of great pastry emporiums where you can sit and sip a capuccino and great sweets inside or outside, where in good weather it is a total pleasure. As with most of Europe, you can sit there as long as you like, rest your tired feet and soak it all in.

Big square surrounded by beautiful buildings. Lots of people out and about on a cool October evening. Buildings surrounding the square are beautiful. Lots of restaurants with outdoor seating. Families, couples, young people all mixed together.

Hotbed of activity . This place is amazingly. Surrounded by old building and loads of little bars and food places. Have a beautiful Christmas market in December. Not sure why they can pour themselves a proper beer - seem to all be half full in this town. Still..... this place is a must see
Old Town Square. The heart of old Prague and a must see. The square is surrounded by lovely architectural sites and the tower looms large as a recognizable destination.

Soak up the atmosphere . Just a magical place where can you sit outside in the autumn sunshine, sipping a cool glass of fizz or the local brew whilst a band is playing Dixie music. The sights and smells of performers & street food is a delight to the senses.

Breathtakingly beautiful buildings. You expect Prague to be beautiful but all the buildings were slightly different and intriguing in their own way. Loved it during the day but it came to life when the light faded and all the lights came on.

Spend several days here. We were lucky enough to rent an apartment with views of the Old Town Square and never tired of them in our week there. Great architecture, museums, the astronomical clock, great restaurants (although a bit more expensive than those off the square, still reasonably priced). Also a starting point for a lot of the tours in Prague. Make sure you have your camera with you.

Light festival. Very disappointing as only one building lit up and only tasted about 5 minutes then shortly repeated itself. Not worth the effort going into city to see it although locals loved it, why?If they saw Sydney's vivid they would go beserk.

The most beautiful Old Town Square. The Prague Old Town Square is, for me, the most beautiful one. No other town in the world has so picturesque and large Old Town Square with well preserved old houses, where you can find nowadays attractive restaurants, cafés, hotels, souvenir shops etc. It's very pleasant to have a coffee, lunch or dinner in front of these restaurants, especially in the summer time, and admire many tourists from all over the world, who are passing by.

Heart of Prague. This is perhaps where you should start your Prague trip. The square has impressive historic buildings around it, museums at stones throw distance, multiple street arts and great cafes. The famous astronomical clock is also here. A day or two in Old Town and you can tick off most of top 10 must visit places of Prague
urban delight. stroll through here as you make your way around this walkable city. Much to see including musicians and children playing.

To miss this Square would be ... to miss Prague. Prague is one of the most interesting Capitals in Europe and the Old Town Square is one of the top 5 attractions there...It is the end of an almost perfect line that starts with the Castle, passes over the Charles Bridge and continues in the Old Town (or the other way around). Yes, like the Charles Bridge it will probably be overcrowded between June and September, and no it might not be as colorful as the Piazza San Marco in Venezia or special as other squares like Times Square, Piccadilly Circus, La Concorde which are of course of really different styles ... But it is the center of so many different possibilities for you to enjoy Prague: the old streets, the so many pubs, restaurants and eateries, everything revolves around this Square ..So since you are there ... Enjoy it ... ...As I wrote in my title ... to miss this Square would be ... to miss sort of ... Prague

Another "must" if you are visiting Prague.. This square is the centre of Prague's tourist areas. There are a number of restaurants around the edge and the Astronomical Clock is in the centre. There are numerous shops in the vicinity and also other tourist attractions and churches/cathedrals. There are entertainers and people renting out Segways - I was dying to have a go but though that I would run amok if I could not control it. The whole area is pedestrianised.
Must visit and Happening Place!!. There are so many things going around. You are amazed to see all of it. Wonderful and Enthusiastic crowd all happy and enjoying :)

An amazing city, with so much. The Old Town Square was very close to my hotel and I went through it everyday. There was always something of interest. It is a good place to eat, with both restaurants and stalls with all kinds of local food produce. For a few days there was some kind of fair with stalls selling various goods as well as entertainment. The Square is fringed with shops, including a confectionary place which has a small museum and has demonstrations (with free tastings) of making chocolate. It also sells a greater variety of sweets than I have ever seen. Vendors sell tickets for tours, or hire our segways. There are several old churches and one has animated figures every hour. It is well worth a visit while in Prague even if you are not staying in the area. It is also central to the shopping area which has a wide range of goods, including crystal and glassware as well as other notable local manufactured goods.
Must see this. What a beautiful place and there's so much to see you need 5days to get around it all and there thousands of bars and resturants to eat&drink
Buzzing!. Lots going on here. Worth waiting to see the clock tower strike on the hour. Good pubs and restaurants around the square.
Buzzing. We enjoyed the buzz here. Street performers, shops, statue and loads of people. It was great to soak up the atmosphere.
the principale place to visit in prague. a unique place unavoidable to visitI spend each to enjoy the activities, musician groups and building.

Excellent atmosphere day and night. We stayed in a hotel right on the square and we enjoyed the early morning scene when it was quiet as well as the chaotic afternoon when thousands of tourists were there. There are always some entertainers in the square keeping the tourists amused. The night scene was very nice with all the buildings lighted. We enjoyed walking around the area after dinner each night.

Really nice day and night. It feels like you have gone back in time. Love the historic feel of Old Town Square as well as the entire city. The old clock is here. There are plenty of restaurants as well. When i went there was a jousting show with horses. It's nice during the day as well as at night.

Old Town Square. One of our favorite locations to go each day, grab something to eat, shop as you walk, try new foods, have a drink, or visit a Starbucks for a Lathe! We enjoyed watching the people of all shapes & sizes, dress they wear, hair styles, body piercing, shoes, and more. An easy visit on your way to the square or Charles bridge! Go & have a terrific time!

A Must Visit with Hordes of Tourists. Old Town Square is simply amazing. Not the statue of Jon Hus, the Protestant Reformer, in the square. Though nominally catholic, Czechs regard him as a national hero.You will also want to see the astronomical clock, although the hourly "show" can be disappointing.I would not recommend eating in any of the restaurants here since they tend to be pricey and touristy.Enjoy the Square - you are in Prague!

It looks like a film set, but its real!. Its incredible to wander the streets of Old Town as it never ceases to surprise you. Every building is so very old with their own identity by colour, architecture, doorways and finishes! Its also endless and kind of fun to go off tourist track. I felt so safe here as there are thousands of tourists! Enjoy - it is truly beautiful.

Favourite . Old town square is an amazingly romantic place. At night the beautiful Church of Tyn is lit up giving the whole square a lovely romantic feeling. The amount of beautifully decorated facades in many different building styles are very interesting. The astronomers clock and old town hall are amazing.
Late summer break. Amazing mixture of the New & Old. The centre is busy seemingly drawing people from all around the globe. You feel very safe and there is virtually zero litter.

Absolutely Beautiful. Although very lively almost all of the time (or so it seems when I was there) it is one of the most beautiful places I have visited. The hustle and bustle of the crowds - most of them coming to watch the clock hit the hour - make the experience!

Crowded square with lots of interesting things to see. Love to explore the shops around the square! Didn't realised the clock tower was one of the highlight until seeing everyone was surrounding the site waiting for the clock to animate. Although nothing much to boast about but it is quite ok to stop by and have a glimpse at it. There are lots of interesting food/snacks around that is really nice to try with.

Fun Place. From bubble blowers to Segway hawkers, this place was jumping with activity even in the cold windy and rainy weather we had the entire stay in Prague. There are many outdoor cafes, some with heaters, and all with plenty of beer flowing. The action is non-stop and there is much to see so make this a must-see when you are in town.
Busy but lovely. Lovely to be here. Kids having a blast with the bubble maker man, and running around carefully watching their icecreams. A plaza like any other. And i liked it, like any other!

A focal point of Prague. You must visit this central point of Prague. eating and drinking around the square although good can be more expensive than lesser areas. careful you do not get run over by a Segway.

Busy at Times but Beautiful. Visited the Square a couple of times on my visit to Prague. Such an old-World feel to this Square, so much to see and do. Great place to relax and have a beer. Wish I didn't have acrophobia because the photo from the top of the Old Town Hall is spectacular. Did not visit at night but the square is very safe during the day, nobody bothers you. There is a very helpful Tourist Information office right near the Old Town Hall.

Old town museum. This is the very center and the most beautiful part of Prague. Just sit somewhere at the center of the square (around Jan Hus monument) and admire the 360' surroundings.The Town Hall with astronomical clock, the Gothic Tynn Cathedral, Baroque St. Nicholas, astonishing houses in different styles,.... will fill your soul.Don't forget to repeat at night time,

Beautiful city square with many attractions and restaurants . The square is very large with many, many attractions. There are several large churches - active and one turned into a concert hall. The old city hall has a tower with spectacular views and a very old mechanical clock with a small show every hour. There are statues in and around the square. There are museums for art and other. There are many indoor/ outdoor restaurants. This is a major and must attraction.
Very traditionnal area. The site is nice vibrant lots of activities can be done very good restaurants. It is mainly good for eating and relaxing but a reak cultural site.
Quaint . A lovely old square with lots of drinking and eating places. Busy, but no one bothers you. Would be beautiful when the Christmas markets are in full flow.

Great place for people watching. This is a beautiful square so recommend you take the weight off your aching feet and enjoy a beer at one of the pavement bars or restaurants. Lots of food stalls available in the square but beware the ham cooking on the bone over wood is delicious but they cut a massive piece off and it is priced by the 100g

Beautiful. Be wary of food stalls. The square is stunning - Do not buy from the wooden foid stalls the ham spit and potato/bacon and cabbage looks enticing and the menu looks cheap but its in small writing and is not in english - it turns out you pay by the weight which (they add two slices of bread to add to to the weight - we didnt realise until we paid and got charged an arm and a leg - the food was also cold.. Was difficult to converse with the servers (they played ignoramt and were very unresponsive when challenged) Really spoilt my afternoon and was dissapointed - want to warn everyone!

Beautiful Buildings. Everywhere you look in Prague old town, you can't help but fall in love with the gothic buildings and the city in general.My 3rd visit here and everytime I discover something new.It is a must when visiting Prague.

Great day out for all the family. Lot's of choice for places to eat and sites to see, the astronomical clock is brilliant, as is the Tyn Church. I have returned for many years, there is never a dull momement in the square.

Lively !. This was the buzziest part of the town. People were gathered here relaxing , roaming , playing games and playing music . The architecture of Prague anyhow is so beautiful. We came here in the day and again on our last evening in Prague as well
Old Town Square. Lots of walking, shopping is the best part. I'm not sure if The Old Town and the Old Town Square is one and the same.

A great place to walk and take in the sights. There are lots of shops and restaurants as well as beautiful churches with wonder classical music concerts in the evening in churches. We attended a concert at the spectacular St. Nicholas Church.

Must See Area of Prague. Take plenty of time--and a good map--to explore Old Town. So many buildings, alleyways, shops, and cafes are there to explore--little nooks that lead to wonderful surprises. So much history is based in this area that a guide book is recommended to experience and appreciate it all.
Great atmosphere. Soak in the atmosphere of old town Prague. Simply sit in a cafe and watch the world go by or engage in the many activities occurring in the square. Great experience.
City break. Really pretty square with so much going on, weddings, artists, architecture, well worth a visit especially to sit and watch the Czech world go by.

Relax and watch the world go by. A lovely venue, to sit in one of the bars, have a drink, alcoholic, chocolate or coffee and just watch the world pass you by.
There are people performing in the square to watch

Beautiful place; Way too crowded and commercial. This was the center of activity in the Prague of past. When we were there in July, however, the place was overwhelmed with huge tourist groups, scam artists, guides, Segway tours, religious groups, etc. I'm not saying you shouldn't visit it but you should know what you are getting into, especially at busy times of the year. Least crowded and most pleasant early in the morning. Prague has many other beautiful areas that are less way less touristy.

Wonderful city. Prague is truly one of the worlds great cities. It's exquisite and very old architecture shows care and consideration from bygone times. The mechanical clock in the square is definitely worth waiting for. The Mechanical genius shown in the clock is something quite spectacular for its time. Bravo!
Amazing. Beautiful square in the heart of Prague. Nice to walk around, grab a beer and a slice of ham, and just hang out.
Lovely Old Square with the Astrological Clock. Hordes of tourists flock to this area during the day, so be prepared for the crowds. We enjoyed seeing the diversity of the architecture.
Relax and enjoy. This is a place to sit and relax,do a bit of people watching. There are all sorts. There are bars and street entertainers and also the famous clock.

Very busy. I was last in Prague 15 years ago, then it was an adventure and something new. In most respects Prague has not changes and was just how I remember it but the number of visitors and the proliferation of souvenir, restaurants and places of entertainment have increased exponentially, not all of these are good. Prague is a reasonably sized city but the centre is far more commercialised and tourist orientated than I remember. Last time I was here there were groups of people watching the clock strike the hour. This time the crowd would not have embarrassed a division one football team – It’s only a clock!! Prague is a victim of its own success and although there is much to see and do the tourist areas are in danger of becoming the Blackpool of eastern Europe.
History. If you want to roam around here do it with a tour because you will not get the full history and stories of what happened here. Love it.

Thriving. Just an amazing place to sit and enjoy lunch or a beer and watch the world go by.
So much going on; guided tours on foot or on Segway, street entertainers, artists you name it!
Don't leave Prague without at least trying one of the street cafes. Particularly good when the sun shines.

Beautiful place . Love this romantic country so much to do so many places to eat
Beautiful place to be
Loved the library with the book collection looks like u can drop for miles
It's a mirror image

Beautiful, hot spot for action and relaxation.. You have it all in this square, seasonal food venders, bars and restaurant who mostly have out door undercover seating areas with gas heaters and blankets making cosy beer drinking. The astronomical clock is situated here, fascinating to look at, visit to the top to see the inner workings and or sit and drink Czech beer whilst you see a massive crowd appear and disappear in front of the clock for it's hourly performance.

Nice old buildings. The square is surrounded by nice old buildings and worth a visit. Lots of restaurants but a bit pricey. Worth a visit. Beware of the money exchange offices located around the square as some give a very bad exchange rate.
Beautiful. Gorgeous to look at, just beware of the restaurants in the immediate square as they're quite overpriced. Explore the backstreets for fabulous food & beer.

Not to be missed! Best in Prague. This is the most interesting and unique square in Prague and should not be missed. Take good walking shoes as it is all cobblestones. But the architecture is worth seeing, lots of small restaurants around the square to have a small meal or a coffee if you wish. Very enjoyable.
Extremely overcrowded. Good (but expensive) restaurants, nice historical sightseeing and all year attractions for everybody.
Very nice. Tours from here, nice buildings, beware of rate of exchange on exchange houses they may not very clear about commision.

People Watching centre. The square is quite large and provides exits to other areas of Old Prague such as Charles Bridge, Jewish Town, Powder Tower and Municipal House. The surrounding streets have lots of shops and restaurants and bars. The square itself is a mecca for tourists and locals alike. On the hour, the crowd swells in from of the Old Town Hall with its famous clock to watch the mechanism and its rotating figures. Bordering the square is any number of restaurants and bars. The Tyn church is also a favourite attraction that borders the square. This is a must when visiting Prague to get the full flavour of the city.

Must see. The first time I went to Prague I was excited by the architecture, because any building along the way to the Old Town Square would be a national treasure in California. But my companion kept pushing me along saying, "You ain't seen nothing yet." He was right, when we got to the Old Town Square I was dazzled by the architecture and then by the history.

What Energy!. Love the energy in this place regardless of time of day. The night views are amazing- looks like Disneyland castles were inspired after the architecture in Prague or just eastern european for that matter.

Big and busy. The area around the clock gets exceptionally crowded on the hour when the figures appear. The centre of the square provides a panoramic view of all the surrounding buildings. Most old town walking tours start from around the square. Photos of brides and grooms posing in wedding attire in Horse and Carriages could be seen every time we went into the square. The world and his wife seem to be there every day.

full of restaurants and historical buildings. A typical old town city center square. This one offers great people watch and very good shopping.There are a ton of outdoor restaurants all good and very reasonable. From here you can visit many sites in the city centre. A great beginning or ending to a day in prague
CLOCK ALONE WORTH THE VISIT. Lovely square but a 12:00 AM the astronomical clock is the centerof attraction and worth seeing and watching its performance.

Amazing Square!. Old Town Square is a must see when visiting Prague, featuring the famous astronomical clock that puts on a display every o'clock to symbolise the hour. When it gets close the the hour hundreds of people gather around the clock to watch it so if you are going to see this get there about 20 to to get a good spot.From this Square you can easily access Jewish Town, Power Tower and Charles Bridge. The bars around the square, as you can imagine, are more pricey than other places in Prague but not so expensive that i would say to avoid them. If you don't want a sit down meal, behind the clock are stalls serving hot food, snacks and beer.The whole Square is full of amazing architecture and grandiose buildings.
Beautiful!. Lots of tourists here but still found it very relaxing & you could spend an entire day here - drinking, eating & shopping.

Colorful & beautiful. The old town square is an amazing place where you can shop for souvenirs and for the famous Czech crystals, also you can eat at vast variety of restaurants, take a photo of the astronomical clock, may be attend a performance or a concert in the churches and at the end of the day after sunset you can just sit to relax your feet and may be watch some street art. It is very near to the Jewish quarter so you can take a walk there, also Charles bridge is very close. It is really very amusing to be there.

Too Crowded. Way to crowded, we went first day afternoon when we were in Prague. too many people, was just too hard for us to take a good picture of the historic building. Then we leave after a quick browsing. Then on second day, wife told me she wanted to return again at night hopefully crowd would lesser. We were there around 10 p.m, to my surprise, the crowd is same like we saw in the afternoon. we have no choice but to wait, if you wanted to take a good picture. Mind you, in old town square, people would not stop passing through at front of your camera lens although you have already speak "ready..1..2..3" nobody would stop aside to wait for your photo shoot moment.

Cheque Point Money changer rip off beware !. The A Clock is a treasure , but the Cheque Point money changer that shares the square rip you off.I got 40% less than I got just round the corner 2 hours later . Do your self a favour , avoid this tourist trap and spend 5 minutes to walk down the road . I could have fed the family for 2 days on what these guys ripped me off on .
Gorgeous . Visited at night in pouring rain and the place was still amazing. Definitely worth a visit going back tomorrow to see it in the daylight

Great people-watching. There are lots to do around Old Town Square, shopping, dining, studying the architecture of buildings, observing street entertainers, and watching international tour groups parading through the square. You must try a trdelnik sold at one of the pop-up cafes surrounding the square. It's like funnel cake, but baked in a cone shape, not fried, and filled with ice cream or Nutella. Vendors will try to sell you tours; an interesting one seems to be the Segway Tour, as we saw several groups going through on Segways.

Pretty place. I love this plaza, great location to spend your day, tourist spots are all around. There are a lot of restaurants but I will suggest you to look at trip advisor before you go to the restaurants, as I heard from a local that those restaurants food are usually for tourists, and from my own experience, those kiosk and restaurants are expensive, foods are not particularly good and the service are poor. Good place for pictures and church visit! I love this place a lot:)

Absolute must see. Can't visit Prague without coming to old town and visiting the square! Highlights from here included a free walking tour and climbing the old town hall tower. Only downside, the crowds of people...if it weren't for the zillions of people, this would be a 5 star attraction.

Try to ignore the crowds.... The Old Town Square is at the very heart of this beautiful city, and despite the hoards of tourists, the irritating Segways flitting around, and the people bumping into you whilst obsessed with their selfie sticks, it's obviously a must see. If you can, get there really early to fully appreciate the magnificence of the architecture. Otherwise, grab a seat at on eof the bars surrounding the Square and enjoy some people watching. Sure, beer here is twice the price of bars a few hundred metres away, (but still cheap to UK eyes) but it's a worthwhile experience.

Spectacular, but busy. As we went on a Saturday on our way to finding a restaurant for lunch we probably hit this place at the worst possible time: it was heaving with people.There are many places to eat around here, but it is spoiled somewhat by the large number of touts selling tours either by Segway, bus or vintage car. If they were corralled somewhere else then visiting the square would be a nicer experience.
Atmosphere. Such a lovely open space, with nothing, but everything. Sit in a bar and watch the world go by...I did not want to leave

Square of delight. . It's the hub of the historic city and is surrounded by amazing buildings and restaurants/bars. You should also note that it's the most expensive part of Prague for food and drink but better options can be found a few streets back.

Saturday morning stroll. What better way to start the weekend than wandering around the Old Town Square... Although it was the beginning of autumn, the twelveth century square was filled with tourists, cameras at the ready, all snapping away at the lovely architecture, and pastel shaded buildings surrounding the area, and the church steeples towering high above. Stop and enjoy a coffee, or a beer, at one of the many restaurants and watch the world go by. So much history here!

Rivals the best of Europe. This square has been magnificently restored to its historical splendour. Come very early in the morning before the crowds arrive and soak in its richness while languidly sipping coffee in one of its many cafes. Return for a magical late night visit and see it illuminated and resplendent.
A must see. A must see in Praha but get there early to avoid the massive crowds. Lots of food vendors and restaurants to choose from and a great place to people watch.

Stunning and busy. My friends and myself visited Prague for a chilled hen weekend and were not disappointed. We stayed relatively close to the city centre and always found ourselves popping back to the Old Town Square for a choice of restaurants and there was always something going on.

The Must-See in Prague. The Old Town Square exemplifies the entire city. Fortunately, Prague was lightly bombed during WWII, so most of the buildings, some from the thirteen hundreds, are still standing and well preserved. A wonderful example are the churches and buildings around the square. I suggest that you arrive there about 15 minutes prior to the hour so you can view the oldest working astrological clock do its thing on the hour. It is a fascinating contraption. Just follow the crowd. Otherwise, spend some time in the cafes on the perimeter of the square and relax in the arms of history.
Great place to spend some time. Very busy. Check out eateries and pubs away from square. Loads of street entertainers. Must see area.
Crazy busy.. Every direction is a photo op. Day or nite are both beautiful. Thousands of tourists. Beautiful famous clock but do not wait for the hour display.

A must see in Prague. Everyone going to Prague has to take in the sights and sounds of this square in the daytime and at night. Surrounded by restaurants and some hotels it is the centerpiece of tourists in Prague.

A very happening place. The ambience in the daytime and at night is different. During the day, street performers perform music or acts on the square. During the night, the square was quiet. I spent my last night quietly in the square. I was sitting on a bench in front of Jan Hus Memorial, drinking a can of beer, and enjoying the night. I like the warm and soft lighting. I like the quietness. I love everything in Prague!

Gorgeous square - well worth it.. There is so much history and beauty in the Old Town Square. From the statue of Jan Huss to the clock tower and crosses marked at the church for the Christian martyrs. Beauty everywhere and fun food.

Very mediaeval with beautiful buildings.. Must see the old Town Hall with its tower and astronomical clock, and the Church of our Lady before Tyn. Can also climb the townhall tower, for wonderful views.
Part of the Rick Steves audio guide walk. Vibrant meeting point for many people. A large open area with lots to see and do. We were passing through so did not try any food outlets
Great Old Square. We sat in the square a lot having a wine or beer. Lots of activity and prices were OK. Good people watching too.

Lively view of the city. We stayed at a hotel in this square (Old Town Square Hotel) and spent a lot of time here. It is very lively with musicians playing most of the day anything ranging from a group of 4 or 5 musicians to a single piano player. It was very nice to sit at one of the outdoor cafes and listen to the music and watch people. If you can stay near this location it would be highly worth it. It is close to the Jewish district and shopping as well.
Nice buildings and resturants . Lovely old square again very busy. Clock tower lovely didn't see the famous figures though?. Where comfy shoes so much walking all old back streets
great for people watching. Stunning scenery all around.Plenty cafes, bars & street food for all.Street entertainment is great.Enchanting when dark.

Beautiful square especially in early morning. The old town square was beautiful, surrounded on 4 sides by gorgeous historical buildings. When going in the early morning while it was still quiet, it was especially beautiful.

The best tip for Prgaue visit. just take an hour without running anywhere, without planning where to go, and simply sit in the main square, maybe with a hotdog or something else (but not inside of the restaurants) and just watch this amazing beautiful square, the Astronomic clock, the statue, the almost taking from a fairytale towers and the people. .never done it before, but it was amazing.
Nice place to sit and look at people. Nice atmorphere and lots of people walking and sitting in the terraces. Beautiful buildings around the square.

Centre of Prague tourist area.. So much to see and enjoy, everywhere you look there is history. The buildings which surround the square have different fascia's which reflect the history through the years.Stand and watch the astronomical clock but please keep your valuables close as there are many people ready to relieve you of them and you won't even know until it's too late!!!There are many restaurants and bars where you can sit outside and enjoy the atmosphere and of course people watching a must. However you will pay more and just walking five minutes away from the main area you will find cheaper places with just as much enjoyment.
Beauty. Great place to sit and have a drink or dinner and enjoy the heart of this great city. You can feel the history and this area has been well preserved.
OLD TOWN SQUARE, PRAGUE. Beautiful historic square.Too bad there are so many touristsAll the surrounding buildings are amazing.Try to ignore the tourists and watch your wallet!!

Be carefull. It's a great place But please be carefull of pick pockets scams bullies and never go into a club if u r invited normally will cost you loads of money. Stay out of the Irish bar in in old sq bully guy and monkeys there fill sorry for the owners !! On the up horse tour great as ate most other things there James Dean ba.r 80s bar. cafe cafe. Value for money if u look around enjoy
excellent views and old world charm.... great old worldly charm all over..walk aimlessly, take pictures and selfies along side old structures...a nice evening to be spent here...

Most popular spot!. This is the main spot in the old town to visit. You can find too much crowd here. You can also find souvenir shops , restaurants and cafe in this area. A must visit place in Prague.

Amazing architecture. This is a must-see! What a beautiful place to visit. The architecture in this city is amazing. Prices in bars and restaurants are more expensive, but you are paying for the view - and it's worth it.

Gypsies, Tramps and Thieves. Old Town Square is the centre of the tourist universe in Prague and attracts the most eclectic of people. Keep your valuables close to you and enjoy the passing parade of locals and visitors. Every twilight we sat with a glass of wine and enjoyed the kaleidoscope of humanity and celebrated diversity.
Amazing for Christmas markets. We visited Prague in December and the square was filled with Christmas markets and had an amazing atmosphere. Definietly recommend going during this time.

Beautiful!!. We walked through the square every day to get to our tourist attractions. It is absolutely beautiful with lots of places to eat, shop, and take beautiful scenic pictures. Every street connected to the square (which is central) takes you to new, amazing places!

All mediveal history in one square. I strongly recommend to visit and spend half a day. You can see gothic, reneissance, barroque and also younger styles of buildings. There is an extraordinary clock with hourly show. Many restaurants to sit down and taste the best beer - Pilsner Urquell. Many shops to buy famous Czech glass products.Atmosphere is great. Just three minutes to get to famous Charles Bridge over Vltava.Must see !!!

Astronomical clock is a must see. Old town square is a wonderful place to visit, lots of old buildings and architecture to admire, cafes and restaurants or just sit on the benches in the sunshine and people watch. The astronomical clock is a must see, it chimes every hour on the hour with moving parts!

super! explore the buildings inside and out.. Astronomical clock fun to watch. Be mindful of people around you and sticky fingers as people gather. Amazing clock and great photography in the area. The Munich Germany town clock gives the most amazing show that last a while. This clock goes quick, so be on time.
History of an beautiful city. To see the best of Prague, take a walking guide tour with Parvel personal walking tours, you will not regret this. The very best tour we have ever been on
A bustling town square.. We stayed very close by and enjoyed walking to and walking by Old Town Square daily while we were in Prague. Lovely statuary and the clock is wonderful to see.

Pleasant time. We were here in July and it was incredibly busy with very friendly locals and visitors. We spent ages enjoying the atmosphereand the awesome buildings surrounding the square. Lots of shops to browse in the side streets and restaurants and cafes packed with people. A very pleasant couple of hours in a great old town centre.

You must visit this central site. Shops, street theaters, coffee shops and more. The square is the central site for tourists in Prague. Visit by day and come back at night,the square magically changes. Safe to wonder around at all hours

Busy Busy Busy. This is a must see for any traveller, the surrounding streets are filled with restaurants, cafes, bars, shops and museums as is the square. The architecture is breath taking and plenty of things to see and do, the astronomical clock is nice especially lit up at night. The area is steeped in history. The area is also busy at all times filled with street entertainers, guided tours and tourists as well as the odd wedding.
always nice. pleasant people watching, relaxing, Segway folks and spray painted "performers" are a bit over-played
fantastic atmosphere. fantastic place just to walk about or sit in a bar and people watch plenty going on just a lovelt square in the hub of prague

History and a bit of trouble!. What a cool old square! I loved walking the cobbled streets and getting lost amongst the huge old buildings, each with their own history to share. I did a walking tour through the square after I had already explored it myself, which was good to get a different perspective and get an idea of the statues and who eh were etc. I say trouble because on the day I went solo here, there was an anti-terrorist demonstration that really scared a few people. There were gun shots fired, people screaming and running and men in ISIS garb with a flag resembling the group and no one to speak English and explain to tourists that it was in fact a demonstration and not a real terror attack. That spoilt my opinion of the square on the day but it has since been improved and is a beautiful place to "Czech out" :)

Lots to do and see. Very fun area, lots of shops and restaurants around, some with rooftops. Funniest part if you go is to wait and see how disappointed crowds get when the astronomical clock goes off and it's underwhelming.

Activity Abounds in this Main Square. Every old European city has a square and Prague is no exception. This beautiful cobblestone area is surrounded by lovely buildings, churches, shops, cafés and, of course, the astronomical clock. It is always filled with people, street artists and activity. The day we were there just happened to mark 700 years of the coronation of their king so there was a re-enactment of that event complete with a parade, jousting matches and horse drawn carriage rides! What fun!

Architect and History Delight. The Old Town Square is breathtaking especially at night!! The gothic architect and history is abundant in this beautiful city. I have enjoyed it so much that I would love to live here!

Busy and Vibrant . The square is always vibrant and full of tourists. A lot of activities and attractions take place throughout the day and night along with beautiful buildings all around and famous restaurants. A must-see to everyone who visits Prague.
Must see. Central square in old town. Huge one. Something is always happening here. Beside enjoying in architecture you can also enjoy taking a break in one of the cafés.

Major landmarks. It is the heart of Prague. Look out for The Old Town Hall complex comprises a 70 m tall tower, Powder Tower and three adjoining buildings. Then focus on the biggest attraction, Astronomical Clock where wooden statues of the 12 Apostles parade every hour. You should see the huge crowd that gather there every hour , just waiting for the moment. There are many cafes/ restaurants and souvenir shops to visit.

Crowded But Worth It. We walked to the Square on our first afternoon in Prague. On our way, we saw dozens of small shops and restaurants, containing everything from Starbucks to crystal to souvenirs. The Square itself was heaving with people - many of them Czechs! It really was fantastic with wonderful architecture so we found ourselves a seat at an outdoor restaurant (many to choose from), ordered a couple of drinks, and waited for the Astronomical Clock to do its stuff - we had an excellent view. I highly recommend a walk through this square.

Loved the activities in "Old Town Square". Loved the Bubble man - he was so accommodating. This was the first time I had seen someone do all these bubbles - then later we saw them in some of the streets. Typical gold painted statues and musicians but the Bubble guy was FUN!

Beautiful at any time of the day…!. A must tourist attraction while visiting Prague. It is walking distance to major attractions in Prague. Can take city tours for many companies (Martin Tour, Prague tours, etc). Many shops and restaurants. I recommend to the the city tour first and then, can find out all the tourist attraction around the area, churches, synagogues, palaces, Charles Bridges, etc.
Great buildings, plenty of eating places. This square was amazing, the buildings and architecture is stunning. it is very busy, but we always felt safe

The real essence of Prague. I don't think you will ever find the right time of day to visit the square as it is always packed, being basically the epicentre of the old town, but don't let that put you off.My Wife and I spent 4 days in Prague, and passed through the square on many occasions and it was always busy. Nevertheless, try and find time to just sit and soak up the atmosphere, and make sure you cover the whole square as there is so much to see. There are various forms of street entertainers, food stalls, horse drawn carriage rides, and buskers, and despite the hubbub it always felt safe as there is a plenty of police presence. A must is obviously the astronomical clock, but try and make time to go to the top of the Old Town Hall itself, (there is a lift), where the views are just amazing.Make this your starting point of your stay in Prague,and you won't go far wrong, as you can certainly get your bearings of the city better once you have visited here.
Photo opportunity !. Amazing buildings with statues all around the roofs and murals on walls. Buskers playing while we were there, all adding to the atmosphere. Would recommend a visit
Don't Miss the Astronomical clock at the top of the hour. Very rich historical buildings and streets. Crowds of Tourists from all over the world. Many Cafes to sit and relax.

Enjoy your visit! . I have mixed feelings about the square. It's big and beautiful and interesting. Definitely join the crowd at the Astronomical Clock, gaze at the nearby architecture and feel the energy of those around you. There's a helpful Tourist Information bureau along the square. We were there on a sunny mid September day and the square was packed with tourists and perhaps a few locals. Gosh it was busy!We bought a dessert treat from a vendor that we realized later was rather expensive and not worth the calories. We stopped at a souvenir shop and bought a small trinket for a collector friend. It felt like we were such a bother. Usually being a tourist is so much fun but sometimes it's not. It was our first day in Prague and I felt mildly disappointed. We were there for five days and things improved and we loved the Old Town area. We often found ourselves at the Square and often because we'd become lost in the maze of winding streets. I think all roads lead to the Square! We avoided the food vendors and put off buying any more souvenirs until our last day. Prague is a beautiful and vibrant city! We loved being there. The Old Town Square is the heart of it all and definitely worth a visit.

Busy. The old town square was very busy when we arrived and there was a lot of seller trying to get you to do there stuff when all you wanted to do was take in the architecture and views it is a very lovely place to visit.

Lots of Tourists, but some must see buildings and the Clock. This area is very crowed in nice weather, but it has a fun energy of sidewalk cafes, street performers and museums. Some of the architecture is amazing.. be sure to explore all the windy streets around it also!

Stunning ! . Our first visit to Prague. Old Town Square has the wow factor the first time you walk into it, many fantastic buildings of gothic style and architectural interest dating back to the 14th century. Worth a visit day and night. A lovely atmosphere with many nationalities and age ranges enjoying the experience

Amazing How the Exciting. The Old Town Square is the place where all tourists headed to on their sightseeing. Whether it is the meeting place of group tour as well as individual free walking tour, or the path of most escorted tour, everyone run into each other here in the Old Town Square. In addition, almost all visitors will be gathered around the Astronomical Clock to the hour in order to watch the show. Yes, it is a business place in this huge square.

Place popular and packed with tourists. Anyone interested in street food found there a wide range of street stalls offering all kinds of dishes, I recommend the sausages. There are also souvenir stalls, and guided tours of local guides.
old town square. Beautiful buildings. Lots of shopping and restaurants. The beautiful old astronomical clock is something to see. You can go to the top of the tower for wonderful views.
Romantic place. If you want to spend some romantic times in Prague you have to go there. Especially in Christmas time is it here Magical!!

Well worth the effort. I cannot walk very far, a few blocks maximum, and the Old Town Square was a perfect immersion experience well within my tolerance. Do note, though, that even in mid-September it was swarming with tourists, tours, touts and, no doubt, assorted malefactors.To start with an overview, spend a bit of tome in the middle of the square anf just look. An amazing variety of architectural styles are visible in and around the plaza, from romanesque to high gothic through renaissance, baroque and so on.The Jan Huss memorial, huge in the center of the open space, dominates. Read the three paragraphs your travel book has about him and his movement, a proto-protestant immensely memorialized in this very Roman Catholic country, which burned him at the stake for his pains.In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, this section of Prague was a gathering place for artists, writers, scientists and musicians. Many of them hung out around the Old Town Square. Note particularly the building where Einstein gathered with fellow student friends to puzzle out the foundations of modern physics.The astronomical clock and its various displays, located just to the side of the remaining bit of the old town hall, is too astonishing for a brief review. Read about it in your travel guide, which should have a photograph near the text; understanding requres a bit of study. If spectacle is all you want, be there with the others in their thousands at noon for the show: mechanical figures, all highly symbolic, doing their assorted things. The clockworks are many hundreds of years old, and with repair and maintenance, remain operative to this day.The best quality garnet shops in the city are just off the Square. We looked at the sights, perused garnets and moldavite, bought, and sank gratefully into chairs for lunch at Ristorante Anna, a nice and moderately priced spot on the street with the garnet shops.Old Prague in a conveniently packaged stop; a must-see.

Must see !. This is most beautiful square in Prague !! There you can see Old Town Hall and Astronomical clock. Try perfect czech beer. But if you want to eat and drink and don't spend much money go in side streets. You will pay less money for everything !
Historical square. Amazing to stand in this square early in the morning or late in the evening. It is much less crowed and the buildings just glow in the quiet light.
stunning , lively , wonderful. this is one of my top beautiful square in Europe, as its area is so big and lively, very beautiful cathedral and signature attraction. a must see when visit Praha .

A Prague must-see. A group of 12 mid-20 guys on a stag do dawned up Pragues Old Town Square on a mild, sunny Saturday afternoon. We had an amazing time. Not so sure about everyone else around us... All joking aside, it's absolutely beautiful. Great architecture, lovely people and is just as much of a sight to see at night time. It's great to see, but that's all there was to do (except for cafes, pubs etc.). See it and then move onto something else I suppose. We weren't there for the sights as you can imagine, but we appreciated it all the same. If you're in Prague, you may as well go to Old Town Square.
Amazing. Prague is an excellent place to visit. Extremely nice and very good place to visit on foot. Food is marvelous and very nice places to visit.
Always pretty. We been there at the morning, in the middle of the day and at night, at sun and rain it always looks amazing, very romantic and infinity ways to go and buildings tonsee

Busy but Beautiful. Such lovely buildings surrounding the square, lovely to walk through. Prague is very touristy during the summer months so be aware of how busy it will be, but don't let it put you off.
Lovely. Sit back and enjoy the wonderful views. It's very relaxing watching people enjoy it. Just sit and have a coffee or a drink, definitely a place to visit.
Could be better. Essentially a lovely square with some great architecture above first floor level. The cafes and bars, on the whole, are cheap and nasty. The square deserves better.

Beautiful square, prepare for the crowds. The square is surrounded with beautiful buildings and there is a huge statue in the middle. The draw of the crowds is the Astronimical Clock. I had read there were crowds, but didn't expect wall to wall people, so be prepared. A must see in Prague.

Bringing back in time. Spent a Saturday morning at the Old Town Square . A lively filled square with music, food vendors, street entertainment, shops and great restaurants. A place you felt welcomed and filled with life.Like the old days when people looked forward to meeting up with neighbors and family members.

Biggest square in all of Europe!. Outstanding place for the day! It is the biggest square in all of Europe and a must see! Watch out at night for all the gents trying to get you in the gentleman clubs!
nice!. a very nice and beautiful place to have a coffee and an ice cream! lots of restaurants around as well.

The highlight of my trip to Europe!. My wife and I and two other couples (from Iowa) spent 10 days in Europe. The 1st 7 days were on the Emerald Sun, one of the river boats of the Emerald Waterways fleet, going down the Danube from Nuremberg to Budapest. The cruise was outstanding in every way, and I would highly recommend Emerald Waterways. At the end of our cruise we spent 3 nights in Prague (got there by charter bus through Emerald) and fell in love with Old Town, and Old Town Square. We enjoyed sitting at the outdoor cafe's, eating, drinking, and people watching...Prague for me was the highlight of my trip to Europe, and to be honest I really wasn't all that excited about going to Europe in the 1st place. We always felt safe everywhere we went...during the day and at night also. Prague didn't get bombed during WW II so it is in pristine condition. Old town is the oldest section of Prague, and there is nothing like it in this country. Most, if not all of the buildings in Old Town are older than any in the US. I highly recommend a visit!

A must see!!. The Old Town Square is spectacular. The statue of Jan Hus in the center of the square is very special. The old tower and clock are fantastic. There are many nice restaurants, shops and specialty food shops on the Square. The steeples on the Church are quite unique. Definitely a must see!!

Great history. Definitively visiting Prague is because of this old square were fantastic historic buildings are located. Visit the Tyn Church, the astronomical clock and for sure the Carlos Bridge. Take a boat trip and enjoy everything this town has to offer.
Really fun. It was really fun because the clock. I liked it how their would always be street performers in the square.
lovely. a lovely place to go what a nice surprise to go to the square and it was nice day or night we ate most nights there to get the atmosphere it was lovely

Worth the hill. You can not miss this place if you visit Prague. It sits proudly perched overlooking the city and is beautiful both day and night! Walk up the hill and look around the gardens and the massive cathedral within the walls. We didn't pay for any of the additional stuff, all free, and felt we saw enough. You also get great views of city and bridges

So much to see and do!. This town square is one of the most vibrant, lively squares I've seen. Such a joy just to walk around, watch various performers, and enjoy the architecture. Lots of restaurants from which to choose, a great way to spend the day.

Tour. Everyone must go to the old town square. There are jazz trios, singers, mimes and many cafes and shops. The only minus to the square is the tremendous crowds. I suggest going early while everyone is still sleeping

Best place to relax while still enjoying Prague. This is an amazing place in the heart on Prague where to have a beer and a sausage or ham sandwich while enjoying the buskers and street art. An excellent place where to breath and relax after a day of sightseeing.
All roads takes to old town square . Better to start your tour from there .. The most sites to visit located there.. Also renting and booking tours bikes, and more.. Cafes and restaurants also

A wow. In todays super fast, stressful, digital world it's great to walk into the old town and be able to step back in time. Walk along stone streets with no cars. Look up at catedral spiers without seeing mobile phone masts. Visit a gallery grab a bite to eat and sit outside a restaurant into the night sipping a glass of wine people watching.
A very nice place. For couples or friends you can walk for hours and not get tired .have to walk in the day and in the night. Many good restaurants

A should'nt be missed place. this is where you find different restaurants, Czech cuisine hooray! coffee shops and souvenir shops as well. Do not leave Prague without drinking their BEER...you can find it here. Not pricey as well.
1st priority in Prague. excellent square..nice place to sit and enjoy different things....there are few important installations around...
Nice to hang out. Very pretty square and full of visitors and the usual tourist fare - living statues, buskers, horse tours etc. The architecture is great. Enjoy!
never seen a square busy with tourists. It is really amazing to see the massive people from all around the world in this square.. very nice and historic..
romantic. if you're in for a genuine romance, try visiting Staromestska square at 19-00. sit at the monument facing the astronomic clock, watching the figurines dance every hour at clock's strike

Beautiful to visit be can be expensive. Myself and my wife just returned from a 3 day city brake to Prague , Prague is stunning , Steeped in history and a must for a city brake , BUT keep away from the tourist traps such as the Old Town Square " Food is very expensive in the tourist traps , Take a walk down the many cobbled streets and back lanes and you will find much cheaper eats . ALSO BE WARNED Taxi prices .If you need to get a Taxi only use the yellow Taxis with AAA sticker on the side of the car ,  There are non branded taxis and they will rip you off , BE WARNED !!

Nice location to hang out. Very busy with tourists. Was told to be careful of pick pockets and was on guard but never felt being targeted. Horse and carriages rides available. Restaurants and cafes to chill out and grab a beer and some food. Relaxing to spend a few hours and go to the top of the astronomical clock tower for the best views and less that $10

magical. night or day this area is fascinating with the old architecture,all lit up at night, the hive of activity during the day also, has a lovely relaxing atmosphere, great place to just people watch, have a meal or drink and visit the clocktower and local buildings ,very tourist friendly in a picturesque spot
Worth a visit. Very interesting and full of history but packed especially when the astronomical clock is due to perform! Obviously the area is expensive for refreshments as a result.

Well worth seeing. This square is full of architectual genius! The buildings are all stunning - make sure to look up. Well worth exploring some of the side streets too as they are equally as charming and there are some lovely 'hidden' restaurants.
Wonderful place to visit. I don't think anyone will argue this is a beautiful place. You have to see it for yourself. Pictures are nice but does not do it justice.

Old town square Prague. It is a lage area next to the astronomical clock, very touristy. We took a carriage tour from here. It's very active, especially at night when street entertainers perform. Worth walking around especially in the evening. The statue of Jan Hus and some churches provide historic attractions to visit as well.

Timeless Experience.. This historical square is busy day and night. With it's spectacular buildings, astronomical clock, street entertainers, bustling cafes and watch out for the horse drawn carriages. This square has an amazing atmosphere and is the heart of Prague.

Fairytales and Dreams right before your eyes!. Absolutely romantic town square. Full of life, tourists and great eateries!You are surrounded by old buildings and there are many buskers showcasing their skills around the square. We chose a restaurant serving some nice ciders, beer and Czech food. It faces the square and it was absolutely wonderful to dine there during the sunset. Tip: Do have dinner / drinks in the area. Romantic and not expensive.

Beautiful architecture. Very busy square, but has a lovely atmosphere. Can get a bit busy with the Segways, but not really a problem. We were lucky and were in the area when the jousting was taking place

Nice scenery (avoid the ice cream). This is the "Rome" of Prague - that is, all roads lead here.Some nice scenery of old churches, and you can access most things in the Old Town from here. The Jewish area is close-by as well, so it's a good central location to expand from when visiting and exploring Prague (at least this side of it).It is incredibly crowded, however, and you WILL be harassed by segway tour guides.Side note: don't buy ice cream from the stands here - you'll be ripped off.
Beautiful place to people watch. No.1 attraction in Prague. It's a must see but there's so much more too. Watch your wallet and belongings. Pick pockets would love it here.

Old Town square . Huge square full of entertainment. Loads of cafe and bars around the square to soak up the atmosphere but these can be pricey. Look out for the segway driver's as some are learners who obviously need some experience and can be quite dangerous

Fairytales are meant to be lived. If I had to recommend when to go to old town square, it would certainly be at night. Or, perhaps just before sunset, so you can see the secret of the Astronomical clock as it strikes on the hour. The lights, the magical Tyn church, the buzz of people on a warm or cool night, the clock, tower, old buildings and lively history and stories coming alive in your mind as you walk. There is something special about this place. Even with the buskers and neon lights from Cartier and Paris street, squint your eyes and fall back in time.. Hear the alchemists and black smiths in the distance and see what other stories come alive in the night as you find the view points, an interesting bar or a place to have a cold drink on a hot day, or cold night just for the view:).

Center of the center. If you want see this beautiful square in the best look came in the morning (7-8)at the corne of sq. Dlouhá and buy the koláč with bluebarries and cofe sit at the banch and enyoj the atmosfier. And for your second look came in winter or midnight and the mediaval times will breath at you. Watch out for Golem or headless knight.

Fantastic-always something going on. Wow!! What a fab place.There is always some kind of street entertainment going on.There are the horse drawn carriages for hire for the tour of the old town.Great bars & shops.Great to just sit & watch the world go by.

Fasinating location. Old Town Square is a wonderful place full of beautiful architecture and history. There are many cafes and restaurants located here. Definitely worth a visit. We also visited a Dali exhibition around there which was very cheap and interesting.

Totally awesome!. Now I understand why people fall in love with Prague. The architecture is so out of this world and it can be observed in the heart of the Old Town Square. Although it has the same usual food stalls and street mimes, it is more than the typical European Square. It has so much character and happiness in it. Words can not describe the feeling. You have to be there to experience it. We went there in Autumn and the atmosphere added a loveliness to the architecture of the place. Be ready to walk around because there are a lot of surprises in the alleys of Old Town Square. If you get tired, there is a foot massage place right there. Dont forget to try their trdelnik.

Not to be missed.. Take your time and walk slowly around this square. So much to see and absorb. Restaurants, shops, stalls and food stands. You can take a horse driven carriage and explore the old city in style. They park on one of the sides. Go through the side alleys and explore. Fascinating. Beware of pickpockets!! Backpack back to front. Go in a close knit group. A spot to absorb and photograph.

Full of history (and people). Full of tourists, as one would expect. History everywhere, tours (including free tours), and we even visited a free concert. I guess it depends on one's luck. Every building is worth staring at for minutes. There are small streets and passages that would probably take you to yet another interesting location everywhere. A lot of expensive cafes available in the area, I suggest simply walking a few minutes into the less crowded old streets to find exactly the same menu with better prices and sometimes even quality

Magical Christmas experience especially at night. Quite stunning with the tree and castle and cathedral all lit up at night, small intimate Christmas market with killer roasted chestnuts and thick, goopy hot chocolate. Beautiful!

Perfect start for a stag !. We went for a friends stag due to Prague. The old town square has a lot of historical meaning to it. The bridge connects the old town with the new city and you will find some good artists on the bridge. To be fair they do a great job. The new town square has lots of restaurants. The place has become expensive over the years but Prague still remains a very beautiful old city.
Amazing . This square is so alive like a festival. You can eat something , listen music or only sitting . This area is very close to all old places
Great destination.. bustling place with people from all over the world soaking up the history and experience of this beautiful place.
A LIVELY PLACE. A must visit with whatever you are seeking - notable buildings, food, a place to people watch. Oh, and souvenir shops.
Worth visiting!. We visited this place on a hot summer day- so obviously crowded. But still spetacular! I belive it would be amazing on spring.

Another point of interest that can not be missed.... When you are in Prague there are a few places that you can not miss, and this is one: the cobble stone, the restaurants, the architecture, the history and the people will be the best ingredients to create a perfect memory....My recommendations: walk a lot, but at a slow pace so you can see everything that is happening around you. Enjoy a Pilsen Beer and drink it very slowly so you can remember this great moment....I forgot, take lots of pictures, because you will like to share this moment with your friends....
Take it all in. Be ready to shop till you drop, enjoy the restaurants, have a dring, share a meal, walk the streets. Enjoy! Wear comfortable shoes, cobblestones can be a killer to your feet.

One of the best places in Europe. Well you will simply be taken away with the beauty and buzz of this place. The Old Town Square is simply buzzing with life and boasts one of the most magnificent sculptures you will ever see. The sculpture depicts the Czech hero who defied the corruption of the then Catholic church to found the roots of Protestantism across Europe (or at least that was the lone form the guide which sounded true). The old clock in the square is a marvel of horology and has a following of hundreds of people milling in the crowd each time it strikes the hour. The four figures are death, avarice, envy, debauchery, ( I think) who are challenged every hour by the twelve apostles. The clock dates from 1401 and still works so a great piece of engineering. Grab a seat at a bar and just enjoy the life of the place.

Clocks and bubbles!!. A trully impressive European Square full of buzz and rasamataz from buskers, statuseque posers(who can't resist coming to life to shcok the kids) to the art of blowing massive soapy bubbles which the kids chase and stamp out! The piece de le resistance though is the astrologcial clock which shows the 12 apostles traversing round on the hour....and wait for the cock to crow at the very end!!

Not to be missed. Relish your time in the Old Town Square by pausing on the terrace of any one of the cafés...watch the passersby and the buskers Asa they entertain you with floating bubbles and fire!

Beautiful. Internet pictures do not do this justice, beautiful. Lots going on, great for bar scene and people watching. Buildings are stunning. The only irritating things are the segways which zoom around everywhere, even the small streets, watch out - but I believe they are being banned on the square.
Great Place. We were here several times on our trip to Prague. It is spectacular both in the day or night. See it in both perspectives.
Nice but crowded. By day, this is one of the prime tourist areas, by night it's drunk British teens, but it actually is a nice place to have a beer or lunch at one of the cafes lining the square.

Key central spot in old town. The square is considered to be the central meeting place in old town. There are a number of interesting sights very close to the square with the Astronomical clock in the square a must see.

The most beautiful place on earth? . Visited prague for some sight seeing...and it's certainly what I got.I could and did sit in old town square for hours. It's so beautiful and relaxing. The astronomical clock....St Nicolas church, and the everstunning Church of the lady tyn takes your breath away.Obviously in the centre everything is slightly dearer...but you're still looking at less than 2 euros for beer!
Great atmosphere and history . Great place to go to get a glimpse of Czech Republic history. Amazing atmosphere with plenty to see nearby. Great for a walking tour

Beautiful and full of character. This is one of my most favourite European town squares that I have been to so far. So much to do here for tourists, family's or couples alike.The atomic clock is a must see.The food stalls and restaurants amazing. Photographers dream also.

Centrepiece of Prague. See what Mozart and Einstein saw in the centre of the old town. The square is the heartbeat of Prague and the kicking off point for most tours. Just a coffee watching the passing parade is entertaining.

Beautiful square especially at night. . The square holds the oldest pieces of Prague history , the famous town clock that rings every hour brings thousands of tourist everyday to see. The old castle, the mini side winding streets and the amount of shop vendors for their famous jewelry Granet and Amber are all around the square. In regards to food avoid eating around the square , take the side streets or eat in the old Jewish quarter . Out tour guide was very nice to tell us that Prague sees millions of tourists every year and the restaurants in the square know this and don't offer service , try to add extra money on the bill and basically takes advantage of the tourists knowing they are not coming back. If you want to buy an ice cream or a sausage no problem but sit down dinners should be away from the square. Will post some restaurants shortly.

Praha Old town Square. Very interesting and central touristic spot in Praha. One has to visit this place at least once during day time and once at night. Very friendly and interesting. A central point for every Old town visit.
It is recommended not to eat and drink at this square, very overpriced. preferable to approach sidestreets and eat and drink there.
Good. Its not far away from charles bridge. You can go there walking within 10 min. Lots of things to see there and much activities.

A square. Yea, it's a square.
But it has some charm.
Nice atmosphere, a bell tower with figurines moving about every hour, and bars ofc.

Great. My favourite part. Just back and was 30 degrees. Also been in winter with markets filling the square. Astronomical clock there (big letdown)and plenty places for a cold beer or food reasonably priced for area. All other sights (Charles Bridge, Jewish quarter wencelas square)all 10min walk in all directions
The hub of the city. A lovely place to sit and watch the world go by, whilst sipping a cold bear or indulging in some wonderful cuisine.

Great area but unpleasantly packed full of tourists. Hard to enjoy this beautiful place full of tourists. I don't think even 10% of people are genuinely from Prague. Weekends are full of drunks using Prague as their own seedy playground and trash can. Its a pity that such a stunning city sold itself short. Probably worth visiting in the winter.

The Best. So pretty and plenty to see. A photo opportunity in every corner and the atmosphere is vibrant and friendly. You can spend all day in the old town square between the monuments. Churches, towers and cafes

Very pleasant square but packed with tourists for most of the day. Every traveller to Prague has to come here but this makes it a very busy place. Great architecture surrounds the square, including the astronomical clock on the old town hall and the Jan Hus Memorial. There are loads of living statues, food stalls, touts for tours of the city and segway tours to navigate but try and enjoy the sights while you're in the square. A large crowd gathers on the hour to see the astronomical clock animations, but watch your wallet as pickpockets are known to target this gathering.
Huge square, very busy. This is the main square in Prague, it was very busy when we visited. Many people go to see the astrological clock which activates on the hour.

Interesting enough. The Old Town Square is very attractive with beautiful buildings including churches, houses and cafes.The clock tower housing the astrological clock is there (huge crowds on the hour for the show) and one can pay to climb to the top and get great views. The Jan Hus memorial dominates one half of the square located in front of the tourist office. Many tours start from here including a couple of free walking tours (recommended).Not surprisingly there are many cafes and restaurants in the square and the value and quality of these vary greatly.Beware the Segway riders!
