A must see, but be prepared for hordes of tourists. It is worth seeing for all of the history. However, when we visited (during the middle of the European summer) it was absolutely over run with tourists, to the point where we could barely move.
where it all happens. great atmosphere where you get street artists, performers, concerts even as well as street food and restaurants

The heart of Prague. Along with the Charles Bridge, I think this is the heart of Prague. The best attraction at this square is the medieval astronomical clock, which is the oldest clock still working! At noon, you will have the chance to see the 12 Apostles passing above the clock.Do not miss it!At the old square it is very likely to see the flea market. Except the Christmas and Easter market, there are also occasional markets and the flea market that operates every other Saturday.

Nice chilled out square. This is a great place to come, grab a seat and get some people watching on the go.Plenty of bars and restaurants around it to chill out in.It's a big, clean and friendly place, with the clock at one end and a few museums at the other.Lots of street entertainers, and at night, everyone just seems to sit down on the cobbles and relax...

There's resons why this is so crowded. It is a shame that Disneyland makes this place seem less real. But this is the real thing. Gorgeous views of fairytale castles and the astronomical clock make this he place to go. It can be a bit spoiled by the number of tourists and there is a consequence to so much great cheap beer (there always seems to be drunken and loud youth).
Pretty. This are is particularly pretty in the evening. The astronomical clock is an incredible feet of engineering and worth seeing but a little overhyped

Prague emblematic spot. Big square with a lot of interesting buildings. For sure the most interesting is the Astronomical clock and the tower above it. There are also a lot of terraces where you can enjoy a drink and something to eat. A must if you visit Prague

Amazing at night. Spend the day or night here and you will not be disappointed.Stunning in the evening all lit up.Entertainers,bars,eateries,shops,its all here.No one mithers you into purchasing anything.Brilliant
Expensive. Very busy and artists perform free throughout the day and evening. Restaurants tend to be more expensive although not necessarily better
Lovely place. Lovely architecture, lovely beer. If you wanna meet some local habitants dont go during weekends - then they are running away from city as too many tourists are coming

Fascinating spot to people watch. Sat outside watching the people go by at midnight, all drinks 100 crowns each. Felt very safe. During the day the buildings, shops and street entertainers make this a must visit spot.
Fantastic old Staromestske namesti. Outstanding place the make the smile and make you happy. East to go there and with great shops and restaurant
lovely place to spend time chilling. get here mid morning during the spring or autumn, and once you've seen the sights, hang around and chill. It's a lovely place to jsut take it all in.

Beautiful town square. Prague is known for its history and this town square says it all. It is huge and surrounded by magnificent buildings. Always busy and the hub of activity as it holds the Astronomical Clock, monument to Jan Hus, Tyn church and many restaurants and retail shops. A must visit when in Prague.
A truly magical experience.... The Old Town Square is not only a timeless and breathtaking part of the city, it is also home to some of the best restaurants and attractions in all of Prague.

The heartbeat of Prague?. Locals, tourists, cafes, restaurants, bars, street performers, an ancient clock with a fascinating backstory...what's not to like? We were there when an Easter Market filled the square, adding to the excitement. Throw in simply beautiful Spring weather and it was a wonderful experience. Three days in Prague and we visited at least once daily, not always intentionally given the winding streets of Old Town. Old Town Square is a must visit spot when in Prague.

Breathtaking. Do not miss the astronomical clock on the old town hall building especially as it strikes the hour,also the cathederal and square itself,thronged with masses of people and entertainment,the usual bars and eateries,simply wonderful.

A must see sight. Hot and crowded in summer (and probably at other times), with large groups of tourists. But the architecture is amazing and you can't visit Prague and not see the square and the famous astronomical clock. Have a coffee in one of the many cafes and just watch the world go by.

Hustle and Bustle. This square is a hub of activity. It holds the Clock tower, a monument to Jan Hus, the church of Tyn,several restaurants and retail shops. Take the elevator to the top floor of the Clock tower and be rewarded with breathtaking vistas.

Joyful. Lots of tourists since the weather was gorgeous. Walking, hanging around the area all day long was not boring. You could spend your evening listening to several young musicians who perform their music ver well.

Charming old square. This was a historical square surrounded by beautiful old buildings and amazing architecture. I believed it was one of the oldest squares in Europe. It was a very happening place with lots of cafes, restuarants, boutiques and souvenir shops. Old Town Hall Tower and Tyn Church were the prominent landmarks Please wear comfortable shoes as the cobblestone roads could strain your legs. Generally, this was the place for you to appreciate beautiful architecture, so sat at the roadside cafe and relaxed.
Fun, interesting center of town.. Nice center of town. Difficult to navigate away from center because of so many radiating streets away from the center.

Busy, busy, busy!. This square is very large - I believe I heard it is the largest in Prague (except for Wenceslaus Square, which is really a boulevard) - and the people of Prague and her tourists use it well! Restaurants and bars are all around the perimeter, a large monument dominates the center, and the old church clock tower puts on a show every hour during the day. We saw street performers of every description, too. This is a great place to see in Prague!

Must see . Great place to meet up and see all the street performers. You can also see the big statue of John Hus, the great reformer. The astronomical clock tower is also near by. Lots of restaurants, shops and interesting landmark. I really doubt if there is any visitors to Prague who would not visit this Square.

Good food and drink choices around the square. The days we were there, there was street entertainment on. Good place to sit and enjoy a meal and a drink no matter what the time of day. Lots of restaurant choices just off the square down the small lanes
Lovely Place. I like the originality of the place. The stony pavements look vintage. It is a very crowded area with people busy taking picture, including me.

Real medieval square!. You feel like in 15-16th century there. Old music from medieval band, magicians, surrounded by high spires of several hundreds years old churches. You find there numerous restaurants and cafes, this is also a popular meeting point for different sightseeing and pub crawling tours. The only BUT - the amount of people. Sometimes you just elbow other people because you have to find your way through the crowd.

Vibrant place. Square again backs on from the clock - lots of bars and restaurants to visit, there is a viewing point above the clock which you will have to pay for bust again the views over Prague is simply well worth the price.

A step back in time. One can spend a lot of time just looking around as so much to see plus the funny looking pastry is way to good to miss and along with a Coffee makes the day. We spent almost a day in the area and still did not see all

More than the clock to see here!. One of Prague's most visited sites, with the Astronomical clock packing the square in front of the clock every hour when it chimes. But there is much more to the area here than just the clock - lots of shops, historical building and other attractions. We stayed at the Grand in the square, and it gave us the base to explore the area. One of our favourite places!

Meet you at the Old Town Square. Tonnes of gorgeous architecture and history here. Take a tour that includes the square! Unless you like carrying around a guide book, that is. You will learn tonnes and it will be more interesting once you have the historical background and context.

Fun in a street cafe in Old Town Square. There are many interesting sites in the Old Town Square. While a new friend suggested going off the square to eat, to save money, I found the experience delightful. My soup and husband's beer hit the spot, and watching the people go by was a large part of the interest. Also, while seated (a great pleasure, after a lot of walking), we were able to look at each building on the square, enjoy its beauty, plan for a time to watch the clock chime in a few minutes, and discuss all that we had done that morning. The young man who invited us into the street cafe had an excellent manner and seem to enjoy guiding people to his place. After this respite, we were ready to walk on to the metro.

Great place to hang out and people watch!. Old Town Square became our touchstone...always knew we could meet there and we used it as our base for exploring! Like most tourist gathering spots you may find that you are repeatedly approached regarding tours etc...but we never felt bothered or put upon and we always knew where we could pick up one of these tours if we decided on that route. It can get a bit rowdy...again, pretty common for places like this but it's lovely and best enjoyed early or later in the day for my taste.

The most popular area of Prague for tourist's.. Any trip that most everyone make's to this most wonderful of cities you will more than likely end up here,either to take some stunning photograph's ir marvel at the amazing clock or tower's or go for a meal or drink,it truely is breathtaking.I've been going to Prague for 20+ year's and i still think it is awesome .We were here recently ,10th -- 17th July and on a roasting hot week we were here most every day.We had a meal and drink's in several of the pub's,bar's and restaurant's in and around the square,most often CAFFREY'S IRISH PUB,THE GEORGE AND DRAGON PUB and took in some tower's ,i still find THE ADTRONOMICAL CLOCK amazing.There is alway's a lot going on in this square (STAROMESTSKE NAMESTI) from tour's,living statue's,street performer's,segway operator's, horse drawn carriages and big crowd's both night and day.This is the No 1 tourist hangout and were there are big tourist number's you will also find theives and pickpocket's so be on your guard.All that said it is very safe and a wonderful area of Prague and just magical at night and a must go destination on any trip to Prague.

A must if you visit Prague. Keep at least one evening for this visit as you will need to enjoy the key areas such as the Astronomical clock and the tower and the statues etc. The tower itself dates back to 1338 but the clock was first installed in 1410 and rebuilt by Master Hanus in 1490. The surrounding buildings and the artists in the square are worth spending time on but try not to eat there as its too crowded and not good value for money.

Crowded but beautiful. This Old Town Square beautiful and the history amazing. The 600-Year-Old Astronomical Clock in the square is a must-see, but be prepared for a large crowd to watch it "perform" on the half hour.
Love the entertainment!. We had so much fun just walking through the area, stopping in at outdoor restaurants and people-watching, and enjoying the street performers.
Worth seeing. Fabulous place, well worth seeing, sit have a drink and people watch, that's good fun. Lots of restaurants to choose from.

Amazing Square!. You have to go to this square if you are visiting Prague. The atmosphere, cafes and restaurants are just excellent. We were there on a City Break for five days and went to the square in the afternoon to 'people watch' then in the evening to eat. There was also a Jazz Festival on for two nights which was outstanding!

A must do - Must stroll in the old town square. And wait for the 12 o'clock astronomic watch - a unique piece of art- to play its very peculiar ding-dong with the full dance of the puppets... if you are lucky as we were, there may be some stands in the square where you can taste some of the local Czech street food.

Fantastic looking place to see. This is a fantastic looking place. The buildings and architecture is awesome.
If you are in Prague then this place is a must see.

An OLD TOWN Town Must-SEE, MUST-EXPERIENCE.. Well, if you came to the heart of Prague, you might as well view what now draws people to old PRAGUE TOWN SQUARE:The celestial clock. Restaurants and cafe line the cobblestone street cross-crossing the OLD TOWN SQUARE. Have a bite to eat or a cup of tea or espresso. Be ready though - the clock has animated characters that rotate out of the clockwork on each hour. I loved this town square. You need to see it.

Another must-see in Prague. Like the Charles Bridge, the Old Town Square is both not-to-be-missed AND totally overrun by tourists. The old homes and churches surrounding the square are just beautiful and it's kind of hard to believe that such a large and lovely place still exists intact. Get a cold drink from a mini mart and find a spot on the benches by the Jan Hus statue and just watch the Segways, buskers, tourists, and a few scammers go by. The astronomical clock on the tower is kind of cute but not so amazing that it justifies the throng of people waiting for it.
Square full of life. Really nice square with nice buildings. The square was full of life all day. You cam eat, make shopping in the nearby streets.You can also wisit the tower for a nice wiew.
Its Alive. Great architecture, full of people out for fun, plenty of good eateries nearby that are very well priced (not in the Square - tourist prices). Fantastic place.

So beautiful. I went to Prague 25 years ago, and it is still very nice ! more coffee shops, for sure, but still this special feeling of wellness.The Charle bridge is also very nice to visit, and the castle

Must see!. Even though I've been to this place like thousand times before, there is something that always brings me back and makes me see it somehow different every single time. The atmosphere of Christmas/Easter markets is undoubtedly the time to pay a visit though!
tourist. love it all, and the most is the where the bands play their music there. we pass by almost everyday during our 4 days stay. amazing.

How could this not be excellent.... We stood among the crowd and watched as the skeleton did his or her work around the fascinating clock in the Old town square, Prague. Some man was talking to a group of tourists about it and I faintly heard, mediaeval clock, built by... and a few other snippets now forgotten. But I wasn't there to hear that. In fact I wasn't there to hear anything. Travelling is about soaking up atmosphere, the whispers of times gone by, the presence of lovers who held hands once in front of this beautiful clock and those who will in the future. This square takes one back to former times, and you cannot help but imagine the people through the centuries who have stood here and watched time go by with a skeleton to symbolise just how fleeting and transient life is. A wonderful experience in Prague.
The Heart of the Old Town. The Astronomical Clock is the not-to-be-missed attraction in this area. The square is full of old world charm, but beware of pickpockets!

Must be one of the nicest squares in Central Europe. There is plenty of good architecture in this location, churches, clocks and amazing buildings. It is very busy as it`s the starting point for a number of Prague Walks. Apart from the buildings there are lots of bars and restaurants surrounding the square but be wary using them as most overcharge the tourists, also be on the lookout for the Pickpockets as this is favourite hang out for them, also money changers that usually are near official money exchange bureaux, they will cheat you offering high exchange rates and the normal is you end up with Czech or Slovak crowns that are out of circulation. Use the banks or the ATM machines.

Beautiful Square. The heart of the old town of Prague; the Old Town Hall with Astronomical clock (scene of the first Defenestration of Prague) and the Church of our Lady before Tyn dominate opposite sides. The third side has the huge Jan Huss monument, while the fourth is an arcade of shops and cafes. During the day the square is full of tour groups and street performers, with peak crowds every hour to see the Clock chime. At night the crowds are less, but there are often concerts taking place.
Great location. It is the happening place in Prague. Always something going on.best view is from the top of the tower.

This is a gem of a European old town square. No matter how busy with tourists, this square never fails to amaze! In winter, the Christmas tree is at the heart of the square and it makes one really appreciate the holiday season, while in summer the colourful crowds and entertainers never fail to distract from any stress one might be labouring.

Magnificent buildings and entertaining! . Old Town Square is an area you can easily spend a large amount of time, due to many street performances and general people watching. Beautiful architecture and lots of cafes and restaurants, however expect to pay higher prices than a few streets back from the main square.

Beautiful place with old buildings and the square that comes to life. It is very crowdy around the astronomical clock because they are waiting for it to chime but you're best off going inside and seeing the extraordinary panoramic view! The square has lots of street performers and restaurants all around to sit and enjoy as life passes by.

Beautiful square, lots to see.. Fantastic square, lots to see, places to sit and have a beer and a bite to eat, for not too much money. Look up at the interesting architecture and around at the buildings, so beautiful and very romantic. What a wonderful place to be, apart from all the crowds! Better in Winter. I could come back here so many times, without getting bored.

Beautiful square. The square is very nice,one of the nicest from Europe.It is very crowded during the day and also during the night,a lot of people are here on the terraces or to take some beautiful photos.The buildings looks very nice well renovated and the atmosphere is nice.Beautiful place in the heart of the city!
Beautiful. So beautiful! Always be wary of pickpocketers though. There is a lot to eat and see. You can just grab a seat and enjoy people watching as well.

extremely nice. A lot of people waiting for the bell to chime on the hour but of course if you go in- between you'll enjoy the view more. It is surrounded by colourful buildings and the facades are all extraordinary and you'll feel like the place belongs in a fairy tale. The Tyn Church lends a little bit of drama to it with its slender spires. Relax on a café terrace or stroll down the square and you'll get your fill of Postcard Prague!

A must to see. This is a lovely place to visit, the architecture is amazing, there's so much to see and do, there are tour guides all over the place they speak many languages, and they are free, so if you want to know more about the history of this place they will tell you,
not to be missed!. if it is the only place you see, you will leave Prague feeling happy. A not to be missed experience.
A Prague must see.. What can one say? It's a town square. Lots of street performers. Great atmosphere. Hang about and wait for the astronomical clock to strike the hour. Beats Big Ben every time.

Lots of things to do.. What a great place to visit. From the shops, the statues, to the clock and there always seems to be some kind of festival going on. Was able to go to one of the many vendors selling sausage, a potato dish, ham cooking on spits. This food was fantastic. It always is busy but its where you get to mingle with locals and tourists. Many interesting buildings around the square. There are bars and restaurants also where you can spend some down time. Well worth the trip. Watch your wallet in this area. Area is know for pick pockets so keep it close..
Magical Place. This is a magical place and a absolute must to go while staying in Prague. Especially beautiful at night.

Go see but don't spend. Great lively square- surrounded by gorgeous buildings and lots of street performers. Avoid the bars and restaurants in the square. Their prices are up to double what you pay elsewhere

Beware of Segways!. Its a wonderful old square full of beautiful buildings and fountains. Unfortunately its extremely busy and difficult to get around. There are people on Segway bikes zooming in and out of the crowds. The number of people at the clock every hour is huge. Although you must go and see it you do need to stay very long.

Hit it and quit it. Compared to the rest of Prague..not the best. The city is very touristy, but this is borderline overload. Also, it's full of homeless people haggling you left and right...and the segway tour people. Of course, you have to go here because there is a ton of cool stuff to see!

A must visit!. It is very crowded and busy but completely understandable why. Lots of things to see including the clock and other attractions. Surrounded by restaurants and stalls and filled with talented street performers.

A must see. If you are ever in Prague, this is an absolute must see. There is so much going on day and night. There is the beautiful Church of our Lady (entrance off the square between the restaurants), the astronomical clock, climb (there is a lift to the very top) the town hall tower and view the surrounding city, eat at the many restaurants and fast food outlets, have a coffee or beer in the middle of the square (not cheap) and expecially don't miss the square as night falls and all the buildings are lit up.

Over run with tourists but still a must. Like all famous city squares, this one is over run with tourists and surrounded by indifferent restaurants. But the architecture is brilliant and there was a lively Jazz Festival on. A fun place - lots of atmosphere

This is a must in Prague!. If you don't visit this square, you can't say you visited Prague. After you visit the Astronomical clock, just head to the right and you're there. If you are there for a few days, visit it daily, as the atmosphere changes! There are sidewalk cafes, occasional festivals, and lovely architecture. You can also view the square from the top of the clock tower; there is an elevator to get you there.To head onward to Wenceslas Square, look for the narrow alley between a Starbucks (left) and the Crystal shop (right).

So much !. so much history. so well kept.even the multitude of shops, cafes, restaurants - all mesh very well into the atmosphere. and the astronomical clock is a wonder really.absolutely great to spend an afternooon ( and an evening:))
Great European square . This is a great place to stroll and shop and see some of the sites. There are a lot of unique places nearby so take your guidebook and just enjoy it.

The essence of Old Prague- a must see when in Prague. Quaint medieval square, very well preserved, with a fascinating clock. If you only have one day in Prague, then this is a place for a quick visit. Note that it is quite crowded with tourists.

Beautiful architecture!. We are well travelled... this is possibly the most impressive square we have ever been to! The various architecture is like candy to the eyes. It took quite a while to take it all in. Prague is a beautiful city!

Appalling Hotel(hostel!. have just `endured` a 9 night stay, from 8th July til 17th July, And as someone who has worked in `Hotels` for over 20 year`s I can Honestly say, this Hotel (Hostel) has got to be the WORST I have had the mis-fortune to stay in? I arrived, after 14 hour`s travelling, in very hot weather, dripping of sweat, tired and exhausted, to be greeted by.... `what`s your name` and `Oh` your with us a Long time, the person then asked me to pay taxes, which are like 20p per day ! The other female on duty, threw aa registration card on desk and Never even said a word or made eye contact !!!It felt like they were a couple and `I` just walked in on them arguing? NOT ONE SMILE, OR HAVE A NICE STAY ! I was then rudely told `lift is there, breakfast is from 7-10 ! Got in the lift, were I looked at the `metal plate` on lift wall, breakfast from 7-10.30! Room was excruciatingly HOT. I read on HERE, there was good air-con...IT WAS A `FAN`, with a one metre cord on it ! So hard to place anywhere in room, but where it was ! Asked for a DOUBLE....Got 2 Very uncomfortable `SINGLE BEDS`` pushed together !!! Also, Pillows were flat, no filling, sheets/blankets/duvets/sleeping bags? (Still unsure WHAT they were?) Ridiculous ! And they were covered by, what I can only call `what looked like `CURTAINS`? I also read...ON HERE, There was ``black-out curtains` ! There was one nett curtain with an even more see-through (BLACK-OUT) curtains? A joke? Went asleep exhausted went down to find breakfast room and met RUDE reception guy who booked me, so rudely in and asked `have you been on all night`? He the `Ranted on about YES, I hate it and only get less than £20-a-day/night ! And moaned on....I have to say breakfast was OK, not Fantastic, as I also read ON HERE !!!! LOTS OF BREAD, HARD BOILED EGGS, LONG THIN SAUSAGES, TEA, COFFEE, MEATS, FRUIT ...But the toaster? You can put your toast in, go and get your tea/coffee and STILL WAIT 5 Mintues for it to be TOASTED !!! Also, after a few day`s I noticed why I had to put my cereal and warm milk into a hot bowl? I seen the lady fill the bowls for cereals with HOT bowls, NOT taking cool one`s off, placing HOT one`s on rack `THEN` placing cooler one`s on top !!! Anyway went into town, less than 5minutes to Old town sq ! Very good Location (at least!) But is it worth it? NO !!! I came back later and into the bar, where they were busy, food ok, Very cheap, but as I say it was...ok ! Barstaff hardly spoke any english. They were working extremely hard. Later on in the week...They were replaced by other staff who didn`t speak english !!

The main and important place to visit in Prague. You can not visit Prague without visiting the Old Town Square and the astronomical clock.This is the first site in Prague tourists needs to reachWhen we visited there were concerts and performances by artists throughout the day.It was very fun

Lovely beautiful architecture, lots of lovely bars to sit and watch the world go by............. Very small square with lots of history, make sure you book a tour, plenty of bars/restaurants with outside seating and friendly attentive staff, drinks slightly more expensive than elsewhere - approx. £2.50 instead of £1/ 0.5l - still better than uk prices!!! - lovely to sit down and admire the view.

Fantastic surroundings. I'm not really one for appreciating the architecture but have to say that the architecture here is stunning. Visited during the Jazz festival so lots happening and very busy but a great time was had. All amenities so close and walkable, whether modern shopping or the Lesser Town and Castle. Great starting point for every day.

Best To Visit Between Christmas and New Years!. Visiting the Old Town Square between Christmas and New Years is so worth it! The square is picturesquely decorated and there are loads of market stalls selling goodies and souvenirs!The Czech sugar and cinnamon roll-ups are a very yummy pastry to munch on along with mulled wine!It would also be delightful if one visited whilst it was snowing!Such a marvellous sight!

So much buzz. All is happening,music ,people, horses and carriages , historical buildings ..... Best time to see at Christmas . Markets ,lovely tree and Bethlehem ,shows for children with live donkeys and other animals. Lots of fun.

I love Prague!. Prague is one of my most favourite European cities. I love the vibe of the Old town with its amazing architecture. I love going in the summer when you can just sit outside one of the fab cafes people watching. Great for shopping too.
Beautiful Square. Visited around Christmas time. Square was beautifully decorated with a fantastic tree and atmosphere. Excellent traditional markets and horse and carriage rides.

Amazing architecture, amazing atmosphere. This square is bigger than it appears, and is the one place in Prague that you absolutely have to visit. The architecture is stunning, from the astronomical clock to the statue of John Hus, to the Tyn church, it is mesmerizing. The atmosphere too is unique, you have a feeling of the history of the city, almost like you are no longer in the year 2015. Really a memorable experience. One issue we did have was orientation . When we went looking for the street leading from here to the Hard Rock café , we could not figure out the street signs so well. But this does not take away from the square. Just expect some slight disorientation when you leave this magical place!

A Very Olde Square, with a Very Old Clock and 2 old Churches & with a Big Black Monument.. The large black monument in center square is of Jan Hus, a man who started the Hussite Religion, and was burnt alive for his trouble. Also commemorated are the 27 Martyrs who were beheaded on this very spot. Not a very cheerful monument!The Astronomical Clock is one of the three still running in the world, but looking at it I'm not sure that anyone can understand it, certainly I couldn't.The 2 Towered old Church of Our Lady before Tyn was completed at the start of 15th century; but for the first 200 years was used by the Hussite Religion - and we know what happened to them. The other church is called Saint Nicholas.Watch out for those uneven cobble stones, and, from experience I suggest you buy your food from the outside stalls, I found it delicious and it saved me several euros.On the weekend there was plenty of outside local entertainment, and therefore I could imagine the Xmas Market would be frantic. Well the online photos agree.Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.

Great place with a wonderfull atmosphere.. This was our favourite place in Prague. We spent most of a day looking at the great architecture, eating great street food, listening to all kinds of street performers and watching people. This is such a vibrant place and it is the heart of the city. Really a place that every tourist to Prague must visit.

I love this Square!. By far one of my favorite squares. It has everything you would want - cathedrals, art galleries, pubs, restaurants and shops. Be sure to stick around for the "announcement" of the Prague astronomical clock which I believe occurs every 12 hours. Great views from the old clock tower which you can climb. I have been to Prague on many occasions and spending time here each trip is a must!

Fascinating square, but too much going on in the middle to really appreciate it. It's clear that Prague's Old Town Square is a beautiful and interesting spot but, with everything going on in the middle when we were there, it was impossible to get a really good view. There was a large Jazz Music stage and associated bits and pieces erected in the middle, together with what I suspect is a permanent array of food stalls in the Summer, which added to the vibe and atmosphere of the place, but drastically interfered with the overall impression of the Square

Beautiful & Historic. Beautifully preserved buildings, statues, and history make this a required and fun place to visit. Plenty of shops, tour opportunities and visually outstanding things to enjoy. Of course the restaurants are touristy, and you can find better prices and food quality a few blocks away, but the people watching is fantastic and....let's face it...we are tourists! One caution: where large numbers of visitors gather, so do professional pickpockets, so take the same precautions you'd normally take in any larger tourist site and watch your belongings, purse and wallet.
a must visit in Prague. It will be very crowded and this is a nice place to visit including the marvellous clock tower ! there are plenty of restaurants nearby as well
the most popular place. Always something going on in the square, lots of entertainment, cheap places for snacks and more classier restaurants.

Can get a bit crowded!. At around the hour a huge crowd gathers around the Old Town Hall tower for the chiming of the Astronomical clock. Personally, I was a bit disappointed, you can just about see some figures moving behind a window, but even though I am over 6ft tall and had a good spot, not very impressed. But the rest of the square is definetly worth a visit if you appreciate architecture and buildings.

Awesome food. Old Town Square has alot of really cool architecture and incredible food. The clock is cool and there are alot of really nice restaurants but stick to the street food for price and portion size.
Amazing place. Perfect weather , music and nice stroll is what you need on the Charles bridge in the old town. You can visit Europe's biggest disco too :)
Fun square. Great for people watching. We saw some performers and it was fun. Great for families. Take the trip up to the Tower so you get a panoramic view of Prague

Wonderful atmosphere a must to visit. Lots of facinating sights all clustered around the square, people gathering around the church clock for the chiming of the hour, in close proximity to the jewish quarter. Buy tickets for the hop on hop off bus including river cruises for the whole of your stay

Beautifully preserved medieval town square. This spacious open square is one of the most beautiful in Europe.It is also the scene of many fun, free activities in the summer. In the last few days, we have heard the Czech national Army band play, and listened to some avant-garde jazz from Norway! Sometimes you pay to occupy a chair, but standing up and listening, or walking around the square while listening is FREE!

Best at night. At night all of the towers are lit up creating a beautiful scene.Last night they had a 60's type concert that was terrific and free. You could eat diner or have a drink. Only problem it is incredibly crowded, no doubt due to the concert. This shows just how lively the city of Prague really is.
Lots of walking. walking around seeing the old architecture. all cobble stones. bring good walking shoes I destroyed my flats on the stones

Astrology and Architecture. If you're a fan of old architecture, you have to see this place. At least three stunning major landmarks.
Also, if you have any interest in astrology or like a nice watch you have to see the astrological clock.

Huge square. There are shops galore here. The thing I liked was to walk to the astronomical clock and watch the time show when the clock sounds the hour. Little men come out and run around and a rooster crows.

nice hanging area. nice place to hang out, take a ice cream or something from the bakery and just sit and watch the people passing by. Was a jazz festival when we were there so it was nice just sitting and listening to the musiz
What can I say?. Prague's main square is one of the most beautiful spots on Earth. It is a great place to spend a few hours strolling around and watching all of the buildings and people.

Must see while in Prague. Crowded but a sight to behold. Just makes you think you're in a different world and not in Prague city! Sights of the astronomical clock, the church, and the square itself will make you pause and take a few moments to realise it's for real.
I Love Prague!. Joined the bike tour, and enjoyed prague a lot! The culture, the friendly people, the buildings. It was a great experience.

Trippy. Well of course all the guidebooks say that you should go there, but in my opinion only to see the sights. True, some nice buildings and street food but so many tourists and people trying to make money out of you. Watch out for the Segway people especially!!

Lovely at Christmas time. One of the prettiest old town squares I have visited. I went shortly before Christmas and so the square was filled with the stalls of the Christmas market. Lovely atmosphere.
Must go. You can walk, you can shop, but what you will do the most it's enjoy the beautiful scenery and place...
A nice "old" place with lots of interesting buildings. Very nice place with lots of old buildings and good atmosphere. Tends to be a bit over-croded in the high season.
A place to definitely visit. Prague is a city that most talk about and only some visit - you should make a space to visit this beautiful city.

Gem of a Town Square. The beating heart of Old Prague.... rarely quiet!
Well worth spending time just soaking up the atmosphere with a cold beer.
Lots to see for everyone.

Beautiful Square to Sit and Eat Gelato in. We had so much fun eating gelato here and people watching...it also has some wonderful buildings, and beautiful architecture to see as well. We went up above the clock tower and looking down on the square and the city is breath-taking. Worth the wait to go up and do. And of course, everyone loves to wait to see the clock perform too!
Charming. Here you find historical buildings like the engineering wonder the astronomical clock, street performers, restaurants and newly married couples dancing. It's charming and a lot of fun!
Old Clock. Loved the 14th century clock, the statue of Jan Hus, the good restaurants (with Starbucks afterwards!).
Magical. Don't miss the astronomical clock - do find time to wait until it marks the hour - it's so very beautiful and special.

Atmospheric Old a City Square. We were staying just around the corner and so walked through the square several times. It's vibrant and buzzing. Loads of street entertainment. Yes, it is a tourist trap but it it is lovely. Go at night as well for a whole different perspective

An absolute must see in Prague. This is a must see in Prague. It's alive at any time of year (considering I went there in the dead of winter) and it has what I consider the best site in Prague, the astronomical clock. The surrounding alley ways filled with little shops are great to walk through. Take your time, walk around, have a cup of coffee and enjoy the scenery and all the amazing things happening at the same time. You could literally sit here for hours people watching.The one recommendation I would make however is don't get caught up eating food here. Even though everything in Prague is relatively cheap (if you're coming from the USA or a Eurozone), there are much cheaper restaurants slightly off the beaten path. It's easy to get lost in Prague but also easy to find your way (you'll always pop out at a big site; Jewish Quarter, Old Town Square, Wenceslas Square, Charles Bridge, etc). Get lost, find a small little restaurant, sit down and enjoy the great, authentic Czech food.
Prague. We had great weather and there was a lot to see. We had lunch and dinner near the center. There where lots of small streets to explore. Would like to go back someday.
people watching central!. Grab a bier and a nibble or two and just take in the sights and sounds of Prague. Great place to stop every day!

A True Melange.... A great place to spend your afternoons with lots of displays and attractions around. From food stands offering regional products, to small cafe facing the square, to the occasional street artist, there is always something different and unique to appreciate. Lots of touristic stuff to do as well, from carriages rides to funny pictures opportunities. A great place to finish your day....
Great place to people watch and have a nice meal.. Very interesting and you must checkout the sculpture for Jan Huss and the old clock tower and watch it on the east side at the top of the hour.
Great place. We stayed near the Old Town Square and spent a lot of time just wandering around. Plenty of entertainment and places to eat or drink.

Charming square with a lot of buzz . This square has its own charm and several cafe's around.. There are Segway tours that you can take from here and the parisaka street also starts from here. Look around and if your feet hurt stop by for a Thai foot massage . There is also a moser store here- the bet glass in Europe

Wandering the old town. As we were staying in the old town we were able to wander and wander. Interesting small shops and many many restaurants and eating places. A relatively compact area with a variety of things to see and do. Churches, markets, food. great

Relax on the historic square. I have been there three time...and every time I go, I want to come again. You can enjoy various on-road restaurants with your favorite drink while enjoying the old and awesome architecture. You can also take rides on horse or vintage cars, if you like. There are mostly random events happening there. I suggest a must visit place while in Prague.

Bustling melting pot. Despite this is tourist crowded place I like this bustling melting pot. After seeing the astronomical clock tower one must climb up for a great view not only the square but also other buildings and landmarks around.But my favorite time is in the night when is a lit bit less tourist there but the time when is a great time to see the lit up charming Church of Our Lady before Tyn (Kostel matky Boží před Týnem). It is like to be in a fairy tail.There are many restaurants, not cheap one but you pay for a beautiful location. There are also some wooden stalls where you can get the grilled sausage or Prague Ham this is the trap as the price is not for the serving but for 100g!, beer also a bit expensive 60 CZK.Of course general precaution should be observed with o pickpockets as every where on busy place around the world.
Lovely little square. A really nice old town square with loads of bars and restaurants as well as sights - be sure to check out the clock, it's one of a kind!

Charming architecture and Christmas market. A square the charming buildings, particularly good to view at night when they are lit up. Noteworthy is the set of clocks on the side of the church that are quite beautiful.We visited in December when the Christmas markets were on. These were nice and quaint with a great atmosphere - especially with those amazing buildings as a backdrop - better than more famous Christmas markets like Brussels.

You must visit if you are in prague. The Old Town Square is the center of most of the main tourist attractions. The place exudes charm but expect it to be jam packed with tourists, touts and tour groups. Nevertheless, it is a must see part of the city.

One of the most beautiful squares in Europe. The church (which apparently was used as the design for Disney's famous castle) overlooking the square is phenomenal - particularly when it's lit up at night. Make sure you return to the square after dark! It's still busy then, hough not as crowded during the say. The square, architecture (which reminds me slightly of Bruges), the sculpture and the church combine to make one of the best sights I've seen in Europe.

great deal and location. Traveling with my wife and niece and her boyfriend, we wanted a place to stay that was reasonably priced and centrally located. The 3 bedroom apartment was perfect! For 2 nights in Prague, we paid less than we did for 1 night in Salzburg. The check-in location is a bit dodgy, but they gave us a map, directions and keys. The apartment we stayed in was about 1.5 blocks away from secure underground parking, necessary if you are driving. It is also 1.5 blocks away from the Hard Rock, and another block to the Astronomical clock area. The apartment had free Wi-Fi, 3 bedrooms, one was part living room, and one room had a double and single bed. The building was a bit complicated, but didn't take long to figure out the outside door and internal door are controlled by a chip in the keychain that opens it. Also, the apartments are numbered, but the keychain is lettered to indicate which door. Other than this we were pleasantly surprised by the size of the apartment and location. If you need a place to stay in Prague with family, this is the location for you. We will definitely use this service again next time we are in Prague.

New Years. We visited old town square many times during our holiday but New Years eve in Old Town Square has to be the best new years night we ever had. There is no official fireworks but people can set off fireworks as they like, it's a bit crazy but very enjoyable.

Where the Action Is. this area was very crowded with tourists but worth visiting. We went to the top of the clock tower on the elevator and the view was fabulous! Also lots of restaurants and festivities happening here.
Charming architecture. Building and the spires and steeples are awesome. Do your touring in the morning. By noon the old town are is unpleasantly crowded. Prague has been discovered....try Krakow.

Staromestske Namesti. Busy area with a lot of old charm and attractions. Difficult to get around due to the lack of street signs and the poor information given by the 'information centers'. Great public transportation.
A must see. Go here and step back into time. This is a beautiful city and worth seeing. It is not Paris or Rome but a worthy see. Very safe and friendly.
Beautiful. This is an amazing location in Prague. Little bit biased that my wife and I got married here. Really cool place at Xmas time with the market.

Beautiful Square. Beautiful area relatively unspoiled by major redevelopment or even more fortunate the ravages of war.Cafes and restaurants in square itself are a bit of a rip off but there again what else would one expect.
The nevralgic center of Prague. Definitely worth a visit to this historic and very beautiful square in the center of old town Prague, its impossible to miss it

Very interesting and happening spot. This seems to be a hub of activity in Old Town Prague. It is surrounded by a mixture of very ornate and stately old buildings and sidewalk cafes, as well as modern shops in a sort of indoor multi-level mall building. The center has a farmer's market-type collection of vendors. It is something that should definitely not be missed.

Living in the middle of the crowd. Spent about a week in Prague and stayed at a hotel at Old Town Square. Best view of the Astronomical Clock while having breakfast every morning, and seeing the place crowd up with flocks and flocks of tourists. The Architecture and Building colours are simply beautiful.

So pretty. Pretty, busy, masses going on. Lots of places to pass the time away. You can get land train from here an pony and trap rides and hire segways too, or you can just walk. THe clock is quite something and if you can wait for the hour then it's a bit of a moment!

Most terrible country ever!!!. Czech people are rude with English speakers, cold, and impolite. The central station Praha h.l n. is crowded and dirty. Small city was built hundred years ago and never had any maintenance!!! Be careful of pickpocket

Must visit - charming place, lots of history, great ambience. I can't decide which is better - Charles Bridge or Old Town Square ... let's just say that if you only had one day in Prague then you must spend it in these two places. Lot's to see around Old Town Square - Astronomical Clock, Church of Our Lady before Tyn, and other landmarks ... the view from the City Hall Tower is amazing and there is always some street performance in the middle of the square ... lot's of restaurants around the square ... sit here to soak in the ambience and enjoy a drink but go a couple of streets away to get much better food and much better prices.
Pleasant day. Just a lovely atmosphere and full of tourists from all over the world. We popped into the café for coffee and cake, brilliant.
nice. Full of pubs and entertainment. Historical buildings all around you. You can enjoy it during the day and the night

Buzzing . Definitely worth visiting.. I went there with my mother and just walked around, had a delicious meal at one of the restaurants there and got to see the famous and beautiful Astronomical clock..the square is always packed full of tourists and with good reason - it's at the very centre plus there's so much to see and do. Loved it

Christmas Heaven!. You really cannot miss this place in Christmas. Such a beautiful time to visit. It is very cold but the wine, food, and lovely ambiance make it more than worthwhile. Do try the sugared almonds and do NOT miss the Tredelnik and hot wine. Lots of hand-crafted souvenirs to buy and so many things to see. Absolutely lovely.

nice places to eat. The old town square is THE PLACE in Prague.The square has all the activities one is looking for as a tourist. There are host of good restaurants and places to eat nice lovely foods and beverages. There are small restaurants every where in every corner of the street.

world's most beautiful square!. Amazing place where you can spend hours just watching the beautiful historical buildings and crowd of people admiring them! Go up to the clock tower - amazing viewing deck!

Fun place day or night. This is an active place day or night. We went here at night on our first day in Prague. The square was packed with people. Lots to do and see here. Many places to eat, some good, some bad, but all pretty expensive as tourists abound. Be sure to see the Astrological Clock chime on the hour and see the 12 apostles do their thing.
Loved it!. Though I have been here many times, I think this is one of the most beutiful squares I have been to. Take a seat in one of the bars
Great Christmas Market. Went to Prague for the Christmas Market. The square was covered in festive lights etc. Plenty of market stalls some selling hot drinks and things to eat to keep us going!

Identity building of Prague city. It is quite beautiful place to visit in Prague. One of the must visit attraction site. People gather to see the beauty of the old town hall building and astronomical clock.

Beautiful square, lots of cafes/souvenirs, but too crowded!. Old Town Square is obviously a must see in Prague. The architecture is absolutely beautiful and is not to be missed. HOWEVER, the walk into the square from Republic Square is lined with souvenir shop after souvenir shop, which truly ruins the ambiance of the cobblestone streets and historic buildings. Once in the square, there are a bunch of restaurants/cafes to have a bite to eat, but also a TON of tourists. This can be expected during the summer months, but for me this makes it almost unbearable. There are some small stalls around the back of the square - closer to the Astronomical Clock (which is beautiful by the way!) and I bought most of my souvenirs here since they offered a couple of different things and comprable (or cheaper) prices. There's also some food stalls sellings traditional Czech dishes. Definitely a place to check out, but be mindful of your belongings and be prepared for mobs of tourists.

Great stepping off point. Fantastic stepping off point for exploring Prague and its history. Take a walking tour to fully appreciate the social, architectural and political history of a really interesting city.

A unique ambience. One of our favourite place in Praha. The square were typically full of attractions: dancing, singing. It was surrounded by few old buildings. We always had trdelník (originally called Kürtőskalács) there, a very popular traditional sweet pastry. We always enjoyed being there.
a place never miss it. a wonderful pleasant place to visit, joyful, vivid, the historical clock one the most important sites to visit and charle;s bridge

Old indeed, and full of cafes plus tourists. The historic town clock provided a very short but interesting little show at noon. Refreshments nearby make good sense following. There was an art happening on the Square, beneath the clock in which 15+ people painted all-over silver, wearing blindfolds and carrying umbrellas, arranged themselves in an everyday tableau then silently held that pose. An intriguing statement!

pretty. They were having a concert in the square when we were there. We ate dinner at a sidewalk restaurant and had the best seats in the place. We could hear the music, watch the people and enjoy a meal. After dinner we walked around a bit. There are a lot of shops, including Cartier, and lovely architecture.

Beautiful Square. The square is steeped in and surrounded by history, lots of amazing buildings, churches, monuments and the astronomical clock, there are also lots of shops, restaurants and cafe's to choose from, all serving very good food in a lovely atmosphere, be careful not to be caught out by the added tax, most places include this in their prices, some do not, we ended up paying an additional £5 in tax for lunch at the Café Italia which came as a surprise. The square is well worth a visit at night.
beautiful old town square. The old town square is beautiful and is near to Charles bridge. Also the old clock and the tower in the old town square are beautiful.
Christmas here was magical. Absolutely brilliant place, we had visited Prague during christmas time and it was absolutely beautiful and stunning I would highly recommend

Jan Hus day. We were very lucky as there was open air concerts (choir and orchestra performing sacred music) in the old town square as it was a national holiday. There was also spit roast hams and BBQ sausage and pivo's of beer available from vendors. The clock tower continues to enchant while striking the hour.
Nice. There is very very nice astronomical clock from beginning of 15th century. On the square is Church of Our Lady before Týn from 13th century.

Great place to take a break and try some Czech food.. Great place to people watch as well as get some good street food. Make sure to be careful about the street food though (definitely get some Tredlnik at some point in your trip through Prague), there's one thing that they sell by weight and it's not clear from the sign that this is the case, and it ends up being kind of a ripoff. So I would stick to things that don't come in bulk. The Jan Haus monument is faboulous and you can see some good street performers and just watch the people as well. Great place to take a break after a long day of walking.
People everywhere. See the Astronomical Clock. Hang on to your handbag, pickpockets everywhere. Great shopping! Lots of bars, cafes, glassware, garnets and people!
Must see. You have not seen Prague if you have not visited The old town square and seen the astronomical clock. There were many great street performers as well - bring some coins to support them!

Very touristy - but good for me, as a tourist!. Loads to see and do here, and close to many of the great must-see sights of Prague. The Old Town Square is smack in the middle of the major tourist signs, with the Jewish quarter and it's great up-market shopping on one side, Old Town on the other, and a stones throw from Charles Bridge and across there to Lesser Town.In the square itself there is the Astronomical Clock and he achurch of Tyn, and too many gorgeous buildings to count all around. The square is full of buskers (of quality) and Hare Krishnas and Segway renters and horse drawn carriages and bubble blowers and many more. We loved it.

Crowded. Lots and lots of tourists here- it's a real tourist trap and the restaurant and cafe owners make the most of it- very expensive compared to other parts. The Astronomical clock is worth seeing, although I think it's a bit overrated..

A must to do in Prague. This is a must visit when in Prague. Lots of bars and restaurants and a lively atmosphere. The clock is a must see and is very popular. High end shops within easy walking distance make this an ideal location to shop, people watch and enjoy some good food

Worth a visit. Beautiful day or night various amazing buildings to look at and the astronomical clock.different cafes and restaurants to try,various activities music and displays going on.perfect place to relax and people watch always plenty of people about.

People central. Nice open town square surrounded by incredible architecture. History abounds in this spot. The clock is a delight and of course the area swarms with tourists from all corners of the world. Many cafes and restaurants fringe the square and are reasonable (but not 'fine dining'). There's always something happening to keep you amused. However, keep a watch for the hordes of dangerous Segways zooming through the crowds (please Prague, ban them). Also a good spot to regain your bearings before heading back into the maze of lane ways.

A glimpse into european middle ages.. A real trip into medieval period. Prague was a top-notched city for astronomy in the Middle Ages and that place has kept the spirit of it. The magnificent and complex astronomical clock still functionnal is a masterpiece. We enjoyed climbing in the tower where the view of the city is excellent. Terraces all around were crowdy and were providing a nice opportunity for people-watching, especially when the clock was ringing at every hour. Cristal shops were everywhere and colorful. Some pieces were exciting and very modern but we found them in more little workshops nearby the place. Street animation was nice aand contributed to create a medieval atmosphere.

Captivating Old Town Square. There's always something to do and see in the Square. Ther's shopping, vendors, street musicians. I would highly recommend staying on the square ~ it's central to all your exploring.

Can't visit Prague without visiting Old Town Square. Advantages:- The view of quite impressive architecture on almost all sides of the square.- The famous clock. (Tourists stand for 10-15 minutes to wait for the minute clock "show" that happens on the hour. Need to see it once, to say you did.)- On the clock side of the square are vendor booths selling sausages, potatos+kraut, fresh made potato chips, etc. The food is actually very good and fairly inexpensive.- Quite a few other restaurants and ice cream sellers well into the night.- The square is "alive"! There are as many people in the square at 12 midnight as 12 noon. You really get a feel for Prague in the square.Disadvantages:- If you dislike crowds, this may not be the place for you. But then, almost every tourist spot in Prague was crowded.
Very amazing architecture. A lot of people, loved there were many police which made you feel comfortable. The building are old and beautiful, this place has a lot of character!

When in NYC go to times square and when in Prague..... Just a must for exploring the old streets, cafes, restaurants, and of course people watch. No lack of "Kodak moments" . Take the time to stop at a key located cafe and have a great local beer and take your time watching the people and taking in the scene. One of the great treats of Prague/Europe is their tradition to NOT rush you or try to turn the table. Its yours , as long as you want..enjoy! Note: easy walk to the metro (subway) , or easy to hop on a nearby tram (tram # 22 is great for sightseeing).

And we thought the Swiss were kings of the kukoo clock. Besides the coffee and dining at the cafe's there is the architecture and the clock. I mean. When have you ever just stood there waiting for the clock to tick away. If you are really into that kinda thing then this will BLOW YOUR MIND. Also if that isn't really your thing then this is pretty cool.
A must. A must!! So much to see and do there. The tower, the stores and restaurants!! The horse drawn carriages and vintage car rides...perfect for people watching.
One of many. All. The squares in old town are surrounded with beautiful buildings. The clock was interesting to watch at 15:00.

Prague at its best.. This is quintessential Prague. It is wonderful any time of day or night. Lots of fun places to stop and look, or to get a refreshment or meal. We did not find any really fine restaurants, however, some pretty good local cuisine is available.

Delight for all senses. Every corner, every wall, every building has a story to be told. The architecture of this square has so much to offer!! It's safe to walk around at any time of day or night. Just around the main cathedral and its tower is the Astronomical clock: an splendid display of synchronicity, art and visuals not to be missed! the oldest clock in the world still working to perfection.

OK, but dun buy tickets to go to the clock tower!. The old tower square is always full of people, so be carefully of your wallet and belonging. Me and my friends bought student price tickets to go to the clock tower. The service was bad and it did not worth for 70 krones for students, since all you can see the the overview of old tower square, not how the clock works !!!!Disappointing ! However, we went up there during sunset, so it is a gd place to take photos. Please bear in mind that there are lots go tourist up in the clock tower, you have to be tolerate that people may push you. So, for me, I would not recommend you to buy a ticket to go up clock tower. If u want to see Prague's over view, i would suggest Novoměstská radnice !

A very pleasant square. Although it is always crowded, the square is a very pleasant place, with a lot of things to see and a special positive energy. Stroll along the square, wait for the astronomical clock show, take a picture with Jan Nepomucki and try delicious Praha Ham and sweet trdelnik.

Can not be avoided. Despite being very crowded - the old city square is an amazing place to be. Every hour the old clock will do its show - with a lot of people gathering to watch. I prefer sitting at one of the restaurants/cafes and getting a beer or a drink will trying to relaxe in all the fuzz.

where history blends with fun. The settings of this sqare are old and amazing, but when you stop gazing in awe to the high clock tower and finally pay attention to ground level there is a lot to see and enjoy. Restaurants and shops, street performers, street food, street music and the show provided by the people, tourists and locals mingling, winding at different speeds and in different outfits. I could spend hours just sitting in a nice terrace, sipping a cold drink and enjoying this show.
Pedestrian area - great atmosphere!. Great atmosphere - strolling through Old town , lots of activity , stunning architecture , completely safe
Center of the excitement. Fun to see where all the action is, but rather hectic. If you like quieter spots, go to a nearby side street for a nice cafe table.
Prague 2015. Great place to people watch whilst having a meal or drink. Can be a bit pricey but worth it. The views around are great and many places to explore.

My Favorite Spot. Old Town is a must see. I lived in Prague several months and loved walking around Old Town and embracing the history, shopping in the stores, and listening to street musicians. Try some Trdelnik while you're there too!

Segway nightmare. Beautiful view from clock tower, astronomical clock disappointing.
Segways stopped square getting a five star.
Atmospheric heaven. Fantastic story behind the history, albeit at times tragic but a wonderful place to enjoy the stories and architecture.

Stay near here for easy access to everything. Loved this plaza. So much walking through different path ways around the square. Loved the open air markets, the people watching, the shops, the restaurants and the sites. Best place to stay near as well.
The clock is worth watching when it chimes. Great for people watching spent a leisurely afternoon watching the various entertainment with a drink

Busy town square. Great for people watching and there is always some artist of sorts making music or entertaining the people. Busy busy busy with people I expect most of the day. If you like the energy of crowds, you will love the square.

Beautiful old town square. Wife, my baby son and I had a wonderful stay in Prague. It's one of our favorite cities now. The old square was jubilant with life and history. Such an old place that central to all the must see locations in Prague. The Charles Bridge is about 10 minutes from the square, the astronomical clock is right in the square along with lots of restaurants and entertainers.

Big summer crowds. This amazing square is huge and surrounded by architectural treasures, but I'd like to return in a quieter month to fully enjoy it. In high summer be prepared for crowds, which of course add excitement to the space but also detract. Especially lovey at night which the Gothic and Renaissance towers are strikingly lit.

Perfectly European!. Lots of people, live acts, tons of places to eat and have a beer, great surroundings and beautiful architecture of old town surrounding you! This place summarizes Prague in its essence and soul. Unlikely anyone visiting Prague would miss this. Important would be to take out time and enjoy this place in its full glory...
Great. This area is very popular with tourist you must go up the tower for spectacular views of the city it cost about 120 crowns, the area is alive with stalls, shops and resturants.
Heart of Prague. Really busy area but probably my favourite area in Prague mostly because of the buildings in the area especially the Astronomical Clock Tower.
Great people watching place. Not too expensive to sit and enjoy a beer while people watching. Busy during the day and no problem finding a seat.

Mrs michelle Jones. What a lovely place to visit u can spend hour's just looking at the building's there amazingly beautiful loved the clock tower and the lovely little streets x fab places to eat and drink too well worth a few days away

Don't expect much from the astronomical clock!. Old Town Square is a lovely European Square, a must-see when visiting Prague. The Tourist Info storefront is stocked with countless brochures and has a helpful, multi-lingual staff (though curiously they sent us two blocks away to the separate tourist center for information on the Jewish Quarter). Many tours leave from Old Town Square, so it's hard to imagine that anyone will visit Prague without passing through. For those planning their trip, we'd advise not to get too excited about the much-discussed astronomical clock -- and don't spend much time waiting for its top-of-the-hour "show." It must be one of the most over-hyped such things in all of Europe!

Busy town square. Busy square with the usual ingredients: street artists, museums, restaurants, pubs and souvenir shops. Nice place to laugh at all the tourists and see the astronomic clock.Watch out for pick-pockets and segways.....
Old Town Square. Stroll along slowly and admire all the old buildings in the square.Lots of history.Drink in any one of the bars or pubs they serve beer that taste so good.

A very vibrant place. The Old Town Square is very busy and vibrant. It is surrounded by so much wonderful history and the area is filled with tourists, locals, performers, restaurants & shops.We enjoyed the time we spent in the square and visiting the historical sites that surround it. The only detracting thing for us was the grafitti. Hopefully this is something that will be addressed in the near future.

Lovely town square. Had a wonderful time in the old town square - it was fun, interesting, and the smell of the food from all the vendors was amazing! The outdoor seating g was nice, saw some great street performers. We found a nice Irish pub and it was so much fun! The architecture of the buildings was spectacular. It's a beautiful place to go and there's a lot going on. Be sure to visit this beautiful square.
Amazing. Beautiful square with church, clock and many other historical buildings. A must if you are in Prague
Perfect spot for hanging out. Excellent place for people watching. There are wonderful street performers here in the summer and a huge market at christmas time.

Praguelicious. Beautiful baroque to gothic style architecture around every corner. Bustling night life and street performers. After dark keep your wallet in your front pocket. Don't piss off the Prague ham man! What ever portion he decides serves you is what you need to purchase or your not eating any of the tasty ham.

Fantastic square with beautiful buildings. One end of square in particular had an array of superbly kept buildings, despite many having ground floor used for commercial uses. Pretty lively with buskers and stalls selling freshly roasted local sausages etc. Nice ambiance sitting in a cafe watching the world go by.

Great place to explore. Old town square can take a person back in time. There are historic buildings and churches, restaurants and cafes, many shops, booths and street performers. Great place to begin an exploration of the city.
Praque 2013. Fun place to hang out in the evening. There are little carts of items and food to buy which is really nice on a cold night. Watch for the clock.
I cannot describe how beautiful this is!. I could spend weeks just staring at the amazing buildings around this square. It is really beautiful and interesting.

Beautiful Prague. The old town square is a great hub to any Prague trip. Besides being gorgeous, there are wonderful cafes here and along the many side streets around. And the Starbucks just in front of the clock is the earliest coffee shop open if you're an early riser!

Not to be missed. Use a guide! I took the pedicab (after talking him down to half the price) and it was an unexpected treat. The cobble stones are killer on the feet and the sights are so dense that it is easy to miss something without an expert. I had 3 guide books that I was using and the pedicab tour guide was able to add more information and pointed out several things I missed after my first two trips to the square.

Lovely square at all hours. This is a huge, buzzing square in Old Town with lots of busking taking place. It's the general meeting place for everyone it seems. Lots of restaurants offer a range of food and beverages but not cheap as you would expect. The buildings a pretty spectacular with varieties of architecture depicting the various stages of Prague's wealthy inhabitants. The centre piece is the Astronomical clock which comes to life on the hour for a brief couple of minutes.

Lovely square with great vibe. Lots of restaurants and bars. great views of clock tower, church and other architectural buildings. Lots of little shops to get souvenirs. Only issue I disliked is the amount of smoking.

Nice area. Everywhere in Prague is beautiful, and Old Town Square is no exception. Shops, street jazz, musicians, and people from all over the world converge here. Plenty of restaurants near by, the Astronomical Clock, a short walk to Wenceslas Square, and a short walk to the Charles Bridge. Old Town Square is a great place to start any day in Prague.
Great atmosphere. . If you dont like crowds- avoid. If you love a good atmosphere, beautiful architecture and great entertainment- you can't miss this!
Breathtaking. We didn't book a tour here we just walked through and enjoyed the street entertainment, beautiful architecture and food stalls. Well worth a visit!

Crowded Tourist Trap. Beautiful buildings, but not really a lot to do unless you want to shop for over-priced nick-nacks in the shops. Walk through, see the clock and some churches, go to a less crowded and touristy part of town for shopping/food/beverage.

Buskers were great. This place is wicked!! Watch the buskers, watch the people, watch the astronomical clock, have a beer in the many restaurants but beware, its expensive to eat and drink in the Square.

Beautiful spot. This square is indeed one of Europe's finest. The astronomival clock is one of a kind, though the every hour event is somewhat disappointing. Just walk around the square and look around.
lovely architecture. In the day at different times it is interesting buT if you are around at night drop in to have a looK because when it is lit up it is very beautiful

Excellent place to people watch. This was lovely for coffee and food. Staff very friendly and helpful. We ate lunch which was baguette with chicken, really tasty. Reasonably priced to other places. Good place to sit and watch some of the attractions in the square. Highly recommend
Don't miss this. The orological clock is tremendous and definitely battling the crowds to see. Very busy square but lovely, and old.

Heart of Prague. Wow, the center and heart of Prague.
The whole square is a beauty with marvelous bulidings all around.
Musicians, treats to try .
Sometimes a bit too full of tourists !!

Go to the Square more than once.. Be sure to go several times during your stay, both day time and night, and take in the astronomical clock when it is "on the hour" as well as going up in the tower of that building to get excellent 360 views of the city. People watch in the square. Don't bother with the restaurants there, but seek out a quiet street where the staff are more grateful and considerate of their guests.
Fantastic visit in Old town square. The building structures and designs are very nice. The view is magnificent. I would definately go back visit again.

Storybook Beautiful. Old Town Square has a magical quality to it that is hard to explain until you get there. It's a perfectly preserved Medieval Square with stunning architecture in every direction you look. The twin-towered church in the square looks like the original model from which Cinderella's Castle in Disneyland was based. And the famous clock tower of the Town Hall draws a crowd every hour on the hour as an elaborate mechanical procession of the 12 apostles rotates by the onlookers below. The place is always busy and noisy and filled with expensive tourist restaurants and cafes. We happened to find a great pizza place, called Al Minuto, however, in the left-hand corner of the square as you face the clock tower. The individual pizzas there were as good as any I've had in Italy--and the service and staff were friendly and efficient. We went back twice during our visit!
Awesome. What a place you feel as if you are in the middle of a magic land, its is a beautiful place with lots of character, some of the original buildings from old era. Lovely place

Need to see in Prague. Staromestskaya Square (Starogorodskaya Square, чеш. Staroměstské náměstí) — the ancient area of Prague located in historic center of the city (Starr Mesto). Its area makes about 15 thousand sq.m. The area is surrounded with town houses with facades of various architectural styles: Gothic, Renaissance, baroque, rococo.This place is known since the XII century, at that time the area was the large market standing on the intersection of the European trade ways. In the XIII century the area began to be called as the Old market, and since the XIV century — the Staromestsky Market. In the XVIII century the area replaced some names — the Staromestsky parade-ground, Bolshaya Staromestskaya Square, Bolshaya Square. In 1895 the area received today's official name.On the square passed the royal coronation processions following during the Prague Hail. Except solemn events, on the square there were also tragedies. In 1422 there were collisions caused by execution of the leader Prague needy Jan Zhelivsky here, in 1437 the last gusitsky hetman Jan Rogach with the confidants was executed here. On June 21, 1621 on Staromestskaya Square accepted death of 27 participants of Stavovsky resistance against a dynasty Gabsburgov. In their honor on the sidewalk about the main town hall, placed 27 crosses, with symbols of a sword and a shipasty crown.
always vivid. always full of life, with billions of all kind of people. Tourists, locals, immigrants, men, women, something in between, attractions, distractions, fun and not so fun.

Festive Easter Week. Full of people and decorated wooden huts selling traditional handicrafts of decorated Easter eggs, hats, gloves and scarves. Food vendors selling sausages, ham, chips, candy and pastries. Live music performances. A fun place to visit during Easter.

History at it's Best. This was the most amazing place, full of history , Shops, Resturants, Culture, Crystal, resonably priced, a must see, so much to see and do for all the family, Prague at it's Best, Architecture at it's finest.

square next to clock. Adjacent to astromical clock. German market taking up whole of square selling food and craft products. Stage with occasional performances. Plenty of cafes, restaurants around the square. Tours start from stage side of square. They offer free walking tour of town

"A Must-see!". the square is a pretty amazing sight to behold with Tyn church towering over it and the city hall with the famous astronomical clock (which wasn't what I expected). Packed with people & so much going on! You can just hang out there all day!
Old World Charm with an Updated Vibe. There is always something happening in this square, which is ringed by churches, beautiful buildings and outdoor restaurants.

Nice, but sooo crowded. Pass through to see the Astronomical clock and the buildings, but wander around the side streets for restaurants and small shops. When the clock does its little "show" on the hour,it's almost impossible to walk through there.
It's the Heart of Prague. Your in the heart of all the action that is Prague. Suggest that you allow time to visit the many locations that surround this square, also enjoy a meal in a sidewalk café.
Charming suqare. Old town square is surrounded by excellent restaurant and landmarks. It's a real romantic place and definitely a must to see

Beautiful old buildings. It is amazing to see all the history and the old buildings with so much character. You can imagine how much effort went into building these beautiful old structures. Well worth seeing.

its a must. a grate area can take you back century's just by standing there but drift off to the student quarter to cheaper bars un try un pick up some local Chrystal not to mention the Russian Champaign
Must see historic architecture. Ignore pushy segway tour guides and spend some time here absorbing this historic multi century site.

old town square. Surprisingly prices are reasonable and food is very estethic
& good.a lot of suveners shop and the highlighte iz thd cristal work which is oc good quality

Behind the Iron Curtain what a pleasant surprise. This is a must see city nothing like it . We were there in 2012 in August the people the bier and the food were all great .Very good exchange rate for US dollars .

The heart of Prague. If you're a tourist, the Old Town Square is the beating heart of Prague. Surrounded by quaint restaurants, hotels, the astronomical clock and with the two prominent cathedrals on each side, this square is unmistakably beautiful and no trip to Prague would be complete without it. It will inevitably be full of people at all times of day or night, mainly tourists. One of the best sausages I've ever had was from one of those vendor stands lined up one next to the other on the astronomical clock side of the square. If you want to sit down to peacefully enjoy your sausage and beer, there is a small park with benches right behind the vendors. The only real annoyance of this square is the many people on segways that can sometimes be going extremely fast through the crowds. Not very safe for them or the pedestrians.
Crowded. A beautiful part of Prague, with wonderfully preserved building. But, even in March, be prepared for a lot of other visitors.
