That's where history begins in prague and hence, you can find most walking tours starting off at this location first. Do go there to look out for the walking tours!

What's not to like?. What a pleasure to sit in one of the many restaurants and cafes around the square watching the world go by in the sunshine and with a drink. Very buzzy square with crowds gathering for the hourly spectacle of the astronomical clock doing its stuff. Restaurants a bit mixed for vegetarians (which I am), but always found something good to eat, and a couple offered to make me anything I wanted! One restaurant (Olive) directly opposite the clock not so helpful. The manager didn't like the fact that a single person was occupying a table for four. Not my fault, they didn't have smaller tables, and given that I had a full meal, I wasn't impressed with him keep walking past tutting at the fact that I was there. I felt rushed and pushed out. However, this was the only time I had this experience. The world and its wife pass through the square, so if you're into people watching and experiencing the buzz, Not to mention the amazing buildings, then go for it. And it leads you down to the streets and onto the Charles Bridge.

Wonderful Mix of History and Culture. To understand the history of Prague this is the first place you should visit. It's most important theme is Jan Hus and his followers, the Hussites, who were the Czech Christian reformers. They are immortalized by the Jan Hus Memorial at one end of the square. There Jan Hus statue is gazing at Tyn Church, the original Hussite Church, the most famous church of Prague and of Czech Republic. Finally there is an area in front of the Old Town Tower where 27 Hussite martyrs were executed in 1621, marked by white crosses on the ground. This signified the loss of Czech independence for nearly 300 years under the Catholic Hapsburg rule. When Czechs regained independence they brought down Mary's statue that was in the middle of the square and placed it in a recess on the right side of the Tyn church which is often overlooked. I thoroughly enjoyed these findings, and I hope you do, too.

Beautiful!. The architecture and scenery here is very beautiful in the day and especially at night. Expect plenty of tourists, segway users, slightly higher prices but it is worth it for the views.1 thing to note, in the evening there are a lot of people selling adult shows every 10 steps, beware

It is so pretty, it seems dysneyesque. The 'Old Square' is so pretty, that at a point you feel that you are not really in Prague but in Dysneyworld¡ Try to go early or in the late evening, as crowds can really be a annoying!

Beautiful Square. Very busy, lots going on, segways flying around, you can hire these out here. Horse and carriage rides also available here and also starting point for train sight seeing tour (1 hour around the city) music also here. You can also sit down here and watch the world go by.

One of the "must see" places in Prague. One of the greeat landmarks in Prague. Yes, it is full of tourist, but because tourists like it! There are several events organised there throughout a year, so the square is always changing. Once a Chinese New Year Pavillon, once a Hockey World Championship Fan Area, once a Christmas fair...there is always something happening there.And of course you always have the option to stare like an idiot on the Astronomical clock every hour like the other tourists do! :-)
Funny place. There you can find all you want. All day different people try to entertain you. I recommend to taste trdelnik. Every hour a lot of people watch astronomical clock show.

Fairy Tale Buildings. This is really a beautiful and active square. The one draw back were all the large tour groups and segways. We were there in May and I can only imagine how busy in the summer or holiday time this is. Go to the square early in the day to enjoy it.

This is where to get your Segway tour!. First, Old Town Square is ridiculously beautiful and in my opinion best seen by yourself peeking into all the little areas and walking around in wonder! Behind TYN church is a fabulous restaurant where I ate everyday. The Indian Jewel. I did tours for three days with the Segway group called "Cool Segway Tours" or better known as "the Russians". What nice young men! They were super careful with me and I had an absolute ball riding all over Prague. The Segway was the highlight of being in Prague because I could go all over so quickly. Hate to leave Prague this morning! Make sure you read about this square.

Lovely place with lively ambience. Huge square surrounded by beautiful buildings. We enjoyed sitting and soaking up the live atmosphere. The performances of jugglers,musicians are really really good and worth watching.

Lots of positive energy!. Bustling with activity. On the day that we visited, there was a concert with nice vocals and instrumentals. Truly cosmopolitan and a melting pot. Sculpture of Kafka is a stand-out.
Mesmerising. just as the old town itself this is a must see in this fantastic city. Well worth a visit and most defiantly will be returning

Thank God for the Old Town square.. The square is a good place to just sit down and enjoy the beautiful historical buildings surrounding the wide open square. But the best thing about the square is,....it allows a little bit more distance between me and my fellow tourist!!!.........After the tourist stampede on the nerrow streets of old town Prague, the wide open square is a welcome relief. Expecially one as beautiful as the Old Town Square.

Another Prague tourist trap.. Probably this was once a location worth visiting but it is yet another area of this city's faded glories that has been ruined by mass tourism and the search for quick profits. Avoid.

Stunning in its beauty . A fantastic town square and the clock is out of this world.Lots happening in square with entertainment, vendors and lots more, it's the heart of the city and must be on your to do list in Prague.Also great to see all the old buildings and the history surrounding them and fantastic city to spend time.

Amazing Architecture, Shops, Restaurants.. This is such a beautiful city that is filled with so much history as well as all the amenities one needs. Prague is a thriving, friendly, fun and happening place that appears to be right out of a fairy tale. The architecture is mind blowing, such variety of historical types. You will not be able to stop taking pictures.

A special place. This a special place significant in the velvet revolution, Havel met the people here. If your not familiar with the history, read up on it and then visit and soak up the atmosphere. Lots of activity, a great place to hang out. Of course there's plenty to view around for photos, catherdrals, statues etc

Beautiful holiday destination .. We went to prague in oct 2014 and the weather was awesome , cold and windy .it is a travellers delight . Great history , cobbled paths and a beautiful castle , the famous Charles Bridge , on one hand and the latest designer stores and superb shopping at venceslav square at unheard of prices.Very friendly people and u can have a lot of fun in the old town square , with a lot of street performers . A superb tourist destination .
Too touristy. Although I loved Prague I found it to be a little too touristy even out of season. Don't exchange money in Old Town Square you will get ripped off and avoid hiring a Segway.

Beautiful and vibrant. The old town square is a really nice place to hang out. We spent quite some time wandering around stalls and sampling local foods, watching street performers, waiting for the astronomical clock and relaxing in local cafés watching the world go by. I would recommend an afternoon doing this to anyone!
A lovely place. It was really nice just ambling around here, looking in shops and lots of other places, a good place to walk, just be aware of tourist traps

Sit down and watch the world go by!. Plenty of eateries, fabulous buildings and architecture. Very busy at the weekend but better during the week. We didn't feel ripped off with prices for sitting outside with good views of the square. Plenty going on for just sitting back with a drink and people-watching. prices are very reasonable for food and drink. Lots of little food huts about with some very interesting offers.
Old. Great history, cheap beer!!Great amount of beautiful buildings , outdoor cafes that are nor very expensive like Vienna or Venice.

Always amazing place.... The old town square is always the best experience in Prague. The feeling is to be in a fairy tale place, but for the incredible number of tourists but there's no chance...during the night, the experience is also magical and why not to have a drink there?

Prague visit May 2015. great tour with JP. Very informative and humorous...we love Sandeman tours. was the right length as we kept moving but not too difficult to keep up and we covered alot of history!

Spend the afternoon. The square is always full of activities from street musicians and performers to food vendors. It's a lively and fun place to grab a bite for lunch and take in some other attractions. You can also do some tours of Prague from this location. Plenty of things to do here as well as getting some great pictures.

Just soak up the atmosphere and architecture.. Give yourself time to wander around the square, there is so much to see from beautiful architecture, street vendors, musicians and street performers of all types, restaurants to while away the time in and the Town Hall clock to gather in front on the hour to see the Apostles through he little windows. Tour kiosks and tourist information are all available along with antique style cars to ride in or go for a 20 minute ride in a beautiful horse drawn carriage. Don't rush your visit here.
Lovely square. There's even a C and A!Some nice shops to look at and of course the horses statue but best shops are away from the square

Old town square. Well worth the visit lots of things going on every one wants to see the clock there are entertainers, places to eat lots of gift shops horse and carriage rids Segway tours all the tourist things the street off the square has all the expensive top brand shops.Worth a visit at night too.
A place to do !. Heart of the city, bands and animations are everyday here ! You can eat, drink, take sun and watch! This place and buildings around have a great history to learn !
Incredible place!!!. If you are visiting Prague you must see the Old Town Square with its incredible atmosphere, you can really feel the history here!

Understand the Clock. Don't focus on the hourly chime and movement. Understand how this clock predicts seasons, sunrise, etc. A marvel of 15th Century math and engineering before realizing we travelled around the sun.
Beautiful. You can't avoid a look at this place. Heart of the city. Can be crowded at times. They had big LED displays for the ice hockey which created a great atmosphere that evening.
nice old town. lovely old town.nice cathedrals..nice castles.nice restaurants.excellent coffee shops..souvenier shops
A must See!. Like: awesome buildings and church surrounding the sqaure. Relax at the cafe for people watching or join in the crazy crowd that surround the astronomical clock when it hits 12 noon!
lovely location. I have been on holiday with my family 2 years ago in Prague. It s absolutely amazing!!! The old town square is magical. It s a must see in Prague!

Arguably the most beautiful old-fashioned square in Europe. This square is bustling with tourist activist all day. At the square, there are two churches, town hall and astronomical clock amongst other things like restaurants, street performance etc. This square also hosts Easter/Christmas markets and is starting point of many tours. Arguably the most most picturesque square in Europe.
vibrant old town square. I loved the old town square in the summer time ,there are plenty of cafes and bars nearby to sit and people watch on a nice warm day.

Lively and a bit much. Really lively, energetic square to visit full of people, musicians, vendors, etc. The Astronomical Clock is really interesting -- go up it if you get a chance. The square was fun to see once, but I didn't have much of a desire to go back, given that it was swarming with tourists and was just a bit too much after a while.

Anyone can not miss this. What can I say? It is hard to miss this place, as majority of main tourist attractions are located within the vicinity. There are some constructions going on as I went there last month, which perhaps giving us a little less convenience to walk around. But it's just great to be here.

Walk back in history.... Old town square is an area of Prague that is, well...old. It has old buildings from different times in history that you can view from the square or get close up and in some cases enter. The square lights up at night which was pretty neat. When I was there the weather was so-so but there were still 1000+ people walking in the square. It is a touristy area of Prague so while there are a lot of souvenir shops there are also some great restaurants off the square. Very walkable and a must-see when in Prague.
A real picturesque. Old Town in Prague is where you can find the famous Astronomical clock. No matter what time of the day you come here, a massive crowd usually hangs out here.
Lively town square. Great place with lots of people, restaurants, cafes , live music etc. There is always something interesting going on there!
A must see. This is a beautiful square surrounded by impressive buildings. It is very crowded with tourists who are fascinated by the astronomical clock or enjoying a beer in the many outdoor cafes.

Great Atmosphere - Too Crowded. Atmosphere here is great - very lively, musicians playing here and there, everyone enjoying the wide open space and staring at the stunning architecture. More ornate than Vienna - this is a must see.BUT.....Once you've seen the square, and the Astromonical Clock strike on the hour - get out of there - Way too crowded, and cafe's are way overpriced. Seen it once - move on!!

One of Europe's best squares. The Europeans know how to do a square, and the Old Town Square in Prague is one of my favorites. Vibrant and fun, with beautiful views in every direction. Do yourself a favor and have a meal or a drink in one of the overpriced restaurants that line the square, sit back, take in the view and enjoy.

Crowded and Touristy. Of course it is a historic area, and the Astronomical Clock is there, but boy is it ever crowded. The crowds take away from whatever ambiance the area has. Combine that with the touristy stores and once was enough just to say we have seen it. We saw no need to go back, preferring other areas of the city.
Busy busy. Wait til the clock strikes....it is a must! It is great fun with all those people around you. And the excitement is almost touchable.

Stunning architecture, lively atmosphere! A must see when in Prague!. Another fantastic historic city square, lively, lots of hustle and bustle and gorgeous architecture. I was overwhelmed by the intial views of the old historic square. Oozes colourful stunning buldings, atmosphere and a great place to soak up the street artists, musicians and general tourist vibe. Guaranteed are lots of restaurants, bars and outdoor seating as well as tourist attractions. Whether you want to climb a clock tower or sit and watch the world go by, you will be guaranteed an enjoyable experience. I would also recommend wandering off the square as well as there are many hidden little streets with bars, shops and restaurants and a lot cheaper than the main thoroughfare. May 10-15 2015

Old Town Square, Prague - a walk back in time. Since the city of Prague was barely touched by the devastation of WWII (only a portion of the clock tower in Old Town Square), the narrow city streets and alleys are like walking through this magnificent city hundreds of years ago. Quaint shops, great cafes and restaurants, and sense of medieval Europe hits you immediately. Getting lost is half the fun, as well as coming out on the north side and hitting Charles Bridge. Prague is my favorite city in Europe, walk through this wonderful city, starting at Old Town Square, and it will soon be yours too!
Excellent, astronomical clock tower is a must see. One of the best spots in Prague.......good for spending the evening in the old town square, followed by beer at one of the roadside pubs

One of my favourite places. The Old Town Square is dominated by the amazing church of Our Ladfy before Tyn, with multiple spires that is absolutely beautiful. Elsewhere in the square is the old town hall with an impressive astronomical clock (free) and a tower you can go up by lift (admission fee) for views over the rooftops in all directions. Around the square are attractive facades - mostly hotels and shops - and in the square there is always a crowd of tourists, and often entertainment such as musciains, mimes, food stalls etc. Definitely a "must" for any trip to Prague.
Old world charm. Nice place to enjoy some free time to relax and unwind whilst enjoying the old world charm Prague has to offer with some great eateries to select from.
Ahh, Europe. The squares in Europe are so lovely. This one is no exception. Everywhere you look there is something magnificent, old, historical, magical. It's just a wonderful place to sit and enjoy.
Lovely and lively . Magnificent architecture with bright color inspires joy and happiness.restaurants.cafes and pubs are busy with tourists also lots of shops .it is very entertaining

Perfect cury. Perfect place to sit, eat crepes and watch the world go by! Always so much going on in old town square. Grab a coffee in a bar and people watch or grab a wine, get under a blanket in the outdoor seating area and watch the clock!

FOOD - VENDORS - LOTS OF PEOPLE - FUN - BUSY. We visited Prague in late March - which we thought would be the low season. What a surprise when we arrived - it was the local schools two week break. It was busy!! We had a nice time visiting the Old Town Square and talking to some local people. We enjoyed some of the local delicacies and purchased some of the local crafts. There are lots of cafes, bars and restaurants around the square if you need a little break. We had a nice visit.
Place to be. In the heart of Prague, its a beautiful square with lots of fine dining restaurants where you can try local czech cuisine
Hustle and bustle. Atmosphere wasn't great here especially being 2 young girls felt very out of place, people would stop and stare at us. It's definitely a mans place.
Lively. Lively and lots to see.. the square is surrounded with brilliants cafes, restaurants and bars to rest those aching feet

Great place to chill out. Excellent place to spend a Sunday afternoon
Beer and some local food under the canopy
Place is active with entertainment and people

A must for any visit to Prague. Old Town Square is the central hub of activity. The buildings are breathtaking. the astronomical clock draws the crowds. In the summer, there's street music and entertainment. Plenty of pubs, shops and cafe's on each street that leads out from the square. Go see!

It's a square ... but a lovely one. not much to say except go and see and relax with a beer/wine etc... it is pretty...but it is after all, just a square :) If you've been to Belgium, Spain, Holland, France... well you get the idea
Beautiful buildings. A wonderful wander around a square of colourful beautiful buildings. A lot to take in so probably worth a second visit
Great Place To Be. There is so much energy and so much going on in this square. The astronomical clock is truly a sight and the atmosphere is great. Full of restaurants and cafeterias. Loved it!
To many restaurants. It is beautiful place, but you do not see much of it... The restaurants put everywhere gardens, so go in the night there...
Must to visit. If you have limited time and can only visit one place then this is the one in the city. Full of great things that must be explored on feet.
Best square in Prague. This is simply the place you must visit in Prague. The astrological clock is a wonder you have to see and the people watching is amazing.

Full of history. When visiting the old town square, don't be put off by the crowds. Have a good look at the buildings around you as they are full of history and are very interesting. We stayed in Prague for 5 days so ventured in to the square every day. If you have the chance stay for a drink at night when it's dark and quiet. The atmosphere changes from the hustle and bustle of day trippers.

Open area with circus like atmosphere. Restaurant encircled arena for street performers and horse drawn carriages alike surrounding a fountain which was under construction when we were there. Here's also where you can see the Astronomical clock.
Beer with a view. Great place to chill out with a beer, even if it is twise the price of every other pub. Best spot for people watching and that clock show if your interested.
Fabulous beautiful surrounds. The old town square is stunning beautiful,especially at night.We particularly enjoyed the light review in tribute to WW2 uprising & the end of the war
Great architecture. A great place to simply walk around and enjoy the buildings. Lots to see and explore. Highly recommended.

Beautiful old town with magnificent architecture!!. We rented a two bedroom condo in the heart of old town and everything's within the walking distance. There's the famous clock tower, hot street food, bars and people watching. I just love the magnificent architecture and coming here in the month of September but still couldn't avoid the crowd, that said a lot about the beauty of this old town. My friend once told me Prague is one of the most romantic city in his opinion. I have to agree with him except it is second to Paris, the city of love. I still remember there's a Starbucks in the heart of old town that's selling beers. We enjoyed walking around all day long for a few days with a lot of sight-seeing. It's a must-see charming old town when you're in Prague.
Fantastic square. A bit too crowdy occationally but such a lovely square. No matter what the plans are, we always end up here. Wish there weren't so many segways around.
magnificent. its one of a kind town in europe, i suggest December for a visit time becouse they build a christmas marken on the old town and ist wonderfull
Must see it. Everyone who travels to Prague must walk through the square. Stop and have a drink and people watch.

Great atmosphere. So much going on. Could have sat and people watched all day. Lots of interesting sights and smells. Hot food stalls gave price per100g which was quite confusing and more expensive than we thought.
Simply Beautiful. The atmosphere, the amazing history and architecture; the open air cafes and restaurants; the sense of invitation
Old Town Beauty. A great place to visit and dine. The charm of course is its historical buildings and magnificent architecture. A must place to visit.
Praha in under 5 days. See Astronomical clock. Eat, drink, enjoy. Buy garnets :) Don't forget to watch the amusing people in the Thai massage places having their feet cleaned by fish...... yuck

Graffiti. Graffiti was everywhere in Prague, honestly not what I expected. I had always envisioned it differently.
Generally the people are quite rude, they don't seem very happy with life at all.
Great atmosphere. It's just a fun area to hang around with the old buildings and the crowds and always something going on.

beautiful and timeless. Our trip coincided with Easter and though a tad crowded, the old town square with its fairy tale like ambience and easter market unfailingly made our hearts flutter. The smell of trdelniks, cinnamon and hot chocolate in the crisp wintry air along with the gay crowd and souvenir shops is a sight one cant easily forget especially the evening times. The crowd of tourists around the astronomical clock is always thick, hence the area is best avoided. Photographic options are best in the evenings. The restaurants in the square are always crowded. We loved walking the maze of alleys along the Old town square and discovering restaurants, souvenir shops and just soaking in the spirit of Prague. Prague is an incredibly beautiful city and the lesser known roads and alleys, cobblestone streets are more beautiful than the more well known cousins.

Must visit there. This is one of the most magnificent places in Prague, on your way to it you find lots of good selling markets and souvenirs, restaurants and coffees . in the central of the square you find street artiest preforming and in the most important the astronomic clock . don't missed it !!

Prague Old Town Square (Staromestske namesti). Obviously the Old Town Square is going to be full of tourists - I would be worried if it wasn't. Lots of stalls, musicians, beggars, and cafes, although be prepared for tourist prices, and interesting young people offering Segway tours - who doesn't want a go on a Segway - wish they had seats.St Tyn's is a gothic must see, but be prepared for big crowds in the Square (Prague seems popular with vast groups of Italian students, as well as even vaster groups of Chinese tourists on a noisy 2 week world tour) especially around the astronomical clock, which is a definite maybe for unreformed people watchers.What the Hell!!!Well worth a visit on numerous occasions

An incredible mixture of buildings and styles. Apart from the astronomical clock and its tower, there are enough buildings round the square to keep you amazed for hours. Sit and have a beer at one of the cafés or restaurants. Have a langos or sausage from one of the stands ...watch the musicians and jugglers perform... The only drawback is that there's not enough ordinary seating for people who just want to sit and watch without consuming something...
Easter market. Lots of stalls selling food and gifts for Easter, street performers and musicians. A very lively atmosphere.
If you are social.... The square is full of tourist, once I had seen it (the astronomical clock), I avoided the place. Reminds me Venice's St. Marcus square.Really beautiful part of Prague.

Can get pestered a bit..... Beautiful part of the city, with some lovely cafes (Cafe Mozart is one which I would highly recommend) however, there were occasions were sedway tours and pub crawl groups would pester to do their tours. Biggest tip....wear comfortable, flat shoes....The cobbles may look pretty,but they are a killer on your feet!! :)

Amazing atmosphere, beautiful square. Always when I have been there, even in the winter, there were street artists, musicians, and lots of people. The atmosphere is unforgettable. Also the sightseeing spots are amazing, towers, buildings, everything. Must visit if you are in Prague.
Lovely. Definitely worth a visit, I loved it. It had a great atmosphere and it has lovely cobbled streets going off it in every direction, you could spend hours wandering. The building are fab.
Has to be on your bucket list. Large open square with some fun restaurants and bars (open to the square) and can't miss the clock on the town hall. You will kick yourself if you miss it.

ESSENTIAL BUT CAUTION AND COMMON SENSE REQUIRED. This is one of the main hubs of tourist Prague and if you visit the city, then you should go. The architecture is beautiful and largely undamaged (apart from one side of the Old Town Hall). The astronomical clock is fascinating and there are individual buildings to see such as the Tyn church (a haven of peace and quiet but watch the opening times) and the Town Hall itself. The down side for me are the crowds - money exchangers (never ever use them), enforced street entertainment, prices that are too high etc. Like the Charles Bridge, the square is never quiet and usually has swarming crowds. Historical note - take a moment to look at the white crosses on the pavement outside the Old Town Hall and consider what happened there after the Battle of Bila Hora (White Hill).
Lively, with good food!. I like Old Town Square the most. During the day its filled with performers and food vendors. Great place to people watch!
historical. there was so much to see in this place, time just flew by and every visit to the square was eventful
Eclectic Heaven. Great fun place with history and culture. Bars and restaurants side by side with shopping and exuberance .
Under renovation. No astronomical clock and lots of the buildings being cleaned. The segways are everywhere as are poor street entertainment.

Be there or be square!. Surely everyone that has been to Prague has been to the Old Town Square which makes it, sometimes the throbbing heart of the City and at others an immovable mass of humanity, all crowded together to take pictures, videos and selfies particularly of the astronomical clock on the Old Town Hall and the gothic facade and towers of the 14th century Our Lady before Tyn. An obvious place to visit but best to time this for when the crowds thin out, to get the best views and impression of the square.
Must visit. A must see square in Prague. Gets very crowded but beautiful buildings all around. Good place to people watch

The heart of Prague. This is the heart of Prague. We were lucky to be there just before Easter so enjoyed the buzz, festivities and the Easter markets. It is surrounded by Astronomical clock and a couple of churches and looks really good. A climb to the clock tower is a must do. A visit to the town hall is also recommended.
great atmosphere. great atmosphere here day or night the clock is a must see, you have to be there on the hour to see it in action. did not eat in the square as it is expensive.

A nice square to walkabout. It is full of small local market stalls, buskers, street artists/performers, and even fire dancers.
Get your cameras out to capture the character of it's beauty day or night. :)
Old town square. The main area of the old town with lot of restaurant, cafe and very very crowded with people. Becareful with pickpockets.

See it at night (and beware the food vendors). We loved the clock, of course. There is plenty of action happening in the square, with living statues, fire eaters, singers, and tourists from all over the world. We loved the views at night, especially as there were fewer people and we could really enjoy watching the clock "show" on the hour. We walked through the shops around the square and generally enjoyed soaking up the vibe. We walked through even at 2 am as our hotel was close and felt totally safe. Of course you have to be aware of your surroundings, but the only time we felt at all uncomfortable was from a group of drunk tourists harassing me and making suggestive comments; otherwise, we were perfectly comfortable and safe.Do avoid the food vendors in the square, or at least read their signs CAREFULLY. We wanted to try the ham and the potato/cabbage mixture and ordered according to the prices, which were like 49 and 89 kroner. When our bill was 850, we were told it was because the price is for 100g (a portion, and we were given several of both items); when we requested to cut the portion size, we were told it could not be done. We could have walked away or argued but we just accepted it and paid the 850, considering our lesson learned. I wish we had been warned though, as $40 US was excessive for what we ordered. Still, we enjoyed the square and found the coffee and wine/beer vendors to be honest and friendly. By the way, the ham was very, very good, even though overpriced.

Great day out. Full of local market stalls, vendor shops, street artists and old world historical sites and attractions. You really need a full day to be able to explore and appreciate all the area has to offer. It is a vibrant place and gets very busy so it can be a challenge to navigate but the rewards are well worth it. A good way to explore it first up is with a City Walking Tour as the local guide provides a good audible history of the area and attractions. Also a great place to pick up a souvenir or two.
wow. We stayed right near the square it is as beautiful at day as it is at night. Great place to have a drink and take in all the street arts.

Nice ambiance . Beautiful place to wonder about and see the clock. There are many people offering segway tours just ignore them but if you want to go then try and barter as there are offer companies at other tourist hotspots like wenceslas square.
Lots of people day & night to view clock & Easter markets. Astronomical clock is fascinating and goes off on the hour from 6AM to 10PM. Views of entire city from top of tower.

Beautiful Place - Icon of Prague. No tourist will or should miss this place as this is at the centre and heart of Prague. Tyn Church built in 1389 stands there majestically reminding one of Harry Potter's Hogwarts. Astronomical clock established in 1410 nearby. Street entertainers including spraying of huge bubbles and musical performance with variety of instruments was lovely. As in any crowded place, just be careful with your belongings. Cobblestone pathways, Hot wine and Hot chocolate shops, restaurants occupy nearby areas. Walk for 5 minutes and you get the view of iconic Charles Bridge, Vltava river and scenic buildings including Prague Castle.
A must see.. If in Prague you will be drawn to the Old Town Square-an area of bustle, history, restaurants, bars and thousands of tourists-forget them, just enjoy the area.
Fun!. Old town square was hosting their Easter market, great place to buy trinkets and local food. We passed through it almost every day on our way to other sights.

Very appealing in the spring. I came to Prague just after Easter. Weather was great and the square was decorated for festivities. Very pretty. Suggest seeing the touristy bits of Prague in the middle of the week when folks are working.

Do yourself a favor.. This and most of the attractions in Prague are awesome, however if you really want to see them don't come on a weekend and don't come in April and May. The streets are filled with tourists and so crowded that it's hard to navigate. May is the busiest time in Prague according to our hotel manager. That said, do what Rick Steves suggests and look up at the architecture and the crowds won't take away the glory of the experience.

Allow Time to Savor the Atmosphere. Old Town Hall can be crowded and crazy, but stay and savor the moments. You are surrounded by various forms of architecture and the famous Astronomical clock where is it rumored that it's creator was blinded once it was finished so that it could not be duplicated. I recommend hitting the square at different times of the day. Catch it in the morning when it is quiet...in the afternoon when it is abuzz with activity, and in the evening when things are lit up. If you are weary from walking all over, grab a beer and an outside table at the Oliva Verde restaurant just across from the Clock. From there, if seated far enough over, you can enjoy the clock from a shaded, seated location while enjoying some food and/or beverages.Oh, and I love Rick Steve's suggestion of first watching the clock, and at the next hour go to the base of the clock and watch the people. The "show" doesn't last long, but it is an amazing feat for the 1400's.
Love it. Busy, busy area with lots of vendors, fun foods, cafe's....shopping... and tons of people. Street performers were pretty cool, too.

Looks just like disney world!. Great location, astronomical clock was excellent, our hostel was just round the corner so really convenient. There is always something interesting or exciting going on such as live street music and especially tours. The tours are really good because my friend and I wanted to see the castle, jewish cemetery and the general history of the Prague. What was great about staying at our hostel in old town it allowed us to meet many young travellers who want to sight see and go out and night and get boozy! I highly recommend clock tour pub crawl and my absolute favorite Drunken Monkey

Don't buy the street food!. Lovely square, beautiful clock, but don't touch the street food. There are wooden type cabins selling Prague ham and beer. On my first day bought the ham, a beer and a bottle of water. It cost 690CK, about £20, total rip off. And had to eat it sitting on the ground. The most by a long shot that I had spent in Czech Republic.

My favourite place in Prague. Although I visited the old town square two times before, it never fails to leave an impression upon me. Not only is the square impressive, the side streets are equally impressive. I was lucky it was not massively crowded as in my previous visits, and the relative calm added to the charm.

A lovely place to wander. I lost count of how many times we visited the square in a three day visit - it would be hard to avoid it. But it really is a beautiful place. I think I'd hesitate to enter any of the restaurants around the square without having read the reviews first. We went down most of the streets branching off the square, and while there were obvious differences them, they were all charming.
INCREDIBLY packed. If Old Town is packed, imagine the epicenter of Old Town. The buildings are beautiful but for me it was not really a place I want to go back to.
History before your eyes. A fascinating old square with plenty to see, with shops, restaurants and bars, also a good market. I particularly enjoyed the astronomical clock.
Vibrant. Plenty of activity always something going on. Attractions all around and a nice cool beer to round it off.

Nice atmosphire. Alot of vistors, might be crauded around round hours... (due to the monumental astro watch)
Very vibrant, sreet artist a lot of restorants turistic trap. ...

Walk about in Prague. The clock is a must and the finger food in the square is very nice,
There are some very good Resterants with loal food.

Abslutely wonderful place to "get lost". Just go off the main streets and explore the side alleys. Get lost and find yourself again. Venture beyond and walk to Charles Bridge and across to Prague Castle.

Great Place to visit at anytime. This place is a must to visit and looks great no matter what the time is.
There is plenty of things to seem and many activities going on in the local area.

Beautiful but be aware of vendors . We visit this place for a second time in our vacation. First with a tour guide from the ship and second on our own. In the second we try the local and well recommended Chez Ham rotisserie they sell in the plaza and a couple of beers and sausages. One of the vendors try to sell us a piece of ham for 469 CZ KC which is close to $20.00 dollars. When we request a portion they have in their menu they don't want to sell us that portion and we left. Then we visit another local that was only 20 feet from this one and we ate the portion we want for only 89CZ KC which was like a half pound of meet and very good. About the taxi drivers we re comes a AAA taxi company and although they are most efficient and trusty , some of them not like to put the meter, just be alert. Until my next review.
The best beer and sousages ever:). Place to spend all day. Looks great 24 hours. Always busy, but very clean. Lots of restaurants as well.

One of the best in Europe. I am a sucker for picturesque squares. There a many fine examples across Europe from the Place des Vosges in Paris to Heroes square in Budapest. Staromestske namesti is crammed full of lovely architecture, great cafes and of course the astronomical clock. It is a must visit sight for any tourists in Prague. I still visit it regularly and I live here!

Easter market. Lots of interesting vendors with foods and crafts. Music and decorations were very festive. Nearby astronomical clock was amazing. Vendors were sometimes very impatient with a tourist unfamiliar with the currency and I am pretty sure one cheated me on my change.

Could sit here all day!. Such a beautiful square that is always busy and always has something going on (either buskers playing music or blowing bubbles etc). Lots of stalls surrounding and plenty of places to grab a bite to eat (however, note that food here is generally more expensive than in other areas as it is so touristy)! Could pull up a chair and sit and watch this square from sunrise to sunset.

Lively. This is truly a bustling and unavoidable part of Prague it is great to stroll through, grab a bite in or just people watch. There is always something going on from a street performer to a festival. I suggest grabbing a snack and sitting on a bench or step and just taking it all in!

Crowded tourist mecca. Stopped because of the fantastic Easter decorations all over the plaza. This was tourist zone central, very crowded and not our cup of tea. We walked around and took some pictures, grabbed a snack. Lots of stalls to buy food and trinkets.

Fun Visit. A square with plenty happening. It's fun to people watch and enjoy the sights. Quick tip: don't eat or drink in the square unless you want to pay a lot more for the same type of food or drink readily available throughout Prague.
Heart of old town. A. Nice walk in the evening with street food, people are shopping busy spending their evening. All high end retail shops are around here
Never a dull moment. Loads of entertainers to keep you interested. Also a great place to relax, have a bite to eat and have a refreshing Pilsner

NIce place with huge activity. Staromestske namesti is probably my favourite place in Prague. There are very nice buildings, all along the square. It is nicely illuminated at night, and there are foodstalls where you can buy a (typically Czech) snack. A lot of services are proposed on this square (Segway, Bike-taxi), but without the pushy aspect you find in other cities.Of course there are also a lot of cafés and restaurants on the square.
Busy and lively atmosphere. Don't miss the top of Two Hall. lots of tourists and busy atmosphere. We climbed the old townhall and city looks very beautiful from there.

The Astronomical Clock and a lot of History and Entertainment!. A lot of history here in the old town square. Do not miss the astronomical clock! It is worth the time and money to go up into the tower for the view.Lots of entertainment in the square with many places to eat and drink there or on the side streets. Also lots of souvenir shopping in the area!

Be stunned by the view. Old Town sq is where the heart of tourism starts in Prague. You'll find the odd carriages with horses, the groups of Korean & Chinese waiting with the camera's till the special clock changes the time, loads of terraces and great views of churches all around. You might even say that one of them looks a lot like the towers of the Harry Potter movie ! Get to higher ground to see Prague's rooftops and have a drink (U Prince Roof Cafe & Bar), but don't eat there. Get to Ambiente Pasta Fresca within 2min walking from old town sq.

a title?. This is Praha for all visitors...It's not all of Praha but all of Praha end up here.....You cannot go to Prague and not visit Old Town Square..Touristy ? Perhaps..... But ten again I was a tourist !

Go somewhere else. Prague is an endlessly interesting city, so don't bother spending too long here. It's difficult to avoid if you are exploring the old town, and it's not unpleasant as such, but crowded, noisy and lined with tatty shops. Move on.

Like a farytale. Astornomical clock,many different types of traditional food and drinks to buy and tourists everywhere. Amazing place which is a must if you chose to visit Prague. Highly recommend it!

Must see before 1pm. Beautifull square with a lot of architectural buildings from different eras. If you want to see the old clock, go there as early as possible. It works every hour but after 1200 hours the square gets over crowded. If you survive the sedgwick tours running all over , you deffinetly wont survive the enormous amounth of tourists.

Very Happening Place. It is a very lively place where every tourist visits during their stay in Prague. It is surrounded by a lot of Cafes, Bars and restaurants. You can easily spend 4-5 hours at this place. Lots of fun things happen and families can have a grand time here. The astronomical clock tower is the main attraction here
Such a wonderful range of buildings to admire. The Old Town Square is the 'Jewel In the Crown ' of Prague. Great to wander around and just look at the beautiful buildings that surround it.
worth a visit. amazing place with too many tourist. The clock is worth a look at, but if you love old buildings you should not miss this place.
Bustling and fun. Street vendors, cafes, sights, street performers - seemed busy at all hours! Great site for people watching, having a meal or drink, and enjoying the architecture.

A Must!. You can't go to Prague and not visit the Old Town Square. It's always buzzing and surrounded by plenty of shops, restaurants and attractions. There's also plenty to see with dozens of street performers and whilst we were there they also had a a large stage setup with bands playing every so often. One thing to note is that some of the bars and restaurants in the square charge higher prices to sit outside than inside.

Easter Market. As Squares go there was plenty of entertainment around. Easter market was unique l expect the Xmas market would be as good. Buskers everyday especially the firedancers. Buildings are lit at night and plenty of restaurants. We saw it when it was cold, snow and wet the summer months they say are the best

Must see. beautiful location, lots of food stands and an amazing tower for a .
panoramic view
Every hour the clock at the main square is a very big attraction- go check it out!
Great area. You can spend a day just enjoying the sights of old town. Easy place to shop as well you don't get hassled like you might in some great cities.
Fun to walk around. We did not buy any food but there was plenty. We did buy some jewelry. Lot's of junk for sale but it was pretty inexpensive. It's fun to people watch. The clock is down there.

Just Plain Fun. Prague's main square is 2 blocks from the Staromestske metro stop, and there is always something going one. I was there a couple of weeks ago on a Saturday afternoon. I just happened to show up in Prague after a business trip to discover the Prague Half Marathon was that day. The square was packed with after race people and tourists, and there were lots of kiosks selling food, lace items, candy, and wooden nick-nacks. I had a late lunch at one of the outside restaurants while waiting for the Astronomical Clock to strike, and enjoyed watching the people. Tons of shopping all around the square, incredible architecture, just an amazing place in general to spend an afternoon. I love Prague. Oh, and beer is cheaper than water! My entire lunch, including 2 beers, was about $10 USD.
A fairy tale square. So wonderful especially at night. The only thing we didn´t appreciated were the sportive stands disturbing the views.

Beautiful. I was there for the easter market. It was very very pretty and full of life. The market stalls were great and the food was good too. The whole place is very picturesque and you feel very immersed.

Beautiful but too crowded in this season. The church and the clock are the nicest parts of this plaza.Beware of the stalls selling ham - although they price by 100gr, they refuse to sell you only 100gr (you know just to taste) - same trick in Budapest! You end up paying a price higher than a nice restaurant for cold ham.

Amazing Prague. i was only once in Czech . i loved Prague. i stay only 1 night in Prague. in very nice Barok style hotel. was very high price of course. will never forget this city. So magnificent place . so romantic. i had business dinner in Panorama. So beautiful view from up to Prague.
Interesting, plasant and beautiful.. Spent time here on two separate days during Christmas Market. Everyone and particularly locals are friendly and helpful. Hope to return on a future trip.

Must see when you are in Prague.... What I liked most about this area was the architecture and fun street vendors. It is like nowhere else that I have been in the world. The smell of wood burning fire heating up local foods was too much to handle! It was so wonderful and special. The trinkets to purchase were actually quite neat and not like typical tourist trap places.

One of the three centers of Prague. This square is like any other square of other European cities. There is much on offer on the streets connected to Square than on Square. You will find Czech Traditional foods and shops on the square. Once you keep moving out of square, you will find the multi nation brands.If you are a christian, there are a lot of cathedrals you need to admire.

Entertaining. Loved the old clock have waited since I was a child to go and see it. Not disappointed The entertainment around the square was delightful. Found a very nice cafe in the square to enjoy some gorgeous local foods and sample the beer too
Surreal. Lovely square, always something going on, and its a goldmine for stunning buildings. We were there for easter market which gave it even more atmosphere. You can't miss it!
A must see.. It is Spectacular! Wear good walking shoes as you are continuously drawn down side streets to see what's around the next corner. Lots of eye candy if you love architecture.
Travelling back in time!. Stunning place, especially at Easter. A lovely place to visit and well worth a visit. You won't be disappointed

love this square. love sitting in this square having a coffee and watching the world go by lovely square lots of restaurants, horse and carriage rides, always something going on to watch musicians etc

Romantic. Prague is always a romantic city for me. This is my 3rd time visiting Prague and i always loved it. The Old Town Square is one of the most romantic place for me personally. I can picture myself and my husband walking and holding hands at the Old Town Square. I do have the pictures of myself and my friends visiting Old Town Square.. Beautiful..

Easter Market. Visited the Old Town Square at the end of March and there was an Easter Market going on which attracted all kinds of people - local and tourists. They was serving traditional praguecusine and there's was a music show by some local bands and schools. The area is surrounded by some beautiful buildings and attractions like the astronomical clock. Also lots of restaurants, cafes etc. All in all, it's a must go place if in Prague.

The Center. This square has plenty to see and eat. There are vendors with their carts selling everything from sausages to pastries in the very center. There are other carts selling kitchy tourist items. The clock tower is at one end, make sure to be the on the hour to see the apostles come out and the rooster crow.This square is also popular for meeting a tour guide. We met out free walking tour guide there.
Overrated. The astronomical clock is over rated. It is very interesting to see how many details it has, but the "show" every hour is so minimal.

Excellent "free" walking tour!. Went and took s free walking tour today, provided by Sandeman's Free Walking Tours. We chose the 3 hour historical tour. What a GREAT surprise! Our guide, Filip Huta, was extremely knowledgeable, and witty to boot. Midway through the tour we stopped to eat at Zephy'rs, a restaurant that featured local Czech food and beer. You also got a chance to coordinate and book other tours they offered as well.My expectations were truly exceeded and will most definitely use them to book other tours on return trips to Prague and other cities where Sandeman's operates. I put "free" in quotation marks because if you feel that your your was worth it, you are (lightly) encouraged to tip based on your experience. You will want to tip...and tip generously, as the tour was that thorough! The devil is in the details and we received so many details on historical tidbits, it was amazing. Again, look for Filip Huta for your guide!
Disappointingly overcrowded. Expected way much more. You can't even make a decent photo because the square is overcrowded with tourists & food stands.

Many different things to see in one area. You can spend hours here admiring the buildings. The astronomical clock is also a highlight. Just walking around here admiring the buildings and window shopping is also quite fun.

Extremely Touristy. It's old. It's cute. It's touristy. It's central. Filled with an olde village market, it's cloying, but what you would expect. The best part was the little petting corral (I was there right before Easter).

Gorgeous surrounded by beautiful buildings. We were fortunate to be there just after Easter so everything was geared up to celebrating that. Wonderful little food stalls in addition to the normal restaurants and cafes.

Historical and Beautiful Town Square. If you go to Prague, the town square is a place you definitely need to end up! There are a lot of historic building and great photo opportunities. I didn't spend anytime in the shops, but there was a lot of shopping areas as well, so this area fits everyone's travel needs. Don't forget to stop and watch the clock it is world famous!! The day I went there were a lot of food vendors, I would definitely recommend trying the Ham they have roasting on the side, with a good beer! Like most of Prague, the square is crowded with tourists, Like Me! The square is one of the prettiest in Europe and I recommend this if in Prague!

Beautiful visit at Easter. Highly recommend coming to Prague at Easter to visit the markets here in the square. Lots of craft stalls to buy hand painted Easter eggs amongst other things as well as live entertainment - I thoroughly enjoyed the school children choir that sang and the animals you could feed.... Lovely to wander around in the sunshine. Try the Tredlenik - a traditional sweet pastry that we fell in love with and would go back to Prague for specially! You can find it all over the city.
Historical. Historical location. Lovely atmosphere and lots of restaurants and stalls to visit. Recommend a visit, very interesting.
Very nice square. The main square of prague.Very touristic but still worth seeingLots of restaurants and terraces.However the astronomic clock was a disappoinment
Great square.. This is a wonderfull square, with alot of things nearby. Try to go there both ind daytime, and nighttime. At easter and Christmas there is a market there, with lot of things.

Must do in Prague. We visited the place on easter week-end. It was full of tourists and food cabins like on a christmas market.
Very nice atmosphere!

fantastic atmosphere. we visited during easter and the there was an easter market and it was so fun! full of people and laughter, lots of food stalls with lovely smells and people selling souvenirs. its surrounded by beautiful czech buildings. go have a look

It is a beautiful place!. It is a beautiful square. It is nice to sit in a corner and enjoy the atmosphere of this old part of the city.There are also a lot of junk food's option in the middle of square :)

Has an ancient feel to it. The square is just like any ole square you can find around Europe. I do love the fact that all the buildings are preserved and it still looks like how to would have been in the olden days.

Fantastic Place. Prague is a magic place with cheap and fancy restaurants and stores. In this particulary place, you can find great cafes where to spend a great afternoon. It is a place that all the tourists will visit because it works like a reunion point where everyone will go to see the astronomical clock prague. :)
Lovely place...

Summer = beautiful, busy. Winter = Christmas markets!. It's such a beautiful place to just....be! Sit on a bench and people watch, or wander around and take pictures! It's just so lovely! I've been here both in winter and summer. Of course, it is invariably busy during the summer. Over Christmas, it has amazing Christmas Markets, with amazing booths of trinkets, crafts and food, and a stage with music playing. Don't miss the trdelnik (a dough baked over hot coals and rolled in sugar, cinnamon and nuts) at Christmas! I ate a lot of them! So yummy! The Astonomical Clock is beautiful, but sometimes difficult to get a good picture because of so many tourists around. Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful Place. Old Town square is an amazing place - it is beautiful and has a lovely atmosphere with so many different people, musicians and street entertainers. It is a very romantic place at night when it is all lit up.
Very nice easter exhibitions. Many small shops, specially opened for easter was a good site to see . Lots of beer to drink . Only downside is too crowded.

Magically. We went their on the eve of Easter, it was all decorated. Really amazing.We also visited hired a horse cart to see the old town, one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. The restaurants here are really over priced but offer great food.

Best square in town!. There were food & wine stalls, a viewing platform, restaurants, art gallery, the place where you can do a horse-drawn carriage tour, the astronomical clock, a tourism centre to ask questions, and lovely architecture.

A visit not to be missed. There is something for everyone around the square, we visited the Andy Warhol exhibition. There is a variety of market stalls selling cinnamon rolls, chocolates, meats etc .Enjoy strolling around and either shopping or soaking up the culture. There are plenty of tourist information signs and we had no problems finding our way around the sights.

Beautiful but full of tourists. A beautiful square and well worth the time to walk through. Understandably though it is full of tourists, Segways, and other variously obnoxious tour groups. Don't stop at the cafes, find a better place for a drink and a meal. We were fortunate enough to go during the Easter season and there are a boat load of craft and food stalls. Everything was decorated festively for spring.

Beautiful architecture. The architecture is stunning and the outdoor markets selling local food including Prague ham cooked over timber was excellent. The astronomical clock presents well but for the life of me I can't understand what all the fuss is that results in literally hundreds of people waiting there each hour to see the clockwork display.Prague is a beautiful city with great people. The biggest problem is that its success results in too many tourists. In the town square and other regular tourist haunts such as the castle it feels like a cattle market.

Very Beautiful - 5 Stars. We went as group of 5 and we really enjoyed walking the around Old City Prague. There were many souvenir shops nearby, people from that city are very friendly and the city itself is very beautiful. Overall: 5 Stars

Very beautiful place, but occasionally the service is not very friendly. The Old Town Square is the perfect place to go after a long day of touring, when all you want to do is grab a pint of the local beer, and watch the local people. I have been here three times, and while the overall experience is great, I have found the the people working in some of the bars and cafes ringing the square are a bit aloof or downright unkind to tourist. They have a captive audience, they know you will come, and don't feel the pressure to give good customer service. I know that European standards of customer service are lower than US standards, but my customer service at a few of the cafes stood out to me as lower than average even for Europe.
Tick tock. Great architecture and lively atmosphere. Don't miss astronomical clock.Bars/restaurants more expensive than away from this tourist area.
Beautiful. One the main attractions in Prague. Really gorgeous square. However, stay away from the restaurants there and go to the ones in the side alleys - much better and cheaper.

Very Medieval. Has a feel of times gone by and great place for photo's .lots of bars and cafe around but i was very unimpressed by the 'fare' on offer ... very bland not a lot of choice, that was 10 years ago now so I guess things will have changed.Poor customer service was also order of the day and didn't see many locals smiling ...perhaps they are now ?Bought some lovely antique garnet ear rings and loverly amber only to discover a couple of years later you can get it imported from Prague in New York a lot cheaper ! Worth bearing in mind if you are a city traveler xanother

Overpriced. Everything was way overpriced. Beer was 80 crowns (3 euros). Too busy and loud. Nothing really special. Everything there can be found elsewhere at a fraction of the cost. Some of the people advertising the tours (especially the segway tours) were very irritating and sometimes even scary if they suddenly jumped in front of you. The astronomical clock was beautiful, if sometimes overly crowded. Try to go earlier or later in the day.

take the free walking tour by Keith. worth going to and do take the walking tour by 'Keith' - its free of charge and gives one a comprehensive overview old town, jewish quarter, adjoining parts of new town
Amazing city!
You can't miss it. Obviously a place you can't miss when you are in Prague. Lots of people and lots of life. Try some food or hot wine from one of the many booths. Or try the hot chocolate.

Really beautiful - a must see in Prague. The old town square is fantastic. It's a must see in Prague, there are a huge number of lovely markets selling everything from clothes, to food to souvenirs. The square has a lovely ambience, lots of musicians playing and people rambling around. It's also right beside the clock which is a very popular tourist attraction. Lots of coffee shops and restaurants on the square too if you want to sit and watch the world go by.

A place to revisit many times.. The Easter market was on so had a special atmosphere, lots to look at. Go at night as well as the day as it is magical, Wouldn't eat there though, go off the square for better value menus.

Beautiful and busy. Very busy square lots of people lots of things happening lots of things to see... everything is pretty! I love to just stand in the middle staring at the surroundings and absorbing everything!

Wonderful architecture and people!. Old town square in Prague is a beautiful tourist attraction, especially if there is a festival or gathering. There is also a lot of street food here. The pork that is cooked on the street here is first class. Go enjoy Prague, it is small for a European city and walkable in a weekend.
Easter weekend. Amazing tour for the most attractive part of the city the guide well prepared, beautiful city quite cold in this time of the year but totally worthy
lovely. i liked the little food stalls selling hot food and drinks expecially the mulled wine. i disliked how it wasnt easy to understand where old met new

A magnificent place to watch the world pass by.. A beautiful & culturally rich square, with caffee's & restaurants spalled all around as well as magnificent historic buildings. A place to relax & take some time to breath. The only problem is the people attempting to make you buy random trinkets. When all you want is to do is have a drink or something to eat. It's not just people on the street, some of the restaurants are sending people around with cameras taking a shot of you & trying to charge for a crap magnet. Stay away from them & you won't have a problem.
Wonderful piece of history. The square is BEAUTIFUL! It is alive with people. Performers, cafes, lounging, walking, you could spend hours in the square watching people!

Happy Easter in Prague!.. Our trip to Prague was for 10 days and without knowing of our perfect timing we were there for the 3 day long Easter celebration held in the square, it had stalls, parades, a stage for singers, local entertainment, and getting to eat the local food and mingling with people all over the world, a really amazing experience as is Prauge itself, the Astronomical Clock is on the Square also which is a must see for its on the hour show, not much of a show but the history and atmosphere is enough in itself.

Visit during Easter Fair. Nice plaza but quite crowded, especially with the Easter Fair in place. There were many nice historical buildings and numerous restaurants around for you to spend at least a day.The Easter Fair looks fun with many stalls selling traditional foods and stuff. But that also made the plaza more crowded so beware of pick-pockets.

Long weekend. Looks like we hit lucky. Plenty to see and do because of the Easter market in and around the square and other parts of Prague central. It was our first time in Prague and wasn't sure what to expect but thoroughly enjoyed it. I would recommend staying central with everything in walking distance. A1+++

Overall great experience. Prague is definitely one of the more beautiful cities I have been to and this square is a major reason why. Look out for the traditional ham food vendors in the square though. They advertise the ham and potatoes by the 100 gram portion but then push you on minimum order requirements and before I knew it my lunch had cost me 700 koruna (about 30-35 Canadian $)
a good place to visit during Christmas. We went there during Christmas. There is a very big Christmas tree in the middle of the square. It's very beautiful.
Great Eiropean Square. A greatEuropean square with places to eat, drink, shop and people watch. Beautiful at night when all lit up.
A happening place with lots of activities.. The astronomical clock and various style architecture make the square an interesting place to visit.

Easter markets in full swing. The square has a really nice ambience about it especially at this time since it is all decorated for Easter and there are market and food stalls all around.Too many segways around nowadays though.....what's wrong with your feet?And don't get me started on those flippin selfie sticks which nearly poke your eye out on every turn!!Back to the square though it is lovely, but my tip for eating and drinking - go one or two streets back and everything is much cheaper and calmer and you can find some lovely cafes.
Anticlimax!. We stood for 25 minutes waiting on a clock doing something interesting. It didn't!Otherwise this is a lovely place & worth a wander-round whilst in Prague.
Do not miss. This is probably why you're in Prague. Take your time to browse, it's worth it. Take in one of the nightly concerts. Good times.

A Must See. It can get really crowded, but you have to check out this beautiful square while you are in Prague. It is nice to sit for a bit and enjoy a coffee to take it all in if you have time. Make sure to see the clock and Tyn Church.
Nice area to walk around and eat and shop. Enjoyed the marketplace with the local crafts, food, and shops. Cute town square to spend some time. Purchased many souveniers here
easter market. seeing the clock tower was wonderful but the Easter market was taking place and was a real treat. beautiful Easter eggs, flowers, food,
Beautiful. Old, beautiful, but overcrowded square. The beautiful churches. The old astronomical clock. Markets, shops, restaurants.

Old Town Square. Old Town Square is a wonderful place where history was made. There are many important building and pleasant. Monument of Master Jan Hus (famous religious reformed, who critised the Church), the work of Ladislav Šaloun, was unveiled in 1915 in the midle of the Old Town Square to mark the quincentenary of Hus´s death at the stake in Constance.
Beautiful. Bustling with tourists, the Old Town Square is really beautiful, nice to walk around or to sit and have a drink.

Crazy about Prague!. You can't go past how busy Prague is by day and by night. It's abuzz with entertainment, segues, stalls, cafes and restaurants all around. Make the most of your time here. If I only I stayed an extra day!

Beautiful Location. The Easter Market was in full swing during our trip. Loads of stalls full of local foods and beers. The town square itself is surrounded by beautiful architecture and loads of restaurants and bars to grab a bite to eat and a drink. Easily spend half a day wandering around exploring.
Beautiful and fun!. Large square surrounded by beautiful buildings. We went here when there was an easter fair and had so much fun.

A great urban space. A favorite urban space, the square is commodious and surrounded by interesting architecture and the brooding Tyn Church. The old city hall and the wildly popular astronomical clock anchor the opposite side of the square. A standard gathering place for visitors plus nice people watching at the al fresco restaurants.
The jewel of Prague. I never tire of watching the astronomical clock strike the hour. Be sure to go up in the clock tower for a great view of Prague.

Disney in Prague!. Maybe the hot March sun (when we'd been promised cold and wet) made it special, but the Old Town Square is just breathtakingly beautiful. The astrological clock is the main attraction, but all the buildings are gorgeous. The square was full of stalls bedecked in Easter decorations for us, with entertainers, beer stands, hot pork sandwiches (scummy) and huge crowds (watch for pick pockets). Marvelous huge Art Nouveau sculpture in one corner. This and the Castle are the best parts of Prague. Avoid the pricey shops and cafés though!!!
Lots to see and do. The square is typical of town squares. There was lots of entertainment, great street vendors and restaurants on the periphery. A great place to people watch.

Easter Market. We did not realise that Easter was such a special time but really enjoyed the market in the square and the entertainment all for this time of year. Not as expensive as others I have been to around Europe!

The heart of Prague. It is where you have connections to all major parts of the Praha, Prague. It is around 300m away from the main metro station, Mustek, and is around 15min walk away from Charles bridge. There are nice restaurants around with some stores offering you the great glassware from Czech. To me, it is all Prague is about. Actually, I started my journey there. I crossed this square a thousand times to reach other places of attraction. You only need to walk over there and feel it. You can fix all your appointments from here :)

Easter Market was the final ingredient. We were there 23/27 March 2015 the market made it very atmospheric. Try the sausages hmm. The clock is very impressive 500 years old. It must be a holiday in Italy as there were hundreds of Italian students

easter market. By chance the Easter market was just setting up. there is a great array of stalls selling lots of different Easter type decorations etc. Lots of good street food stalls and of course being the Czech republic beer stalls. From the square there are tours available by bus, vintage cars or walking. The walking tour is unusual in that they do not ask for money up front. At the end the guide will ask you to pay what you thought it was worth. Our guide was Karel. A very knowledgeable and funny guy. We saw all the sights on a 3 hour tour which includes a stop for lunch/drinks
Great place to sit and watch the world go by. This was especially great as they had a Easter market when we were there, lots of stalls and lots of cafes to stop at after all your walking

So many amazing buildings. Climb to the top of the tower if you are fit enough enjoy the views of Prague if you are lucky enough to find a market there as we were enjoy the atmosphere and food and drink

Very pretty. We were here during the Christmas Market and the square was filled with lovely stalls selling great quality Christmas decorations, gifts and foodstuff. Many stalls with hot mulled wine and mead.Lots of choice of restaurants here too.
very popular. very popular area,always busy. didnt get to see the square in full as it was full of colouful market stalls ready for easter, loved the clock and the ringing of the bell

Architecturally exquisite but .............. The market distracts from the joy of the buildings and creates a tacky feel. It obviously takes full advantage of the earning potential for local businesses, but one quick look was enough for me. We found much more interesting and quiet squares to enjoy.

Must visit. Yes the square is tourist; but we were tourists! There was a pre Easter festival going on with kiosks offering hot mulled wine, beer, sausages and ham cut from huge hams on spits, baked goods, and if that wasn't enough restaurants all around the square. Everywhere you go in Prague there are spectacular architectural sights and statuary, and the old town square is a good place to just take in the richness.
Easter Market. Good shopping experience and street entertainment.Large crowds on the hour for Astronomical ClockGood coffee and cakes, but expensive for Prague

Old Town Square. Just the best place to be to get a real feel for Prague. Lots happening in the square throughout the day and evening..as other reviewers have noted. But do avoid the cafes in the square as they can be very expensive. A short stroll to any side street will get you the same at a much more reasonable price.We travelled in October. The weather was great and the crowds much reduced. Good time to visit.

so much to see. So much going on in such a small place, food from the stalls sausages, hog roast and chicken kebabs were excellent value and tasted good, and all washed down with hot"Kingswood Cider" from the cider hut. Lots of decorated clown eggs and cotton items to buy. will most certainly visit again

A place where people gather. This square is famous for the astronomical clock which plays every hour. Many people come to watch the event. The clock in in the church tower which can be climbed or for the less energetic the lift provides quick access to the top.

The most beautiful square in the world. The Old Town Square in Prague is poetic, historic, romantic, and beuatiful in the day time and night time. It is simply the most beautiful square I have seen. You can find here Gothic buildings, Rennaisance buildings, Art Nouveau statue of Jan Hus in the middle of the square and many nice houses built in the beginning of the 20th century, but also houses with cellars from the Roman period. There is the Astronomical Clock - a must see attraction for everyone and also the beautiful Tyne´s Cathedral a stunning Gothic building with slim spires. This is significant especially for Danish tourists, as the Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe is burried here. There are also many cafés and restaurants. You pay though for this phantastic location....

Beautiful place, fantastic Easter festival. We visited around Easter time and there were lots of stalls selling food drink and handmade items. Lovely place, quite busy. Lots of shops and restaurants around.

Beautiful buildings. We visited the square on numerous occasions as it appeared to be the hub of the city. There were loads of restaurants, bars, shops and a market. We sat in one of the bars all afternoon and watched the astranomical clock (where crowds gathered every hour on the hour to watch the chimings). There was also a wedding which was interesting. Only downside - price of the beer! Much cheaper elsewhere but worth it for the people-watching!

There during Easter Market. What a lot of local vendors with attractive, local souvenirs! Don't be afraid to bargain, especially if you are buying multiple items! The Square itself is rustic, right in the middle of Old Town and gives a great sense of Prague in days gone by.

Beautiful. Really beautiful
Filled with people, sound, colors and live. Lots of restaurants and shops around the astronomical clock. If you have time: climb the tower of the old town hall, The view is worth it. (And there is an elevator)

Good place to visit. We visited her and loves all the little shops can get some good bargains
The place is full of history and great if you have plenty of time to view

A place to remember. The Old Town Square has plenty of things to see or to do , starting by admiring the famous Astrological Clock or beautiful buildings , with amazing facades in an authentic Art Nouveau style , continuing with a visit of Easter Fair in march or april, ending with a coffee or a beer in the restaurants nearby or even a lunch.Don't miss the chocolate shops, manufactured best quality chocolate ...yes , yes, here in Prague not in Swiss :)
A must see. Enjoy spending time in old town square nightly. Architecture, shops, restaurants, etc. it gets very crowded, but well worth the time spent there

Wish to go back to 18th Century?? Visit this place.. Everything about this place is beautiful and takes you back some 200 years in past. Astronomical Clock, singers playing in background, children playing with soap bubbles, food and drinks- what else is required for a beautiful evening!

The Heart of Prague. Old Town Square is truly the heart of Prague--a must to visit! Enjoy the wonderful architecture of the Tyn Church as you wait for the top of the hour to see the astronomical clock on the side of the Town Hall go into motion as the skeleton pulls the chain and the windows open to unveil the 12 apostles going around in circles, then the cock crows, and the bell chimes the hour. Old Town Square is the setting for the seasonal markets as well. I've visited both the Christmas and Easter Markets and especially love the Easter one with the uniquely decorated eggs.

Just beautiful. The view on the square is amazing, you just see historical buildings and they keep the street without any asphalt so you really feel you are in an old town square.On the pavement you can find 27 crosses. These crosses mark the 27 Protestants that where beheaded here for their believe by the Catholic king in 1621.And off course there is the astronomical clock.If I have one advice, if you want a coffee or a beer, just walk away from the square, just a few hunderd metres and the price will be half of what you pay on the square

Lovely bit of history. The old town square holds many historical tidbits to tickle your fancy. From the balcony where communism began and ended in the Czech republic to the famous astrological clock there is plenty to see and study. My only complaint about the square was the number of street performing human statues. There were at least 6 or 7 there, all with little noise makers in their mouths. Made what could have been an amazing place much less attractive.

Lovely Easter market in the square. if you travel to Prague in the run up to Easter the squares are filled with numerous sheds selling handmade Easter gifts and food and drink - a wonderful atmosphere for all

A must see!. Beautiful place. The Astronomical clock, all the buildings, architecture. Everything has its own charm.
Do not miss to try the Prague ham and halusky. Of course with a glass of beer.
Stalls,stalls and more stalls. Bright and colourful stalls selling everything from local food to souvenirs,great street entertainers,plus the Astronomical clock.
Must see!!. Loved all thebeautiful streets and buildings!! Just a must see area of Prague! So Fun watching all the people!

A lot of Prague flavor all in one place. It was the Easter festive when I was there. There was a lot of great food and performers. You are steps away from museums or a quite walk through the less traveled streets of Prague. Downfall is the crowds! It's wall to wall tourists and tours trying to suck you in. If you can avoid that, you have a chance to soak in some local flavors.
