Beautiful. One of the nicest squares in Europe. A must for all visitors to Prague. Beautiful in both summer and winter (for the Christmas markets which are great - although they cannot match those in Germany). Beautiful views can be had of the main square from the top of the town hall.
beautiful. the architecture, bars and restaurants. Very friendly people. We enjoyed the local food, shops and churches.

Tourist trap but a must do!. Its a real tourist trap and all the bars and restaurants are much more expensive than elsewhere but if you area a tourist I feel you just have to accept that and wallow in the fabulous views. Of course you must stand with everyone else to watch the clock. We loved it and it is really a must do .
Exciting. This is an exciting square because as well as the clock to see there is something happening throughout the day and night such as band entertainment etc.

Christmas Shopping.. Well laid out with a Christmas tree in the center. Communication was a breeze as all the stalls had people that could speak English. Loads of sights to see around the square as well.

You can feel old prague.. You can find many historical places, restaurants, Bars, and Souvenir shops. It's also the centre of nightlife in the area, and the clocktower in the centre puts on a bit of a show when it strikes the hour.

Christmas Market is one of the BEST in Europe!. The Old Town Square was the site of the Christmas Market. It was wonderful with crafts and food and drink! At night with all the lights it is really spectacular! A must see and do!
Old Town. Old town is a beautiful area of Prague with lots of little alley ways that lead where you least expect to end up.

Heart of the city. Loved the square and the astronomical clock, crowds gather to watch the saints parade just before the hour strikes, always a good cheer at the end! Take the lift up to the top of the tower for amazing views of the city and Bohemia. Beautiful buildings with carvings set up high on some of the walls. A walk early morning is worth doing before the crowds arrive to see the memorial stones set into the ground by the tower. Two large churches and a monument to Jan Hus, a religious reformer. Many bars and restaurants, street performers and tour touts. Tourist Office very good.

Bars, clubs but not for those on a tight budget. Nice place with regular street performers, but the bars,restaurants and clubs are quite expensive in this area. It's also the centre of nightlife in the area, and the clocktower in the centre puts on a bit of a show when it strikes the hour.

Best place to visit. Amusing place to visit. You can find many historical places, restaurants, Bars, and Souvenir shops. If you like antiques, or famous brands go around. Don't forget to visit the Clock Tower, and eat the Coulach soup in one of the out door restaurant located in the Old town Square....

Lively Square with centuries of history. From the Jan Hus statue, churches to visit, and entertaining street performers, this is a lively must see in Prague. Astronomical clock just on the side of the town hall. Lovely place to find a restaurant and just people watch or relax.. Something to see in every direction. The surrounding buildings are lovely.

Beautiful and historic architecture. The square was one of our first experiences of the town square that is common in different cities throughout Europe. It was beautiful and was amazing to think that there are buildings in this square alone that are significantly older than the very existence of the United States of America. I would recommend this as a must-see stop while in Prague. One more side point, at this time the Czech Republic is struggling with some economic challenges and we found the pricing of nearly everything we bought or experienced to be very reasonably priced.
Nice but busy. The place itself is absolutely gorgeous but full of tourists most of the day. Come early in the morning to feel real atmosphere of the place.
Must-see!. This part of town is so beautiful. There are random performances in the center, lots of restaurants and cafes surrounding the square, astronomical tower, and gorgeous architecture.

From Gothic to Art Nouveau. Variety of different architectural styles in the Old Town Square in Prague is astonishing! Take time to notice the details of the facades of the buildings, and do not hesitate to enter courtyards. When I'm there with my guests I encourage them to explore the "secret" corners which I discovered during my walks.

Lively and Fun!!!!. Old Town Square in Prague is one of the best town squares in Europe. The square itself is surrounded by beautiful Baroque-style buildings and leads to a series of side streets that contain a variety of shops and eateries. The historic Our Lady Under the Tyn cathedral dominates the square and makes for a picturesque setting as the sun goes down. The famous astronomical clock and Jan Hus memorial are worth checking out as well. But the real attraction, aside from singers, performers, and mimes, is the food. There are several great cafes where you can get a really good meal, but in my humble opinion, the street food is some of the best in Europe. Nothing beats a grilled sausage, a side of potatoes and ham, and a liter of fine Bohemian pilsner! Prague is a fun city, and the Old Town Square is a great place to start!

Old Town Square. Old Town Square is the very Heart and essence of Prague-Shopping, Street Entertainers, Astronomical Clock, amazing Architecture, The Meeting Place for most Tour Companies.If you miss old Town Square then you missed Prague!!!
Travel back in time. Its very crowded but so lovely and a nice experience to see the clock and just enjoy coffee and people watch
charming!. lovely place ! the astronomical clock is very beautiful.the place can be suite crowded , with a lot of tourists , people on segways, streetartist and occasionally a market !

People's square.. This large square is often filled with people. I was there in a huge party. Music, dance, beer (The Czech beer!!!!). Restaurants and the old church surrounds the square. A excellent idea for lunch. The astronomical clock is in a corner and must be seen!

Busy. There are lots of people doing their acts here, you can go around and watch them all, there are some really amazing (a balancing guy), creepy (a clown head), and musical (a Dixieland band) things to watch. Lots of people bugging you to join there tours, we got approached at least 10 times.

nice old town turned into giant shopping mall. The town buildings are beautiful and old but the sad thing is like many old towns in Europe, the "shopping" business corroded these old towns. There are too many stores many chains that you can find right at home. It was impossible to find something made in Czech Republic - everything was made in China junk.
pre-holiday/holiday season. The Old Town Square is gorgeous during holiday time at night. Totally worth a visit. At least once you should come to Prague in winter and see this spectacular scene.
breathtaking!. the rich history, architecture and breath taking astronomical clock. the cafes are quite good and the tour guides are very efficient.

It is what you expect it to be!. Of course you will visit the Old Town Square, and it is very festive and magical. It is full of interesting attractions and restaurants/cafes as well as a variety of street performers playing music, or dancing etc. Make sure to visit the Astronomical Clock on the hour, in order to see the little "show", but don't expect too much!

A Lovely Square with food/street entertainment and things of interest. Amazing Buildings, lovely relaxed atmosphere, food and entertainment(usual statue type people/live bands. take a walk down the various alleyways to see other local shops.

Magical. I have been to Prague twice in the past four years to visit the beautiful Christmas markets. My favorite is in the Old Town Square. In the evening, it is just breathtaking as the sun begins to set and the entire Square takes on a magical glow. The ambiance, the food, the drink, the crisp air and the cheerful crowds...it just doesn't get any better. I have never felt more in the Christmas spirit that when I was there. Loved it!
Excellent place. Liked : Very nice place with a lot of historical feel and intricate Bohemian architecture.Disliked : Transport is not so good in this place
PICTURE ESQ. Gorgeous square, full of fun and games and plenty of atmosphere. A real must to see.. Statues, stalls and little shops.... All very beautiful.
Beautiful Architecture. Loved the hotch-potch of building design. Also, the street musicians although the guys on segways were a bit intimidating.

In love with the lively, colorful Old Town Square. Welcome to one of the most colorful, lively, sunny cities of Europe. The square is full of people from all over the world. Some performing music, some standing as statues, some blowing huge bubbles, etc. Lot of Segway companies operates from here and definitely try one. The place is bustling with people, food stalls, other stalls and colorful buildings. Old Town clock is also here. The liveliness of this place will call you again and again.
Interisting to see. I'm not much of a history person so it was nothing spectacular to me. Won't visit again but it was interesting once so see though.
Busy square. Very busy with tourists, not that much to see except for the clock. All the restaurants and cafés around the square are very pricey.

Amazing interesting place. A lot to see and hear. The houses around are each different. If you look closely you will see a wall that remained and left from a ruined house that was used as an archive and was bombed during the war.

Crowded for Christmas Markets . . .. But worthwhile the huge numbers of people. Weather was fairly mild for December- we walked everywhere and were comfortable with layering clothing. Lots of displays and great food and drink in the different markets. Lovely city!

you will never go hungry !!. The square is surrounded by little shacks which each provided some form of hot food and drink. The smell was amazing and we had real trouble choosing which one to try out!!
The streets leading to the square were pretty and very well maintained and we felt as if we could walk anywhere without worry.
Lovely, romantic and busy!. The square is pretty much the same as any other but well worth a visit, The clock tower is worth seeing too :)

Historic and touristy. As with so many famous historical places I guess you have to share it with the masses with means tourism takes over. Apart from all the modern restaurants, shops and sight seeing tours there is still a lot of real old Prague to be discovered. A very safe place to walk around even at night time.
A must see. A very cute square with such a nice environment. The street food is really similar to Vienna and this caught my attention. I loved to see the architecture there too.
heart of Prague. Buildings,people,entertainers,history. Probably overcrowded in main season. Guided walk well worthwhile( free through Prague Airport transfer)

very nice spot!. The old town square is full of character. Don't miss the astronomical clock-every hour on the hour you can see the figures move and ring a bell. The square has vendors and street performers, and has a casual, relaxing atmosphere. It is very near the center of Prague-and an easy walk.

The people, the atmosphere,... So goodddd. you can go here and appreciate was surrounds you. You can see people playing music ( the music was so good), you can also see the clock, there is also some place to have a snack. Really good and nice place to go.

Beautiful area, The heart of Prague. You must visit this area if you are in Prague and visit the Astronomical clock! it is a must do, also enjoy the flock of tourists moving around the vibe that Prague gives you! it's not like any other place, there is something here that gives you that spirit of adventure!

Can't visit Prague without spending a some time here. Walk through it a few times just to soak up the "feel" of Old Prague. The architecture is varied. The people watching is incomparable. The street performers are humorous. Take a seat on a bench and enjoy the sights.
LOVE the music. a cold gray day-a bit of a drizzle-BUT all turns into joy when the jazz band starts to play-you buy a sausage and a hot wine and settle into the atmosphere
the most crowded square in Prague. It is the center of the old town. Everybody goes through it during the day or in the evening. It is lively and connects to many interesting places and museums.
Worth visiting. Must visit the square day and night time.Two different atmospheres. Try and visit the tower at nighttime for good views of the lights.

Old Town Square. Simply beautiful! with lots of stands for street food, hot wine, souvenirs and so on. Also the Astronomical clock in there is a major attraction sight and it also opens every hour so you may wanna plan your visit to be able to see it when it opens. It is a very beautiful part of Prague, there are also lots of shops and exchange places in there so definitely don't Old Town Square.
Beautiful square, amazing clock. Can't go to Prague without going to the Old Town Square. It's beautiful, with colorful buildings all around and of course the astronomic clock. Don't miss it.
Lively Square. Great for street performers, food huts, Segways, E-scooters, and people-watching from an outdoor café. Watch out for pick-pockets!

Fantastic Square, Church, and Clocks. In terms of what there is to see and photograph in the Square, this is really a 5-star attraction. I'm downgrading it a bit because of the crowding that takes place at certain times (when the clock is about to "perform"). We went there in mid-December, so there was a Christmas market and this undoubtedly contributed to the crowding. I suspect we took photos of every building around the Square, as each one seemed the equal of or better than the one next to it. The clocks are the big draw, of course, and they weren't disappointing. I've seen people write reviews complaining about all the tourists, but if you remember that you, too, are a tourist, you'll realize you shouldn't be so judgmental.

Centre of the Czech World & Not to be Missed!. This square has everything! The astronomic clock, a tower, the Tyn Church (which is truly awesome), the Jan Hus Stature, a miriad of cafes, and bars, a market at different times of the year - and a huge throong of happy, excited people enjoying this awesome place. Everyone will come here who visits Prague, and it is this place you will remember first!

Makes you feel like you're in the middle ages. Prague has a Medieval charm to it and Old Town is the pinnacle of that charm. The small, winding cobblestone streets are amazing. The clock is a bit underwhelming, but it is so unique you must see it.There's tons of tourists, but it's not a burden with such beautiful scenery. I would avoid eating around this area because it tends to be overpriced and of average quality.You would be doing yourself a disservice if you missed Old Town square!

Must See.. Everyone will tell you the same thing, there are three things you must see when you visit Prague. They are the Charles Bridge, Prague Castle and the Astronomical clock in the Old Town Square. The clock is an amusing oddity that is surrounded by tourists and onlookers when it strikes on the hour. The Old Town Square is a wonderfully vibrant place with marvellous old buildings framing a fabulous urban space of great beauty. Sit on one of the seats provided and enjoy watching the world go by!

The astronomical clock is not to be missed. The square itself is very touristy, I would skip the food stalls and market stands and spend your time checking out the facades of the buildings. The astronomical clock is truly a wonder.
Bohemia at it's best. I loved the business, buildings and atmosphere. There are lots of shops and the smell of street food was amazing. Lots of people there enjoying and photographing the sites.

Start of walking tour. Joined a "free" walking tour (works for tips) with Keith (an American married to a local). He was an excellent guide and added many extra pieces of advice to help with the enjoyment of our weekend

Not as busy as expected. Wasn't too busy mid-March, annoying folk on segways trying to take you on tours. Just walk! We were ripped off a little by one of the street food vendors so be careful what you ask for, we were overcharged as we didn't ask for a small version. Lovely spot to sit at for an hour, buy a beer local and bring a packed lunch!

Happening. There is always something going on on this square! It is full of life, with beautiful buildings and alleyways all around, a must-see when in Prague! Food and drink is enjoyed a lot cheaper further away, but not with the same cool view and life.

Russians must love clocks. There's a clock. There are hordes of Russians (and tourists of other nationalities, but let's be honest, mostly Russians). And there are lots of over priced restaurants. Be warned - if you're paying over 50 czk for a beer in Prague, you're paying way too much for both the beer and the food. It's better to get a beer from one of the stalls on the square, and perhaps a hot dog a la carte.The best of the best of busking is here though, so that keeps the place worthwhile, and the view of Our Lady on the Tyne can't be beat. But outside of that, there's nothing to keep you here too long.

Take you time and enjoy!. This is the true medieval heart of the city! Whether day or night, this place "never sleeps": crowds of curious tourists, street artists, local guides... Just try to just soak in the atmosphere! The Church of Our Lady before Tyn is well worth a visit, but take at least one glance at the beautiful baroque and renaissance buildings surrounding the square: Dům u Minuty, Goltz-Kinsky Palace, House At The Stone Bell. And, of course, be there on the hour (every hour) to watch the procession of the Twelve Apostles and the representations of Greed, Death, Vanity and Pleasure who all set in motion on the facade of Astronomical Clock.

Must See. Very touristy area but still a must see. I was here is March, which is off season for tourism, and it wasn't super crowded. You definitely noticed a difference from a day visit and an evening visit to the square and I highly recommend going at both times to experience it

Never get tired of passing through,. The old town square of Prague is beautiful, and steeped in history. The highlight is of course the astronomical clock with its hourly show which draws huge crowds every day. The church of Tyn which overlooks the east side of the square is very impressive and combined with the facade in front of it, seems to follow you as walk across the square. The best thing to do is to find one of the free tours (the one with the yellow umbrellas are the best) and let the guide fill you in on all the wonderful nuggets of history that the square beholds?

Be sure to see it by day and by night. The old town is impressive whenever you see it, but do try to take a walk around it at night, including Charles bridge. It is impressively illuminated and there is an 'energy' that gives it all a great atmosphere.

Overcrowded and ham selling street stall is a rip off. The square is lovely architecturally and historically but the crowds are a bit intense. And the street stall that sells spit roast ham will rip you off (their prices are listed per 100g, and they give you large pieces - we were charged 1000kcr for a meal for two which is preposterous, but we saved some and put it in the hotel mini fridge so we had enough for another meal). I read on here (now!) that others have been ripped off by the same place too, so please, dear reader, avoid the ham place.

Very touristic but still lovely!. Beautiful buildings like in most areas in Prague! There are many tourists around, however it is a place that is worth your visit. Do not forget to try the local street food at the little wooden cabins of the square!

The Hub of Prague. If in Prague this is where your sight seeing will start, so much to see and do from Art museums , Churches , the Clock and the old town hall. You never know what you will see in the Old Town Square in the way of entertainment and the odd demo. Check out the little food Kiosks , they are cheap and offer some interesting local dishes, we loved the crisps on a stick.Great location to pick up tours of the city and get your Prague Card.
Do not miss!!!. Fantastic scenery and wicked pancakes. Worth a visit both in the day and the evening. The children will love the clock.
The square never sleeps. You have to see the astronomical clock, the whole parade of Saints is a history lesson. Lots of smalls places nearby to grab a cheap meal and a beer.

Amazing. This area is so rich with history. The buildings, the shops, the food in this area is fantastic. There are tours you can take, lots of side roads to walk, just the atmosphere is amazing. This area can lead you to all other areas also. Great place to start
I FELT TO BE IN THE MIDDLE AGES. This was my tenth (or so) visit there.Never enough.Nicely kept, amazing buildings.Unbearable many people around- like myself

A must visit while in Prague!. True, it won't take long to visit the town square, but you must do it while in Prague. It is beautiful with the lovely buildings, but you also have to be there on the hour for the astronomical clock. Every hour you get a really cute show by the figures on the clock.
lovely area. Well worth the visit, clock is great! seems like their is always something on, pubs etc a little pricy.
Must do at night . What a stunning place Prague city is, we enjoyed every day walking around this fantastic city. But in my opinion it comes to life at night. You have to go here.

Charming, old square. Rather charming, old square with an intimate,atmospheric feel to it.There is always the buzz of the brisk cafes and the milling crowds. Its best enjoyed I think in the evening after the sun's gone down and the lamps come on.Not really for you if you don't like crowds, young people and lovers!

Awesome. Everywhere you turn its another place where ol Tyco Brae or Copernicus or Kafka or some other incredible Czech built, lived, or invented something! The Clock tower is mind-bending and epic. The craftsmanship and attention to detail are breathtaking. The square itself has tons of shops, restaurants, merchants, clothes, books, internet cafes, you name it, and people are all happily chattering and laughing, whether they're walking, sitting, or pushing tots in strollers. Lotsa children playing,and people all over the place! Yes indeed my friends, its all quite festive and pleasant as can be. Either walk around and do stuff or find a nice spot and just chill out to people watch, its one of the worlds great pedestrian squares, absolutely, and best of all? It comes in everybody's favorite flavor; FREE!
Must visit and linger. Great Czech street food and 360 degree views. Lots of characters, hawkers and gawkers. The free tours aren't!Try a Segway

The Keystone to a Great Prague Experience. The Old Town Square is an experience not to be missed. I strongly suggest that you visit during the day and also at night. The lighting and night time scene is unique. The Square is free so that is a plus, buskers and restaurants make for a pleasant scene. It also the center where your walking tour across the Charles Bridge or in another direction to the Jewish Quarter can begin. There are open air markets just a block or so off the Square for fresh produce but other items. I found a most interesting original oil painting by an artist who has had shows here in California at a reasonable price. Prague is really a gem. We are so glad that we were able to visit.

Spectacular vibrant place. Really amazing place, spectacular arhitecture of all the marking buildings around. . Lots of turists here to admire it. Lots of fancy cafes as well as hotels. Went actually in August 2013, was perfect in the evenings. People were partying casually in the square.

Magic. for the best pictures, you should go there. go up the clock tower to see everything in Prague. theres are restaurants around but you have to try to find the choice factory (don't visit the museum) but you have to try their hot chocolate..it is simply the best

nice to hang out and watch people go by. Central to the city and within walking distance of various sights like charles bridge etc.A great way to get a feel for the city and the moment we arrived we were lucky to see the astronomical clock and watch the apostles walk out....this happens on the hour and a crowd of tourists can be seen collecting around the clock every hour.Some street performances in the square- music , mime etc which add the feeling of celebration in the square.We were there in february when temperatures were very low and it was great to walk around and pick up a glass of mulled wine or hot chocolate at the various restaurants dotting the square- they have cans of these at the open areas facing the square and you can buy one and enjoy the warmth as you freeze !!Lots of local stores selling touristy bits but also some nice crystal if you enjoy riding /exploring on a segway then this is the best place to find one of the various companies providing these for hire , the tourist office is also around the square and so good place to start off your visit of prague.And if like me you just like to sit and people watch then this is a fun place to do so and just absorb the spirit of the city and enjoy the beautiful old structures surrounding the square especially at night when they are all lit up.

Lunch in the square. The old town square is a cobbled area, as are virtually all of the streets in Prague, which overlooks several attractions such as the astronomical clock, at the minute house where Franz Kafka lived, the old town hall and a large monument in the centre of the square which is the Jan Hus statue (a reformer during the 14th to 15th century).There are plenty of places to eat here both inside and outside and watch or listen to the street artists or even book a Segway tour.It is a hustelling and bustling cosmopolitan area which has something for everyone.

Best Area of Prague. Me & my partner stayed in the Savic Hotel which is just a street away form the Old Town Square. We definitely hit the jackpot with the location as it was by far our favourite area. Their are a few food stalls and the famous clock. The buildings are gorgeous. We also found a rooftop bar in the old square which we had a cocktail at and watched the sunset. Perfect!
Center of the Action. Old Town is truly a lover of all senses-- the smells, the sights, the people, the art, its truly magical.

A Prague must-see!. Went to Old Town Square on my first day in Prague and immediately felt like I was immersed in the culture. The square is central to all the main attractions. My favorite part was exploring the surrounding side streets with authentic Czech foods, shops, and people. Truly a beautiful area.

the heart of the city. the square in itself is beautiful, with a mix of mediaeval and baroque buildings. the main attraction is the astronomical clock, of course, which gathers a crowd at every hour. this is where all tours start. Free tour is good enough.

bustling square. Some great displays marking the end of communism poignant but shocking. great little stalls and segway operators offering tours but make sure you hustle as everyone is cheaper. Avoid the beggars by all means as they are not real a true homeless person will be picking out bins so dont be alarmed when you see this even if it is few and far between. Dont fall for the beggars with dogs or in praying position as they are part of gangs and are rotated. Do Not swap money with anyone in the street if anyone asks you say no and walk away rudely or you will be swindled but dont let these few thing overlook the vibrancy of this square just be vigilant and alert as pick pockets are extremely active in Prague and its not just men, old ladies, girls and anyone normal looking really
Lovely friendly environment day or night. See the astronomical clock. Watch the street performers and try some local foodstuffs whilst taking in the sights. Beautiful architecture.

amazing. it is a very impressive square with amazing architecture ,all around the square are shops selling all types of goods, coffee shops and restaurants , there are street entertainers in abundace and whilst I was visiting there was a fantastic jazz band playing.a very nice area to relax.

A must to see but walk around it.... Beautiful place but there's just too many tourists around. It's more like a noisy funfair at the square but best is to walk around at the smaller & quieter streets where you get to enjoy the buildings. The restaurants at the square were expensive and I'd an unpleasant experience at a restaurant at the square which charges differently from the menu shown. The courtyard sits has the same menu but higher prices. Still, worth to drop by.

Living is good in this place. Pretty square. Famous clock is there. Some musicians are there usually. A lot of cafe restaurants. Surrounding roads of the square which has a lot of very attactive touristic shops
Picturesque. Truly gorgeous, go up the tower in the old town hall, many sites and good street food on this, the most famous of Prague's squares
very picturesque square. Good sightseeing and range of bars and restaurants. Very busy with lots of people looking at the famous clock.
beautiful. very scenic place, very picturesque. glad we got there on the strike of the clock as it was nice to see .

The centre of toruism.... Be prepared to be on guard and hassled around in this centre of Prague. There are many people who want to see the natural beauty of this area and you can understand why when you arrive.

Beautiful. You can spend hours just marvelling at the architecture around the square but then you would miss out on all that takes place at ground level. Jugglers, life statues, a man with performing doves, some great live jazz bands and a real feel good factor. DON'T miss it.

Picturesque. This is the perfect hub for any city, with a buzzing vibe and restaurants and pubs all around with views of the cathedral and astronomical clock nearby. Will always be fond in my memories, loved it!

Over rated. There is nothing at this square which will make it 'must see'. Food stalls and a few entertainers, that's what it is. Prague has so many other things to offer. If you are at short visit, don't bother to visit it.

Prague tri[p. Would advise you to be there for noon to watch the old astronomical clock .Large crowds gather to see this sight. Plenty of bars and resteraunts in the area.
Get away from this square and enjoy one of the best pints of Pils for approx 97p. Amazing value.

Lots to offer. The old town square was lovely and a great point in which to get your bearings for where you will go next. A lot of tours go from here and there are plenty of guides offering free walking tours. There are lots of restaurants surrounding the square. A tour guide told us they are overpriced and recommended eating elsewhere, however we found the prices reasonable and they were convenient! Thw astronomical clock is also located here. You can climb the clock tower for the equivalent of a few pounds and get an amazing view of the city.
brill. Gonin may onwards more to see lock and palace visit a must avoid exchange near clock..they rip u off,,,

Great square!. One of the better squares to visit in Europe in my opinion. We arrived here in June and they were having some kind of a food festival with tons of stalls set up selling lots of great treats, both sweet and savory. The Glockenspiel and the house of the stone bell bookend the area so you have a couple great sights to see around the square. Make sure you take some of the crazy small alleys around the square to get to local bars or pubs and try some of the great food around here!

Bustling Old Town Square. Lovely old square, you can buy food and drink from the Little market stalls, they were setting up for Chinese New Year as we left, try the Dali, Warhol and Mucha Exhibition just off the square if you need to go inside to warm up!

Beautiful and very romantic. Standing in the square alone was unforgettable and very romantic. There were markets surrounding the square where you could get hot food and drink and little restaurants under gazebos with a great view of the square. People would also crowd around the astronomical clock every hour which was exciting too.

well worth a visit. If you come to prague the the zoo is well worth a visit and it is not expensive at all. It is about £5.00 per adult and is huge and you can easily spend 5-6 hours here as there is so much to see.To get here from Floren c metro station get on the tube train on track one and stay on fro two stops and get off at Nadrazi Holesovice then exit the metro and get the 112 bus which takes you straight to the zoo.

great. Its one of the main attractions and its easy to see why. a beautiful, cobbled square with some spectacular buildings. Its the best place to get your bearings and do some serious people watching.

Beautifull Historic Site. THis is the square where I was based on! Is very beautiful and it exploding with history! Is completly packed with tourists and is mainly focused on atracting them to buy souveniers and add massages and fishes eating up your feet dead skins.This Touristic part is not attractive to me personaly, but anyway is a totally beautifull site, that makes you forget the passing by tourists like myself and a great sausiches little seller with street music attractions.

Really Nice. Great place to start your tour of Prague - nice in daylight, maybe even better in the dark! Tyn church is spectacular and it's ironic to see the 2 analogue clocks beside the astrological clock!

Tourist Centre of Prague. As with every place in Prague it is picturesque. Would recommend viewing the astronomical clock, especially on the hour, I won't say what happens as that would spoil the surprise. Lots of restaurants and souvenir shops around the square. Also, it is a short walk from the Jewish Quarter which is well worth a view.

Relax in a Beautiful Old Town!. Getting to the Town Square by public transport was very easy!Even though it was cold and sometimes rainy on a couple of days, we loved walking round the town square! The mulled wine and hot cherry drink served by the al fresco restaurants in throwaway cups were especially nice as they were like a quarter or third of the normal price; they tasted good and you could walk around drinking and looking at the great sights, all within reach of the square. The famous Astronomical Clock is sited here and chimes every hour! It's a must see sight!There are also street acts to see! The buildings are beautiful and it's nice to venture to some of the unusual restaurants and cafe, such as the cubism cafe, which was interesting, and contained various artworks; the views were also great, allowing you to people watch! You can always try and negotiate for whatever item you wish to puchase. I bought a garnet ring - Prague has its own garnet mines and these are controlled by the government. I got a discount of over 50% by shopping around. Whilst looking for a sparkly bobble hat, the shop assistant offered, without my asking, to reduce the cost of this item! I was therefore confident in asking other shops to see if they could compete with a competitive price!There is a reassuring police presence in the Square.

Beautiful. Become lost in the history and culture at the heart of the Czech capital. Sample the bars, cafes and various shops. Don't forget to watch the clock on the hour (even though it is a bit of a let down.) Dislike: the amount of intimidating drug sellers who follow tourists around the square.
Entertaining tour. We arrived on a Monday and were able to see the square when it was quiet as well as when it was busy. Lovely place with some nice restaurants to eat in.

great place to spend some time. Great architecture all around this square. There are often shows held on a stage. When we visited it was the chinese new year so there was entertainment and a few stalls set up around the square.Quite a few restaurants here too where a good meal and a couple of drinks were more expensive than on the outskirts but you pay for location.We enjoyed people watching on the heated terrace of one of the restaurants.
Old Town Ssquare. Great place to stroll and enjoy a great atmosphere of Prague - lots to do and see, Fab shopping, great restaurants fun place to be.
Grand Prague Cafe. Good cake and coffee and view of the famous clock. Lots of fine buildings to look at and photograph.

Never come to Prague without visiting famous old square. the square is like the centre we seemed to always start and finish there, so much to do around, worth a visit up the clock tower with excellent views, nice stall in tower selling pockets watches in clock designs. Make sure you see clock on the hour

Impressive!. This was my first visit to Prague and I most say that I loved Old Town Square. The buildings are beautiful and very ornate. There were lots of people / tourists about and this gave the place a lovely "buzz". There were street vendors and artists doing their thing and this added to the feel of the place. Of course one of the main attractions in the square is the Astronomical Clock and it is worth waiting for the clock to strike on the hour to see the passage of the 12 apostles. The clock was installed in 1410 and it is the third oldest astronomical clock in the world but it is the oldest working astronomical clock in the world. I really like this square and this part of Prague. Although it was very cold on the day we walked around it was well worth it and well worth exploring the small streets of the square.
Historical square. A town square full of history, fantastic architecture and buzzing with atmosphere. There are some great places to eat around the square too.
A must. Great beautiful square.Of course no one will go to Prague and not visit it.It is full of tourist and therefore all shops around push the price a bit high.

Wonderful experience. We stayed in Old Town for a week after a Danube cruise in December. We were a five-minute walk from Old Town Square and went there several times either as a destination or on our way to another attraction. It was an amazing place, with sights such as the Astronomical Clock and Old Town Hall, and shops and restaurants in the historic buildings. It was fun to wander around the Square as well as up and down the small narrow streets surrounding it. In addition, the Christmas markets were open, and it was great looking at the merchandise and food for sale as well as watching couples and families visiting from different countries. We managed to go there at different times of day and night, and, while crowded, there was always a friendly, holiday atmosphere.

It has an old atmosphere. you will feel the touch of the history for sure! It is a beautiful part of Prague that you have to see! Come during the morning or afternoon otherwise its full of tourists! no wonder!
Great food. Ate here twice and both times food was great ,service was excellent just what we need to warm ourselves as it was so cold outside

Not to be miss ...full of history..... Stumble upon this square by chance...getting lost and love, as is in my list that I want to go. Didn't know that is just round the corner of the hotel where i stayed. Very cool place with so many MUST SEE landmarks.(The Astronomical Cloak, Old Town Hall, Church of our Lady before Tyn...)Does not matter what time of the day you visit this area, you just want to hang and stop for few minutes....heart of Prague. Lead you to so many places, walking distance...remember to get the map from the hotel you stay. Get the feel of it.

A must visit place. It is a great place for a walk. There are amazing views from the top of the hill. Some great photo opportunity. Many small restaurants to stop in and shops to visit. Great narrow street and colour buildings. A must visit when in Prague.
Greatest square in Europe. This place have realy genius loci. When we come, it was dark, but this winter atmosfere get us. People are polite, and very kind there.

Just sit and enjoy the atmosphere. The square is wonderful there are so many different people around during the day and night, so people watching is great. We tried loads of food stalls available around the square and would highly recommend! It's superrrr beautiful too

A must visit. I cannot imagine anyone visiting Praque without seeing the Old Town Square. Fine restaurants, shops, city hall, astronomical clock, and links that radiate out to interesting blocks and blocks of fascinating sights.

Commercialisation increasing. Old Town Square is the heartbeat of the city and a truly beautiful historic spot. However it is being spoilt by the many distractions that make it hard to cross it without being hassled or run over by the speeding segway touts looking for business! One day there will be a serious accident but I hope before that they will be banned so that walking tourists can enjoy the square in something closer to its original form and atmosphere! Also the tables outside the pubs and restaurants are increasing and almost taking up half the square. It should not become like a Disneyland but a joy to cross and wonder at the architecture and beauty of the variety of styles.There seems to be no limit to the touts, segways, stalls and guides or no rules!!

Heart of Prague. Located between Wenceslas Square and the Charles Bridge, on this historic square, among churches and beautiful buildings, tourists may find a Gothic tower (from the top of which, you might enjoy great views over the Old Town) and the very famous old astronomical clock.

concentrated history and beauty. This place is full of historical moments and buildings. From 14th to 20th century. There is the statue of Jan Hus (Czech priest, philosopher, early Christian reformer and Master at Charles University in Prague. After John Wycliffe, the theorist of ecclesiastical Reformation, Hus is considered the first Church reformer, as he lived before Luther, Calvin and Zwingli.), balcony from which was established communist regime in Czechoslovakia 25.2.1948, Stone Bell House from the 14th century with the gallery, Old City Hall with the Horloge ( astronomical clock) and many other sightseeings

A must see. This is a beautiful square, and if you are visiting Prague, I can't imagine missing this site. We were there in November-- so definatly not the major tourist season-- and there were still many street performers out and about. They were mostly very entertaining, and the acts varied anywhere from classical music performances to a little pig in clothes.The architecture here is lovely, and there are lots of shops and restaurants in the area.

Old town Czech experience. A true microcosm of the Czech culture. Great walk up authentic food vendors around the periphery. This can be a stroll through or destination -- it is central to many places. Spontaneous entertainers many using/showing midevil instruments and costumes. The Clock was a bit of a let down for us. But considering how old it and everything else actually is the whole experience is amazing.
Vibrant and exciting. Very busy square with so many beautiful buildings each one outdoing the next.many activities going on to keep you amused

Noizy place. Look. I've lived in Prague for years and this very center place I could describe as "see the astronomical clock and run as quick as you can." Why? There are lots of street artists making noise, lots of low turists taking a rest, booths with thrash food and the vibe of that place is all in all strange. There are many many more friendly places in Prague.
Brilliant for absorbing the atmosphere of Prague.. Brilliant area for absorbing the atmosphere of Prague. Plenty of places to eat plus the clock (chiming on the hour) can't be missed.

The heart of Prague. Also the butthole of Prague.. Old Town Square is at the center of everything. The architecture is gorgeous, the crowds are lively, the history is immense, and there's so much to do/drink within walking distance. But don't eat here or buy anything here! There are decent restaurants literally one block away in every direction, but the ones on the square are twice as expensive and not as good as anywhere else in the city. Also, stay away from the souvenir shops - those are all Russian, not Czech!Anyway, Old Town Square is a beautiful place, and expect to drunkenly wander through it quite a few times during your stay in Prague.

Old Town Square & Surrounding area by 28yo Local. The square is located directly in center of old town and the main attractions are statue of Jan Hus and mainly, the old town hall and astronomical clock. Situation with pickpockets is getting better each year, however keep eye on your pockets and belongings when watching the astronomical clock could be worthy. I would definitely recommend to get a walk in surrounding area located between Celetna street and line of streets Dlouha, Kozi, Hastalska - it's a network of narrow streets with amazing atmosphere of old Prague, my favorite even I had walked around for hundred times:) Don't be surprised with higher prices of goods and services offered in the area, it's a touristic center so the prices reflects this fact. Anyway, there are nice places where to get a coffee in Dlouha Street. I (I'm 28 ) prefer NOD cafe located above the Roxy club. The place has kind of atmosphere I've enjoyed i.e. in Berlin or Amsterdam..

Chinese New Year !. It's the Chinese New Year Festival right now, so the place is packed with people. (even more than usual!) Do come at the hour so you don't miss the astronomical Clock ticking! It's a full show going on there! There is so much to see that you will enjoy going through the square multiple times during your stay! Have Fun!
magical. we were here over xmas and it was magical, every hr when the clock struck the crouds gathered to watch. must visit

Fantastic. I loved it here and came down every day. The atmosphere was buzzing, street food was fabulous and we were lucky enough to see the Christmas tree being put up. Old Town Square is somewhere I could visit again and again.
A lovely little square. A beautiful square in the nighttime and daytime! Definitely pay the 120CKK to go up the clock tower, it's a lovely view.

Place of dreams. If you have never been here before all I can say to me this was one of the 2 most important places in Europe I wanted to go to and it certainly didn't let me down then and still doesn't if you don't like this place you can't be pleased

Old world charm alive with people. The old world charm of the Old Town Sqare in Prague was a highlight of my visit. Surrounded by shops and restaurants, the flavour of Eastern Europe is a delight. I loved the style of the buildings surrounding the square and it is just so pleasant to sit there and watch the activity going on around. There were peoples on segways and buskers blowing huge bubbles, and musical band and the old clock all so enchanting. There are horse and carts available for those who would like to see the city in style, and small market areas selling souveniers and also food, a true visitors delight.

A global experience!. The square is quite large and hosts a variety of activities at all times. Old Town Square is the heart of the city of Prague. Also, it is the focal point by which most activities in the city take place. I have walked the city back and forth and Old Town Square with its astronomical clock feels like home away from home.

Busy town square. The Staromestske namesti has one of the most interesting astronomical clock which gets busy every full hour for its change which makes the square busy. However, the offer of museums and attractions here are a must.
My first impression of Old Town Square. This is the most medieval place we have ever seen on our trip to Europe. Its like walking onto a movie set. Magnificent!
Starry Square and Tinny Steeples. Meet the world here ...busy with visitors of all nationalities, shapes and sizes. Lots to look at and listen to :-)
Lots of shops and the famous clock. lots of places to grab a bite to eat, but it does get crowded. What was nice is that the police had a van in the square and offered tourists helpful information.
Lovely. Lovely clean square. Very busy. All guided tours leave from here. Plenty places to eat and drink , just sit and enjoy the surroundings.

Have to see.... ...well when in Prague....
We waited for 9pm with many others to see this and it was nice to see. Its a very busy area so be aware of your surroundings and the people. Great to see a piece of history

This is IT!. this is a one of the most beautiful places that you can imagine and/or see in the whole world. Beautiful, breathtaking views. very dramatic and super romantic, for those who's more down to earth, place is full of history.

Lovely square full of life. To see the clock, see the shops, start to explore the little streets and see the buildings around the square.
Pretty place to see, most of the time there is also live music in the square which makes it nice
Expensive restaurants though, better to eat a little out of the square

Charming. A lively place where there's always something going on. Look out for the Prague carnival stands to find out when things are scheduled. We ate in a couple of cafes / restaurants and found them a bit pricey, although the standard was ok.Avoid the scrum around the Astronomical clock and try to get a table near the window in Cafe Prague to watch it at midday.
Beautiful Architectures around the square. Beautiful Architectures around the square, feel the historic Europe atmosphere for an Asian tourist like me!
The main point of Prague. Here is where you start the visit to Prague. Here you can find nice cafés, nice souvenirs stores and the famous Prague Orloj( the astronomical clock) .

Beautiful buildings but don't eat on the square. From the astrological clock, Tyn church and many many other beautiful buildings this is a central place to start your adventure in Prague! But if you want to eat find one of the many lovely eateries off the Square or you will pay a premium for the privilege! Do make the effort to climb the tower of the clock as the views are superb?.. There is a lift or alternatively a lot of steps!

Medieval meets Modern. On a good weather day it is easy to spend hours here amongst the locals and tourists alike. Vendors on food stalls offer all types of delicious nibbles while horse drawn carriages await their next charge. The Glockenspiel Clock, whist entertaining is nothing compared to the one in Munich.

Plenty to see and do!. There's always something going on in the square, whether that's a pianist or a ventriloquist or a world hackeysack champion, so it's a great place to while away the time if you're stuck for things to do - which you should never be in such a thriving, cultural city such as Prague. The square is surrounded by tons of winding streets lined with interesting shops and places to eat, and plenty of museums too.

Romantic and fun to travel. Prague old Town gives us a taste of combination of: History, fine architecture, Romance and a place of fun to travel. Kind of "take it easy" and enjoy it.Old Town Square is defiantly answer all of the above.

Carnival atmosphere by day and by night. The Old Town square is a treat with performers and crowds throughout the day. It is fun to watch the atmosphere transform as night falls and even more performers come out to play. Take the inexpensive ticket and walk / elevator to the top of the astronomical clock tower for the best view of the square and its activities

Nice area to walk around .... Interesting architecture and people watching in this area. The street vendors sell lots of random things but the tubular desserts were incredible. And lots of places sell beer!
Vibrant Central square. Especially good in the evening...lots of life and central for exploring. Lots of bars with outside heating.
Best place to lounge all day - much going on. love this place, from the clock to the cathedral to the restaurants to the bars to the street performers - our fav place in Prague

So much to see everywhere you turn. Although it was February, gloomy and cold, and seemingly the season for getting repairs and renovations done on ancient crumbling facades, Prague's Old Town Square nonetheless buzzed with life and colour.Forget the dates and the house names, just walk slowly round the perimeter enjoying every shop frontage, every quirky sign and fresco, every roofline. The place is full of interest and you don't have to spend a single koruna to enjoy it... if you can resist those yummy smelling spiral doughnut things that the vendors sell.Just wander and enjoy it, making sure not to miss the chimes at the top of the hour from the Old Town Hall. Meander down the side streets in every direction and just keep on looking up above the ground floor to spot all the mad and characterful detail on the buildings.
Living Square. This place every visitor in Prague have to visit. All kind of happening, vendors, clowns ... what ever. Good food and of course good beer!

Beautiful architecture. As we went at a time that is off peak for tourists, it was not as busy as I imagine it gets. So it was lovely to stroll around the old town square, drinking a cup of warm mulled wine, and taking in the gorgeous buildings. Truly a place where time stood still...beautiful.

Centre of Prague with lots to offer. This place is buzzing whether you visit in summer or in winter. Eating places surrounding the square. lots of interesting iconic buildings and shops thrown in too.
very nice. very nice place one of the best in the world ,very clean ,a lot of activities ,nice shops and restaurants ,safe and clean ,you must see it .
A nice Stroll around........ The centre of prague is filled with attractions,Food,Drinks,Shopping,etc,,,,,Amazing stroll around the old town...

Daily visit. 4 of us went daily for the ambiance always something going on,
it was nice to just people watch whilst taking a hot apple juice

Just.. Beautiful!!. Prague is one of my favourite cities in Europe, and the old town square is clearly one of its most interesting and beautiful spots. In summer time, there are many street artists performing here, which adds to the ambiance of the square. The architecture is just stunning with all its different colours. Sunset is amazing here, with the setting sun accentuating the colours of all the buildings. There are also many bars and restaurants here, you could easily spend a whole day strolling around in this beautiful place.

Great entertainment and street food. If you are hungry for food, drink and entertainment you cannot go wrong. Huge sausage, slabs of cured pork, lovely bread, hot red wine, hot sweet bread and great music. Be prepared to take part with the street entertainment .... be warned!
Stunning architecture. Beautiful buildings, lots of places to eat and have hot drinks. Large and small shops worth visiting.

A hive of activity. This square is the heart of Prague. Here you will find markets, merchants, music, and fun all round. Make sure to visit the Astronomical clock and nearby churches. The square is particularly busy during December and early January during the Christmas Markets, so enjoy it then if you're in town. Also try a 'Trdlo': a traditional Czech pastry. They are cheap and delicious!

Real Europe. I have read a quote about prague and that was " Prague - A city of love an romance" this quote is just 100% true. Just after landing at the Prague airport I got the feeling of love. Prague is the real face of europe with so many lovely old architectural buildings.
Nice square. Feels like I'm back in the olden times at the square. Nice old buildings surrounding the square. Very lively and full of nice shops and restaurants.
Go early. Huge square, and great buildings all around, but this place is mobbed from late morning on. For the best experience - go early and enjoy the space. It's really lovely that time of day.

Everyone stops to see the Clock..... Yes it is nice, and old, and attractive...but...on the hour, its no big deal...why stand with all the crowd here,.....go at night and you still see how it works without the crowd! (Okay, you might not have the light for your picture, but the picture doesn't show the movement anyway, so take your clock pictures at any other time during the day, and see the on the hour movement at night...

Go out of season for a peaceful visit!!. Last night at 9.30 pm with a cold wind blowing and hardly any tourists to be seen this beautiful square was very peaceful. If you go in the tourist season be prepared for large crowds and all the usual tatty tourist paraphernalia!!
Must see in Prague. The Old Town Square in Prague is a must for any visitor, especially at Christmas time with the Christmas Markets and snow on the ground.

Fairytale square. I don't think there is another place in the world that looks like a painting from a fairy tale book. Especially at night it is magical. If you want to take the perfect photo you should go to the terrace of the U Prince hotel. You won't regret.

Great little European square. My favorite building was in this square (Tyn Cathedral). At night it looks like Dracula should live there. The square was bustling with tourists and street performers. Vendors sold sweets, hot wine, hot chocolate, etc. The famous clock tower is in this square also. It was cold when we were there, so no one was really just hanging out. I'd love to return in warmer weather, as they say a lot of cafe type restaurants are sat up in the square and the people watching would be great!

Easy to access, doesn't require a lot of time. Everyone local recommends visiting the Old Town Square. It is easy enough to walk there from anywhere in the Old City. There are a couple old buildings and churches with views to admire, and the overall European feel of a quaint town square to enjoy. But otherwise, I wouldn't expect to spend much time here unless you're in a cafe/restaurant.

Historic & atmospheric Old Town Square. The Square is the heart of Old Town Prague, and its a must to find some time just to wander around or sit in it (even if its winter!), and to soak up the historical atmosphere. The Square is variously surrounded by medieval/Gothic, Baroque and Neo-Classical buildings, including buildings with frescoes, which is quite a rare and beautiful combination of architecture. The Astronomical Clock is also a must see. A walking tour - some are free - is probably the best way to gain a feeling and understanding of the Old Town Square. Just try to avoid buying food or drink on the Square, as the prices are very expensive (c. £3 for a coffee, at the time of writing), but there are plenty of places nearby where a cheaper deal can be had.

Top sight. The most beautiful Old Town Square I have seen.. Go back in time to an era of elegant architecture. Consider visiting in winter and early morning, when the square has few visitors. Nearly all the buildings around the square are worthwhile looking at. End with a coffee in one of the Cafes or a meal at the rooftop terrace restaurant of the Hotel U Prince
Christmas Market. it was very disappointing. basically repeated shops over and over again to fill up the market. Also very very expensive.

Vibrant, Interesting.. Don't miss the Old Clock!. We met some friends and walked through the Old Town Square and its avenues. Though the weather was cold, the square was crowded with happy tourists and locals. The main attraction is the animated Ancient Clock.

Breath Taking architecture, you can smell the history. A must for any visitor to the Czech Republic. The old town square seeps history and you can literally feel the scars and beauty this square has to offer. Not only does the Old town square host the Orloj, or astronomical clock, but also the best markets and Opera galleries and city can offer.

Loved Prague!. Been to Europe and have not gone to Prague yet? It's a must go to place that has so much to see and do. Easy to find a place to stay and places to eat. I don't typically like lighter beer but the beer made in Prague tastes so much better than I have had before. The Bridge Band is another "must see" if they are playing and the photo ops never stop. I will return - many, many times.

Great atmophere. The place to visit in Prague. It is buzzing. You do not know where to look or where to eat or drink next. Lots of entertainment, buskers, cafes and of course the famous astrological clock

Can't go to Prague without coming across the Old Town Square.. Meeting place for most excursions, tours etc. Full of charm and character. Wander away from the square and up the side streets which lead to other areas with cafes and shops. Try a traditional Prague cake shop where you can sit and have a coffee and probably one of the best cakes you will ever have for very little money. Prague is just one of those diamonds that you visit and doesn't compare to anywhere else I have been. Visit as much as you can but use a guide, good guides just make the attractions come alive.
Lovely place!. A real historic place, very beautiful. Spent all weekend here looking around the markets, going to the clock tower. Lots to do and see, very pretty!

Christmas atmosphere and warm feeling. Lots of Christmas food tables, all very good. Great jazz music on open,, humming of tourist of many languages, possibility to drink "honey wine"-very sweet,hot,tasty!

Back in time. The experience is lovely. Horse and carriages available for rides. Lots of places to eat and drink. Lots to see and experience. Beautiful little shops to buy from cut glass to crystals and gifts.
Excelent. Love Christmas in this town,...is like a postal. A lot of items for sell in market. You can see all the town just walking around. There are a lot of little street with a lot of history

Beautiful and busy - May 2013. I've been here twice now, and can't describe how gorgeous this whole place is. There's so much going on that you'll have trouble deciding in which direction to walk! The booths set up selling food and drink are worth the visit, and be sure to check out the Toro Negro, a little sit down restaurant situated directly across from the Astronomical Clock. We had a drink there in time to watch the Clock Tower do its thing, after which the audience that never fails to gather every hour applauded the "performance." Check out the Church of our Lady Before Tyn, the myriad of performance artists that crowd the central plaza...hell check out every angle. It's beautiful, but crowded. Prague has become a veritable Mecca for travelers, and it's easy to understand why once you've spent even a little bit of time there.
Christmas festivities. Thousands of people looking for a good time coupled with music, lights, a ginormous Christmas tree and food and local drink, created a scene that will not be forgotten.

Old Town Square. Swing band playing in the square was awesome. Whole place was buzzing, even in January. Great food and bars all around. Check out the Comix Alternatiff bar if you like things a bit different. Cheap beer and a relaxed atmosphere. Loads of character and extremely friendly and helpful English speaking bar staff.

A Wonderful Snowy Christmas Scene. We loved the Old Town Square with its Christmas market in full swing and the beautiful Christmas tree and nativity scene at the centre of it all. There is plenty to see around the square the churches are beautiful with free classical concerts on offer in most. The square is surrounded with cafes and restraunts all serving good hot drinks. We only ate dinner in one of the square restraints it was nothing to rave over. A little way off the square however you will find a range of better quality places to eat.

Old Town Square. The Square is fantastic- entertaining, full of shops, bars and restaurants. The clock is a must see on the hour every hour - the show only lasts a minute so get a video ready and watch. It's as well to go with a guide to hear its true history
Beautiful architecture. Stunning architecture. Unfortunately some staff in one of the heated outdoor restaurant areas not very pleasant!

Atmospheric. As we were with Martin our guide it was all great. The stories about the Astronomical Clock made us re visit to see if the icons did actually come out and deliver as Martin said they would..... and guess what... they did.

Old Town Square - clue in the title. This is the centre of old Prague, and the key tourist honeypot for the prowling segway tour guides.The square is big and open , but surrounded by fabulously decorated buildings. The square has the famous clock easily located by the hoards of tourists waiting for the hour to see the show.This is where you can hire faux classic cars for trips and get onto free walking tours.Definitely a place to go , but watch out for the segways

Not to miss!. A must see when you are in Prague. The astronomical clock is amazing, loved the narrow streets and beautiful architecture, plenty of shops and restaurants, although they are bit pricey because of the location. Lots of tourists!
Touristy. A beautiful, but crowded place with lots of action and tourists. A little shady especially at nighttime

Beautiful but expensive to eat and drink there. Beautiful and definitely worth the visit bad I would recommend going up the clock tower as the view us fantastic and there's even a little if you don't want to walk!
Must see. This is definitely one of the places which you must see if you are in Prague. Since I had only bussines meeting there I was really happy to have a minute to see this square.

Especially at night..... The Old Town Square - probably one of the main jump-off points for your sightseeing around Prague, as most of the routes to Charles Bridge, the Lesser Town, The Castle and Wenceslas Square lead off from here.A great place to find restaurants, cafes and bars, but of course as in any city you will pay extra for the view. But just have one drink and sit at a pavement bar people watching for a while.In the square you will find the astronomical clock, which always attracts tourists and tour guides on the hour as the clock strikes and.....well you will have to see won't you. Also dominating the square is Tyn church and the Town hall tower. At night in particular when the fairytale turrets on Tyn are lit up it is a memorable image.By the way, there are some great restaurants hidden down side alleys, and one in particular - Melijice I think from memory - has superb food and service at a good price. The 2kg roast pork knee and the plate of ribs are just 2 of the very filling and superb meals, washed down with a glass of Czech beer of course!

Beautiful architectural features. The abundance of spectacular buildings with their detailed mouldings, gold leaf, turrets and towers make this a brilliant place to see. Lots of benches around for you to relax and take it all in, with street performers, music, cafes, art museums and the Astrological Clock it should be on everyone's list when in Prague.

Good Times. I loved old town, the square is so wonderful! My favorite is seeing all the people there. Horse & Buggy, the Astromonical Clock, restaurants, churches, food stalls, so much to see & do! I loved this area.

I went with my mum at Christmas . Absolutely stunning in the day and night, very clean loads going on, everyone extremely friendly, lots of mini stalls things are beautiful and prices are good too! Will definitely visit again
fab. Amazing with such a diversity of buldings so much to see a trip up the clock tower is a must the veiws are spectacular

wonderful buildings. if you like looking, look no further, all sorts of styles and ages mingle to create a sort of fantasy vista of a medieval town.the clock, churches, bars, restaurants and history and architecure to admire, its what youve come to prague for
Lovely Christmas Market. Everything was amazing, can't wait to be back in Prague! It was pretty busy, but the atmosphere was simply fantastic.
Babylon. Atmosphere and many languages. Big Christmas tree and the illumination made the evening and night unforgettable.

Lovely to go when Christmas market and large Christmas tree here. We went to Prague at beginning of December and it was lovely to come to Old Town Square when the Christmas Market was here and drink hot mead and eat and listen to music. Lots of people there especially around the clock when it was due to chime so recommend you pick your spot early. Lots of lovely shops on back streets near there and a market and places to eat.
monuments, historical sites and monuments again.... Beautiful historic buildings of architectural gems mass. It is necessary to take the foto camera and spare batteries. Recommend

Magical. The town square is like something out of a fairy tale. It's truly beautiful. Somewhere I'll never forget and will happily go back to see in a heartbeat. Very central to a lot of Prague's attractions and if you go during a holiday (like Easter or Christmas) there are lovely markets. I advise going in the evening as well as during the day as it transforms at night, there is live music and it's a less busy.

A great place to begin exploring Prague. There is plenty of interest in and around the old town square such as bars and restaurants and particularly noteworthy are the good quality performing artists which certainly draw the crowds. This is a good starting point for which to explore the heart of the city. You do get many people offering tours which you can partake in if you wish, each trying to outdo the other, but it is easy to explore independently - just follow the crowds or not depending on your interest.

Good atmosphere. Nice place, nice Astronomical clock. Entertaining band that played most days there during my visit. Market stalls there too where we bought trdelnik (the spelling of this is almost definitely way off) and you have to eat some of this pastry in prague!
the only one in the world. unreal has to be seen to be believed fairytale magic look high and see the golden cockral see the movements on the hour

Just magical. It looks like it was right out of a fairy tale. Great town square with lots of options for seeing some of the main attractions in Prague. Make sure to go back towards the end of the day to enjoy some live music after a long day of walking. Did this both evenings and it was great!

Absolutely stunning. The square is beautiful especially at night. During the day it can become quite busy, possibly because Charles bridge is moments away and many hotels are situated around it. I would recommend going at night time to really see its true beauty as every is lit to perfection and there are less tourists.

"Atmosphere". Day and Night a Beautiful place to be in all four seasons.I gets very busy on the Hour, its the clock that does it!!!The square cafe's are pricey.... so try of the Square for food and drink.

Timeless Beauty. This is the heart of Prague and is the most practical starting point for any tour of the city. Reach this square by purchasing a 24-hr transit pass (110 crowns/$5) at any metro station for unlimited rides on metro/trams/buses/furniculars, then take the green Metro Line A to Staromestska. This is where the famous Tyn Church (the inspiration for Disney's Sleeping Beauty Castle) and the Astronomical Clock (the oldest working clock in the world) are located. If you're here starting the first week in December, the Christmas markets are open for business, so enjoy their holiday treats like trdlo (spiral fried pastries covered in sugar), mead, and svarene vino (sweet mulled wine), perfect to keep you warm in the frigid Czech weather. Avoid buying souvenirs in Old Town since they are terribly overpriced; instead, hop to the west side of the Vltava River to Mala Strana for cheap goods and a wider selection of restaurants and shops.
Plent to do. Lots to see here, the performing artists, mime, jazz, singers, statues etc. Loads of bars and restauarants close by. Just good to wander round and enjoy
clock viewing. We drank mulled wine whilst waiting for the clock and spent a long time people watching, The square is full of different places to eat and lots of different choices of restaurant

Picturesque square with vibrant atmosphere. The Old Town Square in Prague is beautiful and as many other reviews have mentioned, at night it is magical, especially the Tyn Church, which dominates the square with its magnificent twin towers - whether it's true or not, our guide told us that Walt Disney based his fairy castle on this church. There always seem to be lots going on in the square and in the evening we were entertained by a fantastic music group and fire dancers. The Astronomical Clock, built in to one side of the Old Town Hall Tower, dates from the 15th century, and on the hour crowds gather in front of the tower to watch the wonderful show as the clock chimes. It begins as the two windows above the clock open, and the twelve apostles march round, whilst the other figures, either side of the clock, begin to move. The figure of Death holds its hourglass and beckons to the Turk (symbol of Lust) which shakes its head in response. There is Vanity portrayed as a man with a mirror and Miserliness as a man with a moneybag, shaking a stick. When the apostles finish their journey, the golden cockerel at the top crows and quivers its wings, the bell rings and the clock chimes the hour. Below the Astronomical Clock are 12 medallions with the signs of the zodiac. Definitely worth a visit is a trip to the top of the Old Town Hall tower which is almost 70m high where you can enjoy an amazing view of the entire city. It doesn't cost much (seniors get a reduction) and there are lifts, so you don't have to climb if you don't want to.

Like a smaller Paris. This town constantly reminded us of Paris - the same romantic feeling in a city of cobbled streets and people on the move.The Old town square has to be the starting point for any visit to the city - there is the cathedrals, the clock and the markets to be enjoyed and then wander off down lanes and enjoy life in Prague
A must if you visit Prague. This is a must if you visit the lovely city of Prague, lots of things going on in the square to do, see and eat
Very nice place. This is something must see in Prague. But always full of tourist. My advice: take free walking tour in Prague :)
Try to see this at night. Plenty of people walking around, Well lit. Plenty of street food and usually some kind of entertainment or music happening on weekend nights.
Astronomic clock. Old town square is the main centre of city where many streets come together. In the middle is astronomic clock. many comediants are there during the day and some traditional markets

One of the most beautiful square in the world. This place simply has tremendous atmosphere. Very pitoresque, very old, with dominating Tyn cathedral, old Town Hall with its tower and Alchemist clock, Small square. The best way to walk to Old Town Square is through Celetna street. Go up the tower!
The place to start in Prague. Beautiful. Full of culture and activity and lots of shopping, restaurants and things to do. Have a leisurely lunch in this area and plan the rest of your sightseeing.
amazing. this is really amazing place what I never seen in all world. It looks like a movie or pleasant dream when are are there

Picture Perfect Square. You could easily spend all day in this square, just relaxing at an out-door cafe and people watching. If you don't have time to explore the whole city, do at least come here. This square represents the heart of old Prague.

The Ideal Old Town Square. You come upon the old town square by entering it from one of it's many side streets running through the old town. The square is what I would think an old town square should look like, cobbled and stunning old buildings and church surrounding it. The astronomical clock is the centre piece for a lot off people but do have a walk around the square to get a better look at the architecture.
Very good but crowded. After Christmas and close to New Year it was a zoo but it is very beautiful and well worth the visit.

No. 1 to go in Prague. Please read the history about this place to understand all what you can see at this magnificent place - every building is so special and once you know what you are looking at - the place become much much more interesting and not just beautiful!

Authentic Old Town Square. This is what one would imagine an Old World town square would be: large, cobbled and busy with locals and tourists alike. During Christmas, a large and inviting Christmas market, fills the square.We enjoyed just walking around the square, nibbling on a local sweet, sipping mulled wine.

Something for everyone. The stunning architecture of the church and the astronomical clock and all the other buildings, it's just amazing. There are musicians entertaining the whole square, there are cocktail bars and restaurants around.Also, check if there are some interesting exhibitions, when I went there in August 2014 there was an Andy Warhol exhibition and a few more

A real life Disneyland. I was lucky to visit just before Christmas and Old Town Square was full of fairy lights, market stalls, a huge Christmas tree (or two) and the bars were alive with people of all ages - it was exactly like a winter wonderland. Old Town Square is vibrant and central, we spent a lot of time drinking mulled wine and people watching. The nautical clock draws the crowds quite literally on the hour, but I have to say I was a tad disappointed at the 'robotics'. I loved the square and if I had to sum it up in one word it would be 'magical' (definitely influenced by the time of year me thinks)!
Fun Christmas Market. The Old Town Square is great fun at Christmas with its market stalls and decorations. Surrounded by gorgeous old buildings it is a treat to visit.
A visit to the church. It has beautiful interior and from there you can know a little more history of the past as there provides notes of descriptions in different languages.
fantastic. This is the most wonderful place that I have had visited in last years. Really fantastic. You fell like in a dream. We want return as soon as possible.
Beautiful. Says it all in my review! Stunning place, the clock is cool and there's a lovely cocktail bar up high behind it so u get some astronomical views!

Intrigue. The town square is full of history, stories and character. I could walk around it all day and never tire. The Town Hall and its tour is amazing but the highlight is certainly the astronomical clock. The memorial of the slaying of the 27 Lords is somber but fitting.

Christmas Market extraordinaire!!. My family visited the Old Town Square during the Christmas season and thoroughly enjoyed the city, the square, and the market. It was an amazing market with lots of good booths to choose from including food and drink. We had a "Grilled Cheese sandwich" which was amazing. The cheese was grilled over an open fire and then served on a piece of bread - delicious. The Mead was outstanding, and the atmosphere was beyond belief. I told my wife that I expected to see Tinker Bell flying down from the cathedral spire at any time. I highly recommend Prague, the Old Town Square, and especially the Christmas Market!
