The place of the Astronomical clock, the place of street artists, the place where ice hockey fans gather to suppert the Czech national team during the world cup.. this is the place where it all goes down!Beautiful buildings (over 800 years of architecture on 1 square!), pleasant terraces and a large variety of food and beverage kiosks.Defenitely a 'must see' for everyone who visits Prague for the first time - no matter if you go there for the cultural highlights or pub crawls, it all starts here!

Grab a snack at a restaurant in front of the clock in order to avoid the crowd. Nice open square with the clock being the big draw. We avoided being jostled in the crowd by having a small meal in one of the restaurants which sits facing the clock. That way we could sit and watch when the chimes went off. Beautiful churches surround the area with small crosses in the middle of the square marking where citizens were beheaded for their religious beliefs. Yikes! At the time we were there, a museum on the square was doing an exhibit on Tim Burton and his artwork which my teens loved.
Beautiful. A lot of beautiful architecture in one spot! Definitely worth the walk. Don't miss a free tour or get another proper explanation about the area.
People watching par excellence!. Refer to comments made for Old Town. This visit was part of our Viking River Cruise on the Elbe River. It was fantastic.

The Clock. Wall to wall tourists and I was one! Mind out for segways tho. Lots of local buskers, some were very good and plenty of choice regarding bars and restaurants, some of them outside type with heaters.Lots of city guides touting for business. They seemed to be doing well though.

A place with many offerings. Besides the great astronomical, clock, the old town is the place to find many great deals...free and paid walking tours, places to eat, Hard Rock Cafe, money changers, tourist info, souvenir shops, Thai massage shops , the way to the Jewish quarter, .. Low end and high end shopping..

Beautiful and entertaining.. I’ve been to Prague three times now and always set aside few hours to walk around the square. Architecture is beautiful and never gets old to look at; great people watching; Dali museum is right there not to mention some great shopping all around the square. During my last visit, I got the outside table at one of the restaurants there to get dinner and enjoyed the view for couple of hours. I was greatly entertained. Must see after sunset. The date of my last trip was 2012 although options at this site only go as far back as October '13

Touristy - but worth it!. We visited this square several times, once for food and another for a drink at the end of the day. Its a lovely square, but chock-a-block of tourists...so don't expect to move that quickly. However there are a lot of things to do just off the square (2 churchs and the town hall) all worth a look in!
Must see. This historic square is so beautiful, from the famous Astronomical Clock to the horse-drawn carriages, the church spires and food stalls, and the delightful entertainment.
Just another Old Town Square. The square was busy with lost of tourists and local youngsters. The buldings were typical european buildings. There were street performers everywhere.

One of the major attractions in Prague. While in Prague, this Place is a must to visit... for all it is Worth... Its history, its architecture, its Cultural Heritage and all those beautiful narrow streets leading in and out of this square! It is magical in the evening or at night... when the Whole square gets lit!! And those wonderful restaurants along the square!

Gorgeous. Spotless, charming, bustling- history is thick and rich, so is the beer and food! Wars have done the damage but the people have rebuilt everything beautifully. One of the most gorgeous cities I've ever seen.

good place to spend casual time. there is nothing very special about this place but if you want to spend come casual time have few drinks in restaurants on square. you will enjoy good view of the square with some small musical shows.
A must do. Great atmosphere with market stalls, entertainment and great eateries all around in an almost medieval setting

River cruise from Budapest to Amsterdam. River cruising in Europe is one of the best ways to discover the hidden gems of the Old World. As waterways were the only "highways" in ancient days, many lovely old towns lined the major rivers of Europe. Our 15 day cruise from Budapest to Amsterdam took us through the Danube, the Main, a man-made canal and finally the Rhine. It was a relaxed and comfortable way to see Europe, especially if you have already seen all the big, flashy touristy cities - the usual suspects, Paris, Munich, Frankfurt etc. On the river cruise, you visit towns you will never see when you undertake a land trip as many are small and quite out of the way. That does not make them any less attractive or interesting.If you have the time and have already seen the "usual suspects", do splash out on a river cruise. It is a little more expensive but well worth the money.
nice place not more. the clock is nice we wait 15 min to see the "show" it was disappointed we think we are going to see something extraordinary and it was nice not more.

Great atmosphere and lovely architecture. Can't beat the buzz of an old town square and this one delivers. It is well kept and makes tourists feel welcome. Loads of restaurants and places to drink as you expect as well as street theatre to watch too. Felt very safe here even solo late at night. Lots to snap at and people watching.

Watch the world go by. Atmosphere, just soak it up, buskers & horse drawn carriages. Cafes & restaurants to suit all tastes & pockets. Look out for pickpockets. Wander down the side alleys & window shop. View the astronomical clock & watch the newly weds posing for their photos. Shop selling absinth & a selection of Czech beers including a cannabis beer!!!

Beautiful square. Great spot to just sit and look around. Gorgeous buildings and architecture. Many street performers and people walking through. I recommend getting a beer and some old Prague ham and just enjoy it in the square.

Best place in Praha. It's where you can find everything: from Pub Craw people meeting each other to really nice pubs and restaurantes... from people on the square singing to people just performing something interesting... from shopping to drinking... from the Clock to the Bridge (the Astronomical Clock is in the Square, and the Charles Bridge is just a few minutes walking!)

Busy but worth a stroll. Very crowded and touristy the four times we walked through there. The restaurant we chose for lunch was terrible (one of the few ever rated terrible by me) and now I have forgotten the name. But the Astronomical clock is worth five minutes of your time to see it do its thing on the hour. And the shop Erpet (almost opposite the clock) is worthwhile for crystal. If you love ice cream, go down the side street next to Erpet about four blocks and there are two good ones: Boom and Angelato (turn right just after Boom to find Angelato on a side street). The square is much prettier early in the day or around dusk when the crowds are gone.

Must see. This is the center of all the action, any place you need to go in old downtown will start from the clock and make its way out on your journey. It's beautiful, it's historical, and it's a must see!
Beautiful but Busy!. No question, the buildings around the main square are worth a second and a third look. Best to visit early in the morning though as the square gets very crowded during the day.

Town Center. The Old Town Square offers an amazing view surrounded by tons of history. There are so many different places to check out. My favorite activity was grabbing a beer in the square and people watching. There are also many activities to participate in. Not to mention there are many great restaurants.

Worth seeing the interesting buildings here. And watching the clock on the old town hall is fun to do once. There was some good music on or near the square - and some not so good buskers as well. Beer is expensive in the square (twice what it is nearby) but may be fun to sit and people watch briefly.
Quite nice but crowded. This is a nice little area full of restaurants and shops selling kitsch. At the top of every hour the place becomes crowded due to the astronomical clock. Worth a visit.

One of the best area in praque !!!!!!. Honestly , i really really fall in love w/ this area, this area is sooo beautiful w/ all the historical buildings surrounded, astronomical click , cathedral, some luxury designer boutiques, but what i love the most, this area is so live, u see lots of food street, and those tasted yummy, pork knuckle, sausages, wine, whatsoever. What impressing me the most was all those artist in the street, u can see streetmusician , painter, artist performance, magician, and some more, very very entertaining, this is one area I always visit everyday, mostly afternoon to eveninf, so beautiful to see all the lights blend w/ the cultural and historical building, love it very much !!
A Buzz. Our hotel room looked out on the square. Buskers, Horses and carriages, people, food. Busy from sun up to loong after sun set. Only one word describes it and that is magical.

The centre of everything. I liked the Astronomic clock ,the huge cobbled square which was crowded with people ,especially in the evening enjoying watching the variety of street "theatre " and the beautiful old buildings and restaurants .

Great but Crowded.. The entertainment provided was only equaled by the views of cathedrals and the "Rathaus" with its animated scenes on the hour. Wait for the rooster! Unfortunately every tour group in Prague seems to be there every hour on the hour. It is really crowded but it is big enough that you can still get around easily.

The only place justifying an August European Vacation.... ...especially if you like to people-watch. I was there at the height of tourist season after lengthy walking tours of other Prague attractions and sitting in one of the square's outdoor restaurants enjoying a beer or few while watching fellow tourists was rejuvenating. I could see the Astronomical Clock, Church of Tyn, Seqway groups, and street performers from my seat. Had to repeat it a couple of days later after seeing the Castle. Watching restaurant hawkers trying to snare customers in was entertaining too. A less populated square might pale in comparison.
ESSENTIAL PRAGUE. Hang out a while. Read your guidebook and look at all aspects carefully. Crowds are a little turnoff but don't get discouraged.
Amazing. Yet more interesting buildings all around this square. Street musicians too. Horse drawn carriages. Very interesting.

We spent nearly the whole day. on our first day in Prague there was a lot to do, we saw a museum, walked around the whole area, went on a walking tour i bought a phone near the main shopping center.
the only thing which i couldn't get was a horse and cart ride

Picturesque but very crowded. The varied architecture of Prague is beautiful with the Old Town Square including the Astronomical Clock, Tyn Church, etc. However, it was so crowded with tourists and the usual over-priced street cafes and performers, that it is rather overwhelming.

Wow!. Walked over the Charles Bridge from our hotel, walked along the cobblestone streets looking at the shops and building and then suddenly, the square comes into view! Wow! There was so much going on, tourists, buskers, and people hawking tours and stuff. The best is standing in the square and looking at the surrounding buildings. Jaw dropping, beautiful, well preserved buildings.Wow!

Tourist trap. Although the architecture here is beautiful, the square is an overpriced tourist trap. There is no true czech culture here. There is no Czech music, dancing, or puppets, only street performers you would find anywhere in the world. Very disappointing. Anywhere on the Square is extremely overpriced. To get better priced meals, get off the Square. Most of the food is not very good anyway.

Focal point of the Old Town. The square is the starting point for many of the tours and the astronomical clock is a draw from 9 to 9 when the chimes and animation draw the crowds. During this time beware of pickpockets who prey on unsuspecting tourists. The other thing to beware is the amount of segways running loose on the square often in the hands of inexperienced pilots or experienced pilots too busy looking at pretty girls. There are often things going on in the square with buskers, bands and flower displays.Some will say it is a bit of a tourist trap but a visit to Prague would be incomplete without it.

Astrological Clock. Absolutely beautiful, but don't knock yourself out trying to get there on the hour to see the animation. The figures pass by an open window on the inside. Nice to see if you happen to be there, but not worth arranging your day around the 'performance'.

Atmosphere, music & art. Don't go just for the clock, the tower and the Tyn church: next to it, the Kinsky museum has a great collection on Asia and the ancient Mediterranean, which was almost empty when I was there - unlike the always crowded square! Also, if you have the chance, enjoy the buskers who usually play on the evenings. The atmosphere is amazing and relaxed.
nice. beautiful, we saw many couple taking photo with white dress! but the restaurants near-by used old prices, and higher service fee

Must see location. Wonderful buildings all around, including the tower with the famous clock. Nothing to tell you that Kafka's Dad had his shop nearby and Kafka walked to primary school through the streets nearby.

Authentic, Ancient, a must visit for the ambiance.. It is just not possible to miss the old town square, even if you are just rushing through the city.Authentic, well maintained, Ancient..... it is all this and more. The ambiance especially is over powering with its mixture of smells, sights and heady air of history. Just wander around, taking in the surfeit of shops and the fantastic chocolate in a small shop en route from the Charles bridge to the town square. The marionette shop with its collection of puppets was indeed a sight for the eyes, as was the astronomical clock which was a unique experience, though personally, I found the ancient clock in Vienna better. But that was Vienna and this is Prague. To each, its own.
“Holidays in a garden of paradise”. After last year' s visit, we could not imagine that our stay could be even more perfect. It was amazing!
Always Beautiful. Old Town Square is a must visit when in Prague. Very historic but still functioning town square (the small Christmas market is great if you are there during the winter).
Crowded. Well you can't miss the old town square out but it's crowded and over touristy with plenty of tat. However just step a few yards away to experience a lovely city.
A must when visiting Prague. This is without a doubt the no 1 place to visit. The clock, the atmosphere and all the activity is well worth a visit.
Stunning Old Town Square. From one end of the town square to the other, it's simply stunning. Very busy always around the Astronomical clock.

Beware the Foreign Exchange vendors . The beautiful Old Town Square is a gem of a place. But your nice visit can easily end up being your worst memory if you decide to exchange money in and around the various forex dealers. Please be aware of these unscrupulous money changers. The terms and conditions are not clearly displayed in English and you can be charged over 27% (yes that's right!) by them. We were recently duped into thinking that they were charging 2.7% which is displayed clearly, only to be told that this the locals rate (why would they need conduct forex in the old town square when their bank would do it without commission?). They made us sign a disclaimer without clearly showing the amount of deductions they were making and we ended exchanging $200 and getting charged $50 in commission!It's best to ensure that you contact your bank and enable a debit card from which you can easily remove cash from an ATM which gives you a relatively good rate with no commission. So don't let these agencies get away with your hard earned cash and ruin your holiday!

head on a swivel. strange title, but its true, there is that much going on your head will be on a swivel, from the buskers and some of them are really excellent, to the guys and gals zooming around on their segways,to the absolutly breathtaking architecture of the buildings, shopping it must be a ladies paradise, pubs clubs, tours, cafes, resteraunts, you name it prague has it, i could go on for ever but i aint going to bore you,when you go to the old town square if its getting near the hour on the clock go and stand infront of the astronomical clock and watch it strike the hour as it finnishes a guy at the top of the clock tower blowes a trumpet in all four directions then waves down to everyone nice little experiance,

Mixture of styles. It was a little bit strange, because all the buildings from this square have different styles and belong to different arhitectural eras. But every buildig has it's quallity and all are beautiful. This is one of the crowdest places in Prague, but Prague is not as crowded as the other towns I visited. My favourite was the astronomical tower with it's clock. Too bad it wasn't working when I went there. I would go there one more time just to see that clock in action.

Pleasant setting to watch the world go by.... We visited here several times - once to go on a bus tour, once to see clock tower (and climb to the top for fab views), and once or twice for refreshments. Some good buskers!

Beautiful architecture . The architecture of the square makes it very easily easy for one too imagine life in a bye gone era. It is fabulous however as with many well trafficked locations it comes with its fair amount of kitsch. Try to get off the main square and discover the little gems a little further a field and you'll be rewarded with a more authentic and reasonable experience. Must say the astronomical clock was beautiful but a bit of an anticlimax when the clock struck but nonetheless a must see. The towers and the bridge makes the old town more medieval feeling and are must sees. Get off the beaten track and meet the locals and it will be worth it.
Beautiful!. It is amazing to sit in this square and imagine the number of people who have walked the streets, and ponder the history contained in the square!

Worth a stop.... But don't buy anything or drink anything as you will pay an outrageous price...but it is pretty and definitely worth a visit. The square is large andif you do not go "on the hour" when everyone is watching the astronomical clock it should be seen...take a look at the Jan Hus statue and of course, a great view of the "Tyn" church.
Great Atomosphere. The town square is surrounded by historic buildings. In the evenings there are many buskers performing. It can get quite crowded.

A lovely and romantic city. Very beautiful with castles, Charles Bridge, Astronomical Clock, Old town Square, and everything else. Definitely worth the time and money to get to the top of Astronomical, Castles, to see the whole city. The city is just like what you always imagine in any fairy tales story or movies and makes you want to come back again and again. We did Food & Culture tour for 4hours and it is actually a good choice. We had so much FOOD and they are GOOD. Highly recommend!
great architecture. Great site, you should visit it!When you get tired of walking then there are a lot of nice pubs and restaurants everywhere.
old town square. beautiful town square,the clock,restaurants,shops.free walking tours,concert halls,museums,every thing wihin easy reach.
Must view in Prague. Surrounded by classic building. Recommened to visit in early morning as it will be crowded after noon.But the food from stalls are a bit over priced.

One of the kind and best in Prague. Prague Old Town Square is one of the most visited places in Europe and Prague. It has been dated back to 12th century and include unique historical gothics and barock/renesance buildings ( most famous is By Stone Bell from 14th century) and churches ( St. Nicolas -barock 18th century; St Tyn from 14th century). Most visited is centuries old Clock ( from about 1410) with day, month year and time calendar, music and 12 apostols spinning from the window of old tower. Old town gothic tower and adjacent building has been Prague city house and it was built by King J.Lucemburg in 1338. You can claim up to the tower for splendid city views. During the day and at the evenings, many musicians and artists perform at the square for tourist. Most of the churches have an evening high quality classical music concerts. There are several hotels near by ( Grand, Rott etc.) and numerous restaurants and bars and street refreshments kiosks. At the western part of square, there are stand for city bus tours, tourist infomation shop and numerous exclusive shops. A Short walk from square is a Karlova street which leads to 14th century Charles Bridge built under King Charles IV.. Merlantrichova street in north part leads you to Wenceslav ( Vaclavske namesti) square with nany shops, restaurants and night bars. About 10 minutes walk you can visit Old Jewish cemmentary dated back to 15th century ( with more than 12 layers) and Synagog Pinkas also from 15th century.
Nicest central square in Europe?. Art gallery, restaurants, the old clock, street food, street entertainers a great buzz into the night.

Old Town Square. Some really beautiful buildings of historical interest and soak up the atmosphere and surroundings over a coffee or something stronger at one of the many pavement cafes lining the square as they cater alfresco all year round with patio heaters for that all important people watching to add to the mix as people gather around the astronomical clock to watch its hourly chime.. Don't miss the opportunity to climb the Old Town Hall Tower for a stunning view over the square.Wenceslas Square and Charles Bridge have some amazing architecture too, in all Prague is a wonderful place, its has plenty of atmosphere for either a romantic break or a trip with friends.

Fabulous!. If you have only a short time, you must go here and the Charles Bridge (Karlov Most). The square is large, with multiple churches, a ton of cafes and a number of street vendors, lots of people people watching (and probably listening) - sit on a bench or in a cafe and spend a bit of time before you wander through the shops on the square and adjacent streets. Check it out at night, too! Restrooms are available in your restaurant, but there are public, well marked WC's, also.

Lively and buzzing place with a backdrop of castle,astronomical clock. Amazing place- lively and buzzing with restaurants, tourists and a backdrop of castle,astronomical clock. We were lucky to have perfect timing and could watch some local musicians playing music in the square which was a treat for ears.We also started our 3 hour walking tour from the square.

Sure to put a smile on your face. Walking around here it is difficult to know what to look at first. The place is a hive of activity with buskers, lots of choice in restaurants and heaps to see. This whole area is where I recommend if you only have a day.

Lovely square. Brilliant atmosphere, always filled with tourists and casual Czech's enjoying their meals overlooking the square. Lovely street music played along with entertainment in the square. Buildings are beautifully designed. Definitely worth going on a free tour collected from under the astronomical clock.

What a Great Square!. Beautiful large square with the most beautiful architecture surrounding you. Lots of stands to buy fresh sausages, ham, ice cream, etc. Also the astronomical clock is something not to miss and lots of restaurants. Go at night to see everything lit up, but don't miss during the day either!

Very nice. We enjoyed the architecture and walking through the old city. It was very nice to see the different cultures and people. The clock was a must see at least once. There was a market nearby where we found most of our souviners. It was also nice to sit on a bench and just watch the people.
loved it. Beautiful buildings, and good places to eat. We sat a coupls of nights in a restaurant overlooking the square it was very pleasant.

The clock certainly chimes. Go and see the astronomical clock on the hour. Not to watch it chime but to watch in wonder the engrossed expressions on hundreds of tourists. Maybe they have come thousands of miles to see this. Now go and find some interesting restaurants in the myriad of passageways and side streets. All the restaurants on the square will be full of clock-watching tourists.

Pick up a horse drawn carriage from here. A popular focal point for tourists, surrounded by beautiful buildings and an array of quality bars and restaurants. You can pick up a carriage for a tour of the area from here. You'll also find several quality street artists performing in the vicinity

OLD TOWN SQUARE. Astronomical Clock. TYN Church. Not Wenceslas Square but The Old Town Square is must in Prague. Such a beautiful square, each historical building is well kept, astronomical clock, churches, restaurants, coffee shops, street musicians ..... this is Prague

Almost goes without saying, visit this place. Beautiful architecture and a great atmosphere. So many restaurants and attactions to visit.
A small tip would to find a restaurant on one of the side streets of the square. You'll find considerably cheaper food and beer.
Magic. The Old Square Place takes you in a different time. the little show of the Big Clock, the small restaurants and generally the atmosphere make you live Prague deeply.
Its beautiful, but not stunning.. Have expected it to be much better. Probably die to bad weather, the square didnt look very impressive. It is not big nor delicate.

Sit and enjoy the view. We stayed in a hotel only five minutes from the Old Town Square and went there every day to sit at a cafe or on one of the benches just to people watch. It's a lovely square with the famous astronomical clock at one side so lots of tourists gather there. You can watch the horses and carriages and drink coffee at one of the many restaurants around the edges of the square. The Alphonse Mucha museum has an entrance there and it is definitely worth a visit. We saw a Dali exhibition while we were there. The side streets are cobbled and full of small shops and cafes. We heard an astonishingly good pianist busking in the square. It's very entertaining. There's plenty to do and see in Prague so make this a regular spot.

Enchanting, bustling Old Town Square. There's no better place to stay in Prague. Prague’s majescic Old Town Square is located in the heart of the city and close to everything. A labyrinth of twisting cobblestone lanes and alleys surround Old Town Square, and every time I turned a corner, the view took my breath away.You will be transported to an entirely different era. The square is lined by magnificent Baroque and Gothic churches, as well as imposing Renaissance palaces; and of course the Old Town Hall,and the astronomical clock; which draws large crowds to watch the procession of saints at every hour.There are plenty of cozy cafes where you can experience local fare, and pubs, each with its own menu of beers. You could explore this area for days and still not uncover all of its hidden wonders.

Fairytale. Number one place to visit in Prague. Its like a fairytale. For sure you will visit the square more than two-three times. Very nice buildings with impressive architecture, thousands of people from different cultures, you can sit and just spend you time seeing their reactions. Full of musicians and entertainers, plenty things to see, have your walk and enjoy your day. Square is surrounded by small shops, café and restaurants. A great selection of everything.
Oups! Im not alone.... If you like nice historical buildings and crowded places this is one of many places in Prague for you!But remember only a block or two from here the prices are much lower

Beautiful and atmospheric. As soon as I walked in to the old town square I got such a lovely feeling. The buildings are beautiful and it has such a lovely atmosphere. Surrounded by cafés and restaurants. We visited once at night and again the next morning, making sure we got to see the astronomical clock striking the hour. I wish I could have spent more time here!

Beautiful, the stuff of Fairytales... An absolutely lovely place. Our apartment was just off the old town square, so we were able to experience the magic every day, and through the changing pattern of the day. It was equally lovely all the time, night time was especially lovely.

Old World Feeling. The square is surrounded by tons of little shops and cafe's. The proximity to the Charles Bridge is close. The Alphonse Mucha museum is hidden behind a cafe but worth the admission price to see some original paintings.

great place to visit. A must see if you are in Prague. Plenty to see and do and a great many places to eat. You cannot make a visit to Prague without visiting at least a few of the attractions here. Stunning architecture and central location. Always surrounded by musicians and entertainers - its also a photographers delight!!
Very interesting site. Really liked exploring this side of the city, so see monuments and old architecture. Try to join a walking tour to have information on the quirks of the city.
tour guide. all very interesting, plenty of places to eat, lots of attractions, shops, and you do not get hassled.

Atmospheric. Stunning buildings surrounded by musicians and entertainers which never gets old (apart from the copious amount of golden statue men who I personally find more creepy than intriguing). You definitely need to visit here when coming to Prague.
Cant Miss This!!. A frenzy of sites and sounds-- street entertainers, cafes, endless tour guides, historic sites close by, etc

Nice. Pros - You can actually notice something new everytime you get there! The clock on the hour is really cool.
Cons - Very very crowded
Beautiful Square. Such an incredibly beautiful square with so much to see and do! Loads of nice restaurants and bars and the square is just amazing to look at!

Iconic place and a must visit!. You simply can't afford to miss that place (and I'm pretty sure most visitors to Prague won't). Great view of the old city center, festive vibe, solid choice of restaurants in the neighborhood.

Great People Watching. We loved the Old Town Square. It has loads of people, different types of entertainment, a great number of restaurants and street vendors. Also the place to catch a carriage ride if you want one. We enjoyed sitting on the curb listening to music and watching people. Also a great place to make your start and ending point when exploring all the little streets that come off of it!
Beautiful place. One of my favourite places in Prague, there is always something happening there, be it bubble blowing or other kind of street entertainment.

Crowded but beautiful. Only thing I don't recommend are the food vendors selling traditional Czech food. I thought it'd be more like street food but it was way more expensive than in other parts of the city.

Fun loving square. We just loved visiting the Old Town Square. The astronomical clock was awesome. Hard to believe it was built in the 1400's. It works just great. Our tour guide explained all of the different things on the clock. Every hour the clock chimes and the doors open up at the top of the clock. The were several bands playing in the square during different times of the day. Lots of shops and places to eat all around the square. Very enjoyable.
Old Town Square. Nice place to sir and watch the world go by!!Expensive for drinks and food. Beautifully lit at night, and plenty of restaurants in the adjoining side streets

Old Town Square. This square is everything it is hyped up to be.The atmosphere in the square itself is always exciting and is where every gathers after waiting for the famous astronomical clock to strike and show it works on every hour.It must be the most photographed clock in the world.The square itself is always full with unusual buskers and the square is surrounded by shops ,stalls and restruants which together should account for a couple of hours of your visit each day of your trip.A really great place,I would highly recommend a visit.

Wonderful city. Old Town Square stunning, takes you back in time. Vibrant city full of life and fun. Food, beer available while you enjoy the ambiance. Architecture absolutely beautiful. Lots of shops, restaurants, pubs to serve all ages.
Dumplings. Fruit dumplings covered with poppy seed. Just like mom use to make. Excellent. Could not find them in any other restaurant.Went ther three times.
Fun atmosphere. Of course, you have to go there it's where everyone is. The clock is there and amazing architecture.
Beautiful. This square is right downtown. It looks like a fairytale. There's a lot of music, bars, restaurants and the clock. You can go in the tower for a nice view.

Loved Prague. This is an absolutely stunning city. The old town is just amazing. I was also pleasantly surprised at how fairly priced the surrounding restaurants and bars were in this city - and the Food, Beer & Wine is second to none. The square is very busy and there are lots of tourists, but it is still worth seeing (and there is lots of great people watching). Once you wander out of the square things get a lot quieter (we were the only people having lunch in the restaurant we found) and it gives you a chance to just soak it all in. Prague is also a very walk-able city - we saw most of the attractions on foot.

Utterly Bonkers Original Bohemian. Its like stepping back in time in some Bohemian fantasy - stolen straight out of a gothic novel or black and white film, although the colour version is so much more with a stunning vista wherever you look. Wandering around the square you come across all sorts of high end shops and boutiques check by jowl with bars pedalling Absinthe.

Wonderful!!. Probably the highlight of our trip to Prague. A great selection of everything that Prague has to offer in a pretty central location that is easy to get to - even from the edge of town!Pros: Eclectic architecture (no shortage of photo opportunities), easy walking, great variety of restaurants (at sensible prices), very competitive shopping, enthusiastic (not necessarily talented) free entertainment, no pushy touts and safe and friendly (even at night). Cons: the entertainment is the Square was a little bewildering during our daytime visit!Staromestske namesti is a wonderful intro to Prague!

Great ambience. during our visit in Prague, we actually visited the old square couple times. the astronomical clock, the view from its tower, really something you can not missed. don't forget to try a bite of Trdelník/Kürtőskalács, we still craving for it even after couple months (there's only 1 store that sold this bakery in Jakarta-Indonesia, but the taste is totally different). the surroundings are worth to be explored on walking tour. you can go to The thai massage in the corner of the square after that, my wife even got her back pain healed. but the price is a little bit pricey. one thing we also enjoyed is the old tram, something we could not find everyday here in jakarta.

Old world feel. The architechture in Prague is breath-taking. Although Old Town Square is touristy and crowded, it is still something you have to see while in Prague. The views of all the old building and their gothic looking spires was impressive to say the least. The view from the top of the astronomical clock was amazing! Be sure to try some of the food from the little vendors in the square. Sure, it's touristy, but still pretty good.
WELL RUN RESTAURANT. Had a lovely meal - staff very nice - and prices very goodPortions enormous Would go again suitable for couples and families

Great to people watch and while away the hours. Lots of bars and eating establishments.A place to people watch and watch the street entertainers at night.Hot toddys or hot chocolate and food to consume off the street vendors.With magnificent architecture and the striking of the Clock

Beyond Magnificent. One of the most beautiful squares I've seen. You can spend an entire afternoon strolling the square, dining, sitting and marveling at its beauty or shopping. Parizska Street has many of the top fashion salons... Prada, Gucci, Zegna.. be prepared to pay!! While the food prices are unbelievably low...goods are not.
Great place. Great place. Lots of tourists. Just a great historical place with all beutifull buildings. Museum is outside. We were travelling in the dream. Must visit !!!

Vibrant. Had a lot of fun listening to some medieval style street music, seeing all the little cabins selling their touristy wares. Food from the stalls is overpriced and one is hassled by staff from restaurants to enter their particular establishment, however, food isn't too expensive considering the location and you get an interesting view during your meal. We had a wedding take place during our lunch, doves released and a horse and carriage pull up right next to our table. Worth a visit for the architecture and only moments away from Charles' Bridge.
Beautiful. Gorgeous architecture. Bustling with people. Celestial clock is amazing. Make sure to go at night when it is illuminated...beautiful!
Nice space. As i had been living in Prague for a couple of years there, i visited there quite a few times. There was always some activities and atractions there.
prague. it´s amazing, is no need to say anything else. a lot of friendly pople. good food, a lot of things to see. czech beer is unbeatable. the centre is car free zone.
A must!!. For me, it seems to be the heart of Prague. This square has a lot of history. If you do visit Prague, this is a must!!

Fantastic view from clocktower.. For just a few CZK you can ascend to the top of the historic clock tower in the square and have a panoramic view of the city. If you go early in the morning there are no crowds and you can take your time.
Interesting. numerous lovely buildings with a busy center square of musicians and street performers, restaurants pricey

Magical. Too bad it is so crowded because the buildings are so beautiful in this square. It really is magical. Don't miss seeing the astronomical clock on the hour. Read about this amazing masterpiece before you see it

Fantastic clock. This is the main area for tourists with all the shops and restaurants being here but the first thing we wanted to see was the clock and it was as good as we had been told the whole area was lovely from the cobbled streets to the wonderful buildings it was a pleasure just to soak up the atmospher and I would highly recommend you visit

Just worth a short visit. Granted, the buildings are original, rather than reconstructions like so many other European squares, and the main square is lively. Still its mostly food stalls, overpriced cafes and restaurants for tourists, and a very over-rated glockenspiel. Since Prague is so inviting and walkable, stroll through here, but head to the Castle or Charles bridge. And beware pick-pockets whenever the tourists crowds gather on the hour!

Stunning!. A beautiful square that is well worth the visit, but quite pricey so make sure you've got some extra money out if you're eating here. But it's worth it at night as everything looks lovely lit up.

Crowded and Touristy. A fun place to see and be seen. The area is surrounded by cafes and shops. One good shopis Erpet right near the square, with an added bonus of public bathrooms that were very clean and neat. Crowded with tourist and performers. A great place to get the feel of the city.
crowded in summer. lots of street performers, cafes, and outdoor restaurants. Fun shopping. Watch out for pick pockets though!

Unique architectural mixture of centuries. Many tourists are excited by this place whixh is one of the most famous tourist attractions of Prague. Old Town Square is indeed a unique place where you can see the concentrated mixture of buildings - architecture which takes you through the centuries. My advice for those who like architecture is : sit at the bottom of the centrally located statue of the famous reformist of early 15th century Jan Hus and just look around and enjoy the spirit of the place. Than go and dip into the narrow streets of the Old Town.

Nice place. The area is lovely with lots of ancient buildings and the Astronomical Clock. If it's summer do wear a hat as it can get quite hot walking around.There are lots of restaurants around the square and along the roads that radiate out from it. The ones in the square are filled with tourists and stay open late (till around midnight) whereas the ones further away close earlier.Nice place to visit and people-watch.

Crowded but amazing. It is big square with all building all around during your walk to Charles bridge. There is plenty of restaurants, shops and hotels. There is also a tower called Orloj where you may see each hour good performance of old times atists mechanics. It is a little bit over crowded but it is worth to see it.

Fabulous Historic Square. This huge square is surrounded by history. The fully-restored buildings range from the 14th century. The centuries old astronomical clock attracts thousands of viewers when each hour strikes, the rooster crows, the bells ring, and the disciples emerge. Watch for pickpockets in this crowded venue. Numerous indoor/outdoor restaurants abound, but beware, their prices are pegged to the tourist, not to the locals, who think anyone paying $5 for a cup of coffee or beer is crazy. And they are right. The same can be had at half the price just a few blocks off the square. A statue of Jan Hus is a central feature in the square. A stair climb or elevator to the top of the city hall's clock tower is worthwhile for a grand view of the surroundings and a bird's eye view of the square. A must-see location when in Prague.Gaye and Peter, Victoria, B.C., Canada

Historical and Lively. Always packed with people in the summer, it mixes history and a bit of street art: artist of all types perform their shows there for hundreds of tourists. It is the starting point for many of the walking tours (I strongly recommend Sandemans, especially with a guide named Martin who is a local and knows a lot about history and seems passionated about it). Although the clock of the Old Town Hall has been rated the 2nd most disapointing tourist attraction, I'd recommend you get to know about the clock's history and symbolism: it makes it very interesting indeed (but do not expect much from the "clock show", cause there isn't much indeed).

Lovely for people watching!. Lots of bars & restaurants, lots of street performers, and the Astronomical Clock is here too! Some of the tour companies operate from this square too. Shopping area is all around here. Pavements are cobbled EVERYWHERE so take comfortable footwear!

Brilliant place. It's a constant hub of activity with tons of tourists and restaurants wanting their custom and money. But it makes for an amazing atmosphere, with the architecture taking you back to how you imagine old London would have looked before the blitz and great fire. Wonderful place.

Stand in awe. Is a historic square in the Old Town quarter of Prague.With its ancient buildings and magnificent churches, this is one of the most beautiful historical sights in Europe. The most notable sights on the square are the Old Town Hall Tower & Astronomical Clock, but you can give the procession of the Twelve Apostles a miss.Numerous cafes and bars dot the old town square and you can sit in any of them for hours soaking in the beauty.
Beautiful city. A lovely square with lots going on - Street entertainers including music, mime artists, giant balloon making for children. Nice restaurants.
Amazing city. This city was stunning, you really feel like you are in a fairytale. The old town is one of the most beautiful place i have ever seen, with the big tower and the astronomical clock
busy and interesting. lots to see. food vendors very expensive. restrooms nearby the area. the double zodiac clocks were great to see. the streets were old and the architecture was beautiful.

Beautiful, historical and lively. The middle of the action. It's neat to be surrounded by such old, historic buildings, but also to have contemporary life going on in the middle. Things get crowded and there are lots of people, it can get a bit hectic. The churches are beautiful to visit, and there are plenty of cafes, although we had to hunt a bit for good food.

A great square. Very busy and full of tourists, but great fun ,safe,but a tip if you want to eat buy something take away from one of the side streets and bring it back, sit on a chair and watch the passing paradeEnjoyed by my wife and i

Stare Miesto, Prague. Out of our European tour we found Prague the most beautiful. Old Town is absolutely beautiful, with very old buildings,it is almost like being in a fairy tale. We stayed in a 14 th century building, located in a small square, with walking distance to restaurants, cafes, shops and the river. We were there for four nights and it was ample time to see and enjoy the Old Town. A must płace to visit.
Very crowded and amazing. Standing there between two churches on a big square, watching what's going on...so many people, such a great atmosphere...is just beautiful. Don't miss it and enjoy it!

Essential for all visitors to Prague!. This place is simply a must for any sightseers in Prague. Not only is it indescribably beautiful but it is so conveniently located that you will find yourself returning to it time and again. It is just a short walk away from the New Town and Wenceslas Square, and in the other direction you have Charles Bridge leading to the castle and St. Vitus Cathedral, and in yet another direction you can easily reach the Jewish quarter. In the Old Town Square you have some great bars and restaurants as well as the Church of Our Lady before Týn and Astronomical Clock. If you have the time you should climb the tower of the Old Town City Hall (the building with the Astronomical Clock) where you will have panoramic views of the town. Visit it during the morning, the afternoon, the evening and at night and visit it often!
Loved it all !. Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !

The Square. Plenty of things to entertain i.e jugglers,mimes also great buildings, restaurants and pubs. Well worth visiting twice once in the morning when its quiet and when it is lite up at night. A great place to people watch.
A beautiful town square. This town square is the most beautiful asset of Prague's Old Town. A must-see is the Astronomical Clock! But also visit the Brazilian steak restaurant, just off the square.

Fascinating if you have a tour guide. We were here on Thursday before we met the Naked Man tour guide on Friday. What a difference a day makes after we received historical information. I want to get back, fascinating.

One of the most beautiful places I've ever been. The highlight of Prague. It's like you are in a fairytale. However, it's really crowdy if you visit it during morning and evening. Try to go very early in the morning to see it at its hole glory without the tourists.
Just amazing. This square might be one of the nicest in Europe. Beautiful, colorful, Joyful and full of life. Must be visited at night and during the day.

Old Town Square. I loved the Square. It was full of people most of the day. A lot of people gather there to listen to bands and musicians playing on the square all day. There are quite a few places to eat all around it. From there you can go visit the jewish quarter, the King Charles Bridge or even walk along Parizska Street where all the luxury shops are.

Lively, Lots Of Restauants. A huge square that has plenty of restaurants, the famous Astronomical Clock and street entertainers. A perfect place to sit with a beer or a coffee and watch the world go by !

Simply stunning. Everybody told me the old town square was beautiful, but I was nonetheless impressed by its beautiful architecture, typical food stalls where you can taste Czech specialties or restaurants and cafés where to sit down and simply enjoy the view. It's definitely a must and deserves the maximum rating.

Must see!. The heart of Prague and a must see... you are bound to pass through it a few times while you are there anyway. Defintely take a trip up the tower and get the best views of the town, we did this before sunset and got some amazing pictures!

Beautiful old town square. Loved this square where you are surrounded by beautiful buildings, street entertainers and unfortunately lots of very annoying segways (is there anywhere that is free from American influences??!!!!) that aside it’s a great place to while away a couple of hours listening to the bands and people watch in a great atmosphere. Wish there were squares like this in the UK
Beautiful scenery . What an amazing place the square of Prague old town. Went up high in the central building and took done really nice pictures. The views were stunning.
it was included in our tour. it was a weekend and it was very busy did not have much time to look at the small souveniors shops it all looked QUAINT.

Lively and beautiful. Tyn Church and the Astronomical Clock are the two highlights. We took the elevator to the top of the clock for a great view of the square and surrounding area. That was great! Many restaurants and shopping in the Square as well as street performers livening up the Square which was fun!

Best place in Town, Castle excepted.. Knocks spots off Wencelas Square. lots of interesting building around it and cafes. The clock tower is worth the climb (there are lifts as well). Great atmosphere at night. Watch out for hidden charges in some restaurants.

A must see - but go at 7 am!. This place is a must see for every newcomer to Prague, so by all means go there, but it comes at a price, during prime season there are people everywhere from morning to midnight, so my advice is go very early in the morning and your will have much better experience. Also, go once very late in the evening to see it at night - it is truly a great place.
Must watch the old Clock. At every hour the clock will do a great performance. Also worth to go up to the tower, has great view from the city skyline.

Lively square. There's the usual touristy stuff such as horse carriages. Then the great architecture and pleasant atmosphere A must see as it is in the center of historic Prague, this lively square is surrounded by baroque buildings, vibrant cafes, street entertainers and craftspeople.

Great place to hang out. Head for the Old Town Square to enjoy a lovely atmosphere, meet with friends, settle down with a drink and enjoy watching the world go by. We spent some time enjoying musical groups doing there thing - also people watching and generally enjoying the amazing architecture that surrounds the square. The buildings are utterly beautiful and a photographers dream. The churches, cathedrals etc are a must to visit and an afternoon spent here is worth every second

Beautiful Place. Old town square very beautiful square with many restaurants, cafes and shops. The square is really busy at certain times of the day but very pleasant experience. I will be back to visit as I didn't get round to see everything it had to offer.

So much fun and beauty. This is another placed it worth going to several times in a stay in Prague. We went there in the morning, the afternoon and at night time. The buildings are so simply incredible to behold, plus there's all kinds of fun activity including rather bizarre musical shows. It's fun to go on the hour and see the Astronomical Clock do it's show.

Popular tourist location. Plenty of restaurants and bars. Crowded after 9.30am. Lots of historic buildings to visit. Food stalls open until 9.30pm and prices are low. A very popular location with tourists. It is a short walking distance to Charles bridge.
Old town. We walked there from hotel in 15mins max. Street performers. One guy collecting for an engagement ring which was amusing.
Beautiful and quaint. Absolutely awesome place to be surrounded by beautiful buildings, The Astrological clock is right there on the square - Check out the hourly show

if you just have a few hours in Prague, go there. That is the heart of Pragure, with the astronomical clock, with all the beautiful buildings, the medieval streats sprouting from there... Visit there, and you can say that you have experienced Prague, even if for just a couple of hours.

You have to see this!. Beautiful place full of positive energy and many tourist of course. There is lots of street artist around. Also you have to try trdelnik. Some kind of cake selling everywhere around this place

Romantically beautiful !. Last month I was in Prague. It's a city with many faces. The most intriguing is the language. I could not fathom any grammatical tips so that I could learn some Czech. but otherwise, it's was such a joy to roam around the squares and streets of Prague. Its history is so rich, and the castles, palaces, monuments and museums, are well kept and well guarded. But what I liked most was the night atmosphere. It felt safe and homely going round among the lit up shops and restaurants. We were in a hotel close to Wenceslas Square.  This square is awesome! It's so long and active!And the incline towards the museum is so imposing!! From the other end you can walk through a few narrow streets that reminded me of our Imdina, and you find yourself in OLD TOWN SQUARE.  OH...this is an amazing place.... it bubbles with activity. It felt like being in a romantic place where you feel your heart beating faster with excitement! The crowds are so happy, so many nationalities enjoying themselves simply by walking around, or drinking at a bar, or having dinner in one of the many restaurants all around. To see everybody smiling and having fun is a joy to behold. Something else I noticed is the reasonable prices of drinks and food. I was misinformed about the city, having been given the impression that it's very expensive. It's very reasonable, and the people are so helpful, although I have to say that It lacks knowledge of the English language.Very few people speak good English, but we got around easily in spite of that. The old clock attracts many tourists, as it has a particular tone on every hour.  I can say only this.... if you haven't been.... you must go....and be as romantic as you can!!! Enjoy Prague!
Great Place to Start. This was our first stop and we came back many times. People watching, the home of Einstein, St Nicolas Chapel, Tyn Chapel, the Astronomical Clock, and Trdelnik.

This is really Prague. Yes - go for the ambience, go for the people watching, go for the varied architecture. Don't miss it. It's fun to eat at a cafe surrounding the square, but be forewarned these restaurants are pricier than those off the square. (But, when will you have a chance to do this again?) Various musicians playing around the square. Watch out for the Seg Ways. They zoom around often uncontrollable, but it's fun to watch them maneuver between people. Wait for the astronomical clock to perform, only if you have to wait 5 - 10 minutes. It's pretty simple, but people seem to enjoy it nonetheless. Just enchanting.

A Must See When In Prague !!!. I liked the world-renowned Astronomical Clock, the Restaurants, Cafes and the few shops on the one side of the Square. The Chocolaterie VIVA Praha offers awesome & delicious Belgian-origin, but Czech-made chocolates. It even has a "museum" showing you how superb chocolates are actually made! Remember to take your Camera with you to the Old Town Square and to have an eye around for any rarely-hitting pick-pocketers. Rarely hitting because the place is most of the time supervised by discrete Police. So, nothing to be really scared of, just have an eye out for your personal belongings... Especially, your pockets and wallets!

A Must See. Great place any time of day - and make sure you see it different times of the day as it looks different depending on how the sun is hitting the area of with the churches and buildings lit up at night.

Touristy, Loud, but Heart of City. A good guide can bring this large square, its buildings, history and personalities to life. Mid day in August it is pretty full with lots of tourists, tours, Segways and entertainers. We passed through on a walking tour and again several times on our own. Even though I don't like crowds, it's a must see.

Quirky and atmospheric.. Wow! Rich in character and culture. Amazing street artists & buskers and surrounded by impressive buildings. Took numerous photos. Enjoyed travelling through the square to other parts on Prague...although we often lingered.
Nice. You won't get tired of admiring it, as long as you ignore the usual street performers, and the hundreds of tourists you'll find everywhere.

Love it early morning. When the street swiper is still working and the first weary eyed people come out of their hotels and homes it's great - I love tourist cities in the mornings or at night - it's totally different during the day.
Busy. Lots to see many attractions on a par with Covent Garden in London singers and entertainers restaurants etc
Beautiful mob scene. Beautiful, amazing and mobbed. Even the younger folks on our tour were exhausted after 3 hour tour. There is so much to see.

Beautiful place and beautiful atmosphere. In Prague everything is pleasant. The art, the desire to do (but without the frenzy) that is breathed in every corner, the music .. everything makes you feel in a modern world but at the same time romantic and special.
Take a walk back in history. The whole ambience was nice. Only problem is the crowds...you can't visit Prague without seeing the famous clock that is in the square.

Quite a rip off. Loved our first visit to Prague and the Old Town was our favourite, however we felt that the equivalent to around £22 was very expensive for a portion of potatoes, cabbage and bacon and ham with two slices of bread! My husband could not see a price before ordering and did not realise that the price 'depended' on the weight of the meat you were served. These were bought from the wooden cabins in the square. Myself and my daughter had a dish that was similar to a pizza except that the dough was fried, one would have been plenty between us, bought from another cabin and was fairly priced. Saw quite a few tramps/beggars here but they were not offensive or intrusive. Tip: remember to have 10Ck (about 30p I think) for all the public toilets, some hotels also charge even if you eat at their restaurant.
Super Place. Wide open area filled with street entertainers and tourists enjoying the scene. In the middle of the most important places to see in Prague. Day or night, lots happening!

Wow!. Will take your breath away with it's medieval splendour. All of the attractions listed in the guide books are worth a look. The square is surrounded by excellent cafes and bars. The street entertainers are of a good standard too!
Tourist Attraction. Nice major square with many people hanging out and music. Also food stands and shops so its a must see.

Nice square. When you go there you will see old buildings together. Its lıke you passing to the history. Clock tower has really different show. You should wait for the show. But it will worth. Its different gate to the prag history, and was enjoyable.

Lovely place to watch time go by!. Very busy but great combination of art, history and culture. Must watch astronomical clock on the hour!!! Also make sure you do the tour of the Town Hall and underground to see the real Prague. Prices for food a little more expensive here so wander down side streets for better food and slightly cheaper. Also avoids the crowds at busy times.

Worth a visit in the evening!. During the day hours it might be too crowded and busy, so you can find yourself trying to take photo with another 1000 people.Go there in the evening, the buildings are beatuiful!

You'll feel inside a fairytale. I love the different types of architecture, and it makes you feel like you're travelling through time. Every building is unique, worth to spend a little time just wandering around. You can't miss the astronomical clock, with its performance hourly.It's a place filled with history.

Gorgeous!. Walking through here on our first night was unforgettable. The old architecture, and the colorful buildings and huge churches made us feel like we were transported into a fairytale. There were many tourists around, which I guess is normal as this is the main sight in the city. And be careful about the prices of restaurants on the square, as they seemed to be higher than many we found just outside the center.But other that we found it to be so beautiful and majestic. A must visit for anyone coming to Prague, especially at night!

you cant miss it!. Old Town square is the hub! Thousands of people day and night strolling around. Musicians set up and people just stop and drop to listen to the music! Its got a great vibe, plan to hang out and stay awhile!

Magical and Majestic. Everyone will visit the Old Town Square but make a point of visiting it in the evening when the old buildings are all bathed in light. It's both magical and majestic.The square is a hive of people enjoying the ambience and being entertained by various very talented street artists. It has that "feel good " atmosphere.

Beautiful Place in Prague at Night!. A beautiful & notable town square in Prague. At the weekend, you should try come at night and enjoy the rest of your night surround with bunch of local people crowds here. Many street performers, a great foods and somehow its quite romantic dating here. Basically, I love the local people here, since they're very nice and friendly with foreigners. You could also explore the whole town square by walk until you find the Charles Bridge and its very recommended to stop for awhile & enjoy the river view. Its totally worth it and fantastic!
Must seee. So beutiful and so rokantic place. You feel history and some special power of oall old prague. Every one must see it.
Old Town Square Enchantment. It was like looking at the Harry Potter neighborhood. You could imagine them flying on the brooms around the towers... quite magical with very little imagination!

Medieval splendor -old town square. This is almost the 1st stop in Prague for all tourist. The street is made up of cobble stones. And dates back to the 10C with the church of Tyn on one side which is a gothic masterpiece with fairy tale spirals on one side. On the other side u will see the famous Astronomical clock, which chimes by the hour which is a work of art. Almost all guided tours begin from around the market place and you can see the guides with their colorful umbrellas around the place.One can spend hours roaming around the alleys of cafés, galleries and quaint souviner shops.Since July ,August are tourist months, the place does get overcrowded.

Nice but Krakow is Better. With Krakow fresh in my memory I have to say I enjoyed that Old Town Square Better. Both had lots of things going on but the beauty was greater in Krakow. Both were busy, but Krakow seemed to have more local attractions to see. You do really have to watch out for pickpockets here in Prague.

Magnificent atmosphere. The Old Town Square is lined with magnificent buildings in different architectural styles, from Gothic to Baroque.The most famous building on the Old Town Square is the fourteenth-century Old Town Hall. Its Gothic tower, built in 1364, is one of the most recognizable buildings in Prague. To the north the square is bordered by the eighteenth-century St. Nicholas Church. It is one of the most beautiful of all Baroque churches in Prague, and its interior is especially impressive. In the north-east corner of the square is the large Jan Hus Monument.

Heart of the city. Wonderful place,it's beauty is majestic. Come early in the morning or later in the evening so you can take all of the pictures and avoid tourist crowd. Heart of the city from which all others attractions are very close by.

Old Town Square Prague. Beautiful square even in the rain, fantastic architecture from different epochs. Small galleries and restaurants and bars dotted around the square. Great image of the old black church rising up from behind newer buildings.

Loveliest square amongst Europe finest.... One of Europe's finest medieval square where all the happenings could be expected. From throngs of of tourist to cultural performance. Have a cup of coffee and take in the atmosphere, plenty of coffee house and souvenirs shops around. Toward the east is where all the luxury shops are located. If you haven't been here, you haven't been to Prague.

Fantastic square. This is an amazing town square the whole thing is built using cobbles. There are lots of little bars and restaurants but for dinner get out of the square and go a few blocks and get good food. Don't forget the wonderful clock.

nice but very busy. This is the centre of the tourist trap area but worth spending time in. Go early for pictures. During the day the restaurants all have tables out making it a very atmospheric place to spend time. The architecture is interesting to view. However the prices in the restaurants are comparable with UK prices for beers and food. There is a nice statue, stalls to eat from, horse and carriages for hire and street performers. Worth spending time here.
Majestic. Neat to people watch and observe street performersOld town clock pretty interestingHusband liked the Mexican restaurant
Fairy tale beauty. The old town square is breathtakingly beautiful. Be prepared to share it with thousands of others equally eager to discover its charm.

First stop in Prague. The Old Town Square is the natural place to head for when you arrive in Prague. It has been here since the 10th C and today forms the tourist heart of the city. It is surrounded by expensive cafés, shops and galleries. You will find the wonderfully gothic Týn Church with its fairytale spires on one side. At the opposite corner is the Astronomical Clock on the side of the Town Hall, with its hourly show of animated characters. Most walking tours leave from under this clock, just look for guides with different coloured umbrellas depending on the tour. They take you to some hidden places you would never find by yourself, in the streets around the square.

Good for a drink. Loved having a drink here and sitting on the kerb watching the many buskers. The astronomical clock is good. Make sure you get there at least 15 mins before the hour as it gets very busy
Wonderful!. One of the best squares I've ever seen. You really can't miss it! If you go, try typical Prague ham and trdlo (some kind of brioche) but beware of the expensive restaurants!
Old square. Classic medieval, beautiful looking old square. With many entertainers about. Gets REALLY busy though. And watch out late at night. Lots of drunk people and a few unsavory types.
Old Town Square. Lots of fun and activity. Great place to eat or have coffee or just sightsee. Go in the church attached to the front building facade.
Beautiful historical centre. Beautiful square with amazing buildings and the opportunity to sit in a cafe and absorb the atmosphere.

Lively and picturesque.. The Old Town Square was always busy no matter what time of day you pass through. There are musicians, street performers, beautiful buildings and lots of restaurants. The Astronomical clock always draws an audience every hour. It is also easy to get to the river and the Jewish Quarter from here. Lovely part of the city.

Like from the books. Wonderful city square with amazing view wherever you look. So many things are going on at the same time, it takes some time so you can soke up all thats coming your way. If you are in Prague this is where you have to get to see. Spend some time there, feel the vibe of the city.

Etched in my memory forever!. I just could't have enough of this gorgeous old town square - which I can confidently say could be one of the Top 5 squares in Europe! Always buzzing with tourists, interesting cafes, music, gothic architecture and the Prague Astronomical clock! WOW! Don't miss the hourly spectacle of the clock...

Fantastic place to come at Christmas time!. Loved this place, but beware of the restaurants, you can get charged SOOOO much by mistake and not even realise.
I recommend going at Christmas time, absolutely gorgeous with all the markets :)

Beautiful town to walk around. We stayed near old town square and it was during Christmas, I enjoyed walking around the square even though it can be pretty crowded. I enjoyed the atmosphere, the lights and just the whole mood.
Astronomical Clock. Well worth going to see, but keep an eye on your wallet because of pick pockets. Lots of entertainment going on.

Great Location but beware your dining choices!. A great location to stroll at any time as many others have described. My word of warning is to watch your choice of snacks. The stalls selling Prague Ham look great but the price is for 100g not a serving which will cost four or five times more. To be fair the signs do say this but most of those ordering seem surprised when the total presents itself. A hot-dog and beer seemed better value!

Great Square Central to Most You Want to See. The buildings are stunning and the clock is really cool. You can go to so many interesting places from this square including the best shopping areas which were a pleasure for my wife and daughter. Prague visitors have to see this square.
Four day stay in Prague at the Astoria Hotel.. You can stroll around the square and listen to the many acts that are playing.No one is in a hurry and you can sit and soak in the atmosphere.
Beautiful. Full of tourists, very quaint and beautiful, lots of shops and dining options there. Very crowded esp near the clock tower but it is one of the main attractions for Prague.
Amazing. A fabulous meeting place of many different nations and cultures. Fantastic architecture, museums, bars, restaurants, churches, designer shops such as Cartier, Tag Hauer.

Must Visit. Great place to hang out in Prague thousands of people having fun , street musicians , local bars all around. try and be there at the hour to see the Astronomika clock and see the display of the gospels.

Spoilt by its success. Like most of Prague, this once wonderful architectural square has been spoilt. Once wonderful buildings now housing worldwide national chains and the beautiful fabric of the building has been lostOnce you fought through the crowds, pickpockets and pressure selling, overlooked the overpriced tat (gift??) sellers, restaurants and bars you can see some beautiful buildings ... but you do need to look hard to see through the modern age first but it is something you just have to do when you visit Prague

Each time of the year it hase its atmosphere. Anytime you come here no matter what the weather is you will enjoy its stunning atmosphere which is indescibable. Astrological clock is must see whn you are vositting Prague and I am more than sure that you will love it....

Must go during the night!. I love this square, really. But it can get too crowded during tour guiding times.During the morning it's just a lot more quiet and at night the lights on top of St Tyn Cathedral are simply breathtaking.This square was the starting and ending point on the traveling video I made with my GoPro of my 65 day trip around Europe. You're more than welcome to take a quick look at it. Enjoy Prague!!https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fjjLoF8jWs4

Just an ordinary square. I've visited some cities in my life and I've seen many old towns and squares but for me this is just average. If you want to see beatiful old town landscapes I would recommend you Budapest.

Heart of old town Prague. I love the Old Town Square. Yes, it's full of tourists. Yes, you'll have trouble squeezing through the crowds gathered beneath the astronomical clock as it approaches the hour. Yes, the restaurants and bars scattered around the square are expensive. But I never get tired of walking through it, of gazing up at Tyn church (either stark against the blue sky, or with its towers lit mysteriously beneath the stars), of listening to the musicians who give it its soundtrack, of seeing the waiters spraying the tourists with a water hose in the summer. The last time I was there, there was the Bohemia JazzFest, and I stood listening to the music with a beer from the nearby stands that sell food and drink. Make sure to visit it during both the day and the evening to see its different faces.

A place where you arrive anyway. It is difficult to avoid this historical area, especially many tours are leaving from here. At least try to avoid making shopping or eating here, it is not worthing at their prices! And be very careful when exchanging foreign currency!!!
Where everyone goes!. Went there every night as it was buzzy. People friendly and wanted to talk. Such amazing unspoiled architecture.
Spectacular!. This is the only clock in the world that is over 400 years old that is still fully operational. Would recommend this to everyone and remember to view on the hour!

A Great Place Ro People Watch. Tis large square which dominates Old Town in Prague is a great place to watch people while getting a bite at one of its many restaurants or ice cream stands. The square is frequently filled with spectators watching the many street performers. The Astronomical Clock on Old City Hall is just a few feet away.

Happy square . Breath taking beautiful.... Lots of live music, whats else can you ask for? Nice at day and night.... Climb the tower (although there is que...) to see it from above, and just hang around...

Great atmosphere. Avoid near the hour! Lots of tourists like to wait for the clock to strike. Be aware of the crowds. There are lots of lovely eateries in this area. Try going of away fromthe main streets to find quaint little restaurants.

Be Careful!. This is a fun old square with an awesome clock, and a lot going on. It is busy and crowded with local street performers. It is ripe for pickpocketing so be extremely careful with your things, and be very aware of your surroundings. That is good advice for Prague in general.
what a vibrant place. a bustling square where it seems everyone wants to be.....and all at the same time...lol lovely buildings plenty of photo opportunities
Its one of the required spots to see in Prague. It is the center of Prague and is a must see - astronomical clock, Jan Hus and all the glorious buildings around the square.

Amazing view of a well preserved old historic area. Check out the John Lennon wall under the Charles Bridge just as you are getting onto the castle/palace side of the bridge. Its a nice tribute that is worth looking for.

It took my breath away. When I first walked into this beautiful space I was dumb struck. It is amazing to see and words cannot describe the architecture. It is a very busy part of the city with tourists everywhere.

Prague is awesome!!!!. What a beautiful place!!! I do think that Prague is magic city and the old town is one of its most powerful places. Nice view from the astronomical clock and very nice stores and restaurants all around the neighbourhood
Square. Wonderful place to visit. The clock was very nice and the dolls were neat to watch as the clock chimed the hour.

Beautiful. It is a pleasure just to walk around it. It is clean and tidy. Lots of people but still organized. Plenty of Cafés and Restaurants. The Astronomical watch is a bit over rated to me, and loads of people just stand in front of it to wait for it to ring. This is a bit annoying because they don't even let you cross them and this is why I gave 4 stars and not 5.

The Heart of Prague. I always love getting back to this square. It's always crowded and lively, day and night. You can enjoy the ambience from the surrounding restaurants or simply sit on the square watching amazing (and sometimes bizarre) street performers. Perfect place to chill after walking for a day and being encircled by beautiful historical buildings.
Exciting. Very nice but very busy square. A lot of tourist groups pass here with their guide.Don't waste too much time on the square it self, go visit the surrounding monuments and buildings.
Outstanding place to visit. Very interesting and historical place. You can see old homes, small shops with high touristic prices, good cafe.

Good to start here. This square is the perfect meeting point for friends but also for many tours. There are beautiful buildings to gaze up at. The square can get busy but it is not overwhelmingly so. All roads meet here.

so much fun. This is where all the hustle and bustle is,tourists from all over the planet, shows, coffee shops, shops, restaurants, Astronomical clock, concerts, Thai massage places ... all in an old medieval place which makes it a great place to have fun.

Pretty as a picture.. What a great place to sit and watch the world go by. Yes the prices in the bars and restaurant are a little higher, but what a view, great to see the clock. The 1st I went to Prague, we just followed the crowds and found ourselves by the clock with everyone else, it was the place to be. I didn't even feel intimidated with the large crowds, as I know it's usually a pick pockets dream.

The Central Attraction of Prague. It is the number one place anyone visiting Prague needs to visit. It is a very large town square. Old beautiful ornate buildings surround it. Tourist gather for street entertainers, musicians, out door cafes. Just beautiful!

wonderful. full of sights and sound, very lively and friendly place, street performers, scooters for rent, lots of restaurant, shops, pretty crowded place but thats how it makes it a tourist destination, people in groups with guide speaking the tourist own language, police roaming around and garbage collecting trash regularly, you can simply sit down and watch all the happenings around you, you can buy sausages with beer and the famous bread trdelnik which i really like.
Lovely. Lovely place with an excellent café culture with fabulous restaurants and pubs and great street entertainers.. Buzzing
Lovely day out. Very busy, vibrant and excellent entertainment. The Old Town square looks even more magical in the evening when beautifully lit up.

A must for the first time traveler. This is the second time we have visited Prague and was very displeased a what I saw. The cultural Identity of this square had been damaged by Outdoor Cafes, Second rate Musical acts , and the really ever powering Souvenirs arcades however a must for the first time visitor to Prague
Lively square. The street performers,bars and restaurants were great.The Astronomical clock was impressive as was the Jan Has monument
Old Town Square. Once a glorious open space, and whilst the buildings that surround it remain as lovely, the crowds and noise are discouraging.
