Old town square. Unique atmosphere of an old town. I recommend to visit the town hall view. Especially during the Christmas time - you will avoid the huge crowds and experience beautiful view on the christmas market and the christmas tree.

Get into the true culture. Liked all of the shops and the entertainment, especially the concerts at the church in the square. Did not like the crouds that gather on the hour for the animated clock performance

Place to hange and people watch. Nothing much else to do, but you can't miss it if you're in Prague. It's on the way to everything. The best time of day to hang out here is during the afternoons when there are brass bands playing. Grab some snacks and park it on the stone ground in the center. Nice way to relax after walking around the city.

Most beautifull square. wonderful, charming, fascinating. Town Hall and Astronomical Clock, beautiful architecture, many restaurants and caffe and of course many people with cameras. It must be experienced. Most beautiful square and town in the world. Still my capital.

NEVER CHANGE MONEY AT CHEQUE POINT!. Real Thieves!!! If you want to be literally stolen without a gun this is your place in Prague to change money!!!. They advertise premium rates which totally mislead tourists and spoil your day! On April, they paid me about 15 cz per euro (actual rate was 1/27 approx.), so you received almost half of your money. They do not explain the rate, make you sign a paper without any information and after that you receive the most ridiculous exchange rate ever!! and when you realise that claim that the transaction is done, and nothing can be done, no refunds!! But if you are persistent and keep complaining as we did, we stayed over an hour on the entrance of the shop having a lovely beer, and putting away any single possible customer, explaining the meaning of "Premium Rates", hence no business for them!!, the clerk finally gave us all our money back, as she just wanted to get rid of us!!!
Beautiful. Big open square to sit and watch the world. Never seen anything as old and in fantastic shape as the buildings in Prague.Can't say enough about how beautiful Prague is.AND VALUE FOR MONEY.

Terrific. This square is very-very beautiful, it is surrounded by some beautiful buildings, towers, churches. Many people come to visit. The only thing that I didn't like - there are a lot of homeless people, and a lot of gipsies. The police does not do anything to them, just leaves them there.
Lots of history & architecture. The square was always busy with different activities, the clock was a phenomena by its self. The foods were excellent as well.
A must see!. Such a beautiful area! Besides having great things to see like the Astronomical clock, there are lots of great restaurants. Must also try the chimney cakes!!
Beautiful square. This is a lovely place to visit and enjoy the cafes and watch the street entertainers. Very busy with lots of tourists though.

Wonderful place at night. Very wonderful place.
But they overchare to the tourists at the restaurants.
Be careful when you pay the bill.
Confirm the bill again.

Beautiful!. The old town square in Prague was definitely my favourite part. Every aspect of it was beautiful. The people here are so friendly and the place has a welcoming, great atmosphere. In the evening it is lit up and the views are like nothing else. One evening we visited there was a local jazz fest and the atmosphere was great, everyone outside having a beer and a dance. Loved it here, would go back in a second. LinziGallo

Great one. It gives me an old essence of vintage and oldies feeling when I went there. Everything is good and sometimes the place can get very busy. I love the Trdelník at one of the locals shop which I forgot the name. Definitely satisfying! Great place for walk

a Historic square. has to be seen but extremely crowded by midday. Dont bother joining the crowd to see the clock strike the hour and the little men coming out, a bit disappointing. But the Square has a wonderful atmosphere if you can stand the crowds of tourists

Wide square surrounded by history. Apparently left alone during WW2 due to Hitlers love of the place and we are very glad he left it as it was, lovely place surrounded by beautiful buildings and history.
Really characterful and busy. Very well laid out with street theatre and dining/drinking options, but also very busy. Recommended for a short visit and lunch.

It's Definitely Old. The square is large and filled with beautiful structures,tourists, street performers, and pricey restaurants but with that said, definitely stroll through it. The astronomical clock is there and if you want to people watch, you can definitely find a seat at any of the restaurants. We tended to walk through it many times just based on our travels around town and it was interesting to get different vibes during different times of the day. An interesting tidbit: we were walking through and there was a very large crowd of very "dedicated" Swedish football (soccer) fans outside an Irish Pub preparing for the evening game against Sparta, the Prague team. They were chanting and singing outside of the pub and later in the day, they were PEACEFULLY escorted by riot police to the stadium. Definitely an interesting site to see and hear. The square is heavily traveled so watch your personal belongings as you would anywhere touristy.
very nice city. Everything is very well developed in terms of tourism. The buildings are well preserved, the markets are clean, helpful people
Just so unusual and so charming. I loved the buskers they are so talented and original one of them was a group of 5 who played 5 instruments and it was like being at a concert.

Must sit and enjoy the atmosphere. Old Town Square has plenty to offer and we really enjoyed just sitting outside at the little cafes around the square with a drink, watching all the activity and street performers. Great atmosphere throughout the day and into the night. We stayed 3 days in Prague and found ourselves coming back to this area at one point or another everyday.

Lively and historic Old Town Square in Pargue. We visited Old Town Square three times over a 4 day break in Prague, each day was different. A regular venue for weddings in the Old Town Hall, the very popular astronomical clock, lots of artists performing in the square itself and number of cafes for a bite to eat.Recommend you go there on a Saturday as there is lots of live music and much busier than a weekday.Enjoy one of the most beautiful parts of Europe, a must for people who like short breaks, allow 2 full days as a minimum.

A must stop. Once you have located this area- all roads lead to various sites from here. The sites in the Square itself are many- Astonomical clock, Church of Our Lady Before Tyn, an area where one can buy local food fare for reasonable prices ( think farmer's market stalls that have everything from bratwurst to longes ( longush).Shopping is close at hand . Just a few blocks away is the famous "Charles Bridge" which should be seen in the daylight and at night.

I had to see it. We walked across the Charles Bridge and got to the Clock, so we sat down and had coffee ice cream and with the rain almost missed the parade of the saints. bought a tourist clock of the thing.
As beautiful as you would hope. This is the most beautiful city center I have seen. The buildings are just unbelievable. Don't miss it. It's everything you hope it will be and more.

Kind of disappointing.. When in Prague everyone gorse to watch the astronomical clock strike the hour, but I have to admit it was a rather disappointing experience. You stand around with a large crowd as the hands move ever close to the top of the hour. When the hour hand reaches 12, the skeleton on one side rings his bell and raises his lantern, then the hours are struck and the doors open and the apostles rotate through a little door. The striking stops, the door closes and that's it, that's all, it's over. The crowd actually started laughing at the underwhelming performance we had just witnessed. So definitely go and see the clock because it is beautiful and worth a photo, but if you feel you don't want to wait in a crowd for several minutes to see the "performance", don't feel that you are missing something spectacular, because it is really short and not all that great.

Wow!!. Last July we visited Prague after a long holiday before that and the most important thing on our mind was to visit a laundromat. While walking to metro station in our search for the one and only laundromat in Prague we chanced upon the Old Town Square rather unintentionally. Happily enough for us it is one of the most breathtaking spot I have come across in a long long time. To add to the beauty of the churches and astronomic clock, there was a local rock band playing some soulful music, the whole atmosphere was romantic that i kept coming back to the spot again and again through out trip.
here yea hear yea!. This square is where you will gather for sounds os jazz to opera, mims to marienettes. European charm of a life time..
Scenic Architecture. Enjoy the twist in the medieval architecutre with the modern bustle in this city that has adapted well to capitalism after decades under Soviet rule and vigilance.
beautiful and interesting. Beautiful and interesting. Many many good shops and good restaurants. You need good walking shoes to walk aroundToo many people visiting
Great place to see. There is so much going on in this area of Prague. Cafes, stores and art exhibits. Go there both in the daytime and night if you can. Prague is so beautiful at night.
Christmas Ambience. Fantastic walk around the old town square. Stop for some hot wine or take in the passers by. Be careful of pick pockets and enjoy. Highly recommended!

Super Crowded but worth it. The clock tower display that happens on the hour is a ton of fun. Also, we were lucky enough to be in the square while some choirs were rehearsing in the churches. Beautiful music and beautiful buildings. A must-see

A Must See - Beautiful, Entertaining,Historical. You've got to be able to handle the crowds, but the square is worth the effort. It's historical, beautiful, and entertaining from street musicians to the mechanical clock. Lots to see, hear and do. A must see in Prague.

Soak it up and enjoy:). The only reason I go with 4 stars instead of 5, is it can be a bit of a tourist trap with people congregating. Otherwise it is the place to be. Street artists and musicians, the Astronomical Clock Tower, food, shopping, and quick walks to many other landmarks and sites, I truly enjoyed just hanging out and people watching. Almost every day I got a drink somewhere on the square and just took the time to soak up the atmosphere. During 3.5 weeks in Europe, this was the one city and location where I just wanted to soak it all up and be a part of it for as long as I could.
Center of activity to start your city tours. The place to find cheap (and even free) tourguides, but check first what you get for your money. Don't eat the food sold on the square.
Very busy but worth it. Wonderful facades, great atmoshphere and crowds waiting for the meteo clock to chime. Watch out for the segway tours, they try to bully their way through.

Impressive architecture, very touristy. A must-see, obviously - the architecture is really something. It was mobbed with tourists when we were there, so you might think about some off peak times if you have that option.

What a city!. The Old Town Square is everything it is billed to be. From amazing architecture to historical interest--everything is Disney-like to a North Carolina boy.However, summer in Europe brings crowds, big crowds. Be prepared for close contact with the world's tourists. That should not put you off, but as we were repeatedly warned, Prague is like any other city in that crowds attract accomplished pick pockets. Gentlemen--keep your wallet in your side pocket, and put a "dummy" wallet in your back pocket. And, ladies, keep your purse under your arm. Most of all, invest in RFID wallets and passport protectors. All cities have high-tech folks with scanners that can steal your critical account/passport numbers.

The most beautiful square!. It's amazing how a "simple" square can be so astonishing!And exists in the form of the Old Town Square in Prague.Besides the beauty of the surrounding buildings and its churches, there's always movement, street performances and the inevitable astronomical clock!A must visit for every tourist!

One of the best main squares :). One of those wows around the corner...
If you hunt for good food, look close and choose. There are some nice alternatives among the truistic bunch.
Spend at least 3 days in Prague. We toured Prague, Cesky Krumlov, Krakow and Budapest. We enjoyed all of these destinations however Prague was our favorite.
Pretty little place. Perfect for grabbing some street food, watching the crowds pass by and enjoying the warm summer air in Prague.

fun place to hang and centrally located. tons of people from all over the world, music in the streets, where the astrological cloak are... find a little place to have a coffee or a beer and enjoy yourself

Its big and its majestic. After the Charles Bridge, take a 10min stroll to the Old Town Square and marvel at the magnificent architecture all around you. Of course there is the famous clock and plenty of restaurants as well but there is a majestic feeling of old world splendour as you walk through the square. This is where you should change your money into Czech crowns but remember, there are plenty of people watching for careless tourists.
Awesome buildings. Just a wonderful vista of baroque and Art Deco buildings. The clock is awesome and the crowds entertaining.
Town square. Building architechture is very beautiful. Thai massage by the square is excellent. Food is ok. Prices are good.
unequalled architecture. Very touristly in July but good humoured and we had a great time . Make sure you carry a water bottle !

It draws you in. The square is full of history, cobbled stoned and large.The buildings that surround the square are originals with Prague missing out on the majority off damage in ww2.The square has the glockenspiel which draws many tourists after 9am every hour. I visited the square on an early morning walk and found it a lovely place to visit.The square has numerous entry points and exit points an it is relatively easy to get disoriented.Something of note is that food and drink is more expensive in the square.All said and done, an amazing place to visit.

Great History but disappointing to watchthe Astronomical Clock. We visited it the Square on our own and afterwards with a tour guide and even she said that visitors find the clock movements very disappointing as when it strikes on the hours 2 doors open and little apostal statues moved round very briefly and then it is all over. Tourist are waiting for something else to happen but the figurines are all you see from the top of the clock. With a good tour guide you will get a better history on the working of the clocks and the building around the area.

The very essence of Prague. Hard to believe - given today's crowds - that this exciting place was almost deserted during the Soviet era. It is today a hive of colour, noise and activity at the very heart of Prague, with historic old Bohemia all around. Two things bother me just a little...1. The price of food around the square is around 50% dearer than surrounding areas.2. The youths who swill beer and get progressively more obnoxious as the day wears on will, if not controlled, eventually spoil the place for everybody else.

Astrological clock, Jan Hus statue all in one place. Old Town Square is one of great places to explore in Prague. In one corner you see a statue of famous Czech Jan Hus,across is the Town Hall with famous Astrological clock and the square is surrounded by lots of expensive cafes and restaurants. Try to go early to avoid huge crowds.

So pretty. Brilliant place to people watch, see the Clock, find out more activities to do (there are lots of people who come up to you advertising cool things).Overall, out of the 11 cities we visited on our Interrrail trip, the Old Town Square was by far the prettiest - definitely a must!
Too crowded!. Went there this summer. Couldn't enjoy the atmosphere. Just too many people. Avoid this place if you don't like crowds!
loved the little clock. This was the last thing I did in Prague. Sat and had an ice cream and watched the Prague astronomical clock. all over in a few moments but lovely to see non the less

Awesome Vibe. The vibe in this square is awesome. We were in time for the Jazz Festival and although I am not a jazz fan, the vibe was just awesome. Downside of course, is the huge crowds there - there is a reason for that!

Typical REALLY Old Town Square. Wear very comfy shoes and walk everywhere around this historic, beautiful place--look at all of the interesting, lovely buildings, walk through the Jewish Center and over the Charles Bridge.

My favourite in all of Europe. Hands down Old Town Square in Prague was my absolute favorite place in all of Europe. The atmosphere is fantastic for old and young, plenty tp do and see and most food is reasonably priced. Beautiful! You have to go there!

Just another gotta see. Live entertainment and open air market some days. Leave the made in ...... Souvenirs behind, the market had glass bead makers and blacksmith on site for truly unique items. Food galore and lots to see.

Love it!. This is the most beautiful square in Prague, imho. No visitor to Prague could miss this one. The famous Tyn church, astronomical clock, St. Nicholas Church, and many beautiful buildings are there. There a lots of shops around that area. During the days it could be packed with people but in the evenings the square is much more quiet and the lights from the tower, Tyn church, give the place a magical look.
Full of Life. This place just bursts with life. The sightseeing is incredible. Wherever you turn your head, you see something worth contemplating.

Simply amazing!. Kongen TIPS!
Rise early morning and stroll the town to avoid the crowded tourist. This was around 8am.. By 9 t0 10 am this area here will be ful lpacked with tourist.

The most happenings. Very big square , makes you feel living in the past with all that imagination being royalty and passing the people. You will see horse carriages coming,going around,entertainers performing. Lots of excitement happening here.

spent lots of time here. Many good restaurants, cafes, the Astrological Clock, shopping, etc. There was nothing I didn't like about Prague or the Town Square. There's good nightlife here and it's safe to walk around at night on the main streets.

Place you should go. You have to see this in Prague. Many castles surrounding.
We were here at Sunday night also and it was very cool. There was like 200 people just sitting ja chilling. Someone played guitar and someone singed. It was so european and good feeling!

Fabulous. Great place to walk around and explore, to sit down and grab a drink. To watch people passes by, and as yourself-enjoying and having good time in this city and on this amazing city square.It has a beauty of some German cities as well as touch of Cracow (Poland) . It is beautiful. Like always there is something happening. Music festival, comedy… it is always busy and full of people. Food available on every step from mini kiosks, ham. Pastry…hot dogs, fresh and smells delicious.Dreamy place. Beautiful.

Sure it is touristybut fun. The Old Town Square is another great starting point to branch out from to discover Prague. There is lot to see in the area. The side streets leading to/from the Square are lined with bars, cafe, shops, and art galleries. The Square's perimeter showcases various architectural styles. Worth checking out especially at night when, like many places, it really comes alive!
Romantic, charming and dynamic. Just came recently from this place. Romantic, charming and dynamic. Always with interesting people and sights.

Awesome. The old town square is magical- especially at night when lighted and less crowed. The church of Tyn and the old clock make it even more beautiful. One of the most beautiful squares in Europe I think- and would have been even better if it wasnt so crowded. I suggest to visit it a period with less visitors (maybe in winter but not Xmas).

Beautiful. This is a beautiful square to visit in Prague, wonderful Tyn Church and the Astronomical Clock, lots of cafes and bars nearby also. Worth visiting during the day with a return at night when everything is lit up, beautiful!

Hard to miss. Great place to visit. Our hotel was only a short stroll from the square and we spent a lot of time vititing it. Lots of shops and restrauants unbelieveable architecture. A great experience.

Simply charming!. I loved walking around this area on my trip to Praha. There are quaint little cafes and restaurants for lunch or dinner. There's performers in the square, narrow brick road streets with little shops...only thing is it's very touristy, but I can understand why.

Go early. Loverly old square full of history and great to walk around in. However as we were there in the middle of the day in July so were a few thousand other tourists that destroyed the atmosphere somewhat.
The best time to goi is as early in the day as you can.

Beware of the food carts. You kind of can't go to Prague and not go here. It's beautiful, very historical and is at the center of everything. With all that being said - it kind of looks like any other European old town square. Special advice: don't let the food carts serve you too much of their food because it may be delicious but it's really expensive. Assertiveness is a must here....
Charming old place!. It's a really beautiful place on Prague! During the day it's full of tourists coming from everywhere, so you should go with patience if you are looking for good pictures!
Touristy but cool place. It's quite a unique square. Many restaurants and shops around. There're some street shows too. Enjoy!

Old Town Square. A don't miss tourist attraction. Everyone gathers at the Astronomical Clock on the south side, but also see the monument to reformer Jan Hus and followers in the center, the white Hussite church on the north side, the Tyn Roman Catholic church on the east. Entrance to the Tyn church is through the shops in front of it. A number of open air restaurants on the square. The Jewish quarter is a few blocks north and well worth a visit. Entrance to the Jewish cemetery and synagogues is 300 crowns - about $15 - but well worth it. Men wear a hat or buy a souvenir kippa for 5 crowns - 25 cents.

Fascinating Place. It was a vibrant place with so many attractions eg carriage rides vintage car rides, great restaurants and the amazing astronomical clock. It was also a convenient place to be dropped off by the buses and to arrange pickups either with friends or public transport

An inexpensive treat - eat here at night!. Such an amazing place - we treated ourselves to a meal sitting out on a restaurant terrace underneath the fantastic astronomical clock. Cost for 2 course meal & drinks for 2 people was under £30. We listened to live jazz as we ate - playing in the main square- and watched the clock strike the hour with its parade of figures. Magic!

Must do place to visit. Everyone has to see the clock the Old Town Square and take a stroll across The Charles Bridge. Beware of changing money. Rates seem to vary greatly and we even had one guy who was working in an official money exchange outlet trying to get rid of UK £50 notes. He wanted us to swap our UK currency for these notes and tried to say that the banks would not accept them in Prague. These made no real sense to us and I suspect the real reason was that they were fake notes! I never accept UK notes from anyone except banks and even that isn't always fool proof. Beware of people approaching you in the streets to exchange cash.

Old Town Square is one of the great squares of Europe. First of all, this square is big. The memorial to local hero Jan Hus is big too. In high season it holds thousands of tourists. Most of them seem to be waiting for the the Town Hall clock to strike the hour when death tips his hourglass and the 12 Apostles parade.In addition to the Town Hall, the Tyn Church, The St. Nicholas Church, the National Gallery and pastel houses line the square. It is beautiful. Just be on the lookout for pickpockets.

Old and Charming place of Prague.. The Old Town Square is always beautiful, but if you have an option, go there during the Christmas week. Combination of the holiday spirit, illumination, bazaar, x-mas tree and millions of people celebrating together is a winner! Hot wine and local cooked in front of you will keep you warm ;)  Be aware of local "Currency exchange" places. Banks are closed and these guys have no limits. Make sure to read information BELOW the currency rates sheet and DO NOT hand over your money without confirmation how much you are getting back!

lots to see and do around this square. horrible tourist every where just look up at the monuments like the clock and the buildings around. I would recommend to go to the gallery's visit dali warhole and mucha.

It's a square. Ok, putting the architecture of the tower and the beautiful buildings aside. The old town square is a square. Alot of tourists and many people trying to sell tours etc. Well worth a visit but don't stop here to eat or drink as you will most definitely pay overprize.

Fantastic Square, lots of action and lovely photo opportunities. The Old Town Square is the place to be if you go to Prague and offers many possibilities for casual dining and a great view on various old buildings that give you a great photo opportunity.

Typically European - at Prague prices!. I loved Old Town Square - my favourite part of Prague. It is so sociable and you see such a range of people, from stags and hens, to lads and girly city breaks, to families, to couples, to a bride and groom having their photographs taken with a horse and carriage. It's a great place to people watch and try the endless brands of beer. Prices are the cheapest we came across while on our trip, you can eat and drink like royalty compared to Germany or France. the quality is really good and even though there are endless restaurants in the square, i found they all did something different. at every quarter to the hour you noticed the crowds of people waiting for the famous clock to chime on the hour. I was a little underwhelmed by the display but it was defiantly a spectacle to see and you should hang about to see it while your there. It's more interesting if you learn the story behind it.

Many superb performers on the square. We pass by the square when we were looking for the astronomical clock. We love the performers on the square.Restaurants around the square are quite expensive though.
So much happening!!. Old town square is where we spent most of our evenings during our trip to Prague. You are surrounded with people, music, food and history.

Beautiful Historic Square. One of my favorite places in Prague, the Old Town Square brings one back in time (except for the overabundance of segways!).The clocktower that rings on the hour with a scene of rotating figures, the steeples on an old church that Disney must have copied, the little shady area with park benches, the open square itself, all give a cheerful and friendly invitation to those visiting Prague --- one you won't find that much elsewhere in this city.....

Crowded but Exciting. This area is surrounded by baroque buildings, restaurants and don't forget to see the Old Town Hall and Astronomical Clock. It is the oldest still working clock in the world. Yes there is a crowd on the hour to see the clock, but get there early so you can look around and find the right place to wait. There are plenty of tourist shops to purchase gifts for friends back home. Allow an hour to wander around this area.
you have to go. very beautiful/historic with clock etc. prices not so extortinate as most famous squares so have at leat a drink!

Centre of attractions. A must for all visitors.At the Square, baskers are seen plying their trades. Seems to be some sort of scheduling as they appear throughout the day. From guitarists to fire throwers and all types of musicians on different instruments.Food stalls nearby but should avoid the meat sellers as they are pricey n of average fare.The astronomy clock n clock tower are nearby.

Always something to watch!. There is so much going on here, it's awesome. My boyfriend and I were in Prague for 3 days and we kept coming back here because we loved the atmosphere. There are street performers everywhere, we loved the bands that played. There are restaurants where you can sit outside and enjoy and cheap, delicious beer. (more expensive in the square because you pay for the location) and the astronomical clock is super cool. Awesome culture.

Beautiful Square. I loved the old town square! I had arrived before my friends who were flying from a different airport, so I went for a wander on my own and stumbled across the square by chance. It was a glorious day and I sat and watched the world go by with a beer in the sun and the time flew by. The architecture was beautiful. A must see!
Loved this place. Buzzing with tourists, many restaurants, good food and beer..... loved this place. I spent a lot of time here..... just looking around......

Best at the right time. On the hour, the square is usually very busy - the astronomical clock is quite an interesting invention, and the story behind it is quite gruesome. Lots of shops in the area, with a lot of novelty items, art etc. Stools and Restaurants if you are hungry.
Amazing Building Architecture. Lots going on always filled with activities. lots of people, artists, sights, musicians, dancers, tour guides, tourists, churches, cathedrals, restaurants.

everyone has to visit the Old Town Square. There are always lots of people and lots going on - musicians, dancers, tour guides, tourists, locals - lined with churches, cathedrals, restaurants & street food and little streets that lead you to other amazing buildings. Of course the Clock is here too.
Nice buildings surrounding the square. The buildings surrounding the square are really beautiful and quaint in a sense, other than that, there is nothing much to see.

Impressive. Beautiful buildings, good restaurants of varying style and price, local food stalls and that clock. The clock is impressive although its action on the hour a little disappointing. Streets leading off the square also give straight and esay access to other parts of the town such as Wenceslas Square and the Jewishh Quarter. It's also very busy.

Great to sit and watch the world go by. The square is a beautiful part of Prague. It's buildings are centuries old and you will be amazed at how beautiful they are, especially the famous clock. There are entertainers in the square like jugglers, sword swallowers etc, brilliant place to come in an afternoon. There were horse and carts there too.There are many places where you can sit in the sun relaxing with a drink or something to eat. I loved the Salvador Dali museum in the square, I was very pleased to visit this attraction, being a fan of him work.
Beautiful buildings and lots to see. We spent two days touring around the Old Town Square. Lots of great shopping and food. Enjoyed people watching and seeing all the segways go by!

Great Buildings with Great Memories. Prague is the best to see the architecture of 18th Centuries. Old building with new vision in competitive world.Most importantly people those havent changed ... Great to see the place

Charming!. A delightful charming square. Prague is unlike other European cities as it was not damaged in the war and so preserves that charm that is lacking in some other cities. There is always something happening. Be a bit careful of pickpockets as with all crowded places

The heart of the city. fascinating and always filled with activities. lots of people, artists and sights. Encircled by old houses, landmarks and restaurants, cafees and last but not least a historic landmark.

Is that a clock?. All Prague visitors have to see the Astrological, or is it Astronomical Clock chime the hour. A very large crowd is always there in good weather, entertained by buskers until the hour cometh.

Stunning. The architectural styles around the Old Town Square are incredible. I saw so many tourist groups rushing up to the town hall, taking photos of the Astronomical Clock and moving on, which is such a mistake.Buy a drink, linger around the fountain and just soak up Old Town Prague!
Old Town. Simply stunning buildings, plenty of places to drink and eat. There is also segway hire here along with walking tours
Always something going on. Loved the buzz of the Old Town Square and the varied entertainment as well as the fantastic buildings. It took two visits to spot the Apostles on the clock!1

Crowded but worthwhile. The Old Town Square is a great starting point for your visit to Prague. The square is mostly for tourists and visitors, locals avoid it. You will find an assortment of restaurants targeted to visitors- Irish Pub, English Pub, Hard Rock Cafe, Italian restaurants etc.Some small food vendors that serve more local food too such as pastry-Trdelnik-(not to be missed!) and roasted ham. The square is crowded particularly in the evening and on the hour to watch the clock. There is usually entertainment- street performers- which provide a nice variety. You may see a wedding party posing under the clock.If you have been to New Orleans, the square in Prague reminded me of the area outside of the cathedral in New Orleans.
Great for photos. Plenty going on. Street entertainers and passing horse and carriages and various other forms of transport. Beautiful buildings. Busy but not overcrowded.

Always something thing to see. We spent 5 days in Prague and passed through the Old Town Square at least 3 or 4 times a day. There is always something going on and something to see. Several times there were musicians performing usually in costume, who were very talented. It's worth it just to stand and listen to their music. The atmosphere at the square is always cheerful, and you can chat with tourists from all over the world. This is a wonderful place to spend some time.

Wonderful square with great restaurants.. We enjoyed seeing the mimes & bands that were playing on the square, also lots of weddings. We enjoyed sitting in the restaurants, I had the biggest piña colada I ever had in a pineapple.

Absintherye. I'm find....the nice little-little bar,...for...and about the ABSINTH .... I drunked with that nice tea with absinth... :D :D Thats memry,..it's very important for me, because the "reception" in this place a perfekt "thing"....:)

A city must see.. I lived here while studying abroad. Many tourists and can be very crowded. Beautiful architecture and history. Many great bars (with cheap fantastic beer) and restaurants. Obviously more expensive due to the proximity, however, great place. Watch for pickpocketers with purses and unattended bags.

Beautiful time in the Old Town!. The Old Town Square is probably the most beautiful place in Prague. We kept coming back there on the four days we spent in Prague. It is full of life and the buildings surrounding it are impressive; you can see a collection of Medieval, Renaissance and Baroque houses.

You haven't seen Europe until you have been to Prague. The architecture in this square is truly amazing. We didn't know where to put our eyes. There is the astronomical clock, small squares and little streets to investigate, beautiful hotels, restaurants and beer/cafes everywhere. There is so much going on. Along with the old is the new. What is nice is that we noticed not only tourists like us visiting but "regular" residents enjoying their city. You can eat, drink, sight-see, listen to the music, enjoy the shops, or just sit, have a drink and people watch. There are free tours for people who want to know more about the city. If you feel like walking around there are the bridges - Charles and don't forget the castle/fortress on the hill. Transportation is not a problem. The Old Town Square is a great starting point.

Great Architecture. At the Old Town you would think that Tyn Church and Astronomical clock are all that is there to see . Ask the lovers of architecture and they will tell you that they could spend days together admiring and studying the buildings and houses around the square. Houses such as 'At the Blue Goose', 'At the Golden Angel' , 'At the stone table', 'Storch House', Kinsky Palace' etc etc. Buildings of different periods and different eras co-exist here. For us ordinary tourists, they were a visual delight but for the experts - each building was a gem. Old Town square is full of activity all the time and its a good place to sit around and have a drink or have an exorbitantly priced lunch or dinner. You can go in for street food as well. Thousands of people visit Old Town square as it is the hub of the old town.

The free tours are worth it. The architecture is truly beautiful and picturesque and it is amazing to see the astronomical clock, but if you want to fully understand what you are looking at, I recommend the free tours. Just look for the umbrellas!
Magical Place. If had plenty of disposable cash, Prague would be one of my frequent haunts. A city full of inspiration, magic and intrigue.

Gives Prague the Title: A city that doesn't sleep!. People-watching is the best past-time in The Square! Then there's always some musician (s) sitting right there in the middle playing away or there are performances on the stage. No matter how many times I've been there there's always something else to see and do. Of course...concerts every day, and a short walk up to the Theatre. Then of course, every bar and resturant vied for your business so you come sit and watch the football!!!!

Beautiful architecture. Prague has the most amazing architecture and you can really make the most of it in Old Town Square. It is probabaly the busiest part of Prague with lots of people so hard to get a great picture but beautiful nonetheless!
Very busy at night. You will see lots of artists and interesting people float through as it begins to get darker, a must for any young travelers who wish to meet people

Charming city and enchanting experience. so many things to see and do in Prague, the old town square is bustling with street entertainers and exhibitions to see, a real marvel and pleasing to the eye.

A Must Experience. This is the heart of Prague. Don't miss the Astromical clock--fun to watch, very busy area. Lots of things happening, street performers, numerous cafes, variety of shops. Really electric atmosphere and so enjoyable anytime day or night. So much to see along the way, don't miss this attraction! Also take time to explore the alley ways all around the square.

Best place in Prague . Simply the best and most fun area of Prague, the square is always full if people, street entertainers, food stalls, music, dancing, tourists, locals, bars, restaurants, outdoor seating for drinks ect etc. it's a brill place, not ruined by tacky souvenir shops, just brilliant European city centre stuff

Great During Christmas Season. So beautiful especially at night and loved the kiosks with hot spiced wine and all the food. The people watching was fun as well and you could tell there were people from all over the world there.
Lots to see. Lots happening all around you, street performances, astronomical clock which comes to life every hour on the hour......just very very crowded.
Buzzing !. You will never be lonely here - loads of tourists but a lovely atmosphere. The cafes and bars are welcoming and friendly and the cosmopolitan feeling is almost tangiable !!

So much going on. Full of street performers, very lively and in the centre of the city. Drinks are expensive, as expected, in the main square. But eateries away from the main square are more reasonable.

Must See in Prague. Shopping and historic areas both together. What more could you want? Make sure you see the Astromical clock in the Old town square. The people of Prague are also very friendly and accommodating. This city will just amaze you.
Wonderful Bridge with a view. We went in the late evening over the bridge, what an amazing view to the town. Try it and you wont forget it.
True to it's name.... Old town squere was a very nice square though packed with people - mainly tourists... but that's Prague...

The charm of the middle age.. Not only the famous clock but all the narrow streets and alleys all around,the statue of jan Huss help you to understand why prague is such a touristic magnet and what it's character is,for our pleasure.
Ol town Square. This is the heart and soul of Prague. All kinds of people gather here and with art galeries, restaurants and performers, a great place to visit. The clock is also around the corner

Great time at Christmas. We were here at Christmas time And it was very special. Lots of stalls selling honey mead, hot wine and "grog". Different foods and lots of gifts etc. The buildings surrounding the square are very picturesque. Well worth a visit while in Prague.
music and spires. Ambiance like I had never seen in any other European city; something about this place really enchanted me.

All roads lead to the Old Town Square. If you go to Prague you of course will go here. Yes, it is touristy. But don't let the street hawkers and guys dressed up in weird costumes get you down. There is a lot to like here. Plus, the space is so big, it does not feel cramped, even with so many tourist. Compared to the main square in Venice, this seems more intimate (and far fewer tourists).

Simply amazing. Absolutely full of Life and energy! Good street food, drinks, music, free entertaintment, nice view, architecture and monumental clock....what else? Oh, look out for pickpockets, they're crawling everywhere!!!

Very much where the world gathers - a special place. This is a spacious grand square with so much to take in, making you feel part of the history of this very different city centre.There are different language 'free' walking tours [large tips appreciated] and so much to see - don't rush - relax - do 35 countries in a week NEXT week.

Fantastic area. We walked through this square on a few occasions during our short break to Prague. We also stopped off for a drink in a couple of the outdoor seating areas around here. There is street entertainment of different varieties.
Fairy tale. As I was there just before Christmas, this square, full of beautiful decorations, reminded me of fairy tale. Strongly recommend to visit

Great Christmas Market. On Christmas, the atmosphere is festive and the Czech don't spear money on decorations! Be ready to face low temperatures and even snow! But don't worry, hot wine and lots of traditional dishes will keep you warm.
Make you you stop and have a coffee. Enjoy watching the world go by and have a coffee in the old town square and watching the buskers or street performers!
beautiful place. We stay here the last days of our river cruise. it was great to see all the sites, We saw a lot for the day and half we where here. Wish we would have more time.
Awesome. Cannot miss Old Town Square, the heart of Pragoe for many centuries. Loved the Astronomical Clock and statue of Jan Huss. Architecture of square fascinating.

So crowded!. The one thing we were told not to miss in Prague was the Old Town Square. We joined a walking tour early in the morning and we were quite surprised to see that the square was already full of people. There were just too many groups milling around, especially near the clock. Without the crowds, the square was lovely, surrounded by old buildings and churches, food stalls in one corner, coffee shops and retail stores and the tourism office. We were warned to take care of our belongings as pickpockets also abound in the area, and they just mingle with the crowds. The astronomical clock was beautiful, truly a gem ahead of its time. Just watching it was an experience in itself, with all the moving figures, etc. We wanted to return in the wee hours of the morning to view the square without the people but didn't have the time to do so. Perhaps on another visit,

Lots to see. The Astronomical Clock in the square draws many tourists but there is a lot more to do here than just see the clock. Horse and buggy rides, shopping, bars, restaurants, street vendors are just some of the things you will see here. Plan to spend a couple hours just walking around. Beautiful at night.

It's attractive but crowded.. Beautiful place in a beautiful city, but both place and city are shoulder to shoulder tourists (at least in May, and I understand it's not high season yet. You should probably go there. Then go out of the city and look at some great countryside and villages.

Excellent during the holidays!. Visited the Old Town Square on a couple of occasions, but truly enjoyed the festive nature of this area during the Christmas holidays! The Square was all decked out, the huge Christmas tree lit up for all to enjoy, and the vendors out with unique gifts! An excellent time to spend an evening checking things out. It's also a very worthwhile location outside of holidays too!

Great fun. Somehow the square feels authentic although it's packed with tourists and is clearly for them and for those catering to them. The Czechs playing Dixieland jazz just added to the fun. The tourist office north of the statue of Jan Hus is especially helpful. I saw it at night after an annoying train ride and Old Town Square felt like Oz.

Must see, enjoy the clock, watch your pockets. So touristy but so beautiful. The clock is amazing, even when watched in a huge crowd of people. We found that going early in the morning or late at night was the best way to experience it.

Almost always wonderful. The Old Town Square is one of my favorite places in Prague, not only for the view and architecture but also for the people and the events that take place there. It seems to attract people day and night. The statue of Jan Huss is one of my favorite places.

Heart of it all. There are many attractions in Prague, but this is kind of a heart of everything. Walking distance from Charles Bridge and lots to see and do. Churches, Astronomical Clock, beautiful architecture and lots and lots of bars, restaurants and souvenir shops. Yes, it's crowded with tourists, but still a must see in Prague

It is a romantic square and very lively place.. It is a very lovely place day and night and all seasons. Of course Prague Astronomical clock is the big attraction there. Nights are wonderful at this square. There is always something going on during the nights like live music, dances, on the giant TV soccer matches besides the plenty interesting food at the kiosks all over. There are lovely jazz music bars and restaurants around and nearby the square.

astronomical clock. if you don't know what time it is the astrnomical clock will let you know, as well as, what astrological sign you are under, wether it is day or nite, and what you should be doing on the farm. also every hour it chimes and some doors open and a parade characters glide by. get there a few minutes early 'cause the plaza fills quickly with expectant tourists.

NOT TO BE MISSED. Totally for the tourist but justifiably so. Astronomical clock interesting but have seen other clocks particularly in Germany do so much more on the hour. Plenty of places to sit and watch the world go by as you eat or drink at the slightly inflated prices you would expect in such locations. Needless to say the Irish and English bars aren't anything other than Czech.Do note that the local fast food stalls selling smoked Prague ham, etc show their prices per 100 grams so are not as cheap as they may appear but still taste good.Directly opposite the astronomical clock is a hotel where you can go upstairs and get and excellent view of what it does on the hour (and a sit down) for the price of a beer or a coffee and their cakes are excellent. (Sorry forgotten the name).
Hangout Zone. This area is never quite except late night, you can sit by the many cafes, sip chilled beer, hog on some fresh Ham and bread, walking distance from Charles Bridge

You can't avoid Old Town Square, so enjoy it!. You won't find any Czech natives here -- the square is populated entirely by tourists -- but as a friend said, "The tourists are there for a reason." It's a beautiful, open area in the center of Old Town, virtually unchanged for centuries. It's a great place to sit and have a drink, people-watch, and listen to street music. There's also the hourly spectacle of the Astronomical Clock putting on its little show.
Experience Prague. You feel the nostalgic culture as you walk around the square. Beautiful architecture. Worth visiting!
Beautiful. Loved Old Town Square - short walk from our hotel at Wenceslas Square. Good entertainment acts and plenty bars to sit out.

Some what disappointing. The shopping is great in the bohemian glass stores. The restaurants are ok but are dependent on all us tourists waiting for
for the Clock Show. The biggest disappointment was the Clock Tower.
Lovely part of Prague. Definitely worth a visit - little stalls, great views, good cafes, clock tower etc. Nothing to dislike!

Beautiful and lively. This is really the best place for tourists. Lots of attractions, plenty of cafés where u can have great food. Good place for shopping too. This is the probably the heart of Prague with lot of action. If u visiting Prague make sure that you stay close to town square. U can also find tourist guides, city tours, etc from here
Nice place. Beautiful square with a touch of history. You will find the popular Old Town Clock. There are also stalls selling typical Czech meal. Are held here as well as various social events.

The clock in the square was worth waiting for.. Outdoor restaurants, albeit touristy, were everywhere. Live music in the square. Nice shops lined the way. We got off the main square to eat at more reasonable prices. The clock with the apostles was fascinating. A “Kodak moment" as we used to say.

One bustling, overcrowded, interesting place.. It's a must to visit the Square just for the astronomical clock especially when it does its thing on the hour, but the shops and restaurants are also fun and interesting. I had to laugh when we attempted to purchase a piece of jewelry in a shop and the clerk quoted us a price in the Kronen, in Euros, with a credit card, and in US dollars. That was interesting! The number of people on the Square at any one time is a bit daunting if you;re not a fan of huge numbers of people. Also, protect your money and credit cards because this is a pickpocket's heaven..

Feel the City's Rhythm. This is the heart of Old Town and all the streets branch out from here. The buildings surrounding the square are historic dating back as early as the 12th century but with many of the facades restored to later periods. The famous astronomical clock is in the square as is the Church of Our Lady of Tyn. There are several restaurants and pubs and great people watching. Street entertainment abounds.

1000's of People with the Same Idea!. Depending on the time of day (or the weather) you can join 1000's of your newest friends in the Prague Old Town Square. Not only are there numerous restaurants, bars, and trinket shops; you will find the Town Square Clock Tower, with the 600 plus year old Astronomical Clock and St. Nicolas Church where, if you are lucky you can attend an Organ Concert. Besides all these activities, there will be numerous "performers" you can enjoy and dozen's of Segway drivers you may have to dodge.
Really nice place. This is the heart of Prague, very beautiful city, it's a must place to go especially in Christmas, there are lot of activities, you can spend all the day walking around.

Music and a clock. Everyone will gather at the astronomical clock on the hour to hear the rooster crow, the skeleton ring the bell, the doors open and some saints march by..and then it's over! There's usually music in the square and at night, many of the pubs are loaded with drunken tourists! Go during the day!
Beautiful Square. One of the most beautiful squares in Europe. The buildings, the color, the buzz, it's great. A must see in Prague.

Great People Watching. This was one of our favorite parts of Prague. Beautiful architecture and there is always a lot going on. The food is great, both street vendors and restaurants. There were street performers all the time, ranging from great to terrible. This is a must see, and be sure to spend some time here just hanging out.

Clock tower, street entertainers, cathedral, carriages and more. This square is the main tourist site in Prague and coffees and meals reflect the popularity of the area. Prices are twice what you pay elsewhere (just the same as every other city in the world).The architecture is gorgeous. The clock tower area gets very crowded around the time that it strikes the hour. I recommend getting a drink in one of the cafes that face it so that you have a comfortable view and don't have to worry about pickpockets while you are looking.

Over Crowded, over hawked, and tacky, but beautiful buildings. Lots of hawkers trying to get you walk or sedway all over town.Very busy, in fact in spoiled the whole trip, too many crowds.But then that is Prague, which is smoke filled pubs and lots and lots of people. But get off the main areas, like this and Charles Bridge , Nothing to see there really, try any other bridge for a good view. You'll still find smoke filled bars and restaurants but not so many people and the building make it a truely beautiful city
Old World Charm. A very well maintained square, perfectly immortalised from the bygone era. Surrounded by beautiful buildings and there was an Easter Market when we were there.

The astrological clock which chimes on the hour is a must see. Plenty going on. Beautiful architecture, stunning cathedral towers, excellent restaurants and a huge range of good quality street entertainment.
A must. Of course you'll have to go here and see the magnificent square. All kind of things are going on everywhere and whereever you look there's something to see.

Good place as any to start sightseeing in Old Prague!. You can not really visit Prague, without crossing this plaza at least three times. Sure, it is a destination - even marathon had finishing there during my visit. The Orloj (astronomical clock) is the star attraction for every visitor. Tynsky Chram is number two, but it's many restaurants, small streets leading up to it and passages add to the ambiance.It is always fun to watch a busload of oriental tourist spilling quickly from the bus, aim and snap their cameras in all direction, preferably including them self, their partner in every pic.I found the pricing in the restaurants quite reasonable even in comparison to non touristy part of Prague.Beer may be 10 Korun more, but remember - that's $0.50!

Beautiful but watch your pockets!. Love this place, but beware of hucksters, scammers, pickpockets etc., especially around money exchange kiosks. The place is packed with tourists and as a result the seedy people wanting to take advantage are also out in force. I also noticed that a lot of the vendors and kiosks were Russian, not Czech. Make sure you are getting authentic, quality products.

Cool square but very crowded. The only complaint that we had about Prague in general was that it was very crowded with tourist and nowhere is that as evident as in the Square. It is a lovely square and worth seeing but there was always a lot of people there.....

Great for people watching.. A short walk from our K and K hotel down store laden streets to end in the old square. The statue of Jan Hus needs refurbishing, crowds line up to pay to ascend the bell tower of the old town hall, watch the little figures go around when the astronomical clock chimes, visit the church of St. Nicholas, Tyn church, Franz Kafka museum and more.However, to me the best was people watching. All sorts, sizes and shapes. Musicians play, Mimes mime and restaurants abound. We had lunch purchased at a smoker - sausage and ham with special fried potatoes. Be careful as the portions are large and the cost is by weight so don't be afraid to ask for smaller portions or share. Then try to find a place to stand at the few available tables and maybe start a conversation with your neighbor. Meanwhile, watch the interesting people with a local beer or coffee in hand.

A "don't miss" stop in Prague. This lovely square is iconic, from it's astronomical clock to it's many restaurants and great street vibe....street musicians and other performers help to communicate the joy of this old-world city. Lots to see and do....I know many say to avoid the cafes circling the square and we usually go off the beaten path for our meals....but the people watching while drinking a tall pilsner is an experience not to be missed.

Lots to See and Do !. The square is located in the center of historic Prague and is surrounded by baroque buildings, vibrant cafes, street entertainers and craftspeople. The area in front of the astronomical clock will be crowded each hour on the hour to see the clock perform - arrive at the clock 10 to 15 minutes before the hour for a good view.
Beautiful square. Lovely square, fabulous buildings. Worth seeing, the astronomical clock puts on a show every hour. Be aware of pickpockets, but we had no issues at all.
Culture plus. This was amazing. The square was a buzz with people, restaurants and markets. A great location for cheap food and the beer. It was overally beautiful.
Best place for a relaxing evening. liked everything at the SQUARE..The live music..amazing food..street shows..and relaxing breeze..its a must see place

Lots to see and do. Great crystal store here. Be aware that the square in front of the astronomical clock will be crowded each hour on the hour to see the clock perform. There is also a good money-exchange place here, but be careful to negotiate as they really tried to rip us off the second time we used them until we showed them the exchange rate they had given us the day before. There are also good evening concerts at the church on one corner of the square. Interesting statue of Jon Hus in the middle of the square. The square is also only about a 5 - 10 minute walk from the famous Charles Bridge.
magic at xmas. the place truly has an amazing vibe/scenery at xmas time. we travelled as a couple and it was very romantic plus provided ample entertainment. well worth a visit anytime!

A do not miss in Prague. If in Prague you will likely find your way here sooner or later. Throngs gather for the hourly ringing of the clock with animated figures appearing. We have seen similar clocks to this in other places in Europe this one is pretty nice even when it is not on the hour. Get there early because is gets extremely crowded as the hour approaches. Secure a good spot for your photos and prepare for a massive crown. The whole square is full of beautiful views and photo ops.

All roads lead to Old Town Square. My husband and I had a joke on our trip to Prague about always ending up in Old Town Square. No matter where we had been sightseeing during the day, it seemed like we always ended up here. It was a fun and bustling place to enjoy a drink, people watch, and just hang out. There are many vendors, restaurants, performers, and shops to keep you entertained. If visiting Prague, you will inevitably end up here!

Cool place!. Cool place to wander around for a bit, a few stalls here and there and watch the clock, it does a bit of a show every hour, impressive when you think about when it was built. I would recommend to go back to the square at night when it's all lit up- stunning- especially if you are into photography

Entertaining Tourist Trap. It's one of those big town squares with food and street performers and cool architecture all around. Lots of activity. Good sausages and beer are a bit higher priced than elsewhere. Watch out for vendors advertising 100g portions of Prague Ham or potatoes, but a reasonable serving cost much more.
Cosy square. Fun place to people watch and enjoy the vibe of Prague. A lot of street artists when the weather is nice and great architecture to look at!

Photographer's delight. Old town square is the heart of the lovely city Prague with the world famous astrological clock .. Few 100 years old. Loved the colors and the funny and very different statues throughout the city, with maximum skeleton figures found on this clock. Would require 2 to 3 hours of your time to go around the square sufficely.
Fun town square. Wonderful architecture, great lively entertainment and many cafés to enjoy. A top spot to experience in the city of Prague.

Magical!. The Old Town Square is a magical place. The beautiful architecture, small little alleys with tiny galleries, street musicians displaying their talent in a beautiful way and the fantastic food makes the place very engaging. We spent a lot of time there, especially at night, when all the buildings are lit up and it becomes truly magical.A must visit in Prague, though eating in the restaurants can burn quite big a hole in your pocket. To avoid that, we used to take the tram to the suburbs and had amazing food at cheap rates.
People watching.. The centre of tourist Prague. People watching is a favourite game and it's free. Many cafés and restaurants to suit everyone.
Amazing place. This is a really amazing place to see in Prague. The whole place by itself leaves a pleasant print in your memories and you will definitely want to come back here.
Wonderful acchitecture. The lovely architecture from the surrounding buildings is breath taking! The clock is a bit over-rated, yet if you are there to enjoy Prague, its a must see attraction!

Entertaining Square. We walked to the square twice as it was a center hub for everything else we were going to do. The clock is great and crowds draw when it nears the top of the hour. There are plenty of street performers and its a great place to grab a bit to eat and watch people.

Vibrant square with wonderful architecture. Busy atmosphere with lots of performers and people milling around. Lots of people to observe. The buildings surrounding the square and the statue inside are great pieces of architecture. Thats before commenting on the clock tower! Always worth a visit even if just for a wander through

stunningly beautiful. Old Town Square is one of the main places to hang out in Prague with incredibly beautiful architecture surrounding the square. Make sure you go to the clock tower and up (either by stairs or elevator) to see great views of the city.
Nice but very busy. It's worth seeing but you should expect a very busy/touristic place! Often there's great performers in the square and the church is impressive.
Beautiful, not to be missed. One of the most popular destinations in Europe and in the world. It has the old time charm when one walks through the small lanes of the old town.

Pretty bustling during the evening.. I like how people gather around and enjoyed some entertainment with people doing small parades and playing some music. We can see some cultures and folklore music there and then.
I really like that environment!
The iconic image of Prague. What you see everywhere that shows Prague. This is it.. this is the place :) You will really be amazed with such beauty.
A postcard. It has the most iconic view of Prague and is really unforgetable. The place is amazing, at daylight or at night.

truly beautiful space. It is a wonderful space, surrounded by the Old Town Hall with its unique and amazing astronomical clock, the beautiful dual spired Tyn Church, St. Nicholas Church, a statue of Jan Hus in the center, and many other examples of beautiful architecture. It is difficult not to be impressed by this lovely large area. Also, while there were plenty of people in and around the area, it was not so overly crowded as to interfere with the enjoyment. One evening they installed a huge tv screen to enable folks to watch the Czeck national hockey time compete. Also, Prague knows how to use lighting at night to beautify its architecture.
Should not be missed. A visit to Praha would nt be complete without a visit here, great spot to take in all the action of the astronomical clock and the great street theatre of the square.
Very impressive. Very impressive square, a must see in Prague. The buildings are well preserved. Lots of tour touts there.

Pretty but crowded. The Square is very pretty but is usually jammed with tourists, including lots of tour groups. The area in front of the astronomical clock is packed every hour with hundreds of people waiting for the clock chow. Once you get off the square, the crowds diminish a lot.

Fantastic experience. We lived in a nice hotel in the old town during our stay. There are lots of restaurants in the region as well as many fancy snack shops. The souvenir shops were quite expansive compared to the small market in the town. Nice food and beers. It is a must-visit place in Prague.

great square. this is steeped in history and you can see heaps of old building, the clock, etc and eats or just a coffee. Generally the people are great and why wouldn't they be they want your money. If you want to shop go to Wenceslass square but we found that was all, whatever!!
Very nice. We visited prague at the end of may. Great square to walk around and in the evening when it got chilly it was great to sit outside in one of the bars under the gas heaters

Best Place to hang out in the evening. The square is quite nice at all times but in the evenings it comes alive with jugglers, musicians and other acts. The restaurants on the square are not unreasonably priced for beer so one can sit an have a few beers and enjoy the entertainment and people watching for about $10 per person if you drink two beers. They also have decent food and desserts in the square so its a great place to go after dinner for a coffee and dessert.

Breathtaking Sight. A most colorful Town Square with exquisitely painted buildings bringing color to the square. There are street people in costumes and musicians playing traditional and classical and popular music. The restaurants are wonderful and we had meals in several of them. The floral exhibits are gorgeous and add life to the cobblestones. You can take horse drawn buggies or just stroll the beautiful square. Head to the Astrological Clock to hear the chime if the bells on the hour. Little figurines come out of the top two doors and dance around for a few minutes. It is a wonderful place to experience and if you live there a great afternoon outing for the family.
Go here and sit down at one of the restaurants!. The beer, the food and the view on a Sunny day! Then take a walk around the blocks and return to your table, or one close to it!
Most beautiful city in Eastern Europe. Prague is unique in Eastern Europe as it was not too much affected by the Second World War. Every place you look is amazing.
Spectacular Day and Night!!. This square is just nice to walk around, grab a coffee/ice cream, explorer the plaza, chill for a few hours!
Wonderful!. Worth a wander round - full of activity, beautiful buildings and a wide range of bars and restaurants.

Amazing. A must see when you go to Prague. Music and performers everywhere. High police presence, which was nice.
The architecture is amazing so bring your camera.
There are also stores and restaurants everywhere. Lots of restaurants where you can sit outside and enjoy a meal and people watch.
Spectacular. The main tourist attraction in Prague and you cannot miss it. Plenty of bars and restaurants to sit and watch the world go by!

Art and Music everywhere. The old town square was gorgeous. It's full of artists, musicians, and all kinds of performers. I grabbed some food at the vendor and sat at the sidewalk. A couple dressing in suites danced under the sunlight in front of me. It was like moving the stage to the square. It was so lively!! Definitely a must-visit spot in Prague!

Amazing in daytime and at night. It's a place surrounded by churches dating from different centures which is just stunning! There are several restaurants, kiosks with traditinal food. Quite safe (there is always nearby). There is something going on all the time - singers, dancers, parades...

Huge square with lots of entertainers. My family enjoyed our visit in this huge square surrounded by old and well preserved buildings. Many street entertainers in every possible corner almost any time. We sat in one of the restaurants watching many colorful people and just enjoy the atmosphere.
Cute, cute, cute. Look at the tourists, look at the amazing architecture, the churches. Sit at a cafe or grab a take-away from one of the stands. Rest and thanks yourself for taking you there!
Touristy. Interesting for a few minutes and photos. Huge number of people, very touristy. Several good cafés to sit and watch.

Historic and Beautiful. The square is a great spot to start off a tour of Prague. Several landmarks are right on the square, and it is a popular gathering place for locals and tourists. A highlight is the Church of Our Lady Before Tyn, the amount of gold in the interior design is stunning. (Unfortunately, the church does not allow photographs.) The square is a must-see, especially if you only have a short time in Prague.

Enjoyed the ambience. Spent a few leisurely hours here listening to the music from a local band. Had a delicious meal of ham and sausage from a roadside vendor.Did not like the bread as it seemed somewhat stale. Enjoyed a great concert at the Nicholas church.
Fun experience!. Amazing!! Loved the square, had dinner and a glass of wine listening to some great music. A must see!
very nice. The square is very beautiful, but there are too many people here, especially when the clock striking (Prague Astronomical Clock - the main attraction of the square)

Revel in the soul of Prague. It was the first place we visited after a long flight from Singapore - and it was worth the journey and definitely a fitting introduction to the beauty and splendor of Eastern Europe for which we would spend 15 wonderful days. The town square and it's festive atmosphere made real everything that had seemed unreal in TV and fairy tale books. From waiting for the astronomical clock to chime at the hour, savouring a cup of hot coffee on a cold spring day in an open cafe, to browsing in the quaint little shops selling all kinds of local merchandise, it was exhilarating. I enjoyed it very much with my loved ones. For those who wish to feel the enchantment of both European history and fantasy, never miss this place and Prague in totality.

Beautiful!. Old Town Square is a great place to watch people, eat, stroll and just plain enjoy the city of Prague. Plenty of street vendors selling the Prague ham and Czech beer for lunch or dinner. Gelato for sale. Great cafes to sit down and have dinner or lunch or just have a great Czech beer! Performers from musical, to juggling, etc. A fun place to be that we visited may times over our 5 days in Prague.
Beautiful town square. This is one of the best squares in Europe it has some thing for everyone. Just don't eat there as the food is terrible and cost an arm and a leg.

Great atmosphere. The square is extremely busy both during the day and night with the old town clock beautifully illuminated at night time. The views from the top of the clock tower are spectacular. The nominal entrance to visit the top is well worth it.

Avoid eating in the right side cantine with the ham - prociutto. The prices on the menu board are for 100 gr but they force you to take a piece of meat that may be 300-400 gr. For 1 saucage, 1 ham, 1 beer, 1 mushed potatoe we paid 850 ck = 30 euros intead of 260 ck = 10 eyros!

Beautiful piece of Bohemian history. One word; AMAZING! On your visit to Praha you will not miss this place because it is in the center of everything downtown Prague. Walk around and take your time, you'll enjoy it.
One day not enough. A bustling place to visit. Plenty of things to do and see. Many lovely places to sit and drink and eat.

Wonderful atmosphere. The Old Town Square is a great place to base your exploration of the Old a Town. Beautiful facades on the buildings, cafés, restaurants, cathedrals and the astronomical clock all make for great sight seeing. Not far to the famous Charles Bridge it makes for a great way to get a real feel for Prague.
Enchanting. Wonderful architecture of the majestic old buildings and the peacefulness in spite of all the visitors.
Most beautiful town square in Europe. Unbelievable scenery and many buildings next to it. There is always something to see as well. The clock tower on the edge of the square is amazing.

Fun place to grab some beers and food. The square is gorgeous, with the Astronomical Tower and the Church of our Lady of the Tyn looming overhead (of which both are worth a tour). There's always something going on from early morning till way past midnight. The prices are always nearly double for what you could pay a few streets away from the hustle and bustle of tourists, but it's a fun spot to watch people and grab a couple of beers, especially when the weather is beautiful. Rows of tables set up cafe-style outside every restaurant, or you can sit inside the exquisitely ornate buildings themselves. If you don't like crowds, you may not entirely enjoy the scene....but if you love admiring incredible architecture and masonry and adore the energy of this great city, you'll want to stay nearby and walk through the square every day.

Quirky. The Old Town Square was always a hub of activity, buskers, food vendors and tourists, al fresco dining and amazing ambience. Stunning buildings and the Astronomical Clock Tower is a must for 360 degree views.

What a place to people watch. After walking for a few hours around the Mala Strana and then across the Charles bridge and to the Old Town Square we decided to grab a beer and watch everything happening in the square. Aside from the wonderful architecture around we enjoyed watching all the other people in the square, probably mostly tourists as ourselves, but we had a great time while we recharged. Well worth spending a little extra for the beer here.

A Tourist Must!. What a fantastic place to visit. Very touristy, but it sort of added to it's character.There was a real buzz about this square, which was very multi cultural.Crowds of people gather around the clock on the hour, but you can always find a spot to watch from. Lots of street artists doing their thing, as well as cafe's and restaurants.There are also some kiosks selling traditional czech food.The buildings are beautiful, and definitely worth a visit at night when they are lit up.A tourist spot not to be missed.

Classic town. It is a nice square where there a lot of classic and beautiful building around.It is an enjoyment just to stay in this square enjoying the street music for 30 mins.Take your camera and start shooting in all 360deg direction in this place.Obviously it is something you cannot miss while you are in Prague.
Beautiful historic location. Lovely broad square with musicians and displays, surrounded by cafes and restaurants. Wander around in pretty well any direction and you will find something of interest.

A Happening. Old town square is an amazing place. Fabulous architecture, beautiful statues, food, trinkets, street entertainers and of course, the Astronomical Clock. Just go through the square and take in all of the sights and sounds. It is quite an experience. On the hour, the Clock " performs". It always draws a big crowd.

Beautiful!. Went for Easter and the Old Town Square was amazing. It was decorated, had loads of market stalls selling lovely items and amazing different foods and drinks all at a reasonable price and there were street performers all around.So nice we returned everyday of the trip!

Lots of historic buildings. There's lots to see in this square.
You're surrounded by old buildings including the Astronomical Clock and there's lots of cafés and restaurants to grab something to eat.
Nice to visit

Old Town. The Old Town is a nice place to visit in the weekends. There's a lot of places to visit and see, like the royal castle. The houses are small and there is no cars driving around. The restaurants in the area are good. There's a lot of small shops that sells souvenirs. There is one place I can recommend, it is the area between Old Town and Slussen by the water.

Awesome. Must visit. It is really beautiful square with no single boring building on it. It is somehow private & relaxing even with crowds of people. Best to be visited in evening, it is especially beautiful with buildings lighted up.
a must to visit. Vibrant and interesting area with a multitude of various activities to keep your attention. Plenty of cafes and great for people watching
Stunning. Really beautiful - definitely visit during the day And at night - two different, but equally great experiences

Amazing. So many things to see here I could write paragraphs. Grab a tourist guide so you don't miss even the smallest drawing on the facade of buildings. Make sure you see it both during the day and at night, beautiful at all times.

A fun place. Very good place to spend an afternoon. All kinds of food, local and otherwise, and even though there are the usual tourist shops, there are also nice stores to buy some well made local souvenirs.We had no problems with pickpockets but were told to be careful.
Heart of the city. Lots of tourists but still a lovely atmosphere, lots to see. Performances, food stalls. Beautiful buildings. Worth seeing.

Beautiful spot in Prague. This is an amazing spot a must do in Prague but go as early as possible as it gets so busy. Early morning is good for photos afternoon evening is good for music and people watching.

Steeped in History. Much to see, so you best read up on the history of the square and the buildings around it, before you dare to face the crowd that seems to be gathered at the square at all times of the day. Locals told me that it's only this crowded from the End of May until early September.
Feritale. If you love history and beauty, this is the place. It is one of the most visited cities in the world. The old time square will move you. It's unlike anything else I have seen.

So much going on.... You can easily stay here for the day eating drinking people watching and relaxing in the sunshine. Plenty to occupy the whole family and I recommend hopping on a bus tour from this location.

Pretty place. Worth a visit. especially the bylanes just to soak in the architecture. There is a young lady who runs a Trdelnik store - it was very chilly and she gave us really nice warm toasty trdelniks... [i hope i am spelling it correct]

beautiful Prague. Gob smacked ,such a beautiful city and a photographers dream.
Had three days there but could have stayed three weeks.

Much better than Wenceslas Square. The clock is the obvious focal point and attracts hundreds of people on the hour every hour. Good choice of bars and restaurants and close to Charles Bridge. Street Entertainers not bad too
