Cool square, lots happening, don't eat at the stalls!. Really fun and lively square when we were there when the sun was out, lot's of street performers and stuff happening. However as mentioned, don't eat at the stalls.Crepe's and stuff were fine, but the stall selling sausages and czech ham was a massive rip off. Wouldn't usually eat at stalls like this but were in a rush to get to our tour starting so had no choice. The prices displayed are for weight, but you don't get to choose how heavy the food you are served is. So the price displayed isn't really close to the price you end up paying and unless you speak czech or refuse to pay, you'll be caught out. Massively over priced and would definitely avoid.

Too crowded to see and enjoy. Wish we could have seen what must be a beautiful combination of sights and activities without the almost claustrophobic feeling when surrounded by huge crowds. It was impossible to appreciate the many beautiful attractions when you are literally boxed in by an endless number of large tour groups, people on Segways, overpriced restaurants and picture takers. If you are fortunate enough to be staying nearby, you could probably get there in the morning. Or later in the evening and thus enjoy all that there is to see. Midday was simply a horror.
Great atmosphere. A very popular place for eating and drinking - and totally traffic free! You can even dine with a view of the astronomical clock!

Quirkiest Place. There are so many attractions surrounding this square, had the chance to visit the Alfons Mucha exhibit, Týn Church, St. Nicholas Church and the Astronomical Clock, the best thing is its proximity to other sites (Charles Bridge, Powder Tower etc)

Beautiful, if you can avoid the crowds.. Staying a stone's throw from Prague's Old Town Square, i was able to enjoy the quiet, morning facet of this normally bustling area. The Square can get very crowded from mid morning, especially around the Astronomical Clock on the hour, Segways zip around, artists entertain small and large crowds, and trying to avoid being in someone else's photographic 'way', is a futile exercise. Plenty of places to eat or get a coffee and a good reference for exploring the old quarter further. And of course, beautiful architecture.
Many things to see. Lots of things...The Astronomic Clock, City Hall, Souvenir Shops. Every building has something beatiful to see

watch out for rip-offs. The square is a lovely place to visit, but beware of the prices charged at the picturesque cabins selling food...it is by the 100g! I watched tourists being charged over 8oo korona for one slice of bread and a chunk of pork (500k=£16 at the moment)...and two youngsters buying sausages separately handed over 500 notes and only got change for 200-the stall holders ganged up together when they protested...one left in tears.

Another great square. Every corner you turn in this place you find another photo moment. His Si lovely and always places to get food and drink and lots of beer places to stop off and wet your whistle.

Restaurants, stores, and lots of people. When we travel, we like to get a feel for the personality and history of a place. Staring at the center of an area is usually a good idea, and I supposed Prague is no different. That said, Old Town Square told me almost nothing about Prague. Between restaurants with outdoor seating areas clogging the walkways, souvenir shops cheap and dear, costumed characters (including someone in a Lego suit), hawkers, and a gazillion people, I could have been in Times Square for all I knew. Yes, the Astronomical Clock is a wonder, but surrounded by thousands of people when it sounds off. The street musicians are quite good, but amplified singing of popular songs is not why you go to Prague.There is much history there, but you get no sense of that except in the early morning hours when the place is abandoned. Which pretty much tells you the best time to see it.

Lively and pleasant. Like many other areas of Prague, the old town square is like stepping into another era. We were fortunate enough to see some performances and try tradition foods from street vendors. A must see whilst in Prague.
Great spot to sit, relax and have a drink. We loved sitting out in the afternoon and evening. Our favorite was the Prince Hotel outdoor restaurant....about $5-6 for a beer or iced coffee.

Gorgeous but almost trashy. The wonders of the Old Town Square are architectural, historic and the stuff of legends; chiefly among them the 1410 astronomical clock, the statue of Jan Hus (John Huss) and the gothic/baroque churches and palaces. Unfortunately, despite rainy, cold weather the Square was mobbed. Hungry homeless types scavenge the leftovers from open air eateries and literally watch you eat, hoping for a few scraps. There was a drunk sleeping on the pavement in the drizzling rain. We have not seen one policeman. The food stands serve ham heated/grilled over wood-burning stoves, sausages and a mix of potatoes, cabbage and bacon. Beer is an obvious complement. It is all overpriced, too cold and too salty to merit a recommendation. The beer is OK. The two pink Port-a-potties labeled "Jenny" in the center of the Square reinforce the impression the Czechs care more about tourist numbers than their cultural heritage. Once I got past this fairly shocking first impression, I loved the elements of the gorgeous Square. The astronomical clock is a wonder, especially when one pays attention to the 4 figures next to the dial and below the procession of the apostles.

Lovely town square. We loved Old Town Square. We spent many hours drinking, chatting and people watching here during our recent visit to Prague. The astronomical clock is lovely - very innovative considering it was built in the 14th Century. There are lots of designer shops (Dior, Louis Vuitton, Hermes to name but a few) and lots of shops selling the usual tourist tat. And the lovely, hot weather we had when there didn't go amiss.

Best Place to Get a Taste of Prague. If you are a visitor to Prague, you have to go to Old Town Square. The crowds, shops and restaurants are all there because of the historical buildings, astronomical clock, and the events. When we arrived at the square, a jumbotron was set up for the crowds to watch the Hockey World Cup. The energy in the city is palpable. The history of this amazing city is everywhere with this square the center of it all.

Awesome. One of the most stunning squares in Europe and teeming with life - a must see for any visitor to Prague - if you see nothing else an evening visit to the square is a must. Restaurants and bars on the square do charge a premium but not over the top by any means.
Makes you come back again and again. We got married in Ratusha on the Old Town Square and it was unforgettable experience =) We couldn't find better place for that!

People watching heaven. The Old square has something for everyone - plenty of lovely old buildings, shops, segway riding, astronomical clock and bars and restaurants galore.
Fabulous place to soak up the atmosphere, enjoy a drink and people watch for hours.
Amazing!. The sights and sounds, the street artists, the sidewalk restaurants - what a marvelous experience for the senses!
very Good. The square is always very entertaining with street shows, good choice of dinning places. although missed some lights in the centre statue, otherwise good square to spend great time.
Medieval astronomical clock. You want to arrive here about 10 minutes before each (any) hour to see the "Orloj" astronomical clock work in motion.

See Prague starting from Old Town Center. From the old town center, you can see Prague. The castle, the church, the astronomical clock all the souvenir shops and the branded store, you name it they have it. There is also the horses drawn carriage that can tour you around. I also experience eating street food as roast ham and sausages which yummy .

Gorgeous & entertaining. There is always something going on in Old Town Square. It is a beautiful area with the Astronomical Clock, plenty of restaurants and food stands and there is usually a musical act or circus act performing which really keeps the area alive! I love it here and I would suggest staying in a hotel/hostel near this area.

The Prague Marathon. Brilliant place with loads going on, plenty to see, hear, eat and drink! Even with the marathon going on the streets are clean and feel safe. We really enjoyed our too few days there!!

The main attraction in Prague. We were in Prague during Easter week and the Old Town Square was beautiful with many type of stalls for food, souveneirs and the like. We had lunch in the square twice and also stayed for dessert. You have to come here during the day and the evening to be admire the square and surrounding churches.

Touristy, but go anyway!. If it happens to be raining you'll have more of the square to yourself, with great grey scale for photographs and the wet stones really pop on camera. If you're stuck with the sun you'll be mired in tourists, but 3 pc bands playing gypsy music and lots of vendors make it feel authentic. Plus the Parisean cafes will open and you can just people watch for hours.

Beautiful square, lots of music and fun. Fantastic, beautiful square with lots of people playing music and having fun. The astronomical clock is something fun to see with a huge gathering of people standing by to see it every hour. Just a wonderful place to sit and people watch, all sorts of nice restaurants and such nearby. Also the meeting place for a bunch of tours. Whatever you do - don't miss this spot while you're in Prague.

Breathtaking! Everything I expected Prague to be!. My first encounter with Prague was a bit underwhelming. We arrived after dark and drove right to the hotel we were staying at, so we were unable to see any of the enchantment of Prague upon arrival. The next morning, we went off to find a walking tour. Unable to find the guide (we got a bit lost), we ended up in a dodgy end of the city near a train/bus station. From there we backtracked to a local Mc Cafe to get our bearings, and I was able to download a walking tour of Prague on my phone, which consisted of 20+ sites to see. We began our self-guided walking tour, and slowly but surely we were able to understand why we always heard people fell in love with Prague! We stopped in Old Town Square for lunch, and that is where I first truly felt the wonder and excitement I was so eager to feel! We dined at a restaurant with seating in the square, and it was amazing to be able to sit and immerse ourselves in the buzz of the square and local culture and all of its beauty!

Prague Essential stop. Although this is clearly the center of tourism in Prague, the sheer beauty of the surroundings will help you block out all the sounds of people selling everything. From the astronomical clock, to the church to the statue in the middle this is a definitely feast for the eyes and great photo opportunities. Please make sure you see it after sun down and watch the buildings light up.

fantastic architecture. a fantastic area to visit. the architecture of the buildings never get boring to look at. can get crowded towards the middle of the day. I went in the summer and now looking to go back again for christmas.

Worth every bit of your time. It's one of the most beautiful squares and a must see. The buildings surrounding the square are built in different architectural styles and the most important landmark is the Astronomical Clock. It's always crowded,but it's worth every bit of your time. You should take a minute or two to sit on the benches near St.Nicholas Church and just enjoy the view.

Too many people on a Sunday. Too many people to really see what the square is like, plus there was a huge TV screen broadcasting ice hockey playoffs that all the Czech crowds had come to see. I suspect that most of the restaurants and cafes there charge way over the top.
Old town square. The square was very pretty and the highlight was the astronomical clock and the little cafes in the square.

Crowded but worth. As I am living in Prague already since 2008 I have seen already all the city has to offer and I can say is one of the best places to be during winter / spring .lots of events ongoing, a lot to visit/see but careful on your pockets.for pictures best moments would be early in the morning or after 9 pm.plenty of shops around and exhibits

Prague is awesome!. all of Prague is awesome,so much old cool stuff and history,i was here during christmas and there was snow and festivals and people everywhere,lots of mulled wine and food,very nice spot
Must visit. Old world charm. Street cafes and shops gives you wonderful feelings. Just sit in any of the cafes to eat and spend your time leisurely simply lazing around.
Crowded with tourist but a MUST see. Tons of tourists/crowds but full of history and sights, great place to eat average Food and people watch.
Wonderful. The Astronomical Clock is really an amazing spectacle. Bearing in mind it was built in the 15th century without the aid of modern day equipment it is truly a wonderful feat of Engineering.

beautiful church. The old town square is a lovely area with the most beautiful church and the clock amongst its attractions.It is bustling at all times of the day and night with places to eat and drink and entertainers to watch.

Another of our places during our trip. It was almost midday when we visited quite crowded but still enough room to move freely as we are not big fans of crowded spaces.
Our opinion was it was over rated but everybody has a different view of any attraction.

A wonderful place. This square alone makes a visit to Prague worthwhile. The architecture is striking, as is the old town area in general. Dominated by church spires and towers the view in any direction invites a lengthy viewing. The astronomical clock is a marvel considering its age. It chimes with a display of the apostles on the hour from 9am to 9pm. The white crosses around the corner from the clock have an interesting history as well. The statue of Huss indicates the religious divides of the past and lessons for those willing to learn. The food stalls and other entertainments both add and detract to the atmosphere. On one visit, Czech Republic was in the finals of the Ice Hockey World Cup and the crowd of avid fans sang, waved flags and roared its way through the game adding even greater character to the square. Prices for everything around the square are inflated, food and drink especially so. Ask the price before you order. On a sunny day, the square is absolutely packed with thousands of tourists. There is a need to be aware of pickpockets, segway novices and horse drawn vehicles. The best advice is to get into the square early in the morning before most arrive and enjoy the atmosphere, archtitecture and history. It's a short walk down to the Charles Bridge and old Jewish Quarter from here. If you don't wander the square on a visit to Prague, you've done yourself a disservice. A must for anyone interested in history, architecture and cultural significance and for someone just wanting to be impressed.
Classic and romantic. We arrived prague at night time, since the hotel we were staying was very close to old town square, we walked there, it was really packed, everything was lit up, so romantic!
Charming!. This was a wonderful and beautiful part of Prague. It was so picturesque my husband and I really enjoyed it
Bars and restaurants. The astronomical clock and the entertainers on all day. The prices were reasonable in some of the restaurants around the square

Nice place to visit. Very nice place, with a nice vibe and very pretty architecture. The astronomical clock is interesting and still operates with no electricity (as it did in medieval times). Very crowded but must see!

Top Attraction in Prague. nice stroll around the Old town square. It reminds me of Florence yet more mysterious.Must come if you are visiting Prague.Watch your purse when you are around the astronomical clock. We tried some of the food stalls, the roasted ham or something. It was very expensive. They don't put out the price; but then it is the prime area after all, so I guess it was our fault for not asking before ordering.
Must Visit. Love the antique and historic buildings in the square. Been there last summer, beautiful view and weather. Love this city, even though lots of visitors.

Lovely buildings but so crowded. I found this attraction difficult to rate because the buildings in the square are beautiful but everything else is as average/poor. Far too many people for it to feel comfortable walking around. If you want to eat any of the food from the stalls please be aware the prices quoted are for 100 grams not per portion. (Ham, potato etc). Also ice cream are prices per scoop but you get half a scoop not a full one....where as if you walk off down one of the streets off the square you can get twice the amount for much less money...http://www.boom-gelato.cz/en/gallery/Also be careful when changing money as in a lot of the exchange places what is advertised is not always what you get. Example we changed 60 euros.... one quoted 900czk another 1200 czk and should have been 1532czk which we got at another.

Magical. This was the first visit to Prague after a twenty year hiatus. We had come for ten years in a row both before and after the Velvet Revolution but this was the first time since the Caech Republic had joined the EU. What was once a magical place, Prague remains so, but with overwhelming and crushing numbers of tourists (we among them) and the commercial honky tonk that comes in its wake. The activity in the square now is such that, except for the snake charmers, you could be standing in the middle of the main square of Marakesh. Yet, the beauty and wonder of the city, its authenticity and essential character remains, so long as one looks up and marvel at what you see while trying ignore what is going on around you.

Old Town square. Very crowded, particularly when astronomical clock is due to strike on the hour but if you stand well back it is fine for viewing and photos also less than 5 minutes from hotel Cloister Inn
Nice place to visit. nice place to hang around and socialized ,surrounded by beautiful architecture,definitely recommend to visit.

So much fun!. This is the place to go in Prague. Lots of different people. Everything from 14th century buildings to Segway tours. Lots of open air cafes, tons of shops selling Chech glassware and garnet jewelry. We did a tour of the city in a old car, best way to see it. Music was everywhere. Loved, loved this city!!

Must see location. The square comes alive when the sun is shining, and we were lucky enough to be there when it did. Musicians and other acts captivate audiences in one of the most beautiful and historic backdrops in the world. It truly is a must see when visiting Prague.
Lovely. A very busy and crowded place, but worth visiting to check out the amazing architecture (and the astronomical clock)!
The old clock. There is a lot going on all time in Square the clock figures go round every hour the road can be hard on your feet put on flat shoes

Surrounded by history. Loved the square even though it was extra packed with tourists with the Prague marathon being run the next day. The statue of Jan Hus was especially important to me as someone who has an interest in church and Czech history. There's plenty to see and do even if you're only people watching
astonishing. It is so beautiful that you don´t know which side you must see first. You feel sorry to leave it. I loved it.

Worth a visit as its the city center. As a part of the city center, this place is one of the main tourist attractions of the city. Most of the guided tours starts from here and there are many restaurants nearby.
So much fun! Great architecture!. This place is VERY busy...day and night! The Astronomical Clock is amazing...there are so many great restaurants and street vendors!!!

Fun and interesting. Lively with the Easter Market and the street entertainment. Nice place to people watch and then there is the Astronomical clock!! Lots of cafes and shops surrounding the area....great place to visit!!

Great square! A definite must-see in Prague.. We were fortunate to have stayed pretty close to the Old Town Square. It has great architecture and is a great place to people watch. The astronomical clock is there as well which is very cool.

Very interesting. We enjoyed visiting the Square, taking a drink and just people watching, very good. There are plenty of bars, restaurants which seem very popular. We were told they were more expensive than some of the back street ones, but its location every time.

what a clock. The square is wonderful lots going on you can just stand and wait for the clock to chime or sit and have a meal or drink in one of the many cafe's. it's good to see it both night and day.

Activities All Around. This is one of the nicest squares we have visited. There is a lot to see and do - churches, food stands, architecture viewing, experiencing the astronomical clock (must go up inside it!), bars, restaurants, shopping, statutes, people watching. The square is not that large - we were lucky to have gone when the crowds were less than summer, but it was still busy and we did brush shoulders. There are many tour groups so you can take advantage of picking up a tip or two in your favorite language.

must see!. Beautiful square with historical buildings around, cathedral and astronomical watch that perform every hour. Many restaurants around, bars and clubs. Very busy but with special atmosphere of local culture. One of my most favorite places in Prague!
Exciting. There is alot going on in the old town square-something for everyone: food music, showmanship, history. It is the central meeting place of Prague. A must!!

Lots to do, lots to see. First thing we did was go to the money changer. The place we went to did not ask for a service charge unlike at the airport. We did some shopping at the souvenir shops and ate at the park benches. I had the chance to feed the pigeons, didn`t know if it was allowed but i did it anyway. There were horse carriages, human statues, thai massages, churches, lots of buildings. There were also musicians and people dancing to their music at the middle of the square. The square had a festive atmosphere. A definite must-do.

Easter Markets. In April the Easter Markets were on (I assume this is an annual market festival) which was really fun! There were lots of stalls selling crafts, souvenirs and street food snacks. It was very crowded but that added to the lively atmosphere.

The most beautiful cathedral we've ever been to!!. The windows are wonderful, giants, colorful... the outside is gorgeous, huge, magnificent... It is a must see! I just wonder how much money the church invested on those temples while their people were starving....

Excellent Square. Amazing square where the famous Orloj is in. Many cafes and restaurants nearby. Distance walking from the Namesti Republiky (where the Municipal House is in) and from the Charles bridge (Karlúv most). Agartha jazz pub is very close from this square. Must see!

Fun Area. There is always some type of busking in the square and the surrounding buildings are beautiful. You can branch out in any direction to find food, shops and interesting streets. Great area just to explore.

Go up the tower. Square is beautiful and varied. Buildings are from different eras and architecture and combine for visual feast for the eyes. Loved it all. Go beyond square into smaller square and don't miss Storch building

The Old town Square is the lovely heart of Prague. Surrounded by beautiful buildings - the views are great in daytime and tastefully illuminated at night. The clock is the high point - but just wander around and dig the vibes. Good sports pub to watch football matches as well.
Beautiful Square To Visit. The Old Town Square is not only beautiful because of the grand buildings located there, but it is also a hub of activity! It's a great place to visit.
Great Centre. Real atmosphere, variety of buildings and styles. Good options for eating, both in restaurants around the square, and food stalls

Nice but crowded. Nice place to sit down and take a beer, while you're waiting for the astronomical clock to strike the time. But it's many others here, who want to do just the same, and it gets crowded. If you're just walking around the sqare, it can be a bit difficult with all the people. Have a good grip on your bag!

People watching deluxe!. What a beautiful town and there is always music and things to watch while drinking a good beer, or having a fabulous strudel or other fine pastry....many many outdoor restaurants

The best part of Prague Old Town square. I have been to Prague many times over the years, but I never fail to visit Old Town Square ..its an excellent place to visit to see the historic buildings.. especially at night when the buildings are lit by flood lights.... also there are many and varied places to eat.. according to your own taste.. not forgetting the Astronomical clock that everyone wants to see...also there are the horse drawn carriages to take a sight seeing tour of the city.. don't miss this excellent Square....

Nice but overrun with tourists. The Old Town Square in itself is a really nice place and there are a lot of pretty things to spot. But also, it is absolutely overrun by tourists. That kind of took away of it's beauty by daylight a bit. We also crossed it by night and I liked it much more because you realize just how big it is and how impressive the buildings all around are. When we went there at night we saw a group of drug dealers hang around the edge of the square but they did not bother us. But I guess if people are on their own that could be a bit off-putting

Beautiful! Not to be missed!. This old town square is absolutely beautiful. There are plenty of places to eat in the square, and an old church where the giant sized time pieces come out, while the entire square looks up at it. Plenty of sight seeing to be done around the same neighborhood. They have horse-drawn carriages you can rent, and it's just breathtaking!
Historic. We had the advantage of having a guide to point out places of interest. Make the most of your trip and hire a guide-you will not regret it.
A great place to visit.. Would really recommend going up the tower. I loved walking around in here. A must if you are in the city.

Always something to see. No trip to Prague would be complete without seeing the astronomical clock chime on the hour and trumpeter at the top of the tower. The musicians playing at various points in the square were lovely to listen to and a wander around transports you to an age gone by.

THE TOURIST HUB OF PRAGUE..!!!. And as most people have noted this old historic square of Prague is seriously crowded at all times especially with the dreaded tour groups wandering around complete with hyper guides franticly waving umbrellas above their heads, and the surrounding restaurants reflect this too in their prices. But having said this try eating in the extortionate over the top St Marks square Venice, and you'll see the difference. This old square in Prague does have a lot to offer for everyone including the famous Astronomical clock tower, St Nicholas Cathedral, eating stalls etc. I also felt some of the restaurants weren't too expensive either considering where they are but, just off the square the prices start dropping dramatically, just shop around and you'll find a perch to sit and do some serious people watching with a beer or two, and along with some street performers makes a nice place to visit on a daily basis. It's also a very historic place with some stunning architectural buildings to behold from a long gone era of Prague.If you do feel like shopping here don't, unless you have a hefty bank balance to match. Just walk along to the outdoor market and you'll find the same gifts at a fraction of the price, you can also haggle a little too they don't mind. Remember this place never sleeps night or day and there's something for everyone here, if you wander off the square don't panic, as nearly all the cobbled roads lead to the river or back to the square at some point, just enjoy the experience.Do also be aware of pickpockets around here as all it takes is one of those scum bags to spoil your holiday, and a magical time with one act of complacency....!

An amazing place, perfect to fly in dreaming. This one of most beatiful hall in Europe. During morning is fullfilled by a lot of people and you can make a free tour with kind guys that recruit tourists (I suggest you to make it because is very interesting). In the hall there are many bar, cafe and restaurants, where you may choose to energy yourself. In the evening, when darkness come down, the hall becomes noir and very suggestive. It's a magic place and you couldn't miss it if you're in Prague.

Stunning. The actual square itself is stunning! All the old buildings are just out of this world with how beautiful they were.We never ate or bought anything around here as it is double / triple the price. We found the same stuff right by our hotel - 20 min walk away and a lot cheaper and the food amazing. Tip: only go to look at how beautiful it is.

Old world preserved. The center of Prague is an architectural wonderland, seemingly unchanged over the centuries. We have visited many such cities and towns in Europe, and Prague ranks with the best. Every direction is a visual feast, including stunning interiors as with the Tyn and St. Nicholas Cathedrals. Musical performances of high quality also abound.

must see sight. It's near to impossible to miss this square and it shouldn't be missed. Heart of Prague with several interesting buildings and the astronomical clock. Also the location of the beautiful crystal artwork of the Moser shop.

Surrounded on All Sides by Options. The exterior of this cobbles square has restaurants, souvenir shops, churches, fast food eats, and galleries, Inside the square there are usually some buskers and street performers. Many tour groups will be going through here en masse and I would say easy pickings for pick pockets. Many walking tours will start in this area. Even if you do not put this on your list of destinations you will surely cross the Old Town Square several times during your stay. At night the facades of the square are dimly lit and makes for excellent photos.

Must see in Prague. Prague is a beautiful city, and this area probably the most beautiful part of it. It is always crowded with people and the restaurants around the square are double and triple the price of anywhere else.

Magic city. Having visited Budapest last year ,we wanted to go to Prague and we loved it. If you love history and lovely historic buildings you will love Prague. You can take one of the sight seeing tours with an English speaking guide and see the main places of interest 3 1/2 hours. Then you can go out on your own and do it all again knowing what you are doing and where you are going. Too much to see to describe, suggest you take a good guide book and read it on the plane
Lively Square. People seemed to be enjoying themselves and they were willing to share their happiness with others. The whole town speaks English very well and communication was never an issue
Just beautiful. I instantly fell in love with this square. We were there as they were prepping for Easter. Lovely square, in a lovely city!
Very nice place.. The tourist trap of Prague and it is indeed worth the visit. Very crowded and expensive so eat and drink 100m outside the centre for half the prices.

Touristy. But still love it!. Yes there are tour groups everywhere, and businesses and people trying to offer anything to tourists in order to get their money, but if you ignore this and look at the buildings, the space and feel the atmosphere of everybody enjoying themselves then it's good. I wouldn't really bother with the restaurants, from viewing several menus they looked pretty ordinary but very expensive (expected in the tourist centre). Visited this area back when Euro 2012 Football tournament was on and there was a great atmosphere.

Interesting but busy. The striking clock seems to be what people were here for. There are lots of bars and restaurants including an Irish bar and an English bar. Very crowded in the square. Street entertainment, which was amusing
Great at easter. We had a short break at easter. Lovely market with Czech food, drinks and artisan goods. Fantastic time of year.
History, sights & entertainment. The square around the clock was packed with bars, entertainers. Fun wandering on the small narrow winding streets.

Fabulous buildings. A really fabulous square surrounded by great houses and churches. Extremely crowded so be there early to see the square. Lots of tourist trap restaurants, but they´re OK anyway, just make sure you did order all the "courses" they put in front of you.

Great scenery & luxury brands shopping area. I love the ambience and beautiful old town. Area feel so much safer as compared to shopping in Paris. There are 2 rows of luxury brands i.e. LV, Fendi, Gucci, Dior, Ferragamo, Botega, Burberry etc which u may want to spend more time there as the service of all the sales staff are great n attentive n shopping here is so peaceful n quiet unlike the stressful shopping in Paris. Because Czech korno rate agst Eur is favorable now at abt 27.4 instead of 24-25 it used to, you can consider to pay cash in EUR to get bigger savings.
nice oldtown. I like old town because it is rich in history and the buildings have different styles. It is good to know the history of art so you can appreciate it.
Mesmerizing. Visited this during Easter time. Quite festive and beautiful with little easter shops teeming all over. :D

If you are in Prague, do not miss the Old Town Square. I visited Old Town Square in July 2013 with friends. To get there, take the metro to Staromestska.At the Old Town Square, it is common to find many temporary market stalls. I was attracted to the stalls selling hand-crafted products. The shops in Prague that were offering Bohemia Crystal and Slavonic Art had caught my eyes when I was at the Old Town Square. Although I did not buy any, I had a wonderful visual feast of beautiful hand-crafted art when I visited the Old Town Square admiring what the many shops and market stalls had to offer.It was possibly difficult to miss the Powder Tower which is one of the original 13 city gates in Old Town, Prague. This majestic tower is of Gothic design, as best as I could recall.While visiting the Old Town Square, make a visit to the Astronomical Clock Tower. The view from the viewing gallery of the Astronomical Clock Tower was amazing. Thankfully, there are modern lift facilities to take visitors up to the viewing gallery. Of course, for the adventurous, walk up via the stairs. There is an admission fee to get up to the viewing gallery of the Clock Tower. Students (including international students) can enjoy concession, so please bring along your student passes.Along the streets of Prauge's Old Town Square, it was common to find horses on the streets to ride on. Enjoy the old time charm of riding on horse carriages.In short, you must visit the Old Town Square. No visit to Prague will be complete without visiting the Old Town Square.

Essentially European. The Staromestske namesti is a beautiful place. The first foray into another European square is always enthralling and Prague was no different. We walked across Karluv Most (Charles Bridge) and then meandered our way through the cobbled and narrowed streets leading into the square. It was busy upon our arrival at 9pm but we later realized this was the case on the hour every hour for the setting in motion of the four figures of the Astronomical Clock (which is an astounding sight in its own right). During our stay we enjoyed a few Pilsner Urquells in the square and we always found it a pleasant place to be. Keep a pocket map handy as it easy to find yourself lost, particularly at night time. And if I had one tip for the tourist authorities of Prague it would be to ban the Segway's from the Staromestske namesti, they simply do not fit with the rich cultural and historic vibe of the area.
Relaxing. Pick a nice day and just watch the world go by we spent a couple of hours here in the sun just watching people and relaxing its a lovely place to be.

A must-see. Being one of the absolute must-sees in Prague, it is inevitable not to pass through this at least once when wandering the city.The atmosphere is nice although often almost too crowded to fully appreciate. To top off the feeling of crowdiness the space is often loaded with extravaganzas that take up lots os space leaving only rather narrow iles to pass through.It is too beautiful not to appreciate though.
Good. Beautiful like everything in Prague, but this time was too many people. Was also easter trades where you could tried traditional food, buy suvenirs and listen to music!

Surely the most beautiful square in the world... Beautiful buildings from a different period of history all next door to one another so as you glance around you seem to see the history of architecture in just one square. Nice but more expensive, due to location, cafe's, bars & restaurants all around too plus the castle that allegedly Walt Disney based Disneylands castle on make it a spectacular feast for the eyes.

Lovely but crowded. The square is a picturesque place that looks much better in the morning than during the day with all the people and the stands (there was an Easter market while we were there). For a truly memorable experience, make sure you get there early.

Loved the small shops.. No need to say that this is the main square of the city. The castle and towers are just amazing! But even more than that impressed me the small food shops there. The deserts they sell are just delicious!

Get there early if you want to see the clock perform. In the middle of April it was packed with tourists, so if you want a good advantage point to see the clock perform on the hour, you need to get there well before.

Easter in prague. Most crowded but worth it. Best seen at 9 or 10am. Definitely do the clock tower. Only venue with 2 elevators- no climbing for the great views! (Petrin tower and powder towers all require major stair climbs)
Beautiful!. The old town square in Prague is extremely beautiful, full of charm,the astronomical clock is absolutely amazing!

Enjoyed the beauty and energy of the Old Town Square. Old Town Square was decorated for the Easter Holidays with colorful ribbons adorning the trees, great restaurants as well as booths selling food, souvenirs and of course beer. Horse and buggy rides were also available fueling the energy and feel of an old market. The astronomical clock chimed on the hour and if you had the energy to climb the many steps, offered a wonderful view of the square. A great place to stop and enjoy before you go on to the beautiful Charles Bridge.

Stunning!. Beautiful! The architecture and buildings have been well maintained the Old Town Square. It can crowded with tourists though. I suggest visiting in the early morning to avoid the crowds. Lots of nice cafes i which you can sit and have a drink while people watching.
Plaza! Wonderfull. What an amazing place! If you are coming to Prague, you will definitely come here. Take your time, wonder around, have a coffee or a beer. It's wonderful.

"loved It". I was in awe of this city, turned out to be one of my favorites. I looked for out of the mainstream places & had great success. Little (I guess) local Beer Gardens & wonderful small places to enjoy the local food. Never got tired of watching the astronomical clock, a very unique timepiece.

Medieval to modern charm. During Easter time (April), Old town square is filled with small booths that sell food and easter-related items. So, when we visited, the square was basically bustling with this activity. It was quite charming although very crowded.
Perfect at Easter. It was lovely to share the local tradition at this time of year. Easter is very special in Prague. Everyone is out enjoying themselves...eating and drinking...

Pretty but very crowded. The square is a beautiful place and worthy of time. It is massively crowded however and most of the shops sell the same thing and the bars and restaurants identical to the next. The architecture is wonderful and worth plenty of attention along with their interesting history. Just beware the tour groups on segways!

Full of life and archedtcture. This can be VERY crowded with tourists and restaurants more expensive then other parts of Prague. We were there for the Easter Fair and it was full of fun, activity.
The astronomical clock makes a brief show and is fun to see.
hustle bustle. thousands of tourists many attractions cafes beers local junk food but yet original magnificent and authentic we passed by everyday we were in Prague never regreted it

The heart of Prague. We visited the Old Town Square during the Easter season and loved the Easter market that was set-up in Old Town Square. There were great stalls with beautiful hand-painted Easter eggs, plus loads of street vendors selling delicious Czech food. The square is a beautiful place to spend the afternoon, drinking beer and people watching.

Wish I had arrives 20 years ago. The fairy tale cathedral spires tower over this ancient square making you feel like you are an extra in a medieval Hollywood film. A spectacular spot but filled with tourists - it must have been incredible 20 years ago before the crowds and the Segways.

Great place to visit. I was in town during the Easter Markets at the Town Square. This was the hub of so much activity. Booths with souvenirs, various foods and drinks to try and activities. So much fun! Beautiful buildings everywhere you look.

Easter in Prague. The Old Town Square is alive and buzzing with market stalls, bohemian music, vaudeville dancers and tourists during Prague's busiest time of the year ..Easter. The mix of gothic and baroque architectural buildings which surround the Square are breath taking. Everyone is upbeat and the good weather is always a plus. Without a doubt a must see when staying in Prague!

THE HEART OF PRAQUE. The square that is always alive,day and night. Very crowded, as Praque has too many tourists during the year.Looks very beautiful with the colourful buildings,the churches,the Old Town City Hall, the cafe-restaurants and the Astronomical Clock that tourists wait the time that bells to see the show.I love seeing the hourse-carriages and i was lucky to enjoy a concert of classic music in this square.

Incredible. The architecture and history of the buildings is amazing. The view from astronomical clock is breathtaking. We enjoyed a drink at an outdoor cafe and loved the people watching. There were Easter markets in the square with wonderful crafts and food. You can't go to Prague and not spend some time in Old Town Square

Full of tourists but amazing . Now is April they had a small fair with typical food, souvenirs, street artists, everyday I would have to go there and stay for hour or two. Prague is so full of life, it's amazing the energy.

Great to be in the center of Prague. Our hotel was a short distance from Old Town Square which is always full of people waiting for the astronomical stock to chime. We never quite got to see the full show, but loved the hustle and bustle there. Also decent gift shops and reasonable meals. However Czech cooking is sometimes rather wierd

Amazing atmosphere!. Take some confortable walking shoes, because in Prague you have soo many beautiful places you should go! In Old Town Square you will find the best beer; even is expensive, you must taste it!

Crowdy but very nice. We visited Prague during the summer holiday. Old town square is very nice and mainly at night. On the top of the tower you can see nice panoramic views. On the square you can enjoy historical atmosphere with traditional czech beer.

right in the middle of everything. Can't miss this area...people watchers delight! and if you want to go anywhere in the prague area well you probably have to stroll thru this area. watching the astronomical clock it will put you right in this square area. Along with street performers, kids running about, coffee shops, souvenior stands, it's the typical touristy area.

A lovely place if it wouldn't so crowded in season. Probably the second nicest main market squares in Europe after Krakow's. Lovely buildings all around you and the scent of the old times is around you... being blown away sometimes by the ridiculous crowds that make it hard to walk by. After 2 days I've tried to avoid it as a meeting spot and/or destination point.
Go to the Square. The Old Town Square was set up for the Easter Market. It was beautifully decorated and full of cute shops and food booths. Try the Tredlnk and fire roasted ham (YUM).
Alot of souvenir shops . Nice square with alot of souvenir shops and restaurants around. The astronomywatch next to the square. Alot of existing small.shops.around in the small streets.
chilling all day or night. If you want to just watch the life go by, take a seat, enjoy a coffee or whatever and see everything pass you by. Day or night there's always something going on.

A place like no other.. The Old Town Square is one of the most highly-visited places in all of Prague in terms of tourists. It is an absolutely exceptional venue, but I would personally recommend visiting here in the early wake of the evening, when the place lights up and dawns upon you a majestic history incomparable to other parts of the world - and of course, to avoid the hundreds of tourists who make it impossible to move.

Lots of stalls during easter/christmas. If you are in Prague around Easter or Christmas you'll find it's full of very interesting traditional food and product stalls. These aren't tacky stalls looking to rip off tourists, but rather well priced authentic Czech cuisine/souvenirs at a reasonable price. The square itself is in a great location, and is essentially a must see for any tourist due to it's proximity to major sights and its central location.It's also a great place to meet friends at set times during the day as it's very easy to find.
Easter Market. The aroma of local cooking together with cultural music and dance shows, add to the historic setting of Prague Old Town in April.

A bit overdone. The Square is certainly busy. Vendors in booths are lots of same food or products. Krakow s much more diversified and authentic. It's a must see spot and interesting but just a little over done.
plenty to see and do,and sit and watch the world go bye. enjoy tram journeys are diffucult I need to sit due my back injury so we need to let trams go bye if seating was not available

A lot of people but a really nice place. We did visit the Square both in daytime and at night and it was always a lot of people there, also when raining. I loved looking at the astronomic clock ringing! We also took a guided bus tour from the square, just the next one coming up.
awesome. The people are friendly and the easter fair was amazing, but if you don't like crowds beware it is a very busy place.

Happening Square. Given that this is one of the top tourist attractions in Prague, you can imagine that it gets pretty crowded here. However, there are so many things to enjoy. There is music playing and dancing going on, you can join if you enjoy music. The Astronomical Clock is a wonder in itself. But the buildings that surround the square are equally interesting and beautiful. The statue of Jan Hus will grab your attention for quite sometime and makes you want to explore the area even more and know the history. There are a number of small cafes in and around the square where you can sit and enjoy a sandwich and cafe :)
Loved it. We stayed 4 nights right on the square. Loved the location. Fabulous base for walking around. Lots to see and do

Huge square, lovely buildings. Clock is interesting. Buildings are lovely (architecture). Some interesting if rather pricey shops. Didn't eat there as a bit pricey - went out of town centre and found lovely little restaurants.
A Fairy Tale. A magical place that will make you feel as if you're living a fairy tale. There a lot of nice cafes where you can sit enjoy a drink or indulge yourself with some fresh pasteries

Beautiful in Christmas time. I have visited it while on the Christmas break. It looked beautiful! The Christmas market was creating a warm atmosphere, also the Christmas tree was shining bright. It is always crowdy, however people were in a great mood - it's Christmas time!
Tourist nightmare. On one hand, it cannot be avoided, on the other, it's probably the most packed tourist attraction outside of St Peter's in Venice. Watch your pockets.

A beautiful square with unique buildings.. One of the most beautiful and unique town squares in the world. The magnificent buildings that surround the square along with the old city hall and astronomical clock with hourly moving figures makes this a can't miss experience. Having dinner outdoors at one of the restaurants on the square makes for a wonderful evening of good food a people watching. There are always different character entertainers on the square adding to the good times. Take an elevator to the top of the clock tower for a great view of the square and the surrounding areas of Prague.

A must stop, obviously. Depending on what is transpiring int he Square, this can be very enjoyable. Now, the square was full with vendors and performers, and food vendors; and so was full of action, fun and exitement. Enjoy!

Don't miss the clock!. The Old Town Square is lovely - surrounded by old buildings of different styles. Don't miss the astronomical clock on the Town Hall - just before the hour strikes there is a short display by a skeleton representing Death and 11 Apostles and St Paul appear at 2 doors above the clock - a spectacle not to be missed! There is usually some entertainment going on in the Square so look out for that too.

Christmas Markets Superb. The Old Town Square was magical, including the famous Astronomical Clock, but going during Christmas time makes it even more so with the amazing Christmas markets. After traveling Europe and sampling the markets in various places, the Old Town Square market is far and above my favourite, having both unique goods and lovely atmosphere. Even during the rest of the year, I'd highly recommend this place as a good spot to people-watch and soak up the atmosphere. I would highly recommend going to the top of the clock tower for some lovely views, but in my experience they're better during the day as little is lit up at night, so the views and photos weren't the best. The restaurants around the square are a bit touristy and expensive (as you might imagine), but one or two streets away will get you more authentic fare.

Good starting point to explore the old town. The square is similar to many others throughout Europe, but it does give you a good starting point for seeing some of Prague's main attractions. Lots of shops, cafes, restaurants, bars near the square and close enough to the river and bridges to head over to the castle.

Gorgeous. As an American kid I had visions of what old Europe looked like. When I saw old town square it fulfilled those fantasies. Look for the little details as well as the great views The Prague meridian, the crosses made from cobblestones and the back of old town hall that just ends where the rest of it was destroyed.

A must see in the center of Prague. When I refer to "the center" in Prague, this is the location I am referring to. A grand old and timeless square that must be seen at different times to be truely appreciated. Early in the morning you will find the square nearly empty which gives you a great opportunity for unobstructed photographs. In the middle of the day the square is packed with tourists from all over the world. You will hear every language EXCEPT Czech. :-) At night the lighting of the square and the surrounding areas is fascinating. You will also encounter many younger party animals at this time as well. It would be impossible to visit Prague and not visit here.
krakov or prague?. this square reminded me of krakov square (poland) and even had the bugler playing at the top of the tower every hour!!lots of entertainment super bars good food and great beer.

Excellent Way To See Prague. If you are looking for photo-ops, this is the place. It is convenient, safe and interesting. You can see many shops, historical sights. I tried a number of the local food specials. I enjoyed the hot wine, the sweet bread and the ham. I was able to see wonderful sights. I purchased a tour book and it helped understand what I was seeing. The square is safe; however, I was warned to be mindful of pickpockets. I grabbed souvenirs that were reasonably priced. I even got some wonderful chocolate. I enjoyed this and visited several times.
Amazing. Amazing city centre .. excellent for tourists .. loads to see and do .. and very safe day and night .. and lots of food and drink .. very clean

old town square prague. The whole area is quite picturesque. The Astronomical clock is a little overrated but still amazing from the 15th century. The shops and restaurants are fine. One does not have to spend a lot of time here. Mainly it is to see the square and the Charles bridge and history.

Beautiful in December!. Went there for the christmas markets in december. Beautiful buildings all around, especially the gothic tower and the astronomical clock. It was packed with christmas stalls which made it very festive. A lot of good snacks and drinks for a cold evening.
Go up the town hall tower. The square is lively and has a lot going on. We took a trip up the town hall tower, which was really good - a proper feat of engineering

A nice area!. We had a nice walk around old town square, the buildings were lovely, and the cafe we stopped at for lunch was nice. The main highlight is the astronomical clock, a beautiful piece of machinery.

Great!!. The square is great!, so much to see and photograph. It is full of charm and history with plenty of things to take pictures of. It is bustling with activity with plenty of street acts and food stalls to keep one entertained and fed. A tourist mecca so dont expect to be able to take a piccy without a strangers face in it lol.

sight seeing. the old town square has a few major sites to see, you have the astronimical clock and the cathedral to see, if you visit in december there is a big winter market with lots of different stalls
beautiful. lovely square, plenty of nice restaurants and bars, great atmosphere. Great place to go shopping aswell.

Know the local people + free tours. I went there and ate some typical food from Prague. There is a lot of free tours leaving from there. Join one of them to know more about the culture of the place! That city is amazing because of it's history, don't miss the tours and contribute to the guide at the end.
Charming. Great place to stop at a food stand or hear some local music. Thoroughly enjoyed the Square. Visit restaurants and shops.

Can't see Prague without it. Old Town Square is a beautiful, charming square in the heart of Old Prague. There are traditional food stands and souvenir stands along the edge of the square, and bands and singers are frequently putting on performances. It's a relaxing, fun place to check out.

Amazing and a pleasure to visit.. Old town square has everything you need, from the stunning views of the buildings (especially in the evenings) to the food and drink that's readily available. In the centre of the square there's always some form of live entertainment which compliments the surroundings.
Interesting Sights, Street Vendors and Hidden Bars!. Lots of activity all over, some brilliant food and beer samples from street vendors, loads of hdden pubs and bars. Lovely atmosphere.

Unique in the world. What fun! Very crowded, but the figures are high enough that you don't have to worry about your view being blocked. Other reviews have covered everything, so it's hard to add something new. A must see.

Our favourite place in Prague. We visited Prague on a 3 night city break and covered the whole city and it's attractions in that time. Overall this was our favourite place and perfect for sitting down with a drink watching the world go by. There are lots of musicians around too so always something to entertain you.

Old Town Hall Clock is a must see. You will have read the stories of the clock but watching it for real is amazing. Be there five minutes early to get a good spot as each hour is heaving. The food and drink stalls are excellent value and the food is really tasty and the architecture all round the square is really interesting. Even if you are on the booziest stag or hen do, make sure you see the clock.

Absolutely Amazing. As soon as you walk into this square the sight and sounds just blow you away.From the churches and architecture to the sight and sounds of street artists and entertainers.Which ever way you turn, something is going on.It gets even better after dark when everything is lit up.The only downside is the stalls selling food and drink.They are not cheap and really are a rip off.
A Great place for walk around !!!. I have been there 3 time on March,It was very beautiful to see the clock moving, at the moment not high season but careful for your bag.. Please !!!

Takes you back in time. This square really takes you back in time and is very picturesque. If you time it right the clock does
a nice show and is very beautiful.
When i was there there were people metal working and making allsorts of little one off ornaments.

Nice spot. A great place for a glass of wine & listening to the street performers. Be cautious when purchasing food from the stalls, if they know you are a tourist, they will try to rip you off. Not cheap. Waiters will pressure you for a large tip.

Gorgeous buildings, crowded as can be!. We've been staying quite close to this square. It has lovely old buildings, has a unique feel. It's ridiculously crowded, although it's my understanding that it is not even high season at the moment. Nevertheless, worth a visit.
lots of things going off. a lot of student trips when we were there Sunday to Thursday. would still go at this time if you want it to be a bit quieter

Apsolutly amazing. Arived in prague yesterday and went to the old town square at 11pm. Everything was lite up and looked great. People were waiting for the clock to go off ect. Went there this morning and the place is picture perfect. So much to see 360degrees. Would really recomend going up the tower. Smashing views of prague from here and it shows the detail in the oldtown. Had a fab afternoon havin beers and local food in the sun. Plus its a great point to hook up onto some excersions
Charming. This square is so charming and lovely. We took in the site, enjoyed the squares street performers, and ate some delicious and authentic Czech cuisine. A must if you are in the city.

Outstanding Hotel with restaurant. Tremendous location and magnificent architecture. This is what a legacy site should look like! Good-looking frontages on the buildings opposite the square make it hard to have a preferred view - it's all lovely. Sure, you'll pay a bit more for snacks and diet in the bars and restaurants on the square, but it’s a abundant place to sit and take a cocktail and a plate of honest Czech cookery.
Lovely square with lots going on. Huge cobbled space with interesting baroque buildings surrounding. Lots of restaurants and some food stalls. Lots of impromptu acts to enjoy.

Loved it. there is so much thing to love in Prague and this is definatly one of them. i loved walking around in here and the feel that gives you. Go there during the summer time and it would be a great vibrant place to be
Amazing site. old world scene amazing architecture and lots to take in wonderful tourist spot. Very busy watch your purse I believe bad for pick pockets

Delightful. You feel as if you could be in a fairytale illustration! Definitely visit in the evening too, when everything is floodlit. If you walk down the left side of Tyn Church there is a courtyard with lovely shops and a delightful little cafe in the corner which was perfect for lunch.

The Heart of Old Town. Old Town Square with the monument to Jan Hus in the middle is surrounded by beautiful old houses of different architectural styles. It's a real pleasure to see all the variety of decorations on the buildings, listen to the stories about the events happening at this very place long, long ago, enjoy the music performed by street musicians and even dancing for a while. But the main attraction for most tourists is the astronomical clock. It's a fun especially for children. Unfortunately we didn't have enough time to climb the tower above the clock and visit Tyn Church. So now we're thinking about going there again...

Danger in paradise. I was in awe of the buildings and completely living the moment. Enjoyed some local ham specialty and washed it down with a beer, as musicians were playing, artists were displaying their wares, and scores of tourists were strolling about. I fell in love with a painting and realized that they wouldn't take anything other than the local currency. So I went to an exchange place, and a tout told me that he would give me 2,100 of local currency for USD, which was better than the 1,800 at the exchange place. I'm embarrassed to admit it, but I gave this lowlife my money, and he gave me 2,100 units of currency. I happily went back to the artist to buy the painting, and when I gave them the money, the artist told me it was BELARUSSIAN currency -- not accepted in Prague. A quick google search showed that this money is worth $.20 of $1 USD. Be forewarned and don't make the same dumb mistake as me!
Beautiful buildings. Beautiful old buildings in the square. There was also a jazz band playing one day, was lovely sitting in the square listening to the music surrounded with lovely buildings

Nice buzz, lovely buildings, shame about the clock. The Old Town Square is very nice. There are plenty of restaurants and bars around, and the buildings are lovely.Recommend the viewing tower above the astronomical clock - we went up early Sunday morning and it was empty and the views amazing. This was our first morning and it took our breath away.We did hang around for the astronomical clock to go into action, but really it isn't worth it - whilst it is clearly very clever (and to be lauded as it is so old) the odd shaking puppet head and revolving busts were not spectacular.

Xmas markets. We were very lucky that the xmas markets was still running in January. Magical… the christmas tree is the biggest and the most beautiful I have ever seen. The food was fantastic, so much atmosphere. The old town square itself is pretty cool!
Lovely architecture. Certainly worth fighting the crowds for at least one walk-through to see the great architecture and the Astronomical Clock. Better to eat/shop a couple of blocks off the square.
awesome. the most amazing square i think i have seen totally just watch where you eat and drink you would be better going away from squre for drink and food

Full of Activity. We found you tend to go through the square more than once if walking around Prague day and night. It is very big and full of activity, buskers, various stalls selling things, food, and stages with events a lot happening which was good. The whole perimeter is full of shops, restaurants bars and hotels, The Astronomical Clock and Church, it was busy when we were here, it must be mad in the height of season.We did not eat or drink in the square; it is overpriced and not as good as the back streets.Worth a walk aroundJ & M

Old Town Square. lovely place to just sit and watch, with plenty or restaurants and coffee shops to relax in. Various forms of entertainment going on in the square with bands, musicians etc. recommend Caffreys irish bar for a drink or food and nightly entertainment at weekends. The Astronomical Clock draws a large crowd on the hour every hour.

Old Town Square. The square has a great vibe to it--though I,d hate to be in there in high season. Lots of buskers and entertainers. In the square is the famous church with the eerie fairy tale spires and the famous astronomincal clock. People have said that the ringing event every hr is not spectacular--but I loved watching the parade of the saints and the look of the clock itself. It chimes in the hr until 22h00.

So much to do. Best thing about it was the parrot man, pay for pictures with parrots. Can't complain :) Also there were plenty of restaurants, easy to find wifi, helpful people to show you around and lots of things to do.

The place to start. This is a special and beautiful place. There are special squares in Europe; this is one of the those. For travelers who like to know what to do before arriving to your destination, you should know this is the place to start. From here you can get to every other attraction easily and this square is a main attraction by itself. Here you will find food, tours and everything you see is nice. Each time go in a different direction and get lost in the small streets around the square.
A must see. This is one of the places that you must see and visit while in Prague, it is better if you get there on the right time.

Bustling with culture. I stood in the Old Town Square one afternoon listening to the lively music, watching bubble blowers and eating traditional sweets. I really got a feel for Prague in this square and found it absolutely charming! I would also recommend a visit at night as it's breathtaking all lit up. Be careful for overpriced restaurants though!

Fantastic atmosphere. A great place to spend some time, nice atmosphere and some fun entertainers in the square. Word of warning, if you want a few pints, avoid bars around here, they charge around 90-120CZK (£3-4 GBP) for a beer, compared to 20-40CZK (approx £0.70-£1.30 GBP) elsewhere in the city.
Fabulous architecture. Visited Prague in February which was perfect for visiting all these major tourist sites, no crowds and very lucky with mild weather. Plus everywhere was so clean....no litter!

Beautiful at night. Great place to walk around with some fantastic restaurants which aren't that pricey. Some beautiful architecture. Only thing that is slightly irritating is the tacky thai massage place.

Not to be missed!. Beautiful heart of the city. Breathtaking view with all the art and architecture. Among many churches, tourists may find the Prague Astronomical Clock on this square, while the tower at the Old Town Hall offers a panoramic view of Old Town shop. An art museum of the Czech National Gallery is located in Kinský Palace.

The Heart Of Prague. I love the Old Town Square. It's just a real draw in the city and wherever we went, we always enjoyed heading back here. I just found myself smiling when entering the square and soaking up the ambience and seeing the buildings and enjoying the smells of cooking ham and trdnik sweet bread.The square is always busy, day & night. Stunning sight.
Walking. Loved it great for a wander and to have Old Prague ham and hot wine. People watching with a hot chocolate
One of the most importantes place to see. Very good to see the clock and tower! The "cuco" clock is a must see for all the tourists who visit Prague. Crowd and people from everywhere!
Beautiful at night. Beautiful sight at night with special lights! It is quite crowded during the summer and lots of young people hang out there drinking and chating.

Full of Charm. Just brilliant, almost like the town square in Chitty Chitty bang bang!A great mix of old and new buildings,lots of museums,churches and the modern stores such as Marks & Spencer and Debenhams!
we were lucky. Visited in february , we were lucky as was sunny and no some people.Temperature was around 9º ,so sometimes hot when we visited some interesting points

A brief visit is all you really need. So it's a classic - there's no way you will go to Prague and not walk to the old town square and see the astronomical clock. Catch it when the clock strikes to see the movement, but once you've seen it... that's kind of it. There's heaps of restaurants and shops surrounding, but as you would expect for a prime location prices are at a premium. Really 10 minutes and a couple of photos and I was done.
Nice square - very busy. Beautiful buildings but very very busy, most of the time. Many restaurants and shops on the spot. Worth the visit.

Beautiful. Beautiful old square will lovely buildings and a trip up the tower is a must ( there is a lift! ) plenty of restaurants and bars and a lovely place to watch the world go by, especially on a sunny day or warm evening.
A life is here!. Street performers, street food, tourists and photo opportunities. We had great street food here - cheap filling and very tasty - perfect on a starry Prague night.

Overwhelmingly Beautiful. This was our first stop for sight seeing in Prague. Being surrounded by all of the beautiful buildings was almost overwhelming. We loved just grabbing a drink in the middle of the square at one of the outside restaurants and admiring the views of the churches and the clock tower. The food was okay here but way overpriced.. but it was nice just being able to sit and admire everything.

It's buzzin'!. The Town Hall displaying the Astronomical Clock is an interesting site. Especially because you will then find yourself in Old Town Square, with shops and churches and food vendors and restaurants. Lots of action, a very busy place, where street performers abound, and you can indulge in an old fashioned carriage ride to complete the feel of stepping back in time.  We visited the Square several times during our stay. Crowds vary depending on time of day, but there's always lots of action. Very entertaining to people watch there! And our favorite restaurant in all of Prague was just one block off the square.

Not the best square. Not the best square in a capital city, the clock looks fab but is a bit under whelming.and gets very busy even in February. the surrounding area is definitely worth an explore with some great bars.

Wonderful square in a wonderful city. I think this square is probably one of the most beautiful places in the whole world. Amazing architecture, buildings in different colors and from different ages, shops, restaurants, pubs... Maybe a bit too many people trying to sell you something, but that's the same thing everywhere... Anyway, I loved it.

February visit. This is an interesting square with wonderful buildings,best seen early in morning when less tourists are about. The astronomical clock is impressive to look at but the hourly performance of figures is rather underwhelming ! There are also toilets here which I found useful.
Nice place to see. You can check out the Astronomical clock and climb on top of the tower for a nominal fee, its the tallest building around so you really get to see the entire Old town.

Best in the world. Completely breathtaking. It's like being in all of Europe at once. Marvelous architecture. The variety of performers, tours available, and shopping is just perfect. Be careful of your belongings, pickpockets abound.
Prague Visit for friends birthday. Everywhere you turn in Prague you are confronted by beautiful buildings, details and reliefs. The Old Square is very touristy, but equally as beautiful.

best part of the city. When you visit Prague, always keep one afternoon and evening for old town square of this beautiful city. In the evening there is always some music and you can enjoy food there. there is lot of rush but you will enjoy the place, this is a guarantee, but only thing do not be in hurry, relax and enjoy.
very nice. It is a nice experience to walk around or just sit and observe people and the nice buildings all around.
Everything you'd expect..... Fantastic atmosphere, great time...(Astronomical clock)....plenty of entertainment. Loads of bars & restaurants to choose from.
People watching. Great place for people watching and some lovely food stalls. We often wondered through the Square and would sit with a hot wine and chill for a bit.
Busy but interesting. As in most cities this square is the heart of Prague busy,bustling and interesting. A good place to wander grab a drink and people watch
Very good meal. Excellent meal, great service, reasonably priced. We actually went back to eat there again, it was that good. Menu, well explained & you know its good when the locals eat there too.
Beautiful old buiidings. This is the nicest part of Prague which is itself probably the prettiest and most photogenic city in Europe.

Amazing history and vibe. Lots written so I won't double down....BUT be sure to catch the cool clock on the hour as the sun sets...trumpet player rings it in from on high,lights coming on, awesome New Years like feel! Good hot cocoa from street vendors with bad attitudes! Kids loved the trumpeter.
Must see. Wow. We keep coming back. It is beauty at day and night. At morning, we went up and view was gorgeous.

Lovely old square. We passed through the Old Town Square many times during our four days in Prague. Every time we were there, I was amazed at the old buildings surrounding the square and just how well everything has been preserved. The remaining section of the old city hall (attached to the side of the astronomical clock tower, the rest was destroyed in the bombing during WWII) is fascinating and testament to the dedication of the people of Prague, especially given what they have had to deal with over their history. I prefer the square later at night, when the buildings are lit up and there are a few less people around. A must-see while in Prague and one of the nicest squares I've seen anywhere in Europe.

Trdelnik, Roasted Pig and Beer. Walking around the city Center and Old town of Prague, I was located in Bavaria very close and visited it around 15 times in the past years. The Main Square and its romantic horsesrides and little Biergarden. The Churches but also wonderful houses and colors offers the chance to anyone to try a slice of roasted Pig with a fresh Beer and or the famous "Trdelnik" pastry.

A 'Must Do' visit. Fabulous location, and glorious architecture. This is what a heritage site should look like! Beautiful facades on the buildings facing the square make it difficult to have a favourite view - it's all lovely. Sure, you'll pay a bit more for drinks and food in the bars and restaurants on the square, but its a great place to sit and take a beer and a plate of genuine Czech cuisine.

One of our favourites in Europe. Before we visited Prague, we knew nothing about it apart from it had a giant astronomical clock. The old town square is just buzzing with life. We were there in the Christmas period - highly recommend as to see the christmas markets! The astronomical clock was amazing and does a little show every hour :-) definitely one of our favourite places in all our Europe travels, cannot wait to return!

My Favorite Place in the world!. You must see! Sitting at a cafe, drinking cappuccino in Old town Square is truly my favorite place to be. You won't regret! The vendors that are there in the evening are great, I wasn't a fan of the hot wine but the nutella crepes are amazing!
Great for pics. Lovely, as alwAys , watch your pockets when it's busy? Lots of places to have a drink and something to eat
Like a little fairytale city. Lived sitting in the square under heat lamps sipping wine under the stars while it froze outside. The architecture is stunning in every direction.
weekend away. Had an amazing time here in January.with family & friends its a lovely busy place where you can sit & people watch but still have the charm of the place right there.

Walk around, see the sites. The Old Town square is a great place both during the day and also in the evenings. The square is always busy - even at 11pm at night but full of interesting buildings, restaurants and lots to see and do. We just really enjoyed the general atmosphere and ate out by the square a few times during our stay.
Nice. Nice atmosphere here with lots of singers and acts around, good vibe with outdoor coffee shops etc. good place to take photos.
Best in warmer months or for Christmas!. It is a beautiful, large square usually speckled with performers, food stands and souvenirs. The Astronomical Clock is located here.
Nice historical place. An open square, nice historical buildings. Nice clock. Be aware of pickpockers, because it can be very crouded!
stunning. the old town square is beautiful, especially at night time when its all lit up. there is restaurants and cafes around it so you will never be short of somewhere to eat

Perfect. We all know you are going there so have a great time and enjoy everything prague has to offer. Avoid the blacklight theatre that is located as you exit charles bridge. 23 QUID A TICKET. Avoid, My only qualm in Prague. Cannot get anymore helpful than that can you :)

A Visual Feast. Prague's Old Town Square is one of the more beautiful that I've seen in Europe. The square is brimming with color from the beautiful buildings that surround it, some painted with decorative images. Here you'll find the famous Astronomical Clock, a must see, the Gothic Týn and Baroque St. Nicholas Churches and Kinský Palace, which contains an art museum. The square has many outdoor cafes and makes for a nice spot to take a break for lunch or dinner. In addition to the restaurants and shops, you'll also find a variety of street entertainers, horse drawn carriages and the Jan Hus monument. This is a great place to spend part of your day.

Definitely One of Europe's Best Squares!. A square that has the combination of attractions in stunning baroque and gothic architecture, Prague's Old Town Square is definitely one of Europe's most beautiful squares. Climb to the top of the Astronomical Clock Tower either at dusk or mid morning via an interesting elevator and enjoy the breathtaking sceneries of one of the most preserved cities in Europe. At night, just standing in the middle of the square or having beer in one of the surrounding bars, enjoying the view of the gothic Tyn Cathedral will bring you back into medieval period.

Beautiful. Reading Tripadvisor can be a weird thing. Lots of the time I've been somewhat baffled at people's reviews 'aaargh, the waiter brought bread and then it was added to the bill!!!!!!'. Things are done differently in other countries, so enjoy/relish it, is my take on travel.However, I did stumble upon a list of 'Prague warnings', including a bit about pickpocketing scams etc, so when my girlfriend stopped to look at a map, and we were approached by a shaven headed guy who tried to engage us in conversation, while his friend sort of walked behind us, I remembered what I had read, and started chomping like a mad dog to put him off. He did attempt to say 'want to change some money?' to my girlfriend, but I think he knew it was a lost cause, and we all had a bit of a laugh.In this case I was quite glad to read that hanging around looking like a tourist might lead sketchy fella's to see you as an easy target, and it worked out very well that I was able to be surreal enough to not be seen as an easy target ;)
