A Lovely Ambiance. IF you have been to most old European cities you have seen a great deal of squares. Most squares are similar in architecture and wares and goods. What makes Squares so important is that each one is a fine insight into that cities character, history and soul. Old Town Square is one of the more unique squares in that it is reminiscent of a fairy tale much like those found in Brussels or Munich. Furthermore the musicians’ playing classical in the streets is very unique and shows the Czech’s love of classical music. I am told that this is a result of the lack of music options during the Communist days. Regardless, you cannot avoid Old Town Square and there is no reason to want to so make sure to take it all in.

Great for people watching and live music. We wandered around the square several times during our visit and there are some nice cafes and bars around the outside and during the late afternoon local and perhaps visiting groups of musicians start to perform with a mix of pop, jazz and brass band with the usual optional collections and DVD sales.We went in winter and expect it is a lot busier in the main summer season, bt we had fun.

The place to visit. Wow what a fab place! Centrally located near to most of the hotels is the old town square! Lovely restaurants surround the centre where the famous clock is located. When walking back through the square from the Hard Rock Cafe about 10pm, the atmosphere was buzzing! People stood around the clock waiting for it to chime, singers and other acts in the main square.I felt safe here as well which I think is really important. It's not very crowded here so you don't take the risk with pick pocketers!
Buzzing. Loved Old Town Square - the buildings, the bars, the food, the entertainment in the square - everything!
Prague New Year. A beautiful old square which over Xmas and New Year hosts a market - for food, drink and gifts; a huge tree and spectacular lighting of the surrounding buildings. Must not be missed.
Nice place. Nice buildings to look at and plenty of restaurants - not that we ate in any as there are sooooo many good restaurants tucked away rather than the tourist trap of Old Town Square

Wow. Our 1st time to Prague & definitely not our last. We went on Kgb deal flights & b+b £139 local flight also. Our accomodation was 15min tram ride from Old Square, it was great to experience the local transport system. It was such good value. 124 chez krona approx 75pence one way. Our accommodation was rated 4☆ but by uk standards probably 2-3 but more than adequate for 3 night break.

Top of your ''must see'' list. From the hourly show on the Astronomical Clock with the crowds of tourists and the sound of the trumpeter to the ringing of the church bells, this has to be top of your list of things to see in Prague. When J and I visited, there was a jazz band playing live music in the square. Amazing by day and night, when photogaphy is something of a challenge! You should have an ascent to the top of the tower on your ''to do'' list. It costs CZK 100 and there are two lifts to the top where you can get a decent picture of the church with its twin towers. Views across the rooftops in all directions. The walkway around the top is narrow and it takes time to squeeze through but it is worthwhile.

This is a must see. You cannot go to Prague without visiting The Old Square. Watch the figures parade on the Town Hall Clock Tower at the hour. The Astronomical Clock is wonderful.A trip up to the top gives you a spectacular view 360 deg over the city.Luckily next door was a photographic exhibition about the time during the revolution which was very moving and educational about the history and bravery of the Czech people.The atmosphere was great- (be careful of pickpockets though)

Most Vibrant Place in Prague. The square is full of monuments including the astronomical clock, Jan Hus memorial, Old town hall among others. The square is always full of visitors who throng the square in particular to watch the astronomical clock show.there are eating joints and numerous places to try the local cuisine as well. Many restaurants offering a variety of cuisines are located close by.Super place!! :)
very nice place. Nice place, very beautifull with a very nice background! And it's just the most important place of Prague with the watches. and the church!

Beautiful scenary!. Prague is a very walkable city. Friends and I were staying at the Charles Bridge and could easily walk over to the Old Town Square. The lively outdoor performances and dining adds to the fun atmosphere. The architecture is something to see. Beautiful place to visit while in Prague.
Amazing!. The astronomical clock, the buildings, the Jazz band playing all come together to create a lovely atmosphere where you are aurrounded by such beauty.

The Heart of Prague. As the name Old Town Square suggests, this is the place where you get a glimpse of various pieces of Prague old history - Jan Hus memorial, the clock, cathedrals, jewish quarters etc etc. Plus the modern days stuff like Starbucks, pubs/restaurants. You get a different ambiance visiting it at nite. Not to be missed to feel the beat of Prague both day and nite.

Beautiful!!. Brilliant place to sit down and be surrounded with all of the attractions ! can grab a glass of hot vine which they sell on the street while waiting for the Astronomical clock show :) However, I would highly advice not to eat in the bars around as the prices are really high and the food is very truistic !!!

the place to get the best mulled wine!!!. We spent an afternoon moseying around here, alot of museums etc off the side streets, plenty of shops etc. best thing though is the mulled wine you can get from the Italian place on the corner beside the clock! The best and possibly among the cheapest in Prague. We made the trek over twice just for that alone!!
Love these old areas. It is great to see the old shops and narrow streets. The square has a big Christmas market so it adds to the fun

Beautiful, Beautiful, Beautiful. Beautiful, Beautiful, Beautiful this the best description for this square.many place to dine,a large clock ,hangs hourly with load shouts of crowded people.Go to the top of the clock and talk with the young trumpeter.

Historical square in prague. The square is where you can see different people from diff countries walking around. The square also has the astronomical clock that looks beautiful, every hour u can see people gathering to watch the clock sound, and all the mechanism and statues come to life. Very cool.

Overcrowded, but a must visit. Although is always full of visitors, the excellent surroundings (especially the astronomical clock) , makes a visit to this square almost obligatory. You must find a nice corner to stay and enjoy the view a little far from the many visitors. There are some shops and restaurants, but i think that are a little expensive, so walking some meters away you can find beautiful and cheaper ones. From here you can access most places of the old city just by walking.

Marvellous!. The Staromestky square was just full of people day and night including performers presenting different kinds of exotic and traditional plays, dances and music. I really admired the old clock tower from where you could get a view of almost all the Old Prague.
The Heart of Old Town. Historically significant in any era, we especially enjoyed learning about the May 8, 1945 uprising by brave Czech resisters.

Prague must-see. While it is a sprawling city with many interesting areas, you haven't been to Prague if you haven't been to the Staromestske namesti. You have easy access to several of the museums from here, such as the Mucha Museum, Church of St. Margaret Upon Tyne, the Sex Machine Museum, the tower and the astronomical clock, as well as many nice shops and restaurants. It is easy to walk to a few metro stops from here, as well as the Jewish Cemetery, Museum of Torture, Charles Bridge, etc. And lucky you if there is a holiday coming up because there will be a festival in the square!
beautiful. Wonderful place to visit, so picturesque! Had a wonderful time visiting this area each day of our stay

Worth a wander around. If you've been stuck and lost in the old town area then this has some nice open spaces, lots going on and a great feel for some of the old school communal gathering areas of prague. A beautiful square with lots on offering from food to historical viewing

One of Europe's Great Squares!. How ever many times you see this square, it is still a lovely place. However, it seems to be ever more crowded (even during the winter months now) and you need to find a space on the edges to actually enjoy the architecture without being trampled by the tour guides or run over by the Segways! The Astronomical Clock draws large crowds on the hour when you can see the windows open and the figures appear while Death rings his bell to remind you that we are all mortal! The Christmas Market is a shadow of its former self when in previous years, the stalls used to fill the square and overflow into the surrounding squares and streets - my photo from the Town Hall shows how small the market now is. Beware the pickpockets and watch the prices in the restaurants and cafes - they can be exorbitant in the square!

Yes. Your history dive may start here.. Prague IS one of the most beautiful and captivating cicites of Europe. This is where you would want to start exploring. On my first visit to Prague, I joined a guided tour of the centre (recommended! This saves you some time and effort at familiarisation), and this I gave as reference point for my friends on my last visit. There is an angle here for all interests... political, religious, science or merchant history; or just for the avid shopper or relaxed coffee- or beer enthusiast. Visiting in winter has the plus side of less visitors = more space, while visiting at more clement times offers the opportunity to sit outdoors to enjoy... if you find a table and chair! No matter when, history is still alive here.

One of the world's great people-watching sites. You could really spend the whole day here just watching people come and go, especially if you are able to grab a seat in one of the benches at the square. People from every part of the world are here, along with locals doing everything from having raucous beer parties sitting in circles on the ground to newly-weds getting photographed. The entertainment is constant: there are several street bands playing, clowns and street artistes doing their stuff, horse carriages clip-clopping around, and performers blowing giant soap bubbles. All around the square are some of Prague's biggest attractions: the world's oldest working astronomical clock, in front of which perhaps a couple of thousand tourists assemble on the hour, every hour, to watch the famous apostles and the skeleton figures to emerge; the gothic Church of Tyn with its distinctive pointy domes, one of Prague's most recognisable landmarks; the famous statue of Jan Hus, at whose base hundreds of tourists are permanently seated, watching the hustle and bustle of the square; the Czech national art museum, which was showing an Alfons Mucha selection when we visited; etc. There are several restaurants, and if they are full up (which they constantly are), you could go to the food stalls serving delicious hot sandwiches and kebabs. Just off the square is Pariszka, Prague's high street, where all the international fashion labels have stores. The din of the square is suddenly missing here, and the tree-lined avenue is pleasant to walk up and down on. In all, the square deserves at least a half day of your time in Prague, and it could easily be more if the weather is pleasant.

Could spend all day in the square. I can't say enough about The Old Town Square. There is over 900 years of architecture and history. Was there during Christmas. The Christmas markets were through out the square and just added to the atmosphere. The astronomical clock is breath taking.
great. Old town square is beautiful, if you love looking at beautiful architecture... you need to there.. little bars dotted all over the place

Enjoy a beautiful square. A beautiful square with amazing architecture on all sides.The buildings are very old, and have been shaped by differing influences through the years, which, to me, gives the square a unique quality, and, as you look around, you can really feel a sense of its' long history. Quite busy in January, lots of bustle in the restaurants, etc., around the square, and more segways than I have ever seen.We loved the square and went there constantly, using it as our hub to strike out for wherever we were going.The Astronomical Clock strikes on the hour, well worth seeing.At the square you can visit the Old Town Hall, the Astronomical Clock Tower and the gothic cathedral Church of Our Lady Before Tym (all reviewed separately).Also at the square, I can recommend the Staromestska restaurant (reviewed separately).

Lovely. The old town square in Prague was quite an experience - especially right before Christmas! The market is lovely selling beautiful decorations etc. there are masses of people though. We could literally just follow the crowd to find the old town square!
A bit crowded with tour folk and segway mayhem. A beautiful big square. Restaurants are more expensive here. Worth a look butvtake a free walking tour and find out more.

A Must-See in Prague. My family, with two teenagers, visited Prague for five days. This was one of their favorite sites. We took the free walking tour (highly recommend) and enjoyed this site even more knowing the history behind the building and the symbolism of everything on the front. It is easy to step back in time seeing and experiencing everything here.
Christmas markets. The Christmas markets in December were very busy but the atmosphere is great. Keep an eye out for the stall with the beautiful metal christmas tree decorations!

Picturesque square in Prague. Even in January there were performers and people walking about - the astronomical clock is a must see, there's an art gallery that had a fabulous Dali exhibit in January 14, and you really get that hundreds of years of history feel there
Beautiful square. Such a beautiful square with an amazing Christmas tree. Lots of stands with tasty food. The clock is also beautiful. The Old Town Square is a MUST on your Prague vacation!

Beautiful Prague. Beautiful!!!! It is like being back to medieval time. I joined a free walking tour and it was the starting point. It was a fantastic history class filled with great trivia which allowed us, from the group, to see such a fantastic city through a rich perspective. I have absolutely loved the place and totally recommend the free walking tour.
One of my all time favourites. This exceptional place has really exceptional mood, no matter when you come to. It's like a fairytale, romantic and peaceful. Definitely one of my all-time favourites!

Wonderful. Wonderful square. Being surrounded by beautiful buildings in a beautiful city make this square a great place to spend time. Go to one of the many food stalls and get yourself a sausage and beer, or a nice mulled wine and enjoy the atmosphere.

Full of Atmosphere. Visited at Christmas 2013, great atmosphere! The square was full of stalls selling handicrafts, Xmas trinkets and lots selling food and hot mulled wine. The pork sausages and cuts were especially tasty. In the evening the large Xmas tree is illuminated as are other parts and buildings within the square. Don't forget to watch the Old Town Clock [Astronomical Clock] as it chimes each hour. The Square is also the stage for many casual entertainers from musical troupes to escapologists.
super place to visit.. Lucky enough to find some of the stalls from the Christmas market still running.A great atmosphere.Quite a few street performers around. The architecture is amazing.

Fairytale surroundings. This is one of the most remarkable old city centres in Europe I highly recommend it. Some people might give me a beating about this comment but I rate Prague as more romantic than Paris!!

time stopped here. This is one of my favorite places in all of the world. It is amazing to see so many historic buildings and amazing architecture. The church is amazing as well as the clock. The paved streets and people dressed in traditional clothes makes this an amazing experience.

Goes without saying. That this is a MUST visit if you ever in Prague. Visited over December and the Christmas markets all around were very quint. The smell of baked goods, food and glue wine becomes very nostalgic. There was even a petting zoo in the middle. The lights at night were magical as well.

Must visit when in Prague.. It's possible to spend half a day at the old town square taking in the historic buildings and doing a bit of souvenir shopping. Also, a lot of other sights are within easy walking distance.

Great during Christmas. It was crowded, but with such joyful people at Christmas. There was great shopping and lots of good food to enjoy. I do not imagine there is much to fuss about when the market is gone.

Amazing Square. I was here alone and there was a little rain and I was expected to get clear and nice picture when I got here, I am just waiting at the hall and try to walk around this neighbourhood when I get back the sky was clear and the rains stop and yes I just realise that this Old Town Square is very amazing and beautiful circling with awesome building!

Another must see in prague. Beautiful city and atmosphere, but i hoped the tree will be a little bit bigger. Well, no wonder its smaller, i remember a guy telling us, that once the tree fell and broke a tourists neck.

unbelieavable. like from a fairy-tale...especially the cathedralwish there were not that many tourists...and could do without the heated outdoor restaurants...what a ecologically stupid idea...all over the world

The heartbeat of the city. The place to be for Christmas atmosphere! We hung out here on our recent trip to Prague and loved the enormous Christmas tree, the lights, the live music, the stalls, the mulled wine, the chestnuts, the hotdogs. There was a great buzz! If you don't want to spend any money you don't have to.

The Atmosphere of Prague. The town square is the hub of Prague life. Surrounded by great architecture and lots of ambiance most of the places you want to see in Prague are walkable from here. Night and day feel different but are both unique and enjoyable experiences. On your first visit to Prague, go to the square and plan your activities from there. Lots to eat, drink and shop to suit all tastes

Still Christmas market. Last weekend of the very nice illuminated Christmas market and a good and friendly atmosphere. Crowded and losts of stalls to eat adn drink , beware of the tourist trap : Ham and all other items are priced by the 100 gramms , very small written so just a piec of ham ends up for EUR 20 on the bill rest ok

One of the best places in Prague. Staroměstské náměstí is a real medieval tale. The only disadvantage of this place is a crowds of tourists (like me). However, it is better than the deserted streets, especially when there is cold and gray winter. Be sure to visit.

Practically crushed by crowds. It's a beautiful square, but virtually impossible to see and appreciate from the ground. I literally almost got swept up and carried away in a gigantic tour group. It's a bit better at night and actually quite beautiful in the light of the street lamps. It's easier to appreciate the entirely of the square from the top of the town hall tower.
Lovely place to visit.. This is famous for its astronomical clock which defies anyone to tell the time from it. At the end of December, there is much happening, all of it pleasant and safe.
Amazing. Great ambience , architecture and lots of churches , museums and restaurant options , a must when in Prague . Particularly liked the old cars offering city tours .

Beautiful town square, if you can overlook the merchants selling crappy trinkets. I would have loved to see this town square even 20-30 years ago, when it might have still held some allure. The crappy trinket peddlers and storefront merchants have all but ruined the tourist climate here, though, so even though I do recommend you see it for its cultural heritage, don't plan on spending a whole lot of time here, unless you WANT to spend time looking for garbage in the form of tourist trinkets.
The best place in old town. As I put it in my review of old town... This is one of the most beautiful squares in Europe. Christmas time just makes it better!

Fairy tale brought to reality. This old town made me feel like a little girl inside a fairy tale setting. Pretty much a real Disneyland.Prague became one of my favorite cities in europe because of this old town. I can sit all day in a cafe and just enjoy the view around me.The towers, the clock, the pastel colored buildings.. Everything just looks perfect!
Lovely place to spend an afternoon. A must for everyone visiting the city (can't be avoided really, everyone gravitates here!) Gorgeous buildings and history and lots to see/do.

Absolutely Enchanting. My husband and I stayed at hotel which was just half a block from the astronomical clock. This old town square is absolutely enchanting. When we rounded the corner and saw this beautiful square with its old medieval buildings, the fairytale like tower, the church towers and the tower where the astronomical clock is at, it took our breaths away. This is a truly beautiful square--you feel like you have walked into a fairytale. It is popping with life and people and there is always something going on here. There is are stalls that sell food and their Prague ham, which is on a spit, is truly delicious. This square has jewelry stores, souvenir shops, restaurants, etc. You can find everything here. At night, the square is alive with people walking around. This is a very lively square to be in. This is also a very central location to the other attractions in Prague.
Astronomical Clock. From the astronomical clock to the churches, to the little food stalls to buy Trdelnik (unsure if I spelled that right), this location is very quaint and beautiful !

Christmas market 2013. I have visited several Christmas markets in Europe and each city truly has its own unique character and flavor. The Christmas market in Old Town Square is magical. The sights, sounds, and smells were amazing. Be sure to sample Trdelník (pastry rolled in sugar) and hot Medovina (honey liquor). Large roasted hams on spits, sausages on rolls. The Christmas tree and the cathedrals at night. I was there on Saturday, which was pretty crowded, and also on Sunday, which was very pleasant. People were friendly and responded well to my attempts to speak a few words of Czech. Shopping was plentiful. Some items were obviously mass produced, but also possible to find hand-made items. There are also many unique shops around the market square that are not to be missed. Hand-made marionettes, chess sets, matryoshka dolls. The spirit of Christmas is truly alive in Prague.

Nice to look at - but busy. The Old Town Square has many interesting buildings, and you can watch the astronomical clock as many times as you like, but it gets very crowded and even at 10am was packed.

Nice to visit, just can't avoid the crowd. It's crazy, I've been here so many times, but never seen this place empty! Try to avoid the hourly crowd in front of the Astronomic Clock, it could be full of pickpockets too.These are almost every time food stands all around, but don't expect high quality... It's the same with coffee shops and restaurants with terraces on the square. For quality food, leave this place 200 m behind you in any directions. :)But as a real old square it is a must!

So much to see. Again the buildings are just amazing, we were warned about pick-pockets but we didn't have any problems. It was so full of people of every nationality, so much to see. Every type of restaurant as well.

Beautiful town square. I loved all the markets and horses, cobble streets just a beautiful small town feel.
Buy the street food it worth it!
Fun. Try the potato dishes and fried dough dessert. Yum. Stay away from the hot wine, gross unless you like that sort of thing- opt for the bier

The heart of the city. This is one of the busiest squares of the city with so many beautiful things to see. Head there if you get a chance.
Tip: most tours start here as it is a very central place.

Wonderful Architecture. This is a wonderful place to see amazing architecture that shows the development of Prague through the years and many wars it has endured. You will find unique shops, the expected tourist shops, as well as coffee shops (they have a Starbucks) as well as cafés where you can people watch. This is a great place to hang out for a couple of hours and grab some food before heading off to your next adventure in the city.

Christmas Charm. This square attracts so many people that it's difficult to believe one can actually enjoy being there, but it is really so! Probably because of the Christmas spirit, it was really friendly and pleasant to walk around all sights, take pictures and just enjoy the views!
The Place to visit. We like the dimensions and the beauty of all buildings around the square. As we came just before year end, the atmosphere was really magic!We disliked nothing!

Not to be missed!. i strongly suggest to visit this place twice, once during the day and once at night, it's different kind of beauty. There're many attractions, shops, restaurants and museums nearby.

Breathtaking. We arrived in Prague last in the afternoon, and after checking into our hotel, decided to stroll over to the Christmas market in the Old Town Square. After making our way through a few alleys and also being fully impressed with the surrounding buildings, we walked out of a tunnel and the majesty of the Old Town Square simply wow'd us. With the giant Christmas tree in the center of the square against the backdrop of the clocktower, cathedrals, and what looked like "castles" to us, the various booths selling traditional foods and trinkets (probably mostly for tourists), and the festive atmosphere of the crowd, it was simply joyful to be there. Over the 5 days we were in Prague, we would come to the Old Town Square pretty much every morning before we started the rest of the day, just to take in the view again, and each time it was just as fantastic as before. We also spend New Years Eve here, and it was amazing to watch fireworks from all around the square (though it does get a bit rowdy).
Christmas market. Very good Christmas market with good food at reasonable prices. Great atmosphere at this time of year.

Incredible buildings and great Christmas market. The Old Town Square is the highlight of Prague. Tyn Church at night is one of the most incredible sights imaginable. It looks like Darth Vader's winter home - you'll know what I mean when you see it! Go during the Christmas season for one of the best Christmas markets in Europe.

Great for people watching & old city charm.. We were lucky to have rented an apartment a few blocks from Old Town Square. Even though my husband & I dislike crowds, we returned to the busy Square and Christmas Market every day for a cup of hot wine, Czech food and... we actually "enjoyed" the crowd. The Christmas concerts, architecture, market, festive atmosphere, and friendly people made our holiday extra special.

lovely way to shop. the stalls are lovely and the smells are amazing. Always ask for a sample try. I personally didnt enjoy the sausages as they were toooooo spicey. So glad i didnt waste my money on the hot dogs and had the ham hock instead with the chestnuts. The Christmas Tree was enormous and every branch was covered with baubles and lights. We did visit during the day but also at night, I recommend night time the excitement is wonderful and adds to the spirit of Christmas.

Nice square specially during Christmas. On the Square there is a nice statue and well it's surrounded by some lovely buildings, but that you see in a lot of old towns. What made this square nice is that it had a lovely atmosphere due to the Christmas market!. We loved it staying out for far too long, despite the cold!. If you go to Prague, don't miss it, certainly not in December when there is the market.There are two churches there and then of course there is the old city hall with the clock!.Anyway, we liked it.

Good Christmas Market. We visited at Christmas time and toured the Christmas Market. There are stalls with most of hte usual Christmas offerrings along with specialist Crystal shops. Also do not miss that Clock Tower
The day before New Year 2014. Many people nice atmosphere and great food served by street vendors :) .... I enjoyed it .... will come back in spring too!
Quaint. Loads of eating places, great atmosphere, lovely Christmas lights and tree. The church is beautiful and the view from the tower is excellent.

Great place and a must visit!. Old Town Square is an amazing place and is definitely worth visiting with a lot of architecture and history in the area! The important landmarks one can see in this area are Old Town City Hall and its Tower, the legendary Astronomical Clock, Church of Our Lady before Tyn and Church of St. Nicholas!

Romantic. There was a Christmas market on the square. Quit romantic and full of nice odeurs, food, craftmanship, entertainment, etc. And in the middle a huge big Christmas tree with a lot of lights and decorations.

Probably the best square in the world!. We walked here from Charles Bridge specifically to see the famous astronomical clock and the hourly walk of the apostles show which is a must see even if, like us, you are not religious. The barque and gothic architectural styles of the buildings surrounding the square added to the atmosphere that makes Prague such a wonderful city.

Terrific!. This is definitely a place to see during the last week before Christmas. Snow or no snow - you can't help feeling the miracle and joy and hope there. The buildings are a worthy sight, and the narrow streets are lovely in summer, too, but the Christmas-tree, the lights and the festive market turn this place in a dream.

Christmas All Around!. I straight up burst into tears the second I walked into the Old Town Square this Christmas. It's so beautiful--a towering, twinkling tree, hot wine, and the smells of delicious Tredlnik baking just make it the most magical place.

People Watching. The Old Town Square is excellent for sitting sipping Lattes and beers and watching the performers and buskers in the centre. It is full of hustle and bustle and the chimes of the Astronomical Clock. An excellent place to people watch!!

Was quite simply stunning withthe Christmas markets. The entire square was set out with lovely Christmas market stalls with a plethora of lovely food and drinks available. Even though some stalls were offering the usual tourist nicnacks, it was still well done and tasteful. The fact that they run these markets up until the 8th Jan means you can also get a cheap break after the festive season but still enjoy the atmosphere.

Beautiful and crowded. The place is center of the whole place and most of the crowd here seems to be captivated by the clock tower which is a beautiful masterpiece and in fact so beautiful that the creator was blinded so as not to replicate his skill or outdo the one he did. There are so much to see and experience around this place from the beautiful Jan Hus Memorial to the Tyn Church and the many baroque styled buildings all around the square. The place also has a lot of street foods and souvenir shops around and being the center place always have some or the other activity attracting its crowd to here. I made it to here every day when I was in Prague. By the time I visited it was getting prepared itself for Christmas and lots of stalls and decorations were on its way to full bloom making this place a site to be in Prague.

christmas market. surrounded by the majesty of the old churches, halls and towers the smells of chestnuts, hog roasts and sausages cooking on their bbqs, street performers and musicians, all of this and one of the biggest christmas light displays lends to a magical experience for all ages and nationalities, fabulous !!

Best Christmas ever!. Loved the Christmas Markets!The smells,the decorations,the arts and crafts,the crowds!Felt like a wonderland.Just walk and explore every corner of this wonderful city.Try all the street food,you won't be disappointed!

Christmas spirit. The square at Christmas is really beautiful, the tree is the most magical I have seen anywhere. The market had a lot more food and drink stalls this year but I don't mind that. The place is always buzzing and crowded, especially near the hour when the clock strikes. Cafés and restaurants in such places often cost more but these are still reasonable when compared with similar squares in other countries. I guess I should try to come here when it's not Christmas, but for seasonal atmosphere it's hard to beat.

This is where all the magic happens!. A must see while in this beautiful city. The restaurants here are pretty good as well. This is where the astronomical clock is located. They blinded the creator of this clock, so he could never again create something so beautiful. There is always something happening here. Plenty of stuff to see!

Great place to people watch. The Old Town Square is very beautiful. If the old buildings could talk they sure would tell an interesting story. It is also a great place to people watch or to have eat a snack from one of the street vendors. We went here several times during our visit to Prague and enjoyed it every time.

Beautiful Christmas spectacle. We were in Prague for five nights and each night, found ourselves back in the Square to sightsee, people watch, get a treat and just enjoy the whole amazing atmosphere. Really magical place.

Nice Christmas Atmosphere. We visited in December for the Christmas markets and enjoyed ourselves here. Very pretty at night with all the stalls and buildings lit up as well as the Christmas trees. Some beautiful old buildings surround the square and there are lots of places to eat. Lots of stalls to the Christmas market although a lot of them were selling typical tourist tat like lighters and fridge magnets. Some stalls were selling more traditional christmas orientated products and decorations, plus hot wine and other drinks and foods. Worth a visit but it isnt a patch on the proper Christmas markets that you will find in Germany.

Weekend Break. The old town square in December has lots of Christmas stalls and the tree is always a delight to look at. There are plenty of places to eat and drink around the square but generally slighty more expensive because of where they are. It also has the clock tower which is accessible by lift and stairs right to the top and the views over the rooftops of Prague are spectacular. The clock also chimes on the hour and is a great attraction for visitors and is usually very busy at this time.

Good experience. There was a great atmosphere in the Old Town Square. Great mulled wine and ham to be eat as you go around the square. Live music to be enjoyed and great fun. What a wonderful place not to be missed.
Astromomical clock. The clock is the highlight but don't forget to explore the side streets for shopping and interesting antique shops and art galleries.

A beautiful destination. You cannot go to Prague without visiting the Old Town Square. Along with the castle, it is a can't-miss destination. The place is always busy, always has street performers, always has pickpockets (so beware), and has some sights that are unforgettable such as the ancient clock, the Tyn Church, the Jan Hus statue, and many more. Plan to spend a couple of hours just wandering around, and even more time if you shop or eat at one of the good restaurants.

Beautiful at Christmas. I loved visiting the Old Town Square this Christmas. Lots of stalls selling mead and gingerbread. Giant christmas trees, lots of places to eat food (from hotdog stalls to nice restaurants). Good to listen to some lovely carol singing on the big stage. The square is easy to find, and there are lots of streets off it with places to go shopping. The Clock Tower and The Salvador Dalhi museum are also on the town square. Easy place to spend a day!
Christmas magic!. The old town square is awesome at night in December. The markets with the usual magnificent Christmas tree is truly a sight you won't forget.
Impressive. Very nice but too crowded for me.I don't think I would have enjoyed it as must had I not taken the guided tour

Great Architecture. Every where there is great architecture,you cannot walk a few yards without seeing beautiful buildings and statues. It took me ages to look around the town due to just standing and staring

Beautiful, specially during xmas. I got to the old town square close to sunset and it was a great experience, all buildings had the lights on and it is one of the most beautiful scenarios I have ever seen. As it is Christmas a gigantic Christmas tree was assembled in the middle of the square surrounded by all sorts of booths with food, gifts, etc. A band was also playing typical local music and added to the great experience. Only be aware that it is very crowded and if you are with kids, make sure you don't loose sight of them. The lighting of the two churches towers surrounding the square is something impressive. Don't miss it!
old town square. Crammed with tourists but superb; why do people eat outside in thew cold when there are nice places which are warm

Beautiful. Wonderful Christmas Decorations & Xmas Huts/Stores & fast food with the old buildings as a backdrop. Only issue was the number of large groups of tourists. Unfortunately, upto 50 in a group & many school children cause long queues, congestion 7 Frustration through the limited access areas.

Love the Square at Christmas. We really enjoyed the old town square and Christmas market. We didn't spend too much time in the Christmas market because we had visited several other markets in other countries over the past week. The Christmas tree was very pretty though. If you have time, go up to the tower overlooking the square and be sure to see the astrological clock.

Magnificent. The Old Town square must be one one the most beautiful places to visit. It is surrounded by magnificent buildings which take on a magical quality at night when they are lit up. My daughter and I visited the Christmas market here which I would highly recommend.

visit during Christmas. This place is beautiful all in all. But i found it extraordinary charming during Christmas. Here you can find a Christmas market with a lot of goods, food and drinks. Of course there're lots of tourists - be prepared for it.
Beautiful. Went in December so area was set up with Xmas markets. This square is gorgeous, spires of medieval churches all around. There's even a Starbucks in the vicinity.

Prague's most exciting place. The Old Town Square dating from the 13th Century –aka Staromestske Namesti in Czech- is the jewel in Prague’s crowning architectural glory, having been declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1992. Should you have only one day available during your Prague visit, this is the place to start and finish your tour, taking in spectacular evening city views from the top seeing platform of the astronomical clock tower.I visited the Old Town earlier this year and found myself spoilt for choice by the sheer variety of its sights and delights. It’s a treasure trove for style and design aficionados and a Nirvana for medieval history and architecture buffs. As Prague is a different city with each season, the Old Town Square is home to an enchanting Christmas Market in December and an even more joyous Easter Market in April, drawing in traveler crowds from all over the world. No point in complaining that it’s very crowded and touristy or that it has its fair share of pickpockets and scam artists – that’s an epiphenomenon of modern tourism affecting all famous city squares in the world - be it the Grand Place in Brussels, the Spanish Steps in Rome, the Place du Tertre in Montmartre, the Puerta del Sol in Madrid or the Piccadilly Circus in London, to mention only a few very popular and “touristy” squares in Europe. For history buffs, the whole Old Town as well as the Lesser Quarter and the Prague Castle is an immersive experience in medieval history; for the architecture traveler the Old Town Square is a fantastic display of Gothic, Baroque and Rococo, as well as Art Nouveau style.For culture cravers and art lovers there’s a branch of the Czech National Gallery right on Old Town Square, in the former Kinsky Palace, plus an impressive range of art galleries located in the old town’s historic houses. And there’s the small Mucha museum just a 10 min walk from the square on Panska street, dedicated to the Czech artist Alfons Mucha, one of Art Nouveau’s most prominent figures. It displays his paintings and Art Nouveau sketches and has an interesting shop selling artful Prague souvenirs and postcards, books and posters. Some of the artist’s paintings can be admired at the splendid Municipal Hall on Republic square.Of note, the Franz Kafka museum (on Cihelna 2b) can be reached after a 15 min walk from the Old Town Square, crossing Vltava river over the Manesuv bridge. For style seekers there’s an endless choice of boutiques brimming with artful accessories and kooky merchandise for your house or apartment. A special mention goes to the myriad of shops selling some of the most beautiful and eccentric Bohemia crystal creations -vases, glasses, lamps-, many of them unique, coming in the most vivid colours and unusual shapes (photos attached). Vendors are initially asking stratospheric prices but bargaining is possible, and in general they are willing to offer a notable discount, especially if you are paying cash. Once you’ve agreed a price, the only problem is the sheer weight of these crystal beauties … Lovers of unusual and quirky things may be surprised, intrigued or disappointed at Prague's Sex Machine “Museum” (18 Melantrichova St, a few steps off Old Town Square) showcasing various mechanical erotic appliances through history and old erotic films. However it’s more of a quirky exhibition than a museum and not really worth a visit at the admission price of CZK 250 pP (£ 7.5 / $ 12 / € 9 ). Vintage car enthusiasts have the chance to do an “Old Prague tour” in a beautifully restored vintage roadster or convertible from the 1920s ! Photographs attached, details enclosed below. There are some average to good restaurants on the square but I noticed there’s better value for money in the collateral streets and further afield. There are two excellent restaurants at the famous Municipal House on Republic Square, only a 10 min walk from Old Town Square. OLD TOWN SIGHTS not to be missed:(For all sights, the nearest public transport stations are Mustek or Staromestska)OLD TOWN (‘s former town) HALL – Listed historic building founded in the early 14th Century (1338)A very heterogenous mix of medieval buildings from various periods housing Prague’s main Tourist Information Office + art exhibition spaces + the old Council Chamber and meeting room + a Gothic chapel + the underground halls (aka Romanesque-Gothic cellars) + its best part: the clock tower with the astronomical clock. Guided tours cost 100 CZK (adult) / 50 CZK (child) / 70 CZK (students/seniors).Opening hours: Monday 11 am- 6pm / Tuesday - Sunday 9am – 6pmCLOCK TOWER (separate tickets needed)The massive Gothic Clock Tower at the Old Town Hall – roughly 60 metres tall, completed in the late 14th Century, offers stunning panoramic views of the Old Town and far beyond; best experienced at dusk and in the evening !Admission: 100 CZK (adult) / 50 CZK (child)Opening hours: Monday from 11am-10pm, Tuesday to Sunday 9am - 10pm (on certain occasions closing times may vary, please check at the main Tourist Information Office in the adjacent Old Town Hall)ASTRONOMICAL CLOCK – over 600 years old (installed in the early 15th century, in 1410), on the south wall of the Old Town Hall, one of the Prague's most popular tourist attractions and the world’s oldest astronomical clock in working condition. There’s a clock show every hour, on the hour, so no wonder it’s the most crowded corner of the square. Beat the crowds rushing in at the hour by arriving 10 min before, to see the procession of wooden figurines representing Christ and his 12 apostles. The clock shows the movement of the sun and the moon and how they relate to the zodiac signs. Hours of operation of the clock show (apostles parade): 9am – 11pmFor unobstructed photographs of the tower, most spectacular views are at night (and less people too). CHURCH OF ST NICHOLAS – Baroque architecture with Rococo exterior decoration; according to many authors it has the most elaborate and beautiful church interior in Prague. Not to be confused with its –much bigger- namesake in the Lesser Quarter (Mala Strana). The location is great for people watching and photos of the square.TYN CHURCHThe Church of our Lady before Tyn or simply Tyn Church is Prague’s second most important church after St Vitus’ Cathedral. Distinctive Gothic exterior with a heavy baroque interior featuring a colossal pipe organ. Majestic views of the floodlit church can be had from the top platform of the opposite Clock Tower at night.KINSKY PALACE (aka Goltz-Kinsky Palace) – a monumental Baroque construction with a beautiful Rococo facade; now a branch of the Czech National Gallery hosting various temporary exhibitions and a collection of Czech landscape painting. Franz Kafka attended secondary (high) school there at the end of the 19th century. MUCHA MUSEUM – for lovers of Art Nouveau. It’s on Panska street, just a 10 min walk from the square. JAN HUS MONUMENT in the square's centre, unveiled in 1915 to commemorate 500 years from the death of Jan Hus, a major figure of Czech medieval history (priest, philosopher and first Church reformer, burned at the stake in Konstanz / Constance in 1415).CHRISTMAS MARKET Spend an enchanted evening mingling with the locals at the Old Town Square Christmas Market in December Weekdays 9 am - 7 pm, Weekends 9 am – 8 pm VINTAGE CAR TOURS through Old Prague in a 1928-1935 convertible (Old Town + Venceslas Square + Lesser Quarter +/- Prague Castle). The tours, led by knowledgeable drivers, start in the Old Town, taking in the Jewish quarter of Josefov and cross into Prague's Mala Strana district (or the "Lesser Quarter") on the other side of the Vltava river. Prices are quoted per car (for 1-4 persons) and depend on the length of the tour – e.g. a 40 minute tour costs CZK 1200 per car ($ 60 / £ 36 / € 43.5) + an additional CZK 100 for the Prague castle, going up to CZK 3,000 ($ 149 / £ 91 / € 109) for a 2-hour tour. Some of these historical cars dating from the 1920s-1930s can be usually seen parked on Parizka street, in front of Cartier (opposite St Nicholas church). You can also choose & book a tour online at http://www.historytrip.czTo summarize, Prague’s Old Town Square is one of Europe’s most atmospheric and exciting places. Great sightseeing, shopping and people watching in a well preserved medieval World Heritage site, offering something different with each season. Marius C. Berger, MDLondon, UK
Perfect Christmas market!. One of the best places to visit for a Christmas market. Something for everybody. Instead of Munich and Vienna - try Prague.

One of Europe's Higlights. The Prague town square is unusually beautiful with wonderful buildings and plenty of attractions, including restaurants and shops. The best view is from the top of the Astrological clock tower, you can walk around the top to get a 360 degree view, great for photos! Although Prague was not bombed in WW2, most of the clock building was destroyed in the last days of conflict, you can see white crosses in the paving stones commemorating the lives which were lost.

The best choice for Prague. It is Prague's best place to be. It's architecture and overall atmosphere is like nowhere else in the world. Definitely a place to be in Prague. Don't miss it, while in Prague!
Facinating area to wonder about and take in the local flavour. The Astrological clock, the street entertainers and the buildings. In December they have the Xmas market which is great!

Czech it out!. Take everything you could dream a town square to be - I mean in your wildest dreams - and that is this town square. Perhaps one of the top town square in Europe - (I do love Bruxelles though), this one boasts cheap beers, czech nick-knacks, circus-like performing gypsies (sorry, Romani), good food, good people watching, a beautiful river, AMAZING old buildings, etc.an obvious must see. I dont sit and do nothing very much while traveling but I would totally just sit on this square for hours. Its that cool. For real.

Busy Town square. This is one of the oldest parts of Prague and has the Town Hall within it and one church overlooking and one bordering it.The rest are beautiful Baroque buildings painted in a variety of pastel colours containing cafes,restaurants ,shops and art galleries.It is a magnet for tourists and has interesting lanes/roads leading off containing a wide variety of tourist shops.It is just ten minute stroll to the Charles Bridge,another tourist must and from there one can see Prague Castle ahead on the other side of the Bridge.We were there for Christmas Market which was lovely,very different to visit at night(better) than day (still great but less magical)

Best place to visit in Prague. I like walking on Old Town Square. This old square is always nice..., in sunny days, when it rains, or under snow. Here is a soul of Prague. Early morning when there is nobody, early evening when there are crowds of people.
Must visit. The Old Town Square must be visited when going to Prague. The area is large enough so that it doesn't feel overcrowded and the buildings surrounding it are fantastic.

Christmas!. The square is so beautiful at Christmastime with a beautifully decorated and lit tree that you can see from anywhere in the square. Stroll through the markets and take in the smells of fresh baked sweets and local delights. There's a small (3stalls) petting zoo for the kids too. Local vendors set up kiosks selling all sorts of souvenirs. We ate dinner at an outdoor cafe that allowed us to people watch while in the comfort of heated tables and blankets. Don't forget to order hot wine!
Amazing. it was the time of Christmas markets so the square all decorated and festive. it's really amazing and great - all the light, the huge Christmas tree, the food and the whole environment.

Pretty but crowded!. Visited at xmas - the main xmas markets are in the Old Town Square. It was rammed!!! Walking like sardines down the small streets to get there. Though very pretty once there.All the stalls sell the same usual xmas stuff.Hot wine nice.Food - hot dogs reaosnably priced but the potato dishes were expensive, charged per 100g and they cram the food in. We paid almost £15 for 2 dishes.

Stunning Old World Setting.. What can be added to many comments previously given on this stunning square. you have 4 different styles of architecture over many hundreds of years. It is also a lovely setting for their main Christmas Market. The lighting, stalls hustle & bustle just added to the beauty and if you do nothing else whilst in the square, you must watch the Anotomical Clock when it strikes the hour(preferably between 8 - 12), it is an amazing piece of engineering considering it is 500 years old.

Majestic. very beautiful
great place to take photos and walk around no matter if its day or night.
great place to buy souvenirs

Crowded, pretty atmosphere. The scenery is great, but it is always very crowded so it's hard to get a good shot or to relax with your coffee (just go somewhere a block away and the crowds will vanish).

Beautiful at Christmas. Stunning square at Xmas!
There was a beautiful huge tree, great food and drinks and lovely atmosphere.

Like stepping back in time. This place just has a great feeling to it. The clock tower is like something I have not seen before and the building around the square all have something interesting about them. Although the cafes and restaurants were a bit on the expensive side for Prague, most served decent food and all had a great view for people watching.

Beautiful. We were debating wether to go to Prague or Berlin, we made the right choice in visiting Prague. The old town square was beautiful, the Christmas market with all the wooden stalls and smells of the food being cooked was amazing. It was so busy, I'm glad we were there on Thursday and Friday because by Saturday you couldn't move for the number of people.

Even better in december than in summer. Amasing how Praha can tempt tourist to visit in cold december. The square and nearby streets are even more crowded than in summer season. And the Christmas Marked must be the best in the whole world. And every hour people stand here waiting for theAstronomical Clock.
Lovely Christmas market. All kinds of good food, local crafts etc. very crowded but I guess that means lots of people agree with me. Fascinating old buildings surround the square.

Lovely at Christmastime. This is one of the most beautiful squares in Europe. It is quite lovely with the Christmas market during December, but will be more accessible to the buildings during the rest of the year.

Awesome. The most amazing city square I have ever seen anywhere - a photographers paradise. So much more to the square than the Old Town Hall, Astronomical Clock and Tyn Church. Only drawback is that the Czech's know how good this place is and the prices for coffee etc. reflect that.
Top Prague Spot. Great builidngs, food, drink sights, esp with the Xmas market there generating a real party atmosphere.
The place to visit in Prague. A real must place to be, especially at Christmas. A massive lit up Xmas tree, market stalls and bars surrounding the square for people watching. Wrap up warm, its cold.
Proper old Square !. The buildings and architecture and whilst we were there the christmas markets were great so many local restaurants to choose from
A must see on any trip. You really cant miss coming here. Great things to see (and a little geocaching). Check your tour guidebooks or tripadvisor to see all the things in this square to visit.

Beautiful Old Town Square. Very atmospheric with beautiful buildings and the wonderfully unique astronomical clock. Plenty to see, with many restaurants and bars around the square for anything from a quiet drink to a full meal. Beautifully decorated Christmas trees and Christmas market added to the atmosphere.

The Place to Be. We visited Prague for three days after a Danube River cruise and
the Christmas market here was spectacular. Check out photos of it on line. Lots of history here and incredible architecture.
Christmas market. Nice traditional food on the Christmas market, but not too much to buy as Christmas decorations or gifts. Too many people.

Magical over Christmas. The Old Town square during the Christmas season is very special. Beautiful Christmas trees, traditional foods for sale, hot wine, live music and the sense that Christmas here is a season, not just a day.

Magical place. I visited in September and I loved the magical fantasy land feel to Prague. All the gothic architecture was impressive and there was a great atmosphere - this was truly captured in the old square where you could sit at one of the many cafés or restaurants and watch all the hustle and bustle. The clock attracts a lot of people but I found it a bit disappointing compared to the one in Munich. It is however a lovely square and a must visit! Top tip - visit early in the morning to get some great photos minus all the tourists!

Christmas markets. I am very glad I visited Prague during the Christmas season. The Old Town was full of tourists (not Paris or New crowded) and the Christmas Market. At night the entire square was lit up so beautifully even the grinch himself would get into the Christmas spirit. This is definitely a must do on anyone's Europe bucket list.

A Peep in to the History lessons. Located between Wenceslas Square and the Charles Bridge, Prague's Old Town Square is often bursting at the seams with tourists in the summer. Featuring various architectural styles including the gothic Týn Church and baroque St. Nicholas Church, the square is an oasis for travelers wearied by Prague's narrow streets. Among many churches, tourists may find the Astronomical Clock on this square, while the tower at the Old Town Hall offers a panoramic view of Old Town shop.The square's center is home to a statue of religious reformer Jan Hus, who for his beliefs was burned at the stake in Constance. The statue known as the Jan Hus Memorial was erected on July 6, 1915 to mark the 500th anniversary of his death. The square is also home to a memorial to martyrs (including Jan Jesenius and Maxmilián Hošťálek) beheaded on that spot after the Battle of White Mountain. Twenty-seven crosses mark the pavement in their honour. While the installation date of these crosses is uncertain, a nearby plaque which lists the names of all 27 victims dates from 1911.during my visit the Christmas Markets were on so very atmospheric. Great decorations which came into their own at night along with the ad-hoc entertainment from jaz bands and fire juggling. During my three days in Prague i went to the square almost every day and enjoyed the place.

My New Favorite City. So much to say about the magic of this city and this square in particular. I was there in late Oct and was lucky enough to have 70 degree days. 3 days is not enough but this square is a great starting spot. I spent hours just people watching and taking in the amazing buildings and views from each direction. No photo can begin to do this square justice.

Great Atmosphere. We went whilst the Christmas Markets were on so very atmospheric. Great decorations which came into their own at night along with the ad-hoc entertainment from jaz bands and fire juggling. Did find a lot of stalls selling the same goods though which became a bit boring especially if you are looking for Christmas presents !. Some good restaurants line the square.

So visually breathtaking but an extortionate tourist trap. I absolutely love Prague and it's Disney fairtale aethsetics and historic architecture, but I was horrifed with the price of the area, The stall food, the pubs, eateries everything was expensive. What's very sad is they have carried on abusing the tourists who come back less and less because of the horrendous prices. you go about 10 miles out and it's a different ball game. Beware of pickpockets as they are rife in this area. Christmas markets were great, they have delicious hog roasts, mead and mulled wine on every corner. Romance and chaos aplenty. On New Years eve the city centre errupts into disarray as fireworks are launched off buildings, launched into small alleyways where people casually walking through get the shock of their lives. It was quite a spectacle where the festivities move from the square to Wencesslass Square and carries on till dawn, hooker alley was as busy as ever. All in all you really need to see this city. Be wise with what you spend and where you keep your money, a little organisation and a few Czech phrases will help a lot.

simply spectacular. We are from Salzburg,but we both agreed the Pragues old town square is among the best in the entire world.Christmas preparations were on when we came and we only wished we could stay little longer to enjoy the Christmas atmosphere.don t miss this square

Stunning. We visited the Square this weekend and we lucky enough to see the Christmas Tree lights being switched on. The Square had a very festive feel to it and the buildings around the square were all illuminated. Loved all the market stalls selling hot wine, hog roasts and a variety of other food to try. Definitely worth a visit.

I <3 this place. I absolutely adore the square. It us the heart of Prague. I highly recommend the Christmas market, it is the place to be: various food, decorations, gifts, weekend concerts, and the fab Christmas tree.

People watching. Sitting outside one of the mant bars that border this lovely square you can watch the world go by . Had a great time relaxing & quaffing some excellent beer whilst taking in the stunning architecture around the old square . Not too touristy but had a warm welcome from all bar staff . Pity the same could not be said for most shop staff who treated you with something ranging from apathy to distain .beside that would thoroughly recommend a trip here ,we will be back.

Amazing!. Every inch of this square is stunning. The buildings and churches look as if they came straight out of a book of fairy tales. The Týn Church could easily be Cinderella's Castle. It's truly a magical place. It's the main square in Prague, so be prepared for tons of people at all times of the day. They were all just as stunned as we were with the beauty of the scenery around them. Everyone was taking pictures and enjoying the atmosphere. There are many wonderful cafes & shops as well. If you're here for the day, just start at the castle and work your way over to this square. You'll cross over Charles Bridge into Old Town and see many attractions along the way. This route will lead you into Old Town Square. It's a beautiful walk!
Christmas switch on!. The square was filled by the Christmas market and has a glorious view of the surrounding architecture, especially when illuminated at night. Always worth a visit.

Stunning Architecture. One of the most beautiful squares in Europe! It can definitely lean towards the touristy, but that doesn't make it any less stunning. Just walk around the square and see the views. Grab a hot wine and take in the sights. Still crowded in November, I imagine it's packed in the summer. We did want to sit and enjoy a hot wine in one of the outdoor heated cafes, but unfortunately they were all cigarette smoke filled so we had to go inside.

Atmospheric and Beautiful. Such a lovely place in the heart of the city with little lanes leading off the square into cobbled streets with restaurants and bars everywhere.
A good place to people watch and see the beautiful old buildings lit up at night.

Classic square. When we saw how large thrown square was with vey nice architecture it was impressive. On Friday eve and Saturday there was a concert in the square which brought lots of interesting people. 5-6 restaurant around the square. Side streets lead to lots of shops. Don't miss St Vitus cathedral.

"number 1 money exchange in prague!". This is the best place to exchange your money whilst in prague.There is no commission and you get exactly the rate that is displayed for your currency on that day.The shop is open from 9.00am - 8.00pm everyday. Do not be influenced by better rates displayed elsewhere,as these are false and very misleading.As I was running late one day and was half an hour from the shop,I tried several exchanges displaying roughly the same rate and everyone out of a total of 5 was a scam.One would of even ripped me off for £10 less than what I should of got! so I ended up walking into town to the shop I could trust.If in a similar position and you cant get to this shop it is always best to ask first how much you will get,NEVER hand your money over and expect to get what you think.Because once it's gone it's not coming back!The exchange is situated just 2 minutes from the old town square atKaprova 14/13110 00 Praha 1 - Josefov, Česká republikaif your no good with directions just google it before you go or on your phone while your there.
Lovely at Night. Large open square, loads of food stalls to explore and always busy. At night with the lights, trees and towers at either side it takes on an almost magical quality.

Packed, but nice. The best place to people watch, the Old Town Square oozes a charming history that kept us reading enthralled for hours. We really enjoyed having wine and watching everything that was happening out on the vast square. There are plenty of good food choices around too, so take the time to explore the area for a dinner place that really appeals to you -we found a very cosy restaurant tucked away in one of the alleys that served excellent pork and beer.

Lovely, fairytale like ambience. Loved the old town square. The atmosphere was very nice with a number of musicians performing during different parts of the day. The square has a number of food outlets and some nice souvenir shops..At night the church is all lit up and looks lovely..All in all, loved the place and cant wait to go back..

All things you never knew still happened goes on here. What an exhibition of ballet dancers, balance artists and all kinds of people exhibiting fantastic skills. Many dressed in old style clothing and very much in style with the old style surroundings. I came to look at the beautiful buildings in Prague, and I would go back if the town was empty just to look again. However, all this exhibitions of skills going on here was actually more impressive than the buildings at the moment. I think all the balance acts out of Eastern Europes X-factor must have moved here.

Welcome to Prague!. Welcome to Prague and welcome to the center of the actions.Bustling place, full of people, buskers, shops, restaurants, many things to do and see.Iconic place, quaint and gothic.Historic, street leading to Parizska, Na Prikope, Charles bridge, Masna etcOn the corner is George dragon Pub and lots of bars to refresh and quench thirst.

Watch the world go by. OK it's a busy place packed with people taking snaps of the landmarks but we enjoyed just sitting down in a cafe/bar having a coffee or beer (not the cheapest area I might add) and watching the people enjoying their trip especially trying to understand the astronomical clock, snapping the various sights in the area from Tyn church, to the Powder Tower in the distance and watching the people performing on the square

Fun and fascinating. I liked the history, architecture and the craft and food booths with Prague hams on a spit, and some truly creative crafts. The clock tower and hall are amazing. (Starbucks directly across from the clock, I thought a bit much, as was the shark mascot attracting attention for Thai massage out of a building with fascinating, old worl painting)Police are out in force and communicating by walkie talkie to scout out possible pickpockets. I saw a guy I call "Raskolnikov" who was lurking everywhere and looking very unsavory.Some great stuff aside from the typical commercial kitsch and crime.
Clocks and wine. What a location! everything within 100 yards. Impromptu performances in the square whilst enjoying a drink and meal and all good value

Wow. What a magnificient place. It is one of the biggest and oldest places in Prague and it is so nice...True is, that this square is always overcrowded, but the atmosphere is unforgettable. Try some of local hot wines, they are delicious.

Crowded But Fun. The Old Town Square seems to be a must-see spot for every tour group to Prague. During most of the day, the square is so packed with visitors, it's a challenge to navigate. But the street fair vibe can be fun in limited doses. More important, however, are the historic and beautiful buildings, including churches and a popular clock tower. Admission to most of these structures is possible and worth the time if one wants to gain a greater appreciation of the surroundings.
It's a must see. Lots of hustle and movement going on, many great places to buy something special to take home and great food and fun!

Christmas market. Magical. Old Town Square when populated by the market stalls and the Christmas tree is out of this world. I felt as if I had been transported. Really friendly stall holders, I hope they are still there when I hopefully return again. Food excellent, coffee ( I drink mine black anyway) was some of the best coffee I had tasted. Again architecture superb. Again I spent hours there, I visited every day.

The Heart of Prague. It's not only the Old Town House or the underground places or the Astronomical Clock or even the beautiful historical buildings that make that place the heart of the city. It's something else. It's the crowd of tourists amazed by every corner of it. It's the atmosphere mixing music played by street artists with a man showing a miniature live horse (much smaller than a pony). It's the smile during the day and the flashes during the night. It's Prague at its best.

Very nice but touristic shops. Very nice the view the buildings and the roads across the town espesially the famous clock,but I hate people outstanding try to sell you and there was not at all but a lot,also the price are too touristic....
a must go. loved the old town square lots to do entertainment in the square ,lots of shops plenty of eating place big place to walk around

Just a great piazza. What a variety of styles and urban planning. Along history people knew how to lay out attractive plans and design lovely and most impressive urban sites. I can understand the swarms of tourists attracted by the place's beauty. It is always full of tourists but they add a dimension to the place and to its attraction.

sights and smells. although not high season was pleasantly surprised by the area the beauty of the buildings the small stalls which offer a wide range of local foods with plenty of bars and restaurants for all tastes . many sights to see and am sure you be pleasantly surprised

Must-Visit in Prague. This is one of the obvious places you simply have to go if you're going to make a trip to Prague. It's a beautiful old town square area.Make sure you check TripAdvisor for restaurants in the area, though. Lots of tourist trap-looking places.Also be wary of the Old Prague Ham stand. I was really looking forward to trying it, but when I walked up and asked the price, they said they wouldn't know until they weighed it. They then cut off a big slab and asked me for 30 Euros ($40) for it. You can get amazing meals all around Prague for less than half that, so I told them no thanks and walked away.

rest a while. this is a lovely old square surrounded by beautiful buildings cafes and bars. very lively and great for people watching.Lots of good places to eat anf drink. Plenty of outside, but covered areas to dine, they even have fleece blankets on the chairs to keep you warm!

One of my favorite places in Europe. I fell in love with Prague after spending four days there in fall. The main square is so beautiful. The buildings are quite incredible and beautifully colored. The food stands on the main square serve some tasty local treats (the cabbage, potato and sausage was great and everyone must try trdelnik). I could sit here all day and listen to the musicians in front of town hall if I could.

The Heart of Prague. Old Town Square is always buzzing with people! If you're visiting Prague you have to visit this area! They have restaurants and gift shops all around but my favorite part of the square was the food stands with traditional Czech food - Roasted meats, palacinky (similar to crepes, but super-sized), and trdelnik (a delicious sweet pastry). Street performers and little festivals are always in the square. The Astronomical Clock is also located here and all other sights and attractions are close by.

Visiting Prague and Old Town. Prague is different than other European "Old Town centers". Its location is perfect with view of the castle, near the river and of course the center's main attraction the Tower. Everything is well maintained and fun to see. Would go back in a heartbeat.

Cool old square, but constantly busy. Just one of many old town squares dotted around European capitals, but definitely one of the prettiest.Architecture is very nice with many spires dotted around, as well as the astronomical clock. Plenty of street performers as well to keep you entertained even if you're just there to people watch.A lot of cafes and restaurants as well however you'll pay a massive mark-up compared to what you'd shell out just a few streets away. Can be difficult to move around due to the massive amount of people and I believe pickpockets can also be a problem.
Beautiful. Beautiful square with lots to see and to. Definitely go up the tower,at 25 Kč each, its well worth it! Amazing view of Prague too!

Great spot. This is a great spot to check on the town square and the astronomical clock. The amount of people that were visiting was an experience itself. They seem to come from everywhere and all walks of life and nationalities.All sorts of food, beer, cafe's, anything you want you can get it here.

A must see place in Prague. If you are going to Prague than this is the place you must see. Old Town Square is the center of tourism. You can find there the famous astro-clocks called Orloj. You can find Karluv Most and Prasna Brana close around and also a very good restaurants.

Tourist hotspot. Very busy with tourists crowding the Astronomical Clock. Absolutely beautiful. We climbed to the top of the clock tower and had some amazing views over Prague. One not so nice aspect of the square is the many beggars who pick food out of the bins. Quite distressing to see this in the modern day.

A SQUARE TO BE AROUND.. Cheryl and I passed through the square nearly every time we headed out into the cobbled streets of Prague.The architecture of the buildings surrounding the square is stunning with a decorated facade. Heated outside dining in front of restaurants seamed a popular place to dine and watch the goings on in the square,or the little cabins where you can a selection of hot local food (We had a nice sausage with bread).The daytime and night-time happenings in the square can be anything from people levitating to music by individuals or the wacky band we watched one night.The camera made its presence felt with folks taking pictures.If you had visited thirty years earlier you would have been knee deep in little blue bulbs.The square is a place not miss for the above reasons and perhaps many I have not thought of.

Europeon Gothic. Prague has the most incredible Gothic architecture and grand cathedrals, this is a perfect spot for taking photos and a really amazing statue is also there. You might recognize this square from the beginning of the first Mission Impossible movie.

Great. The Old Town area in Prague is great and the Town Square is at the centre of things. Many fine restaurants fringe the square and roaming entertainers always keep things lively.Architecture is not something I know much about but looks impressive enough.Lots of nearby places to visit and really a terrific area.
Expansive and crowded. Lots to see here. Great jumping off point for exploration of Old Town. Beautiful views of the city at night.
Disney in the real world. You just have to go and sit and look at the stunning architecture, fairy castle turrets,astronomical clock and try the local food....
Very historical. Take a hop on hop off bus around the city and you get the added bonus of it also acting as tour bus because you get running commentary of the historical places to look for

MAGICAL. My husband and I recently visited Prague for a 5 day trip. We stayed in the Leon D'oro Hotel which was literally 2 mins walk from the Old Town Square. Ive never been anywhere as traditional, beautiful and truly magical as this Town Square. There was always something going on. The astronomical clock was beautiful and the place lit up at night was magical. The musicians brought tears to my eyes and the little market stalls selling traditional foods were delicious! I cant wait to go back!

The most beautiful square in Europe.. I have visited quite a few European cities and I rate this square as Europe's number one. No where else can compare for atmosphere and the wonderful historic buildings which surround it. The are has many restaurants and I was pleasantly surprised to notice the absence of beggars.
Open Square - good food & Shops. The square is large - Horse drawn carriages. Skip the Astronomical Clock. 20 second show - not much to it. Easy access to the St. Charles Bridge.

Great ambiance!. When walking around in this part of town the architecture will definitely strike you. In this square you have great views of the Tyn church and the Astrological Clock, although the clock chiming is a hype, nothing exceptional

Historical feeling. More historical feeling than at Wenceslas Square, the Old Town Square is one of the "musts" when visiting Prague. Get there at full hour when Orloj (Astronomical Clock) to see the same performance as people had in 15th century. Was there many times couple of years ago.

Amazing place. It a must visit in Prague a very lively square with a lots of tourists and a lot of entertainers juggling balls or dancing and singing and fire eaters,lot of good cafés and restaurants are around here and a lots of boutiques and brand shops are here.

Heart of the city. This is a magnificent square with lost of activities, constant music and entertainment and the astronomical clock is worth a visit by itself. This captures the essence of the city. Fantastic.

This place is great!. More than your typical town square, it is really fun, especially at night. It is really busy with people there to see the clock, but there are various street entertainers who were very good, surrounded by lots of restaurants, bars and shops. There are also little kiosks set up with food and crafts. In the middle, is a kiosk where they spin large hams on open flames and you can buy it by the hunk. If you like ham, get some. This is the best ham I have ever tasted and will forever compare the rest to it. I always felt safe, but with the large crowds around you just beware of pickpockets. During the day, you can enjoy the architecture and the beauty of the surroundings.
Hub of history and activity. There is nothing to not like. Church Before Our Lady of Tyn, Astronomical Clock, Powder Tower~ grabbed by the alluring nature of the gothic style.

The hub.. A definite must to visit in Prague. This large square, which is surrounded by magnificent buildings, is bustling from morning till night. Just sit outside one of the restaurants and 'people watch' whilst enjoying a coffee or something stronger. Mime acts, jazz bands, buskers and (while we were there) an excellent pianist who had brought his own electric piano on a trolley, abound. Old fashioned stalls selling traditional food can be found here and on top of all this you have the phenomenon of the Astrological Clock which draws hundreds to watch it on the hour. We spent ages here, always something to see and entertain you. Don;t miss!!

Party weekend. Beautiful square well worth a look but beware the pick pockets. The prices here are well above what you will pay if you travel down the side streets of the city but it is a must see. The stalls change for night time and it is stunning in the dark well worth a look there is a great atmosphere here it is like a page out of a fairytale. Well worth getting lost down the side streets as this is where all the souveneir shops are.
