A historical square. Old Town Square is a nice place to visit in Prague. The Gothic architecture makes this a terrific place to visit. You can go up the old city hall tower and get an even better view of the square and the city. The only thing I didn't care for was the Astronomical Clock.
Centre piece of Prague. Wonderful architecture and terrific place to watch the world go by fuelled by the local ham and hot wine

Nice but be wary. Definitely a lovely square with a lot of old buildings. The astronomic clock is interesting but I was not really very impressed. In good weather it is nice to linger and look and watch some of the buskers and performers in the square. Like in every tourist centre, the prices are higher than need be and you should look out for pick pockets and con artists despite the active police presence.
Excellent. Enjoyed walking along and browsing the shops, scenery and enjoying the vibe. Lots of great restaurants and cafe's.

Remarkable preservation. Kept thinking that I was in some sort of Disneyworld but it was no façade. Incredible architecture from centuries past with great cafes and bars. Very social place to spend the afternoon or evening. A must do.

Classic European Old town, must go.. The evenings here are just bustling with life. Street performers, bars, restaurants, shopping… your just spoilt for choice.
With all this going on don’t forget to soak in the evening. The candescent yellow mood that the lamps create, on the beautiful architecture surrounding you, is undeniably soothing. Take a deep breath, spare a moment and let Prague herself embrace you.
Great place to be. Brilliant place. Bustling with life. Always lots of musicians, mime artists and entertainers around. Great food and restaurants.

what a truly beautiful city. Our hotel was right on the old town square which we were both endlessly happy about. What an absolutely gorgeous place! Very typically Eastern European but wow. It is an absolute must that you visit here when in Prague. There are lots of shops selling all kinds of things and so many restaurants you could eat at a different one every night for months! It seriously is an absolutely stunning place to be and doesn't lack for things to do.

Circus. Love all the old buildings and St. Vitus Cathedral and all, but the carnival acts of rather low talent street performers and the in-your-face graffiti everywhere detracted from the overall experience. Oh and the throngs of people. Yikes.

Medieval Town Square worth the wait. Waited over a year to visit this historic city and it was well worth it. This is the loveliest place to explore ancient and modern –think Velvet Revolution and the fall of Communism- historical sites. It is also a super place to get great food, great beer and people watch all in one setting. I’d go back any time;

Because you have to.... You can't go to Prague and not visit the Old Town square. It is beautiful, charming, colorful - the way I describe it - what we all think of when we think of Europe. There are lots of restaurants to sit and have bite to eat or a drink, however you will pay a lot more than if you walk just around the corner down a smaller street - where you will also find better food. Sights: You have the clock tour, the statue, two churches, the food vendors, shops, restaurants --- lots going on so you can easily kill some time. Also, a great meeting place for friends. Any way you look at it, when visiting Prague - it is the most central location to all the main sights and you will have to see it.

Beautiful . The old town square is a must on every travelers list. It's beautiful. Well stunning. It gets crowded mid morning onwards and is stunning early morning and dusk then again it changes at night when the music is playing, the buskers ramp up their mikes, and the lights twinkle from the stunning buildings. Sit and watch the action from one of the restaurants/bars

Great medieval plaza. This place has a lot of medieval constructions around it, starting with the astronomical clock and the churches. Every hour the spectacle around the clock with trumpets and medieval music gives the place a great atmosphere. If you're hungry, you can eat the old prague ham, sausages, black bread, and of course a great czech beer.

Always vibrant. The Old Town continues to attract visitors from all over the world. It is always full of tourists. This is the oldest part of Prague and one of the reasons Prague is such a great walking city. It continues to be one of the beautiful places to visit because of the magnificent churches and beautiful buildings.

magical. Absolutely fallen in love with Prague since I first visited with my girlfriend 3 years ago. We are going back for our 3rd visit this November.And the Old Town Square is simply a magical place to be, especially at night with all the bars on the square with their patio heaters.
A Gathering Place. There are places to eat outdoors under cover with heat, entertainment, food vendors with local treats, and is great for people watching while having a beer!

Watch the food stalls .......... The food stalls selling Prague ham will rip you off
Cabbage and ham bottle of water ,650 Kc or £22
Never again only because it was a woman
And I was holding the table for us .
Talk about ripping tourists off ,not only that it was poor quality............

Attractive and lively. This is the centre of the Old own and you can not go to Prague without visiting. Lots going on, street entertainers, market stalls, cafes and bars. Quite expensive so make sure you read menus outside and review prices. As with anywhere in Prague, don't sit down if there are no prices on the menu.Lots of different architecture all within one square.

Such History. We got to visit just at the time that there was a huge Breast Cancer Awareness Walk getting ready to start. Our tour guide got us to the key areas before the crowds arrived. Beautiful architecture!

Alive with music and cafes. The Old Town Square was delightful. People everywhere enjoying the atmosphere, the buskers, the music. Very lively. Lovely cafes doing a roaring trade. All surrounded by the magnificent architecture and beautiful crystal outlets.

Beautiful Square with Fantastic Architecture. The Old Town Square was one of our favourite spots in Prague. On this square you can do many things: admire the architecture of the surrounding buildings, see the astronomical clock, have a drink at one of the square restaurants, get a snack from one of the food stands or catch a performance by one of the bands/entertainers. It is really fun to hang out and watch all the people/things going on. The astronomical clock in action was a bit of a disappointment as it doesn't really do much. Most of the side streets off of the square are also quite interesting with shops and restaurants. This is one of the must do things while you are in Prague.
Perfect. One of the best views ever. Arriving into the square you can see the clock tower wich is really beautifull, and then you look at the two towers and simply fall in love with Prague

Time flies by at Old Town Square. This in one place in Praha where you get to see the old medieval buildings, its moderately crowded with tourists and local people who demonstrate their skills in different ways. There a small local bands playing fantastic music, so dancers performing the traditional dance, etc. This is the place where you just have to go without any pre-determined plan and you will surely loose the track of time. The astronomical clock is also adjacent to the old town square. There are a lot of eating option here, but restaurants charge almost double the rate if you choose an option to sit outside with a view of the old town square.

Charming, magical, medieval, incredible. This place is incredible, starting by the medieval architecture and its history. It's a place to spend some time watching its surroundings, visiting some expositions (I saw Dalì and Mucha), be there to see the Astronomical Clock at full hour, visit St. Nicholas church, and see the many street artists there. Try the city tour before exploring, because it will change your perspective of the buildings, as you learn about them. I advice not to eat on the square though, on the food tent beside the St Nicholas church, it's a tourist trap as the price seems low, but actually they charge you for weight of the food and they don't even ask you how much do you want. So be careful with that.

A good place to wander about. This is a lively spot - lots of people milling about. The buildings are beautiful, many restaurants. Do wander down the side streets and explore. Just off of the square is St. Michael's Monestary that holds evening concerts. We attended one and were disappointed. The actual event was not what we expected based on the promotional information and we found it a bit "cheesy". Also, they sell you "preferred seating" in the first few rows at a higher cost (includes a glass of champagne) but the room is so small there are only about 8 rows of chairs in the entire room. There are a number of shops with souvenirs - while many prices were similar between shops we did find a couple that were much lower so it pays to shop around. The hop on hop off bus tour stand is located at the square and provides a nice overview of the city - particularly helpful if you are staying only a few days; it helps identify where you would like to spend some time. There is also a large shopping mall not far from the square. The food court is worth checking out; really great food and not the typical fast food courts found in North American malls.

Rubbing Elbows. This is a beautiful European square that has a lot of charm and character. It is also very crowded with tourists. There are many cafes and restaurants that are good. An area also wood fire roasts ham with side dishes. Be careful for this because they charge by the pound and it can add up quickly. Try it in early morning hours when no one is around to really get a nice feel and enjoy the architecture.
Most entertaining!. The restaurants, the buskers, the entertainers and the crowds who congregate in front of the Clocktower.
Stunning. This is such an exquisite square. Go to the tower top to get a great view of the city before you even start exploring.

Liveliest place in town. You can't go wrong spending your days in the Square-street performers and great musicians and delicious food and people from all over the world and of course the most gorgeous buildings anywhere. And affordable, too.

Beautiful square. Lovely square with beautiful buildings. The clock is what pulls most of the people there - make sure you see it on the hour. We saw it at 1pm and 5pm (on different days). At 5pm a trumpet player came out at the top which was cool. There's lots of street entertainment in Prague. If you stop to watch/take photos/videos then remember to tip - it's hard work and if you like what they do then show your appreciation. There's lots of places to grab food/coffee, and it's a short walk to Wenceslas Sq & Charles Bridge from here.
Nice place. Mice place, atmosphere, but crowded with people. Anyway nice place for visiting, because of nice sights.

The square is living. I visited many cities at Europe, but every time i tell myself, i have never seen a square before such as crowded as Taksim square and Istiklal street in Istanbul, now I have just seen and surprised, Prague old city s square, lively, attractive but should be careful thieves and pick pocking actually i didnt like cafes and restaurants just around the square, you should prefer norrow streets restaurants

scams in Old Town Square. Well worth visiting, very picturesque, but beware of overcharging and short changing of tourists... particularly by the guy with the booth selling the hot wine and honey wine. Be careful in crowds, the police do not keep a conspicuous presence there because they have nowhere else to be. Go there for the sights, but you may want to consider eating or drinking elsewhere.

You can haggle on prices- don't pay full price!. Everything in Prague, while nice, seems to have fallen victim to the tourism boom. The square is cute, but it's mostly just shopping and places to get a coffee. Please make sure if you're going to take photos with the people who are painted to look like statues that you tip them- I cannot tell you how annoying it was to see everyone snap photos and not give them anything- they are street performers, and that is how they make money.You will run into several people trying to sell you tickets to the various concerts around the town. You do NOT have to pay full price! When we were approached the original price was $22 Euro's per ticket. By the time we went to walk away it was $16, and I'm pretty sure we could have named a lower price.Almost every shop is overpriced- if they are not really busy, you can ask for a discount if you are buying more than one thing. I bought a lot of the traditionally Russian stacking dolls and was able to get a 10% discount on my purchase. (I bought several- don't ask if you're only buying one)Otherwise, it's a nice little area to walk through.

Clock a bit of a let down. To stand and wait in the square for the clock to move round the the o clock was worth seeing but I was expecting so much more ! More interesting was the many bridal couples who had been married in the city hall, mainly foreigners we were told by our guide.

Its a square with beer and tourists. Old town architecture and history, coupled with beer halls and loads of tourists. Great spot to park and have a beer while walking around! Watch out for cars... no seriously, they come through there!

Must see!. The square with the Astronomical clock is a must see when in Prague. On the hour every hour, the skeleton rings the bell and the 12 Apostles show their faces from an open window. Quite unique!

Very beautiful. This is a wonderful area and extremely attractive like the rest of this part of Prague. One of the first impressions we gained was of the quality of the food at the various cafes around the Charles Bridge and the Square. It did not seem to matter where we ate the food was delicious. Needless to say we hung around for the chiming of the astronomical clock which is a must see but make sure you explore the surrounding streets, Havels Market and Wenceslas square. If you have any historical sense then the Jewish Quarter is also a must see. We wandered through the cemetery, the museum and four of the synagogues of which the Spanish Synagogue is singularly beautiful. One note, this is the second time we have travelled through part of Europe in September/October and not only has the weather been pretty well perfect all of the time but the crowds are much reduced which makes exploring so much more pleasant.

Don't miss the Old Town Square. What a great place for a pre dinner walk / drink. Filled with locals and tourists alike the Square provides access to a myriad of street vendors and restaurants down small streets plus the usual buskers.

Great fun -- lots to see and do. Everywhere you look there is something interesting and fun going on: music, juggling, dog drill team, the clock crowds, and eating and drinking and visiting. This is Prague culture distilled and it is wonderful and various.
Must see. When in Prague, definitely see this square with its magic clock, it definitely should be on everyone's bucket list

Breathtaking!. We spent a lot of time here - the Tyn Church is quite spectacular and the astronomical clock is also a must-see. Very nice restaurants all around the square but avoid the vendors selling from the cars - especially the potato concoction which is a dreadful waste of money.Lots of street performers to keep things interesting for the kids--and adults too!

Classic "old"Europe. Old Town Square is truly one of the coolest places to visit in all of Prague. The history and eclectic architectural styles of the buildings is amazing and quite interesting, if you're in to that kind of thing. They've all be restored and are fun to look at. Take a moment and stop at one of the many cafes, enjoy a coffee or a beer and just people watch. While there is quite a bit to do in and around Prague, take the time to relax and really soak in the atmosphere of one of the truly great cities in Europe. That can easily be done right in Old Town Square.
Great to visit day or night. The buzz around the square in amazing. The architecture superb. The restaurants although a bit touristy offer great menus and great food.

Great City Center. My wife and I visited this city square in mid-September. It is alive with people and history, surrounded by baroque buildings, palaces, and the ubiquitous spires that characterize the City. The square is jammed with cafes, craftsmen (and women) and street entertainers as well as budding businessmen who cater to tourist and offer everything from City tours to river boat sightseeing. The astonomical clock on one side of the square and the municipal hall on the other are hallmarks of a tremendous piazza in between. Well-worth visiting..
Old Town Square. Amazing clock - we stayed across the square and the hourly massing of people of all ages to see 600-year-old technology never got ... well old.
classic europe. This square is what people think if when they picture Europe in their minds. it has amazing buildings and history.

love the whole atmosphere.. with the clock and the beautiful churches and outdoor cafes its a great little place to spend some time. tons of shops and street performers. always felt safe. and a great place to start a walking tour which was really good and informative
What a beautiful city. Plenty things to see, We visited the Salvador Dali exhibition that was there and of course the astronomical clock.

Great way to spend an afternoon.. A beautiful square surrounded by fabulous architecture. Lots of cafes, outdoor patios and outdoor food stands. A short walk to a great little market and small shops. Great music on the square when we were there, as well. A very fun place to explore for a few hours.

Lovely, but beware.... Old Town Square is a beautiful historical square in the heart of Prague, a gathering place for literally, thousands of people a day. Lots of cafés and food stalls line the sides of the square. I would caution visitors when they purchase from the sausage and smoked ham stalls (they look like they are under the same company). The pricing of the smoked ham is Czech Kronor 89 / 100g, so one would think we would have a choice as to how much we want. Not so here. The man who smokes the ham cuts off a slab (often a very large slab), even when there are just 2 people eating it, and we don't have a choice but to accept it. He cut 600g of ham for 2 of us. Many people were seen throwing away the extra ham, which is wasteful. As for the sausage, it was tasty but contained a lot of cubes of fat in it.
Everything you need. Full of iconic cathedrals, buildings, clocks, cafes, people, stalls, segways (try one, they're fun) and different sights to behold.

Tredelnik in the square. Get a coffee and a Tredelnik (thin bread dough, rolled in sugar, cinnamon and crushed almonds wrapped around a metal stick and cooked over open coals) and sit in Old Town Square and just take it all in - magic!

What a vibrant place. Old town square is the center of old town. It's full of people enjoying themselves. The astronomical clock is interesting to watch on the hour. The top of the tower provides a great view at a small price. There are plenty of shops and restaurants, covering all tastes.
Must See. This entire area is fun for exploring but the clock is not to be missed. Sure it is crowded and filled with tourists but they are all there because it is so interesting and so much fun.

Amazing?. Put simply, it was stunning. There were almost too many stunning buildings to choose from. You get so overwhelmed by the amount of gorgeous buildings that you overlook ones that would be blown away by in any other city. Prague is the prettiest city I've ever been too....and I do not say this lightly.

great location to visit in prague especially at christmas time... I visited the old town square in December 2012, as we walked down towards the square the first thing we could see was the huge Christmas tree in the middle of the square it was magical. There was large crowds of people in the square itself and it is very touristy but it is deffinetly worth a visit especially at Christmas time. the square is surrounded by magnificent Buildings. There were a lot of food stalls selling very tasty Czech food like sausages, pastries, crepes, mulled wine, etc, I enjoyed sipping the mulled wine as I walked around looking at the stalls as it can be quite cold during the evening time.and the other stalls sold different things like Christmas decorations, hand made crafts, etc. There is also cafes and bars in the square and after a few hours of browsing around the stalls, we sat outside in one of the bars, the waiter gave us blankets as it was quite chilly, and there was a heater beside us to warm us up and it was lovely to have a drink and watch the great atmosphere of the square. There was a big open air stage where a choir was singing Christmas songs and the whole square was lit up with Christmas lights everywhere, it was beautiful. The world famous astronomical clock is also located in the square and every hour on the hour, the astronomical clock comes alive. I would deffinetly recommend visiting the old town square especially at Christmas time it is just magical.....

Lots going on. Busy place.. This place has a good vibe...very busy, nice architecture, cobbles well-maintained. Restaurants are ok, but not great. Central to just about everything you'd want to see in Prague,
Amazing place. Although it was packed with tourists, the square was remarkably clean and tidy. No pick-pockets, no beggars, no trouble-makers; that's what makes a great square really great!
Very busy. The square gets very busy but is mostly traffic free with street entertainers, food stalls and a choice of cafes. The clock is worth one visit on the hour for its' actions.

Can't miss this location!. In spite of the crowds, the Old Town Square is a must see experience. Besides just watching the people and photographing the beautiful churches, there are food stands preparing sausages, halusky, sweets, etc. There are always musicians performing, and it is the hub to key sites within the city. Even in the rain!

A must see while in Prague. This is the main attraction surrounded by expensive restaurants and hotels. You cannot miss while in town. This is where the famous clock town is located with beautiful clock.

best public place in Prague!. Old town of square is a place in which you can see the famous landmark of Prague like astronomy tower, church of our lady befor... also there is vendors who offer yummy Prague food, cooky and absultly hot wine in winter. You can have communication with other tourist there, enjoy street music. ... you will see a person with yellow umbrella! He/she is a leader of town free tour
A Must. This is really the the center of the city, and the main attraction. The Square is big, open, green, and with magnicific Buildings. Go there - sit Down for a drink - and enjoy!

Overwhelming to the senses. Try to catch a free bench under the Jan Hus monument and just look around and enjoy the show. When you get tired of the crowd go behind the cathedral to Ungelt, a peaceful square with beautiful houses and some nice spots to sit and have a drink or a meal.
amazing place. I love this square ... i love Prague ... I love Czech Republic and nothing else my heart is still in Prague and so ...

A Beautiful Tourist Trap. If you're looking for old-school, historical sights - the Old Town Square is great. Please read other reviews for information regarding the astronomical clock, numerous churches, etc. That being said, BEWARE of the tourist trap food stands posted next to the church with the clock. There are a few with roasting pig and a Czech version of potato salad. It looks and smells amazing and you'll most definitely want some. You'll want some until you find out how much it costs. A gentleman sliced off a generous piece of pork and together with a bowl of potato salad, the total came to.......... 580 CZK. That's 27-28 euros or $35. Yeah..... right. $35 for a $7-10 meal? To put that in perspective, every restaurant we visited cost less than that for two full, hearty meals, several beers and a few appetizers. Prague is the most touristy city I've ever been to and they take advantage of it. Be mindful of the prices for everything (don't even get me started with the taxi rip offs) and plan your meals wisely.

Highly recommended. A stay in Prague without visiting the old town square is a sin! Especially more beautiful December when the Christmas market is on, horse drawn carriages,traditional Czech ornaments, food and roasted chestnuts are on offer.

Beautiful, but it does get crowded.. It is a great spot to stop, watch the Old Clock on the hour go through its movement, have a bite to eat at one of the many cafes in the square, or a quick bite from one of the BBQ venders around the square. Lots of entertainers come and go and play for the crowds. It is like a wheel with the streets heading off in many directions from its center, which makes it a gathering point. We always made sure to stop here, and have a coffee before venturing out in another direction.

Best place in Prague. This is where you'll want to spend your time. It can be touristy, but try to get there in the early morning to beat the crowds, or wander around late at night when everything is lit up and you can enjoy the outdoor cafe scene.

Quaint, old wordly. The old town square in Prague is unique. It is has an old worldly feel about it with great restaurants and beautiful surroundings. The clock tower is a highlight at night when it lights up to tell the story of how it came about. The horse and carriages which stroll around the town centre create a wonderful ambience to the square. yes it may be expensive but what part of travelling is cheap. The walking tours are well worth looking into you gain so much in site of the town.I will definitely return to Prague. Loved it and highly recommend visiting.

Too Popular for Its Own Good. We first saw Old Town Square 12 years ago. Then as now it has many unique attractions mentioned by other reviewers. However, the past 12 years have seen an explosion of crowds and hordes of tour groups against which it is impossible to swim upstream. So now, we use it primarily as a meeting place for visits with our son, whose office is a short distance from the square.

A magical place at night. Lovely old square with lots to see. Astronomical clock is something else, but make sure you know all about it to appreciate it's meanings. Crowds gather every hour on the hour to see the workings of the statues on the clock. A trip up the tower gives great views of the city.Plenty of cabins selling snacks, drinks and souvenirs. Street performers are also plentiful throughout the day and evening. Horse drawn carriages and most guided tours leave from this square.Go back at night and the square is transformed into a more magical place with the buildings all lit up.Be aware of pickpockets here. Someone was eyeing us up until he realised we were onto him and then he left.Such a marvellous place along with the rest of this city.

Old Town Square. The Old Town Square is a must. Visit the clock, have dessert and people watch. It can't get any better than that. As long as you don't mind the crowds, the hustle and bustle gives you a flavor of Prague. Visit St. Nicholas Church on the far corner of the square. Lots of street entertainment too. Watch out for the metallic mimes. After taking a picture of them, they insisted that we pay them 1000 czk ($20), my husband promptly deleted the picture in front of them.
Astronomical clock is beautiful. I loved the old town square, a must if you go to Prague, the Astronomical clock is beautiful. Every hour you'll see quite a great scene, that has it's own story.

Too crowded. Lots of historical structures, but so crowded during Spring and Summer...you can hardly move. Lots of police present at the Square, wonder if there is a high crime rate. So just be aware of that.

Old town. Very nice worthseeing place but be careful about the restaurants . Even water is the most expensive thing there:)))you can buy before, also there are cheaper restaurants in the alleys ....Do not forget to walk around on foot it is the best option to see everywhere

the more things change,the more remains the same... Old Town Square and its old clock (ORLOJ) remains the same,as I remember it watching it as a small girl, fascinated by the clocks movements.I grew up in Prague and left for the US many years ago.We love coming back with our grown children and small grandchildren.They all loved it too! We took the elevator up to the observation tower and as always, admired the beautiful view of Prague.Great place to take pictures!

Beautiful but very crowded. Definitely a highlight of the city, spending some time in the old Town Square, walking, shopping, people watching, enjoying a drink at one of the many cafes. It is however, one of the most crowded city squares I have visited and it was busy any time of day, morning, day or night. The crowds just never seemed to dissipate. I also did not like all the "performers" in the square some of whom just stood in costume looking for money, this sort of thing takes away from the beauty of the surroundings. The square is particularly beautiful at night, almost magical. Don't miss going up the tower of city hall, beautiful views of the city and the square from above.

Don 't miss the clock. Be sure to visit the Old Town Square during the day and again at night. The lighting on the square make it feel "magical" at night. The astronomical clock in the center of the Prague Square is not to be missed. The four figures on the clock are set in motion on the hour. Make sure that you see the whole "show" from the beginning. People start gathering about 10 minutes before the hour so that they can have a good viewing spot. Take a few minutes before your visit to read about the rich and interesting history of the clock. Take time to explore beyond the central square. The side streets are filled with interesting shops and restaurants.

Can't visit Prague without coming here. The old town square seems to be the hub of the city. There are little eateries and cafes off to the sides so you can either stand or sit and experience life in Prague. There were also heaps of buskers around too keep the crowds amused. There are so many tourist attractions around here too or not far from to walk too.
A Must on a Visit to Prague. The Old Town Square is the hub of a lot of activity in Prague. We visited several times. Take time to go up the clock tower; the view is worth the climb.
absolute must. The square is beautiful, Always packed with people but still very nice, the church, the tower the nice houses around the square, they all make it worth to come to Prague

Huge and interesting. Enjoyed the old clock and the Jan Hus monument. Enjoyed the lively crowds. Had a bad experience, however, with one of those places selling Old Prague Ham and Sausages. The sign offered ham for 89 kc per 100 grams and I offered one--thinking I was getting a 100 gram serving. Ended up getting 5-600 grams and the guy didn't want to take any off the plate. I shouldn't have paid but I did. So beware of them as well as the pickpockets and money changers everyone warns you about.

Great at night. We were lucky the weather was great and the late summer nights were perfect to enjoy this arena of activity. The entertainment was ongoing and when the turns finished they put their hat round, so not too expensive. We had no problems with anyone at all.

bustling. All tourist go to the old town square. Some want to see the old clock tower, many mill around the square eating from the food stalls that line one side of the square or sitting in the cafes. At night you will chance upon people performing, usually singing, in the square.

You will love it crowded or not. The Old Town Square is one of those places in Prague that you will enjoy crowded or not. In the winter/spring time they have a lot less people but you can still sit outside of the cafes and have coffee or beer as most have the heaters outside and blankets, which I really like. "You can beat watching the world go by with a beer in your hand".In the summer it is very busy but there is a good selection of street food vendors, which sell everything from Czech sausage to huge pancakes, there is also quite a few local speciality foods, which you should try at least once.....I liked them all, mainly because I am a greedy guts..LOL.Just go and enjoy, you won't be disappointed and it is not too expensive, cheaper than London. If your on a budget then walk a 100-200 metres in any direction from the square and you will find plenty more restaurants that are 20 to 40% cheaper than the Old Time square.I have been to the square in summer, winter and spring and I loved it every time.

Beware of some of the food vendors!. There are some takeaway stall at the edge of the Square. Some of them are by weight. What we thought was a 49k dish of potato, cabbage and ham ended up being a 400k- because it's 49k for 100 grams. And it was horrible.I think it's the same deal with the roast meat.

Great place to spend a few hours. The architecture and photogenicity of the Old Town square is great. Many great churches and state buildings, and a variety of street performers. We saw magicians, ballet dancers, musicians, acrobats, and more. There are also a number of food stalls selling amazing Czech food (try the ham and potatoes!). Beer is cheap at any of the restaurants nearby.
Amazing Day and Night. Great buildings and good huts selling mulled wine and sausages. Also good to see at night when buildings are lit.
Old world Europe. Old world charm right around the corner! Take a free walking tour from here to learn more about the history of Prague.

Really great place!. I really loved walks in Old Town Square. Much of street performers, food stands with traditional fare, shops, old churches......Architecture of buildings were really amazing for me. And astronomical clock was really wonderful! Square looks nice at night time too.
Beautiful!. An awesome experience, and one of the best parts about Prague! Great, beautiful old buildings, very open area and heaps of restaurants to choose from! Recommended.

Everyone comes and watch Orloj. I thing the Staromestske namesti is the most famous place in Prague. With interesting City Hall formed of few houses. City Hall Tower is most known of its Solar Clock -Orloj. Every hour You can watch the performance made by medieval puppets (or something that). There is also a monument of Jan Hus. He was killed by pope in Konstanza. There you can see The truth will win - Pravda vitezi.

Overrated. If you're a tourist, by all means stop by.But the hustlers and jerks are only there for your money.Pickpockets abound, and, frankly, I don't need people telling me seating's not for someone who wants coffee but only for people who want a full meal, even though the place is empty.So, OK. It will stay empty.Basically, a tourist ripoff. Go, see the clock, etc., but skip the restaurants. They are insanely overpriced.

Different than all of the other squares. This town square was full of energy regardless of the day or time. While it was full of tourists and entertainers, it was large enough not to be overly crowded. The architecture of the surrounding buildings (Astronomical clock, Tyn church, town hall) was very interesting. The cafes in this square are great for people watching.

Wonderfully ethnic. Definitely different from most other town squares. The strange shapes of the Tyn towers, the curiousness of the astronomical clocks, the clip-clop of the horses' hooves on the cobbled pathways, all make up for a wonderfully ethnic feel. Do not forget to go up the astronomical tower - you can see all this below, and much more stretching into the horizon before you.
Tick tock & much more. While the astronomical clock was amazing, there were many more things to see!! Street performers, food stands with traditional fare, shops, old churches......
Prague. Visit and spend at least 3 or 4 days. Make sure to see the Clock show on the hour. Go in the churches and go to a music event in the any of the churches in the evening

A can't miss attraction. This is very definitely an attraction you can't miss in Prague. Plenty of sights, shops, restaurants and monuments. The crowds were large, but not overwhelming. We went there at least four times in a 3 day visit.

Enchanting!. This square is enchanting! There were mistrals playing when we were there and I could only imagine what it was like in the 15th and 16th centuries. To be strolling around there, knowing others during that time did too...wow!!!

Great energy, Fun at night or daytime, Don't miss this!. The Old Town Square is an interesting, fun place to visit and there is always something going on, day or night. It's filled with street performers, musicians, restaurants and cafes, street vendors and souvenir shops and totally surrounded by a huge variety of architecture ranging from the early middle ages through modern times. The Astronomical Clock is one interesting feature - a gigantic statue is another. We found it such great energy, we purposely visited this square multiple times during our short visit to Prague - don't miss this exciting place!

Great time in prague. I like the idea of having All Cobble stone on the streets around the Old Town Square although I found it hard on my feet walking around the square for hours trying to see the whole place. The place is very historic with nice structures, cathedrals, museums, etc. not to mention the Charles Bridge nearby.

Weekends are a delight. It was great to be in the town square, especially on the weekend. There is always a musical group entertaining. One weekend had a food festival with booths selling Czech specialties-a great opportunity to taste small portions of traditional dishes.

You must not miss this!. The energy, architecture, history and cafes in every direction. The first night we walked into the square from our hotel was magical. The church spires were lit up like Cinderella's castle. The cobblestones connected all of the wonderful cafes and street vendors. There was music in the air from the impromptu musicians. The astronomical clock, tower and statues are breathtaking. Close by to this square is a street that rivals Worth Avenue or Rodeo Drive. All of the top designers, like LV, Jimmy Choo, Prada, etc. line this street. It's a beautiful tree lined street for window shopping.

A great walk-around. Stand in the middle of Old Town Square and you can see architectural examples from the 1400's through Art Nouveau, one of the few places in Europe that can happen. Climb the Clock Tower, try to figure out the Astronomical Clock, see the lights on the Tyn Church at night, take in a concert in St. Vitus Cathedral, and just watch the performance artists (always with one hand on your wallet, as the pickpockets can be devious...). It's a great place to have a beer at night and watch the lights and people. I am not fond of the food, which is overpriced and of poorer quality than you can get elsewhere in this wonderful city. Use the Old Town Square as the center of the star--walk north on Pariska to Josephov (Jewish Quarter), east to the Powder Tower and Assembly Hall (one of the best Art Nouveau examples in the city), southeast to Charles University and the Estates Theatre, south to Wenceslas Square, and west to the Charles Bridge and ultimately to the castle across the Vlatava River. It's a must for all tourist visitors.

Center of Prague. I found the Old Town Square to be the center of the activity in Prague. It is a meeting point, and also the location of the famous Prague Astronomical Clock. At all times of the day there are crowds of people enjoying live entertainment, Czech food, beer, in a lively atmosphere. In the evening the buildings are illuminated becoming a great photo op. The square could be viewed by some as a tourist trap, or by others as quite charming. I choose charming.
Must See in Prague.. Lively square with lots to see. Great place to people watch. Suggest staying in Old Town and close to square.
Stay a while. We had a relaxed time here, watching the street performers, having a drink and people watching. Take time out to relax here; you won't regret it.

Heart of Prague. Although the Square is no longer used as the daily market square it is "the hub" of Prague. No visit would be complete without spending time in Old Town Square to see the main buildings and churches there as well as the town hall and all important astronomical clock but to people watch, catch the buskers perform or eat in one of the many restaurants.

Typi,cal old city square, nice buildings. Typical old city square, lined with very nice buildings. A lot of tourists waiting to watch the astronomical clock do its chimes with moving characters. The clock really is not that interesting, the puppets only move around for about a minute. The reaction of the crowd after it was done was: "That's it???"
Old Town Square Prague. Beautiful square with lots of activity going on. There are multiple stores if you feel the need to do some shopping.

Hoards of people and over priced cafes. Ok, so the buildings are beautiful and charming.But, there are so many people here that it is like being crammed into an enclosed space with hundreds of other tourists. Shame, but way to busy to really enjoy, even on a weekday.

Excellent historical centre of Prague. Fabulous place in centre of Prague, you can enjoy history, extra expensive food or you can go just few steps behind Tyn church into Tynska street and have amazing lunch or dinner in Divinis Restaurante.

Beautiful Prague...both day and night!. We recently visited Prague, and we were overwhelmed by the beauty and history of the city. The square is a MUST see for shopping, dining and a total Prague experience. We toured during the day, but returned at night, and it was like a completely different place! So beautiful to see the spires at night....HIGHLY recommend this location for anyone traveling to Prague!
Old World Charm. Well worth the visit. There are a number of cafes, tourist traps and people watching. If your a fan of the architecture and history this is a place to stop!

whoooaaw!. this old time square is very nice, you can find very beautiful building with amazing arcitecture! when i was there the weather is very nice and it makes the view is really great! but is kind a to many group of travel tourist there so is was crowded

Truly the centre of Prague. This is truly the centre of the tourist area of Prague. There is so much to see and do in the area as well as many choices of places to eat and drink. We were fortunate enough to stay in an apartment overlooking this square and never tired of coming back to the area every night. Don't just stick to the town square but take the time to wander around all the side streets as well, as there is more to see there as well. We took a different direction home one night and found local fruit and veg markets where we purchased the most amazing berries to eat on our train trip the next day.

Touristy, Prague ham ripoff and clock tower. Get ready for plenty of tourists staring at the famous clock tower - and then leaving dissappointed a few minutes after the full hour. The ASTRONOMICAL CLOCK is pretty stunning, considering that it was installed before Columbus discovered America. At that time the only one in the world, they blinded the maker of it so he couldn't create a duplicate. There is plenty of history and back in the days it was a spectacle to see the little figures wave at the crowd. Keep that in mind or you'll be joining the group of people leaving with a big sigh. There are no lasers and spaceships involved...There should be lasers and spaceships involved with the "ORIGINAL PRAGUE HAM", though considering the bold prices... Right in front of the church at the square there are a couple of booths that sell some delicious looking pieces of ham (enough for one and a half person), serve it on a paper plate and make you eat it standing up in the rain (worst case scenaro, of course). And all that for only EUR 25! Fantastic! No, not really. You can stuff your face including apetizer, beers, main course and desert for two people in a restaurant off the beaten path and pay about EUR 20. FREE WALKING TOURS start at 11am and 2pm just to the left of the clock. Get your number from one of the guides with the yellow umbrellas and follow your guide around the city. We went on a fantastic 2.5 hour tour, learned a lot and saw some streets that weren't packed with people. I highly recommend that - I also highly recommend tipping the guide at the end of the tour as that's their only income.
Old Town Square - the heartbeat of Prague. Right in the middle of Old Town, this square has it all - restaurants, mimes, performers, beautiful buildings and many, many people.

The ' must see ' Square of the City. The centre of the tourist area is magnificent in itself. A large square surrounded by shops, bars, cafes and restaurants. It was in a large corner bar that I had my first taste of Absinthe - the preferred sup of various famous painters of years ago, and, after just one I felt at ease, but next ordered a beer !For writers, like my talented wife Jo, in the other corner was a small homage to Kafka, not to be missed if you can prise yourself away from the 'A'.The square is a great central point to investigate other areas. one end leads you to Charles Bridge, the other to - through the stone arches - to some traditional, and inexpensive barsWith a magnifecent clock with a history you must aquaint yourself with and touts selling tickets for various qualities of Opera, this busy and beautifull square is a ' must go 'PS - Try the lanes off it for cheaper restaurants and bars

Center of action, old town square. Having been here before I knew to rent lodging near the square as many things originate here. Even the Visitor's info center with a free computer is on this square. Tours start from here and traditional food is for sale in food booths as well as fancy restaurants. It is also easy to find a cab here or ride in a horse drawn carriage around the hard to walk on cobblestone streets. bring your hiking shoes for this city as you will climb stairs and walk on cobblestone streets.Beautiful place.On the house people gather to see the clock change time and action of the figurines. The best is at noon when more motion takes place.Also take a FREE TOUR, you will tip the guide for his efforts at the end. They really do offer a good service just find one that speaks your language and you can easily understand them.

One of the best squares in Europe. As far as squares go, Old Town Square ranks right up there with St. Peter's Square, Red Square and Trafalgar Square. A feast for sore eyes, there is always something new to savour whether it be other tourists, locals or artists of all makes & models. Very well-known for the famous Astronomical Clock which draws hordes of tourists every half. While looking up, however, don't forget to look down at the 27 crosses on the square to remember the 27 protestant leaders beheaded by the Austrians in the early 1600's. A great place for people-watching from any one of a number of good restaurants.
Lovely square. Really nice square with lots of interesting attractions, cathedral, astronomical clock and tower, even underground access to ancient buildings
Must see place!. It's always a nice place to see, historical and main point of the city, worth to go up to check the view and time to time there is someone to play Trumpet to all 4 sides
People watching. Loads of lovely buildings.astronomical clock.great for people watching(there are plenty of the to watch!)

tourism extravaganza!. Although the weather wasn't too good the place was full of tourists waiting to see the clock perform on the hour. We were delighted to see several bridal parties arriving for their Czech wedding. Found a lovely souvenir shop nearby with bargain prices, always a bonus.
Look for local food. Great at day but better at night, look for local food, if you want to eat in turistic restaurants look for Hotel Prince U

Great place to people watch. This place is always so busy there is so much to see your eyes are jumping from one beautiful building to another. Plenty of restaurant from which you can people watch. On Saturdays there is a wedding every 30 minutes so we were told watching this take place is interesting.

Nobody should (or does) miss it. The square is huge with historic old buildings wherever you look. People stand twenty deep to watch the giant clock ring the hour, the skeleton move and the statues appear from behind the closed windows. THere are street people of many types -- an old man on a hand-cranked instrument singing sad songs, a jazz band, statue people, an Indian chief with parrots, and a man juggling knives. Then there are open seating establishments on many sides.

Prepare for Large Crowds. The astrological clock draws the crowds in as the clock puts on a bit if a show every hour on the hour. There are plenty of crystal shops to browse and restaurants of all shaps and sizes. There's streets to walk up and down and the expensive avenue nearby as well...plenty of people watching and not to be missed.

Lively!. There is always something happening at Old Town Square. One of the liveliest spots in Prague, it is surrounded by restaurants & bars from pricey to cheap offering a mix of traditional czech to international cuisine. There are plenty of stalls as well which offer street food but beware the prices are by 100g so if you are not careful you will end up paying a lot more for the food than stated on the menu. If you are not sure it is better to head for the restaurants where you can get a good meal for a fixed price. There is plenty of live entertainment as well to keep you busy till late at night. The square is quite well lit and certainly adds a lot of character to the old buildings.

A feast for the eyes. Come here in the late afternoon to enjoy the beauty of the old town as it is bathed in soft, warm light, its sharp edges softened by the growing shadows of the approaching evening. When the buildings are illuminated later on, you feel taken back in time and can just imagine Mozart passing by on a carrage on the way to play a concert. .But pay attention to your group - and your pockets and bags- or you might get lost in the crowd as you wait for the astological clock to chime.Magical moments.

A must see square. Nice area with beautifull architecture and lots of places of interest nearby, resturants in the area are over priced. Do not miss out the Astronomical clock and the Church. Try to take a free walking tour from near the clock which full of info.
sit and enjoy the surroundings. I loved the old town square. The buildings are beautiful. I could happily sit in the square for hours just looking at them.
Beautiful, enchanting city. Wonderful people and the square is like a fairy tale. There are food venues about with large hams and beef rotisseries. Good people watching.

Fascinating City No Matter The Weather. This was my second visit to Prague but as my first was when I was 6 and there was a communist government things had changed !!! It is a wonderful city to wander around and while it was very cold and snowed during our visit there was always an interesting place or cafe/bar to call in . Unlike the UK the Czechs take heavy snow in their stride and our journey home was smooth despite a 6 inch snowfall the night before.

Wish I were there now.... The old town square is beautiful, especially at dawn. Try to avoid going there in the early mornings if you don't wanna get drawn in a flood of tourist groups. Lots of interesting street performers--I'm still trying to figure out what the levitation dude's trick is...

Too many structures. Prague felt a little too crowded with buildings and structures. The Old town square reminded me a little of the town square of Bruges. It's nice, but nothing great compared to the town squares at some of the other European cities.
Walking Around. Great to walk in and filled with all levels of shops. Great clothing stores and standard souvenir shops.

Fairy tales enchanting emotion. Never been to Prague? Ok, wait for sunset to get to staromestske namesti, also called Old Town Square or Clock Square...you'll be enchanted by the colors of the gold over the towers of Tin Cathedral, together with the magic that stay inside of the oldest mechanical clock in the globe. You'll feel to live inside a medioeval fairy tale...

Fabulous atmosphere, great people watching!. Best early evening when the street entertainers are taking it in turns to please the passing crowds. Lovely hotdog and ham hock stalls, plus you can get a beer and watch the world go by. My favourite part of Prague by far. The clock tower is a crowd pleaser on the hour, every hour too.

What could be better than.... Shopping and outdoor cafe dining, while being seranaded to music from various locals (from bagpipes to string quartets). You will also see the famous Anatomical Clock that still functions and keeps excellent time in spite of its age -- be there on the hour for a real treat.

Probably the most famous Prague squares. This is where everything is. Astronomical Clock, Cathedrals, street vendors, outdoor restaurants. On the day we went, there were quite a few newly weds taking pics in front of the clock. Perfect place to sit and people watch, let the time go by. All kinds of tours meets and starts here.Be aware of the street food vendors here, Old Prague Ham looks good, but they charge you 89Kr for 100g and only cuts 400g per order. We stopped by for a quick snack, but end up getting a meal portion. We gave what we cannot finish to the homeless guys, but felt we were taken adv of.

See the Celestial clock. If you find yourself in the Old Town Square on the hour, join the crowd around the Celestial Clock to watch the chime. The clock is an engineering marvel showing not only the time, but the phase of the moon, the astronomical period, as well as the astrological time.

Watch the world go by. Great place to appreciate the beautiful buildings, treat yourself to a beer in one of the many restaurants/ bars- although a bit more expensive than other areas it is a great place to people watch and to soak up the atmosphere

A nice square with the Astronomical Clock. It was like most of the square in Europe, with lots of people and restaurants around. You can sit outdoor to have a drink and to feel the romantic atmosphere in Prague. The most crowded place is the Astronomical Clock, and with mechanical performance every hour. A little bit complicated to know the logic behind the clock but just funny to have a look.

stunning architecture and people watching. Prague's old town square is crammed with amazing architecture and beautiful details, from the incredible astronomical clock with its ornate face and moving figures to the gothic Týn Church and impressive St. Nicholas Church. The square is always packed, especially on the hour, every hour when the clock performs its elaborate routine and can get quite overwhelming with the sheer mass of people descending. There's lots of bars and restaurants lining the square where you can take a well earned break and just watch people milling around. After dark the pub crawl touts are out in force, urging people to join one of the many bar crawls, but getting drunk and missing out on the beauty of Prague by night seems like a monumental waste of time to me!

Should not be missed. No point in visiting Prague if you're not going to visit the Old Town Square. Be careful if it's raining - cobblestones become quite slippery and are very uneven in places, so wear some good walking shoes.
Busy. Found it to be very overwhelming. Alot happening so you need to keep your wits about you.much better at night time

breathtaking. I had a flat overlooking the square for a while and I could never have gotten tired of looking out my window at the beautiful architecture surrounding the square as well as at the never-ending liveliness in it.

Very cool place!. I would put this on the top of the list along with the other travelers. We had dinner from a street vendor one night and watched all of the street traffic. Felt very safe at all times and never had an issue with any pick pocketers.

when you want to shop and you have lots of time and you want lots of fun. This is the place to be. this square has many many features lots of shops, and free street entertainment. Many delicacies, and vendors selling their wares and food, on each and every corner, as well quality restaurants where you can eat inside or on the square.

Great place to absorb the Praha atmosphere. They say that only one in four in Prague is a local, so expect to be surrounded by fellow tourists, especially in the old town square. Watch the world go by, while artists ply their trade in the square and the unique Astronomical clock attracts many eyes every hour, on the hour.Take a walk on different routes to Charles bridge from the square and enjoy the hot, freshly baked tasty sugar coated breads on your way.

Visit for old town square church bells. Should try street side food, expensive restaurants not recommended, some of street performers makes worth your time apart from tasking panaromic pictures of whole sqare
Fantastic!. A beautiful square with fantastic old buildings and churches!! Must try the hotdog they sell in the little shops inside the square!

Nothing quite prepares you for it!. I've experienced some big squares (Tiananmen in Beijing, China; the Zocalo in Mexico City), but the Old Town Square has it all: ancient monuments, superb churches, the Astronomical Clock, some seriously good restaurants and beautiful and brightly-hued buildings that outdo even Brussels' Grande Place. Huge crowds gather to witness the quite (and literally) moving spectacle of the 12 Apostles who appear in procession every hour on the hour of the clock, itself a marvel of astronomy and engineering. The clock itself was created in 1490, and is housed in a Tower constructed more than 150 years earlier: it's that sort of history that is so moving. If you're feeling energetic, you can climb the Tower, for a fee, to obtain stunning views over the Old City.In the middle of the square is the monument to the martyred Jan Hus, who was burnt at the stake for heresy in 1415. Further around the square is the St Nicholas Church, elaborately decorated in the Baroque style and featuring not only a huge crystal chandelier in the shape of the Russian Tsarist crown but was given by Czar Nicholas II himself. The Church hosts many frequent concerts and recitals, including especially organ recitals, at either 1700 (Tuesday-Sunday) or 2000 (Friday-Monday). Outdoing St Nicholas in splendour is the Gothic twin-spired Church of Our Lady before Tyn, which houses the tomb of the celebrated Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe (who died in 1601). The church has many beautiful and sumptuously gilded chapels and also hosts orchestral concerts. But note that it is closed to tourists between 1300-1500 and whenever Mass is being celebrated. Be aware that unscrupulous taxi touts near the St Nicholas Church are ever ready to rip off the unsuspecting tourists with unmetered taxis. Rely ONLY on the AAA taxis, all of which are metered.

One of the nicest square in Europe. I like this square. Be there early morning or mid-day or most spectacularly at sunset time! Look at the different building styles around the square - thousand years of history and tradition.

Beautiful Town centre. Apart from Mumbai trains, i have not seen so many people jostling for space in such a small space. We reached this square just before noon to watch the clock tower striking and the articulate figures coming out with every strike. We did hang around the square for half an hour to really feel the spirit of the place. It is beautiful, busy and peaceful at the same time, a very difficult emotion to explain unless you are there to see it.

Start your day with breakfast in a cafe at Old Town Square and wander from there. I recommend starting your walking tour of Prague at the Old Town Square to view the Astronomical Clock and Church of the Virgin Mary before Tyn, then walk onto Powder Tower gate and wander up and around Old Town from there. Every street is filled with gorgeous old buildings that teem with bars, cafes and restaurants. Start out with breakfast at one of the cafes in Old town Square. Enjoy.

A tale city. The old town square and the nearest streets give you a a fairy tale, with black roofs like bad witches castles, music clocks with characters that take life every hour and lots of bars, restaurants markets and shops to make sure that you take something from Prague to your home.

Amazing. There is nothing like Europe during the Christmas season! Prague's markets were incredible, although expensive, and the food was great. The hot wine is a must! & I'm not even a drinker! Totally worth seeing and experiencing.
Beautiful at Christmas in the snow. Stunning markets - fab hot wine to keep you warm and great food stands- like Winter Wonderland exploded.Downside is it can get quite busy and slippy in the snow

Picturesque. This is the typical bohemian scene. Beautiful architecture and a real buzz about the place. Street food looked good, we didn't try any though. Take care with your belongings here as pickpockets are apparently busy here.

Old Town is a place you must go in Prague. The Old Town is the main centre of Prague. There you can see the streets full of people and many attractions that are very interesting. The most interesting is the old clock that has a lot of stories you can find, and is unique in the world.

Amazing. Just look up, look at the buildings and try to forget the crowds of tourists. The astronomical clock draws hundreds every hour. Access to the church on the eastern side is through an arch between 2 restaurants.

Lots going on here!. We enjoyed walking the few blocks to the square from our hotel. You could catch freshly cooked sausage and sauerkraut and eat outside on a nice day or a beer or cider at one of the many cafes. They were having the Race for the Cure one morning while we were there. Lots of shops in every price range

Loved it. Spent every day in this beautiful historic square. There's lots to see and do from restaurants and pubs to shops and market stalls and horse carriage rides, all the horses looked well cared for. The architecture of the buildings and the clock was amazing. There was a good police presence at all times though we saw no trouble. There was a lot of street acts in the square varying from choirs, balloon artists, living statues to sword and fire juggling. We also saw six beautiful weddings while in the square. The Jewish Quarter is just of the square along with all the top shops including Jimmy Choo, Cartier, Tiffany, Dior etc.
Well preserved fairytale square. Beautiful place night or day. Well preserved churches, buildings, statues, a nice clock tower, good food and excellent street performers. What more can you desire???

Resonates with the past. A large, expansive and impressive square surrounded by some very old and majestic buildings. Noisy, vibrant, fascinating and magnetic. It was very busy when I was there but, somehow, that added to the joy of the experience. The cobbled streets can be a bit taxing on the feet (something I noticed having walked five miles on them). Lots of cafe's and reasonably priced restaurants. Lovely coffee. Lovely beer. What more do you want? Like many things in Prague, this is a wonderful place. Went in summer but would love to experience all of it in December. Highly recommended.

A great mix of entertainment. This central square should be your starting point from which to explore the city of Prague. With its mix of architecture, street entertainment, bars & cafes, as well as the astronomical clock, statues & main church, the Old Town Square is always a lively place to stroll through.

Do not miss Old Town Square. As soon as we arrived in Prague we headed to old town square for lunch. It is great people watching with a diverse group of shops and restaurants. The architecture is beautiful. I did not expect to hear jazz while we ate lunch but it was a great surprise. We ate at least one meal there every day and did not repeat a restaurant. Perhaps it is more expensive than other areas but worth it for the atmosphere and astronomical clock.
Lovely slice of old Europe. Beautiful square with food stands, restaurants, musicians, and the Astrological Clock. Great place to grab a bite and a bench and enjoy the surroundings.

You can watch the world go by. This was our favorite starting place for walking and sightseeing, there are a lot of shops, nice stalls that sell food and souvenirs, and people from all over the world! Everywhere you looked you could find a wonderful sight.
Great people watching spot. Some nice restaurants but more expensive than those off the square. Really decent local sparkly wine and a great place to people watch.

You must visit the Old Town Square. We took a walk to the square from our hotel. The atmosphere and architecture of the square is lovely. There are a few people selling tours and horse and cart rides but no one hassles you which is good. We went into the tower (Staromestska radnice) which was 100czh (£3.50) which is a reasonable price. From the top of the tower you get a lovely view of Prague and there is a lift if you can't or don't want to walk. There are some nice bars where you can sit outside and lots of shops and places to eat.
Old Town. Very unique of an old town square, lots of shops and small restaurants. So many people waking around.

Gastronomical!. Enjoyed Old town Square. But beware, if you want to eat at one of the "outdoor" small food court be sure you understand the pricing. We ended up with enough ham to feed four people. You get what they give you and I think they took advantage of us tourists. It was costly and just not worth it. We ate dinner at a restaurant that was recommended by the local tour guide and that was delicious. This area has great shopping.

Very nice and enjoyable for tourists. The square is a busy area with food and sites. Great way to spend an afternoon or night time in Prague just relaxing and eating the delicious food and take in the great views of the architecture around.

Amazing!!. From every angle of the square you will see beauty. This town is simply amazing to see. The structure and architecture is beautiful. There is so much to see and do in this area your head will spin. There are several wonderful restaurants/cafes to eat at. The shopping will take you all day to view each store. The best part of it all is astrological clock. It goes off every hour and you must view it as it goes off. There is always a crowd gathered around it every hour. This clock won't disappoint you. It's the only one in the world like it. Bring your cameras for this clock and the town!!If you have time take a underground tour of the city because there is a lot of the city that is underground that you can't see unless you have a guided tour. Enjoy you visit.
nice paved square. We liked the astrological clock , the size of the square as well as the segways and signed up for a visit on segways
Prague is Beautiful!. Wonderful Old World Feel. Loved outdoor cafes and dinner in an old cellar. Czech food and beer is wonderful. Charming city.

Beatiful Spot. This spot is beautiful, at dust many people gather and relax in the plaza. The astronomical clock is good but I was expecting something espectcular. You can have a snak or a beer in the restaurants around the plaza... I strongly recommend to relax there

Old Town Square for sale. There's been a lot told bout this place. Basically, most of the tourists get there to a) take picture and leave b) have a dinner in one of the innumerable restaurants and comfortably watch the puppet procession c) try to learn something, feel the touch of the antient and different.If you can recognize yourself in the group c), don't go there unless early morning. In other times, the whole place is transformed into a weird kind of open-air supermarket full of pocket thieves. Don't expect anything else but a bunch of locals or settling russians trying to sell you anything, whatever it might be. The second worst place to go during the day and the small hours, however it has no chance to beat the Wenceslas Square with respect to disgust you may feel!!
Lovely. See the Astronomical clock and lots of street performers. Met the actor Jason Isaacs there....made my day.

Vibrant and a must go. When we visited, there was a local food market festival on at the square. It was packed with people, but full of interesting food to try. There were also various local musicians and street performers performing during different times of the day, we thoroughly enjoyed the square.

Center of the center of town. A not to be missed location containing fabulous buildings, outdoor restaurants by the dozens on the square and down side streets, Many events are taking place at the same time and some are very strange. People watching at its best. The old town square is much more fun than Wenceslas which is more a giant oblong than a square.

The astronomic clock. We had the opportunity to visit the clock tower, you can have the greatest views of the city and take pictures that looks like a dream, the old place is full of local and foreigner artists that gives a special touch to your walk.
Buildings are lovely. The buildings are just lovely in the old town square and it gets packed full of people on the hour when the clock chimes
Awesome spot. Old Town Square is good to get lost while exploring this town. Major shopping area and some outstanding vintage hotels and experiences... cant explain in words... just outstanding!

Where the Action Is. During the summer, this square is robust and full of people, activities, entertainment, food vendors, and open air cafes. All points lead back to this square from the radiating side streets around it. Free walking tours all meet at the ClockTower.

Harry Potter film set!. Wonderful square, especially at night when Tyn Church and Town Hall lit up and you feel like you are on a Harry Potter set! Lots of stalls selling food and a real buzz. Tyn church (go through 3rd arch as look at church from square) absolute knock out inside as well as outside. By far the best in Prague.

Everything in one square. Everything you see is beautiful. Anatomical clock and two churches dominate the restaurant/cafe outdoor dining and people watching scene. Music and fun filled acts keep you looking everywhere at once..
Pearl Anniversary. A hive of activity all day with street food and buskers all vying for the tourists. Impressive buildings dominated by the cathedral and clock tower

Stunning buildings. What a beautiful place to sit and people watch over a drink or two. Everything seems to begin and end at this square, guided tours and walks, horse carriage rides, street entertainment etc.The architecture is beautiful and the excursion to the tunnels under the clock tower was eye opening.I would definitely rate this as the place to be in Prague, particularly in the evenings, and wouldn't hesitate to visit again.
A must in Europe. It's Prague, so what else?Watch the little clock show during the day, take the free tour around town.During the night it's also great, just an awesome vibe when you are in it!
Try visiting at night.. Speechless...there ate no words to describe thia beautiful place.Music, great sights, good food...just lovely!

A place that makes you disconnect from day to day life.. Even though it is very crowded at all times, there is something so calming and relaxing about this place... I don't know if it's the architecture, all the teraces, the happy faces of all the tourist passing by, the proximity to so many touristic objectives, the countless street artists or a mix of all, but there is something very special about this place. It doesn't seem like you can get borred all that easily and you feel like time stands still when it actually passes so fast.
picturesque setting.. large crowds but enjoyed all the magnificent historic buildings and monuments that are so well preserved.
Beautiful architecture and history. Loved the old buildings. Well preserved area. Disliked the number of tourist shops selling the same stuff.
Fantastic place. Was a great place to go and watch people, have a drink, watch the clock, take a horse and carriage ride
Does what it says in the guide books. The astronomical clock, the cafe terraces, the architecture - yes, all very touristy but all very nice!

Must Look around the Square. Ignore all the touristy stuff, but just sit down and take a look around. The church with the Astronomical clock, the buildings surrounding the square. The place is brilliant. Love the architecture!Had a bit to eat from one of the stalls set up in the square. Food was delicious (though a bit touristy) classic czech food. Beer available too! Perfect when the sun is out!

Beautiful & Great Atmosphere!. The Old Town Square, is simply beautiful surrounded by outstanding preserved architecture. The atmosphere was lovely , felt safe and cheerful with lots of local dishes being cooked with occasional entertainment. There were plenty of indoor restaurants too. A beer is delicious but relatively expensive sitting under a marquee, however not as expensive San Marco Venice! For me the square epitomised my whole Prague City experience. A more affordable version of Vienna, with its history, culture, architecture, warm friendly, hard working people and delicious local food. I would love to go back again.

Great fun. We sat here quite a lot watching and listening to the various performers and watching the world go by. We sat in one of the restaurants within the square and found it perfectly acceptable. Lots of food stalls round the perimeter, you wouldn't go hungry.

Very nice site. A really nice site, take photos with the famous asronomical clock, but watch for the pickpocketers. A bit crowded, avoid buyin souveniers there, because they're a bit pricy, comparing to street shops nearby.

Very busy square. An amazing part of Prague, the architectural designs of buildings are amazing. A lot of shops selling souvenirs and traditional food. Was very packed and busy but the beauty of this place remains.

Best place to relax. best place for people watching. so many street performers and entertainers around. Don't get carried away by the astronomical clock - its too crowded just watch the fun in the Old town square!

The reason you came here. This is why you came to Prague in the first place: to see the square and everything around. Well, that being said, the square is great but not what I expected... I don't know if that's because I had too much expectations or what, but is just not wow.You have some good restaurants there (if you eat outside is more expensive) and also some good great photo opportunities. The square is wheelchair friendly even when the floor isn't flat.
Why you came to Prague. the smell of the food, the sound of the music and the buskers, the people watching, the whole circus of it all!
Amazing place. This square has so much history and an incredible atmosphere. Really nice a must visit in Prague. Especially doing the free tours around this square is fun.

Brilliant!. This the loveliest square I have ever been to in a European city; the square is full of character with musicians and street performers playing. There are an array of stalls selling reasonably priced food such as excellent sausages and hand cooked crisps. The architecture is just gorgeous, the buildings are full of character and are everywhere you turn. The astronomical clock is beautiful and well worth seeing on the hour. A fantastic place to spend time and soak up the atmosphere of a magical city!
Go up the tower.. The tower has a spectacular view of Prague. And the astronomical clock is there as well. Lots of entertainment in the square. A happening place.

Great atmosphere. We enjoyed hanging out at Old town Square on a number of occasions during our trip. There were great street performers - music, acrobatics, etc. as well as places to eat, drink beer, etc. The architecture is so beautiful and we enjoyed just taking in the sounds and sights.

Exactly What I Expected. We loved old town square with local art and food available to purchase...the only thing that is hard to get use to was while buying food from various cart vendors there are people within sight eating out of trash cans...just something that is hard to forget.
Old Town Square. Super bustling place - just take in the sites - enjoy a ice cream for a dollar - super cheap and so yummy.

Start here. If your not sure where to go, go here! You can eat, drink and be entertained, although perhaps not all at once. Someone will offer you a trip or tour, invite you into their café or you can just sit and watch it all go past you. There are so many things to do and see within a short walk.

Worth to see but don't eat there. No matter what time you go through this square is bustling. Several times we went with my wife through there were events occurring, and this added to the air of business. There were often street performers, some more interesting than others. The focus is the clock at the Old Town Tower, 12 performing Apostles going around at the top of every hour. However the hordes of tourists and young undisciplined and loud visitors are annoying.There are several restaurants around the square, with prices 50-100% higher than their competitors a few blocks away. Also the souvenirs are overpriced. For photographers, it is paradise.

Starting and finishing point for your Prague sight seeing!!. So much to do and see in Prague but Old Town Square is unmissable - whether you just want a beer and watch the world go by, see the street performers, buy amazing street food or souvenirs, take a horse and carriage ride or take in the architecture and history - it all starts here!!
Vibrant city hub. First visited during our bike tour. Cool vibe great people watching. Great value street food. Astronomical clock worth a look but the other buildings were just as interesting

Overcrowded but lively. Here's where all the walking tours congregate so you would be totally swarmed by large tour groups and it can get really frustrating. It's quite the center of old town so you can't miss it really. There's a lot of busking and performances, carriage rides, food and cafes. The streets that lead you to the square are all round souvenir shops. I tried to avoid this area as much as possible once I've visited all the major attractions. For those with a stroller, it's really very cobbled here.
Incredible elegant!. The famous clock, the elegant buildings, the street people, a big mix of people. It's worth going, in a sunny day!
Lots to see!. There was a festival while I was there so there were food stalls and handmade traditional craft stalls in the square. You can also take horse drawn carriage rides from the square.
