This is lovely. step back in time. Ride in a horse drawn carriage and shop in the many shops. Grab a bite to eat or return at sunset for some dinner. Lively square overflowing with visitors and residents. Just great. Go have some fun.

Great and lively place. Loved all the architecture and history in the square. Can get really crowded but in the morning it is pretty empty. Lots of street performers but they are fun to watch. Seemed safe and didn't have a problem with pickpockets but we were also aware of that possibility. Really fun place to be at all times of the day!

So much to see.. It is very crowded but..... It is absolutely amazing to see all the incredible architecture, it is clear that they treasure their history and preserve it for all to enjoy. I spent my birthday overlooking the clock tower and could not believe how lucky I was to be there for my birthday with my best friend and love of my life!
Place every tourist must see. Well, bit overcrowded during the summer season, but also full of street performers. This place is basically must

Cool at any time of day. This is a perfect place for a stroll. It looks great and the street performers in the evenings are really nice. Just be aware of exchage offices in this area. The restaurants and bars are overpriced, but it's worth having a beer or cocktail there.

Mind Boggling!. Its almost too much to try and figure out what to see next and still keep your hand on your purse. The best thing is to book with a tour company because then you can just listen and look without being the planner.
Soak up the atmosphere. A great place to walk, sit and watch. Lots of things going on and wonderful buildings to gaze at around the square. Good fun.

Magnificent place to just soak up the atmosphere. Rented an apartment right on the old square so we could soak up the place every day. Just gorgeous particularly at night when the place comes even more alive with buskers and street performers. Lots of tourists (and those looking to fleece them) but still one of the great squares of the world!
Must see while in Prague!. Just an amazing square with so many architectural pieces to admire. I absolutely recommend this vibrant square anytime of the day!
MAGICAL. The moment i got there all i said was .. " I LOVE PRAGUE". It's a big square with loads of people walking around, surrounded which lots of hypnotizing buildings.

Great for photos and people watching. This area can get very crowded, but is great for people watching. Make sure to go during both the daylight and nighttime hours, since the atmosphere is different.
Magical. Arrived just in time to watch the Astronomical Clock this was great to see, the whole place is just magical visited the square many times and took loads of photos too.

One of the most beautiful squares ever. we went when the Christmas markets were on and it was crowded but pleasantly. A real feel of excitement and so many beautiful Christmas trees and decorations. the architecture is superb of course but it was a real Christmas feeling and felt very special. would recommend Prague at this time of year.

Packed with people. The architecture, street performers and wonderful smelling street food were all good parts of this square.As a traveller on a budget it was a bit frustrating that you had to pay to use what seemed to be the only bathroom available. We also couldn't get in to the church and had to pay to go to the top and look at the view over the square, I suppose we should have expected this! Also the amount of tour groups and people constantly pushing past was a bit of a turn off. But, it was also to be expected to experience the main square of the city!

Favourite Square. One of my favourite squares in Prague, always something happening. We went during Easter and there was an Easter market, with live music, beer, great food, loads of people and an amazing atmosphere. Old city is a fantastic array of architecture and the astronomical clock was my all time favourite :-) I fell inlove with Prague and cannot wait till my next trip.

Beautiful and nice place to sit and relax!. Cannot beat the views your eyes will take in while sitting in old town watching and looking around you. Best place is to pull up a seat at a nearby outdoor restaurant and enjoy a shandy (beer/sprite mixed)...trust me its delish!

Nice city. Prague war a positive surpriseAn old preserved city center with a very mixed architecture.Took a guided tour organized by Prague's airport coaches were very good.I recommend Prague airport coahes for transportation to and from the airport.And the beer was cheap and good :-)

Great town square. The astronomical clock is really fun to watch with a crowd. All of the different styles of architecture make it a one-of-a-kind town square. Food and drink, street performers, and plenty of other charming stuff going on.
Great people watching.. Great people watching, particularly in the evenings after it cools off. In the mornings the tour crowds are annoying.

Favourite area in Prague. There is always something happening here, musicians, dancers, acrobats, horse and carriage rides, you name it its here - this is the beating heart of Prague and full of over priced restaurants, bars and cafes but a must on any visit

A lovely place to sit & people watch. I liked the choice of bars & restaurants & most have seating where you can watch the world go by - It is quite a busy area especially when everyone is rushing to see the clock strike. I loved watching all the different types of city tours, old fashioned cars, bikes horse & carts & mini buses. I disliked all the beggars grovelling on all fours on every cobbled street.

WATCH OUT FOR THE CHEATING FOOD STALLS AND BAD POLICE. At the food stalls along the side of the square opposite Tyn church, my mother tried to buy a 100g portion of ham but the cashier woman saw the 500ck note in her hand and cut her a 400+ ck portion without telling her and, after receiving the note, only gave back a handful of change. My mother then repeated she only wanted 100g but the cashier refused to refund. She blamed my mother for having bad English and not being clearer with how much she wanted and for not recognizing the size of a 100g portion while her coworkers laughed at us. We got very angry and found a policewoman at the square however the policewoman decided to side with the stall people and actually got all sarcastic and also insulted my mother's English before leaving.I was just shocked. The stall people were bad enough but the policewoman actually allowed them to take advantage of tourists knowingly! This made me very disappointed with the Czech police force and it made me feel angry, sad, and helpless. So I recommend you stay clear of these lying cheating business people as much as you can, and when you have to deal with them, always keep your money out of sight until you have asked clearly how much you have to pay and hand exact fare whenever possible or they'll just keep the change and you won't be able to do anything since the police are not only incompetent but corrupt. This happens in restaurants too.

Church of St. Nicholas at the Old Town Square. Not to be confused with the Church of St. Nicholas found across the river in the Mala Strana district, there is another famous church in Prague called the Church of St. Nicholas, which is found directly on the Old Town Square. This is smaller church, styled in Baroque architecture that has been on the square since 1735, built upon the grounds of a much older Gothic church from the 13th century. Inside you can see an impressive chandelier that helps provide lighting for the nice ceiling frescos and stucco decor. The Church of St. Nicholas is also used for nightly concerts which can be purchased at the door upon entry. In the end, while not one of our favourite church visits in the city, it is easy to stop by and see the Church of St. Nicholas on the Old Town Square. We spent no more than 15 minutes during our visit. Other attractions on the Old Town Square, which you can visit as well include the very nice Church of the Virgin Mary before Tyn, the Goltz-Kinsky Palace, the Jan Hus Statue as well as the Old Town Hall building, where you find Orlog - The 'Astronomy Clock'.

Continuous Event. This square is the "middle" of town. You can sit there all day and just enjoy what is happening. From there you will find any number of things to see, do, eat, and wonder around. Most any day the square has hundreds of perhaps thousands of people wandering around - it's huge. From here you can go out in most any direction and enjoy the city, new stuff and old stuff.

Entertainment, culture, food, love. Walk around the square, see the astronomical clock, eat home made crisps, share a big sausage, visit a church or just walk around. The absolute heart of Prague. Must visit! Every day if possible!

THE MAIN place of Prague. everything in prague goes by the old town square, all day long cheap beer and street attractions, there wasnt a day on our trip that we wernet there for at lease couple of hourswe loved this place

PACKED WITH TOURISTS BUT STILL WORTH A VISIT. It's a must see on visit but be prepared for TONS of tourists and few if any locals. Enjoy the square and clock but then move on to the winding side streets and alley ways which are much more fun and interesting for those that prefer to explore.

lots to see. there are lots of street performers in the square to entertain you, VERY busy with crowds, VERY VERY expensive for drink, eg 2 large beers and 2 coca colas 380chk (around £15 !!), the astromical clock is a must see, go to the top of the tower for the best view of prague.
Nice place to visit. The atmosphere on the Square is very nice. The old clock is amaizing. There were musiotions on the Square that played authentic local music that we liked a lot

Picturesque, Bustling, Street food. Lovley views and architecture to admire. The street food is delicious although the ham is overpriced (they charge by weight - you can end up paying 15-10 euros for a plate of ham). The street entertainers fun.
Lovely square. Great for chilling out :) had a lovely sit down watching all the street entertainers there and there's nice bars and food places all around

Very attractive, but crowded in summer. Without the crowds the Prague Old Town Square would be a 5 star attraction. Unfortunately Prague was "discovered" some years ago and crowds are ubiquitous (just one example - groups of young people wearing Prague Pub Crawl shirts come out at night). The best time to take in the architecture on the square is early in the day. Later in the day sit at one of the square-side restaurants and enjoy the wonderful Czech beer. Go some distance off the square to eat where the prices will be better.
Very nice location but poor restaurants. So much history and so much style but to get good service and good food and not be tricked by waiters you have to go outside the area. Just good for drinking.

Astronomical Clock a must. Located between Wenceslas Square and the Charles Bridge .You have to watch the clock at the end of each hour.It features various architectural styles including the gothic Týn Church and baroque St. Nicholas Church, The Astronomical Clock offers a panoramic view of Old Town shop.
Nice. One of the world's great town squares. An absolute must visit when in Prague. Don't forget your camera and show up just before the clock sounds off.

Non stop activity. Always something is happening. Music, dance, food or just watch the astronomical clock tower.Prices of the restaurants on the square are more expensive, so just walk to the nearby streets and prices drops by 20 %.

Only Preserved City of Europe. While staying in Prague, you will, of course visit the Old Town Square which is the heart of the city. Once a thriving market, the square is now a pedestrian area where tourists gather to relax over a drink in one of the many outdoor cafés and restaurants. Don't hesitate to order their best beer even some Germans just go to Prague to drink their famous beer but for me & my wife, Munich's beer is the best. Enjoy this beautiful old city.
Wonderful Place to Visit....Lot's to See. You'll definitely want to be there on the hour when the Astronomical Clock rings to see the magical movements.
Way TOO Crowded. this was way too crowded with tour groups during the day. The local performers are great. The historic band Graf seems to be on the square everyday and they and really good.

Beautiful place. Fantastic historic arcitecture and nice restaruants to visit. It can get a bit crowded though since all tourists end up at Old Town Square sooner or later. Prices are considerably higher on the Square and on Karlova (the street leading to the square from the bridge) compared to neighboring squares and streets. I visited the square in June of 2008, not in 2013 as the review says.

Beautiful town square. This square is absolutely lovely, surrounded by colourful and interesting old buildings, shops, restaurants, etc. it's a photographer's dream! I can't wait to go back and see more of it!

Nice place to hang out and people watc. Watch out for pickpockets- where a money belt. You can also sign up for some tours here and rent Segways. People hang out waiting for a clock to chime on the hour - nice to see how the old clock works with a nice little surprise at the end

Take a look at the Architect style of the buildings around.. Its among a MUST SEE things in prague.just take your few minutes to turn your head around to see what i can say the evolution of Architect styles. There are almost every style back in history of Architect. also if you have time pass the square during daytime and nighttime to see the different view of it,its amaizing.

Maybe the most beautiful city I've seen. This city left me some unexplainable feeling... it's just beuatiful city with nice people, old buildings... and maybe has something that other city's have lost - it has a soul...

Birthday dinner for my wife: Taste and ambience!. We had a major choice to make for my wife's birthday when in Prague recently. Soooo many restaurants on the Old Town Square and they all looked OK. We settled on this one as it had a menu the size of an elephant and could get a front row seat to the whole of life in the square. The service was good, the waiter helpful and attentive to our empty glasses. I ordered the goulash and dumplings and my wife the pike perch risotto. Both were good, as was the beer and wine. The food was very much in a home cooked style. The price was fine. Overall, I would have no hesitation in recommending this restaurant to travelers to Prague.

A beautiful place to people watch. Such a beautiful square. Was there in mid-January, the snow was falling around us and there was a band playing while we drank hot chocolates and mulled wine. Perfection. Plenty of places to grab a drink or a bite to eat and people watch, while checking out the Astronomical clock.

Can't Miss. This is what you came to Prague for. Hustle and bustle, beauty and architecture. All in one place. Crowds were a bit overwhelming at the top of the hour when the clock rings, but wouldn't have missed it.

Magnificent architecture. Don't miss this great part of Prague surrounded by medieval and baroque-era buildings. The Old Town Hall with its beautiful anniversary clock is a must see (plus you can walk up to the gallery for a great view). The Tyn Cathedral was built around 1500 and is quite distinctive vs. other European cathedrals. Unfortunately, not open very often and the entrance is hard to find.

go there !!. A GREAT SQUARE indeed. and it is lovely all the time !! During the day you may watch the lovely buildings around it. At night you may see the lights that adorn such buildings . It is a MUST to visit old town square. Restaurants and cafes are in the plenty but do consider that the prices tend to be on the higher end since it is a very sought after area. Very close to the astronomical clock and the beautiful St.Nicholas church. Worth a visit.
crowded square. Nice square but always crowded. Astronomical clocks are very nice to see but just for once. There you can find horses and small market with souvenirs and traditional food.
Great place to be. One of the best places! You can go there during the day or at night! Always crowded and full of life. Full of bars, restaurants, attractions...
A great place to learn history and people watch. This is where everyone, tourist and local passes through. It is a not to be missed sight. Food abounds, people too. The mix of cultures is right here
Beautiful Square. The old town square is buzzing with life, lots of restaurants, bars, shops and museums. Horse and kart rides in the center, its kept clean and would defiantly recommend going here.
Wow. i like it during day time but i love it even more in the evening as the lights were on! i fell in love with Prague because of this!

Amazing. The Astronomical clock is simply fascinating to watch. It is the oldest working clock (300 years) according to my tour guide. Make sure you book a free city walking tour to get the most value. I highly recommend New Europe tours, they offer a daily walking tour that is based on tips and give you context to the history and background to those major attractions and monuments.

Crowded!. Well, this square is fabulous, but go there later in the evening to aviod the biggest crowds of tourist. As in most of tourist places around the Globe, there can be some thievs so be careful.
Hang Out Here. Great place to be any time of day. Old Town is the place to stay! Their are tours that leave from here. The clock. Grab a beer and just hang out....it is legal to drink on the street.

This is what I picture when I think of Prague. Old Town Square is the beautiful heart of Prague. I was so happy when we actually got to the square, as we had 3 nights in Prague and before coming here, we were finding the place a bit overrated and not as nice as people say. I wish we'd stayed in a hotel closer to this square, then we would've spent more time here, but we were a fair way out unfortunately. We had a fabulous night in Old Town Square - it is picturesque and there is so much to do, plenty of places to eat and shop. The surrounding streets are gorgeous. We climbed up the tower where the Astronomical Clock is, and that was great as it gave us wonderful views of Prague and especially over Old Town Square. It's a shame the rest of the city isn't as beautiful as this square!
Lovely square. Definitely worth a visit - you can see the clock and just hang out for a while. Great views here too of the cathedral!

lovely place. sit down at the cafe and watch the clock chime or just get lost in and aroung the square. althougth i have not taken the slightly pricey tour you can take a carrage ride, also the black and white building next to the clock is a piece of artwork.

Tourist Paradise. This is a tourist paradise and thousands of tourists congregate here. It's bustling, full of people, full of energy with so much to see and admire.
Awesome architecture, quaint, museum, bazaars, eateries etc
Beautiful place to visit. Old Town Square looks fabulous day or night . Lots of eateries and bars to choose from .Definitely worth a visit

Go early in the morning. Old town square is a lovely place to be without sharing it with thousands of tourists so go early to enjoy the lovely architecture and the clock show for 1 minute each hour on the hour.
places to eat and shop are much cheaper a few streets away from the square.

the big tourist gathering. beautiful setting with great architecture. the clock is here also. the streets are very confusing so my suggestion is to bring a map if you get lost but don't use it to get around.

One of the most beautiful places on Prague. The Old Town Square, that is a real history. And also a lot if beautiful buildings, nicely reconstructed. And the astronomical clock. And churches. And statue of Mr Jan Hus in the middle. And a lot of tourists. And the zero meridian just crossing the square. And a lot of expensive restaurants. And tourist shops. And ...So, at all, Go there and spend there some time.

Good, but.... If you want to feel like a sardine, this is the place to go. Granted, it's a must-see in Prague, but be forewarned that it is packed, noisy, and surrounded by tacky tourist shops. However, it makes a great meeting point, and if you branch off of the square you'll find many more interesting shops that are more than just the typical tourist knick-knacks.

Old Town Square. Three ways to see this square. First with a Tour Guide to point out all the fabulous points. Second for yourself to take longer to experience the crowds and experience. Then final my favorite - early Sunday morning - because No One is there. It is like a ghost town with all the shops closed and no is there. It was beautiful.

The heart of Old Town. You should end up here after the walk across the Charles bridge. Plan to be here at round hour to experience the performance of 6th century astronomical clock performance.. Also, you can climb up to Old Town Municipal House towel for great view of the place. Enjoy the glass of beer, coffee or hot wine (only during winter), Prague ham, salty potato pancakes or sausage in the street buffet (more authentic - I recommend that) or restaurant terrace.
colourful. try and avaid the high season as this square is worth spending time in but with thousands of others it is not so good.

gorgeous architecture, teeming masses. If you're visiting in the summer, the height of the tourist season, keep your ears open and over the course of 5 minutes you're likely to hear more than 6 or 7 languages.

Nice clock, shame about the tourists. the astronomical clock is a wonder to behold. alas my enjoyment of it was spoilt by many of the other tourists who thought it was OK to barge through crowds and push people out of the way to see it. and alas most of these were Americans. I don't know what it was about this last weekend but prague seemed to be a mecca for loutish behaviour. Still, the cafes and restaurants around the square were fine and very reasonably priced.

One of the most beautiful places i've visited.... Old Town Square looks fabulous day or night but try and visit in the evening when Tyn Church is lit up, it's like something from a fairy tale. Lots of eateries and bars to choose from as well as stalls selling hotdogs, crepes etc. Definitely worth a visit.
a very large square. very pretty. a great place to eat local food and ice creams. starting point for many tours and buggy rides. lots of Bars and cafes. like most town squares. full of tourists

The best place in Prague!. It was love from the first sight. During our 4 days in Prague we've been comming back there at least once a day. The fantastic atmosphere of beautiful, diversified, old buildings as well as the actors, singers and dancers performing at the Old Town Square make it a special place, where you can feel the atmosphere of late centuries. Many tours start here and there are resteurants and bars where you can order your food and have some rest. We loved a medieval band called Bohemian Bards. They performs at least two times a day and if you are lucky you may witness their outstanding performance of playing old instruments and singing traditional Slavic songs.

Many Sites to See. Head to the clock tower and you and you are in the middle of the fun. Hard Rock Cafe has the best staff of all we have been to. Watch the anatomical clock at the top of the hour, see the street preformers, and eat some of that meat they are cooking on the spits/BBQs...

Colourful Square.. This place is unreal! Myself and my wife really enjoyed our trip to Praque. This square has something for everyone, churches, restaurents, architecture, food on the street, cocktails and beer on the move, plenty of monuments to be seen along the way. My wife loved the cocktails , we both thought the drinks on the go was a great idea! This square is so colourful with people, food and classic monuments. Lots of people about, felt very safe. It was a great experience for the both of us.
Lively. A really lovely square for people watching with many bars and restaurants. We were there during the Prague Marathon which finishes here, and was a great place to be.

There is so much to see in this square and the more you visit, the more you appreciate all that is there.. The churches are enchanting in the evening light.the restaurants are all very special. There is always something happening to watch and wait for.
architecture. A great place to people watch but eat at restaurants away from the square to avoid tourist traps; well-preserved but not unlike other city squares in Europe
a must see. The architecture is phenomenal, as it is in so much of Prague. You can't go to Prague without spending time in Old Town Sqiare.

Music and a show at every spot. Where ever you go you meet people playing an unusual musical instrument or putting on a show.People are standing and watching and the sound of the bells in the back-it puts a big smile on your face.
everyone has to go here. anybody visiting Prague must visit the Old Town Square. it is so charming and a great place to have lunch and just sit back and admire your surroundings.

Buzzing with Activities!. Forget the Old Town Hall and Astronomical Clock! Sure it's in the square so you can say you've seen it. However, the square itself is buzzing with energy and excitement. Everywhere you look, there's tourist, packed stores and restaurants, street food, beer on the go and people watching. Take it all in.

Travel back in time. Old Town in Prague has a beautiful energy with the people, musicians, trams and horse drawn carriages, not to leave out the building that have stood time...not been destroyed in bombings or otherwise. Some folks might feel that it is too crowded but those who are willing to explore can spend days just in the lanes, pubs, restaurants and cafes. Would love to go back.
YET ANOTHER SITE TO VISIT. The town square was of course, wonderful, with local people and visitors everywhere. The shops, stalls etc were very special and we loved every minute of our investigating.
The prettiest old town square. Although it is jam-packed and the food choices there are best avoided, this is easily one of the best-looking squares I've been in.

So much to do and see!. This is the tourist hub in Prague for a reason. In medieval times, it would have been the heart of the city. There are monuments, tourist attractions, street vendors (you must try a Trdelník), and street performers. We saw an amazing marionette ballet. Just a cool place to spend some time.

Lovely but busy. Pretty buildings but lots of people (as expected). Some food outlets are pricey (such as the old Prague ham at about £15 for a chunk of ham and 2 slices of bread) but lots of other outlets are reasonable.

Pricey. Very nice, big city square. There is a tourism office at the edge of the square (in the direction of the river). Horse drawn carriage rides seem to be a focus. There is a candy shop where you can watch candy being made. Be warned...prices are very high.  Smoked ham and bread cost us about $15 Canadian per person. Tasty, but expensive compared to the outlying market area. Prices definitely decrease the further you move from the square.The museums were quite expensive and we would not be in Prague long enough to take advantage of the Prague Card which would have cost a fair amount for our limited stay, but would have got us  into museums either for free or at a significant discount. Something to be considered for an extended stay.

Loved it, our favorite Prague place. LOVED old town square. After touring around it in 2 days we spent the rest of our 4 days sitting in the square people watching, eating icecream, and getting cocktails to go. So picturesque and tons to watch and see. Loved it

Cheerful!. It is really different from other central squares, it is so joyful that you feel the powerful energy and happiness, you feel like smiling.
The only problem is that you need to be careful about pickpocket issue. It gives you an unsafe feeling but the joyful atmosphere outweighs it.

Nice things to see but better places to eat. Although the old town square has things to see like the clock and performers, it's very busy and expensive to eat there. We paid double there for food, when 5 mins away it was much less. People were very load and it wasn't a brilliant atmosphere or good service although we seemed to get lucky on the food as it was good, although we did see people looking less then impressed.

Salvador Dali And Alfons Mucha Exhibition. Great little gallery in the Old Town Square (Staromestske namesti), you have two floors of art. Top floor is Mucha, not very exciting unless you are a Mucha fan. Second floor hosts a really good collection of Dali, as well as a nice museum shop with excellent art books. Look at the photo below to locate the gallery. Once you are at the Old Town Square it's easy to find it, stand in front of a Tyn Church and you can't miss it.
great atmosphere. in the centre of old town, great atmosphere, always many people, great buildings, you must see this place when you visit Prague,

Lovely and picturesque place. The square has some nice restaurants and cafés where you can sit and admire the architecture and street life. If you want nice photos you better come in the evening when there are lots of lights on the facades.

Crowded yet pleasing. People abound in this square, and for good reason. There is fabulous architecture, great street performers, and some tempting eateries. It is a good choice if you want to people watch or just hang out. It is a must see purely for the architecture it holds.

Nice place to empty your wallet. Looking for a place where everything is expensive? Look no further. The restaurants serve miniature portions for twice the price, and small beers cost over 90 CZK. If the stores and restaurants don't rob you, the pickpockets will. There's street performers everywhere and loads of other people who want your money.Protip: walk straight to the astronomical clock if you want to see it, then get away. There's no reason to be staying around for more than 5 minutes.

Beautiful place, capable of being a tourist trap. Don't get me wrong - the place is wonderful, and no visit to Prague would be complete without seeing it, but keep your wits about you. It's not the overpriced (relatively, it's Prague after all) cafés or the souvenir selling shops all around that I would advise against, but rather the small booths selling varieties of street food. Their prices look very reasonable until you discover it's pr 100 grams, and you have no control over the portions size. So, in conclusion : see it, around the turn of the hour if possible (to see the astronomical clock), but don't be fooled into buying horrifically overpriced sausage with a side of potatoes/cabbage :-)
Old Town Square, think of it as an intersection. FILLED with non-czech tourist scammers. Want to buy something trashy ? This is the place. Its not a place to enjoy a break, nor a bite.

tourist trap aaahhhhh. If you like Venice Beach, Times Square and Mall of America then you'll love Old Town Square. Street performers, cops, and tons of people abound. It's crowded with tourists and it's the only place in eastern Europe I moved my wallet from my back pocket to my front. Expect to pay tourists prices.

Worth a visit. We were able to visit this square on a day basis as it was very close to our hotel, and easily accessible on foot. Whether during the day or at night it never ceased to amaze me howmany people seemed to be dallying around! Couples groups and organised tours flocked to see the baroque style architecture and the clock within the clock - though it must be said ...the crowds who waited in anticipation prior to the striking of every hour was not terribly impressive.... To us of to the majority of on-lookers.... It was obvious that a lot of folks didn't feel the wait was worthwhile.Whilst we were in Prague we noticed with interest the building of a stage in the square centre - it turned out that a jazz festival was to take place there on the Thursday night. We went back to participate and enjoyed the entertainment very much indeed.

Old Town Square. When in Old Town Square pay to go up in the Clock Tower! The views are wonderful. We went up late in the day, there was no wait and not crowded. Stay after dark in the square to see the buildings lit up. It is very beautiful. Enjoyed 2 meals at the Hotel U Prince outside and loved watching the people in the square.

Nice but Crowded. The square is very nice, even comparable to places such as the Grand Place in Brussels. if you've visited other Western Europe capitals such as Brussels, Paris, London, Vienna etc, it will be difficult to be truly impressed. But if you remember that Prague is an ex-communist capital, you will definitely begin to recognize its value.the place is quite crowded and there's a terrace right in the middle of the square which has the most rude and unpleasant waiters and the dirtiest glasses i've seen in Prague, but other than that, it's the place to go!

Hot Ham Stalls on Old Town Square. When in Prague be aware of the ham stalls on the old square. Not all of them are what they appear. They will have sign saying 89kr per 100gm but they do not tell you that there is a minimum that you have to buy until after you have ordered. You will end up paying nearly as much as what a nice meal at a good restaurant would cost. The stall to avoid is the one CLOSEST to the church with the clock.

Tourist trap. This is a very nice square spoiled by the overwhelming feeling of 'give us your money' It is crowded all of the time until very late in the evening. The cafes don't want you to sit down unless you are buying a meal even if they have empty tables. The food stalls are very expensive. It is so easy just to step out of the central area and find much nicer places to eat, drink and people watch.

Very romantic. Its so romantic here. Its still rated as my favourite location in all of europe. You will see the twin towers of Our Lady before Tyn on the back ground, and you will see the Town Hall Clock Tower as well. You get musicians playing their fiddle... while we were sipping away our hot wine.

Beware the intriguing ham/sausage/potato street stalls!!!!!!!!. ok pretty square and a "must see" on your trip so go early, admire the buildings, take pics, admire the clock,sit on the Free benches and people watch but for gods sake SPEND YOUR MONEY ELSEWHERE!! It's also sad that it makes me feel better that i was not the only person (half) scammed by the food stalls that surround the square!!!! SERIOUSLY AVOID!! DO NOT be fooled by the stream of constant people they are endlessly serving!! Having seen a dish of cabbage,potato and ham i decided to try it as, at 49k i figured it was only a couple of quid if i didnt like it so got two for me and my hubby handing over 200k note when the vendor stated it was 590k (around £22 for what amounted to two small plastic bowls of bubble n squeak) i immeadiatley told him to take one back!!!! sad thing is i realised straight away how much he was charging me but its clear from reading reviews other people cant have! so we put it down to experience and moved on! still it nagged at mefor the rest of the day especially when we then went to the prague beer museum and spent all afternoon drinking for less than that piddly bowl of cold potato cost!! :/

Magical, especially in the evening. This square is really amazing. Full of gorgeous baroque buildings, plenty of restaurants and small shops.You should visit earlier in the day to avoid the floods of tourists but try to visit in the evening as well, when the atmosphere is worthy a fairytale setting: beautiful lighting of buildings, street performers and horse carriages...

Pretty but atmosphere off putting. Very pretty town square with the tower and church however the atmosphere isnt as great as other european cities with annoying and loud music and dancers everywhere which can ruin the town square, however very pretty place to go!
Beautiful Square. A must see in Prague!! I was there in July and there was also a jazz festival which was excellent.If you are in Prague you will find yourself walking by this main square
What more is there to say. Packed with tourists for a reason, it is a beautiful square wit ha unique clock. It is worth climbing the clock tower as the view is incredible.

the most magestic square in the world!. This is absolutely the most magical square I have ever been in in all of my travels!! Truly Disneyland in real life!! Never have I seen such a dream-like fairytale setting, especially at night! Downright Magical!

Great place to people watch. A large square filled with beautiful buildings, restaurants, and countless tourists. Plenty of places to shop or pick up souvenirs. The place is best to view the buildings in the morning before there are too many people around yet.

Great fun and atmosphere. The Old Town Square was just plain good fun. Street performers, sidewalk cafes, inexpensive snacks like gelato. While we were there some sort of fete was going on and there were stands selling the most incredible Palacinka (giant dessert crepes). At night the lights and depleted crowds make it almost romantic. We thoroughly enjoyed our walks through the square several times a day.

Magical square. It is located near the old Jewish town not to far from Charles Bridge and other attractions of Prague. You would find here more of the same amazing architecture of Prague and of course - the famous Astronomical clock. You should come visit it twice: during daylight and at night.

Absolutely Breathtaking. This is the place to be, everything goes on here from street artists to performers to wonderful restaurants and quality Czech beer and of course the Astronomical Clock (or the Prazsky Orloj ) The clock was first installed in 1410, making it the third oldest astronomical clock in the world and the oldest one still working.The Orloj is mounted on the southern wall of the old town city hall in the old town square. The clock mechanism itself is composed of three main components: the astronomical dial, representing the position of the sun and moon in the sky and the display various astronomical details: " the walk of the Apostles " a clockwork hourly show of figures of the APOSTLES and the moving sculptures - notably a figure of death ( represented by a skeleton ) striking the time; and a calendar dial with medallions representing the months.Also there are plenty of shops especially Designer shops to walk around and purchase items.Certainly a place to visit when visiting Prague

Awesome place to visit. This place is awesome! People do random things on the plaza. There are good resturants all around the plaza. There are high end shops like Burberry, Cartier, Roberto Coin, Tiffany, etc right off the plaza and the architecture is amazing! Don't miss it!
Beautiful sites sourround. the Old town square is full of historic buildings and also full of other tourists like yourself. I recommend stopping first thing in the morning, before it fills up.

Magical baroque downtown. I'm in love with a lot of places of Europe, but I have to say that Prague is really one of the most beautiful..... this downtown place is so baroque, old, rustic, magical, with many coffees, great for city walk and sightseeing. And the astronomical clock is the best, I saw another ones, and this one was the most interactive. The only negative thing about here were the people, idk, they weren't so nice.
Where the action is. Well, you have to come here, don't you? And you can't miss it anyway. So much to see, so many places to visit, so much going on - any time of day.

Ambience of ye olde world Prague. Like most European cities Prague has a vast Sq
full of restaurants, tourist shops and of course the famous Clock, with changing of figures on the hour(until 9pm). So relaxing to sit and relax whether eating or just having a cool drink and soaking up the ambience.
Must see!. The one place everyone should visit. Beautiful churches, cafes, street performers. Very crowded! Good restaurants and cafes all around the area.

Can't visit Prague and not see the main square!. Beautiful square - make sure you see the famous clock show (every hour), try some food from the vendors and go up into the clock tower for some breathtaking views.

breathtaking. Absolutely breathtaking sight, especially at night when you can see why it is said to be one of the most beautiful cities in Europe.
A must see tourist attraction. The old town alone would have me coming back to Prague many times in the future. Stunning!

A lively part of Old Prague. This was probably my favorite place in Prague, and that's saying something!It is a very large square, surrounded on all sides by beautiful facades and a large church and tower on one side. All around are cafes and entertainers/performers, which make it a fascinating tableau. I recommend taking a bit of time and relaxing in one of the cafes near the center to watch the magician/juggler/acrobat/dancer or whoever else is putting on a performance as well as the hoards of tourists making their way through the square. It's really not to be missed.

More Great Sightseeing and People Watching. In the heart of Old Town this square had everything together in one location. The Astrological clock is breathtaking, there are street performers, really good food vendors and of course cold Czech beer. We stayed here for at least an hour soaking it all in.

"Magical". The Old Town Square is somewhere you definitely need to visit when you are in Prague. There is something magical about it, especially in the winter when the Christmas Markets are there, but in the Summer there are Jazz Bands playing and everybody just looks so happy. I danced with my mum who is 83 and this is a memory I will have for the rest of my life. This is truly a wonderful place.

Nice location, a bit pricey, beware pickpockets. Great place to go on a summer’s day and reminded me of Italy. It contains Amazing architecture and street performers in the square, particularly a piano player who takes requests.Just to be warned, pickpockets are common here. So be wary, just keep an eye out for people following you. The other warning is that prices are hyper inflated in proximity to the square, I advise if you’re getting anything to eat or drink get it on one of the sides streets that spur off Main Square.

Interesting Spot, but Crowded. This is an obvious must see in Prague. There are lots of interesting tourist spots like the astronomical clock, however, be warned that it is a rather disappointing event, but still worth seeing. There are many restaurants and cafes in and around the square, but be careful as many are quite more expensive and you will end up paying a lot more than you should for the same food in some of the less crowded areas of the city. The square is usually quite crowded, but this is to be expected with any major attraction in a large city.

Beautiful. On a hot summers day this was truly a surprise and compares very favourably to places like Brugge and Brussels.Plenty of architectural delights, street entertainers and eateries from food stalls to high class restaurants.Definitely a place to,remember and one I hope to return to.

Nice Square, but quite loaded with tourists. In this square you will find lots of buildings which are key to visit in Prague. Because of this reason it is also full of tourist and tourist shops, which reduces the magic of this nice square a bit. Anyway when in Prague you still need to visit it. Sometimes there are some small music performances which are of very high quality. When you want to go out for a night also visit this place, we ended up on a small Jazz festival with a very nice band.

What a scene of history and arts!. Yes, it can be crowded during tourist season, but it is surrounded by historic buildings, museums, and churches. Check out the churches for various types of musical performances, some free and some with nominal fee. A number of street performers, including some great jazz combos.

Amazing!. Just standing at the top of this amazing tower makes you shiver with delight. It is one of the most beautiful things I have seen and you can see Prague at its best on a beautiful clear day. You must watch the clock strike on the hour too!!

The vibrant heart of old town Prague. We really enjoyed this area as it is full of historic buildings, restaurants and music clubs. If you wanted to only stay in this area you could happily entertain yourself for days.
Too many tourists in the summer. The town square was alive with music, and mimes and assorted tourist entertainment. No place to sit.

Very nice place. With its beautiful architecture and splendid building facades, it’s worth the visit. Plan your visit to be there in time to see the show at the astronomical clock. Don’t forget to be aware at the pickpockets.

Lively!. Every hour watch the saints peek from the clock tower, wonder at the beauty of St. Nicholas Church, enjoy the mimes, listen to the music, eat from a street vendor, have a drink at a cafe, then meander down the lanes leading from the Square for more surprises.

Hard To Miss. You will not miss Old Town Square. If you plan to head to see the famous clock, or even the iconic Church Of Our Lady Before Tyne, then you will naturally end up here. It has a nice vibe with some really nice cafes in the center where you can spend some time people watching and even preparing to see the chimes of the famous astronomical clock which chimes on the hour every hour and attracks the swarms of tourists. About a 30 second walk from this clock and the surrounding cafes includes the Church Of St Nicholas. Its small but check it out. The Interiors are nice and its free to go inside and have a look.
Old town square. Interesting but busy. Lots of fun attractions but this is Tourist Centrale for Prague. Liked the clock, disliked the expensive food!

Very pretty. Lovely square, pretty and beautiful architecture. However, I agree with some reviews that the prices are quite high. However, this is to be expected in such locations I suppose! There are plenty side streets etc to go to instead with lovely restaurants for a bite to eat or drink!

Great spot. Prepare to just wander around. Buy a few beers (80 Czech dollars) tasty hot dogs (60 czk dollars) watch the various street performances (top quality).
Soak up the atmosphere and appreciate the impressive and varied architecture!

Very pretty. The Old Town Square is a really nice part of the city. There are bands and performers around, along with various walking tours but the square never seemed to get too packed.It was a nice place to sit and have a light lunch or a drink. It's also really fun to watch everyone mill around the clock when it gets close to the hour.

So Much Energy! All ages from all over the world,. The town square was full of happy people of all ages from all over the world. The vendors were mostly friendly, the food was delicious, many theaters and great shopping from cheap souvenirs to high end designers.

People watching. Super place to go for a great atmosphere. If nothing takes your fancy, just sit and people watch. Plenty eating, drinking places available, but the we were there in brilliant sunshine. Different story in the wet maybe. Police presence which is reassuring.

Wonderful. Wonderful atmosphere and live music. Feels like a mini festival. Give this place a wonder. There are lovely food stalls and you can go up to the tower and keep great views of prague from a birds eye view!
Beautiful place. Simply beautiful place. Even if you don't do any activity you will enjoy your time. The 20 second show of the clock is simply adorable. I am glad I was there.
Less crappy stores, please. So the buildings are absolutely beautiful, so can't you zone out the T-shirt shops and the foot massage shops and other junk? Really spoiled it for me.

The place to go in Prague. This is a must do in Prague and is packed to the brim with tourists. The astronomical clock (which is overrated in my opinion), the gothic Tyn church and St. Nicholas church are all here. Get some local ham from the food stalls and soak in the 600 year old buildings and a nearly 1000 year old history. This is where a lot of people were thrown out of windows (yes, that was in vogue in those times), beheaded or executed over the years. The site of trading, important declarations etc. Go there already !

People Watching!. This is a great place to just hang out at one of the outdoor cafes with a coffee or a beer (make it a Bud - a real Czech Bud, that is) and watch the passing parade for an hour or so.
Astronomical Clock. A little "show" on the hour every hour is cute. take a tour of some sort to find out the history of the clock - it's much more interesting when you know the history!
Great views. Amazing architecture every building seems more impressive than the last. Don't spend too much time at the clock. It's cute but very crowded.

Beautiful. A square full of beautiful buildings with a vibrant and bustling atmosphere. There is a wide selection of bars and restaurants as well as wooden huts selling authentic, on-the-go food (crepes etc). There is always someone performing or playing music in the centre. The Old Town Square is a great place to order some beers and just watch the world go by.

Go there and wait for the clock to work!. Nice place. Must do for tourists. The clock tower is the star of it. Go and pay to climb till the top of the tower and take some nice pics. Be aware of pickpocketing as it is very crowded.

Enchanting. Old town square is just breathtaking; that's when you know you've truly arrived in Prague. The architecture is just beautiful with several different kinds surrounding the square. It's very crowded so be mindful of pickpockets. One of my favorite parts of prague was grabbing some street food and a beer, sitting by the fountain in center square and watching the surroundings. There's always multiple music performances, magic shows, or just sit and people watch! Just being near the Tyn church was amazing, just breathtaking. There's also the famous Astronomical Clock in the square as well which is always packed. There's tour guides in the center in case you want to grab a tour (I recommend Prague Royal Walk Free Tour, the guides with the yellow umbrellas, just awesome). You'll love it. Just don't be a typical ignorant tourist and eat in a restaurant in the square, you will get the tourist price along with it.

no crowds in the early morning. I dragged my husband here at least 4 times to catch a little video of the clock and to get the "perfect" picture. When we were there the first toll was at 0800.... and there was only one other person there to enjoy it. Perfect for unobstructed viewing. Later in the day the plaza came to life with various small shops and food vendors. Fancy shopping just around the corner and a Starbucks for those looking to satisfy a craving. Worth a visit, time it right to see the clock chime!
Can feel the history. Great old building surrounding the square. Lot of restaurants and snack places. Great feeling overall. Watch oit for pocket thiefs.

Bustling. No matter what time you go through this square is bustling. Several times we went through there were events occurring, and this added to the air of business. There were often street performers, some more interesting than others!The focus is the clock, and this increases as the top of the hour approaches, and the parade of disciples appears across the top (about one minute total).There are several restaurants around the square, we ate at an Italian the same side as the Tyn church, that was very nice.

All roads lead to Old Town Square. Great people watching here, and it seemed that no matter what street or what destination we were headed, we passed through Old Town Square. The city's pre-eminent tourist attraction is located here, the Astronimical Clock, and you must be here on the hour for the 20 second performance.I was reading about pickpockets that are supposedly abundant especially in Old Town Square, but we had no issues. You just need to pay attention to where you are. I live in New York; there are pickpockets in Times Square, too, but if you pay attention to your surroundings, you'll be safe.Lots of little stands to grab snacks, gelato, sweets, street meat, etc.

A great centre. Old Town Square is the best place to sit and chat with friends in the evening, having a drink and watching the crowds thin out until it is just a few people milling around here and there. From the square, you can watch the lights come on around the city, illuminating the church and the Old Town Hall, as well as the castle up on the hill. (If you want to impress your travel companions, you can inform them that the financier for the lighting up of the church was none other than Mick Jagger!)Much of the good evening entertainment surrounds the Old Town Square, so this is a great meeting point before a night out to a club, pub or a jazz club.

A busy town Square. Have been to better. . A busy square and ok if this is the only place you are going. The clock is interesting but does nothing spectacular. The Dumo square in Milan or the market Square in Krakow was more interesting in my opinion.

Great square....lots of tourists. Old Town Square....how to describe you...you are interesting and fun. From the beautiful architcture to the astronomical clock to the outdoor restaurants to the funny guy in the "indian" suit doing his somg and dance. Prices at the reataurants are higher than elsewhere, but that is pretty standard in the tourist-traps.

well preserved facades and buildings. Seeing the towers of the Tyn church is amazing at night. It's like a magic fairy tale. However there were far too many drunk people and litter on the pavement. Perhaps it was like that because it was aSunday night. The next morning everything was clean and beautiful

Lovely place to watch life go by. If you have the time to sit around, all kind of things are going around. From the horse drawn carriages driven by people with top hats, to many street musicians and showmen to the many diverse restaurants set up, you can have a great time. Otherwise, there is a lot of window shopping (or real shopping if you prefer) to be done. Check out the Bohemia Crystal shops around the corner.

Busking, vibrant fun place to visit. Looks like Disneyland. Lots of people, historical buildings, wear good shoes and watch your bags and pockets. Seems like the clock is a great attraction especially when it chimes !!

The Old Town Square. This area was bustling, despite the rainy day. It's a great area to while away the time, with many cafes and bars. It's fascinating to see how people congregate to watch the Astronomical clock chime on the hour. It seemed to be a popular place for weddings too. There are musicians and an abundance of 'living statures'.

Great Atmosphere. Its a great place, lots of bars, pubs, restaurants around of all types. Great architecture, and historical buildings. All tour companies have their kiosks there. Its a must place to visit.
Good street entertainment but huge crowds.. The crowds can be overwhelming here at weekends especially in front of the Astronomical clock on the hour.

The heart of Prague !. Great starting place to visit Prague. Go up the Town hall bell tower as the views are wonderful....take the lift !Lots of action,enjoy a drink and people watch from one of the many restaurants around the square.Or take a horse ride through old Prague. A beautiful city !

A dynamic and entertaining location. Music, culture, great food and good scenery.The Astronomical Clock is the feature attraction as it should be.A vibrant Square not to be missed if you are in Prague.

A Must See In Prague. We loved strolling in and around Old Town while we were in Prague. Every turn introduces you to a new street with interesting shops and restaurants. Enjoy your stroll and don't hesitate to visit all of the nearby streets and shops.

Interesting and Full of Beauty and Culture. The Old Town Square is a great place to spend several days. Lots to see and do. Just walking around and soaking in the architecture and surrounding area is enough but add in concerts, tours, boat trips, restaurants and people watching and you have a great excursion.

Beautiful. I am always in awe every time I visit Old Town Square. It never ceases to amaze me with its beauty. I would recommend just looking at things, though, as the restaurants, bars, and clubs in the area are expensive. If you are shopping for souvenirs, go to a bunch of shops to get the best prices. Almost all of the shops have the exact same things, and the farther out you go, the better the prices are.You can pay a small fee to get to the top of the Astrological clock, and that is totally worth it, and there are deals to get in to other towers as well.

Lovely place, expensive. Like everywhere you go, if you want to eat cheap, go back a few streets. Its a big tourist place so there is lots of opportunity for businesses to take advantage of hungry, thirsty tourists!
Beautiful. The highlight of Prague. Make sure to see the astronomical clock on the hour and find a time to get into Tyn church, if possible.

nice but overpriced. This is the histirical hearth of the city, it looks very nice and this is also where most tours start. Walk around and enjoy the buildings and admosphere but don't get ripped of by the overpriced restaurants or the pickpockets! Most tours starts around the town hall - astronomical clock.
IT'S AN EMBLEMATIC PART OF THE CITY. The only critic that I could note was that the square was really crowded.- You have nice bars and restaurants and some buildings that are amazing.-
Beautiful architecture/rich history. The old town square is always bustling with activities and tourists in the day. But the splendid buildings around it makes it worth it to be there.

Breathtaking architecture. Just as the title says. The architecture was breathtaking and the square was lively and busy. There are good bars and restaurants around the perimeter - great if you want to relax and people watch. To observe the astronomical clock is a must.

Beautiful Make sure you see the clock!. The Old Town Square is a must see in Prague. Make sure you go around to the side of the old town hall and see the clock. Also, there are tons of booths there with crepes and sausages, etc. There are many, many tourists here though.
A must see!. It embodies Prague! A must see for the novice Czech visitor. Very safe but be careful of pick pockets.

Fun and spirited square. There seems to be something fun to look at in the old town square come rain, or come shine. Music being played, beautiful carriages with brides and grooms, and the elixr of foods being cooked. All supported with the backdrop that made us feel we had been transported to a mystical land.
Just Beautiful.. Old Town is wonderful and the history is awesome. Take a Segway tour and this expands your knowledge and sites it the city as well.

Vibrant area. We enjoyed sitting at a restaurant in the square people- watching. The square contains many historical, elegant, Romanesque, Baroque and Gothic buildings. Shopping in the market place is popular. Jugglers, rappers and musicians show their talent.

Beautiful. A beautiful place, no vehicles - encircled by restaurants, stores, etc that are housed in buildings that were mostly built in the 1500's or before. A really, really nice place to walk around.
great place to hang out. really beautiful square and great food surrounding it. lots of history and really cool astronomical clock- loved this city!

Storybook land comes to life!. While this is true of both old (pre 14th century) and new (1385-1900's) town's, nowhere is this more crystalized than in this historic square considered by locals as the "heart" of the city. It is bustling and vibrant and filled with unbelievable architectural gems amidst the expected touristy shops and street performers.Fascinating for both people watching and its history. We were fortunate enough to stay right on the square overlooking all it's varied activities, but from any vantage point it is a most enjoyable and entertaining must see.

Was disappointed. Obviously a beautiful place to see and a must-see if you are in Prague for the first time. The place is FILLED with tourists. Which makes sense, however I wasn't really happy with all the shops and attractions nearby. Every second shop was a tacky souvenir stores for kms. If just one of those stores had specialised in something more authentic to Prague rather than cheap artefacts I'm sure that they would make an absolute killing. It was not what I had expected and I found that it ruined the experience quite a bit. I found that I could appreciate Prague if I looked upwards, above the hoards of tourists (not discounting myself as one) and above all the cheap shops along the streets. The architecture is truly magnificent.
Beautiful architecture!. This square is impressive with all its different building styles! You can see the history of Prague through its architecture.

A must see!. A must see if you're traveling to Prague, of course! It's crowded, but that's the main charm of it. Just in front of a large Gothic cathedral you can indulge into authentic middle age era. The roasted ham made in front of you is absolute delight in cold winter days :)

Christmas Markets, Prague. Prague doesn't have impressive indoor Market Halls, unlike Budapest's shabby grandeur, only Open Air ones - so if you're a fan of Markets I'd not visit except at Christmas when you get three for your money - the big Christmas Market in Old Town Square - big, fun and busy - a smaller version in Wenceslas Square plus the regular Market one on Havelske (operates all year round). Good value trip thanks to WizzAir from Luton as the Czechs had the good sense to stay out of the Euro. Prague is worth visiting in any event but the extra variety at Christmas time makes it special. Don't agree with other reviewers criticism of Havelske as just selling touristy trinkets - maybe they visited at another time when the Christmas traders weren't there. Neat and tidy and compact - but the local gen. is to stay away in early January when the place fills up with Russians on hols over the Orthodox New Year. Not the most popular visitors with the Czechs but they'll take their money with a smile. The remarkably-quiet lap dancing club under our hotel seemed to be training its girls in anticipation. Prague now seems to be unfashionable for yobbo stag weekends and found an excellent Bierkeller but too plastered to remember the name.

Beware of people offering Czech Koruny for exchange. Don't ever accept any money exchanges other than from licensed money exchangers or ATM. We were offered fake local currencies in exchanges for Euros. Luckily we did not try to exchange a large amount.
A must. Even so it is crowded. Go up the tower for a view of the town, attend a concert at St Nicholas, and throw a few coins to the artists entertaining you

Crowded with tourists, and for good reason. One of the most spectacular squares in Europe - just magnificent. Visit early before the crowds get too large, and bask in the amazing sight of the medieval skyline. Really extraordinary and not to be missed, even if you can't have it all to yourself.
Amazing. One of the prettiest city squares in Europe with the beautiful astronomical clock on the town hall (worth watching every hour on the hour).
Too Many Things to see. See the clocks. Dine in sidewalk cafes. Watch the people go by. Walk around the square. Look in the shops. Enjoy the experience

Mersmerising place. The flavour of the yown square changes every moment of the day. We saw it deserted on the dsy we arrived. It was nine am and it had just rained. On a sunny day there will be performers and tourists. On a weekend night it is a live party with vibrant clubs, restaurants, bars , live music and young people having a great time. One can't be bored of the old town square.

Wonderful atmosphere day and night. Transported back to another time, remarkable medieval square.cobble stones, horse and carriages, wonder architecture. Church tower with marvelous clock, trumpeter in the tower.some good cages and shops close by with interesting side streets.Watch out for the usual (they are all over Europe), pickpockets. They watch who uses the ATMs. Also some work in threes, one to ask for money and see where wallet is, followed by two others who walk up after to bump into you and pickpocket. Was set up for it but managed to cross street and avoid them.

Stunning place. The Old Town Square should be the number 1 spot to visit on anyone's trip to Prague. Buildings and architecture are the most stunning I have ever seen. I'd recommend a slow wander around the Old Town in the morning (it can get quite busy from 11am).Don't miss the striking of the clock - fantastic!However, avoid eating in this district as restaurants are not as good and quite pricey.

Take the Free Tour. The Old Town area is great, but without the background history it's hard to put it together. Daily at 11:00 in front of the old clock free tour tours start in a variety of languages. We found an American "Keith" who provided a fantastic 3 hour tour of the Old Town highlights. These tour guides work off of tips at the end. It was soft sale and I was happy to tip $50 for 2 adults and 2 small kids. Keith also offers a tour of the Prague Castle complex but we couldn't work it in. Learning the history this way made the trip. Highly recommended.

Beautiful square. A square with old, nice buildings, a lot of entertainers during the day. But as somebody else mentioned, it's overpriced, so if you want to stop for a restaurant, don't do it in this square. Also do not exchange money here, as the rate is "touristy".
Best Place to hang out. Great location with the Astronomical Clock and rhe Gorhic Churches, shows, cafes with great views and millions who come to Prague ro party
Astronomical Clock. Not to be missed,crowded when it strikes the hour.Miss the popular times from late morning.Can climb up the Town Hall Tower-(hard work,if busy).
Very busy. There is plenty to see and do in and around the square with the Astronomical clock being the most viewed

Touristy but you have to go!. I am living in prague for 2 months right in the Square, and it's a bit loud, a bit touristy, and definitely overpriced (for Prague)... the solicitors can be a bit much (peddling tours, weed, bar crawls, and stripclubs) but no trip to prague is complete without a visit!

People watching and beautiful architecture. Great place to have a drink or overpriced lunch/dinner...you are paying for the location, which really cannot be beat! Surrounded by beautiful buildings, the astronomical clock and hundreds of other tourists, it is a nice place to take a break from walking around.
Amazing environment!. One of my favorite places in Prague, has several famous buildings nearby. The square is filled by tourist in the nearby restaurants. The astronomical clock is here!

Great people watching. We stayed a bit off the square - good idea if you like sleep. We walked through the square several times per day and the energy changes hour by hour. It's pretty calm until noon. Tour operators are showing off their segways, umbrellas and other activities but they are not obnoxious. In the afternoon, street performers show off to gather crowds and they are generally entertaining. Then there are the random musicians that may warrant a few coins. There were only a few beggars. There is a Bohemian clock that delivers an entertaining performance t the "top" of every hour. You can't miss it because huge crowds form about 10 to the hour (watch your pockets). We would stop for some wine / beer and tapas at various places round the square and watch the fun. This is highly recommended!

So much to see and not sure where to start. You won't be bored in the square with the churches the clock and the buzz of people and food . U need to hear the clock town chime, and watch the clock, but more than this you need to sit in the piazza with something to eat ( pastry or ice cream) and watch the sights and people that give the centre it's vibe

Enjoy the atmosphere. The atmosphere of the square is second to none. We often rested by grabbing a seat on a curb and watching the street performers or the people taking pictures and walking by. The restaurants on the square are VERY expensive for the area--so I'd recommend grabbing a snack and a beer from a local shop if you want to snack on the square. You'll get a better deal (and better food) at restaurants just a block away!

Touristy, but fun. Overwhelming for long periods, old town square is best enjoyed in several shorter spurts. This square is the centre of everything, teeming with more activity than I would think humanly possible. You could visit this square a thousand times and see something new and different each time. I especially like it early in the morning when the businesses are setting up, and late at night when it's less crowded, but more entertaining. The astromical clock is fun if you happen to be passing by around the top of the hour, but I'm not sure it's worth a special trip. The square is surrounded by many old and historically significant buildings. I would suggest picking one of those buildings each day to visit and get a closer look. Chances are you will be passing through the square several times over the course of a Prague trips, so savour it rather than plow through it.

Lively meeting point. The Old town square is the meeting point for everything and everybody. The square is always busy, day and night with plenty of tourists, attractions, entretainers, restaurants and of course the Astronomical clock.
The hub of all action. Always packed with tourists and deservedly so. Many street performers and tourist sites nearby, so this turns into a great gathering place.
namesti. Bright, open with great buidlings yet plenty of public transportation. Very nice shops and restaurants.

Central hive of activity. The Old town square is the meeting point for everything. The square is always buzzing day and night. There are street performers in abundance, and many of the city's orientation tours start from here. The architecture is a great delight to the eye, and of course there is the Astronomical Clock, which draws a crowd every hour on the hour to watch the appearance of the old characters in the window and the skeleton pulling on the bell. It's well worth the walk to the top of the clock tower for the wonderfull views.

Beautiful Square. On a recent visit to Old Town Square in Parague we were enchanted to watch the Astronomical Clock as it's figures(the Apostles) shuffle past the two top windows. The powder pink facade of the Town Hall forms an entrance to this area. Many places to eat, have a coffee and lots of nice little shops to window shop or buy. Definitely a highlight of our visit to Prague and only a 10 minute walk from our hotel, The Hilton, near Republic Square.

Lovely to sit and watch the crowd go by. A beautiful square with bustling cafes and lovely shops. Prince U cafe/ restaurant is a reliable place to eat and drink and the prices won't make your eyes water. There are a few good jewellers selling Czech garnet in great, unusual designs and lots of stylish amber pieces too.

fun place!. wandered over to the Square our first evening in Prague.there was a concert going on and a japanese bride and groom dancing to the music.what a destination wedding!plenty of small food booths near the square to pick up a sausage and a beer and plenty of people watching to do.

Nice tour. Helen our tour guide was pretty nice. But the trip was 6 hours of walking. We thought it was going to be a combination of bus, walking and boat. The boat was cancelled due to the river being too high and rapid waters and replaced with visiting another church. This was an all-inclusive trip. It included all the major attractions in the area. Dinner was also included but we ran late and had to rush through the historic Jewish quarters and the Jewish museums and cemetery were closed. I think we probably should have bagged one of the churches (after a while they all look alike) and spent more time in the Jewish quarter. We are going back there tomorrow, to check out what we missed.

Great buzz!. Tourist trail with loads of people about, tourists, entertainers, pubs/bars, stalls and trip sellers all make for an exciting place to visit and hang out when in Prague. 27 degree heat and long, cool nights made it a focal point of our trip and we will return. The church, clock and spuare are amazing and to the american girl who walked away from the hourly chimes and appearence of the disciples above the astronomical clock stating 'Well that was disappointing!' - THEY DIDN'T HAVE CGI GRAPHICS IN THE 14th CENTURY!!!!!

Great central spot . A really beautiful square with georgous buildings and bustling with people. A great place to start exploring Prague. There are also plenty of cafes and restaurants there although we didn't eat at any of them.

The place to be. It is full of resturants and bars and very touristic, but this is because it is a fantastic place to stop and enjoy the amazing architecture in the area. A great place to enjoy all the lively entertainment that happens in the square.

Beautiful.... One of the most beautiful squares I¨ve ever seen.Staromestska radnice,Kostel sv.Mikulase,Chram matky Bozi pred Tynem and Palac Kinskych are all there and many other pretty buildings.Astronomical clock is attraction but for me bigger attraction was great architecture of the buildings.Place is always full with people,a lot of stands with czech specialitys,horse carriages,very lively and just great.Be prepared for high prices.We payed 10 euros for two cappuccino,which is nothing less than in Paris or Vienna.But,in my opinion,that is apsolutely the most beautiful part of the city.Enjoy...
Morning stroll. Cloudy morning on Old Town (Staroměstské) square. Square from different perspective:)But you find beer even on morning if you have right instinct.

Must visit. When in Prague, the Old Town Square and the astronomical clock is a must visit. It is touristy no doubt but visit it to soak in the atmosphere. It is crowded with tourists and locals alike and the buskers add life and colour to the place. Some of the acts are good. The street food of sausages and ham turning on a spit is really delicious. For a small fee, go up the tower and you can get a good view of Prague. There is a tourist information office in the Old Town Square where you can pick up brochures. We found an unusual one - tour of a nuclear war bunker. It was simply amazing entering the bunker 16m underground and seeing the equipment kept there in preparation for a nuclear attack. Most of them are still in their original packaging.We found Old Town Square to be relatively safe. There is strong Police presence at the entrances but still watch out for pickpockets when everyone is engrossed watching the clock when it strikes at the hour. There are bathrooms at the tourist information office but take note that you have to pay to use it. Think it is about 0.50 euro.
great place to hang out. enjoyed the mixture of bars and architecture, great place to sit and watch, with a cold beer,obviously!

Beware the Food Stalls. We went to the square to see the astronomical clock and it was nice to see, but we were enticed by the aromas from the food stalls in the square. Whole hams being roasted over open coals smelled heavenly and the prices posted seemed reasonable (89Kc for 100 grams). However, when you place your order, the servers cut off about 500 grams of ham and tell you that they cannot cut it smaller. You end up paying about USD 30.00. Do not get us wrong, the ham is good, but you can get a feast at a local restaurant for a whole lot less.

Astronomically Awesome!. A visit to Prague is not complete until you've seen the Astronomical Clock. It chimes every hour on the hour. A very touristy attraction and a must see (just for the heck of it).
Old town square. Amazing old building. The street entertainers were annoying but pretty normal for a popular town square. glockenspiel worth seeing on the hour!

Wonderful. Sitting in the sunshine people watching and listening to the excellent buskers surrounded by the most beautiful buildings-wonderful! If you stand in the middle and slowly turn around every few seconds it's "wow". The church of Our Lady before Tyn is like something out of a fairy tale, particularly at night.
A magnet to draw you you and keep you coming back. Buskers, buildings, people watching, history and lots a of things to stroll to. Plus a grand trip up the tower for excellent views
Love the clock!. The Astrological Clock was neat and it was great to see everyone in the city gather around to watch!
Old Town Suare. We have been the in April. The weather was nice and we discovered Old Town Suare is very nice palce to see it..It s very interesting place.

Count your money. I had a bad experiance at Cristal & Souvenirs shop located at 3901 Na Prikope st. They gave me back less money then they should and they didn't give me the chance to prove. Be aware and count the money together with them before giving it.

A good way to spend time in Prague. Like most town squares , this is filled with tourists too . But you cannot go to prague and not go to the staromestske Namesti . The astronomical tower stands tall amid the busting area and is a guiding light in a maze of streets around the square where one can easily get lost . Lots of restaurants , shops n more shops , cafes etc to keep you busy . When the weather is good , the performers come out and it makes for a pleasant couple of hours

Touristy, but you can't visit Prague and not spend time here. Prague's Old Town Square is certainly touristy, but you can't visit Prague and not spend time wandering around the square to take in the performers, shops and restaurants.

Truly a Beautiful Place to Relax and Watch People. The time seemed to fly by whenever we were in Old Town Square in Prague. The Czechs have taken such good care of this ancient treasure and we all owe it to ourselves to visit and relax there. At the end of each day in Prague (we stayed 7 days) we found our path winding back to Old Town Square where we could order a beer from one of the dozen or more restaurants on the Square. We enjoyed just sitting, chatting and watching people walk by. Being from America, we realized that Europeans know how to live much better than we do. Many Czechs come to the square to have a nice dinner and walk around. So many people walking! The Square is not open to cars, but we couldn't figure out where everyone was walking to. The Square is often filled with people, whether at 14:00 on a Tuesday afternoon or Saturday night or even at 02:00 in the morning. People always walking around. It was a real joy to do people-watching. You might expect to get a lot of weirdos but we didn't see any. Our attention was more drawn to the young couples dressed up beautifully, especially the women. Many of them wear high heels even though the Square is filled with cobblestones. No one seems to get tripped up.Several reviewers have mentioned the horses and carriages. We had no desire to ride in them, but we enjoyed watching them come past again and again.
