The horses were adorned with feathers and fancy reins and the carriages were beautiful. We felt it was probably appropriate that we should pay them for riding by! (Although we didn't offer...)Old Town Square is a can't miss attraction in Europe. Prices in Prague are still reasonable, certainly cheaper than what we pay in Ohio at restaurants or bars. Probably 20-40% less than USA prices. Now is the time to go to Prague, folks. Watching a country emerge from communism in fits and starts and becoming a European star is a once-in-a-lifetime thing.

great views. we walked all around Old Town Square and found interesting restaurants, shops and people. the weather was not the best for sight seeing but we did not let this stop us, we walked up and down side streets and took tons of photos of different design styles people we met were friendly and helped us find our way when we thought we were lost.

You've seen one you've seen them all. Yes it is a historic city with its architecture intact. But how many squares with hawkers, mimes, and strange clocks can one take. Like a 16th century Times Square.

beautiful!. lost of cafes, tourists going around.typical shops and specially there is one day of the week witch i don't remember that they have this typical market in the center, with typical food and its very fun!

Breaktaking view. This is absolute must see while in Prague: there is something different to do or see on the Square throughout the day and this warrants several visits. There are several tourists / souvenier shops etc.etc.
A parade of fascinating people and activities. Entertainers, food of all kinds, cafes, history, churches. Spend at least a day here hanging out. It is just fun.

Great atmosphere. we found the square to have a great atmosphere, people everywhere enjoying the square, the sights, the food and the sun. We lunched in the square and explored the small streets leading off to good shopping and browsing for souvenirs. A happy experience with buskers and people enjoying life.
Lovely. Try the U Prince Hotel Rooftop Restaurant at Sunset! Awesome. Also the lovely ham being smoked in the square.
Breathtaking. An absolute must see while in Prague: there is something different to do or see on the Square throughout the day and this warrants several visits.

Very commercial. As much as we enjoyed walking through the old streets and looking at the buildings, it is extremely commercial. There are tourist shops: souvenirs – jewelry – t-shirts, etc. everywhere.
delightful. The buildings, the roofs, the colours, the cobbled streets, the kitsch shops, the little alleyways, the restaurants - everything was a delight

fantastic architecture. The architecture in the square as with most of prague is amazing, well worth a wander around for an hour or so, but while the astronomical clock looks good I dont see what the fascination is with the chiming of the hour .

Beautiful Square. Hidden away in old town, I stumbled across this famous square, which has great architecture, statues and cool vendors (very reminiscent of classic Italian squares). A must if you go to Prague!
Wonderful Fun, its happening here. Everyone must experience. Its brimming with excitement. The food, the clock...the history. Take an underground tour.

Near the clock, the center of the old town. Every tourist ends up here, lots of tourist traps shops and restaurants, but still overall a nice place to visit. Sometimes there are shows in the center of the square.
Return to the 14th century. One of the reasons to come to Prague in the first place, this square is as it was 500 years ago. Walk around and immerse yourself in history.
Picturesque. This lovely square with its amazing clock is one of the prettiest city square I have visited. The scene around it is lively. A fun place to visit.

Come Visit and Stay Awhile. This is the heart of old Prague. If you ever start feeling you are old or tired, just come here and get your mojo back again.The "new" buildings date from the 1400's on up, and then there are the older parts....it's really an amazing place. After all these centuries, it's still vibrant and alive without losing any of the charm or magic of days gone by.Please try and make this part of Prague one of the places on your must see list.

A must see. This is the centre of activity. The clock with its hourly show attracts hundreds of visitors each hour. From early morning to late night there are all manner of entertainers - currently listening to jazz, preceded by piano. Horse carriage tours of the local area, the centre for walking tours and much more.

Excellent to spend the evenings. There is a lot of activity in the evening. Lots of food, wine and beer. Groups playing music, a man blowing bubbles, a man painted like a statue are all part of this lively square

Fantastic atmosphere day and night. If you're in Prague you really can't skip this square. The buildings are phenomenal and whilst the surrounding restaurants are a bit more expensive than others, there are sells selling typical Czech food for good prices.
Nice. I'm probably spoiled from living in Europe, but while this square is cool, the astronomical clock is slightly disappointing. A nice square, but you'll find better ones in Spain and Italy.
You can't miss it.. Like the variety of architecture styles and the variety of busker performances. Dislike: too crowded!

Great!. I really enjoyed this area, littered with many little shops and food stands. Quite a few shops were a little spendy but fin to go in and look around. The food stands were inexpensive and smelled great! Lot's of smoked ham, I wish I had got some myself. If you want a place to stop and have a quick and cheap lunch this is a pretty good spot.
Just ok. I can't agree that this is one of the best squares in Europe .if not for the astronomical clock I believe it to be very ordinary

The best place in Prague. The old town square is one of the sights you should not miss if you are visiting Prague. Tha place is full of history and amazing sculptures and buildings like the astronomical clock and the large cathedral. There are also many kiosks that sell souvenirs and food.BE CAREFUL, because some of the locals who sell pork and potato with lettuce may try to fool you and charge you way more than you might expect. I asked for a portion of pork and potatoes and I ended up paying 900czk!!! You should explicitly tell them that you want 100g or 200g of potatoes otherwise they will fill up the bowl above the top and charge you more than any other restaurant. I did't like the potatoes after all and I ended up giving it away to a homeless person.Also, be VERY CAREFULL when exchanging money!!

Tourist Central. Wow! If you are looking for tourists, here they are. It seemed like every tour group must have met at this location and it was packed....and we weren't even at peak season. I think to appreciate this area at all, you need to visit off-season in the evening. Otherwise, it is very hard to see the charm.

Go Early for Something Different. I got into Prague at a tremendously early hour, (I can't actually remember the last time i've seen 5am) but it was a spectacular way to see the city centre. When I got to the Old Town Square- there was literally only two or three other people. I sat for awhile on one of the benches in the peacefulness, and took a couple really fantastic (undestructed) pictures. It was a once in a lifetime experience. I passed through the Square again on my way home (at around 6:30) and was blown away at how packed with tourists it was! It was still fantastic to see the second time around, but I was very happy I had the chance to see it before it got so busy.

Step back 700 years into history ... amazing!. We just returned from spending 7 glorious days in Prague. We just loved spending time in Staroměstské náměstí (Old Town Square). There is so much happening here ... dancing, street perfomers, music ... a feast for both eye and ear!Old Town Square is the oldest square in the historical centre of Prague with a history that dates back to the 10th century.We attended concerts in both St. Nicholas & Tyn Church ... both were magnificent! Took the lift to the top of the Old Town Hall tower for some incredible views overlooking Old Town.Don't miss the Church of Our Lady beforeTýn, Old Town Hall, Astronomical Clock, Jan Hus Memorial, St. Nicholas Church, Kinský Palace, the House of the Stone Bell and the Štorch House.

Very lively but busy spot. Amazing architecture, street entertainers and plenty of eating and drinking bars and restaurants. It is busy here though and when the old clock strikes on the hour its busier still. It is easy to find somewhere a little quieter to eat or drink if you wish by walking a short distance away from the centre. It is a must see on any visit to Prague

amazing. the buildings are so beautiful as others have said you will get neck ache from looking up ! dont forget 10 cr to use the toilets ! i love the blankets in the outside resturants , just what you need on a chilly evening when sitting having a drink .

Interesting. Its a small place compared to other places in Europe so once there it takes a little while to understand that the hyped up reviews are of just such a tiny place. But the buildings are old and the Astronomical watch is one of the oldest int he world.

must visit. A lively and busy square with many shops and restaurants (try not to eat here unless you want to pay top dollar). It is great to stop for a snack of Trdenik (rolled pastry with sugar coating that looks like a bracelet) and watch the people go by.

A must see for Prague. The Old Town Square is certainly a tourist trap but it's an enjoyable one. The astronomical clock is the highlight of the visit and you have to stay for one of the hourly shows. There are plenty of food stands just around the corner for a snack and a pretty reasonable price (for such a major tourist site.) All around the square are beautiful examples of Prague's architectural history and of course plenty of places to get souvenirs of all kinds.
A beautiful place to visit. The Old Town Square has the most beautiful architecture and lovely bars and cafes. It is great fun to watch the astronomical clock.

Fascinating, but Watch out for the Tourist Traps. The square is busy and vibrant with plenty of room to wander, however the food stalls are designed to trap the tourists into paying handsomely for their snacks. The astronomical clock is impressive, however the whole thing is trivialised and no publications exist for sale that explain what it is or how it works. You can climb the tower - again pricey!

Beautiful but so crowded. Old town is a beautiful part of Prague but unfortunately all tourist are going to check it out so it gets very crowded. One morning I got up at 5:00am to take picture of Charles bridge and Old town square and I had both to myself. I know it's early but so worth it. Take the picture, walk around a little and then go back to bed for a couple of hours.
top tourist spot. Fantastic hub to see the historical buildings, enjoy good food at the many wonderful cafes, bars and restaurants, great beer and shopping/
square. Art, shops and tours, chocolate, wine friendliness of the city. The architecture and stunning buildings.

No visit to Prague is complete without going here. The square compares favorably with the old town square in Krakow, though I liked Krakow a lot more. Of course, I don't think anyone who visits Prague as a tourist will have any reason not to visit the square. We were lucky during our visit in that there were constant musicial performances in the square. While we never knew the reason, we did enjoy the music.

Extremely crowded but great for people watching. Great place for people watching but be wary of buying food from the stalls in the square. It's over priced with kebabs etc. be priced by the gram for meat and boy do they overload the meat as a result. Kebab chicken was priced at around €35 - €40 per kg!!! But they tell you the wrap and vegies are free!!!!!

Very quiet on an early Sunday morning. If you want to hit this area without crowds, we had the plaza almost to ourselves on 7:30Am on a Sunday morning in early May. There could not have been about another 20 people around the Astronomical Clock so we could get as many pictures as we wanted before the tour bus and locals really came out. We returned to this same square for lunch (big mistake as the price are really over the top for most outdoor cafe locations) and the area was packed!

The center of Prague. This is the center of the Old town and a gathering place for all visitors from everywhere in the world. Crowds gather around hourly to watch the Clock tower chime. The free tours start from there everyday at 11:00 and 14:00.There are vendors selling Czech food and street singers, dancers and people selling horse and buggy rides. Be wary of pick pockets though!. Restaurants surrounding the square are more expensive so it is wiser to walk a few streets off of the center for better prices.

Great atmosphere anytime of the year. This is just a great place to go to in Prague. I dare say a must-see place for any visitor to Prague. The atmosphere is just great. In summer, autumn and expecially in winter in the Christmas time when you can smell and taste all possible traditional food and drinks. I prefer less crouded places so I choose times when most of the visitor are sleeping exhausted in their beds or enjoying Prague night life. :-)

One of my favourite places in Prague!. I lived in Prague for a semester and this was one of my favourite spots in town. During the winter the snow covers the top of the buildings and the Lady of Tye turns the square into a fairy tail! During the summer the place is files with tourists, street performers, street food and tour guides. It's a must! Spend an hour hanging around, people watching and soaking in the beautiful city!

Great to see, don't stay and buy food or drink. Go in the day, go further for good food at decent prices. It's a tourist honeypot and you'll go because it's one of the reasons you go to Prague, but the restaurants and bars nearby are there to prey on tourists who don't realise the great value for money you have further on.

Great area, restaurants on square VERY expensive. Love the history, architecture, street entertainers...but DON'T eat at a restaurant right on the square - prices were outrageous! Better to have your drink/coffee there, people watch, but eat elsewhere!
Just people watch...... One of the best places to people watch .... Look out for the dancing red Indian who is absolutely useless but just hilarious to watch!
lovely. great on a hot summers night, lots of city attractions come here, open concert, sporting events, etc.

Beautiful!. The Ole Town Square includes the views of St. Nicholas Cathedral, the Astronomical Clock and Tower. The church spires at night are lit up and positively breathtaking. The Square is CLEAN, amazingly so. Lots of food and drink and ice cream stands -- with one exception, the vendors were fair and the food very good.

Lovely to sit and people watch. This is a lovely old square with plenty going on, very popular when the astronomical clock is approaching the hour and people come to watch the figures appear. Plenty of places to eat and drink, but prices here a bit more than in the back streets. Plenty of guides about to take you on tours. Plus tours by horse and cart, a bubble car look alike and a two wheeled stand up bike. Cobbled streets everywhere, so you need to watch where you are walking. Also be on the lookout for pick-pockets. Loved the town. Toilets everywhere but you have to pay about 30p, but all are very clean and well looked after,.
Old Town Square--Prague. The Prague Old Town was delightful. Be sure to stop at the street market stalls for good shopping, and walk up to Wenceslaus Square.

Great for people watching. Of course, the Old Town Square is full of things to see, but it's also great for people watching. Drinks cost a little more, but it's worth it. There's usually some entertainment going on in the square, and there are loads of restaurants, but avoid the one with the same name - our waiter demanded a 15% tip, after giving very mixed service; he didn't get it, and we didn't go back. Go to the U Prince restaurant instead - excellent food and service, and similar prices.
Beautiful but too crowded. Buildings were beautiful but just too crowded for anyone to enjoy. Beware of pickpockets near the clock.

Full of history and novelty. The astronomical clock is the number 1 attraction (and it means so much more once you learn it's history and the functions of the various components).Then take your pick of statuary, architecture, bars, eateries, or just people watching. The smell of the ham cooking in the stalls always made me feel hungry. (I was warned it is the dearest in the world).

Bring sturdy walking shoes. The architecture is spectacular. I wish we had had time to have a tour to orient ourselves to this sprawling and historic section of town. Grand squares and lovely serpentine, largely cobblestoned streets.

Old Town Square. The Prague equivalent of Las Ramblas. Lots of activity, inexpensive food, performers. The astronomical clock is a big attraction. There were also a few art exhibitions going on - Alfons Mucha & Salvador Dali. Watch out for guys on the street wanting you to change money - probably scamsters.

Excellent visit. Lots of people - but beautiful square. Really liked area. Eat elsewhere though as cafes expensive in general.
Loved Prague.

Beautiful square. Very large square in the center of the old tow. My hotel room faced it and it was just nice to look out and watch. There is always some kind of street perform attracting attention. Lots of restaurants and food stalls all around, right next to the Clock.

The heart of Old Town. In the gateway to Old Town you'll find the Astronomical Clock, many restaurants, a few galleries and the Jan Hus Monument. Tip: if you're not set on dining outside, let one of the hawkers in the street take you to an inside restaurant. You may not have the patio but most likely you'll have authentic food at much cheaper prices. Try to get a window view and you won't miss anything.
picturesque. The likes are the buildings, the astronomical clock, cocktails on the roof terrace of hotel u prince. Warnings that where crouds congregate there are pick pockets so be careful.

Nice during day, magical place at night. I was lucky I went to prague during may when the tourists hadnt started flooding into the city so I dont remember being bothered by them... It I a great place to see during the day with plenty of things to do but it is even better at night... Very romantic for a trip with your date where you can hang out, drink a beer. Another way to go is with friends... For a while you think your back in time till the middle ages in that place... Will definitely revisit it!

smaller part of old town. Old Town Square is basically the center and heart of entire Old Town neighbourhood. Crowded with tourists, but with many architectural wonders to see. There are lots of shops and lovely restaurants, as well as other smaller attractions.

LOTS of great shops!. The view is great! The shopping is wonderful and you're right among the oldest buildings and history at every angle! Lots of places to eat too! It was a little crowded at times (every hour on the hour when people would watch the Astronomical Clock Chime) and because the international Prague Marathon was going on too, but worth it!!
Worth taking your time.. There is so much to see and so much history here that it cannot be rushed. You would need to take the full day to discover the best parts.

Don't go to Prague at hight of tourist season. Years ago we had been here when one could enjoy looking around. Now, if you go at the height of the season, you are mostly fighting your way through crowds without really enjoying it.

Great shopping and dining. A must visit while in Prague-long double sided street filled with shops and restaurants-at the end was a small area with many food vendors and a large souvenir market.Really enjoyed visiting this area.

Prague Center. Entertainers of every kind fill Prague's Old Town Square, and everywhere you turn there's something being thrown, lit or played. Like in the rest of Prague, medieval constructions like Týn Church and the Clock Tower coexist side-to-side with classic buildings in harmony. It's too bad that the view to Týn is blocked by a row of houses.
Much to see, people and "stuff". People watching from sidewalk cafes, the Astrological Clock, wandering musicians, and the ability to walk freely among the OLD beautiful buildings.

Gorgeous Gothic Square. A wonderful square, with lots to see and lots of other people seeing it (but don't let that put you off) There is a Starbucks opposite the Astronomical Clock that offers fee wifi and a great selection of bars/restaurants and traditional food stalls around the square. There is a big crowd on the hour for the clock, which is cute when it chimes and worth a visit to see. Be aware (like all crowded places) there is a risk of pick-pockets, my husband caught someone trying to undo his bag. This is a great way to spend a couple of hours - make sure you take your camera.
Must see, but only once.. Any visitor to Prague has to see the square, but it's too crowded and full of people dressed in 18th century costumes trying to get you to attend concerts.

Great buildings, lots of people. The square is bustling with people and cafes and street performers playing instruments. The clock is interesting but was kind of a let down after being to Munich and seeing the clock there. You can climb the tower for a great view of the city. The cafes are really expensive but the ice cream was 1E a scoop.

Very good. You must visit here there is so much to see. Restaurants, seating areas in the square. Entertainment on the square. There is a very gothic theme to the buildings outstanding place to be. You can pick up a carriage here to ride around the local area. The church is very imposing and beautiful behind the clock tower. Cobbled flooring so not suitable for high heels. Ice cream is sold here gorgeous. Don't miss the experience here folks.

ehchanting captivating Praha. A magical place to visit one I shall never forget is Prague. Wander through clean cobbled streets with stunning baroque/medival architecture. Charles bridge is great to stroll along, then jump onto a boat and drink and marvel at the views down the river and back. Browse through the fascinating Jewish town.Later If tired take a horse and carriage tour through the square. Wonderful restaurants. A very friendly city though can be quite crowded and busy. A must visit and probably still my favourite place.
Nice place!. one of Pragues must visit places. great architecture. good for place to sit and relax at one of the resturants.

Best piano player ever?. Just off the old town square is a bar called the Black Angel Bar. If you want to see the most amazing pianist you have ever seen, then pop in here for a drink. This guy makes liberace look like he's knocking nails into wood. Absolutely brilliant.

Stunning Architecture everywhere you look. Prague is a must see destination, the vibrant use of colour, the multitude of things to see the stunning architecture, old and new ,the ease of travel once there ,the many and varied bars and eating places need I say more?This place just ticks so many boxes how could anyone fail to love it?
too many tourists. beautiful place, but unbearable amount of tourists and touristic shops. you should try to avoid going there on a sunny sunday...

Loved it. This is basically the heart of Prague. It is pretty, and the clock is really nice, especially when the bells ring every full hour. This is a great experience. And there are many restaurants and bars in the vicinity, but the prices are a bit high. 5 minutes away you can find Wenzels square. There you can find small huts that sell traditional food and drinks. This was great. I was eating here twice, and it was delicious and so cheap.

One of the great sights of Europe. Old Town Square is full of surprises. Stunningly beautiful architecture, the ever-popular Astronical Clock that attracts vast crowds on the hour every hour and the surprisingly good food and drink on the terraces.What struck me most is how clean and civilised the square feels. Although it gets very crowded particularly at weekends, the atmosphere is friendly and relaxed.Even the street music is a few notches better than in other cities. During my four-day stay there was a pianist playing Chopin, a jazz quartet and a trio consisting of two tubas and a trumpet.There are little stalls selling beer, ham and sausages, but they discreetly placed around the side of the old town hall and lack the pungent smells of hotdog stalls in London or New York.The whole square is pedestrianised, which is fantastic. Transport in the form of horse and carriage, Segways, 8-seater bicycles and other unusual modes of transport is still everywhere - and great fun too.Many of the terraces are owned by the same handful of companies, so whether you opt for Italian pasta or the steaks next door you are likely to be served food and drink with the same, surprisingly high standards. We loved Olivia Verde, whereas the terrace outside hotel U Prince is disappointingly hit and miss in both food and service.The roof terrace bar and restaurant at U Prince is, however, a hidden gem open to non-residents and possibly one of the finest spots to leisure away an hour or so overlooking Old Town Square.The square lacks the amplified music and pushy vendors that blight many other major tourist destinations. Of course Old Town Square has its problems too, with pickpockets, currency exchange fraudsters and rip-off attempts by dodgy taxi drivers. But it has so much going for it that on balance Old Town Square has to be highly recommended.
Favourite square in Europe so far. Beautiful spot, great buskers and amazing atmosphere. My favourite place in Europe so far! Definitely suggest visiting at night to try sampling the food stands

Great Place. Fun to experience. Might see brides and grooms in horse drawn carriages. Buildings are beautiful and interesting. Wonderful to see at night. Just a stroll to the Jewish quarter or Charles Bridge. It is a special place, hence it will get crowded.
safe area with hustle bustle. good place to buy souvenirs. make sure you try to ask for lower price coz some of the shops do give you some discount. rows of restaurants and cafes

Fantastic but be careful. Old town is pretty interesting but I must admit that I had two bad experiences and of course the 12 Apostles /astronomical clock was just plain amazing when you consider that it was built in the 1400's and survived WWII with a little rebuilding. Here's a great tip for the clock. Plan to stay for two top of the hours so you can experience once at ground level (large crowds) then immediately go inside and ride the elevator to the top and experience it from atop the tower. Not only is it one of the best views of the city you'll also heard the trumpet play from all four sides which is exactly as they did back in the 1400's.Now for the two bad experiences....Prague like any new capitalistic city is suffering from growing pains and with that there are those who take advantage of situations. First problem was my daughter had her iPhone pick pocketed from her. We seem to always guard against money thief when we travel but not as much on material items. Be on your guard at all times because some people are trying to catch you not paying attention. Second problem was at a currency conversion store. I want to cash $300.00 US into Czech money. Even though old town is NOT the best place to convert, my family want to purchase some items so I laid down my money at a store that said no commission and 19.1 to $1.00. HOWEVER he only handed me back 12 to 1. When I questioned him we acted like he didn't understand and said "ok you drive hard bargain I give you 16 to 1. I said you give me 19.1 or nothing he then handed the rest over. Bottomline, always know what the conversion rate IS and do the calculation of what you expect back BEFORE you start to hand over any money because that would have been a $100.00 + mistake if I had been paying attention!! Highly recommend the clock and old town.

Old Town. Fabulous atmosphere here - especially when the clock is about to strike, I loved all the little stores selling food in the square. The restaurants here are a little more expensive as you would expect - so we got snacks from the little street vendors and walked a few streets back for our meals.Certainly worth visiting!
Beautiful. Wonderful architecture, very pretty buildings, Lovely place to sit and people watch, the squares always buzzing with lots of street entertainers.
beautiful buildings. beautiful place to grab a drink and look at the building some amazing things to look at and dont forget to look up to take in the statues on roofs etc.

Fading historical grandeur. All visitors and locals congregate at the Old Town Square. The spirit of Prague is here. It is least crowded early morning but I think darkness adds to the mystique and vibrant spirit of the crowd.

large square. The small cobbled streets open out into a large square. There are street entertainers in the middle of the square and all around are restaurants and bars which seemed to be very busy. I wished there were more seats as it was hard standing and watching.

Pleasing atmosphere. Being there you really feel some mysterious atmosphere, very pleasing and likeable.... We've been at the beginning of Easter holidays and the surroundings were appropriate - all decorated with Easter eggs, many colored ribbons etc.

City Center. Overcrowded, sure. It's Old Town Square and a tourist draw due to the Astronomical Clock and such. Lots to see, eat and shop. Be sure to take in some of the churches in right off the square and try and get lost in some of the side streets of the square. Also beware of Cheque point exchange- very shady exchange place in general about the city!

A magical place. We were staying at an apartment 500 metres from the Old Town Square so we often found ourselves in the square - to us, it is the heart of Prague with a magnetic pull that can't be resisted! We visited this city in May when we thought it wouldn't be so crowded, but the good weather saw the Old Town Square fill up with tourists and locals every day, soaking up the sights and sounds of this enchanting place.Whether you find a seat on one of the park benches by the fountain or have a coffee or meal at one of the (overpriced) outdoor cafes/restaurants, the sights won't disappoint.One of the most popular things to watch is the town hall clock striking the hour. People start arriving at least 20minutes prior, jostling for a good spot to watch the 12 apostles come into view and "Death" ring his bell!There is plenty to watch in the square - musicians and all kinds of buskers, and just people watching.There are food stalls in the square selling local specialities, and there are also retail shops, jewellery (lots of amber and garnets for sale), hand painted eggs, marionettes, and plenty of souvenirs.Whatever you do, make sure that you pay the 100kr to go up to the top of the town hall. The view is spectacular!
Overcrowded. Once through here is enough; it was really overwhelmed. See the clock and then go elsewhere. We had a nice lunch at Cafe Mistral not too far away.

Center of activity. There is a lot going on in this area. Good shopping, restaurants, bars and just people watching. Prague is a great place to buy Garnet jewelry and my wife found a great place near the square.

Soak Up The Atmosphere & Enjoy People Watching. This square most definitely has a different feel morning and evening. If you can find a spot to sit somewhere, you'll find yourself greatly entertained by looking in any direction. If you want a bird's eye view head up to the tower of the old town hall.Several reviewers have noted pick pocketing potential, which is very true. Being hyper vigilant, I eyed a suspicious man lingering near me as I ate. When I went to toss my half empty plate away he swooped in and took my plate and fork. Awareness of one's surroundings is vital but so is the understanding that someone may just be hungry.
Unmissable. One of the great squares of Europe. Oozing with character and charm. Go up the town hall tower for a great view. Don't miss the astrological clock.
great sense of the city. We enjoyed that there was a small jazz group playing informally on the square, and especially enjoyed the sense of history and beautiful buildings.

Money exchange alert. Beware the cheque point money exchange opposite the old astronomical clock on the corner. They are robbers, took 200USD from us but only paid 11CZK, going rate advertised 21CKZ when pointed out mistake informed the transaction was completed! Totally spoilt my memory of Prague!
Old Town Square. A great place to visit. Be there just for being. It is important to be there during the night as well.
Worth looking at. Very busy but a good spot to get your bearings, when the clock sticks the hr you can not move. We were continually told to beware of pick pocketers so take care.

Fantastic Old Town Square with the Remarkable Church of Our Lady Before Tyne :). The Church of Our Lady before Tyne is really an astounding architectural of all time! I kept observing its beauty and took lots of beautiful pictures of it. Before we discovered that it was a church, I thought to myself that it looks like a Disneyland castle ;) Worth a visit to the Old Town Square since you're in Prague! Lots to see at the town square too, including the Astronomical clock!

nice to do. We sat by the monument for a few moments in the middle of the square watching the people take horse and carriage rides when a tour party with guide gathered next to us. The guide was English and it was really interesting! we were on a tight time line so could not do a full tour so this was a real bonus and very enlightening!

A classic old-Europe square, where you find the Astronomical Clock. One of three prime tourist spots in Prague along with the Castle District and Charles Bridge area, the Old Town Square is a very good area to spend time while visiting Prague. The most important attraction on the square is Orloj, also known as the Astronomical Clock. If you visit on the hour, you can watch 'The Walk of the Apostles' hourly performance. It is additionally worth visiting the easily recognisable Church of the Virgin Mary before Tyn, which features the two medevel towers topped with four small spires each. The baroque era Church of Saint Nicholas is worth a visit as is the Jan Has Monument in the center of the square. There are plenty of cafes, bars, restaurants and souvenir shops in and around the square as well and if you visit during a holiday period like Christmas or Easter you can enjoy the fairs that are often had in the square. Some permanent stands are set up within the square that sell sausages, trdelniks, drinks and some souvenirs. Overall, this is a nice area to spend some time in the city center of Prague, a place that all visitors to the city should try to find when they visit the city.

Great square, beautiful architecture, lots of people. A must see, visit well before the hour to take photos without the throngs of people arrive to watch the clock for 15 seconds of entertainment. A beautiful square, lovely architecture, bustling with activity.
Nice walk and plenty of shops. It was nice to walk around and enjoy the shops and atmosphere, although can be a little busy and crowded
Almost to crowded. The square has a good atmosphere and there are many things to be seen, but at times it can be very crowded on the square.

Really must see!. Totally enjoyed our time here, even though raining at the time.
Great history, and lovely shopping too

Excellent View of Lots of Beautiful Buildings. The center of Prague is busy.. teeming with life! It seems that everyone passes through here, from visitors to those conducting day-to-day business. A lovely place to just take in the culture of this beautiful city.

An awesome location. Well, to start with, the square is quite large and has undergone some restoring, which can be seen in different ways. Most important of all, however, is that the square is quite unique in Europe as one rarely gets to see architecture and style of different centuries in any other place. Standing there and just turning slowly, gives an overview which cannot be seen elsewhere. If you are fortunate, you can see the famous clock in action, but I cannot recall the times (I guess every hour on the hour?).

lovely area. the old town square is beautiful in the night as its all light up and shows the architecture of the old buildings. felt really safe in this area even though i kept my bag close by. the square contains lots of places to eat and drink but its much cheaper if you go 2 blocks away. the only downside to this square and prague in general is the amount of tourists and tourists groups....i have travelled to numerous european cities but this must be the worst so many people and it was only may!!!
Lovely square and lots going on. Loads of people to watch sitting in the restaurants round the square. something for everyone here. Including starbuckS!

Don't leave Prague without a visit to Old Town Square. After you've visited Prague Castle, seen St Vitus Cathedral and soaked up the atmosphere of the Charles Bridge, you'll want to walk through Old Town Prague to Old Town Square. This is a fascinating place. It's surrounded by centuries-old buildings of various architectural styles, and in the center is the statue of Jan Hus, an early contributor to the Protestant Reformation. On one corner is the beautiful St. Nicholas Church. On another corner is the Old Town Hall Tower and the 600 year old Astronomical Clock. At the approach of the top of each hour you'll see a crowd gather below the clock to watch Christ and the twelve apostles appear, and to hear the hour tolled by the skeleton of death. This happens quickly, so don't allow yourself to be distracted.There are numerous restaurants and cafes along the sides of the square, and the most crowded Starbucks I have ever seen. I visited the square on the weekend before Easter, and it was full of wooden vendor's huts, like you see at Christmas Markets in European cities. Happy people, and good ethnic food and drink plus all kinds of trinkets for sale.If you're up for more walking and window shopping, one of the streets leading off the square is Parizska Street, the high-end shopping street. Here you'll find Christian Dior, Prada, Hugo Boss, Louis Vuitton and more.
Charming. Very picturesque and pleasant to wander around in the evenings. A must stop for any visitor to Prague!
magical town centre. this is a wonderful place any time of day, but esp in the evening. the lights on the buildings around give it a fairytale feel
Favorite Place in the World. Well-restored Renaissance buildings, unequaled astronomical clock, large open space. The square is alive!

Magical.. The Old Town Hall (1338) with the must see Astronomical clock (12 Noon is a good time) the magnificent church of St, Nicolas, the buskers, the cafes, bars and restaurants all the little side streets, the designer stores leading off - the whole atmosphere, wonderful.
Beautiful. Beautiful area with amazing architecture and history. Outdoor restaurants to enjoy the scenery and people watch. Great place to sit and have a beer or a glass of wine.
The fun center of Prague. Easy to get to, always lots going on, both architecturally/historically and street-artists galore, every day (and any different time of day) different things happening. FUN!

Beautiful Square with lots to do. This is a beautiful square with lots of entertainers to watch and restaurants to eat it. The churches are lovely to look at, the restaurants are good, and there are a number of bars to stop at for a drink. It is on par with many of the great European town squares.

The square where it's happening.. The square itself is beautiful, but everyone is here. Including a Dixieland band, Hare Krishnas, and people from all over the world. Take an easy lunch break and grab some wood smoked ham or sausage from one of the vendors. Great views of the surrounding areas. Colorful, fun, and a happy place.

sit and watch the world go by. The square is always full of people whatever time of day and whatever the weather, particularly on the hour when the astronomical clock strikes. Its a lovely place to sit and try the local beer at one of the many bars with outside seating areas and patio heaters. Food and drink is a little more expensive than away from the square but it has to be done at least once.
Lively and Interesting. This is the heart of Prague. Cafes line the square and you will find street performers, tourist shopping, and beautiful Baroque buildings. A must see in Prague

the Center of Prague. the central point of Prague, Old Town Square is the place where the most tours of the city begin and end. It's simply a living postcard at any time of the day and also of the night, well, maybe excepting 3-4 AM :)

Amazing square. Almost every European big city is somehow determined with its main square. And there is a lot of beautiful and interesting squares. But, from many reasons, Old Town Square in Prague is very unique. Extraordinary preserved, very big, vibrant, this square brings You to medieval atmosphere. I just liked it very much.
Beautiful area, can be crowded. Loved the buildings, not too fond of the crowds. But it's worth it. Try coming early if you want an impression of the place with fewer people in it.
Great place. Worth to visit - but too many tourists, too crowded place. Better visit at early morning or late evening

huge array of architecture. find a cafe, order a pilsner, and just look around; notice the varied detail work, painting, and sculpture on the buildings; be a tourist and watch the famous clock strike the hour;

You will visit as a Tourist - BUT to save cash. AS you will imagine, if you sit in one of the bar/restaurants in the square expect to pay double (and not great quality) compared to the side streets - JUST as an example one beer on the Square is typically 5-8 Euro whilst in the side street 2-4 euro.

Almost a fairytale.... The Old Town Square has beautiful buildings and the famous astronomical clock. If there weren't Starbucks, Hard Rock Cafes etc... you could really believe you were once upon a time, far, far away.Everyone warned me about pickpockets in the square - apparently they take advantage of the tourists looking up in awe at the astronomical clock and the magnificent architecture of The Church of our Lady before Tyn. It is not a reason to avoid the square - keep an eye on your wallet and spend some time wandering around this amazing, beautiful public space.

Lovely square. A lovely square - very large with lots of interesting buildings everywhere you look. Also street performers everywhere. Very busy with all sorts of people so the potential for people watching is high. Of course the Astronomical Clock is here and is an essential spot to visit!
never bored. You will never get bored in the old town. It is easily accessable and has everything from restaurants, bars to ice cream shops and souvenir stores!

Very lively and sweet. The Square has a life of its own with all sorts of entertainers as well as beautiful horse carriages. We bumped into the occasional newlyweds in attire which was rather nice. The restaurants are not very good (tourist opportunists) but once you walk a little distance away you can find good places for reasonable prices. Make sure you have enough Czech Crowns though - the currency converters are BANDITS. Best rates are obtained before exiting the doors at arrivals, on the duty-free side.

Like taking a step back in time. Beautiful. Well looked after, it was like being shrunken and put into a model village - it was surreal to see the 14th century buildings and castle in such a good state of repair. Well worth a visit when in prague

The heart of the city. As you would hope - plenty of interesting buidlings and a buzz at any time of the day. Have a look in the churches - but take a coat as they are cold whatever time of year you go!
minis18. square busy not many seats to relax on.market near by with usual holiday gifts.street acts not worth mentioning,but weather lovely so that was a bonus.

You can't miss the square and the clock. We were told that Albert Einstein loved to the clock on the Old Town Square, so I had to go. It is fun and amazing the watch. Spend the effort to know a little bit about the clock before watch its' performance. The square is lovely and has the sense of time and vintage that I love. Also climb to the top of the tower for the view.
Packed with tourist shops. A rather spoilt square overly exploited for commercial gain from the thousands of tourists who find there way here
Amazing place. We always love to come back. Its a very magic place with lots of beautiful restaurants and shops. We all love it there soooooo much

Wow. Amazing architecture and a clock dating from 1415ad with lots of small bars and cafes in the surrounding back streets. Best to avoid the food stalls in the square which are over priced tourist traps.
beautiful!!!. you have to visit the old town square during your stay in Prague :) it is really nice place which you cannot miss!!

Old world charm. It happened to be a very beautiful spring day that I was at the Old Town Square.The astronomical clock and the Tyn cathedral are the main attractions. There were Mocha and Salvador Dali's paintings being exhibited on that day at one corner of the square.You could catch hop-on-hop-off buses conveniently from the square.I had a very nice time!
Must!. Never leave Prague without visiting here. There are so many things to see and do here. Prague's history can be seen by just turning around!

How many old town squares are there in Europe?. As many as there are old towns.So what is it about Prague's Old Town Square that makes it so special? It's got a clock with figures that move on the hour. But I was just in Munich and watched the same kind of show.It's big.It's crowded. It's full of pretty girls and beautiful architecture. Just like every other old town square.I don't know. I really don't. Maybe it's just Prague being Prague, but old town square here is my favorite of all old town squares anywhere. And that includes some really really gorgeous squares. Have you been to Wroclaw? So you know. And Prague is still my favorite.
Brilliant place. Lots to see and do in this square with street food available to buy, places to have a drink, often street performers too. You can't go to Prague and not visit.

Old town square review. Beautiful square. Love the clock show! Walk around. If you are there in Easter it is beutiful filled with large eggs in trees. Visit the tower located right next to the clock. You will receive a great view.
A great place to sightsee and shop. We loved this city and this city center. Lot's of things to see and do. You don't want to miss this part of the city.

What a stunning square.. With palaces, churches, towers and an endless amount of local and tourists, this square is one of the most beautiful places in Prague.This huge square can be enjoyed throughout the day, night and all year long, with so many cafes in it.Note that pickpocketing can be an issue, especially where people gather around street performers, so make sure your valuables are safe.

Random people-watching. This has to be one of the most random places on Earth. Plenty of benches around the square to sit, or watch from one of the cafes around the edge. Wonderful relaxed atmosphere, plenty to eat & drink here, beautiful buildings, people to watch - loved it!!

Stunning. Only back today from 3 days in Prague. We spent some time in the Old Town Square. It is mind blowing. The atmosphere, the people, the restaurants and the buildings are completely unique.We walked to the Old Town Square from Wencelas Square and were stopped in our tracks by the sight as we came out of an alley way to the magnificence of the square. On Thursday morning at 10am the sun was beaming and the temperature was already high teens. The light and the colours was incredible.If you are into your history and architecture you are in for a real treat. Every building has a brilliant story. If you are not into history they are just brilliant to look at. The colours and the symbols are totally unique.But typically for this type of location the prices are horrendous for food & drink.

Astronomical Clock. This is where the famous astronomical clock is located and crowds gather to watch it throughout the day. We walked around the square to soak in the atmosphere and observe the area. The hotel where we stayed was just a short walk from here, so we visited the Old Town twice.
Prague Old Town Christmas Market. Visited Old Town in Prague during the Christmas season. The square was filled with Christmas vendors and local food. Great atmosphere and energy.

Old-World experience and great shopping. Great shopping here..spend at least a half a day wandering around checking out stores, architecture and beauty of Prague. Go to Rukel factory outside Prague to shop for crystal--we got some incredible buys there!--and the tour was fantastic!---this is the place where much of the Waterford Crystal is made...

Must see. It's a must see for every tourist in Prague. There are some beautiful buildings all around it. On the downside, it is clearly a tourist hotspot. There are huge crowds of tourists, school classes and tour groups. There is a little market fair that you can call cute or tacky, according to your taste. Nearly all the buildings around the square have a restaurant in the ground floor.

A very popular place. A great place to have a beer and watch people. Lots of annoying street entertainers. The top-of-the-hour action of the zodiac clock is cute if you have smaller children but soooooo crowded.
Fairy tale like square once the lights are lit.. A must visit just after sunset. Lots of nice restaurants, bars and shops. Try exploring the streets around the square.

Must visit to get a flavour of Prague. This is the centre of the old town and gives you the perfect insight into Prague. The buildings there from different styles of architecture is such a revelation. Do spend a few hours looking at the buildings and also people watching. The drinks and food is about three times the price of elsewhere so you can go elsewhere or get yourself a nice sandwich and sit there on the numerous benches they have provided. There are some great places to eat drink and shop in the areas around the square so try to get lost in every street possible, you'll see something great on each of them. Thought the clock is a bit over rated but see it if you are there at the right time. But make sure you observe the building around the square, that's the highlight.

OF COURSE!. This is the epicenter of Prague, it's 360degrees of amazing architecture, it's also 360 degrees of high end shops and tourist traps. Walk through and imagine its 500 years ago.... But keep walking. the area is full of small cobblestone streets with one amazing sight hidden around every corner... Just get off the beaten path.
Prague Old Town Square. Lively, full of market booths (pre-Easter) and goodies to munch on, easy to reach, lots of eateries etc. The excellent weather helped too.
Crowded. At the top of the hour, bus loads of people clog the square to see the clock which may have been a 14th century wonder but is a bit tired looking now.

Easter Festival in The Square is incredible!. The color, the food and the EGGS! Don't miss the Easter Festival in the square!! It turns the already beautiful square into a colorful, festive atmosphere.

Everyone goes here!. Hustle and bustle, even in April, the astronomical clock is here, you can climb the tower (100 kronas) for a great view, takes on an excitement at night but expect to pay a little more to eat in the square, veer off 100 metres down the side streets and the price starts to drop.

Wonderful Easter Market!. A must see- I would even consier planning your vacation during this time of year. The festival was so quaint with so many good deals on authentic crafts and foods. A beer,fried treats, a hand decorated carton of eggs, and a marionette for the kids- who could want more?

Beautiful Architecture. The old Square is definitely a must if you like historic buildings. The atmosphere is great with lots of bars and street performers to add to the bustle. The square is surrounded by lots of tiny streets to explore. On a second visit to the square, we tried to find hidden away squares and small streets to explore which were amazing. I recommend a good map which shows all the streets as it is a real maze!
Full of character. Lots of lovely little streets to wander round leading to churches and squares off the main old town square itself. Busy but part of the Prague experience.

Small but Perfectly Formed. Great architecture and ambiance, particularly with the Easter markets, felt a bit like Christmas. Not that big a place really can see and enjoy Prague over a couple of days really, good for a weekend break.

Easter Markets. Visiting at Easter is great if you dont mind the cold! Various markets similar to the Christmas Markets in Germany provide great "street food" and little gifts for friends back home. Its also a great rendez-vous point for friends!
Easter Market. Had so much fun just srolling around and try new foods. The venders had some really pretty things for sale.
Magical. So much history, beauty, and energy in this space. Give yourself plenty of time to explore the little streets off the main square.

Had a festival during the time I was there it was great!!. Dont love the tourist traps but it was still an amazing time.. They had live music got to see the oldest working astronomical clock.. All is all is was a fun place to be.. Didnt stay to long but long enough to get a good feel for the spot. Most def a must for prague..

Watch the World go by.. A tourist trap with numerous bars and restaurants, be warned if you sit down you will automatically get a cover charge (£2pp) and if ordering food or drink they add charges for bread (£5) and add an automatic service charge. The famous 500 year old Astronomical Clock chimes from 0900 till 2200 on the hour with the Saints on display and sometimes a trumpeter will join in from the Tower above. Very congested at these times, watch-out for pick pockets. Only try the Prague Ham from local vendors if you like gristly ham, beware as they charge for it by each 100g (our lunch cost £30 and ended up mostly feeding the local beggars) and also the local donut rings which are expensive at £1.70 each (50Kr). Prague may once have been cheap, that is no longer the case and you do feel a little ripped off as a tourist.
Astonishingly beautiful. Also full of tourists and very commercial. I recommend also visiting it again at nighttime: less people and the lighting of the buildings is marvellous. Magical.

Breathtakingly beautiful. Full of history, full of beautiful architecture (baroque, renaissance, gothic), restaurants, bars, shops, markets, the famous Astronomical clock, the Church, the museums............all of them are worth checking out. You could sit on the bench in the Old Town Square and absorb the beauty around you. Here you will find lots of guides offering variety of tours; ghost tours, hop on/hop off bus tour, pub crawl, etc.

Easter Market. There was an Easter Market in the Square with food and handicrafts for sale from wooden huts. This wasn't on the grand scale of the Manchester Christmas Market but it was nice to wander around the stalls and try different foods and it wasn't too packed.
Must visit the tower. you can walk up to the tower and it only costs about £4. Its worth to go up because the view was absolutely fantastic .
Pretty and Bustling. Great historical area of Prague filled with beautiful architecture! A must-see to feel transported back in time.

Busy with plenty of restaurants. A decent square in the centre of old town about a 10 minute walk from Charles Bridge. Plenty of stalls on the square, however have seen better. The buildings around the square are all impressive and it is worth going up the Tower for a good view

Stunning!. We visited Easter weekend and were expecting throngs of people. It was crowded but lovely and manageable! The square is simply beautiful, surrounded by historic buildings, restaurants and shops. There were street vendors and shows - something different every day we walked through. Prices for food, drink, shopping and souvenirs seemed very reasonable compared to other cities we have visited. This seemed like the heart of Prague to me. I can't wait to visit again!

Very pretty but crowded. We visited during Easter week and there was an Easter Market set up in the square which was fun, food and crafts mostly. The square was very crowded but fortunately there was a tall platform in the center which allowed you to see over the crowds.
Pretty at Christmas time. It was Christmas time the Decorations were amazing, the Christmas tree most have been about 70 foot is was beautiful. The Christmas market was lovely too.
Well worth visit. Astronomical clock/ tower, both well worth visit. Market stalls, atmosphere, just a really enjoyable visit.

Cute Easter Market. I really liked the Old Town section of Prague, not only are all of the buildings amazing. I could spend hours walking around appreciating them, but especially during and around easter, there are great markets, with street vendors that specialize in everything from Pastries to sword making. There was even a live choir and a petting zoo. It is close to just about everything which is nice when you are walking around the downtown area. The astronomical clock is also here.

Lots of statues venders .... Beautiful buildings with great art statues. It was Easter time and they had lots of beautiful events including the Astrological clock.On the hour the clock comes alive. There is also a great view of the city when you go up the build to the tower.
Stunning place to visit. A must see when in Prague. Very cultural but expensive to eat and drink. Well worth a visit. Very popular tourist spot

good. Liked:Strahov Monastery was founded by the favor of Prince Wladyslaw II and the Olomouc Bishop Henry Zdík whose decision Norbert received the land in 1140 located on a hill near the Prague Castle where the "strahowało".Church of Our Lady of Loreto shrine built in the baroque style in Hradcany, namely the square Loreta.New Town was founded around the year 880 by Prince Břetislav and for centuries was the seat of Czech princes and kings. After World War 1, and the rebirth of the Czech statehood Prague Castle became the seat of the Czech-Slovak presidents.Renaissance Belvedere in Prague (Czech Letohrádek Královny Anna) is located in the Royal Gardens at Prague.St. Stephen's Cathedral. Vitus, St. Wenceslas and St. Adalbert, in short known as the Cathedral of the Holy. Wit is an integral part of the Prague Castle complex.Disliked:Golden Lane (Czech Zlatá ulička) took its name from the fact that she was once the seat of Jewish silversmiths who worked for the Treasury.

Most Central Point Of Prague, Very Beautiful. A beautiful most central part of Prague, with the Astronomical Clock and views of the Tyn Church. Also where the Easter and Christmas Markets are held. Gorgeous buildings and central streets lead off this square. I would recommend staying somewhere near here. Beautiful by day and by night. I wouldn't recommend buying any souvenirs or gifts of the Celetna Street, that just goes off Old Town Square though as most of them are fake.
Loved the atmosphere. The setting is so inviting and we felt very safe at all times. The outside restaurants were starting to fill and the street food, whilst a bit pricey was good quality.

Lovely day or night. Old town square is where we spent most of our holiday based around.As it was October it was useful to dart into the Starbucks to pick up a hot drink to keep us warm and fuelled a little longer!Astronomical clock isn't amazing but you'll want to decide for yourself!Beautifully lit at night, grab a bench and take it in.

A vibrant, buzzing place perfect for people watching!. We visited whilst the Easter markets were there, meaning there was a profusion of little stalls selling hot wine, beer, non-alcoholic drinks, hot and cold food and lots of souvenirs and assorted goods, with plenty of tacky things and plenty of beautiful things too!As with everywhere in Prague, it is a little 'rough around the edges' - watch your footing, wear flat-ish shoes you can walk in, beware of cobbles and accept that shop shutters will likely have a little graffitti on them. That said, it doesn't take away from the atmosphere of the place - don't get conned by the tourist-trap restaurants (there are plenty of great ones so if you sit down and don't like the menu or prices, get up and go to another one or try a few side streets) but do grab a coffee, take a seat and people-watch, or take one of the free walking tours. It is a beautiful, historical city with stunning buildings and this is one of the best places to see some great examples.If you're here already, after taking a look at the Astrological Clock (be there on the hour!) make sure you head along Celetná to see Powder Gate or head down Pařížská into the old Jewish town, to window shop at the (exceedingly expensive) designer shops and take in the Old Jewish Cemetary.
Easter in prague. The market at Easter was a delight and we loved the Old Square, all cobbly and interesting. Plenty of tours depart from here.
Old Town Square. I liked the history of the place,old buildings with history attached the buzz and all the little stalls selling different things.

We couldn't leave...beautiful!. We couldn't leave...there were concerts playing the whole time, and the sheer beauty of the buildings and concept of the public space kept us walking beyond our feet's possibilities..The littel Mucha Museum had some interesting info and photos that was new to us also..We have decided we must come back to see the rest of the town another time.

Great, as long as you are canny and keep your wits about you. Prague Old Town Square is a mixture of wonderful architecture, high culture and rampant tourist trap!The great things about it are well documented in other reviews on here but a lot of the seedy stuff isn't.Litter and graffiti is quite bad, and a few of the cobbles in the Square and surrounding streets are loose or missing.We had no problems whilst we were here and neither should you if you're careful with where you keep your money stashed out of harm's way, and avoid the hawkers, vendors that don't advertise their prices and expensive tourist trap bars and restaurants.I was initially nervous about having to carry our passports at all times (you can be fined for not doing so) and large amounts of money for food and drink, entrance fees and shopping purchases etc but we were fine after taking sensible precautions.Did see one police arrest but considering the crowds and the setting I was amazed at the lack of visible crime and the low key police presence (plain clothes police are on patrol and do seem to do a good job.We saw beggars prostrate on the ground with hands outstretched but then it was Easter and maybe its a tradition - alms for the poor and all that. At least they weren't aggressive though and didn't pester you.It's also amazing how people will debase themselves for money, from living statues to the black gentleman with the marracas, to a late middle aged man dressed as a native American Indian doing a war dance! Still, one man's people with no dignity doing anything for money is another man's "local colour" so you take your pick. Not all of the vendors are rip-off merchants, some are good value and you know what you are paying upfront so you can't tar them all with the same brush. Equally, not all of the establishments on the square are expensive - again, you take your choice and pay your money - but even going 2 minutes away from the square brings the reward of top quality great value food and drink.The astronomical clock is so-so but let's face it you're gonna go and see it anyway so make your own mind up. Going up the Clock tower is a good experience though if you're ok with heights and getting jostled a bit, and the Mucha exhibition is excellent in a very understated way. We didnt do the Dali exhibition in the same building though, maybe next time we are in Prague!We felt safe throughout in Prague, which really is a beautiful city.All-in-all, use your common sense and you should be fine. Don't stand in one place for too long or get into conversations with any of the hawkers or give anyone the opportunity to rob you. Keep your bag closed and in sight at all times, and any serious money in a zipped inside jacket or bag pocket - that's my advice, otherwise enjoy the Square (and the city) for what it is.

Great Location. I got married in the Old Town Hall and came out to many tourists. What a great experience never to be forgotten. The Old Town Square is a lively place with many markets and entertainment going on.
Bohemian & historical center. Great to take a lot of pictures. One piece of history just around the corner. ideal to walk and take a beer in a bar.
Avoid the crowds. Old Town Square is really beautiful - but, although I was visiting in winter, it was packed most of the time. I can't imagine what it would be like in summer.

Great. Great view, a lot of old architecture around. There is a nice market on the square. But also a lot of exchange booths around. DO NOT use yellow and orange ones, as well as street exchangers - they can cheat on you.
Visit during night. The lights around each Gothic structure will leave you in awe. I loved the walk around Old town square

The Beauty of The Square. Can get ripped off by the food stallholders but a very picturesque area all the same. A good starting point for the daily walks and you always knew where to head back to.
Suggest using restaurants outside the square - miles cheaper.

Picture post card setting. This is a beautiful square, steeped in history, each building is unique and has amazing architecture, scultpures and very picturesque, I kept waiting for Chitty Chitty Bang Bank to come around the corner:)

Easter break. I posted this also on Old Town. Old Town Square was a happening spot. Whether you are a college student or adult, you certainly have a good time. There are alot of restaurants, bars and vendors to keep the square a hopping place even late at night.

Get there on the hour and enjoy the clock tower animations!. Lots of people, I've heard this is a busy pick-pocket area. Certainly there were a lot of "walking ATM's" there, which I found to be curious. The would offer differing exchange rates and just walk up to you. I've heard that they get you to take out your cash and then run with it. Beware! Old Town square is full of life, animation, and history.

Come early to avoid the crowds. This gorgeous square is a center of activity in Prague. Tour groups, merchants and tourists crowd into the market to shop, people watch, eat, drink and watch the famous clock display. Come early, drink some mulled wine and explore.

Nice walk. Very nice old square, with church and the astronomical watch. Full of tourists though, as expected. Nice place for taking beautiful pictures for photography lovers. It's in the heart of the old town and everything is close, Charles bridge is just 5 minutes walking. Nice at night as well, well lightened.

Stunning architecture. Although it seems always to be absolutely packed with tourists, the Square is breathtaking. Get up early one morning and take a walk around, the ornate facades are simply beautiful.

Amazing City. Just returned from Prague, a city everyone should see. Charles Bridge, The Clock, the Powder Tower and everything is so historic, beautiful, and simply amazing. Had mulled wine in an open patio. Found a restaurant, Solobovka - in Prague 1, food was amazing and so cheap. Saw a beautiful 7 piece string concert at the public building - which is so art deco. There is nothing I can say negative about this vibrant city. The beer is much tastier than in North America as they put more hops in it. I highly recommend this vacation spot.

Beautiful square with lots to see. It is beautiful, but absolutely packed with people, day and night. There are guides offering free tours in Spanish and English. We took an English one and it was the best tour of a city that I've ever had.You could easily spend 2 to 3 hours in the square visiting all the churches, museums and simply hanging around. The weather was very cold when we went, but on a warm day, it would have been great to sit outside and see the world go by.
Underwhelming. The square itself is great. The problem is all the people pestering you to buy or visit things you don't want to buy or visit. Most bar and cafe staff are great though.

Fairy tale charm. The old town square in Prague is a must. It is like stepping into a page of a fairy tale book when you walk into the squareI've been to Prague 5 times and each time I'm still amazed by the old town square. The markets at Christmas and Easter are worth a visit but equal the square is worth a visit at any time. If you visiting the square I would recommend you have lunch up on the terraceIn the U Prince for the most breathtaking views. Make sure to bring your camera!!!
great experience. what a magical place specially a night time. we went to the easter market and had lovely hot dogs and hot chocolate i could off stayed there all night.

Visit when there are markets on.. A great area to spend a few hours although we visited when the Easter markets were on which were amazing. Restaurants can be expensive around the square so it's worth looking down side streets.

Most beautiful during christmas!. The square is probably at its best during the holidays. Very busy every hour of the day. The little decorated houses sell all kinds of things from christmas ornaments to hot dogs and hot wine! There is also a stage where they organize events, happend to see a children's choir singing traditional and christmas songs, it was magical!
Atmospheric. Loved the whole feel of the square. Hustle and bustle (Easter time) which may or may not have been the reason. Christmas type markets, live music and of course the Astronomical Clock.
Unmissable part of any trip to Prague. Very busy, but remarkable set of eclectic buildings and of course the famous clock make this a key part of any visit to Prague
Go up to the view tower. Beautiful square and nice views from the top of the clock tower. So after you watch the clock performance go up to the view tower and see prague from the birds prospective..

A good point of reference. If you're looking to get your bearings and reach important tourist destinations throughout the city, the square can be particularly useful due to its large size and unique buildings. Be wary of the astronomical clock, which will bring huge crowds every hour. Most of the goods sold by vendors are remarkably overpriced, and can be found cheaper throughout the city. Unless you really need to pick up a souvenir quickly, avoid buying here. For reference, Old Town Square is a roughly 10 minute walk from Charles Bridge, only a few dozen meters from the Powder Gate, and about 20 minutes from Prague Castle and St. Vitus Cathedral.

Awe inspiring beauty. The distinctive architecture of Prague will take your breath away! Everywhere you look, fantastic ancient buildings beg for your attention. Spend time mesmerized by the wonderful Astronomical Clock. Take photos by the dozen. This is a really wonderful place to visit. And afterwards, settle into to a lunch and a glass of wine at one of the many restaurants and cafes overlooking the Square, and watch the world go by!

Easter Market fun. This was a wonderful square to experience at Easter. Even though it was a week before Easter, the markets were in full swing, with competitions and entertainment on stage, fresh sausage on buns for sale, hot drinks, and the ever present, yummy, cooked dough with almonds and sugar. Yum! I also really enjoyed seeing the hand decorated Easter eggs of all sizes and colours for sale. As this square is central to pretty much everything, and as pretty much all tour groups go through to see the fabulous old clock, it can get a little crowded at the top of the hour. Still, it was wonderful.Of the entertainment that was specifically for Easter, I enjoyed seeing the local girls doing a traditional dance; as well, I found the oyster shucking competition wonderfully entertaining.If you can get to the square for Easter, then its definitely worth the visit.

Ancient market place. The very heart of Prague. I admired the different architectural styles. Obviously you will come across many tourists there, so beware of pickpockets. You can dine in one of the restaurants but the price reflects the location. In some periods there were market stalls which sell food and souvenirs - I would not buy the latter - they are not Czech originaly.

A place to sit and people watch. I liked to sit on the benches in the square and watch the coming and going of the many people who passed through. There are also a multitude of photo opportunities, from the spectacular churches, Astronomical Clock, monument and the Metronome in the distance.

Quaint. Quaint, historic, well preserved with lots of cafes, restaurants, bars, souvenir shops dotted around everywhere.Better to wear a comfortable shoe or trainers, the street is made of cobblestones, not good for the knees & ankles:-)
Nice time. Enjoyed the weekend market in Old town. Lot of hustle and bustle which was nice for tourists like us. Bought lot of souvenirs.
If ever a square typified your vision of times past. Wonderful architecture - well preserved - and the bells chiming make for a magical atmosphere.One cannot visit Prague and miss this

Magical town square. The Old Town Square is a beautiful part of Prague which is highly accessible. It is always busy with plenty of places to eat (even if the restaurants in this area are a little pricier as they are in the main tourist region!). We went in the evening at about 7pm and it looks so magical all lit up with the market stalls. The magic also continues throughout the day when evenmore market stalls are open and you can really explore the side streets. A lot of tours also start from this area making it a great place to go on your first day in Prague!

changed since last visit. I loved Prague when I visited it two and a half years ago. When I returned it had changed. I felt threatened. In Old Town Square - which I loved before - one is now pestered by individuals asking 'Do you want to change money?. DON'T - it's a scam. Then (there a lovely Easter market) I was tapped on the shoulder by a stall holder 'Your bag is open. Zip it up, you must not have it open in Prague'. the zip on my back pack was slightly ajar. Then the vagrants! It was common to see the down- and-outs circulating the Old Town Square, dipping into the waste paper baskets and eating (and indeed drinking) anything they could find. One felt very uneasy.The market was lovely, the Clock still fun, but Prague has changed. Not for the better I am sorry to say.
Market stalls. We enjoyed going around the various souvenir stalls and taking photographs of the clock tower and buildings in the area.
march. Sadly we were just before the tourist season opened, so no horse drawn carriages but compensated by comparitive freedom from .tourist groups/

The beating heart of Prague. The Old Town Square is an amazing area to wander around. On this visit we saw the Easter Markets, and there is always music and street entertainment to watch. Even late at night it is a safe place to walk around and soak up the atmosphere.

Christmas picture post-card perfect. We visited Prague on our 25th wedding anniversary in December as part of a riverboat Christmas Market cruise. It had just snowed in Prague the day we arrived so it was sparkling with fresh snow. The Christmas Market in the Old Square was amazing, the snow was gently falling, and the Christmas decorations around the square were beautiful. Prague's Old Town is remarkable with most of the buildings original. A walk through would be wonderful winter, spring, summer, or fall.

Nice area. Prague is a beautiful city and the square here mixes old architecture, with a lot of czech (and international) restaurants. Plus just a short walk from old town which is also very beautiful.

must see in prague. Old city is preserved as old city. narrow streets and old buildings are very amazing. You may want to visit this place few times so go to this place first. Many good restaurants nearby
Must see it. Maybe the best place to go on Prague, you can feel centuries of history there. It is a very nice please to spend a couple of hours.
Absolutely beautiful. Beautiful square, we went to the top of the clock tower and what a view! The Thai massage in the square is great value and a must do experience, not a bit seedy. 9€

Very interesting area to visit. This square is surrounded by cute restaurants, coffee houses, souvenir shops and much more. You can spend hours exploring all the small streets aurrounding it and it feels impossible to get lost because no matter where we went we wound up back there. Very interesting place. You must visit if you are in Prague.

Heart of the City, Beginning& End for All our days on Prague. Bustling Central area of Pragues Old Town, The Heart of the City for sure - especially for tourists, czechs, which is great, but also for pimps, and hookers, (not so good).The Old Clock is a work of art, and yu owuld need a long time to stand and work out how it actually works. A large market, based in the central area around the fountain, with many cafes and bars around the sides.The down side here is prices and unsavoury folk here too. Your Pilsner is going to cost you between 60-100 CZK here, (£2-£3.50) As a comparison 1or2 streets back, the most expensive Pilsner I had was 59CZK, and in many places I regularly got it between 25-36CZK (£0.90-£1.25) People will say, thats what you pay for central prices, but when you consider these cheaper prices were within 2minutes of the centre, and you get real czech experience, please make the effort. If you read my other reviews, I will list a few real czech puns worth visiting.The other bad thing here is the Pimps handing out flyers for strippers, or calling cards for hookers, and on occasion the hookers themself approaching us...for young lads thats ok, but they were appraoching men, with women and kids...which is brutal. so, its only getting a very good i am afraid.

Old heart of Prague. Thje old square has to be seen and is one of the beautiful sites of Prague. Enjoy take the pictures wonder around the market but I would advise that you head back through the other little streets that feed off of it if you are looking to have a drink or get something to eat. Like all big attractions the prices are always doubled near them.
