The astronomical clock does its thing every hour from 9 to 9, and it really is a treat to watch the different figures parade by the windows until the cock crows! People love it, and rightly so, so there's typically always a crowd. Great view from the top of the town hall. I just like to wander about or sit and have a beer and people watch. The courtyard of Tyn church is worth a visit as well. Definitely a not miss part of Prague, which has so many wonderful attractions.

Nice in the Daytime, Magical at Night.. If you don't already know, Prague is almost as been about the experience as it is about being there having fun. You've got to know when to just go with all the tourist crowds. Old Town Square at night has such an atmosphere to it, one which you need to sit down in a street cafe and just have a beer to experience. There's every language being spoken, thousands of people with faces in maps, heaps of photographers and sometimes even the naughty pickpocket. But it's all what makes Bohemia the place to be, from here to the bridge and to the towers the views are exceptional. The prices are more expensive, so have a beer and people watch.

Breathtaking, and a sure inspiration for Disneyland!. Everyone is a tourist here and your camera will not stop clicking. One great building after another, Prague has so much to offer.The square is touristic but even the drinks and food - while expensive compared to other locations - is affordable.
Astronimical clock. Excellent great cafe around the square, although expensive, good food and beer too (loved the 1 litre jugs)

Must see in this city. Along with the Bridge & castle, this is the main reason why people come to Prague. Love the hustle & bustle of the old square, with lots of cobbled streets with nooks & crannies to explore
you've probably seen the pictures. it is a very highly photographed area, and for good reason, this area is gorgeous. and a must see. some good restaurants are near by as well...
Old Town Square in the early morning. I love the place especially in the early sunny cool morning. The streets are clean and quiet. I enjoyed every moment!

A must-see place in Europe. Well... just come and see it with your own eyes. The monument, the 600-year-old clock and their show, the tower (now we know where disney castle was copied from:))), hot wine and snacks, cabrios and boutiques. Very nice place.
Lots of hustle and bustle.. Lots of people around with the smells wafting from the street vendors. Beautiful buildings all around.

The Old meets the new. Such a wonderful place to visit.Plenty of scenes for the photographer to get their teeth into.You need a 360 degree camera to really see the square at its best.Try and photogragh it in daylight and then in the dark,the lighting is brilliant.As a 'tourist trap' be prepared to pay over the odd's for food or a drink in any of the outlets around the square.BEAWARE OF THE STREET HAWKERS THEY MAY NOT BE WHAT THEY SEEM......(PICK POCKETERS)
So many people in a one square!. If you wish the entire area all at once and all old town - you have to climb the clock tower! There is a lift ;)

Full of tourists, but so what.. Tourists, street performers, stalls selling food, restaurants. What more could one want. The buildings surrounding the Square are beautiful, with lovely painted facades. To see it empty, wait for a rainy day.
Such Atmosphere. This is always a busy place with shops around the square open until about 10pm. Lots of places to eat & drink, all offering various types of food - something to suit everyone.
Old Town Square, Prague. Be warned, do not accept offers of exchanging money on the street, a couple where given some notes other that Czech crowns.
Center of the world. Not to be missed in Old Prague! Beautiful surroundings, lots of cultural opportunities...Convivial atmosphere!

The best of Prague history at one location. If you're visit Prague, the Old Town Square is an absolute 'must see.' The center of the old town district, this is where you will see a collection of exquisite architectural styles spanning over 500 years, plus a tremendous variety of shops and eateries. All of this is within visual distance, and a very short walk from the very popular Palladium Mall and a subway station entrance.
Amazing. The astronomical clock is beautiful and the show every hour is something special. However, like everywhere else in Prague, there are too many tourists. Best see the square at midnight.

A must see if you are in Prague. Make sure not to miss the historical centre. A view to the clock tower and the nearby churches is well worth it too. Many museums are just a few minutes walk away, and around it you can taste some great checz food.
Great atmosphere!. I loved the atmosphere of listening to the locals playing their music and singing, while eating a blueberry crepe from the stand on the square!

lots of charm. the Square itself is very charming, with artists, musicians and others hanging out and enjoying the night. Don't bother eating in any of the restaurants there, but if you do, be sure you don't eat at the outlying tables - they don't accept anything but cash, and won't produce receipts for what you order.

Bigger than i thought. Beautiful houses surround the square and it still atmospheric despite being the tourist hub. Not too busy in November. The clock was a bit of a disappointment- cute but not worth waiting too long for, and gettin cought in big crowds.

Just Lovely. I am sure all visitors to Prague will come here. Make sure you spend some time and take in the atmosphere. Yes of course there is some "tat" but the buildings are just magnificent. Make sure you protect your purse/wallet.
A must see in Prague. A market square with many restaurants, shops and interesting sights. The astronomical clock is intriguing. Time your visit to be there on the hour for interesting actions.
Is it possible not to be impressed with the Old Town Square. Just stunning......it would be impossible not to be impressed with this beautiful heritage site.....

a good point of reference. Because of Pragues confusing layout you will get lost if you explore. The town square, the river, and the main station are good points of reference to figure out where you are. Getting lost should be 1 of your goals. there are lots of nice shops, restraunts and buildings between the above 3 points. The square is always busy and known for petty crime, not least the rip off prices. Go 1 block away for the same thing at a reasonable price.

Wonderful place to sit and watch. This area captures the character of Prague; beauty, fashionably dressed people, the assortment of characters and activities from bands to mime to bubble artists. There are 3 very good bakeries just outside the square to the northeast, especially the closest and most authentically bakery like.

A must see. Everyone who visits Prague must go to the old town square daytime and again at night to see it all lit up. The buildings are just amazing soak up the history of them all including the old clock.A word of caution though although to sit at some bars cafes are going to be a bit more expensive because of the location, we were about to have a snack at one place where we seen the prices on the outside, however when we got the menu it was much more expensive, with a note on the menu that prices can be up to 50% cheaper if you eat indoors.There are lots of bars and restaurant in the side streets, you wont be stuck for choice
The most beautiful city square in the world. There are 5 architectural styles on this square alone. From Romanesque to Art Nouveau, even one Rococo palace...

Food in Old Town Square. The Old Town Square is beautiful. However be care of the overpriced food, especially the ham slices. They charge you by the weight of the ham, even if you ask for a small piece. A simple plate of food cost the equivalent of $36. Also in restaurants, they tend to charge you for items, such as a glass of tap water, bread, and even the table settings. You need to be on your toes when ordering food in Prague. Always carry change if you need to visit the powder room. Nothing is free. Nothing.
Watch the world go by. Grab a coffee in the newly opened Starbucks and wander around the square taking in the sights - Astronomical Clock, Churches, street performers etc.

The magic center. Every town has a center, and this is the navel of Prague, the place where the paths of all travelers cross. Smetana, Kafka and even Mozart walked through this square where each building is loaded of historical symbols. Of course, the Old Town Square would look much better if the city did not allow restaurants to occupy part of the public space. These abusive restaurants have permanently installed tables, chairs and awnings on the historic cobblestone square. UNESCO should look into it because it violates the regulations of World Heritage sites.

beautiful square with overprices restaurants. It's hard to find a domestic person here, this is the place of tourists, which doesn't make it any less appealing, though. Avoid the restaurants directly in this square, food is average but prices are steep. Unless you wanna be in the spot, with hordes of tourists around you.
Well worth a visit. Lovely architecture with a wonderful atmosphere. There's so much that catches your eye, that you don't know where to look.
Very busy. This place was very busy, but worth while to pass by of course! One hasn't been to Prague if you weren't here

Good if it's what interests you. The Old Town Square was certainly picturesque and I would recommend a trip up the clock tower for spectacular views over the city. It's a great place to sit with a coffee or hearty plate of goulash and watch the world go by but other than that there isn't much to do so if you like to be busy I wouldn't schedule more than half an hour for your visit.Everyone says to see the Astronomical clock chime the hour - I wouldn't bother, a complete let down!
Beautifully preserved square. It is stunningly well preserved and gives you a sense of the art, grandeur and history of the city. Full of tourists.

Touristy, But Fun!. Although there are hoards of people, all the time, there's a charm to being in this place. Tons of local shops from the high end crystal to low end usual souvenirs. Restaurants flourish everywhere. They can provide service with warming lamps if it's cold out.
Magical Square! A must for all Prague visitors!. The lovely cobble stoned streets, heritage buildings and delicious restaurants makes it simply wonderful just walking and wondering about!

Lovely!. I love the square with the fresh pork spits roasting and the cinimon sugarbread and the gluwein in the winter! Make sure to visit the astronomical church and see Tyn church all lit up at night! It's beautiful!

Prague Square still has its charm. I specially like the little old timer playing the saxophone in the middle of the Square. The beauty and charm of the Square is that it is not yet spoilt by a slew of international fast food chains. In lovely weather you can sit and have lunch or a cup of coffee.
Heart of the city. This is where everything gets started. If you want to do some tours, just walk around and you will see the different companies.

Picturesque heart of Prague. Picturesque square with a beautiful mixture of architecture. Plenty of places to eat, drink and enyoy the views. The hourly Astronomical Clock 'show' is fun to witness every time.

All that jazz. Could have stayed for hours listening to renditions of my favourite easy listening sounds from street musicians. We also watched the astronomical clock go off at 12. Worth the wait. We waited in a cafe opposite watching in comfort. Of course you pay extra for that prime site so go to the back streets for a cheaper coffee. We also got a worse rate of exchange in the square than elsewhere.

Very Busy Square!. This is the main square in Prague and is very busy with tourists and restaurants everywhere! By night the area is well lit and makes for some great pictures!There are many restaurants and bars around the square however be carefull when checking your bill as we recieved a charge for "Recomended Service" on top of the service charge which nearly doubled the total cost of the bill!

Historic and beautiful.. Great restaurants around the square, and beautiful buildings everywhere, lovely little cobbled shopping lanes around the back of the square.Beware of large crowds of tourists at weekends.
The heart and soul of Prague. The heart of Prague. Culture, food, people, cathedrals - it is all there. And go off the beaten path

very nice area. Since the early Middle Ages Prague's oldest marketplace has been situated in the very center of the city. We would be hard-pressed to find many events in the city's history that do not involve Old Town Square. It has been the site of several unfortunate and tragic occasions: on June 21, 1621, it was here that 27 representatives of the anti-Habsburg insurrection were executed; the Old Town Hall was nearly destroyed at the end of World War Two when the Nazis set fire to it; and in February 1948, from the balcony of the Golz-Kinsky Palace, Klement Gottwald announced the Communist Party's successful coup. However, the square's “dark side” has never robbed it of its rich vibrancy and festivities.This square was exceptional both during the day and at night. Felt totally safe. Every direction you look is stunning. It does get busy though especially on the hour... Plenty of places for eating. Side streets great for exploring.

Old Town Square. This is a huge square teeming with activity. People are everywhere. There are restaurants outside where you can sit to enjoy the activities. The aquare is surrounded by beautiful architecture and well worth the price of a drink to sit and enjoy.
central square with history feeling. very nice historic square with Astronomical clock and Tyn Cathedral, close to Paris street with famous world fashion brands boutiques

This is where it all happens. The sqaure was a lovely place to sit and watch people. You can get some lovley local food here too. Beware the guys selling the cooking ham with beer. They will charge you by weight and tend to give the tourists the fattier cuts which means you pay more for less meat. I got stung but I must say though, it was a lovely dish.

Hmmmmm.... Bit boring..but OK to waste half a day. Astronomical clock is OK, but don't expect too much or you will be disappointed. The street musicians can be entertaining. Well depending on the day you visit I suppose.. Well.. you might like it more..my wife did!
old square. everything you want in shopping is here or close to from the traditional markets to bars or upmarket shops down to the usual touristy haunts

Busy place.. This is a busy and popular place, especially on the hour when the Astronomical Clock performs its magical display, and the Trumpeter sounds across the Square. This is a good place to try hot, mulled wine and good, local sausages, and wander back through the old streets. Beware pickpockets though!

Busy vibrant square. The atmosphere in the Old Town Square is great with street musicians and lots of cafes selling mulled wine. Prague must be one of the most beautiful cities ever. The buildings are magnificent.

Always a busy site. Beautiful buildings and history on all sides of the square, if you can afford it grab a beer/coffee in one of the better on-street cafe's (they've all got heaters on!) and watch the world go past! Disliked the larger crowds at times and seemingly as a central meeting point for all tours/groups for the city!

Old Europe Charm. Get to this place and get lost in its charm. This is the place where you go to have a feel and not if you are counting what to see. I spent an entire Sunday here. What did i do? Heard the jazz singer play his instruments, strolled around, watched the watch tower and clock, bought some stuff,had a beer or two, ate some food and just absorbed the whole atmosphere. Go there and feel the place , it is hard to describe being transported in time and space.

A must see in Prague!. The Town Square is where there is a lot of action. The food, though good, is expensive in comparison to other areas due to the high traffic in tourist trade there. Great shops surrounding the area-again higher priced than if you walk a ways out! But the CLOCK is an absolute must! Get all the details on when, how and by whom it was built. Then be ready at the hour to take your pictures along with hundreds of other folks!

Nice place to stop for a beer. Lots of cafe/bars to sit and enjoy a Prague beer or two! Little bit pricey but your paying for the view of the square and the Clock tower. Very busy at times but well worth a visit.

Great place to hang about. The old town square is a great place to hang about when in Prague and is the place where you'll find most of the tourists ..Its the starting point for most tours and you could easily sit on one the benches and watch the world go by ..There are street performers, hordes of tourists, lots of restaurants and is truly a happening place ...a must visit when in Prague ..

Beautiful architecture. Fantastic old architecture everywhere you look, great place to sit for a drink and take in the views. Only negative is that the restaurants on the actual square are overpriced for food which is of very average quality here. Better restaurants are located just a short distance from the square.
Beautiful place, crowded. Wonderful place to visit, nice architecture and historical buildings. only drawback: it's very very crowded, but in a place like that you can't expect anything different.

Seedy. Brothels and massage parlours everywhere one looked. Buskers trying their hand at entertaining, touts trying to lure you into shops and restaurants. Tourist traps, hidden charges. Viva chocolate shop is lovely but the chef is very forward asking for tips. The square smelled of pee and sewers. Very overwhelming and easy to lose whoever you're travelling with.

Exceptional. This square was exceptional both during the day and at night. Felt totally safe. Every direction you look is stunning. It does get busy though especially on the hour... Plenty of places for eating. Side streets great for exploring.

Loved this area!!. Great lively place to hang out in the evenings. Yes it is touristy, but its a beautiful town square, with loads of nice cafes/restaurants with outdoor seatings, and they serve great hot/gluh wine :)! You can see the astronomical clock - climb the tower for great panoramic views, the Tyn church, St.Nicholas church - beautiful area. Maybe listen to the live music band near the center. We were there almost every evening after a whole day of sightseeing etc...

Must see!. The Old Twn Square will probably be very crowded but don't let that stop you from visiting. Beautiful buildings and plenty of places to have coffee or a beer while you people watch. To avoid crowds visit either early in the morning or in the evening after dinner.
Old Town square. The old buildings, Cathedral, restaurants, stores, local entertainment and general ambience here were great

Iconic Square Lives Up to Its Reputation - Don't Miss!. This really feels like the very heart of Prague. I visited in October and it was clear and crisp - just beautiful. There were still many people this time of year but not wall-to-wall. The striking architecture, churches, and buildings steeped in history, this is truly one of the loveliest and most beautiful places I've been in Europe. This is the site of many historic moments in Prague and Czech history.The centerpiece of the square is the statue of the martyr, Jan Hus, burned as a heretic in 1415.The Tyn Church dominates one side of the square with its two Gothic towers that can be seen throughout Prague. It is surrounded by smaller buildings that lead to the square. Across the square is the beautiful St Nicholas Church is in the Baroque style. At one corner of the square is the Old Town Hall - buildings that were added on to the Old Town Hall Tower over the years. On one side of the tower is the magnificent Astronomical Clock; it really is worth it to stop during on the hour and see this masterpiece from the 1300s in all its glory. (The Town Hall faces the square, the clock is around the corner - get there a bit early to get a good viewing spot).The skeleton (representing death) begins the hour by ringing a bell, symbolizing that death waits for no one. The twelve apostles then proceed out and and a rooster crows at the end.TIP: After your finished watching the clock, look behind you. There is a crystal shop. They have free restrooms! (unadvertised, so you have to know about it). Enter from the square or from the little alley, turn right at the stairs (go straight past the stairs if you enter from the alley) and there you are!As you're facing the clock, note the big brown door/archway to the left in the adjacent building. Fridays and Saturdays are big wedding days in Prague and this is a famous door through which new brides and grooms pass through for pictures. There are many vendor stands where you can get a cup of hot wine, hot chocolate, or coffee, as well as meats,sandwiches, and other snacks. This adds to the festive marketplace atmosphere of the square, Which, after all, was what it used to be.Keeping the Old Town Hall on your left and the square on your right, head across the square and up Parizska to the Jewish Quarter and the famous Jewish Cemetery (you could also hang a left on Kaprova), just a few minutes walk. As you pass the Old Town Hall, note the crosses on the sidewalk that represent the 27 executed leaders of the rebellion against Emperor Matthias in 1621. Legend has it that their ghosts return every year on June 21st, the anniversary of the executions.Or, continue walking out of the square past the Astronomical Clock, make your way to Karlova,and on to Charles Bridge. There are lovely shops and charming streets.There are cobblestones everywhere so if you do nothing else, where appropriate footwear so you can enjoy it. I also found a golf cart tour (I believe tucked away behind the National Gallery) and arranged for a tour of the Old Town area. It was 50 euro (1200KC) for a little over an hour tour. She came and picked 4 of us up at the Hilton and would have dropped us there as well, but we elected to be dropped off at Republik Square for a look around and then walk back. This is an EXCELLENT option for those who might have a little trouble walking as you can see many of the sites of Old Town and Jewish Quarter. The golf cart seats 5 and the cost is for the tour - not per person. We felt it was worth it. There are blankets for chillier days - we took advantage of them on that cold afternoon. Although they advertised that they took credit cards, at the end of our tour she said the credit card machine was broken and we would have to pay cash. We had not been in town very long and hadn't come prepared with Euros so had to go to an ATM while she waited - pretty big inconvenience. We found that a lot in Prague -reluctance to take credit cards. This tour was still worth it though and I would recommend it. HOWEVER - you do not actually see the Astronomical Clock on the golf cart tour, so arrange to see that separately or get dropped off there. Since the clock face doesn't face the square, it can't be seen from the golf cart.
fairy like. fairy like at night. Different every evening. Watch the clock move !! Visit a concert at the church.

Of course you will visit here!!. A fantastic atmosphere for October. You must visit here and be sure to look out for the astronomical clock. It is not just as good as the Anchor Clock in Vienna but you will not want to miss it.

Mingle with others. Just walk and enjoy. Stop for coffee, a snack, a glass of wine or a beer. Citizens of the Czech Republic consume more ber per capita than any other nation. Taste some Czech beer and you will understand why.

Beautiful and Enimagtic. Love the history, amazing unique arquitecture, the atmosphere. Easy access via metro or by foot. Free guided walking tours are readily available in English, Spanish and other languages.

Feels like the real heart of Prague. When I went to Wenceslas Square, I foolishly imagined it to be more like this. The old town square is beautiful, although be prepared to pay a fortune for a coffee (as you would expect). Having said that, as it was my husband's birthday we did splash out on cake and coffee in Cafe Italia (I think it was called) and it was very good!

Great old world square. Loved this square with its cobblestones, beautiful churchs on two sides, statues and the astronomical clock that gets everyone heading to it on the hour. Street food and drink vendors set up right on the square for people watching. Went to four major eastern European cities and this square was the most active of all the places we visited at night, up to and after midnight. Always people enjoying friends, food, drinks and photography.

beautiful. Really beautiful square. Take a camera and snap up all of the chocolate box looking buildings. The jazz buskers add to the experience and make sure you get a hot chocolate, they are more like chocolate sauce in a cup than the milky kind you would get in the UK. I also tried watermelon ice cream, don't do that.
Great square in the heart of Prague. Really beautiful square and especially beautiful at night. Many restaurants and bars around here and lots to see and do. Certainly worth a visit

mr lee will be back.. we came over the bridge into the old town,walked about 3 mins then pow, 3 huge guns just hanging in the air, then street people doing their thing,and very good they where. and then after about another 5 mins walks i had gone back in time,it felt like the 15 century. i had become dr who.enough said. go to paruge.

Hard to take it all in. Old Town Square just appears! You are walking and there it is! Awe-inspiring, open to gaping and staring, it is a place to spend some time just looking. Varied performers, plus the astronomical clock made it worth the wait. The square was packed in October; I can't imagine what it would be like during high season! A short walk from here and there is a shopping center where you can find anything you like, even massages! Some of the ham food stalls sell meat by weight, so be aware and tell them how much/little you want. We didn't and we spent over $30 on lunch! It was good, but we ate ham for two days.

Awesome. Wow, the Old Town Square had us totally amazed. What a beautiful area! The astronomical clock was fascinating, the buildings are just gorgeous with a sight to see everywhere you looked. We enjoyed every minute we spent here. They've done an amazing job of rebuilding this area.

take some pics & move on. Extremely touristy & like with many historic town squares across Europe, the restaurants in the immediate area are overpriced and not that good. Bordering vendors and even some waiters are pushy with trying to get you into their places. Take your fill of pics and move on to other areas of the city.

Architecturally beautiful. The town square is a feast for your eyes with all periodic buildings, the hustle and bustle of tourists, restaurants and activities going on.Always keep your wits about you though in facinities like this, this is where the seasoned pickpockets thrive on the unexpexcting tourists.
Superb. Gr8 place to pass time in Old Town Square. Street performers keep you entertained all day long. Lots of tourists, happening place.

Heart of Prague. Beautiful area of Prague. Lots of good places to eat and shop (although one or two pubs might try and rip you off, so beware of what they're charging you). There were outdoor markets and food stalls when we were there which were good, especially the food as a quick snack.

Bustling and oozing character.. Everyone goes here, all tours appear to start from this location. The Astronomical Clock does it's bit on the hour, followed by a trumpet encore. The food stalls are varied and reasonably priced, a beer and a pork sandwich will cost about 200 crowns. The street entertainers are very good although the horses that congregate in the squuare smell a wee bit! There are lots of small cafe's, where you can sit outside under patio heaters with a blanket if its chilly. It is a beautiful place at night, all the building are lit up, and the atmosphere is excellent.
Beautiful at night!. Vist the Old Town Square at night, that's when this area of the city really comes to life and shows it's true beauty!

You don't want to miss it!. Prague's Old Town Square is a huge square in the heart of Prague where there always seems to be something happening. One day when I visited last year there were well over a hundred artists there with their easels and many were painting or drawing the scenery around the. Another time there was a girl holding up a sign that said: "Free hugs". You can be sure I got one! And there are almost always buskers in the square entertaining the spectators. Another landmark, the Astronimical Clock, is on one end of the square and there are two magnificent churches overlooking the square. On one side of the square there is a large monument to Jan Huss, who was the founder of he Protestant movement in Bohemia. Both the Charles Bridge and Republic Square are located about a half mile from Old Town Square in opposite directions.
You'll forget about time. Probably the best square in Europe. Go there. It's almost magical. There are many things to see including street musicians who are so good you can watch them forever.

Our favorite place to hang out. We kept travelling through the Square on our way to the Jewish Quarter, Lesser Quarter, Charles Bridge, and Muncipal House. Go there day or night and there's activity. Good shops and restaurants are located there. Get day and night shots of the famous landmarks.
Don´t miss!. The Old Town is full of beautiful and well preserved buildings. The architecture is wonderful and astronomica clock is wonderful

Prague in its Glory. This place is not to be missed. One of the greatest places that I have visited in Europe. During the high season, the Old Town Square is swamped with people. It is almost impossible to walk around and not find yourself gaping at the wonders around you. The restaurants are very expensive in the area but they are well worth at least one try. This is where they shot the film "Mission Impossible" (1996) and "Amadeus" (1984).

great day or night. What a great place you have so many lovely building all around the square take a seat around the monument & you an admire them all. In the day try a market stalls with traditional food including local beer & hot wine. In the evenings the buildings seem to take on new shapes so even more sight seeing can be done or choose to sip wine or coffee while people watching.

Chaos at its best. Everyone visiting Prague visits the Old Town Square or at the very least walks across it coming from or going to other sites in the city. Do a miss on the restaurants along the perimeter, they're too expensive and many offer inferior food with even worse service. The Old Town Clock is worth watching once at the top of the hour. Visit the square as the sun comes up and you'll have the whole square practically to yourself. It's breathtaking to see the sun peak through the buildings and cast long shadows across the cobbled square. Visit it between mid-morning and late evening and you'll be one of thousands doing the same thing. Visit it after dark and you'll be amazed at the beautiful lighting of the square itself and all the surrounding buildings.

Exudes Charm. Old Town Square is among the few memorable places I would visit time and again just tosoak up the multi-sensory atmosphere offered by exceptionally beautiful and dramatic architecture, the universe of travelers who eagerly await the performance of the Astronomical Clock, the street performers, the cafes and vendors. And it's only the heart of the complex maze of surrounding streets that invite you to relax and get lost. Love it!

Journey back in time. The Old Town Square dating from the 12th century is a bustling marketplace for tourists. The centuries old buildings are charming and awe-inspiring. The Old Town Hall and Astronomical Clock and Tyn Church attract quite a crowd. Sit back and enjoy lunch or a beer at an outdoor cafe while people watching.

Incredible!. Old Town Square is just breathtaking. Numerous shops, restaurants, bars, etc... Most offer outside seating with heaters and blankets if necessary. Prices although higher in the tourist spots are still much lower than one would expect based upon US prices.

Old Town Square, Prgaue. The square is very pretty and a great place to get a first feel for the city; wear comfortable clothes and walking shoes. Old Town Square can be used as a starting point for sightseeing throughout the city or it's easy to find a cafe where you can sit and enjoy some people watching. Picturesque churches - often offering concerts at various times during the day, the astronomical clock and plenty of shopping can be found nearby. Not to be missed during a visit to Prague.
Great old square. Really pretty and atmospheric. Lots of places to grab a beer and rest the feet surrounded by beautiful buildings
Old Town. Very interesting, easy to get around, but you shoud do a walking tour, to get the history and understand what you are looking at!
crowded!. Definitely a must-do as the square is beautiful, but I would recommend visiting in the morning as the square really fills up during the day.
Neat but way too touristy?. A must see, but really, very, extremely touristy! The churches are very nice, including the tower. The food stands nearby is also good, providing cheap snacks.

an attraction not to miss when in Prague. feel transported back in time - great place to people watch, relax while immersing yourself in the vibrancy of the area, have coffee or dine al fresco! Astronomical clock is in the area and lots of shops!

Pretty and interesting. This is definitely a must see in Prague. You can tell by the large crowds mingling around. Just be careful. This place is also a place where thieves practice their trade very frequently

Caters to Foreigners!. This place has so many things to see, from museums, shopping, boats and castles. There are better places to eat at if you go off the beaten path. Don't be afraid to. You will find cheaper eats and great deals on luxuries like massages for only 8 euros...that equates to about $11 USD

Day or night -- a site to see. Luckily, most tours go from around the square, so we were there nearly every day and two evenings too. Between the cafes, buildings, cathedrals and statues, its just a real happening and real pretty place.

Relaxing spot!!. Old town square is a nice place to take a break and relax. Not only that, but your surrounded by an amazing view of the surrounding buildings and churches. The food is amazing here and i recommend the sausages.

Such diversity... music, food, people!. Great place to sit and people watch! There were many performers, food at both restaurants and street vendors, folks just relaxing... also the starting point for many tours. My advice, explore off the beaten path! So much to see in this city.

Cooooooool Square to see!. You gotta see the Tower, the Clock, and the cool Church all in one square! They usually have live music, and cafe's that you can relax about. Oh, and the "Free Tours" aren't Free. They start Free, but then they ask for money later.
Great experience. You are surrounded by beautiful architecture that spans centuries, comfortable quiet spots, noisy bands and crowds - you name it! A must see in any Prague visit
Go at night. Very touristy and rightly so - magnificent square and all the buildings and churches renovated to a high standard.

very romantic square. Very romantic square to walk on. also by night because it's lovely lighted. go up the tower on the cityhall in the evening: nice romantic lighted view. the tower is open till 22 o'clock what's very nice and it is not so crowded then upstairs. Don't eat or drink at the square because you pay double or triple the price of some other places in Prague. Also the wooden snackbars on the square are to expensive.

Sit and watch the world go by!. This massive, medieval square is something else! The colours, the variety, the buildings, the space, the street artists - all great to see. Take your time and sit on a pavement cafe - and be prepared to be ripped off - but don't mind! It is worth paying the premium to take it all in.
Perfect view form the tower. The biggest square in the Old Town. Nice historical city hall with high tower and famous astronomical clock.
This square has it all. From the clock tower to the cathedral, the art museum, the shopping, the trumpeter playing at the top of the tower on the hour...this square has it all!
Historical & very interesting.. Historical & very interesting. Great shops & restaurants. Within walking distance to our hotel & other downtown attractions.

One of the best squares in Europe. This is one of the best town squares in Europe. Because Prague escaped the ravages of WWII, most of the buildings are the original authentic thing, not a re-built copy. You can spend hours sitting in the square watching the world, and packs of Japanese tourists go by. :) Enjoy the hourly clock show and stroll the cobblestones of one the best preserved cities in Europe.
A must see in Prague. Like all the great squares in the world you have to visit. Stunning buildings there. A place where the people of Prague congregate for special events.
Beautiful but very full. Lovely old square but always very full of large groups of tourists. There might be a quiet time but I didn't find it. Only went into it a couple of times because of that.

Beautiful!. You have to visit it at all times of the day. In the morning it's full of tourists and you might spot a bride or two! in the afternoon stunts start coming and you'd see one at every corner, at the evening the view is amazing and taking photos is a must!
Make sure you are there 10 mins before the hour. The clock is worth a visit, but make sure you get there 10 mins before the hour as it is so busy and beware of pickpockets.
Nice old square. Nice square, but the restaurants around it are more expensive than in other parts of the city. Somewhat of a tourist trap.

Free and a great place to start. The astronomical clock is here - try and see it on the hour. Again, try and grab a bit of info on it before you see it (we used lonely planet) as there are stories behind it. Also the tourist info is on the square

Beautiful Centre. A very popular place with tourists, the old town square surrounds you with stunning architecture entertainment and food. Often there were bands playing in the centre. it is a good place if you want to join a walking tour (look out for the umbrellas) or you can take a tour of the city from the square by a vintage car or by horse and cart. There are many little huts which provide various different types of food. Worth seeing the square both at day and lit up at night.

crowded but fascinating. Great place to just sit and soak in the atmosphere. Very crowded but that also added to the spectacle. Beautiful buildings and loads of character, I loved it here. A word of warning on the premium prices for coffee at the restaurants, we sat down for a break from walking and were prepared to pay for a pricey coffee in order to sit at the square, but after a few minutes of no service decided to go elsewhere. We walked half a block, paid half the price at a lovely little cafe with home made cakes and enjoyed a truly sensational chocolate brownie as well!

ENCHANTING!!. This place and everywhere around it's absolutely superb! You feel transported to another time. Walk around and enjoy the beauty you are seeing in every corner. We had a delicious meal in the restaurant behind the cathedral, not too expensive either.We are planning to go back again next year!!!! and this time we'll go up to the Astronomical Clock, this is something you can't miss.Don't miss Prague, it's one of the most beautiful cities in the world!!!!
Classic old Europe. Quaint cafes, interesting street entertainment, great old sites, hourly clock "show". Friendly locals with good english
Stunning!. The scenery and architecture is absolutely superb! One feels like you are taking a walk in the middle ages! Great place to have a drink and just take in all the beauty you are seeing!

Lovely place to hang out. See the clock, have a leisurely coffee and something to eat, watch all the entertainers and buskers, do some people-watching...you can easily spend half a day here. Going up the clock tower for the view of Prague was well worth the money.

eateries by the square. Im hear again warning people ,the log cabins selling chunks of slowley roasted legs of ham ,Twice i noticed the trouble people were having to pay for the very very expensive meat as we all know that leg pork is not expensive 1 gent ordered 3 chuks but when they asked for money he was flabergasted ,gave 2 back and paid for1 only.Another young man asked for a slice and when told the amont to pay was completely taken aback and his 3 friends all searched thier pockets to find enough money ,they were realy upset at the price being asked to make it more embararrassed the man behind the counter said hurry up please i have people waiting ,i felt realy sorry for the young lad .On our last day i had 200 crowns to get rid of so i asked this same person behind the counter what can i get for 200 hoing i ncould get a small slice of pork no such luck his answer was a small sosage and a small beer so be careful 200 crowns equelled aprox £6

Beautiful & crowded, central.. The square connects you to all parts of the Old Town. Great for meeting. I wouldn't sit at the restaurants that spread around the square, as of they're a bit pricey. And not authentic enough. Other than that if on the walk you can grab a bite next to the old clock, there are nice booths with roast pork and sausage and also Trdelník ( a traditional cake and sweet pastry) which I find delicious.
Very Pretty Square. Good cafes, nice coffee and good for people watching. One cafe just ignored us though and we just found somewhere else to serve us.
I liked it a lot. Beautiful buildings, amazing clock :-) the Town Hall is just terrific! A very nice place to walk in the evenings

Laid back atmosphere. Loved the way people just sat around in the square, listening to musicians or watching different artists at work. There was a very laid back atmosphere about Prague old Town Square which made you feel so relaxed. The buildings surrounding the square were beautiful and the horses and carriages added to the quaint atmosphere. Day or night, the square was filled with people, a great people watching place to be!

Another Square. Nice and spacious. Not overly cramped except with tourists depending on the time of year. If you like to people watch or just like to hang out in a busy place then this would be the perfect place to grab some dinner or coffee.

One of the most beautiful city centres. This is one of the most beautiful city centres I have seen in my life. When you planned a trip to or through Czech, take a day extra to visit this nice city centre.
Must see. Dona little research before studying clock. It is fascinating Very busy at top of each hour as the clock has a little display and trumpeter belts outs a tune.

A good central point!. The Old Town Square is a central point, a place to use to meet people, of a point to find if you have wandered off the beaten track. If you are planning on eating/drinking on Old Town Square then make sure you take a bit more cash with you as you will pay a premium to eat in this area. For better priced food/drink go back into the side streets.

Great atmosphere. Cafes, Restaurants, Food Stalls, Churches, Statues, Followers, Crowds, Musicians... Whatever you desire, it has all... You can easily spend hours here, just drinking coffee, watching people, day dreaming...

Don't Change money at this place. Don't Change money at this place, Comission is zero, but the course is not the left side posted! The real course is at the right, and is not favorable for you! Be careful!

you can't visit it just once, you keep coming back. everything. atmosphere, its magnificence, livelily, absolute superb. could't say anything but positive comments. Been there in the morning, midday, afternoon and night time. taking pics with all sort of light conditions. enjoying a beer under the warmth of the sun at 17.00 in october. super!

Lovely food, Fantastic hosts, well worth a visit!. A very friendly place to visit, very lively & overall very good food! Well worth a visit whether you are with your partner, friends or family you will have a good time.
Wenceslas square. A Czech promotion was on and the square was alive with stalls to try local produce-food,wine and beer!

Always crowded but worth the sightseeing. The layout of this area reminds me of Florence with Church of Our Lady before Tyn at the center and cafes outlining the area between the Tyn Church, St Nicholas Church, and the Old Town Hall Tower. This is the perfect place to start sightseeing in Old Town. Wear comfortable shoes and clothes - you can walk around for hours here. A nice place to shop for fruit or souvenirs is the Fruit Market. If you get hungry, don't fret - there are hundreds of restaurants to choose from!
Beautiful. A beautiful part of Prague. So much to do and see. Great restaurants but if you go out of the square the food prices drop about 50%

All the charm you would expect. This is one of the loveliest squares in all of Europe. You don't really even need to pay to do anything. Just strolling thru at any time of day is charming and a feast of people watching.

Magical Prague. I loved the cafes and musicians playing in the streets. I loved the little food market with the interesting foods at the beginning of the old town. The little boutiques and the nearby massive shopping complex were great. In general just wandering around was a pleasure.

Town Square great for walking about. Pedestrian area so can walk and look and take pictures without having to watch for cars. Huge buildings, one more impressive than the next. Food vendors--be sure to try a trdelnik, a wonderful baked roll that you can watch them make. Delicious and unique! Street performers as well.
String quartet. Loved walking around the Old Town Square, there was an amazing string quartet playing the first night, that we ended up going there the second night just to see them perform again.

YOU HAVE TO SEE THE CLOCK!. Not only is a great place to hang out, and have lunch, coffee or beer, but watching the clock at the top of every hour s quite an experience. Frankly, just watching the people gathering to watch the clock is great fun!

too commercial. I really enjoy a walk there. It's like time travel machine and I was sent to a century ago, however, there are too many shops and bars on the ground floor. It's better to look up (above eye-level) when you take a walk there.
A Must Visit!. I cannot anyone visiting Prague without going to Old Town Square. Have an ice cream and watch the Astronomical Clock do its thing on the hour.
Lovely Place. A lovely town square but very busy, as it is a major tourist place, lots of places to eat and shop. Nice to stop and have a drink while you watch the world go by !

Lively place day or night. So much to see while you sit in a cafe with your drink. Street entertainers, passers by, local shops and the astronomical clock make for an intrresting time. Watch out for the tour sellers!

Lovely spot. This is a lovely spot to stop and have a coffee or meal and watch the world go by in the old square. Not even cold as the terraces are all fitted with heaters which serve the purpose well. Something magical about sitting in the old square especially in the evening.

Beautiful City. The architecture, the cobblestone streets, horse-drawn carriages, outdoor cafes... wonderful city. If you make it to the city center, most sights are within walking distance. You'll get your culture, food, and shopping all in one spot.

A People Watching Symphony. Wide open spaces lined with historic buildings criss-crossed with trolley tracks. Here you will find classic little cafes, interesting retail shops and the usual tourist shops. A great central spot to begin your explorations.

Love this place !. For sitting, people watching, enjoying the sites and sipping on a good beer, Old Town Square is fantastic. Always milling with people and loud and crowded, find a spot, sit, and enjoy. I loved being able to take a break here and just watch the people. It's close enough to most attractions (though, admittedly everything is Prague is close enough to everything else), I loved the mix of the old with the modern.
Still like in Middle Ages. You can still fell like in Middle ages..When you arriive the square, you will be effected..aND the old twon square has some exhibition everytime,also you can visit them.

Beware of dishonest snack food vendor rip off. BE VERY VERY CAREFUL when your food vendor is handing change back to you when you are purchasing food from them esp. staying away from the place that sell traditional snack called Tradclnik (rolled doughnut on open BBQ. The lady who handled my sell told me it's going to cost 59kc and I gave her a bill of 200kc for change, I was getting 50kc for chanhe instead of 150kc. I tried to argued but the lady insisted I gave he r 100Kc.
A must see while you are there. This area has a lot to see. It's beautiful and the history is amazing. There is some great people watching. There are some interesting performers in this area.

Impressive but overwhelmed by tourism. The square is a splendid space with a number of very interesting buildings around it, and central to the fascinating Old Town section. The Astronomical is well worth seeing on the hour. Unfortunately the square is overwhelmed by tourism: not just the numbers of visitors, but the attractions, guides, tours, and a multiplicity of shops and cafes that cater to them. The shops in particular are all very similar and sell very much run-of-the-mill souvenirs. The more interesting and different shops and eating places tend to be just off the square. The tourist information centre is here but is rather uninformative and was not as helpful in selecting sites to visit as we had hoped.
Old town feel. Grab a sausage and a beer. Worth just soking up the typical old European feel. Good photo opps. Easy walking
be there on the hour. Be in the old town square on the hour to see the clock go off... Crowd enjoys and cheers. Take advantage of the restaurants close by to secure your spot.
Beautiful. Find a cafe and enjoy looking up at the architecture , very busy and so early morning or late afternoon are best, listen to the bugler on the hour at the clock .

What I expect a historic square to look like...except.... This is a wonder to see and stand in. Unfortunately, it is packed with people at all times (I'm one of them so I'm guilty). The only down side is that all the stores sell the same or similar tourist baubles and unfortunately spoil the beauty of the town square. Late at night or early in the morning when there are fewer people present it is a wonder to behold.

just go and enjoy. The tower and the admosfeer. Jazz musik and nice terrasses. What a diverence with 20 years ago. It looks good and there are a lot of nice shops. Crowded but lively. Go also to the other parts of Prageu. Les people and beutiful buildings.

Beautiful square but be careful of money changing scams. Visited the square twice during our recent stay in Prague. Beautiful place to be and steeped in history. Pleanty of places to eat/drink combined with street entertainment makes this THE place to be, however be on your guard as we were approached numerous times by people trying to get us to enter into an illegal money exchange with them on the street!
Fabulous Place. It truly is an awe inspiring place. A gorgeous place. Straight out of a fairy tale. It was expensive but well worth the money

fun and beautiful. the street food is fantastic and has beautiful stores and the view from the clock tower is superb. i was there just before new years and the square is filled with holiday hustle&bustle

A very nice square with lots to enjoy.. When you visit Old Town Square, plan for the following:See Astronomical Clock just ahed of the hour to enjoy the 3 minute show of ApostlesGo up the tower above the Astronomical Clock for one of the best views of Old TownSee the beautiful fountain in the square and take note of the flowers around itStroll the perimeter of the square to see the shopsSeek out a Free Prague Tour guide in a red t-shirt who is presenting in your language and follow them to learn about the square and then to go elsewhere with them to learn more about the Old Town, no charge and you can drop off anytime you wish! They are young people with a sense of humor and speak many languages so try until you locate one.Do not eat in the Square! The restaurants are a rip off compared to elsewhere.

Something for everyone!. Night or day, this is a lively spot! You will find good food, good music and good entertainment for young, old and all ages in between. It is the center of old town with the Jewish quarter directly beside the Cartier store where the synagogue is. Past the astronomical clock is the way to Charles bridge and the riverside trail.
Beautiful ......... A lovely romantic site that lives up to its reputation. Beware of professional beggars. They are extremely good actors per our guide. We, actually, saw one "transformed".
A must to see. And be there every hour for the display with the clocks ringing and the show. It will be crowded but bee there!

Historic old town square. A beautiful square with interesting history. Beware if you are in the old town square at 11 on a sunny weekend in September. Many tourists and tour groups converge at once. You see a noticeable decrease on the weekdays.

Lots to see here as focal point of city. This is the main place to be, as there are many restaurants and hordes of tourists all milling around at surely one of the grandest old town squares in Europe. Just stand around and marvel at the old buildings. Have some goulash and the best beer in Europe!
energetic center of city. charming, energetic and full of history, clearly the center of city. Lots of tourists but the area in general is worth visiting

Interesting place - don't miss the clock! Lots of places to find good food. Enjoyed the cathedrals that we visited.. Enjoyed the clerk in jewelry store - very helpful in selecting garnets. Always interesting that public toilets require a small fee - they are clean and well maintained.

Lovely central old big square. Famous for its one in the world astronomical clock which attracts thousands of tourists every day. Most famous wedding place in Prague. The only place Germans bombed during WW2 as they didnt want to destroy Prague being aware of its beauty and history. They only damaged part of the municipal building behind the clock. Lots of pubs and restaurants, houses from 11th century...............just lovely

Very nice historic place.. This bustling square attracts a lot of people-it has a beautiful Old Town Hall building, princes' palaces, two churches, great mansions, and a monument to nation's hero. Be exactly 5-7 minutes before an hour to see the "procession of 12 Apostles" in the upper window of a clock tour!

Advice on street food. It's a nice square just to hang out and watch throngs of tourists go by, especially when it's nearing the hour. I was there on Saturday & Sunday and the square was animated by buskers as well. There are some stalls at the edge of the square selling foods like old Prague ham, trdelibk, pancakes etc. The price for the ham was around 80czk per 100g. However when you order you cannot specify the weight that you want. According to the seller they go by "portions". Each portion was supposed to be 300-400g. However mine turned out to be 450g so it was a very expensive meal indeed. That being said, thankfully the meat was quite tasty.

Just being here is an open air museum. Gorgeous old buildings and yummy street food are the best attractions here. this is the place to start your Prague visit, whether you are interested in a tour of the major sites or just want to enjoy the atmosphere of a lively historic center.
old town. the beautiful old buildings ,the great places to eat,the character of the area, the churches and squares
Worth a Visit. Very interesting and quite lovely. Lots of cages around the square where you can sit and have a beer or a coffee and watch the passing throng.

The main reason to go to Prague. The title says it all -- there are too many sights to see to list them all. Don't be afraid to try the "fast food" just by the clock tower. The ham portions are huge and the "roller pin" confections are worth a try.

avoid sausage vendors. old town square is a lovely historical place but we were left with a sour taste in our mouths after a visit to a sausage stall.i would urge all visitors to beware of being seriously overcharged at these places this is exactly happened to us.all we required were 2 sausages a plate of potatoes mixed with cabbage and bacon bits along with 4 slices of bread we were then pressured into taking a plate of ham which the smiling proprietor led us to believe would be very cheap,we actually found this to be awful and left most of it we then checked how much this had cost and were astonished and outraged to find it cost us almost £34 when i queried the price the proprietor informed me the ham was sold by weight and the price shown was per gram,when i said this was not clear to foreigners he simply shrugged and said this was normal.this episode put us off the old square and we will not be visiting again.p.s if you fancy a sausage,use the stalls in wenceslas square here you get a fair deal without any pressure but please avoid stalls in old square like the plague.
Great. Beautiful place, nice restaurants and little souvenir stores.Prague seams to be a painting! Very nice place.the view from the top of the church is perfect.
Beautiful. I loved this area of Prague, and it was so close to many attractions. I loved the architecture and the atmosphere was great.

Must see, then leave quickly. The Old Town Square is beautiful, every building is a gem and it is one of those places that you have to see - but we did not want to stay around for long. This was a Saturday and it was very very crowded and large parts of the square are just tacky, the usual tourist shops that you see everywhere.As well, all the warnings about pickpockets and scams in the square made me more aware of my immediate surroundings rather than just concentrating on the beauty of the town square and its meaning and history. Bottom line, I would definitely try to avoid the times of the day when the crowd is at its peak - unfortunately that is most of the day! See it and then go to other parts of the city.

lots to see. There is lots to see here! My nephew really likes the jumping spider toy we bought from a street vendor here, and there was a really great Dixieland band playing in the middle of the square. There are restaurants & souvenir shops in this area but it is very touristy so everything is pretty expensive (compared to the rest of Prague, anyway).

A bustle of tours and activity. The square is filled with people and outdoor cafes. Surrounded by Baroque churches and other building. DO stop in St. Dominic's Church to see the magnificent Bohemian crystal chandelier. Yes, MAGNIFICENT!!
Magical. See it at night if you can, and feel like you have stepped into a Harry Potter film set. Always buzzing, so much to see and do.

Very pretty and quaint. The buildings were very beautiful from ancient to modern. Loved it. The horse and carriages and the old fashioned cars taking you round the square. The beautiful old clock. The square was magical. My husband and I loved every minute of our time spent here
Vibrant!. A great place to listen to buskers - there was a really good Trad Jazz group that we sat and watched for an hour! Very busy, plenty of cafes.
live square... Prague a very live city with its small shops and big cheap departments store and its great architecture. Walk around and inside its allies and you won't regret.

Beautiful to enjoy visually!. The Old Town Square in Prague is one of those "must-see" places. You should stand in its middle (if you are lucky to be able to do so because of the crowd of tourists) and bake a 360 degree-look around the square. If you love architecture and monuments you will be in awe! Awesome Square. But not a place to eat, drink or buy souvenirs. This is a tourist trap
The Clocks. Another must-see thing in Prague - clocktower. Suggest to visit at 1200 and be sure to find a place 20 minutes before it gets too crowded. Interesting piece of art.

Long weekend. Prague is a wonderful place to spend a few days, cheap hotels, food and drink amazing architecture with a relaxed ambiance. The old town square was busy with the cycle taxis and horse drawn landaus, there were locals in traditional costume playing music and dancing. We did the tourist thing and stood and waited for the astronomical clock to strike the hour, a great place to spend time.
european city center town square. lots of tourists, but stilll well preserved period middle european old town square with local flavor

Great place to walk around. Amazing place to go for a walk and get lost in nearby streets.
You can watch the clock tower, eat in the street stalls or take the train around town.
beautiful. here we saw the astronomical clock and climbed the clock tower, amazing views. great value for money. lovely buildings and architecture full of culture

Good old sightseeing highlight. Old Town Square is not that crowded in September and when the weather is nice, it is my favourite time of the year.
Beer gardens are still open and it is easy to find a spot with views.

If you like beautiful old buildings .... One of my favourite parts of Prague. The Old Town Square is very beautiful with some amazing houses, just look up and see how they are beautifully decorated. The Astronomical Clock is nice to watch and gets quite crowded on the hour. There are lots of souvenir shops in nearby streets, some are very nice.Not to be missed when you are in Prague.
Must go at night time!. Most beautiful at night time, when the buildings are lighted. Very much people visiting and selling stuff. Very nice also at daytime, but not as influencing as in nightlight.

THE OLD TOWN SQUARE: ENTERTAINMENT GALORE!. Not only is the Old Town Square home to outstanding architecture, it is also home to many talented buskers. We simply could not believe the number of street entertainers and musicians that performed there. You can really make an afternoon or evening of it all, taking in the Astronomical clock, eating in a restaurant, having a cool drink, purchasing snacks at the many booths. After dusk the street and building lights turn on, creating a magical site. One I will never forget!
So so. Very nice, with lots of shops and beautiful cobblestone. Didn't like the fact that cafe's and bars close very early! 11:30pm and I couldn't even get a coffee...totally dead!
Such Beauty. I wandered by myself and not once did i feel vulnerable or unsafe. This is by far the safest city i have ever visited

go up the tower in the late afternoon,. less queues, superb view from up there. Listen to Vladimir Pinta and his saxophone on the square, although the Sedgways are expensive, such a fun way to see some of the old town, and they are easy to drive....have fun.
Old town square: a lot of tourists groups. Try to go early in the morning to avoid the groups. And of course the coffee costs twice as much as in the rest of the town.
ok ,just it. as i said is ok but not much diversity,and NOT @ALL ANY LIVE SMILLES,SIMPATIES,nothing special...i wish coult stay in hungary and explore more of that beautefull country..++people.

Got scammed by food vendors. The old town square isn't that scenic to begin with. But we were hungry and succumbed to the tourist-trap kiosks offering smoked ham and potato-cabbage-bacon mix to starving tourists.The prices were for 100 grams, and I assumed that this meant that we would get 100-gram portions. We were served a bowl of potato mix (500 grams) and a piece of ham (300 grams) and the price came to something like 30 euros! This came as quite a shock, considering the man behind the counter didn't ask us how much we wanted: he simply delivered these large portions.DON'T EAT THERE.

This is the Place to See in Prague. You won't run out of eateries, pubs, tour offerings, and places/sites to see. Plenty of Bohemian Crystal shops and other souvenir places. Easy taxis to and from the Olde Town area. Certainly Not a tourist trap - it's a Must Visit.

A must to see site if you come to Prague!. Herewith is the turistic centre of Prague. You can take a horse carriage to visit some of the smaller streets and sites (approx 30 euro for half an hour), you can also take some of the old cars (from 30 to 50 euro per one hour). From the square you can also visit the most epxesive street in Prague, Pariska - where the most expensive shops lie, from Louis Vuitton to Cartier.
Old Town. Wonderful place to visit. Great if you have a guide to give you information about the buildings, history, etc.
You will love it. The animating clock is interesting, you can climb up to the clock tower. The cafes around he square are very nice. Hope to see again
Great Place. Full of lovely places to eat, drink or just to wander around and take pictures ..... The buildings here are amazing and the entertainment was great too !!!

A beautiful lively place to relax and people watch. The square is a bustling area full of tourists and locals. There are plenty of bars and restaurants where you can sit and enjoy the beautiful buildings and watch the activity in the square- jugglers, break-dancers, living statues and street entertainers. Be sure to explore the many side streets leading to the square. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes for walking on the cobblestone roads. A wonderful way to spend an afternoon or evening!

Very nice. I was here only a few minutes at nigt, but it was amazing - the Astronomical Clock, the big cathedral and the monument in the middle of the square... to be there is like going in the history. Try Trdelmik? - it is a Czech speciality, something like sweet pastry, I loved that!

Europe at its best. This place has got to be one of the most fantastic sqaures in Europe. Wether you want to take in the culture, have dinner or just sit and watch the world go by this place offers it all. I was also lucky to get to see the Mattoni Prague Grand Prix start at the square recently and the atmosphere was incredible. If you are going to Prague head straight here once you get there - you wont be dissapointed.
Perfect Prague. We just love Prague full stop!! We have just booked our tenth trip. We find somewhere new every visit.

Where history comes alive. The old town square is one place where one can feel history come alive. WIth numerous bands playing, busy cafes, bars and church bells, this place is bustling for 20hrs out of 24. A must visit.

beautiful. we liked everything about Prague. i would walk and walk the streets... the main tip is to wear very comfortable shoes! cobbled pavements are not meant for high heels, so wear flats and better with thick soles.
Awesome. Great place to hang out by the fountain to unwind and people watch. Grab some great food nearby and wait for the Free Europe tour.

Beautiful setting - Always a nice atmosphere. I have been to prague 8 times previously, and I am not yet bored of the Old Town Square. A brilliant setting, and you have a real sense of history. Unfortunately there has been a little more commercial development in recent years (i.e Starbucks) but to be fair, it is still kind of tucked away in the corner and not overly imposing. Sure, the food and drink are all way overpriced, but that's the same everywhere. Simply take a walk along, get some pictures, sit down and enjoy the atmosphere and then walk further out for cheaper food and beer.A must visit in Prague.

Impressive!. Amazing architecture, brilliant atmosphere, especially with the crowds waiting for the astronomical clock to do its thing on an hour each hour. A must in Prague! Stay around for a while, have a drink or something to eat from many stalls and enjoy. No place like this anywhere else.
great atmosphere. Great place to hang out and to eat. The astonomical clock is a great attraction. Musicians play in different parts of the square and the standard of music is excellent
Very impressive. Lovely architecture and plenty to explore in the side roads that lead off from it. Lots of bars to sit and relax
Brilliant to visit. the atmosphere and the architecture are stunning. The pubs and restaurants are excellent and the watchtower is a joy to behold.

Astronomical Clock dominates.... The biggest attraction seems to be the Astronomical Clock - lots of people are milling about, waiting for the rotation of the figures. However, architecturally, you cannot miss by walking around the square. And if you grow tired, they have smoked ham on one side - delicious! or gelato on the other - best one there seems to be outdoors or various outdoor seating for the restaurants.Crowded so beware of pickpockets - otherwise it's quite lovely!

Old Town Favourite. We loved the square and the Astronomical clock, had to go back twice to see it as so much happens on the hour from the revolving apostles to death ringing his bell, afterwards a great guy plays his trumpet frim the topmost points of the tower. lots happening with acrobats and bubble blowers , sit at a cafe and watch it all happening in front of you , fantastic!!
..keep enjoying. You can keep enjoying Praha for more than a few days. The Old square and All around is pleasure for the eyes.. the stomach...and well! If you are a shopping person also
Great at night. Again lots of history, the clock tower (great views from the top). no problems at night, plenty of low key police presence

Historical and beautiful place with ancient churchs and monuments... The restaurants and bars need to improve the attention to international tourists, and in many cases are not trusty in the prices of the real consumption...
High five!. Definitely visit the clock tower - watch out because some of the cathedrals are closed on Monday. Visit during the day to see all of the people.

heritage site. Well worth the UNESCO rating. Be very careful with exchange bureaux in the square. They have confusing signs as to rates and can rip you off for almost 30 percent of real value of what you exchange, best to shop around if only wanting to exchange 100 Euros, US$ or GBP to cover last day of visit.
Lovely. Just what I expected . The clock is out of this word . such great workmanship.The whole square is a wonder of architecture

Where the action is!. Great location to relax and watch the world go by from one of the many bars and cafes. Dry ginger ale for scotch and dry available at the Italian cafe across the square from the clock.
Nice but can be seen quickly. Go to see the clock tower and meet up with a tour guide. Great spot for pictures, too. But the restaurants are pretty touristy.

Old Town Square. Hus Monument very powerful, especially if you know his story: a heretic burned at the stake for saying things we take for granted. Lovely cathedrals, old clock tower, trumpet playing on the hour. We even saw a cultural dancing festival with groups of dancers from all over Europe who came to perform. Very festive.

Pause for a minute, for an hour.. Oversize square that is the perfect spot to pause from overcrowded streets and just spin around: take in the splendors of Old Town, one building at a time. And get going to your next stop.
a change.. Everyone talks about Wenceslas square - which is a bit of a dissappointment really. The Old Town Square has much more going for it. Lots to see and do.

Excellent beer for different price!. Be aware, same restaurant offers beer for double price if you are sitting ouside on the square. Inside the prices are normal.
Especially at Old Town Square
Real history. Is good to be considered for a few days of culture. Teriffiant place, nice architecture, a wonderfull remember for live

Typical European Square with a Twist in Prague. This is an often visited large square with tons of shops and restaurants surrounding it, for me the main attraction was the Astronomical Clock which puts on an interesting 49 second show every hour on the hour.
Lovely spot.... This is a classic place in PRAGUE and you absolutey need to visit! Lovely architecture.... I did not find anaywhere that beat it to be honest...
Particularly magical at night. You really need to see it lit up at night to fully appreciate its beauty. Quite a magical experience. A very vibrant atmosphere.
People watching. Great place to sit in a cafe and watch the world go by. Visit the old churches and towers and gain a sense of the Czech history
groovy. really cool architecture Disneyland church lots of restaurants and beer and young people the clock is nice etc

It is like a fair every day. I loved going to the Old Town Sq to grab a bite. I mean, the site is a historical gem and the architecture will blow you away, but they have these vendors at night and they make all kinds of yummy stuff. My fave was thet koblasa sandwiches, huge Czech sausage rolls that were to die for! I've been looking for something similar here in Ft. Lauderdale since the moment we arrived - without luck. And the palachinkes (big crepes) made on site... sooo good! They also sell wine and spirits and will give you samples to try. We liked their cider but it magically turned into moonshine when we arrived home, I'm not kidding, it's so strong that I can also have a sip at a time. I keep it in the freezer so it won't go bad. We also picked up a couple of bottles of their honey wine, this one is so delicious and you can totally taste the honey. The Square has everything to spend several hours touring around, then coming back for a bite and a drink, have a rest, then keep exploring the surrounding sites. You will love the vibrant atmosphere of the Old Town Sq!

Beautiful. Beautiful square, lots of restaurants and shops.
Great entertainment around the square both in the day and at night, a beautiful sight to see at night when the square is lit up.

Awesome sight - sensory overload warning!. Wow, this is classic Prague! Not much to say other than enjoy it during different times of the day, watch out for the pickpockets (not me, but I heard other tourists got ripped when watching the clock tower "show", enjoy the bird's eye view from the top of the tower for the classic post card shot of the Tyne church, the myriad of street performers, the other tourists trying to take photos of themselves (volunteer to help and you'll make instant friends especially in the evening when the beers start to take effect) and the food (the pork stand and the trdlo - Prague "donut"). On a side note from the ham vendors, they have the price listed as 89 Kc for 100 grams or something like that. When you order either ham or the potato dish, they serve around 250-300 grams as the "standard" serving size. Either be clear with these guys that you want a small portion beforehand or be prepared to share as 250-300 grams is a lot of ham and potatoes EACH!

wonderful place. you can go there 20 times and not get bored. there are always artists playing and there is always something to see. Also, there are boutiques where they cook traditional czech food and you have to try those! and to forget to see the astronomical clock ;)

hard to say which is better - the architecture or the people watching. This is truly a nice place to lounge around at one of the many restaurants that encircle the place. The astronomical clock and many of the walking tours start and end here, and you can definitely feel the energy in the air. We visited the square in both dry and rainy conditions, and in both the daytime and night time and there was always something new to see and experience.,

lovely but expensive. beautiful place with street entertainers and lots of restaurants,the down side is its very expensive to eat and drink here we got charged £9 for two small beers in one and £17,50 for two bacon sandwiches and two cups of tea in another

The place you can't avoid. Staromestke namesti is the place on your map you can't avoid: most of the places you'll want to visit revolve around this square. Take your time to see all there's to see there.

Quaint old square. There are Easter or Christmas markets there. Tyn´s church dominates the square as well as the statue of Jan Hus. The astronomical clock is definitely worth seeing. If you want to take a horse ride, this is the right place to get on. Many cafes and restaurants as well as a gallery. So basically, everybody can find something for themselves.
My Favorite Square. I like the atmosphere here, just sit down on the bench looking up to the church with romantic lighting all around the square. WOW ! :D
So many places to visit in old town square,prague.. must see it. We watched several places.. astronomical clock,old buildings & monuments, Jewish town,Charles bridge etc.. So it is awesome.

Best attraction in Prague. This was by far the most enjoyable experience when we recently visited Prague.The square had .a total buzz of life and activity from morning to evening each time we were there and if you wish you can eat, drink and watch the world go by and not get bored!Do not miss a visit here- you will not be disappointed.
Very romantic. We walked from our hotel (Alcron, Radisson Blu) and it was charming. Wife loved every step and then we watched the clock - very romantic :)

Beautiful place!. Lovely square surrounded by beautiful buildings, you can't loose the astronomical clock striking the hour, (a little bit too much crowded, at least in July). and eating a sausage in one of te food stands :)

Go Here for Great Food from Street Vendors. As expected, the square was always crowded. We had one of the best meals there on Sunday. The street vendors set up there on weekends. We feasted on the best kielbasa (klobasen) I've every had. We also tried the potato chips on a stick and the pastry made on an open grill. It was so good that we went back there on Monday but unfortunately for us apparently they only set up on weekends. Bummer!1

Just Hanging Out here. is so much fun. It's beautiful and charming at all times of day. After dark, it becomes magical. Lots of streets, restaurants, stores, etc. radiating out of the square. Cross roads of Prague.

Really great for street food but don't get the pork. Loved the square.Go up the bell tower and check it out .Amazing views.I love street food and pork but don't buy the pork from the stands in the square.They cut a massive chunk off for tourists and is over priced.Rip offEat ham in a pub instead.

Great Vibe at Christmas Time. Lots of restaurants, but as they are right on the square can be on the more expensive side. You can find better deals if you are on a budget. The Christmas Markets were amazing.
