Town Square. Very charming with the large Baroque church. ...and Starbucks of course. The cobblestones and tiny store fronts along with the grand church was quite a contrast.
great, try it during the night. great square, the buildings, the watch towers, the statues, the restaurants for everyone. I suggest to visit the square also during the night.

Amazing. To stand in the Old town Square in Prague is nothing short of amazing. The Astronomical Clock, the town Hall, the restaurants, bars, shops and music are incredible. there is so much to see and do. Every day you saw something different. The Martin Tours operate from a booth on the corner of the Square and they can offer trips and sightseeing for everything in and around Prague. Walking up and down through all the little alleyways is wonderful.
Astonishing. It's one of the most iconic places I've visited. Night time is especially great. Don't miss it for the world!
Very rich in history...... I liked everything about Old Town Square. The architecture, the cobblestone.... Everything around me was just historic. It was great to take it all in.

Beautiful!. Despite tons of tourists, the place still feels open and genuine. Heard some really good musicians playing in the evenings, much better quality than in some other tourist locations. The only negative is the smell of horses. They were standing parked on one side of the square with carriages, waiting for tourists.

trip to prague. i visited prague last easter 2012 and found prague a beautiful city especially the old town part which is a must for young and olds. food prices and drink is pretty cheap but like other cities watch out for the taxi trying to over charge you
Nice friendly crowd of an evening. And lots of reasonably priced restaurants in adjoining alleys, beer and goulash and lots more. An inexpensuive evening's fun

One big tourist attraction. The first thing you notice are the throngs of people that congregate here, loads of coach tours make a bee-line for this area, the Prague Astronomical clock, (Prague Orloj) draws many people and the numerous outside restaurants cater for the hungry and thirsty. These place are expensive by Prague standards but they are wonderful for people watching. The buildings that surround the square are magnificent and if you want to do some serious buying or window shopping then walk along `Parizska` or Paris St just off the main square. There are also outdoor markets in the square at various times of the year, the most notable is at Christmas and New Year, see the area when you go to Prague but be prepared for lots of people in the summer months, or see the square in the evening, the whole are takes on a completely different aura, quite magical !!

You can spend hours relaxing!. The old town square in Prague is an awesome place to spend quality time. The architecture and the medieval cobble stoned area is spectacular. There are loads of restaurants lining the square where you can spend great time people watching.

A site you simply must visit. Come there by the hour to watch the belltower show.Look around and enjoy. Have a beer or a glass of wine on the square, but don't expect any service or good fo9llow-upn, nor a good wine. For good food and wine go somewhere else

excellent square. great place to just sit down and admire the facade and clock tower. as beautiful as the markt place in Brussels. unmissable tourist hot spot. do not hesitate to eat the traditional ham old plague.

Picturesque. Whether during the day or night, the Square is a place not to be missed.The two gothic towers and the old clock provide many picture opportunities. At night the Square is filled with tourists who are entertained by the locals making music and performing acts such as fire-dancing.A great place to spend time.

Not enough benches!. This large square, although ringed with impressive buildings, has few benches and trash cans. The main attraction here is the Astronomical Clock, but unless you are fresh and energetic, you can't spend much time admiring any of it as you have to either stand the whole time or cross the chains around the central statue and sit on the low pedestal there.
Stunning. A beautiful, large, preserved town square lined by shops, cafes, and original architecture. Full of crowds and activity. Wonderful by day and night.
Beautiful square. A lovely place to visit, you can wander around taking in all the sights or sit at a cafe and take them in at a distance.

Just Amazing!. Colourful and full of historical facts and buildings, is absolutely beautiful. The best feature about it is the Astronomical Clock, the most amazing clock I've ever seen... there's just so much to do around here, eat a fancy meal, of something typical from the stands, enjoy an ice cream to cool down, etc

Busy, Busy, Busy. Try to visit at quiet times of the day. At 1200 midday it was packed. Some nice looking restaurants ion the area but not cheap and seem a bit touristy. Try to find one of the smaller ones in the many side streets off the square for better value and service.

Very Romantic. A very romantic place that looks like just got out a fairy tail. Loots of attrations at the square and around. The astronomical clock is very original and not disappointing as many people say because it is what it is... a clock with very accurate times for the age it has and some more details that makes it famous and peculiar.Lot's of cafes, restaurants and souvenir shops for tourists around which makes it over-priced compared with other locations in the city.

Favorite place here, not to miss. U can just sit and relax here, there are few traditional street performers and they are just awesome. Many good, cheap restaurant and the food are really tasty..beer is cheap here according to my Aussie friend. The square is a good landmark. It's d centre to all the others. I love just sitting and watching people..its relaxing n peaceful..
beautiful. the square has plenty of bars/coffee bars both inside and out. can be very busy when the guided tours are about to start.

Heart of the Old Town. This is the very heart of a beautiful and historic area of the east bank of the Vltava river. It has the Astronomical Clock, shops, restaurants, and a great opportunity to people watch. It's the touristy heart of the touristy Old Town but it's still great to visit.
Beautiful!. Open square surrounded by beautifully-colored buildings. Visitors must go to the top of the tower to get breath-taking views of Prague.
Old town. Very beautyful place. The clock is really something. The square is a good place to sit and relax and watch. Performers, music, restaurants...

Great place to watch the world go by!. Old Town Square in Prague is a hive of activity. When we went in August 2012, the place was buzzing with people. The sites including the gothic church 'Our Lady of Tyn' and the not to be missed astronomical clock are fabulous. Make sure you are there on the hour when the chimes ring out. The restaurants and bars that line the perimiter of the square are in the main very good with a choice of Czech or foreign cuisine. A great place to spend a family evening together.
Old world charm. Liked: Buildings well preserved, Astronomical clock, cafeteriasDisliked: A bit too touristy and crowded.

Watch the world go past.. Catch a good performance, street market, or watch the world go past. Note others may have the same idea, so the place can get very crowded, especially by the clock, so you may wish to position yourself more strategically... Also mind your wallet and purse.
Beautiful renovations!. It was fun to see how all the old, treasured buildings have been restored and taken over by local businesses.
Wedding Venue. Lovely square with bars & cafe's we were at a wedding in the St Nicholas church which is beautiful inside.

Prague as a melting pot. Here is the meeting place of Prague's tourists - as it should be - history is huge here. The astronomical clock is fascinating but be sure to read a guide book or listen to a tour guide explain the various features of the clock. The churches on the squeare each share in the history of the area. Do go in to see them. Look at the paintings on the surrounding buildings to see beauty. Read the plaques on the monuments - this is history not known to many Americans. Enjoy the fine food and drink at a sidewalk cafe to take in the ambiance. Take time to hear the music of street musicians. Don't rush through this area but savor it's story.
Great place. I love Prague, every place was magic and full of color. I will go again there, hopefully the next year. It's one of my favorite cities.

Wonderful. The heart of old town Prague, great architecture, and a real buzz. The astronomical clock is an odd attraction (huge crowds gather, but the display lasts about 1 minute) and only eat in the square if you want to soak up the atmosphere - you'll pay extra for the privelige!
Beautiful square. The clock, the Tyn church and all the facades to the houses are well worth seeing. Again it is just too crowded in the summer though
Great tourist area. be sure to stick around for the top of the hour to watch the clock chime and movements of the figures.

Great place to sit down and people-watch, good food too!. It is a very nice place to sit down in the middle of the black cobble stoned square. Many people are spread out and simply sit down. You can watch the people milling about, look at the interesting architecture of the buildings and of the towering gothic church and Powder Tower.They have very good Trdelnik for 50 Krowns, crepes and have other stands. There are also cafes surrounding the square.There is a very interesting statue in the middle that is a nice backdrop for pictures.I recommend that everyone go there! The side streets are very interesting too.

Obvious must-see. If you are in Prague, you must make a trip to the old town square. Bring your camera, as there is lots to see and capture. Try to be there on the hour to catch a glimpse of the astronomical clock and see the little show. As always, beware of pickpockets.

The Old Town Square, Prague, Czech Republic. The Old Town Square is dominated by the weathered bronze statue of Jon Hus, located on the site where he was martyred, the twin towers of the Tyn Church, the tower of the Old Town Hall (with the Astronomical Clock, and the Church of St. Nicholas. This is where cultural festivals and outdoor concerts go on virtually non-stop in the summer and where crowds are always to be expected. Every direction features some beautiful old building that takes your breath away.
Busy and full of history. Lots to see, do, eat and drink! It has the history mixed with the modern. A hub of activity from the clock tower and churches to the pubs and beer.
Wonderful. Atmospheric and beautiful. A real sense of history and well-looked after. Once you've seen the sights, sit in a cafe with a beer and people watch.
Beautiful. Really charming area. Beautiful buildings as well as the famous Astrological Clock make this a must see in Pragye

The Old Town Square always makes me want to dance. I love Prague, madly. I always tell my friends if you can only get to ONE major European city, make it Prague. I have eaten, danced, sung, and laughed in Old town square. At Christmastime its lights and color and slices of that great ham off the bone, and at easter its markets and crafts and singers, and there are great restaurants, hotels, and of course the Astrological clock, which *always* makes me laugh. There is so much art, and history and architecture in that one square that you could spend a month and not see and appreciate all of it.

The Astrnomical clock. Very accurate & truly Astronomical, with the phases of the moon & the zodiac all shown on the dial; the 12 apostles also appear every hour in 2 windows, & go around every hour as the clock chimes. No wonder crowds all gather as the hour is near.Dr. Goh

Prague's Old Town Square. Head to the Old Town Square which is surrounded by beautiful and colourful buildings. The Square is huge and busy all of the time. Everyone flocks to the Astronomical Clock to see the hourly display as the Apostles make their apperance and the skeleton rings the bell and watch the golden cock crow and then as a finale a real trumpeter plays out with a final tune from the parapet tower above the clock. This happens 9am - 9pm inclusive. Watch out for pickpockets here as the masses gather and are easily distracted by the display .... hang on to belongings.What is a must see is the twin spire Church of Our Lady before the Tyn. The enrtance is always open but full access is only allowed for Masses of which there is one at around 12 noon. The amount of people in the square can be intense all day and at night and here eating and drinking is expensive. But nevertheless this is a UNESCO centre and is very beautiful.

magical. just a 5 min walk from hotel then from their to charles bridge about another 5 min walk depending how fast you walk , such a magical place at night time when it was all lite up & the snow was falling.
Awesome. With the astronomical clock and a ton of cafes this place comes alive in the evening with performers and concerts. Always lots to watch no matter the time of day.
stunning. one of the most beautiful squares in the world, with lovely churches and the amazing astronomical clock

Love the total experience. I loved the total feels and ambience at Old Town Square, even though it was crowded with tourists, it felt like being stuck in 16th century Europe. I loved the Church of Mary Before Tyne and its towers grand and imposing on the town square. We made sure we were in front of the astronomical clock when it chimed the hour and satisfied our craving for authentic Czech food and beer in one of the restaurants right on the square.
Busy place but classic and interesting place with good sights, churches and astronomical clock. Nice place to hang out, dont forget to watch the hourly fanfare and chimes of the astronomical clock
Stunning. The Square offers an amazing view of several major Prague landmarks, active street life, plenty of restaurants and great people watching. It is a cannot miss location to see,
Full of life and people. Really worth it! Even though I fond people a lit bit rude in the places for buying food, especially the ones with Czech ham.

Avoid the ham/sausage stands. Avoid the ham/sausage/potato salad stands (there are 2 of them) in the row of food stands in the square. They charge by weight, and the food can be an outrageous ripoff, at least for tourists, who seem to be just about everyone in the square. We (two adults, two short and skinny daughters) had a sausage (with bread slices), a big chunk of roasted ham, and a big bowl of potato salad (with bits of ham and cabbage). I think we were taken for a ride; the total was 780 Czk, which is ridiculous considering decent entrees at nearby restaurants are 150-200 Czk. Feeling stupid for not having my brain on at the time, but wanting to warn others...
Atmospheric square. We enjoyed climbing the tower and hearing the trumpeter sound a fanfare from the four sides each hour. We also enjoyed the free buskers around the square.
Great atmosphere. Beautiful architecture, lots of atmospehere with all of the food stalls and restaurants. Definately somewhere not to miss.
The center of Prague trip. Costel Matky is really attractive building and there is no admission fee. Don't miss it. You shouldn't forget to check the receipt carefully at the restaurants in the area.

One of the great City Squares. Love big European city squares and this is one of the top 8.(In case you're interested; Venice, Warsaw, Krakow, Montpellier, London, Rome, Monte Carlo)To be great you have to have: -history -space-churches-fountains-style-fooderies-entertainmentA square must have these in varying proportions and this one has it in spades.History is shown by the astronomical clock, plaques and the mucha museumIt is one of the great spaces that can be crowded in one end and contemplative in others.There are churches and a great big feature in th emiddle of the square.Style, check, with one a modern, stylish street going North from there.Fooderies of all sorts and qualities, including an Irish/ British combo somewhat discreetly in the North.Apart from the human people watching, there is always some music on as the Czechs love their jazz. The buskers aren't one man bands but proper, high quality bands of 5+ people who'll play all afternoon for you. Winner place.

People watching fun. Great day or evening to sit in one of the many cafes and watch all the goings on. Very impressive and grand square - one of the finest I've been to. Buskers provide a good range of entertainment and the anatomical clock attracts crowds on the hour.

An artery!. We were here during easter so there was a market with a lot of things happening! From morning to evening it was a wonderful square to pass by. Go up in the tower to the "city hall" and get a wonderful view over Prague. Try to do it at "the hour" and see what happens... ;-)

Beautiful buildings. Everything we saw in the square was fascinating in its own right. Well worth the visit. Try getting a table at the Grand Hotel so you can have a nice drink or cup of coffee while the clock is chiming the hour.
Grab a seat and people watch!. High marks for the potato, cabbage and bacon dish at the food stalls - a great, filling dinner for very little cash.

Picturesque and definitely worth the visit. We really liked the old town square, and especially Hard Rock cafe :) everything is really nice and beautiful, however it was too dirty and the restaurant employees were kind of rude..

Can't be missed. Literally, if you are walking around Prague, you can't avoid going through Old Town Square, And it is beautiful and very lively. But there are a lot of other great parts of the city to explore. It was extremely crowded (July) at pretty much every waking moment. That detracted a little bit from the whole experience in my mind. It is still great, particular when the trumpet(?) players come out at the top of the hour to play a song for the city from the top of the bell tower. The other thing that was odd to me was that the main church does not sit right on the Square. I just assumed it would...So, yes go to Old Town Square and enjoy a coffee or beer, but explore the rest of the city, walk along the river, across the river, into the hills, etc.

Medieval Buildings, History, Drinking and Eating all in One Square. If there's one square in Prague to visit it's the Old Town Square. Here medieval architecture and history blend together in perfect harmony. Some of the wonders you'll find is the AstronomicalClock, City Hall, Jan Hus Monument, and St. Nicholas Church. There's an abundant amount of shopping huts in the square. Be sure to visit the hut that sells a local specialty called the "trdelnik."It's pastry dough wrapped around a stick and roasted over an open fire.Old Town Square is worth visiting when in Prague.

For fun and For Free. It won't cost you a penny just to walk through Old Town Square, and it's a fantastic place to watch the Euro Football games. There's always something going on. The clock tower is beautiful, not really worth waiting to see it run, but going up to the top IS. There's a great view and photo op. You don't need to buy the ticket for the whole shebang, you can get an a la carte ticket for just a trip to the top of the tower FYI. There is a Starbuck's in the square with free Wifi and the street vendors with Prague Ham or Crepes are a great cheap local yummy meal as an alternative to the over-priced restaurants around the square.

good free walking tour. Restaurants there are generally tourist traps - service can be a bit rude but that is Prague I guess. Try the free (yellow tee shirt guys) walking tour with the Irish commentator - he is good.

Atmospheric and always fun. Great vibe you can have great food and visit lots of good bars but most of all this is the place to people watch and soak up the atmosphere. Always have great musicians or entertainers to watch

Fun - this is the place to be. The hourly clock display is the big attraction, but with all the outdoor restaurants, constant live entertainment, shops, and beautiful buildings surrounding the large square, it's nice just to hang out here if you've got some extra time.
So much to see. A perfect European city to walk around and enjoy - just beautiful. The history of the various people who have ruled this city through the ages is just fascinating.

A must. No dislikes can be told about this superb place; a collection of magnificent buildings and history. Like many things that can be visited in Prague, one should take the time to explore in advance and take a good guide to tell the details.
Lots too see but avoid the overpriced restaurants. There are churches, monuments, clocks, little stores and much more to walk around and see. Beware of pickpockets which your staring up at the clock

Essential part of Prague. Crowded with tourists, but you can't come to Prague and not see the Astronomical Clock. They also have regular festivals and seasonal markets throughout the year, so there is usually some sort of entertainment. The Christmas lights are magical, especially when it snows.
Big open vistas. Plenty of people moving through, there are buildings to look at, local food stalls, entertainers. Watch your bag as in any crowded space.

Magical. The Old Town Square is celebration of architectural styles from gothic to baroque. The most dominant and well recognized structures are the Astrological Clock and the Church of Our Lady surrounded by brightly painted buildings. Numerous meandering alley ways lead to and go from Old Town Square with new discoveries down each one. At night, with the lamp lights lit, the place is pure magic.
A must in your trip. It is alive- it is magical - the heritage and the curiosity of the people / tourists amazed. It takes us back in time - in a wonderful way - we treasure the past and present

Old Town Square. The area in and around the Old Town Square is so beautiful that it is overwhelming. Take time to sit on a bench in the center and take it all in. Most everything you would want to see is within easy walking distance. Jump in on one of the free walking tours to get oriented to the old town area, then venture off on your own. Getting lost is part of the fun.

Worth the Visit. Huge square in the heart of the old town. A definite attraction a lot of crowds and the restaurants here are a little expensive, but to sit outside and watch the people go about their business is a real treat.

free walking tour. the free walking tour was excellent, be sure to tip at the end, the food stalls in the square are a fantastic choice for dinner, beer is cheaper than water and it is perfectly acceptable to wander around with a beer in hand (at least that's what my friends and i told ourselves)

Astronomical clock incredible. Make sure you spend enough time here to see the clock font to life on the hour! A crowd gathers so get there in good time! Lovely restaurants in the square if a little pricey

Historic. Architecture around square is beautiful. Lots of restaurants with patios. Beautiful cathedral off square. Go to the top of the tower for a panoramic view of Prague. It is a real meeting and gathering place. Local musicians play there for some entertainment.
Nice little market. There is a really nice little market here with some good food and drink also nice buildings and good atmosphere.

Great for People Watching!. The square is a great hub to take a seat, drink a beer, and people watch. After a long day of walking about the city, I love to come here and sit at one of the outdoor seating areas to have a meal and some drinks. But, be forewarned, you pay significantly more to eat outside than you do inside of the restaurant. The menu shows you the indoor prices to lure you in and the waiter doesn't always mention to you the price differential up front. Also, typically in Czech, when the waiter brings you the bill they expect to be paid on the spot and also to receive the tip on the spot. Don't leave the tip on the table - someone else will take it! The going rate for tipping in Czech is 5%-10%. The service is less than the service in America, yet the waiters often expect an American-sized tip when waiting on an American. Tip as you see fit.

Like being in Rome. This was a rather cool place, and we went there many times, just to walk around and look at some shops in the day time. And at night you have the church and astronomical clock lit with lamps, making it a centre for people and tourists. There was also stands selling roast pork and wine and beer. If you havent decided what youre doing for tomorrow, there is also a tourist information there with many helpful people.

A lovely relaxing area. Old town square is a lovely, relatively free attraction. It holds the important astronomical clock and some other lovely buildings. Go on the hour during the day to see the clock in all its glory!Surprisingly there are no shops in the square... so go to eat or for a drink or just a look around. There are some stalls, like a crepe stand, which are nice for a snack. If you're eating in a restaurant, eat inside instead of on the square. Their prices are 50% dearer for eating outside and the prices quoted on the menu are for inside- so you might get a shock if dining outside!

Relax and Take in the Atmosphere. Wonderful big old square so you don't feel hemmed in by people. There are food stalls to eat at also Restaurants with outside tables where you can sit in the sun and have a cold Czech beer and watch the world go by. Bags of atmosphere.
nice walk.. Did lots of walking in Praque but it was well worth it , the old town is amazing place to visit. Lots of nice places to eat and drink.
The beautiful heart of Prague. Surrounded by beautiful buildings and with lots of bustle this is the heart of Prague and an absolute must see
Mind and senses blowing. Same walking tour guide Keith was excellent. Don't miss looking at the wall of an old monastery pocked marked by cannon balls.

Charming. We kept returning to this time and again. Between the old brick buildings, the cobblestones, the cafes, adn the shops, what's not to like. We especially liked the store "Blue." A little pricey but a lot unique!

Old Town Square. The buildings on the square are lovely but the astronomical clock was a disappointment. It is very crowded and the activity on the clock (father time ringing a bell and the apostles passing by a window) is small and not very exciting after the build-up it gets. BUT we took a fantastic FREE walking tour of Prague that started in the square. The trip was included free with our transport from the airport, which I would highly recommend. We were met at the exit with a sign with our names on it and taken to our hotel for less than the cost of a taxi. The tour was four hours long - a lot of walking - but the guide was superb and we learned a lot. I would definitely recommend it.
Tyn cathedral. This is spectacular at night when lit up? Looks like something from a Harry Potter film. Make sure you see the astrological clock it chimes on the hour and is worth watching
A must visit !. Be sure to take the elevator next to the world famous astromical clock...for the best views and photos of the square.
FANTASTIC!. What a setting! Find the circular marble cobble that is the "centre of Europe". There is also a brass strip that is the old meridian that was used in the olden days.

Must see but no need to linger. The Old town Square is beautiful and maintains a very "old town" feel. However, it is very very crowded. Everyone stands around waiting for the astronomical clock to sound. We watched the clock strike noon and there was a short trumpet interlude in addition to the clock figurines. While interesting, it wasn't that exciting. I would definitely stop by the Old Town Square but there is no need to hang around for too long.

Beautiful and fun. This beautiful square is a must-see. Filled with people, the famous astronomical clock is probably the most famous building, but there is also a church and other attractive buildings. A large statue in the center always has people siting around it . On one end of the square are stalls with food. There is a real feeling of vibrancy in the square, although I couldn't tell how many of the people were tourists or locals. Try to be there on the hour so you can see the "show" put on by the astronomical clock.
Bask in antiquity. With such a limited history in the USA it was a heady experience to walk through buildings dating to the eleventh century. Beautifully preserved square.

Really unique in my experience. Town centre is a must go, with its astronomical clock, which performs on the hour, as does the trumpeter at the top of the tower. Restauants were surprisingly good value, but do not go for the over priced pork steaks roasted over wood from the stalls. Really relaxing place to chill out as well as visit the innumerable classical evening concerts, starting from 6.00 which are well worth it. Give the monistary a miss though, the 'Songs from the Shows' is over priced, not a patch on the string concerts.

Old Town Square - a must see!. The Old Town Square was just lovely with beatiful buildings. Very crowded though!! We paid to join a tour guide from here and would thoroughly recommend doing so. Square is very central and close to so many other tourist attrractions. Close to some beatiful shops too (Gucci, Hermes etc) if you like serious shopping! Be careful of the taxi drivers situated on the Old Town Square as they charge way over the asking price from here. You only have to walk 5 minutes away to be charged a far price to your destination.
A must see. This is a must see when in Prague, so much happening here. Great just to sit in a restaurant and watch the world go by.

Beautiful and historic old town. Old town square was a staple of our entire Prague trip. From the historic tours, beautiful architecture, numerous shops and the different foods to try, old town square was a wonderful locale. Try and catch the astrological clock.

Most visited square in Prague. Old Town Square is heart of Prague but there are literally a billions of people. So many pubs, bars, shops, restaurants etc. It is the best place to watch live hockey and football games, but only national games
First trip to Prague. The beautiful buildings, wellkept and bright. The jugendstyle. The calm due to tafficpolitic ( no cars in the towncenter)

A very nice place to spend a few hours. I've been in this place at different moments of the day, but the most spectacular is in the evening, when the lights are projected on the surrounding buildings. At fixed hours, the astronomical clock is watched by hundreds of people, photographing, filming, applauding the "show" performed by some marionettes in the tower.

Must visit. Most walking and day Prague tours start here. The astronomical clock goes off every hour and tourist gather to see that. You can find food vendors selling food (I am not sure how traditional it is.). There is always something happening here: street performers, concerts, cafes, restaurants.If you are in Prague you must come here.

A pity about the marquees all over the place. The Staromestke Namesti is beautiful and would be absolutely stunning, if not for all the new restaurants dotting the square, with their marquees up for outdoor seating. However, even these "eyesores" can't distract from the beautiful buildings, the magnificent Astronomical Clock or the frescoed house that Kafka lived in as a boy.

Perfect location for a stroll. The area around the Old Town Square are astonishing, even at night. Do not miss the square when the sun has gone down and have a look at the Astrological clock on the tower on the square.

So much going on. There is so much going on in the Old Town Square! From the astronomical clock show every hour, to the people watching throughout the square. This is the front porch of the entire city and it is a place to see and be seen. It is the starting point for many of the free tip trips around the city. With two churches, many cafes and museums it is the first place on any tourists agenda when you arrive to the city.
Can't miss it. The heart of Prague. Don't miss the clock show at every hour. Al the buildings around are full of history. Great to have dinner outside
First and best stop in the mornings. One of the busiest part of town but is surrounded by the most beautiful views of the river, the bridges, the gorgeous buildings

great spot. If you're in Prague, it's likely you will go here....so, do what everyone does...walk through, be lazy, shop, etc and you'll have a blast (but watch your purses - I always hear that's a spot for pickpockets).

gorgeous, historical, colorful, great shops but don't eat sausage from street vendors or beware turista!. lovely shops, carriage driven horses, tourists (less this year than last, guess it's the economy), the dollar is great right now. Jut wander around, so much to do. Buy gorgeous cashmere colorful pashmina scarves cheap. Be sure to go at sundown, watch the astrological clock, have a beer - Pilsner and watch the late night sun go down!

A good place to spend an afternoon. The Old Town Square is full of tourist attractions, and only steps away from many more, like the Chocolate Museum.We visited during February - bitter cold, snow falling, dim light, but we still liked it, so I assume visiting during summer should be even more pleasant. It is easy to reach by subway or tram and you can spend a whole afternoon there, walking around, having a coffee or lunch in one of the many restaurants and cafes in the square. Souvenir shops seem to be a bit less expensive than the ones around Charles Bridge and Prague Castle.

Can not be missed. Do suggest climbing the tower, checking out the town hall and going underground. Combined ticket from Official Info centre next to clock. Price includes guide and is very good value. Worth coming back soon after dark as the lighting on the buildings is also very good.
Good restaurants and an excelent view. Enjoy sitting in one of the fantastic restaurants you find there and look the people waiting for the astronomical clock to start its show.

Keep you eye on the Clock!. Another great place to vist to watch the people, artists and street entertainment. Most of all though, get there in time to watch the clock at the top of the hour! Prague also has the best beer in the world!

Christmass Fairy-tale. We've spent pre-christmass week in Prague and Old Town Square was an incarnation of holyday! Even with the lack of snow it felt Christmass all the way! Big decorated tree surrounded by numerous cabins from Christmass-market made you feel like a child (excited like one) everytime you passed them! Day and night! But evenings of course were most incredible time to walk by! City-tour bus's excursion starts there with very informative story about medieval ages, the time square started to llok like it does nowdays. I wouldn't reccomend to have a lunch or dunner in caffes near-by as most of them are "touristic" (in the bed way) places and you would not feel warm czech welcome as you can feel if you'll make only few steps away and get into tangled maze of narrow streets tied around Old Town Square.

Great landmark. Its always crowded with people ,but the buzz is a great feeling , its all because of the beauty of the place and place has got a elegant touch to it . It will hold you on for a while once you are there and then you start exploring it in more detail as every structure would be different from the other .....
Incredible at Christmas time. With the large Christmas tree and the decorations and people selling all kinds of ornaments and grog and meat, it was so picturesque. It's a perfect Christmas town.

A great place to be - must visit!. The Old Town Square is truly one of the highlights of Prague. That 'old town' feel with cobblestone streets, lots of laneways with curious shops. And in the Square itself is the marvellous Astronomical Clock. It is amazing and everyone is excited to be there 'on the hour'. This is no ordinary clock (wont spoil the surprise!). There are musicians and great street food to please all tastes. Grab some food and sit down anywhere and 'people watch'. Lots of cafes and wonderful shops. Lovely garnet! I loved being here because it has such a happy feel about it. Enjoy!
Jazz in old town square. Great place to hang out at any time and on our last night in Prague the Jazz festival started and we enjoyed a chardonnay with some great Jazz music.

Almost like a carnival with so much going on. Weddings, music, restaurants and cafes, street performers, tourists, and of course, souvenir shops. A very international crowd, and all ages. If you like people-watching, be sure to drop by - sit in one of the cafes & watch the crowds.
the square is simply wonderful. The square has history on every corner. The clock in the centre has a surprise on every hour. Try to go in the morning you will see why.

Most beautiful square in Eastern Europe. Obviously, that is my opinion. But come on. It is like a real life Disney World. Unfortunately, I can't give it an excellent rating as it is always packed shoulder-to-shoulder with tourists, which takes away from the experience.
Too crowded. If you're overwhelmed with tourists, go to the square early morning or late at night. It's beautiful when you can stand there and enjoy the architecture without being shoved or bothered.

the centre of Prague shopping. designer stores off one side, alley ways of jewellry and craft type shops in the other direction. Be there on teh hour to hear the herald and see the clock. Lots of bars and restaurants, bit on the dear side for Prague but nice.YOU SHOULD NOTE: Toilets in Prague are often charged for even where you are already paying for a meal.
amazing. beautiful square where alot is happening. a must to visit and poeple watch

Looks like Disney World at night. The Old Town Square in Prague is wonderful. While the main attractions are the Astronomical Clock, Tyn Church, Ungelt Courtyard etc, but the charm is in the whole atmosphere of the old town square. It got quite crowded during the day ( the Europe Cup soccer was also going on!), but we enjoyed it most early morning ( before 10 AM) and late night ( after 10PM). Infact after 10PM when the crowds have gone and the buildings are lit ( especially the Tyn Church), the place looks like magical disney land. We loved it there. Fortunately it is in the center of Prague, so we had to criss-cross it several times during our stay - we loved it. The cafes there have outdoor seating that allow to soak in the atmosphere, but be aware they are prohibitively expensive !
recommend.. It's a great place to visit and every one should visit if they are in Prague. Cafe's etc are more expensive in the Square but then that's the same everywhere.
Many of Prague's Highlights are here!. A beautiful location that houses many of the cities most popular attractions! This is a must see!
the best markets in Prague. Enjoy the markets on Old Town Square, if it's Easter or Christmas, if it's spring/summer/autumn or winter, each of the markets offers something special for you.
Nice clock. Good to see the clock with all the little people going round.

Beautiful architecture. It can be difficult to gawk at the building surrounding this square with the large tour groups shuffling in and out. Give yourself time to take everything in, then grab a beer a couple blocks away.

Visit the historic Astronomical clock. The most beautiful city center I have seen. The astronomical clock was truly a wonder. There are fabulous restaurants and the view of the square with its numerous baroque churches is breathtaking.

Great!. Everything is within walking distance from shopping to dining to cultural representations of the city. High-end shops and little souvenir shops are scattered everywhere. One can never go hungry with small restaurants and even the old prague ham and crepes sold in stalls near the Astronomical clock is enough eaten in the small park on the back-side of the store.
Beautiful but so overrated.... Beautiful spot but I am never too impressed with medieval and Gothic architecture. Very overpriced too for the city standards

Lively and historic. There are beautiful buildings all around plus a lot of activity with a street market, musicians busking plus the amazing astronomical clock, which attracted a big crowd when it was due to chime.
Bustling. Lunch at the stand-up cafe where they sell delicious sausage and ham. Don't miss the astronomical clock.
Amazing square, a lot to view.. Not Liked: an event on square that obstructs taking good pictures

Amazing series of architectural treats. One could walk round this square day after day and still discover new delights.Let's get the negatives out of the way first. Allowing the tacky Hundai display to seize a large part of the area was shameful (plus counter-productive in that it made me - and I suspect others - determined never to buy one of their cars). Also, unless you sit on steps or the ground, the only seating available means you have to buy a beverage/food.But I refused to allow crass commercialism to spoil an extraordinary portfolio of beautiful buildings. There was also a highly competent quartet of musicians playing violins and a cello to an enthusiastic tourist audience - and, of course, the brilliant Astronomical Clock which helped put the icing on the good mood here.

Beautiful Ols Town Square. The Old Town Square is 'postcard' pretty, and this is where the Astrological Clock is. Not at the top of the tower as I imagined but quite low down. It's surrounded by beautiful old houses, however, it was very, very, crowded. This was probably because we arrived just after the hour had struck. It was also a weekend and there were activites on in the square. Beware of over charging taxi drivers here and use only AAA yellow cabs.

Fun Environment. The square was filled with fun-loving tourists, cafes and street performers. Everyone was well behaved. We enjoyed the astronomical clock, the tower, and just wandering through the shops on all the narrow streets off of the square.
Beautiful!. Sat here most days and had icecream. Its beautiful. Definitely go to the people with red umbrellas for a hop on hop off tour!
A great square. A large Old Town Square with a spectacular clock tower. The appearance was spoilt for tourists during Euro 2012 because of the large Hyundai screen and stage.
Beautiful place!. Very nice and beautiful place with lots of different coffee shops and restaurants near!

a good place to find crowds of tourists. You have to go. It has many interesting things to see around the perimeter of the large town square. it is big enough to get separated from your party. pick a meeting place just in case
Nice place with strong atmosphere. I like to visit this place. Especially during Christmas time. The only negative thing is that it is always full of tourists.
Beautiful place. Very good to visit but do so early in morning before the tourist buses arrive as it gets packed so moving around becomes difficult.

A sense of Europe preserved. This whole area is absolutely beautiful, the architecture is astonishing. The astronomical clock is pretty awesome, make sure you are there on the our to witness the 12 apostles make an appearance. Lots of great restaurants and shops although a bit pricey. There is a little flea market toward the center where you will find better deals.
More tourists than locals. Lovely square, worth a visit, but too many tourists :-)
Commercial vendors filled square. The square was mostly commercial with no suitable vistas for tourists to appreciate. Enjoyable outside restaurant near astronomical clock
One of the most beautiful sights in the world. Words cannot describe how beautiful this location is - it must be experienced.

Nice but too commercial.. The sights are great, but you can´t help to feel that commercialism has taken over, some of the old buidings were half invisible due to great big advertising flags and banners.Every inch of the square seems to be filled with people trying to part you from your money, but if you don´t mind that, plus all the other tourists aiming their cameras upwards to get some pictures to take home with them, then it´s breathtaking.

History amazing. Ensure you join a walking tour. There is so much more to be appreciated when someone explains the history of the fate of the maker of the clock of life under the communist regime, for instance.

a must see..... We loved the hustle and bustle of tourists taking in the sites, but also the restaurants around the perimeter where we could sit and enjoy a meal and soak up the atmosphere and the site of this beautiful square

Cocktails by the clock. We sat at the U Prince Hotel bar area outside, sipping cocktails and watching the world go by including the hoards of people gathering every hour under the clock! Lovely square, loads of places to eat and drink. Came back several times during our stay.
Much to take in. This city has so much to offer you really need at least a week here to only begin to scratch the surface.
The Heart of Prague. One of the nicest squares in Europe and a must see in Prague. A tour guide or good book guide is needed to truly appreciate the square's value and beauty.

old town square. If you want to be lost in the 16th century in prague, I would suggest first go to old town square in prague. Guarded by the Power gate from the 11th century, churches and towers and most important the astronomical clock, then you should visit this place first.I found reaching there a bit tricky as you have to cross some small narrow lanes but once up there I really liked it. The city tour of buses and cruise leave from the place. Hop into one of them if you have limited time. It will really take you to places in a short time.DO not forget to get you loved ones a sovinour which I found really cheap in Prague (EURO 2). Food is good and cheap compared to paris or amsterdam etc. The beauty of this small places is that the common people really knows a lot of languages and you will not face any trouble.

So Much to See and Taste. You are surrounded by beautifully designed and decorated buildings. For the adventuresome there is the opportunity to try the roasting hams, the doughnuts cooked over open charcoals grills, crepes and of course, Czech beer.
Busy place. Beautiful. Crowded but not so much that you can't move around.
Great ambience. Euro-Cup soccer was on, and giant screen set up in square next to astronomical clock tower. Great fun.

Everything you expect & more. You must see the Astronomical clock when it strikes the hour.Avoid eating a main meal there - there are cheaper restaurants that are just as good in the back streets nearby
Magnificent. Be there to watch the atronomical clock as the "apostles" walk out and the trumpet sounds from the tower. Beautiful!

The heartbeat of the city. The Bones Church has an interesting clock that chimes at the hour, with a trumpet player. Hyundai also had big screens set up in the square to show the EURO2012 soccer matches live. There were lots of great restaurants, shopping and historical scenary. One of my favorite places in Cz.
Very beautiful and picturesque. Not a lot to do here, but it worth visiting as it is the heart of cultural Prague and a very beautiful spot within the city.
Coo-Coo clock. You want to be by the big clock on the hour to watch the sooo cute coo-coo clock.
Prague's main plaza. This plaza is huge! I was there for 5 days and couldn't get my bearings! It is really nice but definitely do not stop for food here, you will over pay.
Heart of the city. This is the city main magnet, seems all streets lead there, so it is difficult to miss walking around old Prague.
Nice, but touristy. It's a beautiful square, but quite touristy. I would not recommend dining here as it will be more expensive.
damn you hyundai. because of the EUROCup, the squadre was all invaded by hyundai stands and flags, and it spoiled all the beauty and attractiveness of the place.
Prague old town square. Brilliant.....love the way they make use of the square with stalls, restaurants and concerts.
Beautiful. A must see in the day and at night for different views of the historic buildings and wonderful street cafes!
Beautiful but touristy. Even though it is clogged with tourists it is a beautiful square, one of the nicest in Europe.
Beautiful buildings. Watched the clock on the hour but found the hype didn't match the event, lots of lovely shops and restaurants nearby and the church is absolutely beatiful
center of town. busiest place of prague, full of tourists and also locals. Very beautiful architecture everywhere and nice people, pretty ladies. Night life is also good.
Must see when in Prague. One of the highlights in Prague. Big square with the astrological clock that opens uo every hour for like10-15 seconds. Tons of people so go earlier to get a good spot.

wow so cool. Prague is a beautiful place to visit. We enjoyed the Old Town Square the best . Historic and lovely. Must see the clock. Very crowded of course! Have the smoked ham roasting an a spit with rye bread, great, yum yum

Prague old city. Prague is definitely worth a visit, all the history, architecture, the culture, food, music and theatre ! Close to the Old Town Square, around a corner leading off the small street right opposite the astronomical clock, one comes to another "market" where hand crafts are sold, fresh produce and also in that square is a buffet-type sit-down eatery where locals go. All Czech specialities and at really good prices, informal and a great place to just "blend in".
Must see. The astronomic clock is in the square. Lots of cute shops and good restaurants.

A beautiful place in a beautiful city. Walk and watch...sit and watch...take pictures of the clock...you will go back again and again to enjoy this beautiful place...so much history and beauty...take your time and enjoy a beer as you take it all in.

Old Town square Prague. One of the most vibrant squares of any European cities! It is buzzing with tourists from morning till midnight and every evening when they lit up the square, it looks magical. Good eateries at the square where one can lounge and people watch too! No vehicles in the square allowed, hence the charm is retained.

Great market at Christmas. The Christmas markets were centred around the Old Town Square. Lots of food stalls. Also free entertainment on special stage for markets. There are lots of restaurants and bars in the area. Watch the serving staff (bars / restaurants) as they tend to take a tip without asking. They add it to the bill as if it is a given. Always get the bill first, pay the stated amount and then give a tip as necessary.

lovely atmosphere and lots to see. The old town square is lovely, with restuarants on every corner and little bars tucked down the side streets. Chocolate shops and loads of shopping. Great atmosphere and the famous clock is situated in the sqaure. There is usually some type of entertainement on and a lovely irish bar called the dubliner is set just off the square.
Great place to while away time if you can afford it. This is where you'll find the Astronomical clock. Sitting outside to drink costs double the price of sitting inside..
Lovely square. Great part of this city, just watch the astronomical prices that go with the astronomical clock !!!!
Keep your eyes up but your footwear flat!. Lovely if you can ignore toot shops however so much great architecture to look at in an odd way it blends in!
Stunning. In the Old Town Square, one is surrounded by stunning architecture. I couldn't help but say "wow" about 15 times as I did a slow 360-degree turn in the square. Photo-ops galore.

Don't miss this place!. If you went to Prague and did not get into this square, with the marking of the hour at the astronomical clock, the Tyn Church, the Jan Hus memorial, and all the happy crowd dining, strolling, laughing, visiting, listening to musicians....I would say you missed the best of Prague. And there are a lot of great places to see in Prague.
the clock. wait with all other tourists to see the clock at 12 oclock. looking on the people is very intersting. watch yourself from pockt theives

Still intact!. I love visiting Europe for the old architecture. Prague was blessedly missed by the bombs of WWI and WWII. This is one of the most beautiful Old Town Squares I've ever seen. The churches and monuments are a wonder to view. It threatened rain the day we were there. The pictures were very dramatic for that sky view!

Great Environment to Soak in. Great environment, sights and sounds. We spent two evenings at the Old Town Square, wherein we settled in for longish dinners at one of the most prominently located restaurant almost adjacent to the Clock Tower. Merely relaxing there and watching all that is happening around in itself is a great feel. The views of the monuments, architecture - especially when illuminated at night is a view not to be erased from our memories easily.
Busy Busy Busy. Very Busy The Famed Clock is a bit of a letdown.The square was packed and was being used as a venue to watch the footy
You can go easily with public transport!. From the best sightseeings, you can walk and take a look at the souvenir shops. The architecture of the city fascinates!

If want to feel the spirit of Prague. You need to go there. The best thing about Prague is that all historical sightseeing places is not too far from each other. You want to take photos of all old buildings, cause this is really beautiful city! With it's own unique history!

Overcrowded, overpriced tourist trap. This is a pretty square, but is spoilt by being one of Prague's main focal points. There are all sorts of stalls and hawkers trying to con you (don't fall for the tricks used by the guys on the roast pork stalls), and probably pickpockets too. The bars and restaurants around the square are the most expensive in Prague - don't eat there, go elsewhere.

Gorgeous!. The Old Town square is absolutely breathtaking in its beauty and architecture. The charming cobblestone streets of the Old Town suddenly open up to this lively, buzzing beautiful hub of activity. All of a sudden, you take in the beautiful Tyn Church, Astronomical Clock, the lovely Jan Hus statue and so many more pretty buildings along with a ton of ristorantes, cafes and food stalls selling traditional Hungarian food. Then there's so many people from so many places around the world - tourists, hawkers, musicians & bubble blowers doing their thing. Take a couple of minutes to soak in all the energy and beauty before you start walking around in the little lanes around Tyn Church, where you will be greeted with some beautiful music. Enjoy the delicacies - the Hungarian Tredelnik & Langose are a must-have!
Don't miss it!. This is a beautiful square with lots of people, activities, restaurants and shopping. You could watch the Astronomical Clock more than once (before and after dinner?).
Dodgy sales tactics. Be very careful how much you`re paying for food and drink! Ask beforehand!
Very Pretty. Old Town Square is worth a visit. It's really very pretty. The only downsides are the number of tourists and the pick-pockets.

Beautiful and rich. The Old Town Square is a piece of History and Art. Some of the buildings are staying there for centuries and witnessing all the changes in our world: inquisition, persecutions, kings, defenestrations, old wars, recent wars, fights for freedom and certainly many love stories, all of that can be seen in the Old Town Square. A true gem!
Dont miss. The place is a magical place. You should not miss it if you are in Psrage

Make sure to check out the clock. The astrological clock in the square is both beautiful and technically fascinating. We also had dinner in the square at one of the several restaurants and it was nice to eat on the patio and soak in the ambiance. It is fairly touristy but, what the heck... I was a tourist :)We were also warned about pick pockets and drunks in the square later at night but did not run into this ourselves (which may have been influenced by the fact that the night we were there after midnight it was pouring rain and both criminals and tourists had likely taken sensible cover).

Always seemed to be Special Events. We went one time when the Christmas Market was set up and that was really interesting.Beautiful open square with several good restaurants to eat sand people watch.Stand back from different side and take in the beautiful architecture

can't miss this!!! a must see!. You can't visit Praha without coming to the Old Town Square. Try to come here early in the morning to avoid the crowd. So much history in this place so attempt to read before visiting to appreciate what you're seeing. Visit the various churches surrounding the square. And head to the top of Old Town Hall for a birds-eye view.Visited Sept. 2009
Beautiful but crowded. The square is really packed on Saturdays and Sundays. Try to visit midweek.
Lovely old square. Have to see the clock at the hour. We also went to the art exhibution which was well worth seeing.
Great Atmosphere. A must go are for all visitors. Plenty of shops & food outlets & great atmosphere.
Marvellous. You will feel in the deep past here-every house is hunderds years antique-its a wonderfull sensation

Culture, history and beautiful sights. A good place to try and stay close to, lots of jazz bars, restaurants and drinking holes. The church and buildings are beautiful and the astronomical clock is a confusing but interesting sight.
Busy. Very busy square - lots to see for a visit but find a back street for food and drink

You have to see it - but it's busy!. This is a must-see if you're going to Prague, but it covers a large area and is easy to find so seems to be the place that all tour parties leave from, so coupled with the large number of people who just want to look around you get a LOT of people, especially as the hour approaches and people gather to watch the Astronomical clock.
A wonderful place. Great atmosphere and towers, spires and wonderful buildings all around

Magnificent. The Old Town Square is the heart of Prague, and a focus for tourists (especially the clock tower). Every building is a treat to see, and the overall effect is outstanding. A must see for lovers of the baroque

Atmospheric!. It really is 'old style' - large and surrounded by restaurants, shops and the impressive old Town Hall. Well worth a visit - wander around and sit in one of the restaurants, have a drink and watch the world go by!

Like something from a movie set. We had dinner on a warm, balmy evening in the Town Square. The beauty and character of the buildings is out of this world, especially with the lights at night. There were lots of tourists as well, having rides in horse and carts. The Astronomical Clock, was very unusual and full of ancient character. We loved the prices in Prague too, drinks and food so cheap!!!

Great Town. This town is great... so many buildings which have great history .. brillant architecture to view - they also have alot of shops so if you are bored of the buildings then you can head to the shops... pretty much the same types of shops you get in London so really in hindsight you are not missing much. I did notice that the town square have alot of thai massages.. probably good as the amount of walking you will do... you will need a good foot/leg massage... great prices if you haggle too.

Essential place to visit. The variation in styles and colours of the picturesque buildings that border the square are eye-catching. If you are into people-watching just sit in one of the many cafes in the square and relax and enjoy.
Awsome place. Everyone needs to go at least once. We climbed the tower and it gave awesome views of the city. The astronomical clock is very interesting.
Amazing architecture. Very large square with various buildings and churches bordering it. The architecture is stunning. And a large statue off the center of the square is impressive as well.

Beautiful public square. Sit in one of the many cafes- rest your feet- enjoy the lovely buildings lining one of Euope's biggest public spaces. Watch the worlds tourists following the umbrellas- often at whistle-stop pace.The Baroque and neo-Renaissence facdes of the buildings reveal none of the harrowing past of this square- read the history before you go.
old town square. a nice square, we sat to have a break here. would be good if they had some more chairs!

Full of life. At all times of day and night during the 4 days we were here, the square was full of life. Children, the elderly, and everyone in between. Locals and tourists from all over the world make this the gathering place of the city. It is surrounded by old buildings with amazing architecture, and restaurants and food stands galore.
Our favourite spot. We loved this square and stopped for soup or a beer each day! Loved people watching!
Great views every where you looked. Loved the sights and sounds - statues everywhere, cobblestone roads, horse drawn carts,

A beautiful square in the medieval style. Staromestske Namesti is a beautiful square in the medieval style. Tower has astrological clock - Orloy. In Orloy are hiding figures wich show in its time. Fascinating spectacle!

a confection of delights. Old Town Square really does have the wow factor. This offers the highest concentration of painted and decorated buildings I have EVER seen and they are all singularly impressive. Just sit and let history and culture wash over you whilst you absorb all its charm and elegance.

An atmospheric place. Prague, is jam packed full of wonderful buildings with breath taking architecture. Old Town Square, allows you to view so many interesting buildings that surround it. I love looking up at the Tyn Church spires which look like something out of a fairytale, especially at night when the little windows are lit.The square changes with the seasons. In Winter it is filled with stalls selling all sorts of gifts and food and in the Summer it is packed with tourists. Events are often held there, so check before you go and you may catch something interesting. But even without events, it is a magical place. The only drawback can be the amount of people milling around there, especially when the astronomical clock is about to chime. But for some this may just add to the experience.
excellent. Astrolabe spectacle is very popular, full of tourists and a loads of bars/rests inthe center
The Center of it All. you can orient yourself in Stare Mesto by the town square...everything radiates out from it llike spokes on a wheel...and the further away you go, the cheaper things are ;)

So much beauty in the one spot!. The Old Town Square of Prague is vibrant while also reflective of its history. It can get very, very busy but you expect that in one of Europe's most beautiful cities. A lovely place to spend time and just be.
A lovely place to spend the afternoon. There is so much to do and see here, the clock, museums, art galleries and lots of food stalls selling traditional goodies. Well worth a visit!

Wonderful. Almost like stepping into a set at off Disneyland! Incredibly clean and well looked after. Restaurants in the square are fairly pricey but just off there on one of the side streets they are much more affordable.

a must... day and night. Old Town is a wonderful old European city that hasn't been destroyed by fast food joints and franchises. There are old buildings, awe-inspiring churches, a statue in the center of the cobble-stoned plaza, vendors of local foods, and fun shops to check out. We climbed the astronomical clock tower for spectacular views. Be sure to check out Old Town in the day as well as the night. The buildings are beautifully lit at night. I had an amazing, delicious hunk of BBQ pig from a vendor in the center of the square.
It's fantastic. This place has a really magic amazing spirit, It'll stay in my heart forever.
Mix of cultures and history. You won't find many places on the Planet with such a great spirit of long history and mixing cultures and religions.
Great place to hang out. Don't eat in the restaurants when you can get great food from the stalls
CRYSTAL AND FUN. If you are looking for bargains on the finest crystal in the world, go no further. This is the place. Barter when you can.

Center of all the action. Awesome place to come - relax in an outdoor cafe and do some people watching. You should watch the astrological clock on the hour as well. If you wander around the Old Town, you will end up back in the square several times because all the roads lead there.
Lovely. Truly a great place to visit! Beautiful architecture from many ages, and great shopping opportunities. Highly recommended!
beautifull place. beautifull place but too croudy. Excellent atmosphere, try to go not the main stream

Amazing architecture. Do not miss the Old Town Square! There are so many wonderful building facades to look at as well as the famous Astronomical clock which "wakes up" on the hour. On a warm day there are plenty of places to sit and watch the world go by too!
Really liked it. Beautifully preserved. Be advised that while mahy of the shops have some very nice merchandise, you will find that the staff in most of these shops are rude.

Picturesque Old European Square. Old Town Square in Prague includes a square and assorted narrow, barely-more-than-pedestrian roads emanating from it. The square itself has several cafes and shops, but the astronomical clock and tower is the most striking feature. At the top of every hour, a crowd gathers to hear the astronomical clock chime and to see its figures set into motion. A costumed trumpeter plays from each of the four sides of the top of the tower and waves to all below.It is a great place to sit and have something to drink and/or a bite to eat while admiring the old architecture around the square and watching the people come and go. And before you know it, you're hearing the clock tower chime again.

Scenic spot. Great buildings, surround this historic square, you will undoubtedly end up here at some point during your stay and you will be clicking away with the camera! Visit day and night, it looks spectacular at both times.
Truely European City. Great architecture. We were enjoying every moment of and the kids were loving it too. A must visit European city!
The architecture is amazing. The architecture is amazing, each intersection has its history

Prague's most beautiful square!. This place is the thing that makes me proud to live in Prague. This is the centre of the Old Town, the most beautiful square in Prague with the astronomical clock. If you want to feel the magical atmosphere of the Old Town and see all those historical buildings, Old Town square is one of the best choices. Definitely a must-see!
A must place to see. Nice square, allot of shops and restaurants. The architecture is amazing

Inevitable "must see" but crowded and "touristy". You can't go to Prague without seeing the Old Town Square - in fact, it sometimes seems that almost any route you take leads you through it! Very crowded and surrounded by very touristy restaurants and bars - over-priced and typically quite poor food.Highlights worth going to see are the clock tower - best view in Prague - and the cellars/apartments attached to it.
Amazing. Old Town Square is the nicest historical sight i have seen so far. Beware of the pickpockets and expensive restaurants
Heart of the Beautiful city. Stay here long enough often enough and you will still find things you haven't noticed befoe

Like Something Out of a Storybook. It was almost a surreal experience both times I got to see Old Town Square. It is like something out of a storybook. An abundance of old, exquisite buildings. Happily, the buildings in Old Town Prague were spared during the war.
Charming!. Unbelievable! You might be tempted to think it's a film set!

Most beautiful and historical sight in Europe. Center and heart of Prague. Buildings of Romanesque, Baroque, Gothic style were built over the 700 years. Old Town Square is sorrounded by full of historical and beautiful buildings. Notable architectures in Old Town Square are Church of Our Lady before Tyn, Old Town Hall and Astronomical Clock, St. Nicholas Church, and Statue of Jan Hus in the center of Old Town Square. Old Town Square had been center and heart of Old Town since 10th century. There are lots of shops, restaurants, cafes, and galleries.
Historic Centre. Somewhere to relax with a cold beer watching the world go by

Our favorite town square this trip. This is a large square with numerous restaurants and food kiosks within a stones throw of each other. We kept coming back to this area as we traversed the city for three days.

One of Prague's gems. The highlight must be the Astronomical Clock. It is absolutely beautiful, as is the building in which it is housed. We were lucky enough to have the enormous doors just to the side open as we passed by. Like a flash we were in, and the ceiling was superb- then we were chucked out, but it is a lovely memory. The trumpeter on top of the tower appeared on the hour (until 7pm )and he was a real cheery chappie, waving to everyone in his fancy costume, when he had finished his solo.The tower opens into a large square with an interesting statue in the centre. As we walked around the statue we were struck by the number of exits from the square. We took one and found ourselves in the old Peacock Inn which claims that the Iron Chancellor, Bismark, had used its facilities when it was a house of ill-repute. We don't recommend their food, however, no matter how good it had been for Bismark!
Food Fest. During our visit to the Square a Food Festival was in full swing.Everything from roasted sauges,grilled Hams and sweets as well as other Czech specialities were for sale.Delicious.
A must see in Prague!. The architecture is amazing, a definite site to visit in Prague - the area is absolutely magestic!
charming. loved the crowds and history and beauty of everything.

just like in the pictures!. this square just doesn't disappoint, they had the ice hockey semis on screens on the saturday and street parties and bands day and night really fun happy lively place loved it and so very safe

A fairy tale view. A fairy tale view - like something that Disney would build only this is real. The astronomical clock puts on a nice display to the crowds once an hour and you can climb to the top of the tower for a great view.Bars around the square are expensive so just walk a short distance before sitting down for a beer.The crowd waiting for the clock to chime is a preferred pickpocket handout - so make sure your possesions are secure.
A bit crowded but still beautiful. The architecture was beautiful and we loved exploring all the tiny side streets off the square.
Night one way day another. The square is very beautiful and surrounded by good restaurants who considering their location, they are not expensive

Nice place but watch out buying food from the food stalls at the square. Big spacious square.Watch out for those food stalls that sell local food at the side of the square. They sell food by weight so if you do want to buy from them, DO tell them that you only want a little bit. They gave me and my husband a big chunk of ham and pasta salad which was absolutely TOO much and we couldnt finish - and it was £25 which was way too expensive for street food. We paid £20 in a local restaurant with proper sit down and serving.

Enormous open space. Surrounded by wonderful architecture, and restaurants, The Prague Marathon ended there on our last day, was able to get closer to the action than at the London Marathon some weeks earlier.

Probably a requirement but is crowded and a tourist trap.. Quickly walked around, saw hourly clock (which was very pretty, though) but was generally too crowded and full of people trying to sell souvenirs...

GREAT place to hang out- we visited here daily!. My husband and I loved the Old Town Square! The astronomical clock was here and was one of the neatest things we saw in Prague. All of the buildings are beautiful around here! My husband and I went here every night to enjoy some Czech beers. There is a lot of outdoor seating in the square, so we would sit outside and enjoy a beer or two every night while people watching. The restaurants here are a little more expensive on the square but totally worth the environment!
A must see. A absolute gem, nice to see that the historic buildings are well maintained.
Expensive. Very expensive. Avoid if you can when buying a coffeee.
this city hall remeber at old year of histrory. this city hall make us remember with old year in europe history. lot of anything you can see here... you can use ride horse to turn around city.

That's Prague!. This is the place I like the most in Prague! Wonderful and impressive buildings around the square and often the cultural activities in place. When I visited Prague, there's a cultural festival in which we passed with the people from the other countries. and I remember there's a bugler on the bell tower on hour, but I'm not sure there's always. In general, this is the most impressive place for me in Prague. Must see.

Astronomical Clock. Like every must see-sight it is crowded during the day (especially a sunny one), so I recommend to visit it early in the morning, but of course in the night it has its magic as well. During some holidays (Easter, Christmas) markets are held on Old Town Square or there are big screens when CZ takes part in some sports event. Don't miss to have a look at the Astronomical Clock (it's on the wall of Old Town City Hall - every hour you can see the figures (apostles) moving, while the Death (the skeleton) strikes the time, now there is a trumpeter under the roof playing the trumpet every hour I think. There are a lot of cafés on the square, but these are really expensive, I would definitely recommend to go to some of the little streets around the square and everything will be cheaper there! You can visit the Sant Nicolas Church, it's free, very peaceful and refreshingly cold in hot summer. There are some good exhibitions in the Old Town City Hall and if you're lucky you can see some wedding or newly-weds coming out of the City Hall.
Pretty town square. Pretty town square dotted with cafes and restaurants. The bohemian festival was on during my stay so there were street performers and food stands, which was good fun.
Wonderful. The Clock was an amazing story of invention and you must hear or read the history of the clock to understands its value to the city of Prague.
Awe inspiring!. My jaw dropped. What a sight. Visit it at night and during the day for the full experience!

So central and interesting. Everything on your doorstep. Again, loved the clean streets, felt quite safe (apart from constant warnings of pickpockets although we luckily didn't experience this). Again, disappointed to see the number of young men begging.

Amazingly beautiful!. We loved the atmosphere in the square and spent time here everyday for all of our five days in Prague. We enjoyed soaking up the atmosphere while having a drink. The architecture is something to see and it it nice to be there on the hour and hear the Astronomical clock.
Cute!. Take a tour so you can appreciate the architecture and ambience of the city! The astronomical clock is incredibly interesting, and make sure to go to the top for the best view!

one of the most charming squares of the world!. This is not a square, this is a jump in the past! Really a piece of history with fantastic old buildings surrounding it. A place you can visit more and more times, you'll never get tired of admiring it!

Crowds and cobbles. Old Town Square is deep in Tourist Trap Territory. Plus it has the most awful cobbles, in which respect it is not much different from the rest of central Prague. Beware the restaurants around the edge as well as the usual tat shops.Raise your eyes to the architectural delights above the square. On one side the Church of our Lady of Tyn. This is a late Gothic construction whose towers are such a strange and elaborate feature. Old houses have been built up very close to the front and all down the side of the church so it is only the spires that can be readily seen from any distance. Then on the other side is the main church and when we were there, among the ranks of badly dressed tourists, were lots of young people who were dressed so well they may have been a wedding party. On the other side of the square is the famous astronomical clock on the town hall. Maybe I'm getting cynical in my old age but I did not think it that special. I found the masses of people gazing up at it as it struck the hour, far more interesting to look at.

Lovely area. Splended buildings round the Old Square. The Astronomical clock was fascinating, be there on the hour for the fun and games! Go back after dark to see how pretty the lit-up buildings are.
Beautiful place. There you could see the astronomical clock, stop here for a coffee or beer. Depend of the season !!

Exciting times in the square. We were there in April when the square was jam packed with food vendors and craftspeople. It made for a very festive time, although there seem to be numerous people selling the same stuff whether it was food or goods.

Gotta love being with throngs of tourists. You can't help but go through Old Town Square when in Prague. Everything is overpriced and crowded. For tourists only. Take a right turn at the Cartier store and walk up that street to prettier digs.
Nice place to spend a complete day. You will love the astronomical clock, the merchandise shops and much more...
Great historic site. Great site to see, but beware of the crowds. They gather fast during the day and it can be impossible to get around Clock Tower by the end of the day.
Who wasn't there can not say that he was in Prague. You must visit if you are in Prague, because it is the main place for tourists

Vibrant Centre of a beautiful city!. We spent about a week in Prague and found ourselves constantly marvelling at the picuresque sorroundings of Prague's old town square!The astronomical clock is a must see, the cobblestone walkways and bustling crowds really make this the true heart of Prague! Plenty of shopping, bars and restaurants in a close vicinity to the area, so a great place to meet up with people and head off from there!Be warned though, the square is NOT a good place to eat or drink though. The mouth-watering ham spits are ridiculously over-priced, so avoid the temptation! The restaurants around the edges of the square will charge at least double that of restaurants a short walk away from the main square, and due to the busy crowds, pick pockets are apparently very successful here, so be mindful of your valuables.We didn't encounter any theft etc in Prague, and the police presence is constant so leaves you feeling quite safe most of the time. The only negative encounter we had in Prague was the ham spit roasts which cost us about 50 Euro for a sandwich (converted into Czech Coruna).
A must see. Although sometimes it is difficult to walk because of so many tourists, it is a must see. You should try the grilled sausage or the cilinder (Ceske Trdlo)
