Great Clock and Tower. Everyone who comes to Prague has to come here, especially to see and experience the astronomical clock at the top of the hour. It is very interesting and the square is packed to watch it. Take care to guard your valuables from pick pockets. The Old Town Hall Tower is the best one to go up in Old Town and you can take elevators all the way to the top if you choose to stand in line. The views are tremendous - river, bridges, castle, the square below, etc. Best place to get a picture of Tyn Church and the Jewish Quarter.

Part of the Prague experience. You have to stop by the square, see the Jan Huss statue and the clock. The clock is interesting even if it is not chiming--read about it, it is no ordinary clock. If you want to see it in action, morning is better with fewer people.
Place with a super atmosphere. This is a very important place, if you go to Prague. You can find the stunning square full of cafes and historical buildings.
Beautiful!. If not to get there in a time, when clocks start beeting - you will see more, because there will be less people:)

Spend Time understanding the time. No visit to Prague is complete without watching the clock. But not just any clock. This clock is unique in the information it provides. You don't have to wait for the hour to chime, its all over in a flash. what you do need to do is pick up a leaflet explaining exactly what the clock shows in order to make the most of your visit.
Major sites. Lots of attractive historcial buildings but very busy with crowds
Prague Easter Market. There was a Easter market while we are visiting the sqaure, a nice initiative

Fantastic!. We went to Prague during Easter week and the Old Town Square was buzzing with activity every day! There was a stage set up where a number of bands played live every day which was fantastic. There were many market stalls selling everything from puppets, wooden easter eggs, iron goods and swords, to hot food and drinks which were delicious. Definitely my favourite part of Prague!
Interesting place. Enjoyed watching the clock strike the hour when all the figures come out and Death strikes the hour. Lots of shops and places to eat and real ice cream.

Good for visiting the turist information center. The old town Square is like all the czech's squares. Some statues, lots of turists on the way from Charles bridge to the information center. A Starbucks Coffee is just around the corner.
History. Nice area to see history, sit in outdoor restaurants and people watch
wow. this isx somethin you have to see lot of old housis and its so nice
Pretty but buy food elsewhere. Lots of history in a very small area. Clock is cool for what it does (especially given when it was built) but don't cry if you miss it striking the hour!
L'Horloge (Orloi) must be watched.... Surrounded by great restaurants, galleries, there are always events on the square.
Cute town square!. Nice food stalls in the area, and the pretty clock
When you are in Prague you cannot miss it. Lovely square, but very busy. It is even better to visit it in the evening.

Entertaining. Plenty of food and drink shoices around the square. Usually, there's music in the air either from a stage or traveling band. The world famous clock is worth seeing in action and learning the story behind it. A trip to the top is also recommended for great photos. The square is a little tight compared to some (Krakow) so I'd like to see some of the "permenant" vendor buildings removed to open things up.
Thursday through Sunday great. Several food vendors, buzzing a bit more than Mon-Wed...just a fun plaza to nosh and people watch.

Rest and watch all the tourists over your favorite beverage.. You will return here more than once. The people alone are one of the significant attractions. The heart of the city, great shopping in all directions. Food, drink, ice cream, chocolate everywhere, no vehicles.
Beautifull and very crowdy!. One of the nicest squares in Europe! Full of fotographing tourists ,but still worth a visit.
Old town square-a must. Of course a "must:"while being in Prague.Pretty crowded, watch out for bag snatchcers.
Awesome. Love this place...right in the middle of Prague but you walk one block and you don't see a single tourist....very very beautiful
Great place. Lots of cafes and food stalls with local delicacies
Visit the Square by day and night. Beautiful by day and magical at night. Many tours leave from the Square....check them out.

Great place to spend a few hours. One of the larger (if not the largest) and most beautiful old town squares in all of Europe. I happened to be there during Easter week, so there were a lot of music, singing, dancing, food and festivities taking place. From the old town square a lot of tours (on-foot) start, like ghost tours, walking tours, etc. The square is always packed with tourists, there were many places to eat, there is the small Dali museum. I heard that there are a lot of pick-pockets, I do believe it as the place is crowded, however, I was not subjected, not did I see anyone being subjected to any such activity. The street food in the square, as well as in the old town is decent. The architecture of the surrounding structures is beautiful. The old town square is a must see, day and night. Other than the alleged pick-pocketing, the old town center, as well as the surrounding areas are safe. I walked around at all hours of day and night and did not feel unsafe at any moment.

Lovely. This a must.....various architectural styles. Loads of people and groups. Around the clock was the busiest.-Old Town Hall Tower-Astronomical Clock, -Church of Our Lady before Tyn and -St. Nicholas Church therefore loads to see in a small area if u into that type of stuff.There was 2 weddings......seeing the bride and groom move thru the crowd...what a photo that would makeLoads of places to eat or just to chill out.Ice cream was cheap also 20 CZF for one scoop.
nice to visit buth tooooo busy. Verry nice old town,buth there are so many toerist that you cannot walk or see somthing

Interesting to wander. Plenty to see and do
Restaurants get busy - book if you find a place you like
Especially at night. This area has a great view of the lightings that were installed at great expense (Mick Jagger helped pay for it) and it is a huge success.
Don't eat here!. The food is very expensive in the Old Town Square. Go to the locals restaurants away from there for a better food for a better price. You can have a good launch for 250 Czech crowns.

Very pretty. Fascinating architecture, cosmopolitan feel. Beware of pick pockets around the astronomical clock. People tend to gather around taking photographs on the hour, looking skywards. Ideal for pick pockets.
Liked the Astronomical Clock. Hard to believe this automated machine was built in the 1400s

interesting at Easter. At Easter there is an Easter market selling lots of hand decorated eggs, and a variety of other stalls selling lots of other things. There is also a stage with dancing and singing going on, and decorated Easter trees. This is well worth a look if you are visiting at Easter time. It does get very busy as it is one of the many foci in Prague for sightseers, but there is plenty to see in the area, and plenty of places to eat.
The most amazing city!. The best advice I can give. Don't be afraid just walk around, take unexpected turns and you will discover the beauty of this city! Visit the Bridge at night it's full of life!

Great if you can avoid the crowds. A good show case of the many facets of Prague, we thought – great heritage, miraculously saved from Nazis and Communists, yet way too many tourists, and crass commercialism all over. Looking back, the Tyn church on the square is a splendour, and will likely stay with me for a long long time.I sympathize with the urge to live like normal people after 40 years of communism, but any way to tone down the commercial stands and bazaar, Mr Mayor!?
The place to start. Can see that in peak times this square will get very busy.

Must start here first, it seems to be the heart of Prague. The Old Town square has beautiful historic Prague buildings around it. There is also a regular market there selling local food and souvenirs. There was constantly a big crowd there, especially when getting close to the hour because that is when the clock will strike and you can watch the little statues on it get animated and the trumpeter play. Good to get a chance to visit this place during the day and once again at night. If you go there before 8.00am you almost get the place to yourself, so for photographers that would be a better time. Do make sure you go up the clock tower, I found that to be a worthwhile trip. They have elevators, so my knees were really thankful for it. Food was rather expensive at the restaurants there, also not much of a choice in menu, plus I found the staff there quite unfriendly.
in love. one of the most beautiful places ive been. i love the architecture, food, culture and people. beautiful in the day, feel in love with by night.
Square. Lovely square but very crowded for most of the day, food and drink very expensive in and around the square

Pretty - a 'must see'. The Old Town square is a beautiful place to see the historic Prague buildings. There is also a regualr market there selling 'Czech' food and souvenirs. Visit both in the day and at night to see it lit up (and watch the animated clock)
Beautiful. Loved it...one of my favourite parts of Prague. Lovely to walk from here to Charles bridge.

So many landmarks in one. Amazing spot to begin your exploration of Prague. It has the Astronomical Clock, St. Nicholas Church, Tyn Church, Jan Hus Memorial and more. I recommend taking the free Sandeman tour which leaves from here as well to learn of the history of what you're looking at as well as get a wonderful walk and story of the rest of Prague.
A must of the Prague visit. Heart of the town. Don´t miss the Astronomical Clock.Full or restaurant, galleries. Very touristic place. Hard to find a restaurant with normal prices there.

Easter Market is worth a visit.. Went for Easter and enjoyed the decorations and stalls. Got stuck in the mad rush to see the clock strike the hour. If you want to take photos and have this place to yourself, early morning is best. It would have been nice to stay and enjoy the square had we not been pestered by beggars who continually approached us asking for money.
Amazing. Make sure you see the clock on the hour. Also the free walking tour was very good.

A beautiful square. This is a lovely place to see, the Clock and people watch. You could sit there for hours in one of the cafes and watch the world go by. The buildings and the streets of the square are something to see.

Historically beautiful. Can't visit Prague without visiting the Old Town Square. A good place to people-watch. Fun to sample native food and to see crafts and souvenirs at the many booths. Surrounded by beautiful architecture.

Like the old market. Plenty of shops that offer meals and handcrafts, crowded at all time, but plenty of life. Close to the astronomic clock. The bars are too expensive and for tourists; look another one out of there, at the nearest streets, it will be better.

Fantastic, a must SEE!. The tower in the middle is great, and the views even better!
I recommend here to also sit, relax and have a drink.
It can be expensive in this area compared to other areas of prague, but it is worth the money in my opinion.
Thumbs up. There was a little Easter market going on with stalls and food. Also a bandstand with local schools singing and playing instruments - truly worth a visit
old town square. people from all over the world come here and still the place is well kept and very clean
Old town Square. Very busy! Try the underground tour - it's really interesting.
Easter market was a pleasant surprise. The square was full of stands selling all sorts of delicious candy and food and off course beer and hot wine. Some nice live music as well.

Worth visit. Old Town Square is a central atraction in Prague, with the crowded square, the interesting clock with the statues getting out each hour, great architecture (which is well preserved) and lots of pubs, souvenier shops and small restaurants all over the tight streets aruond the Center.

Visiting the historical Place. It was my first time to Prague old town square and it was really a good place to go. In there, you will discover not only the old historical buildings but also the place. It is still preserved for us to see it. It's churches (gothic church) are very beautiful and the people are friendly too. I went to the ghost and underground walk tour... it was spooky and yet experienced it. Furthermore, there's this astronomical clock tower which was very awesome. I recommend for those who really like sightseeing..... this is the perfect place.
Lovely Historical Part of the City. A must see to walk around and experience the atmosphere, see the market stalls and taste the cuisine

Tourist honeypot. Understandable that half of Prague's visitors seemed to converge on this architectural centrepiece. A quite stunning setting. But the stalls and tourist 'attractions' are in danger of overwhelming the views and the atmosphere. A must-see, though.
Great place to see in Prague. The square is lively and full of atmosphere. The Clock is beautiful and has great history. It should be admired!

Food Market Stalls = Rip Off Merchants. I would firstly like to state that I had a superb time in Prague, and would highly recommend it to anyone...this is simply a word of warning. Nearly all the food on offer is advertised as a certain price PER 100g...for example the lovely smoked ham that is so temptingly on offer was 89 Koruna (£2.50)...however the sellers will simply serve up whatever portion they feel like (the more gulliable you look the larger it will be) and expect you to pay for it...they tried to serve us over 600g and charge us something close to £15!! This is the case with a lot of the food there, I saw a family of 3 get charged over £25 for some potato and cheese when they originally thought they'd be paying something like £4/5...very very overpriced and diliberately set up to decieve.Eat elsewhere...and just sit in the square and enjoy the ambience...

Nice place to visit.. I was there that it was spring. I loved this square. It has two of the most popular attractions of the city, the St. Mary of Tyn Church and the Astronomical Clock.I suggest to visit this square at early morning or in the evening, when it's less crowded. In the late afternoon it's nice to go to see the sunset from the top of the Clock Tower, where you cans ee the city glowing in a nice orange shade. I suggest it.
Buzzing. Walk around and see if you can be in time for the clock chimes. Else atleast see it once.
When it's dark...it's dark. Great in the day. At night, full of drunks and touts - the latter of which ask if you're interested in weed, sex or "private banana party". Nope, no idea what that is.

Lovely Easter markets. Went through here several times. Lovely bustling Easter markets with great (non-fried) donuts and chunks of Prague ham and beer which were to delicious. Our guide was horrifed by the prices, but seemed ok to us. Weather was perfect so outdoor cafes buzzing, although they had blankets on the chairs in case you got chilly.

Favorite place to hang out. No better place to watch people (or be watched), drink the excellent beer (used to be cheaper than the bottled water), eat (a little overpriced) and marvel at how many tourists visit this city. For a more authentic experience, head down some of the side streets. I enjoy getting lost in this city!

The astronomical clock is worth seeing...that is about it.. The astronomical clock is worth seeing. Get there a few minutes before the clock does it thing, watch it and move on.Other than that a few of the building are nice. The food in the square looks pretty nasty...lots of flies, hornets and bugs on it and it seemed really expensive for what it was.Wasn't really impressed...
One of the nicest squares in Europe. The old town square is undoubtedly one of the nicest squares in Europe, if not the nicest. Full of character and a wonderful place to spend a day.

Still dont get it. Clock, nice.
Buildings, nice.
Crowds, beggars, pick pockets, non stop thumping music, touts, vendors, tour operators with hordes of passengers behind them....at night you can have hookers and glue sniffing kids begging too.....NOT so nice.
Thats what should be in the brochure !

Beautiful in December. I went this past December, i have to say that it is very beautiful with all the Christmas markets and the lights, the tree in the square is amazing as well as the clock which was absolutely beautiful.

A bit tacky. Yes, the architecture and the cobbled streets are nice, but this is tourism gone mad. Very crowded most times of the day and far too many tacky souvenir shops selling absolute garbage!
The astronomical clock is worth seeing though. Get there just before the hour to see it do its thing. Then move on.

Street food was good but beware they charge by pound.. When buying the spit roasted Ham which is very good they charge you by the pound. So tell them two slices or point to how much you want to spend ie: 200 Czech crowns which at time was 10$ worth of meat.

Pulls magnet!;). A good place, it is interesting here, a lot of people here the spirit of history and culture of the Czech Republic, then perhaps it is difficult to be tired, have fun! Restaurants, cafes and shops there is sufficient, although toilets and 10kr. But the noisy, I do not even know how to endure the locals?))
Great architecture - but selling out?. Liked buildings and history, disliked the way they've rammed in stalls selling tourist junk, and fast food.

Amazing Place. We visited Old Town several times during our trip to Prague. You shouldn't miss it, including the McGee Tours, the Astronomical Clock, the local chocolate shops (including the chocolate history museum with the candy makers in the window); try the Tredlnik cinnamon crackers or kabobs at the vendor stands and take in views of centuries of architecture.

Old Town Square / Astronomers clock. Well worth the look, we were lucky to be there during easter markets as well which also added to the feel. The Astronomers clock is something you see and 'tick' off the list. We had a guide who explained its operation in detail, it's great to see and is a marvel for its age, but you see it (at the top of each hour it 'performs' - but you need to be in the square 10 minutes early to get a vantage point - best if you are 'square on') and you move on. I was pleasantly suprised by how clean and safe the streets are. We started our trip in Paris and for all its beauty the streets are well, filthy - more so around the tourist attractions. Prague is truly beautiful, a large, but subtle police presence, the place just rocks. # days in Prague is plenty to see what you need to and appreciate just how magnificent the city is !!

Nice area. The place was full of vendors, great place just to people watch. Though we walked past it several time, we never stopped to enjoy the area. I guess it was so crowded with vendors and people you cant fully enjoy the surroundings.
Buzzing. Lively, buzzing square but beware Prague ham sellers - charged us £14 for a chunk of ham off the bone and the chap behind £17! Tourists beware!
Worth to see!. Nice place just to watch the life around you. It is definitely a place worth seeing!
Delicious. very delicious food and lot's of market stalls offering wide range of souviniers and food.
Heart of Prague. Most excellent attraction in Prague. The town square is a magnificent and exciting place, and a very good memory of Prague. A must see.

Must see in Prague. One of the best locations in Prague. Every building around this square comes from a different century and will tell you an amazing story. Lots of local stands with traditional products, but some of them slightly overpriced.

Absolutely charming. This is a must see. The little cobblestone streets lined with shops are just so full of charm. You can find just about anything, including any kind of Czech crystal. We were there during Easter when there were street vendors in the square for three weeks, which made for a very festive atmosphere.
Easter Market. Fantastic market stalls over the Easter weekend. Buzzing hub of activity surrounded by restaurants bars and coffee shops.
Beautiful place to visit. Beautiful, well take care, police always around to look after visitor
Worth Seeing!. Very busy where you can experience the flavours of praque. Worth experiencing!

Fantastic atmosphere. the astronomical clock - a real sight to amuse, the food stalls selling dough spirals baked over hot coals and rolled in sugar, honey and almonds, the charcoal griled sausages and hog roasts, just beautiful everywhere you look you see the most amazing buildings
Gathering Place. It was a great place to people watch and sort of the hub of all the tourist activity. they also had food stalls with excellent dishes for a meal or a snack.
Gorgeous. nice to walk around. Beautiful town square! Would recommend Hotel U Prince for a few cocktails overlooking the square!

2 days in Prague. Fantastic atmosphere and beautiful buildings!
Good food and prices

Simply charming. I read about all of the pick pockets so I was a little nervous but prepared for our trip. We did not come across anyone that had any problems during their stay. Very charming place with many English and German speakers willing to offer assistance. We went during Easter which is one of the busiest times of year but I would go again at that time.

Fun to walk around. It's pretty crowded, especially around the astronomical clock, but we were lucky to be there during a spring festival. And so the square was filled with vendors selling food, jewelry, etc. One of the churches that soars above this square looks like something out of a Disney movie. The square is a not-to-be-missed site in Prague.Take note: If you eat or have coffee at one of the restaurants surrounding the square, just know that you will pay prices that are a lot higher than anywhere else. But the location is great, so don't sweat it.

Enchanting at Easter. This square was just beautiful at Easter. There was loads of stalls as part of an Easter market. These sold lovely Easter crafts and souvenirs, expensive enough though. The food stalls were good value though and there was a stage with entertainment going on all day. A very central location and a nice spot

Disappointment. I really do not understand the hype of the astronomical clock. Sure there's a history to it but for a disappointing 1 minute of trumpets and ting ting you better can visit the streets behind the square.

Don't miss this experience. This is a most fabulous place to have a brilliant atmosphere, its also steeped in the most fascinating history, as well as modern day bits and bobs, just be warned prices will be high in this area.
Easter Markets. The Old Town Square was great at Easter with craft stalls, food stalls and a stage for traditional dancing.

Christmas square. I have been in Prague twice during the Xmas time. There is a very good Xmas market on the square. You can stroll between the food stalls and taste roasted pork or sausages, take a mug warm wine or punch. If you refer sweets take a ginger biscuit or warm doughnat. There are also market stalls, where you could find unique souveniers to take home.The best place to review the square is the tower of the Old City Hall. You can take a lift up, if you are afraid of climbing. Then you are up, you can see the hole city at the angle of 360 degrees. I would say:"Marvellous"

Great town square, just avoid paying for beer there!. It's a lovely square with the famous Astronomical clock - and often a market of some such (Christmas, Easter...) on. Sometimes a little over packed as you might expect for such a landmark. The beer prices make you wince though - if you have to drink there, maybe best to go inside - it's cheaper then when sitting outside.
Bustling. Always plenty to see here during the day and at night; especially a great place for people watching.

Pretty, but expensive.... It's not bad, but nothing to get too excited about. Very pretty area, but lots of tourists (yes, including us). Everything was overpriced accordingly. The astronomical clock is kind of cool, but is just a clock. It doesn't do anything special. Nice buildings and people, but not the high point of our trip. You should definately walk through it but don't expect anything too spectacular. It's a typical European market square.
do not eat there. a lot of garden restaurants with basic and very expansive food and driks.
Enchanting. full of beauty and history, restaurants and churchs with concerts in the afternoon.
Yum!. Don't go past the street food. I ate 4 trdelnik a day. I still think about them. YUM!

Full of life. The Easter markets meant that this place had a real buzz to it but it was the wonderful smell of Trubnikl, sausages, and other foods that really made it. Lots of great handicrafts on sale and artisans to watch.
Good atmosphere,quite safe. Plenty of life even though street sellers were directed at tourists.
worth the time to visit. i find strolling round the square just absorbing the ambience<and beer> rewarding.but its for tourists really and priced accordingly
Market place. Do take a tour with a guide to explain the history. Worth a visit to see the clock and market stalls.

Old and new. Freat setting with old church and more recent typical houses. Try the pastry cakes that are cooked over coals - delicious. Great views from the top of the tower but the astonomical clock that rings on the hour is a big let down - a real tourist trap !!
Fun Easter Fair. Had a fabulous Easter Fair. Lots of fun and interesting stalls.
Wekend Fun. Make sure to visit the square on a weekend if you are there. Lots of street performers and food vendors.

Came back again and again. Was lucky to be here the week before Easter. The square was crammed with food booths and vendors and a stage. Maybe this is here all year round, I don't know.A castle soaring above the square is RIGHT out of Snow White (looks like an evil queen's castle)Just a good, energetic vibe here. Ignore the other tourists, if you can. This is a very busy plac, positively filled with huge groups of students.
Make the square a daily part of your stay in Prague. Live music, street food, historic buildings including the astrological clock, usually weddings going on. Can get very very busy.
old town. great place, but very busy with tourists and merchants.

Beautiful old town Prague on 5 hour airport stop over. What a beautiful part of the world and so was to get to. I had a five hour layover in Prague so I decided to go downtown. It was really easy. In terminal 2 arrivals area you can buy a one day pass for 110k and walk out the doors at exit E. Thr bus 119 takes you to its last stop (about 20 minutes from airport). Then you get on the metro for three stops and presto you are meters away from st Charles bridge. It is very much worth it to see old town Prague- it is one of the most beautiful squares in Europe. I'm so glad I saw a little bit of this beautiful city.

Became our headquarters!. Having rented an apartment around the corner,we spent considerable time in this beautiful square. We were fortunate to travel while the Easter Market was occuring (3/26-4/15), so were were able to enjoy all the food booths, and also numerous craft and gift vendors. When we arrived at first, these were not yet present, but the square was just as enchanting. The astronomical clock is stunning, and the crowds form on the hour to witness the apostles appear from the doors above, and hear the trumpeter from the tower. There are a number of cafes and restaurants around the perimeter, with prices inflated a bit, but still manageable.The Church of Our Lady of Tyn that really marks the square, is such a spectacular sight. It is just so storybook and charming, and is breathtaking by day, and magical in the night lighting. So much of Prague is accessible by foot, and we found this a perfect location to call home. So thankful we chose this area for our accomodations!

Madly busy but .... ... great to see all the amazing architecture and whiling the time away watching fellow travelers and locals going about their day. The whole of Prague is like something imagined in a fairy tale and the Old Town Square is no different.
A great place to use as a starting point to explore the city.. The clock is magnificent and the square is surrounded by beautiful buildings, cafes and restaurants
Thank you Prague. Full of tourists, very hard to move around but it was a wonderful atmosphere, everyone made you feel welcome. Thank you Prague

Brilliant.. O.K. - it's very `touristy` now, and the prices in the restaurants can be a real rip-off compared to places nearby. However, it remains a fanstatic setting, and one of the few places where i'm happy to do nothing but just sit and take in the atmosphere.

Marvellous. When you stand in he Old Town Square it's like your transported back to another time and if you look around you can imagine how it must of looked back in the old days with horse and carts trundling around and merchant selling their goods and the remaining buildings all keep that feeling alive in how well they have been preserved.We were lucky to have arrived in Prague when the Easter Festival was setting up which was a nice addition to our stay as all of the stalls had hand painted Easter eggs,Willow Whips and other cool things like that for sale.One that that I would suggest for anyone visiting Prague to do is to have dinner or even just some drinks at one of the resturants in the Old Town Square that has an ourdoor terrace/garden so that you can relax and enjoy the view/atmostphere.
Beautiful and Fun. Don't miss Europe's finest town square. It is 360 degrees of delight.
Street Food Good but expensive. The square is fun but unfortunately very touristy!
Great!. We stay in the middle of the old town. The narrow streets are filled top with souvenirshops and great boutiques.
pleasant. lovely during the day.. it wasnt too busy when we went in march. clean. some nice cafe/resturants in the square. good serviceon an evening lovely to look at all the building lit up

Photographers, set your gear ready!!. This is a place where photographers will want to be!!my myself I really enjoyed the view, the old clock, the statues, the people faces, and above all, the awesome architecture.Going in a walk from the side of the "Republiky" Metro station, to the clock tower, and down to the synagogue, will cover the whole area in a simple way... after the walk, a meal in the restaurants scattered around the square will be very convenient, and will make you ready to walk down the allies and the roads to Charles Bridge...all in all, it is the second most Beautiful place in Prague!!

step into history. The square is the main point of reference in Prague, it has the historic beauty, the lively ambiance and the convenience of a place which is accessible top locals and tourists alike. As for every tourists rich place, beware of pickpockets experts; they love busy scenes so they can act without being noticed! But that aside, the square is a place we really loved going to and did so twice! The astronomical clock is a wonder and apparently it is one of the only 3 clocks which still works in the world! Every hour, the clock comes alive by pointing out the time and then a gentleman in costumes plays the trumpet from the top of the tower to announce the hour as well. The medieval feel is still there for sure!

just awesome. just pure greatness...romantic,architectural work, lights....i was gone from all the staff you can see on one square..just perfect and as i was told very rare to see without tons of tourists..i think i was lucky :D..
Yeeeeah!. The best site ever! Be there on holidays! holidays fairs are just awesome :)
Really Fun. Find the Beer crawl tours. Totally worth it. The best beer is called Old Gott. Bring me one if you can
Be careful of pickpockets.. Pickpockets are rife be careful. We were robbed and my husband didn't realise until we needed to pay for something. Crowds are huge so makes for easy pickings!
Beautiful place. A lovely square surrounded by different architecture. Plenty of restaurants and street food sellers. Don't miss the hourly show at the Astronomical clock
Great blend of new and old!. A vibrant area of Prague during both day and night with architectural masterpieces alongside modern shopping centres.

Beautiful Place. See the fairytale church, watch the clock strike (watch out for the trumpet player in the tower), eat a crepe, sit and listen to a jazz band, have a coffee in a cafe or just soak up the atmosphere! Must visit at night!
Magical. Just stand in the middle and rotate 360 degrees, then do the same thing at night. it's magical both times. Great place to people watch.

Old Town Square, Prague. We took the Metro to the Staromestske stop and walked over to the Old Town Square in 5 minutes. This area is so interesting that we spent several days there over the time we were in the Prague area. There is so much to see beyond the Old Clock, which was suprisingly interesting, so we returned to the square at least 5 times. The building facades are so marvelous and the other facilities (restaurants, shops, etc) are worth at least a day of strolling around and around. We recommend this site to anyone who knows a bit about the history of Prague and it's people.

Fairy tale. This aprt of the city was the most beloved for me. The square, the buildings, the lights in the evenings, the towers, the restaurants outside with terrace. Perfect place for a romantic walk.

Eating paradise. A lot to eat along the way and very nice to just walk around the area. Souvenir shops aplenty and a lot of Czech crystals on sale here.Walking distance to many attractions like museums and opera house etc
best area of prague. like the street food and entertainment, muscians etc ,, lovelly atmosphere
better bring your camera!. during the day it is filled with people and fun city noise, at night it is just as lively with still much to see, eat and drink.
Good for people watching. As with most town squares these are great places for people watching, from one of the many cafes and restaurants
Beautiful. Lovely to sit and have a drink and just experience.

Happening Place,..... It's great.... We loved it . The main Town Square is always busy, beautiful building ,busy cafes all around, lot of tourists to admire the lovely Square.... The view from the Clock tower ij just Awesome... A Must- Do....

Just incredible architecture all around. Try seeing it at night too...very special as the buildings are lit up. Just incredible architecture all around. Try seeing it at night too...very special as the buildings are lit upPeople & cafes & shops & cobble stone strees and an amazing feeling just being there. Wear sensible footwear as you will be walking quite a bit and on cobbled streets, which are not compatible with high and narrow heels. So much to see, so many side streets to explore. Try the Maitrea restaurant for a nice vegetarian meal (just behind the cathedral). Walk from the square to Charles bridge. Lots of cheesy souvenir shops to buy junk from if you are so inclined. Some jewellery shops too, a bit more expensive than those away from the tourist area, but they seem to be offering genuine stuff. Garnet is very popular. Czech crystal is also well known, and many shops offer a splendid variety...

Stunning. A must see part of any prague visit - the hustle and bust of the square, the astronomical clock and church look stunning at night, but also the "normal" buildings. Cast your eyes above the ground level bars and eateries and you'll wonder how they've managed to retain such beauty.
Very central and well maintained. Really nice square close to the Jilska apartment where we were staying. Lots of restaurants and a biig ornate clock that had a show each hour

Astronomical clock. Very famous place in Prague with medieval astronomical clock which each hour make small performance. Old town square is known also for tower of Old Town City Hall with obeservation deck and two spires of Tyn Church.
Nice square. Nice square but nothing special to do here. Just look at buildings.

One of the best squares in all of Europe. Outside of Grand Place in Brussels, Prague Old Town Square is the best maintained area in all of Europe. I loved walking around and just seeing everything. Go without a time table, and you will enjoy it more.
beauty. history, the historical center of Prague, many streets, pubs, restaurants, walk, what is shoot
to stay for lunch or drink. to try check specialities from the open grill on the square
amazing historic place. Popular historic place with astronomical clock and tower with view over the Prague

Charming. We visited the old town square on every day of our trip and got excited every time. It has such a charming appeal to it; the old buildings surrounding the square, the great clock tower on one side, overlooking the stunning cathedral on the other, with small stands selling local appetizers and horse-drawn carriages walking around. This must be one of the most beautiful places in Prague. I felt in a Disney story :)
Great food and souvenirs. Have a look at the small booths around the Old Town Square. Bought great food, and also great souvenirs, like glass and mirror with names engraved (engravement for free!)
a must visit place. Brilliantly wonderful attraction. Full of local souvenir shops and historic sites.

Great place to wal around, eat around or grab a quick saisage. In the middle of the squire there are vendors and you can get fresh ham and sausage that is to die for. I no longer eat meat in the US ( hormones, cruel farming) but I could not resist it in Prague. YUMM. My dad had a HUGE chunk of Ham as well. All this with fresh bread and mustard, There are other vendors selling pastry etc.

Not much going on but worth a visit. There were a few market stalls, with some tradiational Czech cuisine, however the people working on these were not the most accomodating or friendly and the food was very average. The place is very central and the Astronomical clock is worth a visit too.

Wonderful sightseeing, but very touristy. Try coming in the early morning (before 9am) or late evening (after 9pm, later in the summer). Then you'll really get to see the beauty of the square, the buildings and their architecture, the details in the stonework, etc., without all the crowds blocking your view.

Great square – avoid the vendors. This is a lovely place and is where you will find the fantastic astronomical clock, a must see, there is also the tower which you can climb to the top of and there is the beautiful Tyn church. This is a very busy and popular area so be aware that anything you buy in the square will be very expensive, that includes the restaraunts, I would take a short walk down one of the sidestreets and the prices will be a lot more reasonable.You also need to visit at night the Tyn church is all lit up and looks amazing.

Perhaps the most beautiful square in Europe. Of course I'm quite biased since I live here. In Old Town Square you will find: St. Nicholas Church - a fine example of baroque, Church of Our Lady of Tyn - a fine example of gothic where you will find the tomb of Tycho Brahe, Monument to Jan Huss, and the Old City Hall which contains the Astronomical Clock Tower. Old Town Square is particularly festive during Advent (Christmas Market) and the few weeks before Easter (Easter Market).

Awesome Food, Awesome Price!. Great food and service, the Czech food was prepared very nice. They serve Fresh Roasted duck which is ready around 1PM that is..... Yes Awesome! Super price! This is what Prague is about, and they give this country a good name!

Start in the square and explore. The square is fantastic, but really is just a starting point to explore all of Old Town Prague. You can easily cover everything you need and want to see by walking - a day will hit the highlights, but several days will let you really explore the area and the culture.

have to visit in Prague. very nice place for tourists but it`s a pity that locals are not there and the shops and restaurants are tourist-oriented.. but the Old City Hall with "Big Clock" is wonderfu!
Beautiful both day and night. There are lots of beautiful buildings here which are also lit up at night. The astronomical clock is great fun to watch and always draws crowds.
Czech history in a nutshell. Combination of historical influences and Czech pride
You are here!. You can't be in Prague and not be at teh Old Town Square! this is trully the heart of teh city. Favourite meeeting place for tourists and locals alike.

Beware of the food vendors. The square is nice enough and gothic and charming. Lots of tours and on a good weather day, it is a must if you happen to be in Prague. Beware the small food vendors who are out to fleece you. The vendor who sells old Prague ham bullied me into paying 510 crowns for a cut of ham, a piece of bread and a bowl of cabage

photographic delight. Lovely square lots to see. Didnt do the tower. The astronomical clock is interesting and just sitting drinking in the atmosphere. But in summer must be a nightmare. Just off the main part where restaurants are is a little deli the food good and prices amazing.

Beautiful square, watch for pickpockets. One of the best from Prague.Square is beautiful, but very crowded.So be careful for pickpockets.Restaurants on the square are nice, but overpriced, sometimes a lot.Better go somewhere else.

Nice to see but beware where to sit for drink. Nice to see but be careful if you see street bar with sign that glass of grog costs 40 KCS and there is a tent nearby, because this bar has nothing to do with tent which is part of the hotel bar and glass of grog in this hotel costs around 80 KCS
Bustling. A hive of activity with a lot to see and do. Can get very crowded in peak times but really worth visiting especially to look at the gothic towers. Plenty of places to eat and drink.

Astronomical clock. This is amazing..every hour it opens and the 12 apostols appear and a guy plays from the top of the tower. at night is beautifully illuminated and all around there are places where you can drink something hot and buy souvenirs. It's also nice to se the others buildings where we found dalì and Mucha's expositions.

Beauitful square. Definetly a highlight of Prague. What a beauitful city, especially when the weather is good, which it invariably is in spring/summer. Some great restaurants & bars, with resonable prices. We found a fab' pizza place not far off the square itself
Do not miss. The central spot for all of your Prague site seeing

Must See. A real site to see & a must for anybody visiting. Try & see a night also as its even prettier. Full of so many tourists on the hour to see the clock, get there before lunchtime or early evening to avoid the huge crowds.

A real must!. We had our hotel near to this square. I guess this is the centre of Prague. Big square with many bars and restaurants and shops. But also many sites like the astronomical clock and its tower. Going up in the tower you have a great view over the square and prague. A must! There are also other sites like Týn church and Ungelt, St. Nicolas church and some galleries. Great place to spend a few hours.

love it. love Prague! very fairytale... great architecture, loved the buildings! Did a moonlit cruise around city of Prague. Had dinner on board, live jazz band, was fab to see the city of Prague lit up at night!

Spacious and full of lovely buildings. Besides the astronomical clock and its history, the Square is spacious, full of history and lovely buildings. Quite a lot of shops, restaurants etc for tourists but not overpowering. One can imagine it will be packed during the high seasons. Again, better signage would not go amiss.

Has to be seen. It is impossible to come to Prague without seeing this square,in my opinion eben more amazing at night,most of the tourists are gone be then and the atmosphere is amazing.After all the years of living here,I never get bored of the Old Town at night

Enjoy...but do not change money anywhere but a bank.. This square is a "must visit" in Prague.But, my wife was "exploited" by what appears to be very legit money exchange office in the square.They have a very clever (and legal) scam going on generally on money exchange in Prague and you will get ZERO help from the authorities if you fall victim. The scam works like this: You open a brightly lit legit looking "bureau de change"-like shop front. Then you exploit the behaviors the tourists expect to encounter at such offices. You offer TWO different rates of exchange for each currency. One is a very normal looking rate, and the other one is about HALF the normal exchange rate. If the customer wants to exchange an amount less than say US$500 you apply the low rate. The customer only discovers the low rate has been applied once the Czech money is handed over and appears to be way less than expected.Thus, people exchanging say US$100, US$50 etc can end up giving half of the their money away, instead of the usual expected 2~5% or commission rate.It's very clever and very exploitative of international travelers' expectations. THERE IS NO CHANCE OF GETTING YOUR MONEY BACK.Shame on the Czech tourist authority for allowing this to continue.Again, DO NOT trust the money exchange bureaus. Go to a bank.

The Old Town Square is buzzing and full of atmosphere. There are so many places to eat and drink that it's hard to recommend.The clock is unique but whilst everyone is looking up I'm sure the pickpockets have a field day!
so much history and charme in one place. also watch out for the free tour guides who start their tours from that square. a goood place from which to begin your sigtsing around.

take a walk in the history. if u want to feel the old prague u should of course have to visit here.it has a unique astronomical clock that is really interesting to see how it works.and there are always nice exhibitions the buildings sorrounding the square.taking a walk through the streets is a real joy.and an advice if u have the chance visit it 5 am it is gorgeus to see sunrise:)have a great time:)
Nice. A lot of tourists, of coures, but a must to visit!
Don't miss the Astronomical Clock in the Town Square!. Fascinating history and beautifully kept site. The old Town Square is a lively meeting place and the clock is its centerpiece.
Magical. The square was busy, very cold, you need to ensure you know the name of the guide company as there were lots of organised groups, can be confusing.

I came to a complete stop .... ... the architecture is deeply concentrated and harmonious. Nothing jars. History oozes from it, epitomised by the statue of Master Jan Huss and his pivotal role. The local flavour is captured by the wood-smoked pork kiosks. The Astronomical clock is truly unique. The kitch souvenir shops somehow recede into the background. And a plethora of interesting views and experiences await one in the squiggly nearby streets.
Charming. Beautiful spot. If you walk 2 blocks away, you'll find restaurants with half price.
Definitely worth a visit.. You can see why it's such a popular tourist attraction. Do your research before you visit so you can appreciate the background.
Fabulous buildings. Signposting could be better though. Clock was a wee bit disappointing - glad we sat in a cafe to watch it as it was a cold day.
Stunning - Going Back in Time!. The buildings are stunning - like going back in time
Lively hubbub. Fascinating variety of things going on all around you

Fantastic buildings........ We stayed about 2mins from the square. lots to see, even more to do. You must visit the stalls which sell traditional chicken skewers which taste fabulous. At 100 koruna each they're well worth it!!
Only a stones throw from Cartier and dior!!!
Fascinating. Loved the buildings. The architecture was so interesting. Great being pedestrian only.
Old town. Really lovely area and wished we had been staying in the old town much more interesting than were we stayed. Would like to visit again in the summer
Lovely place to visit. Lots go on around this old square make sure and visit the dubliner bar great food great craic.

Picturesque. It is worth visiting here at night and going up the Astronomical clock. Great view of the city and is absolutely stunning. I think it was something like 35 crowns to go up - worth it just to have a view and get some photos. There are lots of bars to go to in this area as well.
beautiful!. Clock well worth watching in action, whole square lined with beautiful buildings and sometimes a market there

grab yourself a tour. There are many tour operators offering tours of prague centre. We found one that is free and excellent. The way it works is if you enjoy the tour and only if you want to, you give them a tip. You can see the company and its reviews, on tripadvisor. The link to their site is: http://www.extravaganzafreetour.com
A MUST!!!. you havent been to prague after you visit old town square!!!

A must visit for anyone visiting Prague. Fortunately our hotel was only a few mins from Old Town Square but we found ourselves visiting the square and associated attractions or passing through the square in some shape or for each day. Great photo opportunities in and around the square.
Magical. My second trip to Prague and the magic of the Old Town Square does'nt leave you...Just a beautiful place to visit and watch the world go by.
Great Day or Night. Every hour peple gather to watch the clock strike. Great to experience
The top of visiting old Prague. dominant of the sqaure is awesome Orloj (clock with performance of historic myth and religious statue characters)
a must see!!!. we really enjoyed this spot and well certainly come back back for the christmas market.

Beautiful. Old town square was beautiful. The clock was a little disappointing as I was expecting more but sunday at noon the entire square was chiming. It was beautiful. FREEZING IN FEBRUARY. GO IN SUMMER
Obviously!. You won't/can't miss this if you are in prague, just hang out & enjoy.
The Clock Tower at full hour. Throngs of people despite the negative temperatures. Well, this is a must, like it or not!

Avoid the surrounding bistrots and terrasses. There's nothing to add to the descriptions of this pittoresque place and I totally agree that everybody should visit it at once during the day and also at night. Just wanted to drop a warning that you should best avoid the coffee houses around that spot as it might happen that they charge you prices that are as astronomical as the clock on the square. Ok, common sense that prices are always a bit higher on such spots, but we had to pay 12 EUROS per cup of coffee (!) in one of these establissements on the square. As we complained that this must be a mistake, the manger came (looked rather like a hardcore bouncer) and made firmly clear that each of us had drank a cup and thus had to pay 12 Euro. Not much chance to object when you have such a person in front of you. So this was one misfortune, I don't want to generalise it - be carefull and ask the price beforehand.Else: don't forget to visit the little bookshop on the square that used to belong to the Kafka family. It's a decentbookshop and not at all the tourist trap one does expect.
Fairytale @ Christmas Time. The CHristmas markets were magical, the atmosphere with the decorations, carols, shows was so theatrical in will stay imprinted in my mind forever.

Beautiful. Touristic area, beautiful place for an afternoon walk, some sights are in the area (astronomical clock, Gothic church you can see from any point of the square). Also some good - average /higher priced restaurants can be found in the area.

Tyn Church and The Clock. Very Disneyesque at first glance, was a bit cold to stand around and wait to look at the clock, but interesting to see it chime at 11, I would not recommend doing this at 1 or 2 pm though, as you wait for little then.
Fantastic Architecture. Unique Horlolage, beautiful Týnský Church - go to the square after dark, the spires of the Church are fairy tale like. So much history...

Worth a visit. The square can get busy, even in weather of -13 to -20 C. There are people offering tours (some for free) in many different languages. In February there are no markets or events taking place in the actual square.
It is a good place for a passing visit
popular. this is a popular place to go, but there are a lot of tour rep's trying to get you to sign up for their tours
Cool site, nice atmosphere. Atmosphere in summer was very nice there! Nice buildings around the square!
A MUST SEE. No visit to Prague would be complete without a visit to this Square. Get there on the hour to see the clock (won't spoil it by telling you what happens !!)
Typical Prague. Your crossroad to discovering old part of Prague...
Pretty cool. Great buildings and cobblestone. Rather small square but great sites if you like historical items.
Old World Charm. Lovely place to visit. So many beautiful buildings and quirky side streets. Stunning.

Lovely cobbled square. Make sure you catch the projection night show on the astronomical clock. Views from the clock tower highly recommended and find the ghost walk tour - makes for a fun evening walk !

Like a Fairytale. We visited the Old Town Square of Prague during the Christmas season. The Old town hall with it's famous astronomical clock, the eerily gothic Church of Tyne and all the magnificently coloured and decorated buildings surrounding the square add to it's beauty
Brilliant, the best square in Prague.. The Astronomical Clock chiming at mid-day with the apostles appearing and a trumpeter playing to all four corners is a special moment.
Take a good camera. Really beautiful and historic, go back at night time and dont forget to see the astronomical clock

Beautiful Square. One of the most beautiful Squares I ever seen! There are so many beautiful old and well preserved buildings on this square. There are two beautiful churches too. I should see the square at day light and at evening to enjoy the most of it!
Not great views. Liked the food at cafe italia, disliked rude service in other restaurants and service providers. Nice to see the astronomic clock.

Must see but be careful.. It is the place a lot of history has happened, but full of tourist traps.
Don't eat on the square, head off it and find something on one of the back streets.
Very pretty at night though and be careful of pick pockets

A bit disappointing. This a a big open space with a statue in the middle and some lovely buildings all around it but we weren't very sure what each one of them was and we couldn't find the astronomical clock which we thought was in the square. Perhaps we should have done a bit more research before going.

A Must See!. If you are going to Prague, you must go to the old town square, its such a beautiful place to enjoy. We had lunch a couple of days around this area and watched the world go by, beautiful. We were fortunate to visit in September when it was still very warm but cold in the evenings but some restaurants have outside heaters and blankets which is s lovely touch.
Stunning!. Of all the Citys I've visited Prague is by far and none my favourite, and Old Town Square is just stunning!
Great square. Great - really enjoyed the square with hot wine andhearing the clock chime. Lots of people though will approach you to go into bars and things

Average. The Astronomical Clock is worth seeing. It comes to life on the hour, every hour. Once you have seen it though, the excitement is gone. The Tower is worth going up for a visit. There are great views of the Old Town. If you have an hour to spare, then a visit to the undergrounds (under the tower via the Tourist Info) but don't be expecting too much. It is a bit overrated im my opinion.
Tower on City hall. Beautiful tower on Old town Square City Hall with views all around Prague
ATreat. A must visit, plenty do in this area, pub,s restaurants, old churches, the clock and the market was great, nothing to dislike
Such atmosphere. Lovely landmark espaecially during Christmas when the markets are running

charming and crowded. we kept returning to the square and from then we just wandered around, enjoying the old-world charm. It was very busy in spite of the cold weather, though most tourists spoke a slavic language.

Christmas Market Fun. We went here in Dec. 2011 during the Christmas market and had a blast. The whole square is great to look at and has tons of history. This is definitely a "must" if you are in Prague.
Well restaurated buildings, expenisive area. The old town square is worth a visit, nice buildings, but the area is overpriced.
The Tourist Attraction of the city. Beautiful, medieval, full of history and places to eat or just admire the view.
Great historic sights. So much to see in this square. It's lovely at night and the atmosphere is great.

This would be ''the heart of Prague''. Be aware of... Old Town Square (Starometska Namesti) is located few minutes from either Staromestka or Mustek metro stations.There are a few signs to signal that.When I saw the square, this January, the Christmas Market stalls were still there, but closed.Walking around the square will reveal the Astronomical clock, the Old Town Tower (Starometska Radnice) and the Church of Our Lady before Tyn (Tinsky Chram) along with other beautifully-preserved buildings.What I powerfully disliked about the square is that the place is surrounded by overpriced restaurants, souvenir shops and scam money exchange offices.There are also very few places to sit, which is unpleasant after so much walking around the city!!!The area is wheelchair accessible.
Xmas. You have to love the old square at Christmas. Wonderful market selling crafts, hot cherry brandy and delicious roast ham
Any picture is great at this place!. I loved the principal church and the astronomic clock where each hour you can hear the trumpets.

Living History. Everything we saw and wherever we went, I was in disbelief that such beauty and wonder is available free for the traveller. The Czech Republic is really working hard to provide such treasures. Again, the people are proud of their city and heritage.
Wonderful atmosphere. Just a wonderful place to visit. Lots of lovely buildings and great atmosphere
Old town Square. Fun place, lots of people watching and great hand food.

Don't miss it when you are visiting Prague!. This is one of those 'not to be missed places' in Prague. Beautiful architecture, nice views, good food, helpful people, in fact, there is so much to explore that putting all this into words is actually impossible. This place is for all.. family, children, couples, friends and you name it!!

Beautiful and fun, but be prepared for crowds. We visited Prague in December 2011, so Old Town Square's Christmas market was in full swing. The lights were beautiful, and the crowds were amazing. The bars/restaurants lining the square are fun, as long as you're prepared for high prices, mediocre food, and mostly mediocre service. You're paying to sit in comfort on Old Town Square, and I think it's worth it. Old Town Square is always worth a stroll through, or even a much longer stay. The views from the terrace restaurant of U Prince hotel and from Old Town Hall Tower (the building with the astronomical clock) are spectacular.

Awesome place full of tourists and energy. Old Town Square is my top favourite place in Prague. It is full of life, many restaurants, tourists passing by, energetic.. I never though how important this place will become for me, cos on that Square at one nice sunny Sunday day I met, during a Free Hugs, my first real love which whom I spent a beautiful time together. Really life changing place! :)
Club Heaven. This is where you will find most of the good clubs in Prague (or close) for younger people: M1, Siva, Harleys, James Dean, Zappa, One... and the list goes on
beautiful. lovely atmosphere, great people, good shopping and fantastic places to eat and drink
Christmas magic. We went between Christmas and New Year and the Christmas markets were still on - beautiful, traditional decor, pretty white lights, angels and nativity scenes - so magical
Another world... so well preserved!. Be sure to watch the astrological clock strike on the hour while enjoying a hot wine under a blanket at one of the many cafes in the wintertime!
Beautiful. We went to Old Town Square in December between Christmas and New Year it was amazing, lovely stalls selling Czech goodies music, band playing such a good atmosphere.

Picturesque. wasn't too sure what to expect out of the Xmas market however we weren't disappointed. Lots of stalls selling traditional food and live bands in the centre. The Xmas tree was very impressive and the back drop plus astronomical clock are unique!
amazing. very beautiful old houses and shops... oh and delicious chocolate
A must do at night. The lights make it very special.. ... and don't miss the clock chimes on each hour! This a great place at any time, just to feel the buzz of this great city.
loved the old feel. We loved this old square. After Berlin it was like stepping back in time. The city wasn't bombed during the war so there are a lot of old buildings
A must. we loved sitting in the street cafe drinking beautiful mulled wine watching the world go by. Visit during the day and on a night to get the most from this beautiful square.
Popular tourist and tour meeting place.. Beautiful architecture , many attractions, restaurants and souvenir shops.

Great place to shop and eat. So many little shops and restaurants - hard to choose, but we never found any losers. Our GPS got us lost with all the little one way streets and funny corners, but a good walking map saved the day

A very large open area. Surrounded by cafes, bars and restaurants, with "local fast food" stalls to eat on the move. Get there early for the Astronomical Clock which puts on a show, on the hour, expect big crowds.
Very atmospheric. The buildings, architecture, cafes and shops give so much character to the Square- Christmas time is magical and the hot wine a must!
Christmas Market. The Old Town Square was decorated beauifully, music filled the air, and the experience was fantastic!
Untouched. I felt as if I had been transported back several hundred year. Really beautiful. Try and avoid the glass walled cafes by the clock. £10 for 2 coffees!

Christmas Market. Great ambience with lots of arts & craft stalls, local food & beverage carts & a big Christmas tree lit up. Ideal for gift shopping.
Go early if travelling there on Christmas eve as nearly all of the shops, kiosks & stalls close early

Can't wait to come back !!!!!. This is truly one of the most picturesque places I have ever seen. We were there during the Christmas markets which gave an additional flavor to the atmosphere. So much to see and absorb. Take your time, enjoy the shops and architecture of the buildings and have a cup of tea, coffee or a beer from one of the many cafes.

A vast expanse of space in a Medieval City!. The Square was strangely empty with locals and tourists staying to the periphery during this very hot day but never the less a beautiful place to while away the time. Pricey on the square and we liked the side streets better for food and drink and interesting sites.
Amazing. It's worth to pay for excursion and learn about the place.

Lovely old city centre, very crowded with tourists. The old city centre is beautiful in the way that old city's across Europe (e.g. Tallinn) are beautiful. The most impressive part of the old town in Prague is the sheer size of it. The astronomical clock is impressive as a building, but may be equally interesting at off-peak (not near the hour) times. When the clock chimes (or at least at 3pm when we saw it), there wasn't much to see. Worth a walk through the old town, but it's very crowded with tourists and the restaurants/cafes looked very busy. I would probably be careful of your belongings and children in this area (crowded enough for easy thief and crowded enough to easily lose a child).

Great place for the Christmas Market. Very Touristy but still a great place to enjoy the Christmas Season. Check out Clock and just let yourself get lost and wander around. Great place to find anything from Food to Drink to great Shopping.
Classic. Beautiful architecture, but also filled with evidence of a logn and proud history in the arts, sciences, and engineering, such as the extraordinary astronomical clock
Highlight of our holiday. They had the market on that day and it was fantastic! I am already thinking of going back there next year!
A great setting anytime--wonderful at Christmas. The Christmas market and decorations are bright cherries on top of this sundae.
You have to see it to understand. Loved the clock. Make sure you get to the astronomical clock before the top of the hour to see the spectacular show. Plenty of cakes and things to see. God shopping
Amazing. Amazing being in the heart of the city. Enjoy the restaurants in the square, seat down, have a nice wine and talk with the locals. It's amazing.

Lovely place to be at Christmas. Lovely atmosphere. Plenty of stalls and markets but they do seem to sell the same things. Cafe's, restaurants and bars on the outside of the square and plenty of shops to keep you entertained.
Beautiful. An amazing square, surrounded by old charming buildings. Make sure to go up the old town hall to get the views. Amazing.

RIP OFF. On our first night in Prague we had gammon from the first stall as you enter the square from the direction of the Powder Tower. The hog is on a spit roast. To any of you who go to the xmas market in future be very wary. Rather stupidly I handed over the equivalent of £32-00 to the stall holder when asked.I went back and queried it and needless to say got nowhere. I threw the food back at the stallholder and told him he was having a laugh at £32 for two bits of gammon and 2 slices of bread. I saw many other tourists and locals being ripped off not only at this stall and the advice would be to double check the price before handing a note over to the stall holder which is what the czechs were doing. Not happy then don`t pay. I wish I had just had my wits about me more. My wife and I the went to the trip advisor restaurant off the square called U Mlejnice and had 4 beers, 3 wines, goulash, huge plate of ribs, chipas and veg and paid less ! Don`t be ripped off. I dare say this stall holder will have the same plot next year in the north east corner of the square. You have been warned!

a must see. was there for the xmas market and the colour of the lights and the stall holders made it for me. selling so much of jewelery that was hand made and locally made to food and candles that was all very cheap to buy. if u use euro 100 crowns works out at 4 euro. night time is ideal to go and you will go back again.

Easily the most beautiful square in Prague. Its well worth experiencing the majesty of the city's Old Town Square, with its brightly coloured baroque facades overshadowed & dominated by the vast Gothic twin towers of Tyn church. I would recommend reading up on the history of the square to really get the sense of how important it is to the people of Prague. A market place since the middle ages, it has many of Prague's most beautiful buildings.The 16th-century Prague Astronomical Clock on the Old Town Hall is brilliant. Each hour, from 9am-9pm, crowds gather to see the mechanical statues accompany the chimes, & it's from here that many of the city's walking tours start.

Staromestske namesti. I hardly think that the square itself is worth mentioning as an attraction. What I mean by that is if you are walking around Prague, as all tourists do, you will come across it whether you want to or not!! The astronomical clock is there, St. James Basilica, Old town hall, Church of our Lady Tyn, Dali exhibition, torture museum, statue of Jan Hus etc etc. You get the point. When we visited, there was a mini wine festival held there so we we tasted a few goodies... loved the chips!!
Perfect over Christmas. Perfect time to visit is just after Christmas, before new years. The area is quite quiet considering the time of year yet there are beautiful markets and lighting still up.

Don't miss the Christmas Market. Stands selling food (pork sausage and ham especially), christmas ornaments, and knit goods. Mulled wine (be careful, it'll catch up to you), and live entertainment. Sweet!
Great area. Great restaurants around. Atronomical Clock is a show on its own. The only thing is that you must avoid it if you are afraid of big crowds.

Pretty!. Not to be Missed! Extremely pretty square with amazing architecture and design on the old buildings. Nice cafe/restaurants to sit out and have a bite to eat and drink hot chocolate to keep warm... Especially nice in December when the Christmas markets are on... Recommended!

Climb the tower!. Christmas markets in Prague were good. Watch out because some of the stalls are a rip off in terms of pricing. This is also bag snatch heaven (as we found out). However, the lights are amazing and the atmosphere was great. The best thing was climbing the tower by the astronomical clock to get awesome views over-looking the square and surrounds. We did it at night. Postcard photo material.

Lively and traditional Christmas market. You can spend hours there alternating between looking at the various stands, eating and drinking. There are several performances during afternoons and evenings which add to the festive atmosphere. An experience in itself.

Christmas Markets. This really is the most beautiful spot for me. It's a must see in Prague. If you go during the Christmas season, you might get a chance to go to the Christmas markets and drink lots of hot wine!

Picturesque and interesting. The tower offers amazing views and is a must see? The crowds were heavy after about 10 am and just got busier. We went back at about 0730 another morning to get some better photos.
Fantastic Christmas illuminations. I hate Christmas and I'm an atheist and aparently most Czechs are agnostic but this place is amazing in late December. It almost changed my mind
Great Shopping. Great walk around for shopping and local restaurants. Also leave from here on many of the tours. Boats and horse/buggy tours will allow you to see the city sights while relaxing.
Xmas market. Was great at xmas and the start point for a 4 hour walking tour we took.

Old Town Square at Christmas. Visited over the Christmas holidays and had a great time. Strolled through the Christmas Market while sipping hot mulled wine and hot mead (honeywine). Checking out the clock is a must do. There are many local tours that originate here as well if you are looking for walking, bus, or horse carriage tours. Restaurants and shops here are plentiful although more expensive than in other parts of the city.
Clocks. Good Christmas Market, interesting mechanical clock. Good site for starting walking tours. Not too crowded in December.

Cannot miss it. Every old city has it's three top spots. This one, Old town square with Astronomical tower and panoramic view on Gothic church near by is top spot beside Charles bridge and Hradcany in fabulous Prague. Been in Prague already for a ten times, but never passed beside this square, never.

Super touristy but Christmas market is a lot of fun. The Christmas market was fun... the wares were not that unique but just the food was entertaining. Strudl (coils of flour, sugar, cinnamon on a roll baked over open fire), mulled wine, chestnuts and ridiculously large portions of ham. In the evening there was live music - I think that they have themes. One evening was all medieval music - this combined with the location (cobble stones underneath your feet and Gothic Spires in the background) was a wonderful experience.
The Astronomical Clock. just make sure you're there when the Astronomical Clock starts and finishes, because that is the most important part of this Old Town Sqaure

Old, busy and very touristic. The square with the perculiar looking clock, the restaurants surrounding the square and the food parlors in the square with pork and sausages are a great atmosphere creators and with the occasional live performance, it is definitely a place to visit.
Great for Christmas markets. This gets very busy because of how pretty it all is. Stones through away from the Jewish town, you have the old town hall and little markets throughout.

A great place to end up which you will do.. We were here between 14th and 18th December and there was so much happening. Great market stalls, great Christmas tree and some wonderful music from the concert marquee. Incredibly busy but I guess that is part of the fun. What is it like in summer?The tower is worth going up for a super view of the city although it gets pretty crammed at the top and there is not a one way system in place so you have people squeezing past etc. There is a lift so no need to worry if you have trouble with stairs.You must have a hot wine if you are there when it is cold and just take in the atmosphere.I recommend sitting in the cane chairs in the Hotel U Prince and just relax and watch everyone else bustle pass.Enjoy your trip.
Classic Prague. Great statues, churches, and people. I especially enjoyed the fairly large contingent of Czech Krishna devotees chanting and dancing near the old cathedral.

Best Christmas Tree. We visited several cities in Europe during our trip and Prague's Old Town Christmas Tree was by far the best we saw during our trip. Wonderful sight and the Christmas market was just wonderful. Loved it.

Hustle and bustle of Christmas markets. We had such a great time here for the Christmas Market, although the stalls were somewhat repetitive we spent along time here munching through much of the traditional Czech fare on offer and soaking up the atmosphere.
fantastic. very nice, as Prague as all, and in the Christmas time is better

Christmas Market. A great atmosphere in the old square with the Christmas Market on. Great food and some interesting stuff to see. Avoid the food sellers on the stalls which sell food by the 100g. They will load up your plate and charge you a fortune! When I told them it was too much they were pretty annoyed.

You'll never forget it!. The clock tower dominates but there are so many other wonderful features. Just sit back - enjoy a beer or a coffee and take it all in. It's superb and all kept so beautifully clean.

The Christmas market was wonderful!. I love gothic, medievil and just generally old buildings, churches and monuments. If you do too, then you'll love the Old Town in Prague. As you walk past the Astronomical Clock, look up at The Lady of our Tyn Church, all lit up at night, and sets the back drop for the Christmas market taking place in the Square. With brightly coloured market stalls, a majestic Christmas tree and choir singers the mood is truly festive.Cobbled streets aplenty, remember to look up or you might miss something, the little stall at the foot of the square, just before the clocl, sold the best hot chocolate with cream, mmm.

Beautiful and Romantic. We visited the old time square a few times during our stay because it's really beautiful and romantic. During this time of the year the old town square is beautifully decorated for Christmas and there are nice Christmas markets worth visiting.

Christmas market fun. I visited the square before Christmas and enjoyed greatly all the decorations and market fun. Food was pretty good even though it was (as expected) pricy. There were some choir shows and in general a fun atmosphere.The clock is as always a beautiful and disappointing point (if you were there you know what I mean, if you weren't you will have to go see and understand for yourself)

The best Christmas market. This is THE market to go to if you want to feel the Christmas atmosphere - live entertainment most evenings - food and hot drink stalls, fantastic architecture and very friendly people

Wonderful atmosphere. There is a free tour. YELLOW UMBRELLA. Close to the Astronomic Clock and the tours start just after the chimes at 1100 and 1400 BUT check in with the "Yellow Umbrella" people before the chime so they know how many to cater for! Wonderful tour guide. Very informative, knowledgable, enthuastic too. Kieth and if you have a choice, he`s the guy!! Dont do the Palace tour. Jeff, American. £10 and at the end of the tour we were left about a 20 min walk from where the tour started in the dark and the rain. Not good and there were a couple of young ladies in the group who were a little distressed so we took them back to where the tour started, which was quite a long way out of out way but as genrlemen............ Which is more than I can say about the tour guide!
Heart of the City. For the citizens of Prague - the most important place!Open air gallery : from gothic to rokoko!But lot of commercial activities today!

I was so lucky!. I arrived in the Old Town Square in the opening day of the Christmas Fair - it was so beautiful! People all aroung having hot wine, lights everywhere and the craft fair was a complete delight.
Just Beautiful. Get your camera ready. Particularly at night, we went in the summer time, I have never seen a city quite like it, was very surprised.
Wonderful old town square. Quite beautiful during Christmas time!. Bring your camera. Try to be at the big clock at noon!

Christmastastic!. Normally the old town square is empty but when we went it had the Christmas Market. This made the whole place atmospheric and we wandered around it a number of times over the weekend.

Christmas Markets!! Great fun!!. We have looked forward to coming to Prague for these markets for several years!! The atmosphere is very festive and the shopping is good! The authentic food and drink choices are excellent!!

Don't Miss It!. The Astronomical Clock draws visitors to the Old Town Square, but that's not the only site to see. Be sure to take in the sweeping square with its monument to Jan Van Huss and the Velvet Revolution, as well as the Church of Our Lady of Tyn and the 'other' St Nicholas Church. There is also an abundance of shopping, theaters, museums and restaurants.Visit the Astronomical Clock at the top of the hour to see the clock come alive, then pay for a ticket to the top and take in the sweeping views of Prague and the Old Town Square. There is an elevator in the clock tower, so this one is best for elderly tourists or those with limited ability to climb stairs. Go on a sunny day to get the best photos of Prague from the top. While you're there, be sure to take in the beautiful Town Hall building with it's ancient mosaics. It's a gem. If you take the Underground Tour of Prague, you'll start your tour here.
A great place to vist at Christmas. A great place to visit to get you in the festive mood
Plenty of choice. We love to visit here enjoying the atmosphere, shopping and restuarants. There are plenty of options to eat and grab a drink here whilst watching the people go by
dont miss it. fab restaurants but more pricey than those down the little allys but worth the price for the view of the xmas trees when the market is on
