Christmas atmosphere. The Town Square has a lot of history for those of interest and for the rest, you can enjoy a warm wine, tea or sweets being made and sold right at the spot. The stands with Christmas goods are nice to look at as well and this years Christmas tree is impressive.

Old Town Square at Christmas. The square at Christmas has a amazing atmosphere , the square is filled with various stalls though must are selling local Czech food and drink aswell as christmas decorations , hats and scarfs and a selection of souvenirs.The centrepiece of the Old Town Square is without a doubt the astronomical clock which makes a stunning photograph.The Square showcases Prague's architechture at it's best. In my opinion this is one of the best parts of Prague.

Lovely atmosphere. Visited during the Christmas market and it was lovely. Just before we were due to leave we stood supping mulled wine, looking at the beautiful church listening to the church bells with the lighted angel in the foreground and the fantastic Christmas tree in the background and it started to snow gently. Fabulous!
The Square. Very pretty area. The atmosphere was good as were all the stalls of the Christmas Market.
Greta atmosphere at Christmas. Great atmosphere at Christmas. The Old Town Square was just buzzing with stalls appealing to all visitors across the ages spectrum.
AMAZING. All e lights and xmas decor is amazing! U can feel the spirits with the old town buildings .. it all come together very BEAUTIFUL!

Beautiful Town Square. Loved the whole place. The architecture and the amazing christmas markets was fantastic. Went back several times just for a walk. Terribly cold at the end of the year though so wear lots of warm clothes.

very plesant. I'm not into architecture but even I liked the look and feel of the buildings. Was a lovely place to wander around and I for one would like to go back in the summer to explore more. One thing to be aware of though is that its very easy to get a little lost wandering round the streets all very charming and felt very safe at all times (although be aware of pickpockets), however the lighting at night is rather dim and makes map reading quite difficult.

A Fairy Tale Setting. I loved Old Town Square, especially at night. The Astronomical clock, Town Hall, Tyn Church and the House at the Sign of the Minute made it all seem like a fairy tale come alive! Lots of food stalls at night selling everything from home made wine to roast pork. I've left a little piece of my heart there.

The best Christmas markets. We visited Prague in December when the Christmas were in full swing. This felt like a Christmas market rather than just a few Christmassy stalls (as in Wenceslas Square). Try the pork which is roasted on big spits, and the Trdelnik, which are a little expensive but very nice (and a part of Prague). The atmosphere was great and everyone was walking around smiling. You feel glad to be alive and in such beautiful surroundings with the big Christmas tree and Tyn Church towering over it all.
Unique!. Love the ambiance and uniqueness of the town square. So many lovely little buildings.
What a Place, with its X-mas Market. Very nice atmosphere at night and a beautifull place
Buzzing Square. Loads going on, prices are ok but far more expensive than all other areas of the city. Buy your goods out of the square to get them cheaper is my tip.
Magic square. Wonderful atmosphere with the Christmas Market, concerts and tree. Compact and very clean.
Quaint and historic atmosphere. Shopping and we stopped and had lunch in a very nice Chezk restaurant and had mulled wine and coffee.
Beautiful architecture!. The Christmas market makes the Square even more magical

A great place to go for the Christmas atmosphere. A must visit for the Christmas atmosphere, lots to eat and drink. Watch for the street traders seeling items by the 100gm, you can end up paying much more than the listed prices.

A great place to go for the Christmas atmosphere. A must visit for the Christmas atmosphere, lots to eat and drink. Watch for the street traders seeling items by the 100gm, you can end up paying much more than the listed prices.
Astronomical clock. This looks wonderful and make sure you see it strike on the hour when the apostles parade past the windows and death rings the bell.

Christmas festival. I visited in Dec while the Christmas festival was ongoing. The square was all decked out with a huge Christmas tree and entertainment stage. The voices of children raised in song was inspiring. The aroma of the food was intoxicating especially the roasted chestnuts and meats grilled on an open wood fire. There were lots of kiosks selling all sorts of things and horse drawn carriages. It was just a delight to be there BUT beware of pick pockets. We were warned several times not to take the threat lightly. Do not let this stop you as this place is too good to miss! Do go up in the tower. It's worth the money as the views are amazing. It gets very crowded but you will get amazing photos.

Christmas market rating-more variety needed. Fun, reasonable value if you looked! Really popular with terrific atmospher. But more variety of goods and stalls needed-could be a lot better in this regard

Beautiful! Just beautiful!. Old Town Sqaure is, first of all, in an excellent conservation state. If you manage to see old paintings of the Square, you'll find out that the buildings are the same, the churches are the same, and almost the rocks on the pavement are the same.During Xmas, the town gets an magical appeal. A big Xmas market with some traditional food (Prague ham, hot wine, dough roll, etc..) and some wooden toys also for sale.Huge Xmas tree and a stage with almost every night animation makes it a hardly to miss, on a daily basis, attraction.I'll give it 4 out of five, just because the hassle of tourists by annoying exchange agents.

Beautiful Old Square. Fabulous City Square which was especially well used pre-Christmas with huge Christmas tree and market stalls. There were choirs and bands playing. Food stalls and hot wine available. Very festive although extremely busy on Friday PM and Saturday.

lost in Wonder. here you can feel that you have stepped back in time the buildings are a joy to look t and the clock is a must note that the square gets busy around the striking of the clock so one you have seen it you may want to avoid the square at these times. there are 2 English speaking pubs on the square but you will pay more in them move a street or 2 back from the square for better value

Nice square, must see when in Prague. It's a nice square with old buildings with many cafes and restaurants. In every hour a huge crowd is gathered to see medieval astronomical clock strikes the hour.

So so beautiful during xmas.... Wow this place is probably the most beautiful place I have ever visited in Europe. There were a large amount of markets available with it being xmas but I remember trying mulled wine, hot chocolate and their local break snack (not sure of it's name). It all looked fantastic during xmas and the astronomical clock is just beautiful.

Massive and very busy. Old Town Square has some serious architecture around it – the Old Town Hall to the west and the immense Church of the Virgin Mary before Tyn to the east. The huge Jan Hus Monument would usually dominate the Square, but in the lead up to Christmas the square is home to a huge Chrismas tree and associated decorations and displays, dwarfing the Hus Monument. The Square has plenty to see and enjoy – a great place to hang out in Prague.
I can visit it again and again. The atmosphere, the happy crowd that don't stop eating and taking pics of the square.

One of the most beautiful squares in Europe. I recently was in Prague's Old Town Square, which pulled out all of its holiday charm. The Old Town Square was decked out in holiday cheer with the Christmas market located there. Aside from the fun of the Christmas market, the architecture and buildings make the square one of the most beautiful squares I've been to. It ranges in style from Baroque to Gothic to Romanesque. Off to the side it has a fun astronomical clock that rings on the hour, with an accompanying trumpeteer at the top of the tower. It can be a bit touristic but that's the fun in it all and certainly doesn't negate the beauty of the square.
Tourist Spot. Lots of trinkets for tourist to buy, friendly people, good street food, lots of entertainment and very festive

the beating heart of the old city. Christmas market had lots of atmosphere and fresh baked, barbequeued and roasted food and touristy things for sale.Climbing the tower was easy with lifts and ramps, and a great view of the square and festivities.

Must See. The Prague Old Town Square is a must see with the Astronomical Clock and fascinating and beautiful architecture. Go early in the morning and avoid the crowds. It gets extremely crowded as the day goes on, especially near the Astronomical Clock.

The heart of Prague. The astronomical clock is definitely the main attraction of the Old Town Square and it's well worth going to the top of the tower (we walked up a series of ramps or you can catch a lift). The view from the top is amazing. There are some wonderful restaurants and coffee shops in the Square, but they are very expensive. The markets are great too.
Christmas wonderland!. Visited Prague for the Christmas Markets - nothing better than walking arounf this market and watching the clock on the hour
Lovely Xmas Market. Quite small but plenty of nice stalls selling various goods and lots of food and drink stalls beware these can be pricey.Always someentertainment ie xmas carols.Worth a visit

Amazing xmas goodies. The building and views here are amazing. Take time to look at all the shops and restaurants. If you are going to the Christmas markets definatley have some of the honey wine, it is delicious.

Enchanting at night. This was Christmas and all the decorations were out. All the people were out and it was crowded but apart from the concern for what is in your pocket there was a lightheartedness and high level of Christmas spirit. Glue Wein anyone?
Amazing. This is one of the most beautifull squares in the world. It has everything. Markets all arround the year complement this beauty.
Too much junk.. Too many vendors selling stuff made in China. Takes away from the medival charm of the square. It would be much better if the vendors sold "stuff" made in the Check republic.

breathtaking. an amazing square full of wonderful buildings and what i called disneyland as looks so much like disneyland towers esp at night , but we went and saw the christmas market and from afar you see the amazing treee with the wonderful lights that looked like snow falling on it , never seen them before but superb , then the bars , pubs , around the square , quaint alleyways to explore , the coach and horse rides , the hot wine , bread cakes , and the clock tower with the bugler at top , another place you simply have to visit every day and at night time to with the singing entertainment from kids and adults that changes every 30 mins or so , all this keeps you there and wanting to go back next day
Unbelieveable!. Old Town Square was one of the first historic sites I found in Prague. It was absolutely gorgeous! It's definitely something to see when you are in Prague!
xmas market. beautiful architectural buildings but a lot of beggers and pick pockets, a dangerous place, dont keep bags or wallets on show!!

Astronomical Clock and Underground Prague. The Astronomical clock tower and underground tour of Prague was a very informative experience. Many of the guided tours are quite a rip off and you can in fact follow where they take you on the foolishly labelled maps. But we did have some time to kill on the last day and took a tour of the underground cellars of the old town (which you do need permission to visit) and it was a real eye-opener, covering many periods of history and also illustrating the fact that what you see in the Old Town square at "ground level" is in fact not the real Prague at all!...
great. jolly place - fun at night - and it was Chav free!

Stunning - especially at night. I was fortunate enough to stay around the corner and never tired of emerging from a side street into the square. The astronomical clock is the highlight and we were a week too early for the Christmas Markets but what a nice space to rest and people watch. It really reminded me of squares in Belgium, with great architecture, cafe's, and even a chocolate shop in one corner.

Czech Out Prague. The beckoning charms of Staromestské Namesti (the very name sounds like a Swarovski jewel) pulled us southwards. We walked past the Rott House with its exquisite, decorative murals and cartoons, and along quaint streets fronted by specialist shops (one the violin shop), until the breathtaking Old Town Square opened up before us. We were again conscious of the large numbers of people gazing in fascination at the beautiful buildings. Timeless and serene in the afternoon sunlight, it was difficult to imagine a day in 1968 when the Russian tanks rolled in during the dramatic Prague Spring.Centre stage, the pink and black walls of the solid Old Town Hall command immediate attention. Adorning its south wall is the very famous Orloj or Astronomical Clock designed by Master Hanus. The huge, golden dials tell not only the time; but also the position of the planets, the equinoxes and the phases of the moon. As each hour strikes, the square fills to capacity. Increased crowds flock to watch the chiming display as two small doors open to reveal scenes of revolving figures. The canvas is rich indeed but two buildings are especially captivating. Rising to the east of the square are the commanding, black spires of the Church of Our Lady Before Tyn. Perhaps this haunting, Bohemian façade most epitomises Prague? It is strange, medieval and Gothic. And then, in the north-west corner, stands the elegant Baroque church of St Nicholas. It is white; has superb proportions and is capped by delicate, fluted, green spires.
Magic at Xmas. The square at Xmas mixes the modern with the medieval. Have a smile at the astronomical clock and enjoy the markets and gasp at the Xmas tree.
Xmas Market. Great atmosphere after markets start late November

Christmas market - beware of the ham!. We visited Prague primarily for the Christmas market on the last weekend in November, when there are special festivities for the opening weekend. The market is very picturesque, stunning setting, but compared with markets in Germany stalls are geared to food and drink rather than Christmas goods. A warning - there are stalls selling ham being cooked on big revolving spits, we asked for 2 portions and were charged 600 crowns (over £20) for 2 generous but not outrageously large plates of ham. I remonstrated but since it is carved off the bone in front of you it is difficult to send it back. You can get 2 meals with drinks in a respectable restaurant for 600 crowns - this is a rip-off.

Old Town Square Prague. A must for any visitor to Prague, the Old town Square, and the Astronomical Clock. Which has a story connected with it that the king of the time had the maker killed becuase he wanted his city to have the only clock of its kind. In the Square, at the end of November and all through December are the Christmas markets. These are great., Selling traditional Czech goods and foods
Christmas Markets!. I love this city. Everything you want to see is within walking distance, and the old town square is in the center of it all.
Lovely siteseeing. Nothing to dislike here. Just beautiful views and great food. Go up in the clock tower for the best view.
lots to see. The square has the astronomical clock. there were pickpockets working the crowd as people looked up to watch the clock do it's thing. Lots of good food and beer!
Christmass markets. It was good, I tried many kinds of sweet and czech hot wine was amazing...
Great view of the Astronomical clock. Old world haunting beauty in the square. Must see at night. Very picturesque and romantic.
Christmas tree great. All very pretty and setting up the christmas market

beautiful. really loved it wish we had gone just a few days later as they were just setting up the christmas markets and the atmosphere was already building up but sadly we missed it by a few hours. must try the old prague ham from one of the side stalls it was wonderful
Old World Charm at its Best!. Spires, cobblestones and a castle view- whats not to like?
Interesting. Any number of interesting buildings,restaurants,stalls Christmas market was just setting up.

Be Aware. The old Town square is very picturesque & worth a visit but there is something you should know before visiting.The Old Prague ham stalls smell & look very tempting but beware as it sold by weight, something that is not very clear until you go to pay.Crackling, fat & everything is weighed & you pay 89 krone per 100 grammes, our 4 average sized portions & 1 portion of potato came to nearly £40, its also pot luck as to how good or bad your portion of ham is. Just bear this in mind & enjoy if you can afford it.

Must visit. It's so breathtaking beautiful, that it can be ratet as one of the most beautiful squares in the world, perfect arkitecture, lots of museums, atmosphre, restourants, possibilities to join trips in and outside Prague, use time on it. And one more thing: you can taste fresh food, prepared in the street, try it! Cheap and tasty. Look at the buildings around - each one is a work of art. Bathe in history.

Magical experiance. Walked down to the square on our first night to get our bearings. On entering the square the view was dominated by the floodlit spires of the Tyne church and along with the Astronomical clock and all the outdoor eating places we found this to be an almost fairytale experience. We spent some time here and also wandered the neighboring streets before making our way back to the Hotel. We felt very safe while we were out and very much enjoyed our introduction to Prague
Scenic, both day and night.. Be certain to return at night as most sights are illuminated giving it an almost mystical feel.
Busy and vibrant. Sitting watching the clock strike with hot wine wonderful, watch your bags prime pick pocket teritory.
can't miss. u can't go to Prague and not spend a couple of hours just taking in this gorgeous square.
History at home. Perfect arhitecture, i would suggest to wait for sharp hour with a glass of hot wine bought from the traditional market in the square

Probably the best Central European Square. It's just got everything: lively, of course too touristy, but not brashly so. Interesting things on every side, in depth and in quality. But avoid the Prague ham sellers, however picturesque they look or hungry you may be, unless you want to pay well over the odds.

Don't miss the clock. The marvelous town hall clock is not to missed. The market stalls are fun to browse -- and stop at one of the cafes for a coffee, drink or lunch. Don't worry if it's chilly, they provide blankets -- and heaters!
Stunning. Really pretty - lots of pics to take! The hub to everything. The place to really start your holiday.

A good place to meet. The clock every hour is a strong draw, the square fills up close to the top of the hour to see the Apostles rotating in the clock.
The street food and music are very good.

Tick Tock. The clock was interesting,but not as interesting as inside! the view from the top was Fab.
Public Toilets nr to a nice little cafe on the corner.
horse and carriage ride round the streets 20 mins for 800czk
hard rock cafe just off from the sq
Brilliant!. We went for the Philharmonic concert and it was excellent!
Brilliant at Night. Come here late at night when it isn't to busy to get some really fantastic photos of the sqaure and don't forget the have a drink or two at one of the nearby pubs.

Beautiful town square. Lovely old town square. Visit both during the day and at night for a different ambiance. While the square is clearly geared to handling a lot of tourists, it is worth the visit. The building and statues are worth the trip. Have a coffee or cocktail at one of the local outside restaurants even in the late fall.
Famous place. Lovely area surrounded by many different types of old buildings
watch out for rogue taxis. if you are tired after walking around and eating a goulash soup be careful of the taxis at the entrance to the square. They overcharge by three times the regular fare.

Street Foodies Unite!. Yes, it's crowded and noisy, but for a good reason. A few times a year there are random food festivals here. Actually, I have no clue what the festival was about, but there were tons of food vendors selling fresh potato chips, fried cheese on rye (yes, fried and it is magnificant!) and some sort of bohemian cinnamon/sugar dough treat, to name my favorites. Leave your valuables in the safe and book it to this hot spot for late night activies and entertainment - or just to stuff yourself with carbs, like I did.
A MUST SEE. So much beauty and history. Enjoy the famous clock and the exceptional church.

Picturesque. Buildings look wonderful
But has bercome commercialised

Great place to begin a Prague visit. We visited Old Town Square on a lovely, warm and sunny day. The energy was positive with street musicians, cobblestone open space, lots of shopping, restaurants and people watching, as well as historic buildings. The Tyn Church, astronomical clock and several other attractions are all located here. This is a terrific place to get a sense of what Prague has to offer.

Amazing but beware. The buildings were magnificent. The people were friendly. Only problem was the price of the cafe opposite the clock. We made the mistake of sitting here for lunch - one cheeseburger and chips, tea and pannini and cappucino £38.00. Bad mistake. However in the evening we had a lovely meal a few restaurants along which was well worth the money. Our waiter (Martin) was great and the food was excellent and only came to approx £50.00 for 2 people 3 courses plus wine and beer.

Look up!. This is where you will find the clock and some of the most amazing architeture in all of Europe...In my opinion anyway...Also I happened upon a wine festival in the middle of the square, in talking to the locals there is always something going there!! - You can spend all day and people watch or be done with the clock in 5 mins...either way you will enjoy the visit to Old Town Square!
beautiful old square. have to see the click which is animated on the hour

Beautiful. When we entered this square I felt as though my paper doll house had come to life. The beautiful colors on the buildings, the architecture, just the general feel, nice in the day and at night. We bit the bullet and decided to have a beverage in one of the overpriced restaurants just so we could sit down and have a front row view.
Excellent. The old town square is like a medieval square, everything is perfect, you feel like in a movie

Lunch on the go and great site seeing.. This is a great place to eat lunch standing up and take in the sites. There are a variety of food vendors in the square in addition to the restaurants around the perimeter. You can get some traditional food from one of them and then make your way around the square. Don’t forget to stop at the Astronomical clock. It is worth a roll of film (or a small SD card). Notice the skeleton in the upper right corner. This clock is amazing technology and design for it’s (15th century) day. Ask a local what happened to the clock’s maker.

Keep looking upwards!. Prague Old Town Square is just what you expect an Eastern European old town square to look like! Fabulous old buildings with big pointy spires, the famous astronomical clock and the food market where all sorts of meats and meals are available. And don't forget the architecture, just keep looking up! :-)
terrific. a place to see in Prague, specially in the evening

Vintage Praha at its best!. I spent a little time here on every single day of my 4 day trip in Prague. It is the epi center of the old cultural charm that one might want to see and is home to the faous astronomical clock.Locals and tourists alike are seen strolling aroud this area, soaking in the vintage charm of the town, listening to the impromtu live jazz bands, eating at restaurants or food stalls or takinf carriage rides.A good place to try some local street eats and buy local handicrafts. My husband and I had a memorable and romantic carriage ride around the area.Also just down the road from Old Town Square is Pariziska which is a shoppers paradise!

The ancient and the modern. The Staromestske namesty is unusual mix of the ancient and the modern. At the first sight the buildings and the square are stayed without changes from the old times. But there is no sense of hopelessness. The Old Town Square is living at present time...
Charming!. The Old Town Square is a very charming, inviting spot in the center of Old Town Prague that seems to welcome the entire world to this magnificent City.

Excellent Site. We were there during St Martin's, so there was a market with traditional food and bevergages as well as crafts, extremely busy. Felt safe, due to large police presence. Excellent architecture all around

Beautiful and atmospheric large square that is the tourist hub of Prague - just a lot going on all the time.. Plenty to see even if it is just people watching. Beware that all the bars and restaurants surrounding the square tend to be overpriced. Would certainly recommend the free tour of Prague - our guide was a hugely energetic young Australian man called Ashley who has a wife from Prague and he certainly kept us all entertained.

Prague remains an expensive favourite. Prague remains a favourite destination, but costs have risen dramatically since joining theEU. Fortunately, they have retained their own currency the Czech Crown, but costs are now in line with other capital cities.Selecting a hotel to stay at in Prague is important as there are only older style hotels in the Old Town and that is where most visitors want to stay.It is important to be within a few minutes walk of Wenceslas Square in the one direction and the Old Town Square and the Charles Bridge in the other direction.The Old Town Square is where everyone congregates all day and late into the night. It is surrounded by small restaurants which are excellent but expensive! Everything in Prague is expensive and couples visiting wiill easily get through Euros 150 a day just to cover meals and drinks.The only bargain in the city are the three Opera Houses where visitors can enjoy opera or baller six nights a week. Tickets for these can easily be booked online and e-tickets printed off in advance. Expect to pay £40 Sterling or 45 Euros for good seats. The champagn bars are available at the interval with a glass of champagne costing about £2 or Euros 2.20.Travel on the Metro system is easy, but the tram system is bewildering and not at all wellsignposted for visitors. We tried to visit Prague Zoo but found transportation to it impossible as it involved a tram ride followed by a bus journey.We will continue to visit Prague for the theatres, but cut the length of stay dramatically!
Overwhelmingly charming. Some pricier restaurants right on the square, take your pictures of the amazing architecture and astronomical clock here and walk off the square for dinner.

Beautiful buildings. Beautiful architecture, lovely to wander the streets. great to visit when there are also markets there. Make sure to visit at the start of the hour to see the display of the Astronomical Clock
Gorgeous historic sight.. The Astronomical clock was the best part. It strikes on the hour and becomes animated. Lovely to see.
Old Town Square. A great place to sit with a drink and watch the world go by.

Great square very busy. Very nice square, full of tourists waiting to see the clock, don't wait to long its not really worth waiting longer that 10 minutes. Grab a Starbucks or a nice coffee in one of the many cafe's nestled around the square.
Keep Sat morning free for the food fest that seems to go on all day
The clock. It gets pretty packed on the hour, top tip get there 15 mins earlier to get a good spot

Prague Town Square - Fun But Commercial. The town square in Prague is fun to hang around and watch people. However, it has become very commercial. We were there 6 years ago and then again in October. We found it much more commercial this time and very touristy. However, it is a must see.
A very nice place !. old buildings covered with lots of history ! near you have malls, you can take tour trips with audio guide
Old Town Square. The buildings are really old but very well maintained. The whole area is clean and very reasonably priced.
Great shame about the graffiti. Nice historical buildings, surroundings spoilt by graffiti

INTERESTING AND HISTORIC. Historic like so much of Prague, and well worth a look. The fascinating astronomical clock on the Town Hall, the Tyn church towering over one end like something from a fairy tale.

Good views, good food, good atmosphere. You enter the square and you don't know which way to turn - there are so many wonderful buildings and churches (shame the front of Our Lady Before Tyn is hidden). Excellent starting point for anywhere in Stare Mesto.

Gotta love it!. Crowded? Yes. Beautiful? Yes. Historical? Yes. But Prague is a delight for the senses. Tourists speaking in a dozen or more languages. The smell of Prague ham roasting over a wood fire.Live music being performed nearby. Crisp fall air chilling your nose. The chime of the clock. Wonderful!

A 'Must See'!. The main square in Prague is a definite 'Must See' on any visit to Prague.It can be very busy, especially at the o'clock times - this is because the apostles in the astronomical clock come out of the window in the front of the clock and a trumpeter at the top of the tower blows a salute. This is worth seeing from both inside and outside of the tower.I have heard of pickpockets operating, but didn't notice any suspicious behaviour - this is backed up by a noticeable police presence, and the police are more than happy to help you out with any problems.The main statue was being renovated during my visit so the view was somewhat obscured by some boards, but from the top of the tower it is possible to see the iconic views of Prague including the old gates and Charles Bridge.Jazz is very big in Prague and on a number of occasions there were Jazz bands playing in the town square.I did not eat at the restaurants right on the square, but turning down some side streets there are some EXCELLENT places to eat both main meals and coffee and strudel.If you're going to Prague, you have to visit the old town square

Heart of the City. Always busy, you can pay inflated prices for a beer or a meal but then sit and watch the world go by. Some good stalls selling local delicacies, the smells were good. Two stunning churches, plus the astronomical clock tower on the old town hall.
Old, but rock concert. Whilenwe were there they had a public concert with great music and great food.
Good Atmosphere. This is what I expected Prague to be like, with very old buildings, a square, and lots of coffee houses, good atmosphere.

I could of sat here all day!!. The clock ( not forgetting the trumpter), st Nicholas Church, the horsedrawn carriges, the galleries, the monuments, the shops, the cafes....I could go on and on, I could of sat here all day justing watching the world go by rining coffee or beer in the many bars, magical
Wow, food and drink and many photo ops. The many little streets and alleys leading off the square are amazing and offer rewards at every turn. Go in winter, not so many people, cheaper
Take a stroll down here. Nice setting, lots of different stalls with food and drinks, horse and cart etc, was nice to see enjoyed walking around doing my nosy.

Wonderful square. This is a lovely square surrounded by elegant buildings. There are great views from the top of the clock tower (which has a lift) and the various memorials are very interesting. It's good to see the land train and the horse-drawn carriages, and everything seems well cared forl.
Great architecture. Worth the visit. Go up the tower and stay for the hourly trumpeter.
must see. I could just walk around this neighborhood for hours. Lots of interesting shops and restaurants.
Best Tourist Attraction. This is what I expected Prague to be like, very old buildings, a square, and lots of coffee houses.
A square to walk around. Great area to stroll and walk around to check out shops and cafes
Unique. Another example of Prague's history, richness and power before the 20th century
WONDERFUL. Great place, lots of shops. We enjoyed the restaurants, scenery and the plants are just beauiful. I love the cafe's along the streets when you walk.
Old Town hall. The old town hall is very impressive, especially the clock that tells you the Saints feast day for every day of the year.
Excellence!. How did they make if for the world and being the heritage of the world!
somme building - an mirror image from the past. Somme building give as an image from the past; verry good preservation, architectural and functional.
Very good but very crowded. Lovely experience and well worth the stroll - crowds did become unmanageable at times

Old Town Square a must. Beautiful buildings everywhere. Concerts all the time. Prague State opera nearby. The amazing clock that was so beautiful and built about 500 years ago that the authorities blinded the maker so he could not make another anywhere else. It has 12 apostles moving in a circle every hour and it's huge. Elegance everywhere. Pick up tours at the square, especially Urban Adventure walking tours. You get so much knowledge of the city that way.
Lovely!. The atmosphere is fabulous. The Buildings are gorgeous - you must see the Astronomical Clock!
A touch of Old europe. The buildings and the astronomical clock are a must see.
Picturesque but touristy. It's a picturesque square but far too many tour groups around most of the time. You'll get far better food by finding restaurants down the side streets.
Alwayslively. Well worth seeing; lively with tourists but beautiful.

The star in Staromestske. The Tyn church is awesome, the Astronomical Clock still pulls the crowds on every hour! Lots to see and do, something new hits you at every corner or narrow street, just when you might think you've seen it all!.
lovely old feel. good atmosphere here as the taxi's, guide buses and the odd horse and carriage come in and out, the odd busker singing and church bells chiming!

Beautiful Site to See. The old town square is the center of everything. I recommend finding a free tour (red or yellow umbrellas) in front of the clock tower. Lots of great street food here, as well as beautiful buildings to admire.
Beautiful. We loved the Old Town Square - meandering the main streets and the side streets was wonderful.

Beautiful. It really is amazing. You can stand in the middle of the square and just gaze endlessly. It is ever so slightly Disney, but in a very good way. I wouldn't be at all surprised if Disney took some inspiration from this square! It's lovely, romantic and peaceful - especially at night in the mist.
A must. A lot of great stuff to see. Plenty of shopping but watch the pick pockets
BUZZING. Just love this Square, so many beautiful buildings to look at
beautiful site. stay and wait for the astronomical watch to play, go to all churches (each has something amazing to see) and climb the stais of the tower to see the view. All is memorable!
Best when the booths are operating. Old Town Square is best during holiday periods when the lively booths are filling the square with crafts, food and drink.

Another must see. It's one of the main tourist places as this is where the tours leave from, it's also wher eyou see St Vitus cathedral, St Nicholas' the Astronomical clock. My only problem was because it's the heart of the city the resturants and cafes are much higher priced due to location, but it's like this the world over
Busy Busy Busy. Lots of tourists traps. But very exciting and vibrant. Don't buy tourist crap here if you're going to other towns where everything is cheaper.
Pretty and Quaint. lovely buildings, cafes, shops and restaurants, astrological clock

Lovely. The town hall with the lovely clock on one side and the amazing church on the other side, with restaurants all around. Fabulous atmosphere. Go up the tower of the town hall - well worth it for the views and the trip up and back.

Lovely architecture. Expensive food/beverages.. Many of the buldings surrounding the square are traditional architecture. Very pleasing to the eye compared to the modern boxes churned out nowadays. Lots of restaurants / refreshment places, but the prices are high. Nothing fleecing the tourists!
the old square. the whole area is very clean and well kept. they were also selling excellent fast food. the houses around the square look very colourful and good
Just mind blowing. Everything about this square is wonderful. It was exciting to see so many people enjoying the sights as we were.

Historic part of Prague. We liked visiting the old town square even though it was always filled with tourists. There are some great vistas and sites to see including the outside of the church of Our Lady of Tyn, the astronomical clock and the very old City Hall. Be sure to ask about the tour of the crypt area in the old City Hall. It is generally closed except with a tour guide and you won't know you can see it unless you ask about the tour.
a wonderful story. the best was the music concert just on the grounds of the castle

Fantastic Clock Tower. The Old Town Square is very crowded but well worth the visit. . . . just keep in mind that there are pickpockets wherever you find large numbers of tourists.The CLOCK TOWER is magnificant. Be sure to visit on the hour as the clock strikes the hour. It is amazing that they could design such a clock hundreds of years ago.In the middle of the square you will find a statue of John Huss. John Huss was a "Martin Luther" about 100 years before Luther. Back then the Roman Catholic Church had an army and he did too. . . . his army won most of the battles. The Catholic Emperor finally offered him "safe passage" and he went to Prague for talks . . . . . He was promptly seized and burned at the stake. His followers have survived and you will find Hussite Monasteries in the Czech Republic.The large Catholic Church to the right of the statue is interesting too. It is built close behind some homes. The idea was to build the church so close that the homeowners would sell for a low price but the economy went bad and it never happened. You have to enter the church through a narrow passage between the houses.Don't skip the old Jewish Quarter that borders the square. . . . . . the area to the rear and right of the John Huss statue. It is well worth exploring. Want to eat? Walk down one of the many narrow streets around the square. Once you are 2 or 3 blocks from the square you will find small restaurants with better food at half the price. Don't forget to try the Czech beer. It's very good!

Quaint, beautiful, must-see. Old Town Square in Prague is practically out of a fairy tale book. It is so old and original and you can really feel its history. The clock is beautiful. Enjoy a cold beer or an espresso while sitting outside at a cafe and watch the people go by. I can't wait to go back!

Beautiful. It is definitely worth going up the tower by the astronomical clock for an all-round view of this lovely square - there is a lift. Beautiful old buildings with different architectural styles.

Busy Square. All the buildings surrounding the Square are beautiful but it is very busy at weekends and the eateries are more expensive in this location. The astronomical clock is obviously a huge attraction.

Excellent quarter for history, food, drink, and Jazz. Had multiple nice strolls through the Old Town Square, as Prague is actually quite compact in the older sections. This is a very interesting square now, with a mix of new and old - jazz bars and restaurants mixed in with the Old Town hall and the amazing Astonomical clock. Very close to the Old Jewish Quarter and the Charles bridge.

Heart of Prague. Old Town Square is a beautiful, crowded square in the heart of old town. Here is where you will find the famous Astronomical Clock which was burned by the Nazis as they left Prague. The clockworks survived and the tower was rebuilt. On the hour, as the clock strikes, you see a parade of the patron saints of Prague. Be sure to climb up the tower...I highly recommend the night view of Prague and the Square.Look for the door to the left of the clock that says "For Weddings Only." The clock is next to the municipal building which still conducts civil wedding ceremonies. We saw several newly married couples who were applauded by several hundred of their closest tourist friends!

Old Town Square,Prague. A unique square,with a famous clock tower.Be sure to go up the tower for a view of the city.Wonderful narrow lanes off the square,be sure to get a map at your hotel,or better still hire a guide ,so you get an overall view of the city.Eating in the square is a must,and the food is excellent .There are many shaded areas,either trees or umbrellas,reasonable too.At night take a trip down the river and see all the lit up buildings.Amazing.

Skip the clock!. Waited around with a huge crowd to see the clock move around at noon. Very little movement. One figure moves his arm? Very disappointing. Lots of rude, punk young people that could care less about the history of Prague, they were only out for a party.The view from the clock tower is worth the 100CZK.

Wonderful architecture, expensive espresso. A must-see in Prague. But be carefully if you sit down at a café near the "Astronomical" clock - they've got coffee prices to match (more than £8 - or $12 for an espresso).

B E A U T I F U L. Great, a must, but avoid the summer.. too crowed.
There are a lot of things to do and see around here, avoid eating close by as it is way to expensive and not as good as it is in more local places.

Lovely buildings. The Old Town is a must see, it gets very busy especially on the hour when the astronomical clock performs. The old palaces in the square are very nicely decorated and St Nicholas Church is also well worth a visit. The Tyn is a great sight. Cafes and restaurants are expensive though, go around the corner and most places are much cheaper.
Great for people watching. This is a must stop for any travel to Prague. you can find great food and plenty of barker's selling fun things to do during the day and during the night.

Old Town Square. We were there in September and the whole week we were there, there was a traditional market in the Old Town Square, this is just around the corner from the Astronomical clock, so very easy to get to. We tried the food here and were amazed at how good it was and the variety on offer. It all seemed to be traditional Czech food, there were also a few stalls selling wine, though we did not try any. There was a large police presence here throughout the day, but we did not see anything untoward happen. The chiming of the Clock on the hour attracted large crowds which were difficult to cope with, but if you tried to get up to one of the 1st floor cafes you would be disappointed because all of the window tables were reserved.

Old Town Square in Prague is so beautiful--especially at night!. I stumbled onto the Square from my hotel at dusk to find a live rock concert going on and tons of people eating the traditional food from the stands and drinking czech beer--all as the sun was setting and the Square slowly began to magically light up. The clock tower and cathedral looked liked Disney World from a thousand years ago. Many tourists from Central Europe and beyond. Made my first day/night in Prague so wonderful. It's a beautiful, ancient city with the Castle, the Charles Bridge and regal palaces everywhere. The evening river boat cruise was such a romantic way to see the city lit up at night. Just so beautiful! If you're not on a budget; go to Kampa Park restaurant next to the Charles Bridge right on the Vlatava River. The best restaurant in Prague.

don't miss the views from the tower. There's so much to see in Prague, but make this a "must see". You can easily spend 1-2 hours just looking around here. The views of central Prague from the top of the tower are great, and very different from those from the observation tower on Petrin Park or from Letna Park.

A must do - once. I found the old square very scenic. The clock "show" is very brief and a little underwhelming, but you have to see it. The Kinsky Palace is beautiful and pink. The statue of Jan Huss is huge and impressive. The cafes are expensive there. When we were there, there was a memorial service for the Czech hockey players who were lost in a plane crash, so we likely didn't get the true feel or look of the area as a whole. Don't waste time looking for little shops behind the Tyn church. Just head right up Celetna to the Municipal house and you will find all kinds of shops.

Old town square. A must when you visit Prague.Nice and very interesting place, take a coffee with some sweet on the first floor opposite the astronomic clock. It's cheaper and you have a nice view on the square.The prices on the square are very high.

Great old town feel, nice to walk through.. full of tourist traps. I love the old town square. There are lovely buildings, people dressed in traditional clothing. Lots of shops, souvenirs, cafes, restaurants....but mostly geared towards tourists. Not really my style. I wandered a bit further away from the square and find nicer, less crowded ares for a better price.

Charming but crowded. The Old Town Square is nice. It is big with lots of food vendors and ringed by restaurants.I have actually seen prettier. But is is lovely and clean. There are much more interesting parts of Prague to see and not really a lot in the actual square except for the clock, catherdral and art museum. Prague almost feels disneyesque to me as it is so perfect. We discovered not many people actually live in the area so it alwasy feels like a tourist centre which is too bad.
Not to be missed. Absolutely stunning, both in the day and at night, when it is illuminated. Every building is a gem.

awesome to look at but don't eat the street food.. We sat down to a wonderful lunch of beef goulash with dumplings at a restaurant off the main square which cost us less than the next day when we decided to eat the street food! A couple of pieces of baked ham cost ten dollars and a bag of fresh crisps, as interesting as it was to watch them being made, cost over three dollars! We've had better food and much better value from restaurants AND beer prices near the tourist areas can be three times more than you'll pay in a restaurant off the main drag.

A Happening Place. We spent a night in Prague and visited Old Town Square in the afternoon and evening. The energy in this location is great and there are no annoying street peddlers (such as in Rome) to detract from the experience. We were able to listen to live baroque music and enjoyed dinner at a restaurant in front of the Astronomical Clock. All the facilities in Old Town are in excellent condition and the city is very clean.

nice walk. an old town square is a beautifull area to see. there is a beautiful church , a black theatre "IMAGE" which is cheaper than the one next to the Charles bridge. (buy the tickets in advance), the clock of course is a "must" place to see, to take pictures...if you want to eat in a beautifull place I would reccomend the "Municipa housel" it's not expensive as you would expect.. we had dinner there and we loved it.in front of the Municipal house there is a theatre, you should check it if you like ballet.

Nice, but overrun with souvenir shops. We always ended up in Old Town Square in the evenings, but I must say there are way too many cheesy souvenir shops. It does distract from the beauty of the buildings and the history. What a shame.

although not qualified as attraction : a must see. Visiting prague you will frequently pass the old town square and altough it isn'tmentioned as an attraction it will never bore you.It is surrounde by lots of beautifull (couloured) houses and there are lots ofterraces . Besides that there are almost allways lots of people to enyo the tourists.

Yes!. This is my first trip to Prague, but fifth to Europe. Net, net - I love Prague!! I will recommend it to everyone. Strolling the old town, Castle, etc. is a definite must. From all the art nouveau buildings to medieval structures to the history, etc. A surprise and delight around every corner, at decent prices.

Over priced - Take lots of money with you!. Old Town Square is OK for photo oportunities, but if you need to visit the toilet/bathroom expect to pay 0.40 Koruna or if using Euro, 50 cents One place charged .80 koruna or 1 euro. Nothing is cheap in this square expect to pay a premium for food and soft drinks/coffee. Wine and beer are slightly cheaper than in the UK, but the days of 50p a pint are long gone! Oh, and wear good flat shoes for walking about. The cobbles are are a killer!!
Beautiful but over crowded. Try to outside the big tourist season. Every hour when the "apostles" parade above the Astronomical Clock, it is totally elbow to elbow.
Christmas central!. I was here during Christmas and it was gorgeous! It would have been anyway, the history is amazing and I loved the view of the square from the tower. Great place to see
Romantic... Romantic, beautiful, nice atmosphere......a must see visit in Prague especially at night time.

Free to all and great place to watch people. This square has a famous old clock that has dancing figures all around it that dance on the hour. The sqaure is a beauty for photos. The shops and food off the square are expensive, but good. This is one of the top three things you must see when in Prague (clock, bridge, castle).

Way too many tourists. Last visited Prague about 12 years ago with my daughter and thought it was lovely. Went last month and hated it. It was soooo commercialised and crowded this time - I won't be going again

Stunning. Old Town Square is not to be missed! It is beautiful since it was renovated after the fall of communism, but it has come at a price. It is also the most expensive area in the city and it is full of tourists all year around.The clock tower is fun to see; especially on the full hour when the figurines above the astrological clock come out during the show. At certain times just afterwards a man with a bugle will sound the horn afterwards; very nice show. In the evening you have the most spectacular views when the buildings are lit up; very romantic. Especially in the holiday season when the Christmas market is open it's even more magical.
Awesome historical site. We loved visiting here. Great to see so much history.

Great Place to Visit but Food cooking there is terrible. It is indeed a great place to visit. We especilaay liked the astronomical clock and the trumpet blower on the tower who blows the trumet every hour on the hour and waving goodbye to the people below. Atmosphere is very nice. The old buildings arround are beautiful. However, the food cooking in the centet of the squate is bad. It ruins the nice view and atmosphere of the place.
culture heaven. we went during a culture festival so the centre was bustling with stalls and music bands- beautiful

Not what it used to be.. We have been to Prague several times. Always enjoyed sitting in the restaurants around town square. When we were there in July, there was no outside seating on the square. Also, there were not benches around the square. Really missed sitting and "people watching."

Best christmas market. This place is just so magical. The whole town square is very pretty and worth walking around although there is not much to see, the scenery is worth taking a few photos. Lots of cafes around too..during christmas period, this area is filled with christmas markets and stall vendors set up their business around with cheap food and woodcraft items.

When in Prague- you have to visit Old Town Square. If just for the crowds, the atmosphere and the beautiful buildings and architecture. We all preferred the old town square over Wenseslaus square and enjoyed a nice beverage while viewing the street vendors selling their wares.

Too crowded. I’ve been in Prague before but was unprepared for what I saw. The town of the hundred towers is still there and still beautiful but very crowded. Definitely not going back there in summer. We traveled 8 people together - there wasn’t a single place (pub or restaurant) where to pay only for what we have ordered, always overpriced, quite irritating.

Wonderful atmosphere at night. The Old Town Square has to visited in the evening when it is already dark. The atmosphere is simply overwhelming. The impressing buildings around the square are wonderfully illuminated and it does do you a whole lot of good sitting in one of the cafes there drinking one of the tasty czech beers or sipping a nice cup of coffee. Stef010

a beautiful are of Prague. This was such a beautiful area to spend time in. There were so many lovely buildings to photograph and of course the Astronomical Clock. There are coach and horses to hire in the square and lots of stalls selling food and other goods. The only thing I would suggest is that if you are not meeting a tour guide there then avoid the square around 10am as it was packed with people and hard to walk around.

Beautiful and historical. No visit to Prague is complete without a visit here. It can be completely free as you take in the beauty and majesty. Or sign up for a tour and learn about the history taken place here. Easy access from all transit, there is reallly no excuse to not visit.As other people have mentioned, try to limit your food, beverage, and souvenir purchases here as most everything is inflated.

Beautiful. the site is simply marvellous. Be carefull to the pickpockets. Some people had lost wallet, camera, or other.If you want to taste the flavour of Prague' Ham you could find some kiosks on the edge just in the opposite side of the Cathedral. However pay attention to the weight of your Prague's Ham slice. You will pay for this, and the sellers try to cut huge slices for huge fees

See the sights.... ... but don't buy from the chisellers and grafters on any of the food stalls. Food sold by weight not portions. Listed price for sparrow portion, normal portion four times more!The square is beautiful and scenic by day and the clock is really good fun.

My favourite Old Town in Europe (so far). Prague Old Town is a magical place that even the hordes of tourists can not tarnish its beauty. Cobbled streets where you can get lost and go in circles for hours discovering new things that you missed the first time around. The must-seen sights are the main square, the astronomical clock, Tyn Cathedral; but there is so much more to see including the Spanish Synagogue and the Estates' Theater.

You will fell like in a fairy-tale. The old town square (Staroměstské náměstí) is one of the most magical places in Prague. The astronomical clock is a marvel to behold but you can also enjoy the Tyn Church with free entrance, climb to the top of the clock by just 1.5 € with magnificent views of Prague or enjoy a beautiful walk as if you were in a fairy-tale.

The greatest old square!. So much history and so much beauty! It is a lovely square with not only the most beautiful buildings and churches but also one of the best restaurants- Staromestska Restaurant- on the other side from the town hall, towards the Tyn church.Another treasure is hotel "U prince" where the restaurant has the best views of the square!

You can't miss this. There's a ton to see in this square and in the surrounding area. I recommend going later in the day to avoid the crowds (though be certain that it's always busy, just worse in the mornings).The cafes around there are expensive, but you get what you pay for, a gorgeous view and a chance to relax while walking around a lot. The souvenir shops around are mostly garbage in my opinion - overpriced and not really Czech. Shop in New Town near the Kafka Museum (Fun Explosive - they have 2 shops within a block) for better stuff at a better rate, or the Czech-owned Manufaktura - also on the New Town side of the bridge.
Fabulous. Sensational square. So much history. Too maany people and too many vendors but otherwise wonderful and has to be seen.
one of the best Squares in Europe. a must-see in Prague, strongly recommended to climb the clock tower and admire the panaroma from there

Go early to avoid the crowds. This is a beautiful town square and on every tourist's agenda. In the square, you can see the old town hall and astronomical clock, the house where Kafka once lived and the twin-spire Church of Our Lady Upon Tyn where Tycho Brahe is buried, to name a few of the highlights. You can go to the top of the Old Town Hall for a good view of the square and surrounding city. At 8 and 9 am, it's beautiful to visit and the crowds are modest. By 10, there are hordes of tourists, so I recommend going as early as possible. The square is also a launch pad for many city tours, such as those by Segway, so it can be a good place to start in the morning.

One of the better squares in Europe. As the title says it already... it's one of the better squares in Europe.Why? It's not too big, it has nice features as the Astronomical Clock (Which is a MUST see if you never saw it, but make sure you visit it when it's 'working'...).I like it a lot in the winter when there's snow, Christmas is there... in the summer it's sometimes a bit overcrowed imho.The square is a good starting point to discover the different 'quarters' in Prague.
a must see. Nice shops, definitely a must see once in a lifetime. no need for more then two or 3 days in prague.

When a fairy-tale come true. Born and raised in the city, but whenever crossing THE Square having marvelous feeling of being there. Yes, half a day full of people, but in the rest you can definitely enjoy it. When in Prague do not only see the city core in afternoon as all the tourists do. Take a walk here in the cold foggy morning when all the tourists are waking up and having breakfasts. Enjoy the atmosphere of Old Town Square where life is emerging and people approaching from all the streets leading here. See the spires of Tyn church in fresh day light and relax sitting on a bench. Than at 8:50 AM go beyond Astronomical clock and after spectacular show at 9:00 AM (when many people are still in hotel bathrooms) can you leave this spot. And then return in the late sunset or in the evening to enjoy the gem of mother of cities.Right on this square you may feel a bit of Czech history - Astronomical clock, Jan Hus monument (let’s call him predecessor of Martin Luther), 27 white crosses representing executed noblemen and than 30 years war, but also Old Town Hall damaged by WWII bombing and do not forget about the opposite side of the square, where Kinsky palace is - just the place where communist announced they seized power in 1948. Everything described and even more you find in the square and if you are lucky enough to enjoy (overcrowded, of course) Christmas markets or Czechs supporting their ice hockey team on world cup, than nothing can break it!PS: Depends on you, but as a Prague citizen I advice you not to spent money in restaurants/shops in that area. There are much cheaper and better opportunities. On Old Town Square you pay them only for the location ;-)

Interesting walk through time. From the castle we made our way down to the old town square (Stare Mesto) and walked along the Pariser Street seeing the Jewish district and then on to the Old Town Square (Staromestske Namesti) where we saw the Astronomical clock, which was built over 500 years ago.It's quite a sight with it's huge clock face which rings on the hour when the bells ring, the rooster crows, and the 15th Century statues of the 12 Apostle's comes out and circles. It has a solar clock, lunar clock, and astrological signs which ring the clock face. An elevator is available and is wheel chair accessible for the viewing gallery at the top of the viewing gallery. For some pocket change (Kc20) you can use the telescope for a couple of minutes and look at the surrounding hills and valley.

So beautiful!. This place is magical. Full of colours. Just to see those horses and to pay attention at the astronomical watch, just worthwhile to go! You have also the jewish neighbourhood near. Good combination of culture and relax.

Favorite part of the city. My husband and I visited the town square several times. We visited the clock, we ate some czech fare from the local vendors. We strolled the little streets near the square. This area was always busy and full of energy. There was many local alfresco cafes and shops. The square was in an open area it was great to sit and take in the sights! We loved it

Beautiful place - very nice to walk around and to take a beer. Really like this place have been walking around there several times. Tyin church and city hall with its astronomical clock is fantastic.I easy can sit down and take a beer while watching all the life and the buildings.And from the tower of city hall you will have a great view.

Beautiful Square and Architecture, but very touristy. Certainly a aesthetically beautiful square with building from 14th century through 17 century, but filled with three quarters overpriced restaurants and tourist shops. On the edges and leading out of the square are Cartier, Gucci,Prada etc. Not on par with other European Squares due to polluted facades ( half of Pragues buildings are blackened with soot ) and griminess.

One of the most beautiful squares in Europe. A must see in Prague, containing those Gothic Towers that you'd expect to see in a Disney fairytale film. Full of 13th/14th Century buildings, gothic & baroke, plus lots of bars, restaurants and shops. Pay the 100CZH to climb up the clock tower to get a great view of the city.

Beautiful place to see! So relaxing and fun :). I guess you will go there anyway if you are in prague! but this is a must see and be place!Buy a something to eat and look at the amazing architecture, pet a little goat or just sit on a bench on the square and listen to some guy playing his sax - In conclusion, just go there and enjoy! you will find yourself what to do :)

Crowded, but has its own charm. We went here twice and both times, the place was crowded and crawling with tourists. It was fun listening to a group of students doing an impromptu chorale in the square and watching a couple of men in funny masks poking fun at some visitors. The astronomical clock was fascinating and we waited until the trumpeteer played his trumpet at the start of a new hour. We did not eat in the restaurants, but we did have gelato since it was very warm during that time. There were a number of police in the area probably to deter petty theft.

dont go to prague because of this place, but go to this place because of prague. I agreed with most people opinion, it was a very touristy place. The place was filled with lots of souvenir stores, restaurants, bars, and all those typical stuffs that you will normally see in any tourist spots. However, there are some interesting buildings there too, like the famous astronomical tower, bethlehem chapel and church of our lady. So since you are already in Prague, why not give it a visit? Be sure to climb up the tower to see the beautiful scenery of Prague from the top while you are there. Also another tip, the tower will play a trumpet music every hour (the last hour would be at 9pm), so if you want the visit to this place becomes more worthwhile, be there at the time close to the trumpet play. Last time I was there, it was at 9pm and all the people down the tower clapped their hands after the trumpet music was over. It was a beautiful experience. So though the square itself isn't as interesting as the other attractions in Prague, it is still a worth place to go.
Must see..and then RUN!. Quite fun for mulled wine and weiners....but much too touristy.
Not quite as orgasmic as I had expected, but still a very pleasant spot. Very nice spot, packed with tourists and lots of trappy restaurants, but a good place to people watch.

Check out but don't eat here if on a budget. If you are spending any length of time in Prague you are going to have to walk through the square just because it is so central. It is a great spot for people watching and to take a break, and will occasionally have some events going on (there was some kind of concert thing when I was there).As noted by others, try not to eat meals here because you will pay way more (especially for drinks) and most will include tips in your bill. Side streets are a bit better, but eat near your hotel if it is outside of the city center a bit, you will literally pay half as much by dodging tourist central.

Packed with tourist but stil nice. Old Town Square always has tourist in it during my stay in Prague last winter i would walk through the square every day i was there it was always packed. Its is a nice area very quintessential Europe and a must see while in Prague. Here you can find the Astronomical clock it's very pretty and has an interesting history there were crowds around it but normally they came in waves and there would be lulls with less people around the clock. Take you time here and walk around it's nice a night.

No wow factor. The square is pleasant. Theres plenty of bars and cafes to sit out and wile away an hour or two.The price of drinks is noticeably more expensive here than across the bridge. There was a jazz concert on while we were there and that certainly added to the atmosphere. Cons would have to be the astronomical clock. I was expecting something a lot more interesting. The most entertaining thing about it was the guy playing the trumpet at the top of the tower. There was a huge crowd gathered around it on quite a narrow lane so it made it difficult to navigate through that part of the square. Another let down would be the horse and carriages. The square seemed to be the point where the carriages were picked up from as a result there was a terrible smell of horse urine, aswell as puddles on the groud, which took from the visit to the square.The square itself is beautiful but I would reccomend visiting it early in the morning when there aren't so many people or horses about :D !

This "fairy tale" square is packed with history. Robert Tolbert of Michigan (March 24, 2010) says he expected a square a mile wide and he mentioned a "small statue" in the middle. Ach jo! I must take up my pen (keyboard)!The square was a medieval marketplace, originating in the late 12th century. They built things human-sized in those days. The statue is huge, at least by Prague standards, and dominates the square. It depicts the Catholic priest and reformer Jan Hus, who was burned at the stake for heresy in 1415. The monument itself is from the early 20th century when Prague was still part of the Hapsburg Empire. The Catholic Hapsburgs were the folks responsible for the ruthless Counter Reformation begun in 1621. The statue was a rallying place under Communism. His words, "The truth shall prevail," resonated with people! Each building has a fascinating story of its own. Many have "basements" that were once the ground floor, before the level of the Old Town was raised in response to frequent flooding. This "fairy tale" square is packed with history.TIP: To avoid tourist mobs, go at dawn or in mid-January!! But, please, not all of you!!!

Nice Place to Walk Around. Old Town Square is the heart of old Prague and where you will have tourists walking around, taking breaks at cafes and restaurant around, eating from the food kiosks, riding in coaches, taking pictures. The atmosphere is very touristic and it's a nice experience to be part of the crowd.

Nice but not in the best in Europe. A pleasant place to take in the architecture and culture of Prague - tourist Prague that is. The place is usually heaving with tourists and it would be quite easy to get swallowed by the crowd in front of the Astronomical Clock (go on the hour to see the 'chimes'' but keep any possessions and companions close by). Worth walking down the streets that lead off from the square to see the Jewish quarter and more reasonably priced restaurants and shops. Best way to see the Square is in a guided walking tour so that you can learn about it's history and culture.

Like a fairy tale. We were lucky enough to be staying in a wonderful apartment within walking distance of the square and we came here daily for a week. On our first day, we sat down to eat at one of the restaurants right on the square and overlooking the amazing historic clock. As you'll see in the reviews, people recommend against this. However, for us, since it was only one time, we really did not mind the over-priced food, or the feeling of hustle and bustle as the clock chimed, because the whole scene was so magical and we felt incredibly fortunate to be able to sit and enjoy it. Yes, the food was indifferent, and the service, after they have hooked you in, pretty indifferent, but you're paying for the view and the experience, and we really didn't mind. Our kids had ice-creams and so they were happy, and we felt like we were in paradise. We also took one of the horse-drawn carriages that depart from the square. This was expensive and not really that much fun, it's a bit bumpy and you don't see much more than you would as you walk.

I expected it to be bigger. I was expecting this gigantic square a mile wide. It's pretty dinky. It's nice, though. There's a little statue in the center. The buildings are fairy tale-ish and colorful. For the most part you can roam around free. It's only by the clock that there were a million people milling around.It's a nice place to take pictures and stage pictures. There is enough stuff around to make it well worth seeking out.
Tourist-ville. Don't use any of the cafes here - go round the corner onto any side street and you'll pay about a third of the price!

Must See. The old town square is quintessential Prague--you absolutely must stroll through no matter how little time you have in Prague. Watch the clock chime a time or two (although don't get your hopes up, the show is short and simple) and then if you have a chance, the clock tower has amazing views from the top (and an elevator to get you there). There are also guided tours of the Old Town Hall adjacent to the clock tower that allows you to see the inside mechanisms of the clock as well as several floors of the building, including the Gothic Chapel. It was worth the admission fee and very interesting as well.

Great at Christmas Time. At Christmas time there are all kinds of booths selling food, souvenirs, etc. The tree display really adds to the atmosphere. Even w/o all the displays I imagine the clock (though overrated), churches, and other buildings would make this a great place to hang out and take in the Prague experience.

old t own square prague. tip. to see prague at night particularly the castle and the twin towers. take the elevator in the foyer of au prince hotel in the old town square to the restaurant on the roof, is can be fairly pricey but we just had dessert.

The true centre of Prague. Any trip, no matter how long you stay, should start at the Old Town Square.Beautiful buildings everywhere. Enough restaurants and bars to keep anyone happy. The choice is endless. Free music and the added entertainment of the hourly display from the Astronomical clock. I love to sit with a good book, soaking in the atmosphere and just enjoying being part of the scenery.Once you realise that all routes lead back to Old Town Square, life in Prague becomes second nature.

Definate must see, but not stay for too long.. I really enjoyed visiting the Old Town Square. Mainly it is just a nice place to walk around and look at the clock. I would say that other then walk around and maybe eat at one of the restaurants, there is really not a lot to do. I would recommend trying to visit around a time where the clock will ring (hourly maybe).

Loved the Square. Wasn't crowded when we went (early, mid-day and late evening). During the day, the vendors have some REALLY good eats. The chicken kabobs were good, the fire roasted sausages were especially good but the best thing (we came back to the square a second time just to get 'em) was the peasant potatoes (small skinless potatoes cooked over a wood fire in a big, 3' diameter pan, with onions, lots of garlic and some diced ham). Do NOT sit down at one of the cafes directly across from the clock. Their prices are steeply inflated, they have hidden minimums and the servers are rude. Two very pretty churches right there are on the Square. At night, the one is absolutely gorgeous; prettier than Cinderella's Castle at Disney World. We also very much enjoyed the street market that's maybe 1 block away from the Square.

Over rated. Not really great- you see clock, building of town square , church, square & tons of people.There are so much better scenes & places to see in adjacent countries with less crowds like Bratislava & Budapest & Vienna. The only thing nice is so much tourist stores.

Stunningly lovely at night. One of the beautiful things about eastern europe are their squares and prague is no exception. It is simply a beautiful place to walk around at night time,the only negative being it's tourist packed but them the breaks!

A city not to be missed. Great atmosphere both day and night. The public transport links are fantastic. The food was good especially the dumplings and well priced and the beer was the best we've ever tasted. Watch out for the cafe/bars within Prague city centre as we learnt a costly lesson. Totally agree that you should see the city without a guide. We had planned to follow a tour but once we got there decided to venture around the city alone and managed to fit in plenty of sights whilst we were there. Have to admit the Old Town Square took our breath away and the views from Charles Bridge leading into old town and the cobbled streets coming down from the Cathedral/Castle were ones we will always remember. We went at the beginning of October 2009 for 4 days and the weather was surprisingly warm. Highly recommend a visit and will definitely be planning a second visit.

Cocktails with a view!!. We frequently go to Pargue as we have family who now live and work there. The Old Town Square has a buzz about it, no matter what time of year one visits, and the hot mulled wine, sold at various stalls, is warming and cheering during the cold winter months. Large open-air concerts (FREE!) are often held in the square, and for excellent meals, just go up one of the side streets radiating from the square,where the price for a great meal is a fraction of the price of similar cuisine in the square.For cocktails with stupendous views over Prague, go up to the roof terrace on top of the hotel 'U Prince' which is just on the left if you are facing the clock. Enter the hotel via doors beside their outside tables, and go through to the back of the lobby and take the elevator to the top floor.....fabulous!!!!

The Number 1 Tourist Attraction in Prague. We stayed at a hotel on Starometske Namesti for our honeymoon, which was my 1st trip to Prague and my hubby's 3rd. I was blown over by the beauty of the square. We had amazing views from the hotel room.The square is large and there is always something going on. We saw a wedding and a Hare Kristna festival going on during our stay. It is a hub of tourists, and it very busy, so be aware that you will not get fantastic photos on the hour (which is when the astronomical clock does its thing). Make sure that you try to get to the clock before the hour as it does all the moving stuff before it chimes. The places on this square are very expensive to eat and drink and if you go off the beaten track prices can almost halve!There are gorgeous little winding side streets surrounding this square, which are full of tourist and amber shops and pubs and restaurants. It is worth going down the side streets as they really feel like you have walked into another world.This part of Prague was definately my favorite part. It was very gothic and romantic, and at night when all the buildings were lit up, really warmed your heart.i would say that if you visit Prague, you MUST visit at least once. Beautiful.

Times Square of Prague. Can be a little hectic and a little crazy, since Prague tends to attract a lot of college kids who love to suck down too many Pilsners, but it's a gorgeous area for sightseeing, even if the famous Astronomical Clock ultimately disappoints expectations (watch your wallet when you're standing there watching for the hourly display -- many pickpockets I've been told). I really enjoyed just getting a sandwich from one of the many vendors in the square, grabbing a park bench, and watching the crowds go by. You don't have to spend a lot of money to enjoy the delights of the scenery and get a flavor of Prague.

Great square. Truly one of the best squares I have had the pleasure of visiting. Has a "cool" clock tower and is surrounded by lovely old buildings. Filled with lots of activity, especially at night. We ended up visiting a few times during our time in Prague. A very pleasant way to spend a few hours.

The Very Essence of Prague. Our trip to Prague was brimming "absolutely to the top" with wonderful memories, it is hard to pinpoint just one area of the city that I would consider the "Number One Attraction". Could it have been Prague Castle (Prazsky hrad) where we were able to take some amazing photos of the Cathedral, or the Castle District (Hradcany), where we noticed many locations recognized from various tv commercials and music videos? Was it New Town (Nove Mesto), Old Town (Stare Mesto) or the Lesser Quarter (Mala Strana) ? Or was it the famous and historical Nerudova (Royal Way or Kings Road) Street, where all the charming ancient burgher houses are distinguished with house signs above their main doors, and you could view all of "Golden" Prague and its hundred of Gothic Church spires scattered across the amazing vista? Perhaps it was Charles Bridge (Karluv Most), one of the towers-> Powder Tower (Prasna brana) or Old Town Bridge Tower... or maybe it was one of the parks where we enjoyed a picnic-> the cemetary of the Vysehrad Castle overlooking the Vltava or Kampa Park -> right at the bank of the Vltava? In truth, I would have to say that Old Town Square (Staromestske namesti), best "captured" the very "essence" of Prague. From this majestic and massive location, you can venture out into the rest of Prague, using it as your "compass" for all the other various attractions mentioned. It is the very heart of the city, if I'm not mistaken, all the underground subway lines converge to this area, making it the "hub" of Prague. You can meander through the intricate "old world" alleyways & explore all the various nooks, crannys, cafés & shops.
