Or you can wander over into the other historical areas of Prague to discover each of their hidden treasures & secrets.If you only have the chance to visit "just one" city in Europe... then visit Prague! You feel as though you are stepping "back in time", in a different era, experiencing the "old world" in a time warp. It is a jewel not to be missed!

Humming with activity. Unmissable - I went before xmas and it was humming with stalls and activity. Great for photo opportunities under the shadows of the imposing Tyn Church. There is the bell tower and astronomical clock to see but beware the large crowds.

Old Town Square unspeakably gorgeous. As soon as you step onto the cobblestone streets of Old Town and arrive at the Old Town square, it literally feels like you've just travelled back in time hundreds of years to a completely different era. The cobblestone streets, narrow alleyways, gas-lit laterns, churches, building facades, colours, and their reddish-clay rooves will just blow you away. Going up the Old Town hall tower is a must to get a great perspective of the Old Town and Prague as a whole.

Astronomical Clock is one of the best in the Worold.. The STAROMESTSKE NAMESTI (The Old Town Square in Historic Prague): People watching is fun and makes our trips and pictures interesting, especially at the Old Town Square where you’ll see folks from every part of the World. Prices can be high at cafes and pubs along the square, but it doesn’t hurt to have a sit and enjoy one or two beers or a latte…and people watch! The Square is safe at all hours of the day and night, as well as the surrounding area which is full of pubs and restaurants.THE PRAGUE ORLOJ, also known as the Astronomical Clock: It has recently been proven the clock was constructed in the year 1410 by the clockmaker Mikulas of Kadan, and Jan Ondrejav, a professor of mathematics and astronomy at Prague Charles University. In 1490 a calendar dial was constructed and placed under the clock. Many legends have been told that make people think the clock was constructed by two different people in 1490. This clock, despite the legends and false information some tour guides provide, is still one of the best examples of Astronomical Clocks in the World. In the old days, astronomy was enough to keep the local folks interested, but in later years they added the animated characters to spice things up. This clock is not to be missed if you go to the Square.Recent History of the clock: The clock itself was severely damaged during the end of the Second World War. During heavy fighting in Prague, the Nazi’s directed artillery fire at the Square and town hall (where the clock is). Numerous good folks made repairs in the late 1940's and we have the clock today to enjoy for many more years. I recommend doing some good research on the Internet for Prague and walking around WITHOUT a tour guide to see what interests you, otherwise you might end up in front of famous gift shops. Hope this helped. Happy travels!

Bustling even at night. We went through Old Town Square several times on our two day trip, on our way here or there. I enjoyed it most at night. Everything was lit up and there were still people everywhere. The buildings are all so pretty and there were plenty of shops, cafe's, and ice cream places. Plan a stroll through here at night and you won't be dissapointed. There is also a little jazz club at the eastern part of the square which was playing music in the basement that wafted up to the street as you passed by. The memorial to Jan Huss was also beautiful, but seen better in the daytime.The best part was going up into the tower and the amazing view from up there, but that's for another review!

Amazing!. Wonderful archetecture, amazing people, entertainment, food at every turn. You could spend a day just exploring! There was too much beauty and goings on to describe it all. A great place to hang around for the afternoon!

Beautiful square. The old town square in Prague features a number of interesting attractions and is worth a visit. Unfortunately, it is packed with tourists (just... like... you...) but if you don't go at peak times, it contains some wonderful sites. The square itself is quite attractive as the buildings all around it are a beautiful combination of architecture styles, from gothic, to baroque, to art noveau.The town hall and its astronomical clock is worth a look. You'll recognize it by the giant crowd in front of it. The clock is quite beautiful and surprisingly close to the ground, so you can really take in the details. It does a little animation every hour on the hour, but it's very short and not too interesting, so feel free to skip it. Behind the clock, across the square, is the Church of St. Nicholas. There is a nice fresco ceiling, chandelier, and some stained glass windows inside that are worth a quick stop. The monument to Jan Hus in the center of the square is worth a look if you know the history behind it (or read an abbreviated version in a tour book). The Tyn church (the large gothic church) is closely tied in with this history and also worth a look.

Worth a visit. Old Town Square is just that - a square flanked by buildings, churches, and many shops and restaurants. There's a large statue on one side of it and the Astrological Clock on the Town Hall building. I really liked the Chuch of Our Lady of Tyn, and thought it looked beautiful at night.We visited during the Christmas Market season, which meant that it was beautiful, lively, and full of vendors selling spiced wine, sausages, Czech ham, and tasty treats. I could see where the square would not be as impressive during the rest of the year, but I would still recommend at least one stroll through it to look at the buildings and churches.

Underwhelming but worthwhile. There is not much to see here. Definitely see the clock. Also see St. Nicholas' Church for a small donation. Also check out the medieval courtyard at the opposite end of the square from the clock. There is little else to see here and not really any reason to spend time after seeing these sights. However, the shops and restaurants in this area are open late so this is an evening option. Get lost in the alleys leading away from the square. Take the short walk to Charles Bridge and the river and castle at night.

Old Town Square Market. Just back from the market, not the greatest but the atmosphere was wonderful and worth the trip, The cobbles all around the area mean boots or trainers are the required footwear move away into the small winding side streets for the very best in food and beer prices. The whole area was safe well into the evening just be mindfull as you would be in your own city centre

Beautiful Large Bustling Square. Its well worth experiencing Old Town Square. Make sure that you explore all the streets around and find all the nooks and crannys - there are some fab bars and shops to be found away from the main tourist areas. Food and drink on the square is expensive, and you don't have to go far to find more authentic fare.Read up on the history of the square to really get the sense of how important it is to the people of prague.The astronomical clock is covered for renovation until October 2005 though!
